column2: From the dawn of time men have celebrated the renewal of the earth and its life in the spring. These celebrations have taken many forms, some of them grotesque, some cruel, some merely abandoned. In the great religious tradition of the Judeo-Christian world these celebrations have a specific rather than a general and secular meaning.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Francis Henry Taylor, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York is scheduled to speak at the second Conference on the Arts for faculties of the eleven teachers colleges of the State University of New York.

FIVE photographic exhibitions currently on display here offer the gallery visitor one-man and group shows in several categories and on various levels. Morris H. Jaffe has a one-man show at the Village Camera Club, 65 Bank Street, through April 27.

THE biography of the Wright Brothers, which has been a movie possibility since 1938, will be filmed under the banner of the independent company headed by Burt Lancaster and Harold Hecht, it was learned last week.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 17 -- The general feeling of the man in the street is that President Eisenhower acted wisely in suspending Dr. Oppenheimer. However, the consensus seems to be that in view of the fact it was known that he had associated with Communists in the past, further action in the case is hardly required.

IT is planting time again. In New Hampshire and, in fact, all New England, there are certain set dates on which gardens are planted. Tomatoes, for instance, are started on Town Meeting Day and the garden itself is planted on Decoration Day in May.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Army announced today that troops are now getting two new weapons capable of using atomic explosives -- the "Corporal" guided missile, and the "Honest John" heavy bombardment rocket.

WRITERS in comparative religion find numerous similarities in faith and practice among the world's faiths. These have been used both to prove and disprove religious belief. Alan Watts, author of "The Legacy of Asia" and "Behold the Spirit," in MYTH AND RITUAL IN CHRISTIANITY (Vanguard, $4.75) suggests that Carl Jung's theory of the collective unconscious may help explain the persistence of certain religious concepts in widely separate times and places.

MOST remarkable these days is the industrial and commercial revival of the Mississippi. The river has shaken off its Huck Finn dreams and become a part of the twentieth century. For nearly 2,000 twisting river miles from St. Paul to New Orleans, the chunky towboat is fighting the railroad that banished the packet boat.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Housing scandals and the distrust they have created in Congress threaten continuance of Federal housing programs that have become a mainstay of the nation's construction industry.

If the average citizen had wandered accidentally into the medical meeting at the Statler Hotel in Washington early this month and heard the discussions, his normal reaction might have been to look around for Buds Rogers, Flash Gordon or Tom Lierbett.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, said today that there might have been some persons with "ulterior motives" who contributed to a delay in the development of the hydrogen bomb.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 17 -- Former Representative Ernest Greenwood, a Democrat, who as a political unknown unseated W. Kingsland Macy by 135 votes in the First Congressional District in 1950, said today that he hasn't given much thought "one way or the other" about suggestions that he make a third try for Congress this fall.

Mr. Barrett graphically portrayed the soft center of Greenwich Village, but overlooked the surrounding toughened flanks -- the factory lofts and cold-water flats inhabited by artists who, working an average fourteen-hour day, have little opportunity or inclination to rub shoulders with the bistro chiefs.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 17 -- James C. Hagerty, the White House press secretary, gave a preview today of the speech President Eisenhower will deliver on Thursday night to the meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in New York.
Glimpses of Paris will be offered to New Yorkers on Fifty-seventh Street for ten days starting Wednesday. The festival's proceeds will go toward American and French educational and welfare projects.

BACK in July, 1953, it was noted in this department that a champion had appeared in behalf of complainants who had been writing to our Drama Mailbag concerning visibility in some of the local playshops.

HOUSTON, Te., April 17 -- Texans are reserving judgment on the Oppenheimer case until the results of the scientist's hearing are in. They appear to have adopted an attitude of "wait and see" regarding the allegations against Dr. Oppenheimer.

In our Congress there has been some sharp criticism of the projected economic and technical aid to India and the threat that it might be sharply scaled down. This criticism and threat is based upon an adverse reaction to the "neutralism" of Prime Minister Nehru, and the feeling that we should not force our assistance upon nations that do not show a basically friendly attitude toward us or toward the cause of the free world.

IN 1950 Ingvild Schartum-Hansen, then 11 years old, was one of six Norwegians chosen to attend the first Children's International Summer Village in Cincinnati in company with children from six other European countries and Mexico.
William Barrett's article "The Village: Bohemia Gone Bourgeois" (April 4) suggests some deeper crisis at the heart of American cultural life. Why has America's Bohemia been unable to sustain itself?

A bright new dawn is breaking on the New Jersey Intracoastal Waterway for small-craft owners. This busy succession of channels, both main and tributary, is one of the most widely used routes in Eastern waters, handling most of the northern craft bound to and from Florida, and carrying an enormous cruising and fishing traffic throughout the summer season.

The nation's $25,000,000,000 electric power and light industry is taking a careful look at the power policy of the Eisenhower Administration. Utility executives generally agree the new policy of "more local and less Federal" emphasis on power development is a step in the right direction.

The final phase of Easter buying pushed department store sales in the city ahead of the same week of a year ago by about 15 per cent, according to merchants. Estimates ranged from 12 per cent to 18 per cent over 1953. Last year this was the second week after Easter.

A WARM romantic regard for what is absurd and paradoxical in the behavior of English country people is characteristic of Margery Sharp, remembered for "Cluny Brown" and "The Nutmeg Tree." Her generous wit is always the ally of her protagonists, never their critic.

PARIS, April 17 (AP) -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin has told President Rene Coty he turned against the proposed European Defense Community in its present form because the Soviet menace had decreased while France's insecurity over Indo-China was increasing.
ALBANY, April 17 (AP) -- Governor Dewey appointed today Assemblyman Lewis W. Olliffe of Brooklyn to the bench of State Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District -- Brooklyn and Staten Island.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 17 (AP) -- Mrs. John B. Hannum 3d's El Arabi, a Pennsylvania point-to-point horse making his first start over timber, withstood a stretch challenge today to capture the thirty-third Middleburg Hunt Cup steeplechase.

Women headed by Mrs. Fraser M. Horn are furthering the sale of tickets for the performance of "By the Beautiful Sea" on the night of May 6 at the Majestic Theatre for the benefit of the Girls Service League. An encouraging subscription has been reported.

SINCE "By the Beautiful Sea" is just right for Shirley Booth, it is also just right for thousands of her friends. It is just right for her because the background is unpretentiously gay, the mood is cordial and generous and the part she plays is amiable.

BERLIN, April 17 -- Vladimir S. Semyenov, Soviet High Commissioner for Germany, again rejected today proposals by his Western colleagues that they discuss the easing of trade and travel within Germany.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 17 -- Six Senators will participate in a public colloquium devoted to "The Eisenhower Administration -- Success or Failure" on the Princeton University campus during the next three weeks.

Despite the great increases in personal savings since World War II, 41 per cent of American families still do not have savings accounts. This is one of the findings of a nation-wide survey made on behalf of the 4,000 member institutions of the United States Savings and Loan League.
HANOVER, N. H., April 17 -- The postponed christening of their new heavyweight shell, the George Jewett, didn't slow down the Dartmouth crews today as they won the varsity and freshman races.

SAN MATEO, Calif., April 17 -- Andrew J. Crevolin's Determine, taking his final California prep for the Kentucky Derby, made a show of the field in the $25,000 added Bay Meadows Derby today for his sixth consecutive victory.

THE continuing debate about the Administration's "New Look" policy -- a policy now severely tested by the Indo-China crisis -- has been complicated by the hydrogen bomb tests in the Pacific and the lullaby tactics of Malenkov.
PARIS, April 17 -- The French Administration took urgent measures today to combat terrorism in Casablanca, the largest city of French Morocco.
Many dinner parties will be given at the third annual April in Paris Ball, known this year as the "Bal de la Soie," to be held Tuesday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Plant or transplant shrubs and rose bushes before leaves open. Prepare soil and dig holes in advance so roots need not be exposed to wind or sun. Water thoroughly before firming soil about the roots and water once a week all the year.
Organization of a social welfare advisory committee of the American-Korean Foundation was announced yesterday by Gen. James A. Van Fleet, chairman of the foundation.

FEW German leaders carried a heavier burden of responsibility during World War II then Albert Kesselring -- and few officers have ever been better prepared than he for high command by aptitude, personality, background and training.

Few of the so-called "war baby" raw materials can boast a more spectacular career than magnesium, the lightweight metal being made today mostly from sea water. Magnesium was just getting a commercial foothold as a structural metal when World War II began.
A group of college student panelists agreed yesterday that greater emphasis on liberal arts education was needed in the high schools and colleges.

More thorough training in oral and written English, broader cultural background and a more effective system of guidance are recommended for students preparing for business, industrial and professional careers in a report of a self-study made at Lafayette College.
Chinchilla is coming back to the New York fur market. The New York Auction Company, at 226 West Twenty-Sixth Street, will display up to 10,000 pelts beginning June 15 and auction them a week later.

THE heartaches that pile up for a would-be musician in search of an audience is the theme of this touching story by Edward Tripp. It is strongly supported by the expressive. often wistful, illustrations of Maurice Sendak.

PARIS -- The French were happy to learn recently that their beloved Palace of Versailles was no longer in danger of falling to pieces. Their sustained efforts during the past two years to raise necessary funds for essential repairs, by the organization of balls, lotteries, galas and other functions, have made possible the announcement that the roofs of the chateau are now rain-resistant, that staircases are solid underfoot, and that crumbling walls have been reinforced.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Arab states will receive substantial United States aid for economic development in 1954-55 if Congress approves plans of the Foreign Operations Administration.

CALIFORNIA poppies, because of their easy culture, long-flowering season and brilliant coloring, are now cultivated in practically all of the forty-eight states. The plants are at their best where naturalizing effects are desired, especially on hillside sites.

WHEN it comes to selecting tools for a given job, the business of sowing seeds can become as elaborate or simple as one chooses. In spring some gardeners get as much psychological lift out of acquiring another late-model trowel or a different-shaped hoe as their wives do in buying a new Easter hat.
The New York City Opera Company's new production of "Show Boat" was presented at the City Center yesterday afternoon, and one listener found it a delight.

CHICAGO, April 17 (UP) -- Protestant Church leaders are to discuss Sunday school teaching and decide whether "to overhaul the old model or trade it in for a new one," according to an announcement here today.
Hundreds of New York builders are in trouble with Federal income tax authorities because they reported their profits as "windfalls."
I was interested to read in your section recently a letter from Robert Anderson in which he said that he does not consider any actor or actress to be irreplaceable.

OSWEGO, Ore. THE spring display of daffodils is under way in gardens and commercial growing fields of the Pacific Northwest, with the peak of bloom arriving about mid-April. Plantings in higher altitudes bloom later, while those in sunny, lower areas start earlier.

IF gardening has been more work than pleasure in past years, the odds are the wrong kinds of plants have been grown. Annuals can be fun and they can give big returns in flower production for a minimum amount of work and expense.
There will be a drawing for new mainsails and jibs made of dacron at the International Class meeting in the New York Yacht Club on Tuesday night.

ROME, April 17 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano confirmed this afternoon that the Pope will impart his apostolic blessing, Urbi et Orbi, to the city and the world, from the outer balcony of St. Peter's Basilica at noon tomorrow.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- The Chicago Cubs, blasting six opposing pitchers for twenty hits, today ran up their highest score in thirty-two years, crushing the St. Louis Cardinals, 23 -- 13. The contest was the longest nine- inning game in National League history -- 3 hours 43 minutes.
Sal Maglie and Carl Erskine will be the starting pitchers for the Giants and Dodgers, respectively, when the two teams meet for the third time at Ebbets Field today.

PRINCESS BRINDA'S autobiography is mainly the record of a marriage arranged at the tender age of 7 (though not consummated till nine years later) -- a marriage leading to a life of splendor, social-mongering and enslavement.
AUSTIN, Texas, April 17 -- Gov. Allan Shivers has come through a money-raising special session of the Texas Legislature still firmly seated in the political saddle.
IN Holland, a little country only slightly larger than Maryland, an amazing variety of food and drink is produced, which, fortunately for American consumers, is coming here in increased amounts.

The stock market moved in a more orderly fashion last week as prices edged up to the highest levels since mid-September, 1930. Encouraging statements that the end of the business adjustment might not be far off had a salutary effect on market sentiment. Trading, however, was limited to four days because of the religious holidays.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, April 17 -- The celebration of Easter mass here for Negro soldiers was a symbol of the policy of racial assimilation of the Roman Catholic Church.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial comment of April 7 on the departure of Samuel Sears you conclude with the observation that what the "McCarthys" are doing "is a fundamentally subversive operation." You note that they are practicing this subversion on the constitutional relations between the Legislative and Executive branches of the Government.
The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman described beauty, truth and goodness as "bombproof" in his Easter message yesterday.

A new Figaro was heard at the City Center in last night's "Marriage of Figaro." He was Norman Treigle, making his first appearance in the role with the New York City Opera Company. The young baritone turned in a commendable piece of work, acting with assurance, singing clearly and forcefully with good quality of tone.

In a deal in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the four-story apartment building at 1154 President Street, between Rogers and Nostrand Avenues, was sold by the Adme Realty Corporation to the Mannru Realty Corporation for investment. There are twenty-eight apartments in the building, which occupies a plot 70 by 127 feet.

GUATEMALA, April 18 -- John E. Peurifoy, United States Ambassador to Guatemala, has been recalled to Washington for consultations. He will leave Tuesday, and probably will be away for the rest of the month.

" Now You See It" arrives at 8 o'clock tonight at the Longacre. Conforming to the title, Milbourne Christopher, who is billed as "the international sorcerer," will aim to mystify spectators at his one-man show of magic, the first on Broadway in fourteen years.
While the wind from the Hudson River whipped at Easter finery yesterday morning at 11 o'clock, from within Riverside Church came the musical proclamation, "Christ the Lord Is Risen Today."

" The Apprenticeship of Ernest Hemingway, The Early Years," by Charles A. Fenton, instructor of English at Yale University, will be published May 17 by Farrar, Straus Young. The book covers the years from 1916, when Hemingway was a junior in high school, through 1923 when his first novel was published.

CAIRO, April 18 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Egypt's President, administered the oath of office today to Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, his successsor as Premier, and to the reshuffled Cabinet, announced early this morning.

Of 3.5 million acres turned to high-price crops in the drought-stricken Southwest, between 75 and 90 per cent should never have been put to the plow, according to the Soil Conservation Service. In a special report to Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson the service observed that payments for crop insurance, agricultural conservation practices and loans had had the combined effect, over this period, of encouraging speculation in marginal land completely unsuited for cultivation.
ROME, April 18 -- Pope Plus XII described today the potential horrors of the hydrogen bomb, but made it clear that he considered its use permissible in "legitimate self-defense."
The first day of Passover was observed yesterday in temples and synagogues over the city.
A new financial roadblock threatened yesterday to halt construction of the New York Coliseum.

IT was Phineas T. Barnum, the master showman, who received credit for the expression, "There's a sucker born every minute." He proved his point by becoming wealthy through painlessly snatching dollars from the out-thrust hands of the gullible.

Robert R. Young interests attacked as unfounded yesterday the New York Central Railroad's argument in its latest petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission to disqualify Mr. Young and his supporters from becoming directors of the road.
New York's traditional Easter Parade, which started a hundred years ago as an after-church stroll, was more in tune with its historic origins yesterday than it has been for many years.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 18 (UP) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta, Ga., won the second annual Babe Zaharias open golf tournament today with a par 73 for 224, two strokes better than the honoree, Mrs. Babe Zaharias.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, said today that the House Committee on Un-American Activities was "considering" the public release of secret testimony given by Dr. Oppenheimer in 1949.

Teen-agers want to learn how to talk about controversial subjects "without getting mad," a large group of them told the Young Women's Christian Association of the United States of America. Their answers to questions of citizenship were listed yesterday by the "Y" to open the seventh annual National Y. W. C. A. Week. Y-Teen Day will be observed Thursday.
Henry H. Laskau won the National Amateur Athletic Union 10,000-meter walk for the eighth straight year yesterday at Clove Lake, Staten Island. His time was 49 minutes 37.6 seconds.
MEXICO CITY, April 18 (AP) -- Mexico's Government-owned oil ndustry is drafting plans to make more use of natural gas, which comprises some 27 per cent of the country's oil reserves.

The Finance Committee of the City Council announced yesterday that it wanted to hear at first hand from State Controller J. Raymond McGovern how the city could avoid extending the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services.
JERUSALEM, April 18 -- Peace lay over the Holy Land today as pilgrims stirred from their lodgings in preparation for Easter devotions and celebrations.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, April 18 (UP) -- Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Fisherman, winner of the $30,000 added Gotham Stakes at Jamaica yesterday, and Determine shared second choice ranking at 5 to 2 today on the Caliente future book for the Kentucky Derby May 1.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Good rains in some sections of the Southwest and partial relief in other areas took the edge off the demand for wheat last week, after all futures had shown comparative strength early in the week.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, April 19 -- President Syngman Rhee announced today that South Korea would attend the Geneva. conference next week as a final effort to unify his nation peacefully.
Throngs of worshipers filled St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for the traditional Easter services.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- American Indians rank with the best of forest fire fighters today.

Vice President Nixon's answer to a hypothetical question in respect to Indo-China has evoked wide comment and the expression of an apprehension that is not hypothetical. As the State Department promptly and correctly pointed out, the Vice President was asked what would be the policy of this Government on the use of ground troops in Indo-China in the event of a French withdrawal from the country.

The one-story garage-type building at 5, 7 and 9 North Fifteenth Street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn has been leased by the Acme Finishing Company from Alfred H. Berkof. Colony Realty was the broker in the transaction.

ZURICH, April 18 -- The release by the Bank Deutscher Laender, West Germany's central bank, of all Sperrmarks for transfer abroad within the scope of existing payment agreements is regarded by Zurich bankers as the first decisive step toward abolition of all German foreign exchange restrictions.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 -- A resounding spring pick-up in steel does not seem to be in the cards. But the same facts and interpretations that support this outlook also rule out significant declines over the next two months.
The Budget Bureau's recent rejection of a Pentagon proposal that Home Loan benefits be extended to men in uniform is another blow to service morale.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- Dr. You Chan Yang, South Korea's Ambassador to the United States, said today that his country would take part in the Geneva conference opening April 26, on the strength of assurances given it by the Eisenhower Administration.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 18 (AP) -- James Session, the Kentucky Derby hope of Harry James and Betty Grable, reached Derbytown ahead of the pack today.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- For every 10,000 persons in the United States there are 435 on Federal, state and municipal payrolls, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

Duplication and overlapping in the migration field were considerably lessened earlier this year when the seventy-year-old Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, widely known as HIAS, and the United Service for New Americans were merged. Included in the merged unit now are most of the functions of the HIAS and the USNA -- notably immigration, resettlement and naturalization. The consolidated agency also has absorbed the overseas migration services of the Joint Distribution Committee.

DALLAS, Tex., April 18 (UP) -- Vic Seixas, the 1953 victor, won in four sets from the favored Tony Trabert today for the singles honors of the Dallas Country Club's eighth annual invitation tennis tourney.
Permanently pleated, priced for any pocketbook, treated to resist wrinkles, blended with silk, Orlon or dacron, cotton will be fashion's queen this summer. And it never has been prettier.

Forty-five hundred worshipers attended three morning services yesterday at the Fifth Aveune Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street. Four hundred of them were admitted to the 8:15 A. M. communion service in the chapel, and the main church was filled to capacity for morniing worship at 10 and 11:30 o'clock.
The Department of the Interior rescinded yesterday the permission it had granted a circus acrobat to balance on his forefinger on the top of the Statute of Liberty.
Net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company fell 24 per cent in 1953 while gross income dropped only 8 per cent, the company reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (UP) -- Robin Roberts and Curt Simmons pitched with mid - season brilliance today as the Phillies took both ends of a double-header from the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 -- 0 and 7 -- 1, at Connie Mack Stadium before 9,975 fans.
Thousands of churchgoers, in the early postdawn hours, paid worshipful Easter tribute yesterday to the risen Christ.

Sanitation Commissioner Mulrain is opening his annual spring campaign against "litterbugs" today, and this time he says it will last throughout the year. Fine. We hope so. The campaign will include attention to uncovered or inadequate garbage cans, littered sidewalks and kindred offenses.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Accelerated tax amortization certificates covering eighty-four new or expanded defense produc tion facilities, with an estimated value of $204,759,223, were approved by the Office of Defense Mobilization from March 25 to April 7.
Weather developments in the cotton belt were the primary influence on cotton prices last week, according to a review of the market by the New York Cotton Exchange.
The maritime industry of New York will move on City Hall tomorrow to oppose any extension of the city sales tax to its activities.

The John B. Stetson Company, the country's largest manufacturer of men's hats, and the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, A. F. L., have reached a wage agreement intended to stretch to twenty years their record of strike-free relations.

Economists in recent years have been worrying lest excessive taxation cut investments below the point at which the economy could remain dynamic. They also have spent some time searching for that point.

WASHINGTON. April 18 -- Secretary of State Dulles returned to Washington today to prepare for a week of conferences on a ten-nation Southeast Asian security pact. He laid the groundwork for it in London and Paris last week.
DUBLIN, April 18 -- Ireland's second springtime Tostal festival opened here this week-end with scenes of pageantry on a scale never attempted before.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- Attempts by the Western powers to prepare the ground for high-level talks on limitation of armaments and control of nuclear weapons will be resumed at a meeting of the United Nations Disarmament Commission at 11 A. M. tomorrow.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $78,746,880,440. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

PARIS, April 18 -- The arrival here of a United States agricultural mission to negotiate for the disposal of American surpluses in dairy products, cotton, tobacco, oranges and apples, has aroused some concern in French business and official circles.

MONTE CARLO, April 18 (AP) -- Lorne Main of Canada today defeated Tony Vincent of Miami, Fla., 9 -- 7, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, to win the men's singles honors in the Monte Carlo international tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Gordon Gray, president of the University of North Carolina and former Secretary of the Army, has a well-earned reputation as a willing handler of political hot potatoes.

BELGRADE, April 18 (UP) -- Yugoslavia will attempt to persuade the International Olympic Committee and the International Football Federation to change their amateur rules this year so countries can provide some compensation for their athletes without professionalizing them.
As newspaper executives arrived here yesterday for a week of business meetings, several said they regarded the Nixon Indo-China remarks as "a trial balloon" of the Eisenhower Administration.

The lost-and-found department at the Stony Brook (L. I.) School comes in for little attention during the course of a year. Last Friday, however, it was the center of attention as the entire student body and faculty participated in a tennis ball contest -- the like of which never had been tried before.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 18 -- The winter racing season closed in lovely spring weather at the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Frostbite skippers will now put their eleven and one-half-foot dinghies into mothballs as quickly as possible and concentrate on their larger craft for the Summer campaign.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was very much disappointed in the view taken by Sol Markoff, associate general secretary, National Child Labor Committee, in his letter to The New York Times of April 5, in which he opposed the change in our laws which allows teen-agers to work on farms.
A good pair of scissors may mean the difference between triumph and disaster for the home seamstress.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, predicted today "an upturn in employment and a decrease in unemployment" before the end of the year.

AMSTERDAM, April 18 -- Two leading Dutch machine factories will merge. They are the Werkspoor of Amsterdam and Royal Machine Factory owned by Stork Brothers Co. of Hengelo. The new company will have 32,000,000 guilders capital.

PROMINENT among this week's exhibitions is that opening on Thursday at the Whitney Museum. American nineteenth - century painting will be on display. It is an exhibition organized by the American Federation of Arts, which has been touring in Europe under the sponsorship of the United States Information Agency.

The stranger in New York is struck by the lavishness of the Easter celebration. He is struck by the uncanny power of the spring to transform the most urban landscape in the world. Nowhere is Nature pushed into the background as in this stony, overbuilt city.
Starving for hits on the steady diet of southpaw pitching that is being fed to them, the Yankees bowed to the Senators, 9 -- 3, before 16,952 spectators at the Stadium yesterday.

LIMA, Peru, April 18 -- About forty Peruvian students are reported stranded in the town of Puno on the way to the Bolivian frontier, because Peruvian authorities refuse to allow them to to abroad to continue their studies.
MEXICO CITY, April 18 -- The effects of the Mexican Government's sudden devaluation of the peso began to be felt today only a few hours after the rate was changed from 8.65 to 12.50 to the $1.

LONDON, April 18 -- With the approach of the long Easter holiday, the post-budget boom in industrial shares faded out last week. The Financial Times index of industrial ordinary shares dropped from its record high level of 145 points to just under 144 points.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- State taxes on cigarettes merely held their own last year, while state tax collections on sales, motor fuel and alcoholic beverages recorded substantial gains.

A knock on the great portal doors, a fanfare of trumpets and he words "Alleluia! The Lord is Risen!" opened the 11 A. M. Easter service yesterday at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine). Eight thousand worshipers were present.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 18 (AP) -- Dr. Arthur H. Compton, the scientist who hired Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer to direct the making of the first atomic bomb, said today that he believed one of the physicist's qualifications for the job was the fact he was no "innocent about communism.
A mysterious assailant roamed through the Easter crowds on Fifth Avenue yesterday and slashed at the dresses of several women. He disappeared before the victims had detected the damage.
BERLIN, April 18 -- Although Soviet attempts to obtain diplomatic recognition for the East German Government have received official rebuffs in the West, they have had some effect.

LILLIAN SMITH does not write her books in a hurry. "Strange Fruit," that passionately angry fictional denunciation of racial segregation, was the great best seller of 1944. Five years later came "The Killers of the Dream," which discussed the same subject with equal vehemence but in terms of personal reminiscence, Freudian psychology and even more fervent moral indignation,

CLEVELAND, April 18 (UP) -- Ferris Fain, Jim Rivera and Minnie Minosa hit home runs today to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 6-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians in a game held to six innings by a steady rain. The downpour also forced cancellation of the second game of the scheduled double-header.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 18 -- The Eisenhower family, in traditional fashion, donned new outfits and went to church this sunny Easter morning.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 18 (AP) -- Junius Kellogg today was fully conscious and talking with attendants and visitors at Veterans Administration Hospital here, fifteen days after an automobile accident had left him near death.

PARIS, April 18 -- French diplomats this week will do their utmost to press for a settlement in negotiations with Vietnam over that Indo-China state's inedpendence and relationship with the French Union. It is felt to be of great importance that an agreement be reached before the Indo-China phase of the Geneva conference on the Far East.

A loft building at 27 Park Place and 24-26 Murray Street was purchased by the 27 Park Place Realty Corporation, which insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The Seamen's Bank for Savings made a $150,000 mortgage loan in connection with the deal.
ROME, April 18 (AP) --An official English text of Pope Pins' Easter broadcast:
BUENOS AIRES, April 18 -- With nation-wide elections a week away, both the Peronista party and the Opposition are preparing themselves for intensive activity after weeks of mild campaigning.

GUIDO Pagano is a hairdresser on Katonah Avenue in the Bronx. His hobby is amateur movies. Three years ago he returned to Avellino in the grape and olive country in the Apennines, where he was born, to visit his sister. He took his movie camera along, and used it.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- The Eisenhowers won't be around to watch the fun but the annual Easter egg roll on the White House lawn will be held tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt said today Senate investigators would meet tomorrow with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to lay "ground rules" for the hearings into the Army-McCarthy dispute.

Members of the seventy-five-man skeleton crew that will take the Homeric of the Home Lines from San Francisco to Italy are on special chartered flight from Milan. They are due on the West Coast tonight.

Individuality in type marks the season's style. It is seen in the treatment of the bodice, neckline and sleeves. The three patterns illustrated today point out a variety of details in spring and summer dresses.
A new parish house and chapel building was dedicated in an Easter ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street, yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- An unofficial world record-holder, the first Olympic winner entered since 1926 and a trio of Japanese runners head the international field for tomorrow's fifty-eighth Boston A. A. marathon.
George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, will try to patch up the organization's fiercest jurisdictional battle at a peace meeting in Washington next week.
Rates moved narrowly in a quiet and thin foreign exchange market during the past week. Amount of business transacted was reported as light and mostly routine.
VIENNA, April 18 -- Two alleged traitors have been sentenced to death and nine others to prison terms by a Rumanian military court, according to a Bucharest radio announcement today.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 18 -- Lumberjacks from Canada, Maine and Vermont are hacking through the maple forest of the Mianus River Valley at the rate of an acre a day, clearing a wide swath intended to cradle a billion-gallon reservoir.

BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- Jackie Jensen hit Relief Hurler Ed Burtschy's first pitch of the thirteenth inning for a home run tonight to give the Boston Red Sox a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics in the second game of a doube-header at Fenway Park. Philadelphia's Negro right-hander, Bob Trice, pitched out of several tight spots to win the opener, 6 -- 4.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 18 -- Seven thousand persons joined in Easter worship in the chilly but brilliant dawn atop Eagle Rock in the Essex County reservation here today. It was the twenty-fifth consecutive year of the sunrise services, believed to be the oldest in the East.
Following are the texts of the letters exchanged between Robert Moses and Federal housing officials on the Coliseum issue:

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- A private company operating Atomic Energy Commission plants at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Paducah, Ky., was accused by a C. I. O. union today of "a complete lack of responsibility" and a refusal to bargain in good faith.
The Boy Scouts of America will undertake within the next thirty days for the American-Korean Foundation a project to help Boy Scouts in Korea.
TOKYO, April 18 -- Japan is planning to open unofficial negotiations with the Soviet Union for the restoration of some fishing rights in northern waters.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Government has indications of corruption in additional phases of its multi-million-dollar housing program, Albert M. Cole, Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Federal Communications Commission is studying how to brighten the economic picture of television stations operating in the field opened for expansion just two years ago.
AUGUSTA, April 18 (UP) -- The President's Easter started with a 6 A. M. egg hunt and also included a round of golf with his son, John.

LONDON, April 18 -- The Anglican Archbishops of Canterbury and York and the Roman Catholic primate of England, Bernard Cardinal Griffin, devoted their Easter Sermons today to the challenge of the hydrogen bomb to the Christian world.

TOKYO, Monday, April 19 -- There has been no disclosure of how many "asurances" were given by the United States in exchange for attendance at Geneva of the Republic of Korea nor how sweeping those assurances were. It seemed clear in advance of such an announcement that it would be South Korea's policy to paint those guarantees in as favorable a light as possible to justify the apparent reversal of its position.

NEW DELHI, India, April 18 -- The first forthright expression by a Government spokesman of India's opposition to collective security action in Southeast Asia has been given by V. K. Krishna Menon, Indian delegate to the United Nations General Assembly and frequent foreign policy adviser to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18 -- Hollywood opposition to Cinerama was broken today with the announcement that Warner Brothers would film the story of the Lewis and Clark expedition as the first dramatic picture to utilize the giant, three-panel screen process.

SINGAPORE, April 18 -- A major political storm is brewing in Malaya over the rejection by Oliver Lyttelton, British Colonial Secretary, of a request for direct talks in London on federal election and constitutional issues.

LONDON, April 18 -- Aneurin Bevan was sharply criticized by a fellow member of Parliament today for quitting the Labor party's "shadow cabinet" last week. But he received unexpected support in his fight against German rearmament.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- Continued heavy spending by consumers is one of the brightest spots in the business picture, the Government said today.

BALTIMORE, April 18 (AP) -- Harvey Kuenn and Walt Dropo swung heavy bats today as the Detroit Tigers rapped three Baltimore pitchers for fifteen hits and an 8-3 victory over the Orioles before 20,057 fans at Memorial Stadium.

The third Artur Schnabel Memorial Concert was given Saturday night at Town Hall. The program performed by Myra Hess, pianist, and the Juilliard String Quartet featured the American premiere of Schnabel's String Quartet No. 1.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- Administration officials hope to expand the Federal crop insurance program in the Corn Belt, California and along the East Coast next year.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Lebanon and Jordan probably will be the first beneficiaries of increases in United States aid for economic development in the Arab states planned by the Foreign Operations Administration.

The public interest in labor-industry peace makes pertinent an inquiry concerning the reasons for delaying the next steps in the "no-raiding" agreement approved by conventions of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations last fall.
LONDON, April 18 (UP) -- The Moscow radio said today that the Communist-led rebels in Indo-China were still prepared to negotiate a cease-fire with French Union forces.

Tossy Spivakovsky, the violin soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony in Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, was heard in two works -- Mozart's Adagio in E (K. 261) and Gian-Carlo Menotti's Violin Concerto.
The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation of Louisville has definitely established the often-rumored connection between its product and the gentle art of Isaac Newton.
MILWAUKEE, April 18 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs today traded Grady Hatton to the Chicago White Sox for Johnny Lipon and an undisclosed amount of cash. Both are infielders.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Air Force today drew a sharp rebuke from a House of Representatives Armed Services subcommittee for providing ambulance service last fall for the Baltimore Colts football team.

CHICAGO, April 18 (UP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals scored six runs in the seventh inning, including a three-run pinch homer by rookie Tom Alston, to beat the Chicago Cubs, 6 to 4, for Vic Raschi today. The victory was the Cardinals' first of the season.

Visitor Wearing a Patch The visitor, entering unannounced, seemed somehow familiar even though there was, definitely, a piratical air about him. His weatherbeaten hat one had seen before somewhere. Surely those bulging pockets belonged to no stranger -- one coat pocket obviously swollen with garden seed packets (vegetable or flower?), the other with a paper sack stuck into it -- and the baggy trousers were not foreign to these precincts.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, April 18 -- Commandant Gabriel Teixeira, Governor of this Portuguese East African colony, has pushed through a race-relations policy that, for South and East Africa, is revolutionary.

Last week's piece in this space noted that the transcript was now available of one of the most provocative in the long series of round-table discussions held under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

EASTER was observed on television yesterday with much more restraint than in some previous years. For all practical purposes, the networks kept away entirely from the Fifth Avenue and Park Avenue parades, which heretofore had been so shockingly commercialized and cheapened by TV's presence, and gave more emphasis to the day's religious significance. It was a welcome change.

Motorists held their own Easter parade yesterday, moving color-bright cars with chromefestooned bonnets into the city and out again at a pace only slightly faster than Fifth Avenue's pedestrian promenade.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES The case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer points up two things:
HANOI, April 18 -- The French command announced today that troops belonging to all branches of the service had been parachuted every night at Dienbienphu.
The City Administration outlined yesterday a revised housing program calling for 79,154 units to cost $800,000,000.

Le Vouvray has changed its aspect, and for the better, it is pleasant to report. The backyard garden of the little French-style restaurant at 132 East Sixty-first Street has been roofed over and converted into a room that doubles the establishment's seating capacity.

Sal Maglie's magic is still potent against the Dodgers. The Giants beat the Brooks at Ebbets Field yesterday, 6 -- 3, and the Barber gave them a close shave in their home shop for the ninth time in his career. Maglie never has lost in Brooklyn.

A famous jurist once remarked that law which did not fulfill human need was of no use. In the spirit of that comment an advisory committee has just approved President Justice Gutman's plan to hold evening sessions of the Small Claims Part of the Municipal Court.

Despite fifty years of progress in the fight against child labor evils, many continue to exist and work still substitutes for schooling for thousands of migrant children and other farm youngsters, the National Child Labor Committee declared yesterday.
MEDFORD, N. J., April 18 -- King, an English setter, owned and handled by E. B. Kenny of Camden, captured the shooting dog stake at the annual spring event of the South Jersey Field Trial Club today.

MILWAUKEE, April 18 (AP) -- Cincinnati's Redlegs combined tight pitching and power hitting into 6-4 and 5-3 victories over the Milwaukee Braves today before 27,267 fans in the year's first double-header at County Stadium.
SEOUL, Monday, April 19 (AP) -- The text of President Syngman Rhee's statement today on the Geneva conference:
HANOI. Vietnam, Monday, April 19 -- The French-commanded defenders of Dienbienphu and their Vietminh besiegers battled anew today for the fortress' main airstrip.

TRENTON, April 18 -- Senator Malcolm S. Forbes, Somerset County Republican, announced today that a legislative committee would present tomorrow a formal invitation to the New York Stock Exchange to move to New Jersey to escape a proposed widening of the sales tax.
The nation's scheduled domestic and overseas airlines achieved their best safety record in flying history last year, the Cornell-Guggenheimer Aviation Safety Center has reported.
WASHINGTON, April 19--Clyde L. Powell, Assistant Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, refused today to answer questions of Senate housing scandal investigators.
BRUSSELS, April 19 (AP) -Bel-I gium defeated Turkey, 5---1, to-I day to win the international milil tary soccer tournament. I

The average American's indulgence of his sweet tooth and his general inclination to luxurious living is seriously affecting the national level of physical fitness, the American Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation was told last night.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Thirty-six makers of woolen and worsted products filed suit in Federal district court today seeking to block a proposed $1.20-an-hour minimum wage for companies handling Government contracts.
Of Parisian design also are ball gowns, which will contribute glamour to the April in Paris Ball tonight in the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Dodger bats played a resounding tattoo at Connie Mack Stadium tonight, pounding out eighteen hits for a 9-7 Brooklyn victory over the Phillies before a near-capacity crowd of 31,294.
BOSTON, April 19 -- Horsemen re-enacted the rides of Paul Revere and William Dawes in the annual Patriots' Day celebration today.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- From the West, East, North and South, 250,000 visitors flocked here this Easter week-end.
Orthopedically handicapped youngsters should go to camp only when they are ready for the experience, according to Miss Susan Samuel.
Governor Dewey and Mayor Wagner continued yesterday their sparring over finances, without any immediate perceptible effect on the city's fiscal affairs.

The Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York elected Mrs. John T. Harrison Jr. as president yesterday. Now treasurer of the organization, she will take office for a two-year term on May 1, succeeding Mrs. William Crawford White.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 19 -- Alabama's first Negro candidate for the Legislature since Reconstruction days is entered in the May 4 Democratic primary.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The United States Savings and Loan League and the American Newspaper Publishers Association joined today in opposing a proposed ban on certain advertising by Government-insured savings and loan associations. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has proposed such a ban on the 3,304 Government-insured institutions. It would prevent them from advertising the dividends they pay depositors in newspapers and on radio stations more than fifty miles from an association's home office.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- One definite result of Vice President Nixon's reply to the now-famous hypothetical question addressed to him last Friday at an editors' luncheon here, and surely the result which was intended, was to remove any doubt in the public mind that this Administration sees a direct connection between the loss of Indo-China to the Communists and the security of the United States.

A pleasant sign of spring is the appearance of new green cabbage from Florida, which ships more of this vegetable into the city than any other state. New cabbage is tenderer and more delicately flavored than the old, stored types.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, believes the American people are "relatively secure" from atomic attack.

Sometimes at night, during a lull in Manhattan's street sounds, the throbbing of an airliner overhead can be heard here below. High in the darkness someone's steady hands are guiding a huge ship on its course, up and away from this island's fairyland of sparkling lights.

Eight hundred contemporary craft objects from Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Finland, on public view today at the Brooklyn Museum, were shown at a preview last night to an audience of distinguished Scandinavians.

CHICAGO, April 19--Uneasiness over Indo-China developments sparked a brisk demand for grain and soybean futures today. Wheat advanced 3 cents or more before reacting. There were good gains in corn and upturns of lesser extent in oats and rye.
The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., will ask the General Electric Company today to put 5 per cent of its payroll into a fund to provide a guaranteed annual wage.

Decorative motifs used in famous American homes that have become national shrines reflect changing politics and tastes. This is evident in a display of reproductions of wallpapers and textiles from these homes that is now on view at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Government moved today to try to resolve the question of how to distribute power from a Federal project in Georgia.

The New York State Thruway Authority is planning to borrow $300,000,000 to $350,000,000 in the public market on or about June 1 to continue the permanent financing of the 535-mile project now under construction.

Governor Dewey will give a report on the recent session of the State Legislature in a television broadcast tonight from 7 to 7:30 o'clock over Channel 2 and a state-wide network. The address will be recorded and presented over WCBS and other radio stations throughout the state at 10:30 P. M.
TOKYO, April 12 -- The Japanese Communist party, after a period of almost complete political inactivity in the open, is attempting to stage a popular comeback.

Two of the most favorable statistical omens in a long time bearing on the business situation made their appearance over the holiday week-end. These were, (1) the Department of Commerce analysis of consumer spending in the first quarter, and (2) the seventh annual McGraw-Hill survey of intended expenditures on the part of industry.

BOSTON, April 19 -- A second-inning bloop-single by Harry Agganis was the only hit allowed by Jim McDonald as the Yankees, gaining a split in the Patriot's Day morning-afternoon twin bill, blanked the Red Sox, 5 -- 0, today. The Bosox captured the early contest, 2 -- 1, even though the home side allowed the champions the equivalent of seven outs in the final frame.

KAFR EL DAWAR, Egypt, April 19 -- Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Premier of Egypt, gave land to 869 peasant families today. He urged them to be vigilant in defense of the revolution that had raised them from the status of tenants.
LONDON, April 19 (Reuters)--The Wolverhampton Wanderers gained a two-point lead in their struggle for the English Soccer League title today by downing Huddersfield, 4--0.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 19 -- Interest on Brazilian cruzeiro Treasury notes will be paid in] United States dollars, it was an-] nounced today by Banco do Brazil, to the surprise of observers.

There are signs that some appreciable increase in the present small volume of Soviet-American trade may be in the offing. Secretary of Commerce Weeks noted earlier this month that the Department of Commerce is working on a relaxation of present American prohibitions on exports to the Soviet Union. Soviet trade representatives here are reported to be making inquiries about possible machinery purchases.

DETROIT, April 19 -- The Michigan Medical Society withdrew its objections to the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine tonight and said that its members would cooperate in the mass inoculation of thousands of Michigan school children later this month.

Five thousand youngsters, most of them patients at Bellevue Hospital, shouted in joyful approval yesterday at a performance of acts from the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus. The performance was staged in the parking lot behind the hospital.

Harry Gross, erstwhile head of the $20,000,000-a-year Brooklyn bookmakers' ring, pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge that he had failed to file an income tax return for 1950. The Government also had accused the 39-year-old gambler of concealing $63,087 in income that year.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 19 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today authorized requests to Congress for supplemental appropriations totaling $58,708,000, almost all for adidtional loans by the Small Business Administration.
ALBANY, April 19--A bill permitting the direct election of party district leaders in New York City was approved today by Governor Dewey.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 19 -- Vincent A. G. O'Connor testified today that "at least two witnesses" were available in August, 1948, with information linking Joe Adonis to gambling in Lodi, N. J. He testified at the trial of Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County.

The choral ensembles of two colleges of the Evangelical and Reformed Church collaborated in a program last night at Town Hall. The groups were the sixty- voice choir of Hood College, Frederick, Md., which is led by Earle B. Blakeslee, and the forty-three- voice glee club of Franklin and Marshall College of Lancaster, Pa., which is led by Hugh Gault.

Four buildings containing seven stores and eighteen apartments at 746-748 Tenth Avenue and 464-468 West Fifty-first Street have been sold by David Fine to Emil Lublin. The .property occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet and is assessed at $70,000. Walter Scott Co. and Earl Douglas Hanson were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) -- Chairman William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, disclosed today that his Senate anti-monopoly subcommittee was investigating "interlocking directorates" of leading financial and industrial concerns.
Token-dispensing machines were installed yesterday in two midtown subway stations. The expectation is that they will shorten lines and lengthen New York tempers.

VERY likely Milbourne Christopher's magic show, which opened at the Longacre last evening, should be reviewed by a magician who would have standards of comparison. It takes a magician to find fault with a magician.

The Division of Foster Home Care of the Department of Welfare will mark its fifth anniversary today. The celebration will honor a hundred foster mothers and fathers who help care for youngsters in this city who must be separated temporarily from their families. Now, as at every period in the division's history, more such "parents" are urgently needed.

YONKERS, April 19 (AP) -- Stanley Dancer, 26-year-old New Egypt, N. J., driver won both ends of the daily double and Del MacTavish, a Canadian, took the feature $3,000 Class A Hudson pace with Bobby King in tonight's harness racing at Yonkers Raceway before 26,822.
Although Saturday's rain had a dampening effect on box-office receipts, business in first-run film houses ranged from capacity to good over the Easter holiday week-end.
A snake-in-the-grass from the Bronx wound up in a gutter near the Bowery last night in something of a zoological scandal.

LOS ANGELES, April 19 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, announced tonight plans for a conference of the world's leading scientists later this year to search for peaceful uses of atomic energy.

The Korean war cannot be considered ended until the 1,000,000 Chinese Communist troops are removed from Korean soil, Col. Ben C. Limb, South Korean observer at the United Nations, said here last night.
BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- Veikko Karvonen, a 27-year-old mail clerk from Finland, finished 800 yards in front of Britain's favored Jim Peters today to win the fifty-eighth Boston A. A. marathon.

A dress rehearsal of arguments against the city's proposed extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services was held yesterday. Opposition groups mapped their strategy to combat the proposal before the City Council's Finance Committee at a City Hall hearing at 10:30 A. M. today.

The number of United States concerns expressing interest in selling goods to the Soviet Union has increased sharply in recent weeks, Nikolai I. Muraviev, chief Soviet foreign-trade representative in this country, said yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 19 -- Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India and Nepal, said at a luncheon of the Civitan Club today that "victory is impossible" in Indo-China until France grants that country "complete independence."
WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) -- Eddie Yost's homer off Rookie Art Ditmar in the ninth inning gave the Washington Senators a 4-3 triumph over the Philadelphia Athletics tonight.
Testimony in Frank Costello's trial for income tax evasion turned yesterday from gambling and juke boxes in Louisiana to house buying on Long Island.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Labor Department is making a study of the causes of unemployment with the idea of seeing what employers can do to reduce it.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)--Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson pleaded innocent today to charges that he lent himself to enemy propaganda use and turned informer on fellow prisoners of war in Korea to win favorable treatment for himself.

Desserts made with cream cheese or cottage cheese or with sweet or sour cream are appropriate now during the season when dairy products are most abundant. In addition, such desserts have a lightness and piquancy especially appealing in spring.

A check for $100,000 was presented last night by the Philip Murray Memorial Foundation to Histadrut, the Israeli Federation of Labor, for the construction of a labor center in Elath, a city in southern Israel.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Because of rapidly growing enrollment, the Roman Catholic elementary and secondary schools in this country face a serious building and teacher shortage, Samuel Cardinal Stritch, Archbishop of Chicago, declared here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19 -- The United Nations Security Council called off this afternoon's scheduled meeting on Arab-Israeli border clashes because of the illness of Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon.

The price of many commodities on the New York exchanges closed at new seasonal highs yesterday despite the stock market's general decline. Trading was influenced by the situation in Indo-China and speeches over the week-end that indicated the possibliliy of greater participation by this country in the conflict.

Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. promised here yesterday that the United States would "steadfastly resist all maneuvers by the Chinese Communist regime and its advocates to bribe its way into the United Nations on mere promises of good behavior in the future."
Wake County, N. C., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on May 4 on $3,370,000 of school building bonds dated June 1, 1953, and due June 1 from 1957 to 1982.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- If it's organized play, it isn't an Easter egg-rolling.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Heavy sales of Argentine hides to Iron Curtain countries was reported today by Foreign Commerce Weekly, a publication of the Department of Commerce.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., April 19 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities was chided by an uncooperative witness today with undertaking to investigate the possible subversion of fish in the Pacific Ocean.

Floyd Patterson, undefeated Brooklyn light heavyweight, won a unanimous decision over Alvin Williams, a Caddo Indian from Oklahoma City in the main bout of eight rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Victor Andrade, the Bolivian Ambassador to the United States, announced today he had offered 4,000 tons of tin in ore concentrates for immediate sale to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
The reconstructed Brooklyn Bridge will be strictly parkway-like when it reopens on May 3 for two-direction pleasure traffic only. Even bus lines will be barred from the rebuilt span.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 19 -- The French were fighting desperately tonight to stem onslaughts by fresh waves of the Communist-led Vietminh at Dienbienphu.
BUFFALO, April 19 (AP) -- Dr. Albert Einstein told a Buffalo union leader he did "the right thing" in defying a Congressional subcommittee, the unionist said today.

DARWIN, Australia, Tuesday, April 20 -- Mme. Yevdokiya Petrov decided today to join her husband in political asylum a few minutes before a plane carrying her back toward Moscow was due to leave here. Mme. Petrov, 35 years old, made her decision after a long talk with Australian officials and a three-minute telephone call to her husband from the airport here.

Beating the Dodgers seems to have an adverse effect on the Giants. As has happened with distressing frequency in the last few seasons, the New Yorkers went from a sublime Sunday victory over the Brooks at Ebbets Field to a ridiculous 7-5 loss to the Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

A program to conserve the city's water, topped by bans on flushing streets and watering lawns, was ordered into effect yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The Mayor said the city's water supply had fallen to its "worst" April storage level in the history of upstate reservoirs.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was reported to have agreed today to step down temporarily from the Senate subcommittee investigating his dispute with the Army.

HAVANA, April 19 (AP) -- A third nation will make its debut in the International League tomorrow night when the Cuban Sugar Kings open their first season in the Triple-A circuit against the Toronto Maple Leafs in Havana's Gran Stadium.
MOSCOW, April 19 -- Nine leading Communist and workers' parties, including the Chinese, today greeted Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party secretary, on his sixtieth birthday.
This year will be one of adjustment for the Packard Motor Car Company with dividend payments uncertain, James J. Nance president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in Detroit yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Army has ruled that Pfc. Richard M. Gillings of Academy, S. D., was "improperly placed" in the stockade at Camp Carson, Colo., where he was shot and killed in an escape attempt Jan. 10.
CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- Hogs moved up to another new high since 1948 today when two loads of choice butchers sold at $28.50, up 10 cents from the peak of last weekend.
ROME, April 19 -- The Pope's Easter message to the world yesterday was stressed today by Communist and fellow-traveling newspapers in Italy.

The individual replacement system of the Army, which tends to handle men as "bodies" instead of preserving a unit's integrity and pride, is blamed by many correspondents as one of the primary reasons for inadequate morale.
ALBANY, April 19 -- The state "fair trade" law was challenged today before the Court of Appeals.

Lewis Gawtry, retired banker and former national treasurer of the Boy Scouts of America, died early yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He had been admitted March 2. Mr. Gawtry, who lived in Mayfair House, 610 Park Avenue, was 85 years old Feb. 25.

HEMPSTEAD, N. Y., April 19 -- Bob Vogel went the distance today to lead Hofstra's baseball team to a 10-1 victory over St. Peter's of Jersey City. Vogel allowed four hits, struck out nine, and walked six. Nunzio Pecoraro led Hofstra's attack with three singles.
MEXICO CITY, April 19 -- Antonio Carrillo Flores, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that Mexico had devalued the peso because the only afternative to "this painful measure" was exchange controls.
Dither, owned and sailed by Glen NIacNary, and J. B. MooreI Jr.'s Lure shared honors in the[ l%fanhasset Bay Yacht Club'sI frostbite championship and spring

Regarding your recent editorial "New York's Auto Deaths" there is, and has been, a simple and direct means for decreasing traffic fatalities. Since such a way would be likely to annoy the auto manufacturers, I assume that to be the reason it has never been put into effect.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Short term borrowing costs of the Treasury continued today their "see-saw" pattern.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 19 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today it was "unlikely" that United States troops would be sent to fight in Indo-China. He made the statement after he had reported to President Eisenhower.

Washington seems determined to give New York City a bad time over the Columbus Circle Coliseum. First it is a House rider to an appropriation bill. Now it is an official of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, taking umbrage apparently at what might be described as Commissioner Robert Moses' thinking about business first and polite protocol second.

The five-story Packard Junior College building at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street has been purchased by Yeshiva University which will use the property for its new Stern College for Women.

The sun shone brightly on fashion paraders Sunday after pelting rain in the preceding two days drowned the hopes of merchants for a banner Easter. The "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday showed that sales in department stores here last week were only 5 per cent better than in the like week last year.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) -- Four thousand Daughters of the American Revolution, opening their sixty-third Continental Congress, heard tonight that Congressional investigators were heading off communism.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 19 -- Holy Cross won its opening game of the baseball season today by defeating Dartmouth, 4 -- 3, in thirteen innings.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 19 (AP) -- John Landy, still in quest of the elusive four-minute mile, missed it again tonight in his farewell race before invading Europe. But he turned in one of his best performances when he was timed in 4:02.6 almost without opposition.

The Department of Defense, in cooperation with the Military Chaplains Association of the United States, will conduct regional conferences in thirteen key cities next autumn to prepare young men "more effectively" for military service.

Forty-nine young men and five women who have been adjudged the best students in advertising courses in colleges here and abroad, began yesterday an intensive week of learning about the profession from the inside.

THE Connecticut trout opening, in the opinion of those who participated in this traditional event, started on the wrong day. Those, however, who waited until the second day found the weather even worse and the streams higher.

French interiors, ranging from faithfully authentic period settings to rooms that are French only in inspiration, are one of the "Paris in New York" events scheduled to begin tomorrow. Twenty-six shops are involved in a "progressive" exhibition that stretches from Forty-ninth to Seventy-sixth Street and from Fifth to Second Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel Inc., today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for what would amount to a nation-wide reduction in railroad rates on scrap.

In behalf of the Save the Children Federation, a card party will be held on Friday afternoon in the ballroom of the Pierre. Mrs. Claire M. Senie heads the benefit committee. Mrs. Bertram A. Strook is president of the New York Women's Council of the federation, under whose auspices the event has been arranged.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The plan to reduce income taxes by increasing personal exemptions got a serious setback today.

TORONTO, April 19 -- The last key link in the Great Lakes navigation system -- the Lachine Canal at Montreal -- was opened to traffic today, but the Canadian wheat glut is keeping scores of freighters idle in half a dozen Lake Ontario ports.

The annual meeting of The Associated Press yesterday elected six directors, admitted sixteen papers that had been associate members into full membership and heard the report of its board of directors commend the management and staff for "another great year."

The American Safety Razor Corporation has sold its building at 315 Jay Street in Bloklyn to the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. The seller will remain as a tenant in the building for about three years, after which Polytechnic will make improvements for its own occupancy.

There were two markets on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The morning trading was intensely bullish. Oils, chemicals, electric equipments, metal and rubber shares carried The New York Times combined average to 202.15, a new high since Sept. 13, 1930. The afternoon saw a violent drop of prices from their peaks on investor nervousness and profit-taking. The Times combined average ended 1.74 points below last Thursday's close, at 198.96.

Employes of more than 100 insurance companies here began yesterday a mass donation to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. This annual "insurance week" contribution--it actually will last two weeks, Mondays through Fridays--is being held at the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street.

Directors of the Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., and of the McBee Company have approved plans for merging the companies, it was announced yesterday by Allan A. Ryan, chairman of Royal, and Phillip M. Zenner, chairman of McBee.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 19 -- President Eisenhower's leadership was characterized as "confusion and compromise" by Senator A. S. (Mike) Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, at Princeton University tonight.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- The biggest tournament prize in golf history -- $50,000 in cash and a $50,000 exhibition contract -- will go to the winner of George S. May's "world championship of golf" in the Tam o'Shanter meet this summer.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP) -- Manager Paul Richards of the Chicago White Sox called on his right-hand man -- Harry Dorish -- and the relief ace responded with a strong four-hit effort in the last 6 2/3 innings for a 5-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.
Two city officials denied here yesterday the existence of a special "crusade" against off-Broadway theatres in the current campaign to close playhouses deemed fire hazards.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon is disturbed about some of the reaction to his recent controversial speech on the possibility of United States intervention in the Indo-China war. He makes these points:
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 19 (UP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued by Secretary of State Dulles after his conference today with President Eisenhower:

A prospect of lower rates for television advertising as a consequence of subscription TV was held out yesterday by Dr. Millard C. Faught, economic consultant to the Zenith Radio Corporation. Zenith holds thirty patents on various systems of subscription television operations, known collectively as Phonevision, and has fifty more in process.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, April 19 -- The racial intolerance and stormy intellectual freedom of South Africa contrast with the racial tolerance and intellectual paralysis of neighboring Portuguese East Africa.

It seems of some interest to call attention to what lies behind the brutal M. V. D. kidnapping of Dr. Alexander Trushnovich, head of the Russian Rescue Committee in Berlin, which has been providing food, clothing, shelter and counsel to escapees from Soviet tyranny since the Second World War.

FOR his large mural at Grand Central Moderns, Byron Browne has picked as a theme the Battle of Armageddon. And, with no apparent irony, this painting, measuring twelve feet by eight, is proposed as a decoration for a United Nations Building.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 19 -- The Screen Actors Guild today canceled its contract with Tableau Television, Ltd., producers of the "China Smith" film series, because the company assertedly had failed to live up to the residual payments" provisions of its contract with the union. The action, first of its kind by the union, automatically bans actors from having any dealings with the producers.

HOUSTON, April 19 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, the national champion, battled through a tough first set and then breezed to victory today in the opening round of the twentieth annual River Oaks tennis tournament.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 19 -- Turkey's principal opposition party pledged tonight to continue close collaboration with the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The program, announced in a policy statement on the general election May 2, is designed "to put foreign policy above parties."
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- United States aid to foreign nations reached a peak of nearly $6,500,000,000 last year, but was tapering off at year's end.

Ambassador John E. Peurifoy will return to Washington today for consultation. In this case that means discussion of the problem of communism in Guatemala in the light of the so-called anti-Communist resolution at the Tenth Inter-American Conference.

There was plenty of buzzing at Jamaica yesterday. Rokeby Stables' 4-year-old Magic Lamp won the $31,450 Jamaica Handicap by three-quarters of a length It was just about the biggest surprise of the season.
BUENOS AIRES, April 19 -- President Juan D. Peron declared tonight that he planned to make Argentina completely self-sufficient in oil in the shortest possible time.
Following is the text of the address by Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. before the annual luncheon of the members of The Associated Press yesterday:
Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain led seventeen department inspectors into a lower East Side area yesterday to begin the city's drive against "litterbugs."

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The head of the Housing and Home Finance Agency told Robert Moses today he must get Federal approval before adding a twenty-story office building to the Coliseum project in New York.
Pan American World Airways, Inc., last year lifted its net income to a record $10,802,644 from the $6,673,265 earned in 1952, despite taxes that were more than double the year before.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Decreased loans and discounts, total deposits, cash resources, and holdings of United States Government bonds were reported by Chicago National Banks today in responding to a call from the Controller of the Currency for statements of conditions at the close of business April 15. Savings deposits were slightly higher than the last previous call, for Dec. 31.
BOSTON, April 19 -- The New England textile industry needs more tariff protection, a twenty-one-member committee appointed by the New England Governors reported today.
Details of the thirteenth game of the world chess tournament in Moscow, won by the champion, Mikhail Botvinnik, in his match with Vassily Smylov, were received yesterday from Zurich.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- A House Armed Services subcommittee accused a Maritime Administration official today of "reckless" conduct.

This country's shipbuilding potential is lessening steadily and the industry is not prepared today to meet a full-scale emergency, in the opinion of Rear Admiral W. D. Leggett Jr., chief of the Navy's Bureau of Ships.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19 -- Seventy-two wives and mothers of United States soldiers missing in Korea came to the United Nations today from forty states to ask that determination of the fate of the prisoners be placed at top of the agenda of the Geneva conference.

In one of the most forceful statements yet made on this subject Ambassador Lodge has again indicted the Chinese Communist regime as an aggressor unfit to sit in the United Nations. He promises that the United States will resist all maneuvers by that regime "or its advocates" to bribe its way into the world organization on mere promises of good behavior.
The battle of words continued unabated yesterday in the proxy contest between financier Robert R. Young and the management of the New York Central Railroad. These were the highlights:

A two-day hearing by the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Juvenile Delinquency into "sadistic comic books and their impact upon adolescents" will begin tomorrow in the United States Court House, Foley Square.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 19 -- Foreign Minister Mario A. Esquivel said today that the proposed mutual aid agreement between the United States and Nicaragua was "unnecessary" and likely to give a false impression to the Costa Rican people.
A new method of transmitting news pictures by facsimile was described to United Press executives yesterday at their annual meeting in the U. P. offices at 220 East Forty-second Street.

The decision of the Republic of Korea to send representatives to the Geneva conference is the only right and wise one that could have been made. The Koreans have been both apprehensive and pessimistic about the outcome of the conference and President Rhee's Government now states that the decision to attend has been made on the basis of further assurances from the United States.
This country's privately owned, ocean-going merchant fleet declined seven units during March, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Eisenhower Administration prepared today to seek bipartisan support for its handling of the crisis in Indo-China. Congress generally manifested an anxious reserve.
