The perennial battle over extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act has officially opened in Congress with introduction of the Administration's bill for a three-year renewal. Representative Kean of New Jersey, sponsor of the measure, has little time to lose, as the present law expires in less than two months.

A year's study of the woes of a "down at the heels" Chelsea has shown that its old-time residents and the Puerto Ricans in the once fashionable West Side area are primarily interested in solving their common problems -- housing and juvenile delinquency.

Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan reserved decision yesterday on a motion by John David Provoo, former Army sergeant, to set aside his life imprisonment sentence on charges of treason for giving aid and comfort to the Japanese in World War II.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which operates several large department stores and branches, made a new high in sales with $164,060,106 in the fiscal year ended last Jan. 31. This is 3.5 per cent more than the $158,486,747 volume transacted in the preceding fiscal year. Lord Taylor is controlled by the corporation.

Complaints by consumers of electricity supplied by the Long Island Lighting Company were in sharp conflict yesterday with testimony given by a company official at a Public Service Commission hearing at 233 Broadway.

Fifteen of the nation's leading physicians who specialize in diseases of the eye have joined the Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration, Inc., as a national advisory committee. Announcement of the new committee was made in the society's annual report, issued yesterday.

New Jersey made clear yesterday that it wanted the New York Stock Exchange, under that or any other name. Newark has a building -- the old Center Market -- to house it. Jersey City business men have volunteered the money to provide quarters there.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Gamma globulin, one of the weapons being used to prevent poliomyelitis, will be distributed under a greatly different system this summer.
HONG KONG, April 19 -- Premier Chou En-lai will head a four-man Chinese Communist delegation at the Geneva conference, the Peiping radio announced tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. John D. Beals Jr. of 1220 Park Avenue and Greens Farms, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Nicholson Beals, to Stanley Pierson Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Lewis of Short Hills, N. J., and Westhampton Beach, L. I. The wedding is planned to take place in June.

RANDALL, N. Y., April 19 -- Robert P. Hansen Jr., who would have been 15 years old in November, was born in New York City. In the two years since he came to the little farm south of here in Montgomery County with his father and a sister, Dorothy, 17, he learned to love the country. It had made a "new boy" of him, his father said.

Arriving in New York, where have a branch of my company, I read with great interest your editorial which appeared on April 16 entitled "Illinois Primary." I have been an admirer of the fine unbiased new policy of The New York Times for years.
TRENTON, April 19 -- New Jersey voters, perhaps 1,000,000, will flock to the polls tomorrow from Cape May to Sussex County.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Administration is working on a plan to dispose of Government-owned butter that may enable consumers to buy it as low as 45 cents a pound.
JERUSALEM, April 19 -- The Easter week-end lull along the Jordanian-Israeli armistice line ended today when firing broke out at two points in the Latrun salient in No Man's Land.

Prices of cotton futures turned irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The close was 10 points lower to 8 points higher than on last Thursday, with old crop months showing the most weakness.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19 -- The United Nations Disarmament Commission turned down today Soviet demands to include Communist China, India and Czechoslovakia in the new round of atomic control talks.
BOSTON, April 19 (AP)--Two American Woolen Company meetings, previously adjourned for lack of a quorum, will be resumed in Boston tomorrow.

The city's six largest breweries set forth yesterday their determination to increase employment opportunities for Negroes. In a joint statement, they urged Judge Harold A. Stevens of General Sessions to reconsider his resignation last week as chairman of a committee to police a no-discrimination pact in the industry.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., April 20 -- The ocean bottom at Southwest Ledge is not carpeted with snowshoe flounders, nor are the waters crowded by shoals of cod, but there are enough of both present to keep most anglers interested and happy.

Monday's donations to the regional Red Cross blood program totaled 425 pints. Included were 213 pints given at the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street, the first day of the two-week mass donation by employes of more than 100 insurance company offices at that address.

Employment in New York State is now at an all-time high, Governor Dewey told a television and radio audience last night in a report on the accomplishments of the recent legislative session. Mr. Dewey attributed high employment and generally prosperous business conditions within the state to policies he had pursued in the twelve years he had been Governor.

MADRID, April 20 -- The Spanish Ministry of the Army was understood today to have started an investigation of the 285 Spaniards recently repatriated from the Soviet Union. They were released from captivity earlier this month after years in Soviet concentration camps.

The first of a new series of all-purpose freighters, designed for use on various runs, has been ordered by the Holland-America Line. The vessel will be built at the De Schelde yards, Flushing, the Netherlands.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 20 -- The lower house of Parliament voted a resolution of thanks today to Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet delegate to the United Nation, for his support of the Arab cause in the Security Council last week.
BALTIMORE, April 20 (AP) -- The Baltimore Opera Club has decided to discontinue sponsorship of visits to Baltimore by the Metropolitan Opera Company of New York.

Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation's net income for the first quarter of this year declined to $21,443,770, or 74 cents a share, from $25,695,100, or 89 cents a share, in the 1953 period, Morse G. Dial, president, reported at the annual stockholder meeting here yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 20 -- Fordham battered two Navy hurlers for ten hits, including home runs by Joe Pennachio, Ronald Ryba and Kevin O'Connor, today as the Rams recorded their fourth victory in five starts by defeating the middies, 9 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Two persons suspected of espionage were among 309 employes dismissed by the State Department as "security risks" last year, the department security chief, Scott McLeod, said today.
As investor uncertainty continued, the stock market opened soft yesterday, spurted to wipe out its Monday losses, drooped on minor volume in the fourth hour, and ended the day marking time.
ST. LOUIS, April 20 (UP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs battered four St. Louis Cardinal pitchers tonight to take a 13-6 victory and remain in a first-place tie with Philadelphia.

BUFFALO, April 20 (AP) -- A union leader whose refusal to testify before a Congressional subcommittee was described by Dr. Albert Einstein as "the right thing" said today he had apologized to Dr. Einstein for bringing him into the incident.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Five of Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson's former prison camp companions testified today that he once had informed their Chinese Communist captors of an escape plot and tried to convert them to communism.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- John Wayne and his producer partner, Robert Fellows, have acquired film rights to two books and are negotiating with William Wellman to direct the screen versions.
Legal maneuvers delayed yesterday the formal opening of the grand larceny trial of Joseph P. Ryan, retired president of the old International Longshoremen's Association.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Following are the texts of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's formal charges against the Army and of Assistant Secretary of Defense H. Struve Hensel's reply to McCarthy accusations against him:

THERE'S been too much whistle-blowing in the National Basketball Association and too much fouling. Now that the owners in the N. B. A. are about to assemble in their annual meeting, it behooves them to blow the whistle and call a few technical fouls on themselves.

The announcement that Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra would give a program of Brahms at their final New York concert of the present season, which took place last night in Carnegie Hall, was not on the face of it especially exciting.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Industrial production continued to decline in the first quarter of this year in factories making durable goods such as radios and refrigerators.

The sixty-eighth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association opened here yesterday with an address by its vice president, Richard W. Slocum of The Philadelphia Bulletin. He discussed "the gradually narrowing margin between the cost of operation and revenue."

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Congressional investigators were told today the Federal Housing Administration had approved mortgages for 1,149 apartment projects that allowed builders $65,557,000 more than they had spent.

President Juan D. Peron of Argentina was accused yesterday by the Metropolitan Club of New York of "police state methods" and of having suppressed habeas corpus in the arrest April 2 of Raul Lamuraglia, a former Argentine textile magnate.
RENO, Nev., April 20 -- The State Supreme Court today ordered the University of Nevada to reinstate Dr. Frank Richardson, who was ousted from the faculty June 9, 1953.

Brooklyn College took undisputed possession of second place in the Metropolitan Baseball Conference by defeating Manhattan, 6 -- 2, on the Brooklyn diamond yesterday. The Flatbush team has a 2-1 league record.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The United States filed a claim against Guatemala today for $15,854,849 as compensation for the expropriation of nearly 234,000 acres of land owned by the United Fruit Company.

Much has been accomplished by the Waterfront Commission, particularly as a result of the recent longshore strike, but it would be utterly unrealistic not to anticipate further upheavals on New York's docks, Lawrence E. Walsh, executive director and counsel of the bi-state harbor organization, said last night.
A racetrack acquaintance said yesterday that Frank Costello reluctantly invested $6,000 to $8,000 in a gambling venture that returned a profit of $9,000 to $10,000 within a few months.

The majority of parents of young children in New Haven, Conn., generally approve children's television programs, but are not specific about what they approve, the results of a survey showed yesterday. On the other hand, parents who disapprove are very specific about what they don't like.
Watching history in the making is far more beguiling -- though costlier -- than trying to absorb it in the classroom, a group of visiting high school students has discovered.

There is no school for commuters -- that is to say, a school where one learns how to be a successful commuter -- and perhaps after all there is no need for one. And yet every year, with the continued retreat of man to suburbs, hundreds of new commuters join a seasoned brotherhood of short-haul travelers and, without benefit of instruction, must learn the art of commuting.

Expansion of export credit now being studied by the Export-Import Bank will be limited to trade that contributes to lasting economic benefits for the United States and other countries, it was indicated by a bank official yesterday.

Sadao Iguchi, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday that normal trade with the United States was vital to the restoration of his country's self-support and self-respect. He spoke at the opening of the Japan Trade Center, 393 Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Streets.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 20 -- A foundation to aid the blind will be established here as the result of a decision by Superior Court Judge Mark A. Sullivan Jr., to permit liquidation of the estate of Caleb C. Pruden, Elizabeth landowner, who died in 1931.

A management slate of directors was elected yesterday by the Blair Holdings Corporation. The election took place at a resumed session of the annual meeting of shareholders which started on April 13. H. C. Maginn, president since January, retained control of the $25,000,000 investment organization.

The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York said in its annual report yesterday that "the year ahead looks bright for the plan." At the end of 1953, the report said, the plan had assets totalling $4,376,345, compared with $3,588,315 at the end of 1952.

Those of us who need a reminder of a half-century's progress toward eliminating harmful child labor should glance at a portrait of solemn, coal-smudged faces of young boys who worked in the coal mines in the early Nineteen Hundreds. This visual evidence of a past evil appears as the front cover of "The Changing Years," a decade-by-decade report of the campaign to end child labor initiated by the National Child Labor Committee in 1904.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 20 -- The French believe they have about one week in which to finish the reorganization of the defenses at Dienbienphu.

YONKERS, April 20 (AP) -- Stanton Hal, driven by Bill Haughton, beat Prince Eton by a neck in the $3,000 Huguenot pace before 21,890 persons at Yonkers Raceway tonight in 2:03 3/5. Poor Pop was third.
The board of directors of The Associated Press re-elected Robert McLean of The Philadelphia Bulletin yesterday as president of the A. P. for another year. He has been president since 1938.

Prices fell yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges in what was called a normal reaction to Monday's sharp rises. Coffee, cocoa, sugar, wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, lead, zinc, tin and hides closed lower; rubber, burlap and copper moved irregular, and silk and potatoes ended higher.

The International Business Machines Corporation increased its net income in the first three months this year to $10,134,429, from $7,520,105 earned in the initial quarter of 1953, according to the report to be mailed to stockholders today.

There was something baffling about the Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but the Giants finally got around to solving it. They simply waited until the Bucs made the move that almost immediately led to their dissolution.

The city's work-relief program is being halted June 30 because the State Legislature failed either to renew authority for the present compulsory system or to enact a labor-backed voluntary compromise.
The continuing influx of new designs imported from the four small Scandinavian countries would seem to prove that there is something new under the midnight sun.

Caryl Chessman, 32-year-old criminal now awaiting death in the gas chamber at California's San Quentin prison, has written an account of his life entitled "Cell 2455, Death Row." Chessman taught himself to write, studied law himself and acted as his own attorney in the legal actions that have kept him from the gas chamber for the last five years.

COLLEGES and universities, once so hesitant about the upstart medium of radio, seem to be taking to television with a good deal more relish and success. On this morning's agenda are samples of the TV work of Princeton University and Brown University.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of the ground rules established by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations for its hearings into the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army:
MEXICO CITY, April 20 -- The once postponed Mexican-United States Trade Fair will open in mid-October on a Mexico City site still to be determined.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 20 -- A group of women who believe their sons and husbands still are held prisoner by the Communists in Korea spent several hours today standing outside the United Nations buildings, many of them wearing blue ribbons inscribed "Mothers of Forgotten Men."

The Federal Housing Administration pledged yesterday an investigation into alleged abuses in cooperative housing built with F. H. A. mortgage guarantees, according to a spokesman for cooperative apartment owners.
CHICAGO, April 20 -- Spectacular price moves in soybean futures overshadowed trading operations in grains on the Board of Trade here today.

Confident and indefatigable, Secretary Dulles has left again for Europe to attend two meetings which could prove decisive in the East-West struggle -- a struggle dramatized by the roaring battle of Dienbienphu.
BURBANK, Calif., April 20 (AP) -- Seven men were killed today when an Air Force Flying Boxcar crashed into fog-shrouded Mission Peak in the Santa Susana Mountains.

HOUSTON, April 20 (AP) -- The defending champion, Gardnar Mulloy, had to make a strong second set comeback today before moving into the fourth round of the twentieth annual River Oaks tennis tournament.

We sympathize with New York City's need for more revenues, and we will support other forms of taxation to supply this need, but the objections to extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services are so serious and so obviously valid that they cannot be ignored.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson left Passavant Hospital today after a kidney operation. The 1952 Democratic Presidential nominee had a stone removed from his kidney a week ago.
DETROIT, April 20 (UP) -- Virgil Trucks, a twenty-game winner last season, scattered six hits today as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 7 -- 2, for their fourth straight triumph.

During March the aggregate draft indebtedness of Latin-American countries to United States exporters declined for the eleventh consecutive month, it was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The monthly report is based on the draft experience of fifteen large banks.
PESHAWAR, Pakistan, April 20 -- An Afghan Foreign Office spokesman denied today reports that talks were taking place between Pakistan and Afghanistan for federating the two countries.
Documentary in design but contemporary in color and scale are fifteen wallpapers introduced yesterday by Wilton E. Owen, Inc., 515 Madison Avenue, where they are available through decorators.

LONDON, April 20 -- The rebellion in the Labor movement against West German rearmament spread today. With only two of the 850 delegates dissenting, Britain's sixth largest union voted against arms for the Federal Republic now.

Representative Lester Holtzman, Democrat, of Rego Park, Queens, disclosed last night that he was the Congressman apparently alluded to by Senator McCarthy as having requested a change in orders for Major Peress.

Joseph Anthony Maggio, a Brooklyn postal clerk, testified yesterday in Flatbush Magistrate's Court regarding his charge that his name and personality were used without permission in "From Here to Eternity," a novel, and the film based on it.

CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- Hogs closed steady to 25 cents lower today with the top price declining for the first time in nine trading sessions. It was $28.40, down 10 cents from yesterday. Two loads of choice 210 pound butchers reached the top.
A six-run outburst in the seventh inning sent Princeton to a 13-8 victory over Columbia at Baker Field yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., April 20 (AP) -- The green and black silks of Alfred Roberts monopolized the winner's circle in the feature races at Bowie today. The New Jersey sportsman won the fifth and sixth events with Eatontown and Thither, respectively.
BOSTON, April 20 (UP) -- The annual meeting of American Woolen Company was recessed again today until tomorrow -- or later. No action was taken on the future of the company.

New issues of public utility securities valued at more than $38,000,000 will be offered to investors today. For the most part capital raised by the financing will be used for expansion of service facilities.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- The lawyer for an ousted Navy map custodian today named six persons as probable informants against his client and urged the Navy to summon them to a public hearing for cross-examination under oath.
SINGAPORE, April 20 -- A cluster of Tonkinese peasants watched stolidly as our jeep drove by. Their faces were inscrutable under their big, round, pointed straw hats.
Cornelius Shields of the New York and Larchmont Yacht Clubs was re-elected chairman for 1954 at the International Class meeting at the New York Y. C. last night.
EPSOM, England, April 20 (AP) -- American-owned Ambler II emerged today the probable Epsom Derby favorite by winning the Blue Ribbon Trial Stakes at Epsom.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins told the Daughters of the American Revolution tonight that the United States was "determined to fight" if Russia menaced the freedom of any country in the North Atlantic Treaty organization.

The decision of the Soviet Union to declare East Germany a "sovereign" republic has failed to deceive either the nations of the free world or those Germans imprisoned behind the Iron Curtain. Instead, by destroying whatever hope East Germans still had of reunion with their countrymen in the near future, the proclamation has resulted in increasing the number of refugees fleeing into Western Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The president of the United States Chamber of Commerce and Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks addressed a news conference tonight to clear away many "misconceptions" about Canada but found that even they did not agree on the amount of trade with that country.

NEW DELHI, India, April 20 -- -- Jayaprakash Narayan, India's front-ranking Socialist leader, has decided to quit politics to devote himself to the land gift movement. He made known his views today at a conference of social workers called to evolve a program for intensifying the movement.

Nedick's, Inc., has introduced a new type of outlet to its chain of 116 stores on the Eastern Seaboard. The company will open a coffee room today at Madison Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. This will have a seating capacity of fifty to sixty customers and no room for standees.
TORONTO, April 20 (Canadian Press) -- Touring Russian artists will perform tomorrow night in Massey Hall. Toronto musicians will not take part in the show.

The apparent change of our basic military strategy to the "New Look principle bears in itself a terrific amount of danger even if relied upon only partially. The words "instant retaliation" imply the obviously sound assumption that the United States will not start the use of the H-bomb.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20--Preacher Roe's spirit was willing but his arm and his team-mates were a bit reluctant tonight, with the result that the Phillies beat the Dodgers, 6--3, before 21,921 fans at Connie Mack Stadium.

HIS name was Thomas Henry Hines and he looked enough like John Wilkes Booth to be his twin. A Kentuckian, slight in stature but tough and wiry, Hines served as a captain with Gen. John H. Morgan's famous cavalry raiders. His record was distinguished; it made him famous, and the Northern newspapers called him "guerrilla Hines."
Mayor Wagner confronted 300 critics of the proposed sales tax extension at City Hall yesterday and told them to go to Albany.

Jose Gorostiza, Mexico's Under-Secretary of External Affairs, declared yesterday that his nation was making "gradual but continuous progress" toward providing the people with a higher standard of living in the not distant future.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday. The close was 15 points higher to 11 points lower than on Monday with old crop months showing the most strength.

MOSCOW, April 20 -- The newly elected Supreme Soviet, the nation's highest legislative body, met today for its first session. It will formally approve the composition of the Government and adopt the budget for 1954.
WASHINGTON, April 20--H. Struve Hensel, Assistant Secretary of Defense, denounced today as "barefaced lies" the accusations of misconduct flung at him by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
Passengers on the city's rapid transit lines are being offered a chance by the Transit Authority to help it save $5,000,000 a year in operating costs.

HENDERSONVILLE, N. C., April 20 (UP)--Julius Boros of Mid-Pines, N. C., shot a 4-under-war 67 today to take the lead in the first round of the Carolinas open golf tournament in a field of eighty-one professionals and amateurs.

Final details of the opening-day program of the $30,000,000 Cross County Center in Westchester were completed yesterday. Work continued at a fast pace to have the shopping center ready by next Wednesday, when it is to make its debut.
WASHINGTON, April 20--Strong, if often troubled, bipartisan support in Congress was given the Administration today for the coming tests of the Geneva conference, opening Monday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 20 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that plans were being discussed for sending more United Nations military observers to keep a watch on the Palestine frontiers.
Directors of the United States Lines Company have deferred any dividend action until the May meeting of the board of directors. John M. Franklin, president, announced yesterday.

We believe few people would doubt the need of stronger policing of the magazine stands against obscenity after reading the March, 1954, report of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee to Study the Publication of Comics. The illustrations and quotations reprinted in that document were enough to convince us that publications, including "comic" books, were being freely sold on the streets that had no business in the hands of young people.
WASHINGTON, April 20--The text of Secretary of State Dulles' statement today on his departure from Washington follows:...
Senator Herbert H. Lehman has introduced a bill to avert the deportation of Martin A. Madden, brother of Owen (Owney) Madden, powerful racketeer of the Prohibition era.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., April 20 -- A white sloop of the Ghost class eluded the police today on 300 miles of the Boston Post Road and other busy highways between Mamaroneck and New Hampshire.

MOSCOW, April 20 -- The May Day slogans of the Communist party, announced tonight, included a call for collective security of all European peoples, a stronger struggle against the rebirth of German militarism and the "creation of aggressive military groupings."

The International News Service issued an annual report yesterday stressing global expansion during the last year in its service to newspapers, radio and television services. It also emphasized new techniques for news coverage "in depth."

That knotty pine breakfast nook or study that many families have (or want) didn't develop by accident. The story of a thirty-year campaign to popularize the various Western pines was recounted yesterday by the Western Pine Association, which has been running continuous advertising through N. W. Ayer Son to set forth the advantages and beauty of the woods.
CITY dwellers rarely see the crews that probe through asphalt and concrete for water leaks, a job crucially important now, when a water shortage threatens.

Three girls and a boy were rescued from Long Island Sound off City Island yesterday afternoon, largely because two policemen in a helicopter spotted them floundering near a capsized sailboat. However, when brought ashore, they scampered away before anyone could get their names and addresses.

TOKYO, April 20 -- Parliamentary business in Japan is almost at a standstill. The Government and Diet alike are engaged in a furious political battle over charges of corruption in high places in the Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida.

The number of "permanent" substitutes is a serious problem in this city's public school system, Dr. Alice V. Keliher of the New York University School of Education said yesterday. She spoke at a luncheon of the Woman's City Club, 277 Park Avenue.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 20 -- The 38,000 - deadweight-ton tanker W. Alton Jones was launched here today in a building dock of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company.

VIENNA, April 20 (UP) -- The mouthpiece of international communism, the Cominform Journal, accused the United States in its latest issue received today of employing "intimidation and military threats" to line up Western support for its Far East policy.

Created for the commuter and hot summer days ahead, the collection of Jerry Gilden designs, shown yesterday at Russeks, incorporated those attributes women want in cottons for town. Black and black and white were the favored colors.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 20 -- A second person was named today by Vincent A. G. O'Connor as one of those who had given him information in 1948 that Joe Adonis was operating a gambling house in Lodi, N. J.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 20 (Reuters) -- Britain and Iran opened talks today on oil compensation in a "friendly atmosphere," it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Southpaw Alex Kellner allowed only an eighth-inning single by Wayne Terwilliger tonight as he pitched the Philadelphia Athletics to a 7-0 triumph over the Washington Senators.
ST. LOUIS, April 20 -- Higher tariffs on zinc and Government stockpiling of the metal were urged today by Howard I. Young, president of the American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company.
Information media are expanding abroad along with the general improvement of economic conditions. One barometer of these trends is provided by newsprint.

RAHWAY, N. J., April 20 -- A bronze plaque marking the site of the first mint to turn out coins bearing the legend, "E Pluribus Unum," which now appears on all metal currency of the United States, was unveiled here today by Mrs. Sophia Meyner, assisted by her son, Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

Few novelists would have dared to write a scene so full of drama, heartbreak and suspense as that which took place at the Darwin airport, in northern Australia, yesterday. What doubts and confused thoughts must have gone through Mrs. Petroy's mind as she weighed her choice!

The latest industrial production figures issued by the Federal Reserve Board seem to suggest strongly that this country has reached, for the moment at least, something of an economic plateau. March industrial production was only one index point below that of February and only three points below December.
President Eisenhower will be guarded by more than 1,00 policemen during his visit here tomorrow, the Police Department announced yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 20 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies declared today that the Government had "behaved with scrupulous care and regard for international protocol" in assisting Mme. Vladimir Petrov to join her husband in asylum here.

Unable to score in five previous starts this season, Mrs. J. R. H. Thouron's favored Royal Vale, last year's big money maker, finally reached the winner's circle yesterday. The 6-year-old-outsprinted the Phantom Farm's Gideon to take the six-furlong $10,045 Arise Handicap at Jamaica.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 20 -- President Eisenhower will interrupt his vacation on Thursday and Friday to make appearances in Washington, New York and at three places in Kentucky. He will return to Augusta for another round or two of golf and fly back to the capital on Sunday.
The French pianist-composer Jean-Michel Damase made his first recital appearance in this country at Steinway Hall last evening under the auspices of the Alliance Francaise of New York.

Bingo and raffles were legalized in the big majority of New Jersey municipalities in yesterday's special local option election. Incomplete returns indicated early today that only thirty of 567 communities had rejected either of these minor forms of gambling.

The "Freedom Express," the first of three trains carrying donations for South Korea's devastated areas, left here yesterday noon after a colorful, sun-drenched ceremony in the New York Central freight yards.

ITHACA, N. Y., April 20 -- An estimated 250 persons are attending the twenty-sixth Family Life Conference. It opened today at the College of Home Economics at Cornell University and will run through Thursday noon. It will consider the over-all theme, "Ages and Stages of Human Growth and Development."

The murder of Thomas F. Lewis, head of a union of Yonkers Raceway employes, was ordered by Lawrence (La-La) Lynch, the trotting track's deposed "labor trouble shooter," a jury was told yesterday at the trial of William E. Howell.

The 1954 Bancroft Prizes "for distinguished writings in American history" were awarded last night by Columbia University to "Seedtime of the Republic," by Clinton Rossiter, and to "The Undeclared War," by William L. Langer and S. Everett Gleason.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 20 (AP) -- Keeneland stewards today ordered a sixty-day suspension for Trainer Elmer Kalensky and a groom in his employe, Russell Welch, after inquiry into a case alleging stimulation of a horse.

CLEVELAND, April 20 -- A victory for Robert R. Young in his fight for control of the New York Central Railroad would benefit rail employes, the traveling and shipping public, and investors, Guy L. Brown, grand chief engineer of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, asserted today.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The United States is expected to announce within forty-eight hours a loan of about $100,000,000 to the European Coal and Steel Community.
Spring 1954 was a month old yesterday and New Yorkers got a good dose of it for a change.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Major crimes committed in the United States in 1953 totaled 2,159,080, the highest on record, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

PARIS, April 20 -- After nearly two years of living side by side, United States service men and French civilians still view each other for the most part without sympathy, according to a study made at one of the largest United States air bases in Europe.
A group of French wine experts, representing some of the finest red and white wines of Bordeaux, has just arrived in New York to take a look at our American market.

A FELLOW artist once referred to Louis Bouche's "accidental brush." In his recent paintings at the Kraushaar Gallery, Bouche continues to convey that familiar impression of spontaneity in his work. But the casual-seeming effects are thoroughly well worked out.
College students attending the Annual Conference of the Association of International Relations Clubs to explore the question "Why the United Nations?" heard the answer of four experts yesterday.
The country's largest electrical manufacturer gave a frigid reception yesterday to union demands for a guaranteed annual wage.

SCHENECTADY, April 20 -- General Electric Company stockholders were told here today that the company made record profits in the first quarter, although sales were off from the first three months of 1953.

LONDON, April 20--British Government issues resumed their advance when the securities markets reopened here today after the Easter holiday. But industrial shares showed nearly as many losses as gains.

During the past two months editorials have appeared in several New York City newspapers commenting upon my policy of declining to disclose the contents of statements made by prospective defendants in criminal investigations, or to characterize such statements as confessions.
VIENNA, April 20 -- Rumania has changed over to "collective leadership" after the example of the Soviet Union.

FROM some 350 modern drawings in its collection, the Museum of Modern Art has made a judicious selection of sixty-two that have been arranged as an exhibition opening today in the museum's Auditorium Gallery under the title "Figures and Faces.

A major event next season will be the Old Vic's lavish presentation at the Metropolitan Opera House of "A Midsummer Night's Dream." Recruited for it are Moira Shearer, Robert Helpmann, Stanley Holloway, a corps de ballet and a symphony orchestra to play the Felix Mendelssohn score.
LONDON, April 20 -- The West German Government's practice of giving subsidies to exporters is causing concern among British Treasury officials and industrialists.

BOSTON, April 20 (UP) -- L. W. Johnson's Den-Cal, the fourth choice in a field of nine horses, spurted in the Suffolk Downs stretch today to score a two-and-one-half length victory over Thomas Pepper in the Wakefield Purse.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (UP) -- The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, Philadelphia Baptist minister and editor of The Christian Herald, said today United States churches and schools were prime targets of communism and Protestant clergymen apparently were "most vulnerable" to Red propaganda.
PARIS, April 20 -- Reports of separate French negotiations for peace with the Vietminh Government in Indo-China were denied in an official statement here today.

Representative members of the worlds of society, diplomacy and the arts attended the third annual April in Paris Ball, known this year as the "Bal de la Soie." It was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
One of the nation's thirty largest industrial organizations -- the Henry J. Kaiser Company -- celebrates its fortieth anniversary today.

Wool has been brought into the category of the new "miracle" fibers with the application of silicone water - repellent finishes. This was disclosed yesterday by Dr. W. R. Collings, vice president and general manager of Dow Corning Corporation, chemical manufacturer.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Army-McCarthy controversy erupted today with new sensational charges and denials involving another high official of the Eisenhower Administration.

Mrs. John Williams Morgan gave a luncheon yesterday in the White and Gold Suite of the Plaza for Mrs. John T. Ogden, chairman of next season's tea dance and fashion show for the benefit of the Judson Health Center.
TOKYO, April 20 -- Foreign Minister Pyun Yung Tai reiterated today that South Korea had received new assurances of military support from the United States.
Albert M. Cole, the nation's housing chief, was accused yesterday by Robert Moses of having a "marvelous forgettery."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 20 -- A recommendation for a world-wide survey of press censorship was approved today by an eighteen-nation committee.
More than $57,000 in cash and jewelry worth $50,000 were found yesterday morning among the effects of Mrs. Eleanor J. Barney soon after she died of heart disease in her room at the Statler Hotel.
GUATEMALA, April 20 -- An Administration party charged today that the Roman Catholic Church was fighting the Guatemalan Government under the guise of combating communism.

John Houseman is winner of the theatre award given annually by the Shakespeare Club of New York City. The film and stage director was named for the honor because of his movie production of "Julius Caesar" and for his staging of the recent Phoenix Theatre revival of Shakespeare's "Coriolanus."

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., April 20 (UP) -- Capt. Alfred Y. Allee of the Texas Rangers was clear today of a charge he tried to murder George B. Parr, south Texas political boss known as the "Duke of Duval County."

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas told the American people tonight that "we cannot afford to undercut and undermine the President of the United States, whether we are of his own party, or the opposition."
MEXICO CITY, April 20 (AP)--Devaluation of the peso has put domestic and foreign airlines operating in Mexico in a peso-dollar rate tailspin.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 -- The American Federation of Labor's Marine Cooks and Stewards union was disclosed today as the winner over the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, unaffiliated, in an election to determine the collective bargaining agent aboard West Coast steam schooners.

Three out of four youngsters in New York City who need psychiatric treatment must do without, Herschel Alt, executive director of the Jewish Board of Guardians, said last night. In all, he declared, 12,000 children and young people here are in need of such service.
Veterans of the tanbark arena call the Nock Trio a "Polyclinic act," a term of high praise in circus jargon.
LANSING, Mich., April 20 -- G. Mennen Williams, the third man in Michigan history to hold the Governor's post for six successive years, said today he would seek a fourth term.

TRENTON, April 20 -- Bingo and raffles have long been popular in New Jersey. Until they were banned as illegal last April by all county prosecutors, as many as 200 bingo games or raffles were held nightly throughout the state. The great majority were operated for the benefit of civic, charitable, religious, veterans and volunteer fire organizations.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Mrs. Katie Louchheim, director of Women's Activities of the Democratic National Committee, said today the 1954 Congressional campaign would be decentralized clear down to coffee cups in the living room.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 20--Turkey will take her dispute with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development before the meeting of the United Nations Economic and Social Council in New York tomorrow.
Dr. Milton Helpern, the city's new Chief Medical Examiner, believes that every man in the department should be something more than a competent physician and a trained pathologist.

DETROIT, April 20 (AP) -- George J. Kolowich today lost the helm of the Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company, which he has piloted since 1947. Winners of the bitter fight for control of the concern said it would be dissolved.
The city of Seattle, Wash., raised $10,000,000 in the public market for school building purposes yesterday through the sale of an issue of serial bonds maturing annually from 1956 to 1974.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- A swing away from the liberal arts and humanities toward science and technical subjects is creating a dangerous imbalance in higher education, college authorities warned here today.
The city's water reserve showed a slight increase yesterday as officials moved to put into effect the conservation measures ordered by Mayor Wagner.

EMBARKED on what amounts to a grand tour of the Gilbert and Sullivan repertoire, the American Savoyards reached "Ruddigore" last night at the tiny President Theatre. To say that this bit of spoofing of mid-Victorian melodrama by the erstwhile masters of the Savoy is something of a minor stop along the way is, of course, reiterating the obvious.

It is characteristic of democracy that every citizen has a right to air his opinions on any subject. Presumably this also goes for responsible officials. Democratic policy - makers cannot keep the enemy guessing without keeping their own public guessing, too, and this the sovereign people will never submit to.
Americans will spend a billion and a third dollars for travel abroad this year, Ralph T. Reed, president of the American Express Company, predicted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)--The American Cotton Manufacturers Institute urged the Senate Finance Committee today to put a much more liberal depreciation formula in the tax revision bill.

CLEVELAND, April 20 (AP) -- The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company said today it would spend "something in excess of $2,000,000" building a northern terminus for a revolutionary 110-mile coal pipeline.
ALBANY, April 20 (AP) -- Legislation to let Nassau County towns block annexation of their territory by villages has been approved by Governor Dewey.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 20 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight the United States would seek an "honorable and peaceful settlement" in Indo-China at the Geneva conference but would oppose outright surrender to the Communists.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Makers of the controversial battery additive AD-X2 have filed a detailed denial of Federal Trade Commission charges that their advertising claims were false, misleading and deceptive.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Wiretapping operations by the Federal Bureau of Investigation have reached as many as 200 at a single time since 1941, Herbert Brownell Jr. said today.
DETROIT, April 20 (AP) -- Methodist Bishop Fred P. Corson pleaded tonight for a "spiritual purpose" in education in the interest of world peace.
LONG BEACH, L. I., April 20 -- A three-day "Art Circus," involving a large number of men, women and children in this community, opened at the Central Elementary School today.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- The Tariff Commission today reported rising unemployment and falling profits in American lead and zinc industries.
Tea, said to be the most universal of beverages next to water, is the subject of an exhibition that opened yesterday in the museum building of the New York Botanical Garden.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson. Secretary of Defense, said today he had approved a Navy reorganization plan calling for two new Assistant Secretaries.
GUATEMALA, April 21 -- Having failed to negotiate a renewal of its charter, an affiliate of the W. R. Grace Company suspended activities today.

Columbia University's staff and students will begin a two-day donation of blood to the regional Red Cross Blood Program today. Dean Lawrence H. Chamberlain of Columbia College will give the first blood.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -"Pat-on-the-wrist" punishment for income tax law violators has reached the point where tax fraud is becoming "socially acceptable," T. Coleman Andrews said today.

The car could scarcely have been dignified with the name of "hot rod." In fact, when Police Sgt. John Drzazga passed it on Ninety-sixth Street, Ozone Park, Queens, at 1:15 P. M. yesterday, it was a pretty cold turkey.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday, advancing 3 to 15 points.

ROME, April 21 -- On the eve of the first anniversary of her arrival in Italy as Ambassador, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce has urged greater effort to increase Italian exports. She spoke to the American Chamber of Commerce in Milan.

Coffee prices on the New York exchange tumbled the 2-cent a pound limit in all positions yesterday and cocoa fell the 1-cent daily limit in one delivery. Other commodity prices were irregularly lower.

BOSTON, April 21 -- Textron Incorporated took its proxy fight for control of the American Woolen Company to court today. The action came a few hours after the annual meeting of American Woolen stockholders had been postponed for the third time for lack of a quorum.

Commercial paper outstanding rose seasonally $19,000,000 in March to $720,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This new total was 42 per cent above the figure for March a year ago, and was the highest the Reserve Bank has reported since August, 1925.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The battle for Dienbienphu and perhaps the fate of Indo-China hung in the balance today, according to reports reaching Washington.

ALBANY, April 21 -- The incidence rate for early syphilis in upstate New York has been reduced from a post-war high of forty-nine in 100,000 in 1946 to 2.2 in 100,000 in 1953, the state health department reported today.

Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey entertained last night the entire Republican-controlled New Jersey State Senate at a reception and dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The Governor, a Democrat, arranged the dinner, reportedly, as part of a program to improve his relationship with the opposition.
PITTSBURGH, April 21 -- A perverse fate continues to dog the Giants in their efforts to put these pestiferous Pirates in their proper place.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, like many a belle of the Thirties, is in the process of losing its teeth. To an increasing extent it is not now performing a complete job under the statutes which it is supposed to administer. I think, if pressed, even the present personnel of the commission would be forced to admit this.

The New York skyline added a new spectacle last night when a battery of searchlights beamed on the 340-foot towers of the George Washington Bridge. The graceful steel structures were illuminated by twenty-four 500-watt lights, fixed to regular lighting standards on the Hudson River span.
Inoculations with the Salk polio vaccine will begin Tuesday in 105 public and parochial schools in three health districts here.

Authorities on blood diseases challenged a report in The New York Times last Monday, in which a blood disease known as polycythemia vera was described as "cancer of the red blood cells" with a life expectancy of three to five years. The report originated from a meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research in Atlantic City.

The struggling ship operating industry received a pleasant and welcome surprise yesterday from the Brotherhood of Marine Engineers, A. F. L., which announced that in view of the unsettled state of the maritime industry it would extend its contract from Sept. 30 until Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -Commissioner Andrews testified yesterday before the Joint Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenditures that 1,149 apartment builders had reaped $65,000,000 in quick profits, largely by getting loans for more than the cost of the buildings they erected. Mr. Cole said more cases may be found.

RETURNING from a tour of five German and two Italian museums, a selection of nineteenth century American painting from public and private collections in this country may be seen for the next month at the Whitney Museum.
PARIS, April 21 -- United States Air Force planes are flying French paratroopers from here to Indo-China.
ITHACA, N. Y., April 21 -- Conflicts between parents and teen-agers arise from the latter's need to experiment with social relations, individual dreams and ambitions and adult responsibilities.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 21 (UP) -- Kenneth H. Redmond, president of United Fruit Company, said today the company expects a moderate increase" in banana production this year to meet a rising demand.

ATHENS, April 21 -- Premier Alexander Papagos announced tonight that Thompson Starrett Co., Inc., an engineering and general contracting firm of New York, had been selected to undertake the Megdova River project in central Greece [cross on map].

DUBLIN, Ireland, April 21 - Ireland's Finance Minister, Sean MacEntee, introduced a budget in the Dail eireann (Parliament) tonight that brought only a few taxation concessions and contained no special bait for the voters in next month's national elections.
The Forty-fifth (Thunderbird) Division, which engaged in 429 days of fighting in Korea, demonstrated again yesterday that its qualities of mercy and charity equaled its battlefield courage.
PARIS, April 21 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles flew here today to begin four days of conferences before the opening of the Geneva conference on Far Eastern problems on Monday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21 -- Turkey complained today that "profit-making mentality" appeared to be the spirit guiding the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -Relief Pitcher Chet Cornog hurled five innings of one-hit shutout ball and had an unassisted double play as the University of Pennsylvania opened its Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League season with a 6-4 victory over Yale at River Field today.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the performance of "By the Beautiful Sea" tonight at the Majestic Theatre for the benefit of the Woman's Hospital Division of St. Luke's Hospital. Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell is chairman and Mrs. Clendenin J. Ryan, co-chairman of the benefit committee, and among their aides is Mrs. George Grant Snowden Jr.
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., increased its consolidated net profit to $5,180,868 in the fiscal year ended last January from $4,777,048 a year earlier, despite a 1.8 per cent drop in sales.

The long-delayed hearings on the bitter quarrel between Senator McCarthy and the United States Army are at last to begin today. It was back in February -- almost exactly two months ago -- that the dispute burst forth into public view with the order of Secretary Stevens to his officers to refuse to appear before Mr. McCarthy's subcommittee.
Cleo F. Craig, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, weathered a storm of questioning yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

WITH reasonable cooperation on the part of the weather man, next week-end should provide plenty of opportunity for both the fresh and salt water anglers, and reports from the North as well as the South indicate that the fishing has improved during the past Week.

ALBANY, April 21 -- The State Department of Mental Hygiene is undertaking a complete reorganization of its services to convalescent patients who have been discharged from mental hospitals in New York City's metropolitan area.

A spirited defense of testimonial advertising, together with a recommendation for a "Federal Testimonial Commission" to pass on all such material, was set forth yesterday by Jules Alberti, president and founder in 1945 of Endorsements, Inc.

M. Jean Monnet's mission to this country has not bee in vain. He came seeking a straight commercial loan to put the Coal and Steel Community on a broader and sounder base, and reports from Washington indicate that he has been successful in his quest.

Defense counsel for Joseph P. Ryan, former president of the old International Longshoremen's Association, who is accused of stealing union funds, indicated yesterday that they would show he used some of the money to hire "strong-arm men" to fight Communist activities along the docks.
California borrowed $50,000,000 in the public market yesterday or loans to local school districts.
CANBERRA, Australia, April 21 -- The Soviet Embassy demanded today that Australia surrender Vladimir Petrov, a refugee diplomat, as a "criminal" forger who had absconded with official funds.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- As a general proposition the quality of mercy in the Senate of the United States is only less strained than that of charity. When the fires of political controversy grow intense, the familiar phenomenon of an election year, the club atmosphere of "the greatest deliberative body on earth" -- which is the Senate's modest self-description -- tends to become acrid.

Rita Leavy and June Strasser sold the five-story apartment house for fifteen families at 216 West 108th Street to a client of Henry Elkind, attorney, in a deal negotiated by L. J. Phillips Co., brokers. The tax valuation is $23,000.
PARIS, April 21 -- European nations must prepare for repercussions of the United States economic recession, a conference on European unity was told today.

Accommodations for 215 families will be provided in a low-price housing development to be opened Saturday in Brentwood, L. I. The dwellings, priced at $5,990, are being built under Title I of the Federal Housing Act and are being offered through the Edelson Realty Company as agent.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 21 -- Milovan Djilas, formerly a member of Yugoslavia's Communist hierarchy, has turned in his membership card in the Communist League.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 -- Three Korean doctors arrived here today to study on fellowships provided by the American-Korean Foundation.

BOWIE, Md., April 21 (UP) - Willie Hartack booted home three winners on the Bowie racing program today including Ada L. Rice's Pet Bully, the 3-to-10 choice, in the featured $4,000 Boojum Purse before a crowd of 11,640.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson, confirmed today the assignment of Air Force transport planes to ferry French Union troops to Indo-China.

The Atlas Corporation, an investment company which deals in "special" situations, has decided to venture into uranium mining. Floyd B. Odlum, president of Atlas, announced yesterday the acquisition, in behalf of interests he represents, of a group of uranium mining claims and options in the Big Indian District of San Juan County, Utah.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- The Soviet Union announced today a 10 per cent cut in the defense budget for 1954. However, it revealed that expenditures and investment in heavy industry, which was described as the "basic foundation of Soviet defense capability" would be increase and extended.

George C. Biggers of The Atlanta (Ga.) Journal and Constitution warned newspaper publishers yesterday not to take television competition lightly. He urged them to strengthen their competitive position by improving their product and offered a program to this end. To combat color television, he stressed color printing.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The threat of a Presidential veto on farm legislation carrying an extension of high, rigid farm price supports was laid before the Senate today.
Manuel Gayol, a guitarist from Puerto Rico, made his first New York appearance last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

All but a handful of New Jersey's 567 communities have voted to legalize small-stakes gambling in the form of bingo and raffles. The approval was overwhelming in local-option elections based on the constitutional amendment of permission endorsed in last November's referendum.

The aluminum industry has been showing strength despite the general business decline of the last year, R. S. Reynolds Jr., president of the Reynolds Metals Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Richmond, Va.

A comic-book publisher, who boasted he was the first in the country to publish "horror comics," told a Senate subcommittee yesterday that he believed no healthy, normal child ever had been "ruined" by a comic book. A child's personality is set before he reaches reading age, the publisher contended.

The city Transit Advisory Commission is prepared to recommend to the Board of Estimate next Thursday a twenty-month extension of the interim fares of 13 cents on eight privately owned bus lines, it was learned yesterday.
Radio station WNYC will begin tomorrow its third annual Shakespeare Festival, in which thirty hours of programming will be devoted to the presentation of plays, lectures and discussions.

Cheerful as a summer garden is the new group of Loomtogs Originals designed to play their way through long summer days in the country. They were shown by Arnold Constable at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Grain futures had a weak tone today, except for May wheat, which advanced on buying credited to a leading cash interest. Soybeans met support on the setbacks, with May again relatively strong. Pressure was largely on the September and new crop futures.
NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, April 22 (UP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that he would not permit United States planes to fly over India bearing French troops to Indo-China.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 21 -- Trailing, 5 -- 3 after seven innings, Adelphi College's baseball team scored three runs in the eighth to beat Iona, 6 -- 5, today. Justin Terzi drove in the winning tally with a single.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., April 21 -- The Ghost class sloop that disappeared from the McMichael boatyard here yesterday morning was still-missing tonight but the proprietors of the yard believed a settlement could be reached.
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield's three-hit pitching and the Washington Senators' thirteen-safety attack trounced the Philadelphia Athletics tonight, 13 -- 1.

Pearl S. Buck has delivered to John Day the manuscript of a work of non-fiction entitled "My Several Worlds: A Personal Record." It recounts the author's experiences and observations in China, Japan, India, the United States and other countries since before the Boxer Rebellion in 1900.

The directors of Michaels Brothers, Inc., seven-store furniture chain in the New York metropolitan area, voted yesterday to accept an offer by the Richmar Furniture Corporation to buy its assets and assume its liabilities. The purchase price is about $2,000,000.
CHICAGO, April 21 -- The "misleading propaganda" of "food faddists and nutrition quacks" was denounced here today by Dr. Charles Glen King, Scientific Director of the Nutrition Foundation, Inc.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board threatened today to strip the independent International Fur and Leather Workers Union of its right to N. L. R. B. services.
BONN, Germany, April 21 -- West German conservatives are moving to accept the de facto authority of the Communist regime of East Germany.
DETROIT, April 21 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. John Q. Schisler, of Nashville, Tenn., said tonight many television programs were "objectionable from the standpoint of moral, ethical and religious content."

Columbia Gas System, Inc., is offering holders of its outstanding common shares the right to subscribe for $50,000,000 of new subordinated debentures convertible into common stock. The debentures bear 3 1/2 per cent interest and will come due in 1964.

The Republicans of New Jersey's Seventh Congressional District did themselves and their party proud on several counts in rejecting by an 8-to-1 vote the effort of former Representative J. Parnell Thomas to capture the nomination in this week's G. O. P. primary.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- A dangerous monopoly, amounting to a virtual academic "cartel," exists in the granting of research funds to colleges and universities by the Federal Government, it was charged here today.

HOUSTON, April 21 (AP) -- Dick Savitt, a Houston oil man who retired from the competitive tennis circuit in 1951, today defeated Sven Davidson of Sweden, 11 -- 9, 8 -- 6, in the fourth round of the twentieth annual River Oaks invitation tournament.

The large delegation of official and civic leaders that went to Washington yesterday to argue for New York's right to build its Columbus Circle Coliseum had, of course, a much broader objective also. Other important projects due for federal help under Title I of the Housing Law are in jeopardy if Congress should persist in the House effort to write in overly precise definitions for use of slum-cleared land.
Mrs. Russell A. Firestone's Summer Tan, a 2-year-old bay colt by Heliopolis, won the forty-second running of the $13,650 Youthful Stakes at the Jamaica track yesterday.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 21 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy charged today, on the eve of the Senate inquiry into his dispute with the Army, that plans were afoot to hamstring his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

A man pushed a button yesterday and a dripping 130-ton tugboat rose slowly from the harbor bottom twenty-five feet below the surface of Brooklyn's Atlantic Basin. That man and nine others were aboard the Merritt-Chapman Scott floating derrick Monarch, one of the largest waterborne hoisting devices in the world.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, April 21 -- Gabriel Teixeira, Governor General of Portuguese Mozambique, sees nothing wrong with a future united Portugal in Europe and Africa in which Negroes would be a majority. He does not believe there is any such thing as Negro nationalism.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- George Meany asked nearly 1,000 American Federation of Labor groups today to work for defeat of House and Senate Labor Committee proposals to overhaul the Taft-Hartley Law.

Paul Graetz, French producer, has arrived in town from Paris with a print of his latest film, "Monsieur Ripois," which recently won a special prize at the Cannes Film Festival. Directed by Rene Clement and starring Gerard Philipe, the offering was filmed in London with a mixed cast of English and French actors.

United States newspapers set new records in advertising revenue last year, but they will have to fight hard in 1954 to keep their position, the nation's publishers were told here yesterday. This year was described as "the first really competitive year" since World War II.

WEST NYACK, N. Y., April 21 -- A 50-year-old proprietor of a small general store, who lived frugally and alone, was found hanged today in his living quarters behind the store. A search of soda water crates and cigar boxes revealed $23,478 in cash and more than $49,000 deposited in a bank.
YONKERS, April 21 (AP) -George Phalen drove Poplar Perry to victory in the fastest trotting time of the meeting at Yonkers Raceway tonight before 20,593.
MILWAUKEE, April 21 (UP) -Eddie Mathews hit a three-run homer into the center field bull-pen tonight to lead the Milwaukee Braves to a 7-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

LONDON, April 21 -- The president of one of Britain's most powerful unions attempted today to minimize the crisis in the Labor party caused by the resignation of Aneurin Bevan from the party's shadow cabinet.

Dr. Irving M. Peress, the dentist whose honorable discharge as a major provoked the controversy between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army, spoke publicly in his own defense for the first time last night.
About 300 bargain hunters were on hand yesterday as the Customs Service put up for auction the first half of offerings in one of its periodic sales of seized, unclaimed and abandoned merchandise.

The American Theatre Wing, whose principal function since 1946 has been to help groom potentially gifted neophytes for the Broadway stage through its training school, will produce a revue called "On the Wing."

Twenty-one daily newspapers won prizes and thirty-three won certificates of merit yesterday in the thirteenth annual safe driving contest for newspaper delivery trucks. Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, made the announcement at a session of its convention.

The New York Shipping Association, which represents 170 steamship lines and employing stevedores in this port, yesterday criticized Lawrence E. Walsh, Waterfront Commission executive director and counsel, for his assertion that there was no immediate prospect of peace on New York's waterfront.

Uncle Sam has collected more than $107,872,511 from 5,806 business concerns in the last two years, or so -- and not in income taxes. It went to Washington as a result of defense contract adjustments by the Renegotiation Board.

The aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange jumped 106,808 shares between March 15 and April 15 and touched the highest figure recorded since April 6, 1932. The most recent Exchange report revealed that traders had borrowed and sold 2,899,265 shares of stock in the hope of being able to replace it at a lower price on some future date.

Events today: Searle Wright, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; "The Tender Land" and "Amahl and the Night Visitors," City Center, 8:15 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducing; Lelia Gousseau, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 21 -- The Government of Dr. Mohammed Fadhil al-Jamali has tendered its resignation to King Feisal, it was reported today. Official announcement of a Government resignation is not made here until the resignation is accepted and negotiations are completed for a new Cabinet.
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
BEVERLY, Mass., April 21 (AP) -- Political party barriers evaporate when a lost dog is involved.

TURIN, Italy, April 21 -- A preview of automobile engine and body styles for the coming year was afforded by the International Automobile Salon in this city. It was the thirty-sixth such exhibition held in Turin since the first one in 1899 and was inaugurated by President Luigi Einaudi in the presence of United States Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce and representatives of several other nations.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Following are the issues in the Senate investigation of the McCarthy-Army dispute.

BALTIMORE, April 21 (AP) -- A no-hitter and the ball game blew up in Bob Turley's face with only two outs to go tonight when Larry Doby hit a homer behind Al Rosen's single for a 2-1 Cleveland Indian victory over the Baltimore Orioles before 43,383 fans.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (UP) Bobby Jones of Oakland, Calif., proved himself master of Gil Turner tonight when he scored a technical knockout over the sixth-ranking Philadelphia middleweight in 1:12 of the tenth and final round of their rematch at the Arena.
The Police Department is considering the elimination of two precincts in Manhattan and one in Brooklyn, it was learned last night.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 21 (AP) -- The Keeneland race course will get down to the serious business of sorting its Kentucky Derby horses tomorrow, when fourteen 3-year-olds tangle in the $25,000-added Blue Grass Stakes.
A need to mobilize "citizen-educator" resources to provide adequate educational facilities was emphasized yesterday by Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, United States Commissioner of Education.

HENDERSONVILLE N. C., April 21 (UP) -- Julius Boros of Mid-Pines, N. C., kept his one-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the Carolinas open golf tournament today. He and the two pros who are tied for second place at 136 carded three-under-par 68's.

The sixteen-family apartment building at 63 Washington Place in Teaneck, N. J., has been purchased by John H. Wendes from the New Jersey Realty Company. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker in the transaction. The building contains suites of two, three and four rooms.

The board of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies elected Dorothy Shaver and Donald B. Tansill directors yesterday at its annual meeting in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway. Miss Shaver is president of Lord Taylor. Mr. Tansill is president of M. Lowenstein Son, textiles.

Strength for aircrafts and electrical equipments in yesterday's stock market was not sufficient to offset the heaviness in motors, distillers, chemicals, radio-televisions, metals, rails and some oils.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 22 -- Japan's left and right-wing Socialist parties announced their intention to present to Parliament today a joint resolution of nonconfidence against the Cabinet of Premier Shigeru Yoshida.

Members and friends of the National Child Labor Committee celebrated its fiftieth anniversary yesterday at a luncheon at the Commodore Hotel. Owen R. Lovejoy, one of the board of trustees, declared that the first half century of its fight against child labor evils had been difficult, but that the next fifty years would be even harder.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company of San Francisco today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to market $65,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds. The securities, which are to be offered for public sale at competitive bidding, will fall due June 1, 1984.
SHARON, Conn., April 21 (AP) -Christopher Lawrence, 45 years old, former New York State legislator who was found pinned under the front wheel of his car yesterday, died today in Sharon Hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, struck back today at critics of housing scandals investigations that have been started by Congress and the Eisenhower Administration.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 22 (AP) -- Communist China yesterday attacked United States policy on Indo-China and declared "we certainly will not take it lying down" if "armed aggression is directed against us."

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 806,000 barrels last week, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend the gasoline supply was estimated at 178,923,000 barrels, compared with 179,729,000 a week earlier and 156,663,000 a year ago.

Henry Rose Stores, Inc., subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck Co. which handles all buying, distribution and merchandising of women's fashion apparel, accessories and girls' wear for the company, announced yesterday that Lucien E. Oliver, president, will assume the additional office of board chairman.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The National Association of Manufacturers advised Congress today that it was willing to go along with a one-year extension of present corporation tax rates.

THIS is one instance in which the author is more fascinating than his book. George (Specs) Toporcer has just written a detailed, instructional primer for youngsters, especially those of Little League age. He's titled it, "Baseball, From Backyard to Big League." The emotional impact of this book is inadvertently supplied by the author himself. Specs Toporcer is blind.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, was re-elected last night as chief spokesman for the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this city.
State Controller J. Raymond McGovern accused New York City officials yesterday of being "something less than straightforward" with city finances.

It had been a long time between pitches for Leo Kiely. When last seen against major-league competition, the Red Sox southpaw lost a 4-0 decision to the Yankees' Ed Lopat on Sept. 29, 1951. After two years in the service, the left hander returned to the Bosox and yesterday at the Stadium, in his initial outing, Kiely lost again to Lopat, 5 -- 1, before 26,356 fans.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 -- Confetti and ticker tape showered down in the financial district today on 10,000 persons attending a memorial service for a pile driver.

An alarmingly large number of our fellow citizens are viewing life as a game of cops and robbers, with one side always right and the other always wrong. Most of their information and viewpoints come from newspapers and radio commentators. The question consequently arises: What are the social responsibilities of news agencies, commentators, editors and publishers in this H-bomb age ?

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution approved today a resolution opposing adoption of the United Nations Covenant on Human Rights on the ground that it would restrict freedom of religion and speech.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 21 -- The Soviet Union attended its first conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization here today.

The continuing importance of various metals used decoratively on furniture was emphasized in four collections introduced this week. Two of the groups, one trimmed with pewter, the other with silver, are at Bloomingdale's.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, said today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charges against H. Struve Hensel were not "privileged" at this time and so Mr. Hensel could sue now if he so desired.

The opossum world can well be proud this morning because a plucky member of the fraternity who must have been thoroughly disgusted with "playing possum" staged a glorious battle with nine alley cats in Washington Heights early yesterday.
In the wake of overwhelming approval of bingo and raffles by the New Jersey electorate in local option balloting Tuesday, 300 organizations sought licenses yesterday to conduct such games of chance.

The annual card party and tea under the auspices of the Woman's Auxiliary Day Branch of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church will be held this afternoon in the Community House of the church at 109 East Fiftieth Street. Mrs. Bedell H. Harned heads the benefit committee.

ST. LOUIS, April 21 -- No significant substitution of aluminum for zinc die castings has occurred despite mistaken talk to that effect, David Laine, secretary of the American Die Casting Institute, reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The American people saved a near-record $13,600,000 000 last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senate investigators promised tonight a full, fair and fearless investigation, opening tomorrow morning, as to who was lying in the controversy between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.

Manager Walter Alston shuffled the Dodger's line-up, revised the batting order and gave Billy Leos his first 1954 start last night. Only the last of these moves had much direct bearing on the 6-3 victory the Brooks scored over the Phillies before 27,724 spectators, the largest crowd of the young season at Ebbets Field.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Army read into the record of Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson's court-martial today a statement by him that he had cooperated with the Communists "in appreciation'' for being released from jail at a prisoner-of-war camp in Korea.

On the eve of its 1954 drive, the Greater New York Fund issued yesterday its annual report for 1953, when gifts were increased by 3.7 per cent over the preceding year. While this was a "most successful campaign," the fund must raise its sights still higher this year, according to David A. Shepard of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), who released the report at his office in 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 21 (UP) -- Sam Snead has been installed the 3-to-1 favorite in the second annual tournament of champions opening tomorrow.
CINCINNATI, April 21 (AP) -Gerry Staley tonight became the first St. Louis Cardinal pitcher to hurl a complete game this season as he posted a 4-2 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs.
MOSCOW, Thursday, April 22 -- The composition of the Soviet delegation to Geneva, headed by Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, was announced here early today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -Fordham University's baseball team scored four runs in the fifth inning and four more in the eighth to beat Georgetown, 9 -- 4, today for its fifth victory of the season. Fordham was held to four hits, but received ten walks from Georgetown's Jack Vail.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., April 21 (AP) -- The Jamestown Sun, one of six daily newspapers published by the International Typographical Union, A. F. L., said in today's edition that the five others would discontinue publication Friday.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 21 (UP) -- Mention of "the failure of a majority of the members to vote defense assessments" was a reference to two referendums in which members voted to retain a limit on the officers' power to use union funds for its defense program, which includes the newspaper publications.
SINGAPORE, April 21 -- The how and why of Dienbienphu is confusing to many. Why did Gen. Henri-Eugene Navarre, French Commander in Chief, choose such a spot to make a fateful stand?

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -Harold Christoffel, twice convicted of falsely testifying before a Congressional committee that he never had been a Communist, now is serving a sixteen-month to four-year prison term.
Elder stateswomen, 14 to 17 years old, of the Girl Scouts of Greater New York raised their voices yesterday to approve the suggestion that more of their activities be made co-educational.

Warm spring temperatures continued to cheer the city yesterday, although they weren't high enough to set any records. The high was 74.2 degrees at 1:05 P. M., well short of the record of 83.4 set in 1923.
LONDON, April 21 -- Buying expanded and prices improved in the securities markets here today. Only mining shares -- South African gold, Malayan tin and Rhodesian copper -- weakened.
LOS ANGELES, April 21 -- The directors of the Douglas Aircraft Company voted today to issue on May 26 an additional share of stock for each share outstanding next May 5.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- President Eisenhower is sending Gen. James A. Van Fleet to the Far East next month on a military survey mission.

A policeman's identification of William Howell as driver of the automobile in which the murderer of Thomas E. Lewis sought to escape went unchallenged yesterday.
