Howell is on trial in Bronx County Court accused of first-degree murder in connection with the slaying of the union leader by Edward (Snakes) Ryan last Aug. 28.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 21 (AP) -- Vietminh besiegers squeezed Dienbienphu's French Union defenders into a shrinking circle of about one and a quarter miles in diameter today. The rebels kept digging ever closer to the barricades in a downpour of rain.
OTTAWA, April 21 -- Diplomats here believe the Canadian delegation to the Geneva conference may play the role of mediator between the United States and its European allies.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Communications Commission called today for a hearing on the application of radio station WNYC, New' York, to operate additional hours on its frequency of 830 kilocycles.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. announced yesterday that the city was going to be inspected for fire hazards to an extent never known here before.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -- Pearl Bailey will play the role of Frankie in "Carmen Jones," to be directed and produced by Otto Preminger with an all-Negro cast.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 14:
The Public Service Commission announced yesterday a new plan for improvement of grade-crossings safeguards on the Long Island Rail Road.

The Terminal Commerce Building and the Spring Garden Street Warehouse in Philadelphia have been sold by the Reading Railroad to Webb Knapp, Inc., of New York. Mortgage financing was provided by the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company and title was insured by the Land Title Insurance Company of Philadelphia.
The head of the Santa Fe railroad declared yesterday that setting up union membership as a condition of employment made unions likely targets "for progressively stricter Government regulation."

For forty thunderous days and nights the valiant garrison of Dienbienphu has lived a saga of heroism and endurance that has stirred the admiration of the free world. Outnumbered, surrounded and far from its nearest base, it has beaten back all the massive "human wave" attacks of a Communist enemy four times as strong.

LONDON, April 21 -- Partition of Indo-China is being discussed in Government circles as a means of settling the war in that country and checking the southward thrust of Communist China. Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, who flies to Paris tomorrow for final talks on coordination of British, United States and French policy for the Geneva conference, will be ready to present a case for partition should the subject arise.

Frederick H. Ecker, honorary chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, testified yesterday to "the soundness" of the Twenty-third Street area. He spoke at the twenty-fifth anniversary luncheon of the Twenty-third Street Association at the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 21 (AP) -- The new Patrick B. McGinnis management ran into a legal challenge of its control of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad today, almost simultaneously with his election as president.

A truck driver who lost his job as a result of the recent dock strike made a two-gun attack on two union leaders yesterday. The intended victims knocked down and disarmed the driver after the one shot he managed to fire went wild.

Given a stable labor situation, no port in the United States can ever touch New York. This was asserted last night by John L. Eyre, chief of the marine development division of the Port of New York Authority.

Roy T. Hurley, president of Curtiss-Wright Corporation charged in effect yesterday that the Air Materiel Command at Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, was seeking to deprive the aircraft industry of the benefits of the expiration of the excess profits tax.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 21 - President Eisenhower appointed Meyer Kestnbaum today to be chairman of the Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said tonight that "the mounting retaliatory capability of our air units gives full warning to any aggressor of the possible consequences of rash actions on his part."
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 15 -- Netherlands officials are evolving a radical plan for anti-depression legislation.
The drive of city departments to save water went into high gear yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption in the March period averaged 33,802 bales for each working day.

Halibut, the giant member of the flounder family, is coming in good supply from Nova Scotia. Always popular with New Yorkers, who consume 6,500,000 pounds of it annually, the fish is a particularly attractive offering now.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The American Veterans Committee today announced establishment of a defense fund for Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- There is growing and impressive evidence here that the Soviet Union is having serious trouble within the ranks of its secret police.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 21 (AP) -- The University of Rochester today announced the twenty-five high school seniors chosen as finalist in a nation-wide competition for three Bausch Lomb Science Scholarships valued at $3,200 each.
Two new instruments that give a pilot landing in bad weather accurate visibility and ceiling reports at his point of touch-down were commissioned yesterday at Newark Airport.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The State Department's Public Committee on Personnel will recommend in its report due May 1 that most upper level posts in the department be integrated with the Foreign Service.

There is a world of difference between the men who are elected by the people for the purpose of representing them and making laws and defining policies to execute these laws, and the men who serve the nation through direct appointment by the best use of their specific talents.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, chief Soviet delegate, has booked passage for home. Some Communist diplomats have spread the word that he would prefer not to return to his United Nations post.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- There were strong indications today that the obstacles blocking the New York Coliseum were being cleared.
NEWARK, April 21 -- The present upsurge in juvenile delinquency was attributed to "individual emotional instability and social unrest" in an address tonight by Dr. Martha M. Eliot.

Two Rumanian youths, recently released from their Communist homeland after the intervention of President Eisenhower, made a pilgrimage last night to Ebbets Field to learn about baseball and American customs.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 21 -- In balloting today for electors of the members of the Upper Chamber of Parliament, the Catholic People's party emerged as the nation's largest political party. The Communists lost 15 per cent of their following.

Harry Grossman, a member of the law firm of Grossman Grossman, was appointed a special referee yesterday to preside at pre-trial hearings in a suit brought by Robert R. Young against directors of the New York Central Railroad.
Northern Pacific Railway borrowed $4,575,000 in the public market yesterday to help finance the purchase of passenger and refrigerator cars and diesel locomotives.

HENDERSONVILLE, N. C., April 22 (UP) -- Dow Finsterwald of Pope Air Force Base, N. C., survived a triple bogie today to win the Carolinas open golf tournament in a see-saw fight with Julius Boros of Mid- Pines, N. C., through the final nine holes.

CHEKHOV'S "Don Juan in the Russian Manner" has never been played in this country before. At any rate, the Wigs and Cues staff at Barnard thinks so. The current performances tonight and tomorrow at the Minor Latham Drama Workshop, Broadway at 119th Street, have considerable interest for lovers of Chekhov and the foolish era in Russian society that he chronicled.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Special Government attention will be given to the problem of the older worker in industry, James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said today.
MIAMI, April 22 (AP) -- Gulfstream Park concluded Florida's longest horse racing season -- 177 days -- before 14,922 fans who wagered $1,008,982 today.
William White, president of the New York Central Railroad, announced yesterday that he is willing to be examined by attorneys of Robert R. Young "any day that they want, starting next week."

The Yankees yesterday sent Hal Smith, a catcher, to the Columbus club of the American Association on option. Smith's assignment completes the deal with the St. Louis Cardinals that brought Enos (Country) Slaughter to the world champions.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Post Office Department announced today that it had moved to speed mail delivery service in New York City.
PARIS, April 22 -- The Western Big Three are baffled and worried by their inability so far to agree on procedure for the Geneva conference in the face of a rapidly deteriorating situation.

A colorful fiesta atmosphere pervaded the first and second floors of the Lentherie Salon, 673 Fifth Avenue, yesterday, for the presentation of a group of native Mexican Indian costumes by the Mexican Government Tourist Bureau.

The announcement of the disbanding of the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra is at once shocking and deeply saddening. For though it had been widely forecast as the almost certain consequence of Toscanini's retirement nothing seems to have been done to head off N. B. C.'s decision, and the question that arises is what may still be done to save this great orchestra.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Arthur H. Dean, United States negotiator at the Korean peace talks at Panmunjom, left for South Korea today to give President Syngman Rhee the United States view of the forthcoming Geneva Far Eastern conference.

Net income of the Shell Oil Company and its wholly-owned subsidiaries increased in the 1954 first quarter to $33,197,154 from $25,532,640 earned in the period last year, H. S. M. Burns, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

Granville Stuart's "Montana As It Is," a rare work of the resources of the territory and its Indian inhabitants, published in 1865, was auctioned yesterday for $2,200 in the last session of the three-day sale of Western Americana belonging to W. J. Holliday, Indianapolis steel producer.

Four miles north of Times Square, in the same latitude with the Polo Grounds and Yankee Stadium, there stands a kind of citadel to learning, comprising the headquarters for five of the country's most distinguished learned societies and museums.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday numbered 612,884 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 22 (UP) -- Lloyd Mangrum and Ted Kroll battled the excessive heat and the long Desert Inn Country Club course with equal success and tied for the first-day lead in the $35,000 Tournament of Champions today with four-under-par 68's.

DETROIT, April 22 (AP) -- The last barrier to the merger was cleared today when Nash-Kelvinator directors declined to use an option to withdraw from the deal if holders of more than 40,000 Hudson shares demanded cash for their holdings. Mr. Mason said holders of about 140,000 shares, or 7 per cent of the total number of Hudson shares, had file requests for payment.
ROME, April 22 -- The Vatican condemned today Roman Catholics who pushed their left-wing opinions to the point of believing it was possible for Catholics to collaborate with communism.

John D. Rockefeller 3d, chairman of the board of the Rockefeller Foundation, said last night that philanthropy was an important factor in the American way of life, and the giver, large and small, made a fundamental contribution to democracy.

The Federal Trade Commission received the general approval of the man-made fabric producing industry yesterday on proposed rules and regulations under the Flammable Fabrics Act. It also received a brief from the clothing trade asking that it be exempted from record keeping in connection with the rules.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- Expansion of the United States Foreign Service personnel from 1,300 to 6,000 will be among the recommendations in the report being prepared by a special study committee.
NAPLES, Italy, April 22 (AP) -- Dr. Bernard Peters, cosmic ray scientist whose name has figured in the Oppenheimer case in the United States, said today he was not a Communist.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22 (AP) -- Clarence Mendell, Yale Athletic director, said today that Yale had once again refused to join the National Collegiate Athletic Association television program, pending a test of the legality of the policy.
CHICAGO, April 22 -- The National Catholic Educational Association voted today opposition to "conformity" or standardized thinking.

The existence of two separate sets of cases involving security risks at Fort Monmouth, N. J., appeared to cause confusion yesterday among members of the Senate Committee considering Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's dispute with top Army officials.

The following dispatch was written by William L. Ryan, an Associated Press correspondent, who recently visited Indo-China. SINGAPORE, April 22 -- Ho Chi Minh has no real following in Vietnam, said a Vietnamese leader.

Maggie Teyte, soprano, charmed a large audience at her Town Hall recital last night by announcing, as an unprogrammed opening number, "Absence," by Berlioz. She said it would be sung "in memory of my first appearance on 'The Telephone Hour.'"

NORTH CALDWELL, N. J., April 22 -- For the third year in a row, the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its season with a Class A and B one- day tournament over the Green Brook course today. Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair repeated her victory of last season by winning low gross in Class A.
CHICAGO, April 22 -- Harlow H. Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, reiterated today that no depression was "in my vision."

AMMAN, Jordan, April 22 -Foreign Minister Hussein Khalidi anounced today Britain had given "satisfactory" assurances she would "rush all available troops and arms to Jordan" in compliance with the 1948 BritishJordanian treaty if this country became involved in war.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., April 22 -- The state rested today in the trial of Walter G. Winne, superseded Prosecutor of Bergen County, and Superior Court Judge John J. Francis rejected a defense motion for a blanket dismissal of the sixteen charges of failing to suppress gambling under which Mr. Winne is being tried.
BONN, Germany, April 22 -- Another Soviet secret police agent has asked for refuge in the West.
New Yorkers took the opening day of the televised Army-McCarthy controversy pretty much in their stride.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- Farmers took in $6,600,000,000 from marketings in the first quarter, down 3 per cent from the first three months of 1953, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Secretary of the Army testified under oath today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had falsified in his charges against Army officials and about his efforts to get preferential treatment for Pvt. G. David Schine.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 22 -- Achille van Acker, a Socialist and a former Premier, announced tonight that he had formed a coalition Cabinet. It consists of himself as Premier, eight other Socialists and seven Liberals.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Consumers Price Index for the United States dropped 0.2 per cent between Feb. 15 and March 15, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said today.

A new cheese that has been test marketed during the last year in the Midwest made its first trip East this week. Said to be the first new cheese in 500 years, it was developed in two midwestern universities.
PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- The New York Herald Tribune today won a second leg on the third F. Wayland Ayer Cup for excellence in typography, makeup and printing.

HOUSTON, April 22 (AP) -- Dick Savitt, the 1951 Wimbledon and Australian champion, staged another upset today by taking a straight-set quarter-final victory from Gardnar Mulloy, the defending champion, in the twentieth annual River Oaks tennis tournament.
The Wagner administration, besieged by opposition, was about ready last night to abandon the highly controversial proposed 3 per cent retail sales tax on commercial services.
Record sales of $478,849,294 were achieved by Federated Department Stores, Inc., in the fiscal year ended last Jan. 31 and earnings improved to $13,888,484 from $13,543,979, the year before.

LONDON, April 22 -- Britain must wait until the Geneva conference ends before considering employment in Indo-China of the Royal Air Force or British Army forces now in Malaya, Field Marshal Earl Alexander, Minister of Defense, declared today.

HOZEN SEKI, the Buddhist priest who dedicated the Japanese house in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art in West Fifty-fourth Street yesterday [story on Page 20] founded the Ne Yu Yoku Buddhist Church here sixteen years ago.

THE Actors and Writers Theatre, a group of thespians operating in the basement gymnasium-auditorium of St. Clements Church, 423 West Forty-sixth Street, presented "Tin Waltz," a new play by Nat Harris, last Wednesday night.
Longer ships with higher power and great speed are creating new problems for the designers of dry-cargo vessels, it was disclosed yesterday in the annual report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP) -- The president of the Budd Company announced yesterday that earnings for the first quarter of 1954 had dropped more than 50 per cent from the comparable 1953 period but said "it is our belief that 1954 will be a moderately good year."
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield urged Congress today to act now on the Administration's bill for higher postal rates, but his plea went unheeded.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- A top Pentagon official said today that the Defense Department might ask Congress soon for a drastic revision of present draft and reserve training laws.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Hogs recorded gains ranging to 25 cents today, one load of choice light weights reaching a top of $28.75. That was the highest price for hogs since $29 was paid Sept. 29, 1948, and the best price ever reached in April.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Eisenhower gave the Daughters of the American Revolution today what he called "a rough chart of the way we will win the cold war and prevent a hot war."

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 22 (UP) -- Wes Santee, Kansas' star miler, will lead speedy Jayhawk teams into at least four relay events at the Forty-fifth Drake Relays tomorrow and Saturday and Kansas could crack records in all of them.
H. L. Hunt, the Texas oil man whose Facts Forum organization has five programs on radio and television, is planning still another.

CHARLES II liked his mistresses to be pretty and his friends to be witty. His two wittiest friends were George Villiers, second Duke of Buckingham, and John Wilmot, second Earl of Rochester. A biography of Buckingham, "A Rake and His Times,"* by John Harold Wilson, was published the day before yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- Robert Mitchum's first picture after the expiration of his R. K. O. contract in August will be Stanley Kramer's production of "Not As a Stranger."
ALBANY, April 22 -- The State University of New York should take the lead in expanding opportunities for public service training, Frank C. Moore, its acting chairman, said here today.
The United States Air Force Academy, which recently was authorized, will strive to "acquaint American airmen with the best thinking of the world," Brig. Gen. Don Z. Zimmerman said yesterday.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address last night before the American Newspaper Publishers Association, as recorded by The New York Times:
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 22 -- Marshal Tito said today Yugoslavia eventually might join the European Defense Community.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The three top Republican leaders of the Senate denounced Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today amid threats to halt or reduce United States economic aid to India. They rose in protest against Mr. Nehru's action in forbidding United States planes to cross India with French troops and supplies to help the defense of French Indo-China.
A 2.5 per cent reduction in prices of original equipment tires for farm machines and automobiles has been placed in effect by the nation's rubber companies.
Two young purse-snatchers had the honor to be captured early yesterday, after a half-mile chase on foot through the shadows of Central Park, by a prince of the blood.

Tasteful and practical decorating devices are displayed in two model homes in Winchester Park, Huntington, L. I. The houses, located on Elwood Avenue, just north of Jericho Turnpike, are open for public inspection on Saturdays.

The Chilean Line (Compania Sud Amaricana de Vapores) is going ahead with plans to construct a large housing project at Valparaiso for the officers and seamen of its seven-vessel fleet of dry cargo and bulk cargo vessels.
The term "athlete's heart," which is used loosely to describe certain heart conditions that athletes, supposedly develop, was debunked yesterday by a group of experts.

NEW ORLEANS, April 22 -- The nation's great cotton-textile industry was warned today that it must find a way to level out the destructive "boom and bust" cycle if it was to realize its full potential.
A 1,150-pound steer, on its way to the slaughter house, took a look at New York yesterday and got a sudden hankering to return to the wide open spaces.

After winning the fifteenth game to take an 8-7 lead in the world chess championship match in Moscow, Mikhail Botvinnik, the titleholder, went on to play the white pieces against Vassily Smyslov's King's Indian defense in the sixteenth game and wound up with an advantage after forty-one moves, according to British news sources.

OKINAWA, April 22 (AP) -- Okinawa turned out last night in its best bib and tucker for the "home-coming" of the Broadway hit play, "The Teahouse of the August Moon," written about this Pacific island base. The show was acted by an amateur -- but authentic -- cast that was brisk, bright, and competent.

Jed Black of Janesville, Wis., with a record of twenty-six victories, one defeat and one draw in nineteen months of professional fighting, will make his New York debut against Joey Klein of Hollis, Queens, at the St. Nicholas Arena tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- Mrs. Rowena Rommell, a United States citizen employed by a United Nations agency, has been allowed to return to her position in Paris after being recalled for questioning.

ALBANY, April 22 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the New York City Charter permitted the discharge of public school and college teachers who refuse to answer questions regarding Communist party membership before a Congressional investigating committee.

The hearings in the case involving Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the United States Army have now begun in an atmosphere quite different from that which usually prevails when Mr. McCarthy is on the giving instead of on the receiving end.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association agreed yesterday to let the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice inspect its files from 1941 to the present.
Many parties were given at the dinner dance in behalf of the Kips Bay Boys Club held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The occasion marked the beneficiary's fortieth year of service.

A new year-long program of advanced studies for promising young religious leaders has been announced by the Union Theological Seminary. The project has been made possible by a Rockefeller Foundation grant of $525,000, which will support the plan for the first five years.
LONDON, April 22 -- The boom on the Stock Exchange has continued today, although a late reaction reduced new gains.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP) -- Five college championships will be decided on tomorrow's opening program of the sixtieth annual Penn Relay Carnival on Franklin Field -- the 400-meter hurdles, two-mile run, distance medley, discus and heptagonal mile.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- In his opening shot today, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy declared that the hearing by the Senate subcommittee that he normally heads was not "a combat between me and the Army."

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Defaults on Government-insured mortgages have forced the Federal Housing Administration to take over 273 apartment house projects at a cost of $119,339,991, according to official data. In another development in the housing scandals, Arthur H. Frentz was dismissed today as Assistant F. H. A. Commissioner in charge of home improvement loan insurance.
Press, A. Levinson's 5-year-old roan son of First Fiddle, won the featured mile - and - a - sixteenth sixth race at the Jamaica track yesterday.

GREAT NECK, L. I., April 22 -- Eight hundred junior high school students experienced at an assembly today what the president of the Board of Education here described as "our finest hour." A plaster bust of Abraham Lincoln was presented to the school by Jozef Reznak, a Slovak refugee, in appreciation of the Americanization and citizenship lessons he had learned in the school's adult education classes.

When people think a slump may be on the way, they tend to save more and spend less. And it's the "recession talk" widespread in March that gets most of the credit for the record volume of new savings deposited in New York State's 237 savings and loan associations last month.

HANOI, Vietnam, Friday, April 23 ((AP)) -- The Vietminh rebels renewed their attack on the battered northwestern defenses of Dienbienphu today. The French High Command announced "heavy fighting" was under way in that corner of the fortress plain.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Army's case against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy went off today according to plan, but the Senator switched tactics at the last minute.
YONKERS, April 22 (AP) -- Dandy Dick, a 22-1 shot defeated seven top-notch pacers tonight at Yonkers Raceway in winning the $5,000 Larchmont Pace before 20,740 spectators.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- The Soviet Union this year will make the largest investment in its history in heavy capital industries. These include iron, steel and light metals, power, coal, oil, chemicals and machine tools.

While the exotic strains of a koto, a flue, a sho shichiriki and two drums playing Bugaku (Buddhist music) drowned out the traffic noises of Fifty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon, a house was crowned.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A remark by Ray H. Jenkins, special counsel for the Senate subcommittee investigating the McCarthy-Army dispute, that Gen. Walter Bedell Smith might be leaving the country "tomorrow" caught the State Department by surprise.

Custom service is the feature of a new furniture gallery on the seventh floor of John Wanamaker's. A collection of Hampton Shops sectional pieces, sofas, love seats, arm chairs and ottomans on view there demonstrates several of the many variations possible.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The railroad industry registered a strong protest with Congress today over the prospective cancellation of corporation tax reductions that took effect April 1.

PARIS, April 22 (Reuters) -- Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries, defender of Dienbienphu, said in a message published here today that he would rather have his recent promotion canceled than leave any doubt about the circumstances in which it was announced.

Three divisions of newspaper advertising showed gains in March over 1954, but the total was off, according to a summary of linage for the month and the year to date in fifty-two cities, released yesterday by Media Records.

President Eisenhower warned last night that if this is not to be an age of atomic hysteria and horror it must be made an age of international understanding and cooperative peace. And if the nations do not build a cooperative peace, he added, they will be forced one by one to accept an imposed peace, "now sought by the Communist powers as it was by Hitler."

The music that made the program of the concert by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall was all of the so-called "romantic" persuasion of the late nineteenth century. None of it was monumental, or heaven-storming.

The case of Robert Oppenheimer exposes in a dramatic way the weakness of the procedures which the Eisenhower Administration has adopted to eliminate subversives from the Government service. Those procedures were prescribed in a series of Executive Orders signed by the President more than a year ago.

NEW ORLEANS, April 22 (AP) -- Frank M. Porter, president of the American Petroleum Institute, said today the nation's oil industry planned to spend a record $4,619,000,000 for expansion and development this year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- Smoke-rings wreathing above the heads of delegates in the Economic and Social Council meeting today signaled victory for the insurgents in their battle against a ban on cigars, pipes and cigarettes.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Following is the official transcript of testimony today before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations considering the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. The hearing began at 10:35 A.M.:

Two thugs who took $200 from the owner of a Manhattan hosiery store last night locked their victim in the basement, set fire to the shop, then locked the front door and ran away. The proprietor, suffering from nervous shock and smoke poisoning, was found by firemen later and sent to St. Clare's Hospital.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22 (AP) -- New Haven Railroad supervisory employes must either know or learn the financial facts of railroading, the road's new president, Patrick B. McGinnins, said today.

The cotton futures market opened steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, 1 to 8 points up. It worked up to gains of 3 to 15 points, but became somewhat irregular toward the close, when it was 13 points higher to 5 points lower than on Wednesday.

For the third successive day the stock market turned in an uncertain performance yesterday. A few outstanding issues dashed ahead, most of the rest marked time or moved to the rear. Aircrafts were strong and there were good gains for some of the steels, oils, motors and electric equipments. But rails, tobaccos and chemicals failed to respond.

Directors of the General Electric Company yesterday elected as vice presidents William V. O'Brien, George E. Burens and Harold E. Strang, according to the announcement of Ralph J. Cordiner, president.

LONDON, April 22 -- The Leader of Britain's left-wing Laborites, mustering more support than for some time past, gave Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden a sharp warning today not to follow a line too close to the United States at the Geneva conference.
Bevo Francis, high-scoring Rio Grande College star, will not be eligible to play in the National Basketball Association until 1956.

In the new Soviet budget military appropriations are announced as being reduced; appropriations for civilian investment, health and education are said to be increased. What could be better proof of Moscow's desire for peace, the Communist propagandist asks blandly.

Standard Brands, Inc. and its United States and Canadian subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $3,260,364 in the first quarter of 1954. This compared with $2,777,500 earned in the initial three months last year, Joel S. Mitchell, president, noted in his report yesterday.
ALBANY, April 22 (AP) -- An ardent baseball fan who also happens to be New York's Governor gave the minor leagues a boost today.

Arthur C. Ford, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said yesterday that the city would not resort to artificial rainmaking this year, regardless of the severity of the water shortage. In the absence of natural rain, he said, the only solution lies in conservation.

NORWALK, Conn., April 22 -- Thomas B. Wall, president of the Norwalk Hat Company, announced today that the plant had been closed indefinitely. The concern, which manufactured an inexpensive line of hat bodies, placed its production staff on short time several months ago.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday that the city's pending borrowing on bonds -- the first in nine years -- would total $79,200,000, up $29,200,000 from the figure set in February.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 22 -- President Eisenhower nominated Lawrence Quincy Mumford today to be Librarian of Congress.

MEXICO CITY, April 22 -- The Mexican Government started emergency distribution of essential foodstuffs in the poorest quarters of the capital today. It said the campaign was being undertaken in an effort to hold down prices, which have begun to soar since the peso was devalued last week-end.
HEAVEN help the television viewer! If the hearing into the McCarthy-Army controversy runs the expected two weeks or more, the routine of many American households is going to be tied up in knots.
DETROIT, April 22 (UP) -- Directors of Hudson Motor Car Company and Nash-Kelvinator Corporation today approved the merger of the two companies into American Motors Corporation.
BOSTON, April 22 -- A court today denied a petition by Textron, Inc., to compel American Woolen Company officials to change the method of counting proxies for the annual stockholders' meeting.
CHICAGO, April 22 -- Long liquidation was the outstanding feature in grain futures today, with heavy pressure on new crop wheat and on rye, the latter selling at the lowest price in several years.

America was divided on the Korean war, the defense of one state against another. If we sent troops into Indo-China we would be intervening in a colonial war against an independence movement, a step which would be regarded by many Americans with an uneasy conscience.

PARIS, April 22 -- On the basis of reports on the capabilities of the hydrogen bomb, United States military leaders are preparing to recommend recasting of the size and organization of the North Atlantic Treaty ground forces.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- During the week ended April 21, member bank reserves increased $273,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Five new patterns and three shapes are offered in the new Modern American ime of dinnerware by Franciscan. They are on display in a group of coordinated table settings at B. Altman's.
TOKYO, April 22 (AP) -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Diet (Parliament) today that he would resign if the people no longer trusted his Cabinet.

CANBERRA, Australia, Friday, April 23 (Reuters) -- Australia today turned down the Soviet Union's demand that Vladimir Petrov, Soviet Embassy secret police chief granted asylum here, should be returned to the embassy as a "criminal."

GUATEMALA, April 22 -- The Government by decree took over today the operation of San Jose, Pacific port that was closed yesterday morning when Agencia Maritima Nacional, a United States-controlled company, ceased to function.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- One of five persons on trial here on a charge of harboring a high-ranking Communist party functionary in a Sierra Nevada cabin last summer was acquitted today.

The no-raiding pact between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations is likely to come alive next month. Implementation of the ban on inter-union warfare would reduce strikes and improve the outlook for labor unity.

The national headquarters of the Girl Scouts of the U. S. A. repudiated yesterday a charge by Dr. Irving M. Peress that it had telephoned leaders of the Brownie pack in Middle Village, Queens, "to be wary of possible subversion" because of the presence of Dr. Peress' 9-year-old daughter, April.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, worldwide communications and manufacturing system, reported yesterday for 1953 a record consolidated net income of $22,377,611. This was equal to $3.12 a share on the outstanding capital stock and compares with a consolidated net of $22,147,753, or $3.09 a share, in 1952. Results for 1953 were the best since the founding of the system in 1925.

Research workers for some years have been studying how children develop and how they react to what their parents do with them and to them. In the opinion of Dr. Sara Breitbart, psychoanalyst, these researchers might well give some attention now to the ways adults develop and change under the pressures of parenthood, the ways they react to what their offspring do with them -- and to them.

Paramount Pictures Corporation, in its annual report covering the fifty-two weeks to Jan. 2, last, disclosed yesterday a consolidated net income of $6,779,563, equal to $3.06 a share on 2,217,051 shares outstanding.

The Playhouse already is assured of a booking. Contracts have been drawn for Albert Lewis and Ben Marden, owner of the house, to pool their resources in the presentation of "The Girl Most Likely." A local premiere of the Irving Brecher-Jo Swerling comedy is planned for October, after a preliminary spin out of town.

At the annual dinner last night of the Architectural League of New York, Lewis G. Adams, architect, was inducted as president. He succeeds Daniel Schwartzman. In ceremonies held at the league's quarters, 115 East Fortieth Street, other new officers were installed, including Lumen Winter, Moissaye Marans, George Nelson and John Skidmore, all vice presidents.
PITTSBURGH, April 22 -- Leo Durocher and his Giants trooped sadly off Forbes Field today. They had lost another ball game.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- At 3:10 P. M. today, the United Nations Security Council met for the third time to debate how to debate the Palestine situation. At 6:25 P. M. the Council adjourned until Tuesday afternoon. That was the only decision taken.

Two associate professors at Hunter College who were suspended recently as a result of an investigation, have admitted past membership in the Communist party, the Board of Higher Education said yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 22 -- Thousands of persons stormed the National Assembly today in protest against the Government's decision to consider the use of Bengali as a second state language.

Uncle Sam was richer by $25,600 yesterday as the result of 850 purchases made by 600 bidders who attended the two-day auction sale of abandoned, unclaimed and seized merchandise put on the block by the Customs Service.

What passes for comparative peace on the waterfront at this time should not be taken as an assurance that peace is really in sight. The National Labor Relations Board has ordered a new collective bargaining representation election among longshoremen, the date for which will be announced soon. The board is investigating more than sixty complaints made by the parties involved in the recent strike.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., April 22 -- Mrs. Andrew Steidinger of the Cherry Valley Club carded a 45, 48 -- 93, to take low gross prize in the season's first Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class B one-day tournament at the North Hempstead Club today.

MANY of the top trout streams are in near-perfect condition, with water temperatures quite high, streams clear, and hatches reported on several stretches, which is news that cheers dry-fly enthusiasts.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- A soldier testified today that Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson spied on him and seven other Americans who were secretly discussing plans to bolt a Communist prison camp in North Korea.

Trygve Lie, the Norwegian statesman and former Secretary General of the United Nations, has turned over to Mcmillan the manuscript of his "Memoirs." The book, which includes material on his early life, will deal largely with his seven years as chief official of the United Nations and with the major political-diplomatic questions and personalities then dominating the international scene.
CANBERRA, April 22 -- The Australian Government may try to prevent the return to Moscow of a Tass correspondent.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 22 (AP) -- Premier Fazlollah Zahedi asked Iran's Parliament today for a vote of confidence. He asked it to approve a Cabinet line-up in which one minister has been shifted, and a Government program much like that he laid down after he ousted Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh last summer.

At the same time that the French Union forces are making their heroic stand at Dienbienphu the French and Vietnamese are winning a political victory of great importance in Paris. Full agreement is now reported to have been reached on the treaties proclaiming the independence and sovereignty of Vietnam and defining the latter's association with the French Union.
Although getting only one hit, St. John's defeated Manhattan yesterday, 3 to 2, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference baseball game at Dexter Park, Queens.

Mayor Wagner presented a $10,000 check yesterday to the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, for the establishment of two fellowships in honor of his father, the late Senator Robert F. Wagner.
BOSTON, April 22 -- The American Woolen Company, beset by a struggle for control of management, faced today the probability of a strike on Monday.
President Eisenhower's foreign economic program was given general endorsement yesterday by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

New York bank loans to business dropped $90,000,000 last week. New borrowings by sales finance companies were the only important influence on the upside, although nine of the twenty-one reporting member banks showed net increases.
New York State local school districts borrowed $3,124,000 in the public market yesterday to finance school building.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., April 22 (AP) -- Hanes Hosiery of Winston-Salem, N. C., won the national girls' basketball championship playoff last night by beating Wayland College of Plainview, Tex., 46 -- 39. It was Wayland's first defeat in thirty-three games.
Samuel Reber, younger brother of the Army's first witness at yesterday's hearing, charged Senator Joseph R. McCarthy with a "deliberate diversionist movement" in bringing his name into the testimony.
LOS ANGELES, April 22 -- A circus, an orchestra, a theatre group, a film columnist and assorted top-bracket actors and entertainers were named today as possible debtors on unpaid income taxes.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 12 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which noted the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:

Commodity prices on the New York exchanges generally closed lower yesterday. Coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, sugar, potatoes, silk, hides, burlap, rubber, zinc, lead and copper were weaker; wool and tin were mixed and only cocoa higher.

BONN, Germany, April 22 (AP) -- They look like two ordinary cigarette cases and a couple of toy pistols. But they are ideal weapons for an assassin because of their innocent appearance, lightness and efficiency.

Edward C. Maguire was told yesterday to quit as labor adviser to the Yonkers Raceway or surrender his lifetime $15,000-a-year post as Commissioner of the Board of Water Supply. He said he would fight in the courts to keep both jobs.

BALTIMORE, April 22 (AP) -- Duane Pillette, lanky Baltimore right-hander, settled down after the first inning and gave the Cleveland Indians only five hits today for his second straight Oriole victory, 4 to 1.
DETROIT, April 22 (AP) -- Former Senator Blair Moody announced his candidacy today for the United States Senate from Michigan on the Democratic ticket.
More than 1,000 members of the Forty-fifth Infantry Division, home five day's from Korea, got their heroes' welcome yesterday.

Senator Estes Kefauver charged yesterday that the Child Study Association of America had "deceived the public" in presenting reports on comic books. He said the association had failed to note that some of the experts it employed were at the same time being paid by comic-book publishers.

LONDON, April 22 -- The London newspaper critics unanimously took "The Teahouse of the August Moon" to their hearts. And they predicted it would be as successful here as it was in New York, or more so.
Louisiana's pink strawberries are in copious supply on fruit stands these days, and many chains are selling them for 23 cents a pint.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22 (AP) -- The stretch-running Goyamo served notice he would be a stout contender for Kentucky Derby honors by driving to a length victory today in the $38,600 Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland.

On this day all readers and makers of newspapers should handle their favorite sheet with special interest, for on April 24, 1704, exactly 250 years ago, there appeared in Boston the first issue of The Boston News-Letter, America's earliest effort in the Fourth Estate.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- A sparkling victory by Oklahoma A. and M. in the distance medley highlighted the opening program of the sixtieth annual Penn Relay carnival today. It was the only college relay title event contested.

With the Geneva conference only two days away the United States, Britain and France have demonstrated again their determination to maintain a united front by flatly rejecting the insistent Soviet demand for recognition of Communist China as the fifth Great Power at the conference table.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 23 -- The Vietminh seized another French post today in Dienbienphu's northwest defenses. Communist-led troops smashed to within 700 yards of the garrison center.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The directors of the Broad Street Trust Company and the Northwestern National Bank have approved a plan for merging the two institutions under the name of the former.

There is nothing out of line in the Japanese decision to approach Moscow for a reconsideration of the question of Japanese fishing rights and concessions in the waters north of the archipelago. The stretches off the Kuriles, off Sakhalin and Kamchatka, and in the Bering Sea have been vital to Japan's food for a long time and in recent years have played an important part in Japan's exports.
VALLEY STREAM, L. I., April 23 -- The Chief and his mate, Reigning White Swan, at Valley Stream State Park, launched their family of seven downy cygnets yesterday mor
The National Collegiate Athletic Assocation's television committee reached an agreement yesterday with the American Broadcasting Company for the telecasting of college football games next fall.

Scientific evidence that is believed to provide the first demonstration that X-rays change growing organisms in beneficial as well as in destructive ways was presented yesterday to the New York Academy of Sciences.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) -- The nation's Governors will be briefed behind closed doors on atomic energy, foreign policy, national defense add other matters at a three-day White House meeting opening here Monday.

CLEVELAND, April 23 -- The country is "literally going mad with health fund drives" and the public's patience is near the breaking point, the National Conference on Solicitations was told at its founding session tonight.

PARIS, April 23 -- The foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today that Moscow's aspirations to world paramountcy remained unchanged and that the military strength of the Soviet bloc still was increasing. For this reason the North Atlantic Council "acknowledged the need for continuing efforts, vigilance and security."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23 -- Cambodia protested to the United Nations today that Vietminh Communists had committed "open aggression" against the small Buddhist kingdom in Indo-China.
LONDON, April 23--A Board of Trade official said here today that the success of West German exporters in capturing an increasing share of the world markets had been largely at Britain's expense.

JERUSALEM, April 23 -- Jordan's Foreign Minister said today that Eric A. Johnston, President Eisenhower's special Ambassador to the Middle East, would be "ill-advised to come to Jordan." He added, however, that Mr. Johnston "probably will not be barred from the country if he still wants to come here."

CHICAGO, April 23--Net loss of Butler Brothers in the first quarter was $178,821, compared to a net profit of $86,453 for the initial period last year, Bert R. Prall, president, told the annual meeting yesterday. Sales of the Chicago wholesale and retail concern were $26,878,725, a decrease of 2.7 per cent from a year earlier.

NEW ORLEANS, April 23 -- Charging that the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade had created serious trade barriers abroad, the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute called today for re-establishment of bilateral trade pacts.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 23 -- After a day of arguments in Superior Court, Judge John J. Francis this afternoon dismissed the first of the sixteen charges of failing to suppress gambling against Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County.

Back in 1910, Richard Schirrman, a young German school teacher, used to take his city pupils on countryside excursions. Thus began the youth hostel movement, which spread throughout Europe. It came to this country via two vacationing New England school teachers, Monroe and Isabel Smith.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Two photographers were asked today to turn over their film of a still-secret typewritten record of a telephone conversation on Nov. 7 between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army.

Jed Black, the Oak Park (Ill.) welterweight with a college diploma, needed only his elementary education last night to defeat Joey Klein of Jamaica, Queens, in the ten-round main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

In his address to the newspaper publishers Thursday night the President frequently repeated the phrase "cooperative peace." He once referred to it as a cooperative peace for all mankind, but the general tenor of his speech suggested that he was thinking primarily of cooperation among the free peoples.

Tonight is the night of the purloined hour -- the hour of sleep that is taken away, to lengthen the sunshine each following day. In ether words, Daylight Saving Time takes effect at 2 A. M. tomorrow for about 45 per cent of the population.

City Specialty Stores, Inc., in its first annual report yesterday announced its net income at $173,076 on sales of $40,236,178 for the fiscal year ended Jan. 30. The net, which is after $160,000 tax charges, is equal to 9 cents a share on 810,104 shares of $1 par common stock outstanding.

Corridors on the outside, instead of the inside, of each floor will be a novel feature of some of the new Marlboro Houses, a low-rent, public housing project to be built in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn.
Perhaps one should not say that New York is hardly fit for a dog to live in. But it does seem that fewer and fewer of the creatures choose to live here.

Although there has been no official announcement on who is to replace Henry Fonda in "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial," it is generally known that Barry Sullivan, the film actor, will take over the role of Lieut. Barney Greenwald.
CHICAGO, April 23 -- Consolidated sales of Zenith Radio Corporation in the first quarter were $29,335,190, E. F. McDonald Jr., president, announced today.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 1,056 pints of blood from employes of 100 insurance companies in the first five days, completed yesterday, of two "Insurance Weeks." The second "Insurance Week" will be held Monday through Friday, with collections continuing at the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., April 23 (AP) -- The smallest fleet in Newfoundland's colorful history of sealing -- only three ships -- ventured into the Arctic ice fields this year. Today the black-hulled Terra Nova was safely back in port, lone survivor of the tragic season.

NICE, France, April 23 -- The economic and political weakness of French and Italian democracy was held up here this week by anti-Communist Europeans as the major factor of the advantage of the Communist parties of those two countries.
People don't know very much about growing old gracefully, Dr. William C. Menninger, psychiatrist and general secretary of the Menninger Foundation, Topeka, Kan., declared yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23 -- The United Nations began a new round of talks today on the control of atomic energy. The first meeting produced only more gloom about the chances of progress.

BOSTON, April 23 -- The American Woolen Company mustered a quorum today in its fourth attempt to hold the annual stockholder's meeting. After two slates of directors had been nominated, the meeting was adjourned until May 10 to permit tellers to tabulate the votes.

DETROIT, April 23 (AP) -- Scoring five runs in the first inning, the Detroit Tigers knocked out Early Wynn and defeated the Cleveland Indians, 6 -- 1 , today. The game, which was an hour late in starting, was decided in the first ten minutes.

DETROIT, April 23 (AP) -- The nation's auto plants will build 146,177 vehicles this week, the highest volume in thirty-four weeks, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. The agency counted 123,594 cars and 22,583 trucks in this week's total.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- A shocking story of the fleecing of thousands of home owners by "the hoodlum, the racketeer and the bunko man" through Federally guaranteed home improvement loans was spread today on the record of a Senate committee investigating the housing scandal.

Cancellation of harness racing programs on New York tracks because of weather or other conditions will not be made in the future without the consent of a State Harness Racing Commission representative, Commissioner George P. Monaghan ruled yesterday.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 -- President Eisenhower preached the importance of America's spiritual values in these days of crisis on a day-long tour of Kentucky today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 -- Movie offers are piling up again for Frank Sinatra who fought his way back into the affections of filmgoers and Hollywood producers with his Academy Award winning performance for best supporting actor as Maggio in "From Here to Eternity."
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- A 5 per cent reduction in all indivdual income taxes, effective next Jan. 1, was proposed today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

A year-long review of maritime subsidy problems that will go far to clarify immediate and long-range maritime aims is almost completed, Louis S. Rothschild, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, announced yesterday.
SAN MATEO, Calif., April 23 (AP) -- Willie Harmatz, in his next to last day as an apprentice rider, today tied an American record of 47 years by winning six straight races at Bay Meadows.
Mayor Wagner revealed last night that the city budget would be increased by $100,000 for two new "all day schools" for children of working parents.

A report from Albany yesterday should make interesting reading for those who think New York State economic activity is largely limited to up-state dairy farms and the garment industry of Gotham. The State Department of Commerce said some $10,800,000,000 worth of foreign trade was handled in the Empire State last year.
Attorneys for Robert R. Young, who is waging a proxy fight for control of the New York Central Railroad, will have a chance at 10:30 A. M. on May 3 to question William White, Central president.

Mamm-Loeser's, Inc., department store operator, suffered a net loss of $29,933 after giving effect to a $17,729 tax refund credit, the annual report for the fiscal year ended Jan. 30 disclosed yesterday. This is in contrast to the net profit of $32,828 in the preceding fiscal year.

ST. LOUIS, Saturday, April 24 (UP) -- Pinch hitter Jim Pendleton's bases-loaded single in the fourteenth inning drove in Andy Pafko and Hank Aaron to give the Milwaukee Braves a 7 -- 5 victory over the St, Louis Cardinals today.

Large enterprises generally have unsung heroes. Charles W. Jeffers, who died April 16 in an Army hospital in San Francisco, was indeed such a figure in the American effort to rehabilitate its allies in the post-war period.
TRENTON, April 23 (AP) -Four-week-old Ellen Volk, injured by youngsters who thought she was a doll, remained in critical condition tonight after having undergone surgery.

Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, dean of Teachers College, Columbia University, was named yesterday as president-elect of the institution to succeed Dr. William F. Russell, who will retire next year and become president-emeritus.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

RYE, N. Y., April 23 -- Mrs. Jacques Mann of Quaker Ridge won Westchester's opening Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class B tournament today. She carded 45, 45 -- 90 at the Ryewood Country Club to take the gross award. Mrs. Samuel Strasburg of Vernon Hills was next with 48, 45 -- 93.

A broadcast in support of the plea of Capt. Nikolai Evgenyevich Khokhlov, former Russian secret police officer, to save his wife and child from possible imprisonment or death because of his stated refusal to obey a Kremlin order to murder, is to be beamed to the Russian people, the Voice of America announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 23 -- Electricity generated by an atom furnace may be available to homes at economical rates by 1963.

A plea for "fair play" for twenty-one suspended Fort Monmouth, N. J. employes during the present Senate hearings was voiced yesterday by attorneys, who insisted that none of the employes was even accused of being a Communist.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly yesterday in dull trading. Most of the markets were quiet, with activity confined to evening positions for the week-end. Sugar, cottonseed oil, wool, hides and zinc closed mixed; potatoes, soybean oil, tin and lead were higher, and cocoa, coffee, silk, burlap, rubber and copper ended lower.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) - The Senate confirmed unanimously today the judgeship nomination of Archie Owen Dawson, Southern District of New York, to succeed Henry W. Goddard, retired.
PARIS, April 23 (AP) -Following is the text of the communiqu issued here today by the foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at the conclusion of their one-day meeting:

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., threatened yesterday to stage, a one-day work stoppage next Thursday on the lines of the jointly owned New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent to 111.3 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This is the highest level reached by the index since September, 1952. All groups participated in the advance.
WATERTOWN. Conn., April 23 (UP) -- Air Secretary Harold E. Talbott said tonight that the Air Force was developing jet engines of 25,000 pounds of thrust, more than double the power of any now in use.

OTTAWA, April 22 -- The annual migration of the whooping cranes from their winter feeding ground in Texas to their breeding place in the Arctic is under way. Several of the flock of twenty-four -- the only ones left in the world -- were sighted in the past few days in Saskatchewan and Alberta.

LONDON, April 23 -- Business on the stock exchange slackened slightly today, compared with yesterday, and profit-taking reduced a few of the recent gains. But profit and dividend statements of Imperial Chemical Industries and Unilever served to stimulate demand for other leading shares.

Leo Durocher, manager of the New York Giants, will have a dramatic role on "Soundstage" next Friday at 9:30 P. M. over the N. B. C. television network. Scenes in which he will appear are scheduled to be filmed today or tomorrow at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) -- The Washington Senators scored four runs in the seventh after the first two men had been retired to defeat the Boston Red Sox tonight, 7 -- 6, before a crowd of 8,033. The victory left Washington in a two-way tie with Detroit for first place.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of testimony today before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations considering the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. The hearing began at 10:30 A. M.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Mrs. Ruth Young Watt, one of the nation's newest television personalities by virtue of her seat behind Senator Karl E. Mundt, chairman of Army-McCarthy inquiry, is a vital cog in the machinery of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

Christian Action, an organization of Protestant church men and women, made public yesterday a statement supporting public officials and church leaders who oppose Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
American children apparently have a much lower degree of muscular fitness than European youngsters in the same age groups and with comparable backgrounds.

Because the United Nations has been ineffective it has frequently been bypassed. Undoubtedly it is the veto which has been the chief obstacle to an effective international policy. Moreover, the U. N. is not all-inclusive, as it should be. Sixty nations are members, and twenty more desire admission, but their application has been vetoed.

HOUSTON, April 23 (AP)--Hamilton Richardson, 20-year-old Davis Cup player from Tulane University, blasted the national champion, Tony Trabert, in a convincing straight-set victory today to enter the final of the twentieth annual River Oaks tennis tournament.

" Khamishia -- Five Tales From Israel," an episodic feature made on location by Israel-America Motion Pictures, Inc., has been scheduled to open on Thursday, May 6, in celebration of the sixth anniversary of the State of Israel, at four theatres in the metropolitan area.
Emphasizing an effort to "speed up play," the directors of the National Basketball Association adopted two rule changes yesterday.

ITHACA, N. Y., April 23 -- The position of women today in society is a potentially explosive one, Dean Helen G. Canoyer of the College of Home Economics at Cornell said here tonight. She spoke at a session of the thirty-third annual meeting of the New York State Home Economics Association.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The United States lent $100,000,000 today to the European Coal and Steel Community to expend production and revive the European capital market.
The stained glass Statue of Liberty window from Joseph Pulitzer's old World Building was presented by Mayor Wagner yesterday to the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 23--Senator Wayne L. Morse, Independent of Oregon, criticized "the give-away record of the Eisenhower Administration" in a speech on the Princeton University campus tonight.

THE Shakespeare Guild Festival Company, back in business at the Jan Hus Auditorium, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street, is offering "Hamlet" as its second production of the season. Since "Hamlet" happens to be by consent of scholar and layman one of the greatest plays ever conceived in the English language, it follows that it is always interesting to see and hear again.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday. Prices were unchanged to 4 points net lower at the close.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Edward M. Gaither of Philadelphia, glaring menacingly at Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson, declared today that he had been beaten brutally by Chinese Communists after he had told Corporal Dickenson of his plans to escape a Red prisoner of war camp in Korea.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The monitoring of telephone calls in Washington officialdom is regarded as standard operating procedure.
MINORITY groups, even in sports, have to fight opposition every step of the way, a fact that has been brought out in recent months by opposition to archery hunting and spear-fishing.

Thousands of teachers and students in Protestant colleges will speak from Church pulpits tomorrow which has been designated as National Christian College Day by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A.

BONN, Germany, April 23 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union today of an "outrageous and uncivilized" action in an alleged attempt to assassinate the leader of an anti-Communist Russian refugee organization.
ALBANY, April 23 (UP) -- The Court of Appeals upheld today the power of the State Commission Against Discrimination to discipline employment agencies that use unfair practices.

MELBOURNE, Saturday, April 24 -- The Soviet Government's decision to break off diplomatic relations with Australia has caused surprise but the Commonwealth Government is profoundly relieved, according to official sources.

PARIS, April 23 -- Concern over the isolation of the European Steel and Coal Community was expressed during an economic debate by European federalists here today. They expressed fears that it could not be made to function properly unless the single market was expanded by the creation of other specialized communities in the fields of defense, transport, other industries and agriculture.
Whisky sales are slow, and distillers are stepping up advertising to correct a topheavy inventory position, which is their way of saying that warehouses are full and they would like to sell more.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) - Roy M. Cohn, counsel to the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, denied tonight that he had "access to F. B. I. files when I want them."

PITTSBURGH, Saturday, April 24 -- After much travail the Dodgers this morning finished the game they started last night with the Pirates at Forbes Field. The Brooks won, 6 -- 5, in thirteen innings and 4 hours and 13 minutes.
GENEVA, April 23 -- The United States and some of the other Western powers are divided over the terms of the Korean settlement to be proposed at the Far Eastern Conference opening here Monday.

Manhattan still ranks as the No. 1 shopping area of New York City. Running a poor second in population among the five boroughs, its retailers do almost twice the business of Brooklyn, which has the next heaviest sales volume.

HOBOKEN, N. J., April 23 -Flown from Jamaica, B. W. I., to New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, in twelve transport planes, 900 natives of the island sailed from here at noon today on the Netherlands Ministry of Shipping vessel, Zuiderkruis, for Southampton, England.

TRENTON, April 23 -- The dismissal of a death house guard and the suspension of five other officials at the New Jersey State Prison here was recommended today by Sanford Bates, State Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 23 -- Princeton swept to its fifth straight victory, downing Dartmouth, 4 -- 1, in an Eastern League game on University Field today.

With substantial new underwriting commitments looming for next week, investment banking syndicates revised downward yesterday their pricing ideas on new issues of public utility bonds and preferred stocks.

LOS ANGELES, April 23 -- Faculty members and top administrative officials of the University of California will receive pension increases ranging to 50 per cent under a new plan approved by the Board of Regents today.
ALBANY, April 23 (AP) -- Public school construction is booming in upstate New York.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 23 -- Government spokesmen said today that Yugoslavia was ready to assume military obligations growing out of the Western defense system.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The National Federation of Post office Clerks accused Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield today of ignoring the "desperate need" of postal workers for an adequate pay increase.

Paterson, N. J., announced yesterday that it would receive bids May 6 on an issue of $1,064,000 of bonds, to finance school and other improvements. Dated May 1, 1954, the bonds will come due annually on May 1 from 1955 to 1981.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., April 23 -- Peggy Mackie of Inwood carded a 38, 41 -- 79 for low gross honors in the opening one-day tournament of the Women's Cross County Golf Association at Wheatley Hills today.
John Dioguardi, alias Johnny Dio, convicted extortionist and more recently a union boss, was finally read out of the labor movement yesterday.
LONDON, April 23 (AP) -America's "Amos 'n Andy" made a Filmed debut on British television last night and split the TV critics into two camps. There are thirteen films in the series.

A horse race that promised to be as representative as any of the 3-year-old fixtures listed on the spring calendar will be contested at Jamaica today. The event is the $100,000 added Wood Memorial at a mile and an eighth. Weather cooperating, the crowd should reach a season's high of more than 50,000 fans.

THE best story of adventure that has come this way in a fair interval is "The Chisholm Trail," by Wayne Gard. This is a scholarly narrative, burred and bedeviled with footnotes and citations of a sort I often wish historians would consign to their pastors or public archives open to certified Doubting Thomases. But the material of a true saga bursts from the book's learned seams.

HONOLULU, April 23 -- One of the chief issues before Hawaii's Territorial Legislature in its special session appeared today to be the size of the legislative delegation scheduled to go to Washington to make a special plea for statehood now.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 23 -- United States C-124 planes airlifting French paratroopers to Indo-China have been landing in Ceylon since last night. Seven planes had already touched down at Katunayake Airport, about twenty-five miles from Colombo for refueling.

The article which appeared in The New York Times on March 28 under the heading Topics of The Times was an interesting synopsis of the "Handbook of Cyprus," edited by Sir Ronald Storrs. It refers, however, to the extremely important issue of the demand of the people of Cyprus for union with Greece in a remarkably offhand way, attributing this demand to what the article seems to consider a mere congenital discontentedness.

Independent users of aluminum in the United States were assured by a court decree yesterday of priority to buy from the Aluminum Import Corporation at least 110,000 tons of smelting aluminum ingot for each of the next five years.

Metro has bought as a starring vehicle for Spencer Tracy a story of the early West titled "Jeremy Rodock." It was written by Jack Schaefer, the author of "Shane." Sam Zimbalist will produce the picture.
Mikhail Botvinnik outmaneuvered Vassily Smyslov by changing his tactics in developing the black side of a Sicilian defense in the fifteenth game of their world championship chess match in Moscow.
MOSCOW, April 23--The Soviet Government today severed diplomatic relations with Australia over the Petrov case.
A clerk for a cash-checking service was robbed of $10,000 by two hold-up men, and a truck driver was forced to surrender $1,500 to another hold-up pair just before 11 A. M. yesterday in Brooklyn.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 23 -- Rita Hayworth's two daughters were taken into protective custody today by the Westchester County Children's Court. A hearing will be held to determine if they are neglected.
New lingerie trends for spring and summer revolve around fabrics, new construction details, and a wealth of luxurious trimmings emphasizing feminine allure.

NEW BRUNWICK, N. J., April 23 -- The board of trustees of Rutgers University approved today a $3,500,000 building program that would provide sixty classrooms, quarters for 972 students and a student center.
LINDENHURST, L. I., April 23 -- The case of Lawrence C. Lobaugh, which has kept this village in Suffolk County steamed up for a year, has just boiled over again.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored two runs in the tenth inning today against Billy Pierce to end a four-game Chicago White Sox winning streak, 3 -- 1.

Under the leadership of aircrafts and steels, the stock market pushed forward yesterday and almost succeeded in ending the week with a plus sign. Although rails lost some of their earlier gains, their performance for the day was better than that for industrials as a whole.
ALBANY, April 23--Although tuberculosis is declining fast in Western countries it is still the most prevalent disease in the world and is certain to increase in some areas.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 23 (Reuters) -- Nearly 8,000 British and African troops and police were moved up into position in Nairobi tonight to begin the biggest round-up of Mau Mau suspects since the terrorist campaign broke out eighteen months ago.

Representatives of Hi-Y Clubs in Queens and Brooklyn took over the City Council chambers in City Hall yesterday for a day of law-making and ran into the perennial problem of city government -- where to get new tax money.

PEARL HARBOR, April 23 - Fleet Admiral William F. (Bull) Halsey, back in uniform for the first time in seven years, deplored any hysteria over atomic and hydrogen bombs today and said he felt Communists "should have their necks cut off every time they stick their heads above ground."
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Senate investigators subpoenaed today from the six principals in the Army-McCarthy controversy all their records on monitored telephone conversations relevant to the dispute.
Today is the 250th anniversary of the publication of the first successful newspaper in America.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 23 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr. shot a 6-under-par 66 today to gain the lead in the $35,000 tournament of champions with a 36-hole total of 135.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23 -- The United States today attacked systems of forced labor in Communist countries, particularly Red China and Albania.
CHICAGO, April 23 (UP) -- A flight safety expert declared today that most civilian airports had inadequate fire-fighting equipment and organization.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Herb Shriner, the Hoosier television comedian who once headed a harmonica quintet, received a patent this week for a vest-pocket mouth organ with a slide valve.
There seems little doubt that the city sales-tax extension to commercial services is dead, and several lessons can be read from the Wagner administration's experience with this revenue proposal.
CEDARHURST, L. I., April 23 -- A Navy Reserve flier trying to land a plane with a dead engine hit an oil storage tank and crashed here today, but he escaped with only cuts and bruises.

AN objector to the arbitrary discipline of the rectangular frame, Carl Pickhardt, whose latest paintings are at Jacques Seligmann's, designs the shape of each to correspond to compositions within. These depict landscapes of meagre picturesqueness whose basic forms -- rocks, clouds and lakes -- are reduced to flat, suave, darkish patterns, which dictate the contours of the frames surrounding them.
The wholesale price of cocoa beans has almost doubled in the last year, and consumers are beginning to pay more or, in some cases, get less.
