Two off-Broadway theatres, each charged with four Fire Department violations, received suspended sentences yesterday morning in Municipal Term Court.
The search for an acceptable new revenue source to replace the unwanted 3 per cent sales tax on commercial services went on apace yesterday.

BOSTON, April 23 (AP) -- Emil Rieve, president of the C. I. O. Textile Workers Union, today wired the New England Congressional delegation that American Woolen was "being clawed over . . . without regard for public welfare" by "greedy speculators . . . seeking to lay hands on the company's $43,000,000 working capital."

One thing at least may be said with certainty about Mexico's sudden action in devaluating its currency. That is that it was one of the best-kept secrets of its kind in recent years. Last week parity for the peso was 11.6 cents. This week it is 8 cents, a depreciation of approximately 31 per cent.
JERSEY CITY, April 23 -- The resignations of both Mr. Kenny and Mr. Roller were accepted "with regret" last Monday by the Board of Commissioners of the Jersey City Redevelopment Agency.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Sewell L. Avery, 80-year-old chairman of the board of Montgomery Ward Co., expressed his usual pessimism today at the annual stockholders' meeting in the company's offices. He warned that from "the looks of things the country is in a distressful situation."

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, April 23 (Reuters) -- Shakespeare's home town was host today to representatives of fifty-eight nations in a giant festival to celebrate the 390th anniversary of the playwright's birth.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Grain futures again weakened today under heavy liquidation by longs, due in part to light to fair showers in the Southwest. However, there was fair accumulation on the mid-session declines and some week-end short profit taking which rallied futures a little.

The guaranteed annual wage is again in the news. The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., has made this demand on the General Electric Company. Soon the C. I. O. steel workers will present its revised wage-guarantee plan to the steel corporations. Next year the C. I. O. auto workers will propose such a scheme to the automobile industry.

CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -- Employes who purchased the Cleveland Pneumatic Tool Company last year received benefits of almost two million dollars during the past twelve months under two profit-sharing plans.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 23 (UP) -- Restorers of Abraham Lincoln's home today disclosed the only known bed from the Lincoln household had been returned and would be set up soon in Mary Todd Lincoln's bedroom.
MOSCOW, April 23 -- The Foreign Ministers of the Soviet Union and Communist China tonight neared the conclusion of their joint examination of matters that will arise at the Geneva conference.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 23 -- The president of the Manufacturing Chemists Association called today for wider publicity on the achievements of industry and other groups in solving the nation's air and water pollution problems.
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, April 23 -- Dr. Alfred A. Valdmanis, former Latvian displaced person who became Newfoundland's economics chief, was arrested today on charges of extortion.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Borg-Warner Corporation first quarter sales declined to $97,807,117 from $113,944,423 in the first three months of 1953, Roy C. Ingersoll, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting today. Net income fell to $5,001,506, or $2.03 a share, from $6,340,112, or $2.59 a share.
Age limits have been set for boxing referees and judges in the State of New York.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23 -- United States officers stationed with a United Nations observer team in Kashmir will be replaced by nationals of other countries as their tours of duty end.

Louise Steiner, a soprano from California, made her debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Irving Owen was the accompanist, and the Westchester String Quartet assisted in a Handel cantata, Virgil Thomson's "Stabat Mater" and Respighi's "Il Tramonto." Miss Steiner also was heard in Ravel's "Chansons Madecasses."

DES MOINES, April 23 (AP) -- Wes Santee loped in his slickest style to help Kansas again better the existing American sprint medley record and make a walk-away of the four-mile relay as the forty-fifth Drake Relays opened today.

Six thousands seamen from the ships of ten foreign nations took part in athletic games last year in the Port of New York, Harry Nilsson, welfare secretary of the International Seamen's Recreation Council announced yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 23 -- The concept of an Islamic republic, as envisioned by Pakistan's constitution-makers, came under fire this week in a report by two of the country's most eminent jurists.

A vacant business plot 100 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of 102d and Spruce Streets, at the junction of Roosevelt Avenue, in Corona, Queens, has been purchased at auction by Morris Gillman. The sale was conducted by Stephen A. McDonald, vice president of Joseph P. Day, Inc. The property was acquired for $5,200.

Alcoholism is discussed in two books to be published shortly. Simon Schuster will issue on Monday "An Alcoholic to His Sons," a personal story told to Henry Beetle Hough. The book recounts the experiences of a successful man who became an alcoholic and describes his rehabilitation.

Wholesale gambling has "thrived" because the courts have failed to administer the gambling laws "effectively and purposefully," the Brooklyn rackets grand jury charged yesterday.
CINCINNATI, April 23 (UP) -- Ransom Jackson smashed out five straight hits tonight, including one of four Chicago Cub homers that helped crush the Cincinnati Redlegs, 10 -- 3 before a crowd of 6,389.

On the Broadway branch of the West Side IRT line service on Saturdays and Sundays has become abominable. The expresses are only seven cars in length, and there are no locals at all. This Sunday afternoon at 5:38 a northbound Broadway express left Times Square with a large number of standees already.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Senate heard today a demand that the Western conferees at the forthcoming Geneva Conference indict the Communist rebels in Indo-China for atrocities in Cambodia. Cambodia is one of the three Associated States of Indo-China.

PARIS, April 23 -- Camille Chautemps, pre-war Premier who was Vice Premier at the time the French Cabinet broke up in the debacle of 1940, returned today to take up his residence in France. He arrived at Orly Field from Washington, where he had been in exile since 1940.

Excellent Easter business in ready-to-wear and surprising hard-goods business has made merchandise optimistic, according to resident buying offices. A number are now predicting that this year's sales will approach those of the record year of 1953.

MEXICO CITY -- Overnight Mexico has become a bargain holiday land for Americans as a result of the devaluation of the peso. From now on the tourist from the United States will receive 12.50 pesos for his dollar instead of 8.65 pesos.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The recent speech of the Most Rev. Bernard J. Sheil denouncing Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as "a pitifully ineffective anti-Communist" received tonight the "100 per cent backing" of one of the country's most powerful labor leaders.

THE late Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris, former head of the Philatelic Foundation, assembled a monumental collection of the stamps and covers of Hawaii. When half of this valuable collection goes on the auction block Tuesday at Harmer, Rooke Co., no less than sixteen of the rare Missionary stamps, with a total catalogue value of $81,500, will be sold.
BUENOS AIRES, April 24 -- The decree declaring a state of war exists in Argentina will be suspended for ten hours tomorrow while the nation votes.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Boston Red Sox defeated Washington, 6 -- 1, tonight but suffered a severe jolt when Pitcher Mel Parnell sustained a fractured bone in his left forearm when hit by a pitched ball. The crack left-hander, a twenty-one-game winer last year, will be lost to the Red Sox for several weeks.

The care of floor coverings has been the theme of many meetings in the past few months. At one session, Miss Joan Berston of Alexander Smith, Inc., carpet manufacturer, cautioned women against shampooing rugs, with the exception of cotton, since this may result in rot of the rug's backing.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 24 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr. continued to wreck par in the third round of the $35,000 Tournament of Champions today and threatened to make it a run-away when the seventy-two-hole event finishes tomorrow.

CARL FURILLO won the National League batting championship last season with a mark of .344. Considering the fact that this represented an improvement of 97 points over his average of the previous season, a fellow was entitled to wonder if this was a flash performance by the Dodger outfielder. Yet it might have been indecorous to utter the unspoken thought out loud in Furillo's presence: Could he repeat ?

BOOTHBAY HARBOR -- The Maine fresh-water fishing season is legally open. Trout, landlocked salmon and togue may be taken with fly or trolling gear. Under state regulations, fishing in several southern counties starts April 1 or any time thereafter that the ice on lakes and ponds is officially declared out. In other counties to the north opening day falls on April 15.

Two of the major women's golf associations in the East, the Westchester - Fairfield and New Jersey groups, have just completed arranging their schedules.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The Citizens' Council on City Planning is rallying Philadelphia youngsters to the cause of better planning by making the subject interesting and amusing.

THE Cornell - Guggenheim Aviation Safety Center is one of the best friends the air traveler ever had. Very few independent organizations are as determined as the Center is in its relentless efforts to make flying the safest form of transportation.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 -- As a business man, Preston Hotchkis advises other business men: "Get acquainted with the United Nations, because what it does can touch your pocketbook."

One of two familiar former East Coast passenger vessels may soon be returned to active service, but on the run between San Francisco and Honolulu, as the result of the formation of the Hawaiian Steamship Company, Ltd., it was learned yesterday.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 24 -- Princeton made seven hits count for seven runs today as the Tigers took a 7-4 decision from Colgate on University Field. It was Princeton's sixth consecutive victory.

Which waxing agent should the homemaker select from the many on the market today? Although she will have to decide for herself, some experts' advice on types suited for different kinds of flooring may be helpful.

CAMELLIA growers currently are showing much interest in varieties of C. reticulata. This is partly because some new varieties, imported from China in 1948, are proving a great addition to gardens along the Pacific Coast.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 24 (UP) -- A special assistant to Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, said tonight that the military Reserve forces were "far from the caliber" needed and some system of compulsory service seemed unavoidable.

THE word portrait that Norman Brokenshire has drawn of himself in this book is -- for the most part -- not a pretty one, although it ends happily. One of radio's first announcers, noted for his warm introductory signature, "How do you do, ladies and gentlemen, how do you do," he had a rapid rise to fame and then ran head-on into a seemingly hopeless addiction to alcohol, which derailed his career many times.

NEW ORLEANS, April 24 -- Recent irregularities in the public housing program might hold up Federal Housing Administration financing, but not to any serious extent. Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. said today.
In an age when the machine has taken over in the home, many things have changed or even disappeared. Not so with the sewing basket, the traditional companion of the woman with leisure moments.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- The Australian Embassy staff members have been told by the Russians that their departure from the Soviet Union was conditional upon new developments that have occurred in Australia.
Both the military and political phases of the crisis in Indo-China, the keystone to Southeast Asia, were intensified last week on the eve of a crucial conference at Geneva.

ALTHOUGH it would appear that Walt Disney and his industrious artisans have enough projects on hand to keep them busy for several years, the news is that the Burbank studio has been humming -- without fanfare -- on its most ambitious cartoon feature to date.

THE first detailed program for overhauling the function and administrative set-up of the Production Code to emerge out of all the recent talk for and against modernizing the morals guide has, ironically, gone practically unnoticed.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Federal officials are so concerned about reports of overpayments and fraud in unemployment compensation that Congress has been asked for $2,500,000 for a national investigation.

WHY do men like living dangerously? No one seems to know and Colonel Chapman, who has lived as dangerously as any, is strangely reticent about the reasons he was always putting his head in the lion's mouth.

FATHER was tall and smiling, with red hair, a mustache that curled beautifully at the ends, and a perpetual tan. In the eyes of his children he was a hero. He would have been close to the godhead if only he had learned to juggle.

The Federal Housing Administration was set up in 1934 as a pump-priming agency. Last week, in three separate investigations, there was evidence that the pump had been overflowing for some time and that millions of dollars of profits had been realized at the expense of tenants, homeowners and taxpayers.
Home air-conditioning this year should be a bigger business than ever. Best estimates indicate that about $2,500,000,000 worth of room and year-round air-conditioning equipment will be sold.

Astronomers At the .Hayden Planetarium of the' American Museum of Natural History were disappointed to ,find this- out whe they consulted the Sun tables here last week.

GENEVA, April 24 -- The question of Communist China's admission to respectable society has plagued the United Nations for more than four years. Now the debate has been transferred from the headquarters on the East River to the shore of Lake Geneva.
An exhibit given its first trial somewhat more than a year ago now seems firmly established as a regular annual event. This is the Do-It-Yourself Show held here last month for the second time.

THE pattern of winter music in the United States has been derived, in its main lines, from Europe, and it has been more or less fixed over the years. American summer music, though, is a different matter. It has been developing its own pattern and is still very much in a state of flux.
How to make a one-room apartment do the work of a whole house is a problem every small- apartment dweller must solve.
SHAWAN, Md., April 24 (AP) -- Ten horses and riders went out today for the fifty-eighth running of the Maryland hunt cup and only half of the field finished, with Marchized leading the survivors.

Shoppers will get the biggest bargain since the end of World War II next month. But the situation is not promising for the stores' household textile departments, whose profits will be squeezed by the emphasis on promotional goods.
FAIRFORD, England, April 24 (UP) -- Teamwork saved a $4,000,000 United States Air Force B-47 Stratojet bomber from possible disaster, it was disclosed today.
MOSCOW, April 24 (AP) -- The Russians sent another note to the Western Big Three today concerning Red China's position at the Geneva conference.

AS a platform for settlement of international disputes, the United Nations may leave much to be desired. But the United Nations' special agencies, like the World Health Organization, International Children's Emergency Fund, and the Technical Assistance Bureau are winning battles that are more important to half the world.

PVT. EDDIE D. SLOVIK was the only American soldier to be executed for cowardice on the battlefield since 1864. It happened in the European theatre in World War II. Until today the incident has remained as deep buried as the corpse.

REVIEWING "Supreme Court and Supreme Law" edited by Edmond Cahn, reviewer Saul K. Padover makes the statement: "Chief Justice Marshall asserted, and set a precedent for, the far-reaching principle of 'judicial review' -- that is, the right of the court to pass judgment on acts of Congress."

IN a remarkable passage of his review of his life, Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, referring to the time when he was a Professor of Theoretical Physics in California, wrote: "I was not interested in and did not read about economies and politics. I was almost wholly divorced from the contemporary scene in this country."

The uncertain action of the stock market last week -- moving higher at times, then swinging lower -- was confusing even to those "bulls" who reluctantly agree that a healthy intermediate reaction can be expected.

NEW DELHI, India, April 24 -- Prime Minister Nehru put forward today his new programs for ending the Indo-China war while sharply condemning the United States plan for evolving collective action in Southeast Asia.

SPRING is under full swing and throughout the East Coast, many of the fine estates and gardens are now at their height of beauty. So much so that many garden tours are planned by various societies and garden clubs to visit them.

AWKWARD phrases can often be succinctly expressive. One such is the counsel to "re-think it" which really says more than the more grammatical "re-examine it." This is brought up for it seems to furnish the most adequate description of the new version of Handel's Messiah that Hermann Scherchen has conducted for Westminster. It is re-thought.

It always comes, that outdoor moment when everything is happening at once. A rain, a couple of warm days, and the rush is on. Buds open. On the hillsides where one had to search for hepatica there is a carpet of bloodroot. Anemones are nodding in the wind.

THE National Broadcasting Company will take its color cameras into the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the first time on Saturday, May 8, from 3:30 to 4 P. M., to provide the first public showing of the renovated museum, including the new Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium which will be officially opened a few days after the telecast.

EVERY so often a combination golfer - gardener is tempted to simulate the beautiful greens of bent grasses, found on the courses, for his own lawn. And it's no wonder, for the smooth greens of a golf course have such a neat, well-kept appearance.

THE niceties of bidding and play in upper-level bridge games have often been the subject of comment in this column. Discussing them some years ago, this writer observed: "The 'advanced' player finds the expert standard incomprehensible and usually refuses to believe it exists."

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The State Department refused to comment today on an Indian proposal earlier in the day for ending the Indo-Chinese war. Congressional leaders, less restrained, vigorously denounced it.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., April 24 -- George Hinman's Felix finished first in the annual "ocean race" of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club dinghy fleet from the club to Hinman's home off Sands Point today. Second place went to Russell Harris' Stinger, with Jim Moore third with Lure.

For low-cost twenty-four-hour home cooling, one of the newest tricks is to use a room air-conditioner in combination with an attic fan.

THERE is about "Tower of Ivory" an extraordinary reality that helps us see that nothing in this world is meaningless, suffering least of all. This is shown not in words, but in the drama of the characters. It is a story of love that triumphs over sorrow -- a story of a nun who bridged the conflict between the virgin in her soul and the mother in her body.
There has been one constant, recurring theme at a number of national health and medical conferences held within recent weeks. It is the shortage of trained personnel.

Efforts of the International Chamber of Commerce to create conditions favorable to an increased flow of private investments to underdeveloped countries appeared last week to have a good chance of making progress.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 24 (UP) -- Republican foreign policy has been copied from the Democrats and is being administered in a "sorry fashion." Representative Sam Rayburn said tonight.

Steady growth in the use of panel heating is reported by the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau. This type of heat distribution is now being utilized for nearly all kinds of buildings, including homes.

CONTRASTS in techniques will be illustrated in two experimental films on the program to be given at 8:30 P. M. Friday by Film Directions in the auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art. The films are "Sausalito," an impressionistic film of a small California port, and "The Lion, the Griffin and the Kangaroo'" a personal documentary of an old Italian town.

There is a young saleswoman over on Park Avenue who knows that a bonnet is more than something to be worn Easter Sunday on Fifth Avenue. She knows also that to explain this properly to American automobile buyers, she must call a bonnet a hood.

IN her review of my book, "Essentials of Abnormal Psychology," Lucy Freeman has charged that I dwell "long on such matters as schizophrenia versus manic-depressive psychosis"; that I felt that "the importance of sexual impulses in a child's life is overrated" and, above all, that I do not know love as a basic therapeutic principle, and do not discuss the relationship between therapist and patient satisfactorily.

THE daffodil season is in full swing along the East Coast. Even in New England the earliest-flowering varieties have finished bloom and hundreds of midseason and late kinds are in full flower from Virginia northward. Southward, of course, the season has already. waned.

THE perennial phlox is one of the most attractive plants in the herbaceous border and, generally speaking, it is also often one of the most neglected. Perhaps the reason is that the average gardener doesn't understand its whims, weaknesses and requirements.

Tony Schneider scored a single-handed victory for the New York Athletic Club last night by registering four goals in the second half to defeat Army, 4 -- 3, in the final of the Junior National Amateur Athletic Union water polo championship in the victor's pool.

THE growing realization of the value of our art as an unofficial ambassador abroad is illustrated in the current exhibition at the Whitney Museum. Nearly one hundred paintings, representing pretty much all phases of our art in the nineteenth century, are included.

OTTAWA, April 24 -- Draftsmen have completed final blueprints for what Canadian Hydrographic Service officials say will be "the world's most completely equipped ship for map - making." Construction will begin this year at a site to be decided.

A FOYER properly decorated should provide a synopsis of the character of the rooms one is about to enter. It should express the personalities of those whose home it introduces and the decorative style they favor. It should be so stamped with the owner's individual taste that it acts as a transitional passageway between the objective out-of-doors and the very personal atmosphere that exists inside a home.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 24 -- President Jose Figueres flew to the Panama border today to meet the Panamanian President, Jose Antonio Remon. Colonel Figueres seeks to ease the tension that has followed the recent abortive revolt in Nicaragua, which Costa Rica has been accused of helping.

A BOOK of fourteen essays upon as many great composers of orchestral music, nine of these by Herbert Peyser, and the others by Pitts Sanborn, Robert Bagar and Louis Biancolli, is published by Putnam under the title of "Masters of the Orchestra," by Louis Biancolli and Herbert Peyser.

BLOW: Venus and Adonis; Lyre-Bird Ensemble and Orchestra, Anthony Lewis conducting (London). Reissue by London of the recording originally brought out by L'Oiseau-Lyre. Surfaces are much improved in the new London version.

The cost of electricity to run room air-conditioners and year-round central units varies from locality to locality and from house to house. Utilities charge different rates and users of air-conditioners have differing conceptions of coolness.

BOSTON, April 24. (AP) -- Tony DeMarco, improving young Boston welterweight, scored his eleventh consecutive boxing victory tonight with a unanimous ten-round decision over Carlos Chavez of Los Angeles in a nationally televised bout in Boston Garden.

Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the city's private transit industry, acted yesterday to avert a threatened strike Thursday on lines of the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.

THESE latest additions to the Land of the Free books -- a series of junior novels designed to emphasize the contributions of various national groups to American life -- are concerned with peoples who have hitherto received very little attention in books for young people.

Air-conditioning has a long road to travel before it becomes as common as refrigerators. Only 3.2 per cent of all wired homes in the country now have air-conditioning. But in 80 per cent of the homes that have room air-cooling more than one unit has been installed.

Homeowners and landlords may save themselves considerable time and expense by proper selection of water-closet fixtures best suited to their houses.
Hearing aid manufacturers are anticipating increased business. The advancing age limit of the American population and the rising noise in factories are broadening the market.

WITH this tongue-in-cheek novel of a modern king in exile, John H. Secondari adds an ironical R. I. P. to the Graustark legend. What happens when the Strauss waltz is over and that white-and-gold uniform gives way to a double-vent sports jacket?

THOUGH the movies do not come within the range of this department very often, the screen debut of Diana Adams demands a momentary digression from the familiar path. Miss Adams appears briefly but deliriously with Danny Kaye in the ballet which brings "Knock on Wood" to a conclusion.

PARIS, April 24 -- French delegates are going to Geneva with the feeling that the negotiations there on peace in Indo-China will perhaps shape the whole of France's policies for years to come. It is therefore with extreme concern for the success of their proposals that the members of the delegations left Paris last night.

VALLEJO, Calif., April 24 -- A century after Admiral David G. Farragut, as a commander, took over the Navy's first shoreside installation on the West Coast, Mare Island Naval Shipyard will open a four-day celebration on Sept. 16.

PRIMROSES, which the scientific gardener may casually call primulas, start to bloom in mid-April. And like the daffodils, it is possible to have primroses in bloom until late May. There is such a wide variety of kinds, colors and sizes of primroses that there is almost no limit to what can be planted.

POUND RIDGE, N. Y. -- Here, less than ninety minutes from Times Square, the deer come to drink in the marshes where the peeping frogs exclaim. This is a common scene in the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation, which opened recently for its thirtieth season.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 24 -- The University of Pennsylvania crew won the Childs Cup today in the diamond anniversary of the competition for the oldest American college rowing cup.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 24 -- Statistically, Rhode Island's economic pulse is weak. Yet industrial sources whose business it is to watch the patient assert that there are definite signs of returning color.

PITTSBURGH, April 24 -- If Carl Erskine today looked like Brooklyn's ace right hander of last season the resemblance was not coincidental. The little Hoosier blanked the Pirates on three singles and the Dodgers' 3-0 victory moved them to the top in the National League race.

The Giants went a long way toward erasing the memory of thier recent misadventures against the Pirates by defeating Philadelphia's redoubtable Robin Roberts at the Polo Grounds yesterday. They turned the trick, 1 -- 0, on Whitey Lockman's fifth-inning homer and the three-hit pitching of Marv Grissom.

WHILE the fortunes of the drama along the Main Stem are subject to wide fluctuations, seesawing raggedly between hits and turkeys, out on the rich prairies of the U. S. A., the thespian banner continues to be carried high and steady by the touring tent-repertoire troupes.

A union that operates two banks, two insurance companies, a philanthropic foundation, two health centers and apartment developments with a construction cost of $23,000,000 is celebrating its fortieth anniversary this year.

Before the advent of wallpaper, plaster walls of homes of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, were covered with wood, tapestries and leather, according to "Elements of Interior Design and Decoration," by Sherrill Whiton.

WE were flipping the pages of a classic, a play written nearly 2,500 years ago (and which Harcourt, Brace is publishing on the 29th), when our unsuspecting eye lighted on a passage that stood our hair on end. We submit the passage:
Wood-paneled rooms will be in evidence in American homes on a constantly expanding scale, according to decorative trends noted at the recent Exposition of Modern Living held in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Pvt. G. David Schine, a central figure in the McCarthy-Pentagon investigation, has been assigned temporarily to near-by Fort Myer, Va., so he can be available when needed by the Senate investigating subcommittee.

BOSTON, April 24 -- Harvard's smooth-stroking varsity eight opened its season today with an impressive three-length triumph over Boston University on the Charles. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology finished last in the triangular race, another four lengths to the rear.

NOT long ago a New York pet center received a frenzied phone call for medical advice from a midtown physician. It seems that the doctor's pet parakeet, on a routine reconnaissance of the dining room, had crashed head-on into a wall mirror and fluttered down into a bowl of vichysoisse.

THE chief topic of musical London at present is the new organ at the Royal Festival Hall. The inauguration of this instrument at the end of last month, in the presence of Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, was nearly as exciting as the launching of a new Atlantic liner. And as soon as they had recovered their breath, the critics began to analyze and assess the qualities of the new instrument with spirited frankness.

A series of three lectures on major contemporary problems will be delivered next month by Bernard M. Baruch at City College's Baruch School of Business and Public Administration, 17 Lexington Avenue.
The popularity of the room air- conditioner seems to be in no danger of diminishing this year.
A large subscription has been reported for the cocktail and tea dance for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery to be held on Wednesday at the Plaza.

CLEVELAND, April 24 -- A brisk upturn in steel production and leveling off of unemployment has brightened the industrial outlook in this area. Steel operations in the Cleveland-Lorain district climbed to 75.5 per cent of capacity, represented a gain of nine points over last week's revised figure of 66.5 per cent.

This year The Seeing Eye observes twenty-five years of unique service to the blind. Since 1929, when it was officially formed in Nashville, Tenn., it has trained nearly 2,500 dogs to serve as eyes for their masters, in a program largely maintained by public subscription.
Warm weather's on its way, and accessories to turn the backyard into a playground for the small fry abound.

TOWARD the end of his life Beethoven published a series of variations for piano, with violin or flute obbligato. They came out as Op. 105 and Op. 107; and for all the performances they have been getting throughout the years, they just as well could have remained in manuscript.

VACATIONISTS traveling on their own in Europe run a great risk when they venture to the eastern coast of Spain. Lacking the protective custody of a guided tour, with its inexorable time schedule, they are likely to linger much longer than they had originally planned.

FOR those interested in starting a wildflower garden, the members of the violet family are a wise choice. Not only are the flowers attractive, but the plants are easy to grow and readily obtained from the woodland, field or wildflower nursery. They are hardier, too, than their delicate blossoms would indicate.
ANN ARBOR, Mich. (Science Service) -- Pernicious anemia patients can inhale their vitamin B-12 as they do steam or nose drops, instead of taking "shots" by injection.

WITH verbal accuracy and sometimes inspiration, Harriet de Onis has edited and in part translated a collection of Spanish stories. Those which best preserve the grace of the original are the selections from Valle Inclan, Pio Baroja and the Colombian writer Hernando Tellez. Miguel de Unamuno's story, weak in Spanish, is less obvious and diffuse in English.

ALL the turbulent struggle, fiery emotions and tempestuous uncertainty of the life of a brilliant ballet dancer have been woven into this plot-packed novel by Agatha Young. The portrait of Giovanni Cenci is a painstaking picture of a man who achieves greatness in his work but only unhappiness in his life.

THE public figure of today has awakened to a new and difficult truth: If he is not to perish in obscurity, sooner or later he must go before the cameras of television. Once he does, he discovers that he is subject to the fate of all actors on the morning after.

LONDON, April 24 -- The conference on methods of preventing pollution of the sea by oil will open here Monday. Delegates from thirty countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union will attend. Observers from eleven other nations also will be present.

For the week immediately after Easter, traditionally a time when retail business falls off, retailers estimated that sales would drop from the same week a year ago. But they reported good response to post-Easter promotions.

BACH: Concerto in D minor for Two Violins and Orchestra; BEETHOVEN: Romance No. 1 in G, Romance No. 2 in F; Theo Olof and Herman Krebbers, violinists; Hague Philharmonic Orchestra, Willem van Otterloo conducting (Epic). Competent, not highly distinguished violin playing.
The acceleration of income tax payments by corporations is being brought about in slow stages.
Hot water is the simplest of cleaning aids and one with many applications. A score of helpful hints are offered by the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association.

A new exterior siding material that comes in panels 48 inches long has just been introduced by the Badgley Corporation of Rockvill Centre, L. I. National distribution is planned for the product, which is known as Aluma-Shake.

Although land and labor costs are rising for home builders, improved construction techniques should enable them to keep prices steady and provide more value, according to Arthur E. Williamson, real estate broker, of Teaneck, N. J.

A significant part of our economic aid program under the Foreign Operations Administration was set to work on Friday with the completion of the United States loan of $100,000,000 to the European Coal and Steel Community. This is the first instance in which aid has been given to an international group rather than to a single state.

RAYMOND CHANDLER, generally, acknowledged as the foremost creator of hardboiled detective stories after Dashiell Hammett, has written regretably little of late. After a large number of first-rate novelettes in the Nineteen Thirties and four distinguished novels, 1939-43, he has produced only two novels in the past eleven years.
LONDON, April 19 -- Complaints about the secretive nature of Britain's extensive scientific research projects in East Africa have been voiced by scientists here.

THE Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner, the minister of the Broadway Tabernacle Church (Congregational), at Fifty-sixth Street, and the Rev. Joseph D. Huntley, one of its staff, are faced with problems these days that are quite different from those that normally confront clergymen.

Robert S. Lytle's Correlation won the Wood Memorial at Jamaica yesterday with ease. The 3-year-old son of Free America scored by more than three lengths over the odds-on favorite, C. V. Whitney's Fisherman, in the $122,750 race.

The whims and wants of the child, not the parent, should be reflected in the room in which he plays, entertains his friends, studies and sleeps. Within this important corner of his universe, the colors that surround him, the furnishings he utilizes and the light by which he works and plays should contribute to his growth and pleasure.
Last year 50,000 families completely air-conditioned their dwellings by installing all-year central units. This year it is expected that twice as many families will follow suit.

Contemporary living demands electric cooking appliances that are completely automatic, portable and adaptable to many uses. They must be practical for family meals and offer efficient and attractive service in living room or patio.

Dr. Joseph B. Cavallaro, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, called last night for greater emphasis on traditional moral and religious values in the nation's schools. He spoke before 300 members of the Manhattan College Alumni Society at its eighty-fifth annual dinner in the Statler Hotel.

ALL parents should be grateful to Dr. Fredric Wertham for having written "Seduction of the Innocent." Most parents have not read the comic books that many of their children, because of guilt and anxiety, often conceal from them.

THAT DuBose Heyward's writing portrayed the Negro with human understanding at a time when such an approach was new and by some considered daring is beyond dispute. The best of his work had and still has tremendous vitality.

TOKYO, April 24 -- A motion of nonconfidence against the Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida was rejected tonight by the Japanese Diet after a stormy political fight. For a time the life of this five-year-old conservative pro-Western Administration was threatened.
May I add a footnote to the informative description in "The Super-Cabinet for Our Security" (April 4) by Cabell Phillips of the organization and procedures of the National Security Council?

Every year thousands of Americans in the most productive and vigorous age group, 20 to 40, are struck and permanently incapacitated by one of the most mysterious of human diseases, multiple sclerosis. Despite the medical progress of recent decades, here is an ailment whose cause and control are unknown, and which even goes undiagnosed for years because physicians know no specific test to apply.
Within the last month or two greatly improved models of infrared broilers and rotisseries have been made available in all leading appliance and department stores in the United States.

The annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund will begin tomorrow at noon at City Hall. Hundreds of blue and gold toy balloons, helium-inflated, will be released. The balloons will symbolize the 423 agencies of the fund, which seeks $9,000,000 to help them in 1954.
Twenty million American homes have wiring that is grossly inefficient and sometimes dangerous.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, urged today that the fate of United States soldiers still missing in action in the Korean war be included on the agenda of the Geneva conference.

Tips on removing ink stains caused by washable, permanent and ball point inks have been recently issued by the W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company. On a washable fabric the spot should be rinsed with clear water immediately, then washed in soap suds.
MAY 1 is just about the last call for planting gladiolus in the lower South and Gulf Coast areas. In the upper South and the Piedmont regions planting continues until July.

DETROIT, April 24 (AP) -- Ray Boone slammed a three-run homer in the fifth inning, ruining Hal Newhouser's first comeback bid, as the Detroit Tigers trimmed the Cleveland Indians, 6 -- 3, today before 25,445 fans in Briggs Stadium.
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 24 (UP) -- A bonus plan under which workers will get 50 per cent of savings from increased efficiency has been set up by Willys Motors, Inc., a C. I. O. leader said today.

DONNA REED, after fourteen years of playing ingenues and nondescript leading ladies, has suddenly stepped out of the stultifying rut that became her lot, as a result of one good role in one very good film, "From Here to Eternity."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 (AP) -- Sunny Dale, a 20-to-1 chance owned by the Buddah Stable of St. Paul, streaked home along the rail to win the $10,000 Churchill Downs Handicap today. His victory stunned an opening day crowd of more than 22,000 as Churchill Downs launched its eightieth spring meeting.

The heads of the country's two largest steel companies -- Benjamin F. Fairless of United States Steel and Eugene G. Grace of Bethlehem -- are expected to provide arresting news in the business world this week.

The conference that has been scheduled to open tomorrow morning at Geneva is faced with two separate, but related, problems of peace in the Far East. They are separate, geographically. They are related because each reflects the free world's resistance to Communist aggression, subversion and conquest.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 24 -- Danger of a roof collapse in the new $426,000 building at Greystone Park State Hospital near here led to the temporary removal of eighty patients, it became known today.

TOKYO, April 24 -- The Japanese Diet's upper house approved today the wholesale poisoning of animals here in an attempt to wipe out rabies. It cautioned municipal authorities to use their new powers with care and humanity.
GENEVA, April 24 -- France has asked for direct large-scale intervention in the Indo-China war by United States aircraft manned by American crews.

YONKERS, April 24 -- Dr. Rafael Ernesto Lopez, a surgeon who lives at 176 Colonial Parkway here, is believed to be lost in the jungles of Venezuela. He has been missing since April 15 while on an airplane trip.

THE Scott family found their new town a noisy, quarrelsome place. Grown-ups were dead set against kids, and often not speaking to each other. The neighborhood gangs devoted themselves mostly to harmless devilment like heckling each other or zooming across Old Man Taplinger's lawn. He could be absolutely counted on to give noisy chase.

EASTER sales volume this year was slightly better than a year ago. New York retailers would have gone well ahead but rain on Good Friday and the Saturday preceding Easter discouraged many potential shoppers. Areas in which good weather predominated showed a sizable gain in dollar volume.

Financing of about 75,000 new homes in the nation since last summer was made possible through the Federal National Mortgage Association's "one for one" mortgage commitment plan, points out Jay I. Kislak, vice president of the J. I. Kislak Mortgage Corporation of Jersey City, N. J.

AUBURN, N. Y., April 24 -- Householders and builders planning to make use of air-conditioning in their homes no longer are limited to conventional one-room units or central systems designed to cool an entire house.

Phil Brady, electrifying the fans with a 60-yard angle shot, seconds before the final bell, gave a 13-to-12 victory to the Squadron A polo team over a Winged Foot trio at the Squadron A armory last night.
Two new and rather different homes were opened this month in Philadelphia and New Haven. They are the latest units in the General Electric Company's so-called Wonder homes plan.
Otto Krauss has been appointed general manager of the St. Joseph division of Whirlpool Corporation, St. Joseph, Mich., manufacturer of home laundry equipment.
Persons who live where water is short or costly can have all-year central air-conditioning now.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 24 -- Contending that she had worked 20,440 hours of overtime without compensation, Anna M. Stefan of 710 Pennsylvania Avenue has brought suit for $25,550 against the estate of James F. Brown, former police court judge and owner of a tavern here.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 21 (Reuters) -- British police and troops with fixed bayonets today herded 3,679 Nairobi Africans behind barbed wire fences for screening as suspected Mau Mau terrorists or sympathizers.
Air-conditioning is influencing both the outward appearance and the interior planning of houses.

BOWIE, Md., April 24 (AP) -- An 11-5 favorite with the largest crowd of the eleven-day meeting, the Brookmeade Stable's First Aid, won easily under Nick Shuk in the $15,000 added Southern Maryland Handicap today.

Earnings of the Erie Railroad for April will amount to about 16 cents a share, according to P. W. Johnston, president. This would compare with an indicated 34 cents a share earned in the same month last year.

Tremendous expansion or improvement of the nation's highway system is under way or in prospect. The news of it is scattered, much of it appearing on financial pages with the marketing of bonds. But gathered together it bespeaks public and official awakening to the road-building deficit of past years, and promises a better day soon for travel, commerce and safety -- if drivers will use their heads.

Honorary degrees of Doctor of Science were conferred yesterday by St. John's University on Jasper H. Kane, vice president and director of research for Charles Pfizer Co., and Dr. Hugh C. Muldoon, Dean of the School of Pharmacy at Duquesne University.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The publications of hitherto secret documents showed today that five years before Japan all but knocked out the United States fleet at Pearl Harbor, American diplomats in the Far East were urging a Navy build-up to deter Japanese aggression.

The washing machine has been termed the most important single appliance in the home, since, as one home economist put it, "more than any other it has relieved the homemaker of an iron-bound schedule."

WAINSCOTT, L. I., April 24 -- Representative Stuyvesant Wainwright, Suffolk Republican, reported this week that he had received more than 4,000 replies to a questionnaire seeking his constituents' views on matters of current interest.
GENEVA, April 24 -- April, as T. S. Eliot wrote, is the cruelest month and Western statesmen convening in this famous city of negotiations are gloomily prepared to concede that the poet had a point.

Designers and manufacturers are heeding the plea for more compact heating systems. The different types of heat producers are taking up less and less space and are being placed in spots where they don't interfere with family living.

The efforts of Senator McCarthy and Mr. Cohn to obtain a commission for Mr. Schine lasted twenty-five days -- from July 8 to Aug. 1, 1953. For twenty-three days the efforts were made through General Reber; on the last two days, through Under Secretary Smith. This is the story as presented in the testimony of General Reber and General Smith:
Science may have achieved temperature and humidity control within the home, but a solution has yet to be found for controlling the weather-watcher.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 20 -- The possibility that Senator Theodore Francis Green may retire this year is filling Democratic strategy rooms with smoke in Rhode Island.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee sharply criticized the administration of United States foreign aid today. It cited the assistance program for India as an example of poor planning and operation.

LOS ANGELES -- Although the scarcity of public transportation amid the 450 square miles of municipal Los Angeles and the 5,000 square miles of Los Angeles County long has been the despair of residents and visitors alike, Southern California's All-Year Club stoutly denies it is any reason for not getting around and seeing the sights, even without a car.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 24 -- Although the controversial McCarthy-Army hearings turned up on Mountain States' television screens at awkward hours for the average viewer (8:30 A. M. and 12:30 P. M.) interest has been high.

Occupants of homes with air-cooling equipment are advised to keep the filters in good working order to get full benefits from the equipment. A recent survey indicates that the longer persons live with air-conditioning, the more benefits they may derive from it, unless they are "filter-silters."
The Air Force is going to make it possible for the individual consumer to buy a jacket, tack hammer, electric switch or chair at sales of its surplus supplies.

I read with much interest the article which appeared in Sunday's issue of The New York Times, entitled "The Crisis in U. H. F." You see, I am a stockholder in a U. H. F. TV broadcasting station and am aware of some of the problems confronting operators of a U. H. F. station.
CANBERRA, Australia, April 24 -- The Soviet Union will cease buying Australian wool following its severing of diplomatic relations with Australia over the Petrov affair.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- A steadily improving spirit of cooperation and friendship between the Roman Catholic and public school systems was among, the developments reported here this week at the fifty-first annual convention of the National Catholic Educational Association.
The business slump seems to be involving the Treasury in a debt-management dilemma.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 24 -- The Prime Ministers of five South Asian nations, meeting here Wednesday, will be asked by Ceylon to consider the "menace" of Communist penetration into this area.

THE Chinese often characterize a man either as "round," meaning smooth; or as "square," meaning one with strict principles and set ways. Premier-Foreign Minister Chou En-lai, who is the directing chief of Communist China's delegation to the Geneva Conference, which convenes tomorrow, is definitely a "round" man.

CHATTANOOGA, April 24 -- Interest in the Army-McCarthy dispute before the Senate Subcommittee on Invstigations is very intense in the Southeast. In addition to the normal factors that would create deep interest, the fact that Tennessee furnished the chief counsel for the committee -- Ray Jenkins -- has aroused attention in respect to other issues and interests that may not have prevailed otherwise.

When a man reaches 47 years of age and is a vice president and director of the world's largest bank, he has earned the right to coast if he wishes. But Hugh L. Clary has never exercised this right. He does not know how to "stand still" in business.

CLEVELAND, April 24 -- With seven additional furnaces added to the inactive list in March, ore consumption failed to reach the 6,000,000-ton mark for the second consecutive month. Little increase is anticipated this month, it was reported today by the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association.

ONE question naturally arose with regard to V. S. Pritchett's "The Spanish Temper" (see Page 7). Why, from a literary critic, novelist, short-story writer -- London contributor, also, to these pages -- a factual book on Spain?

IN some sixty thousand words, England's leading literary critic has written what is virtually a pocket analysis of the Spanish character. At the same time this short book manages to cover almost every conceivable aspect of contemporary Spain that cannot be found in any guide.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 24 -- Navy's defending national champion oarsmen won their twenty-second consecutive race, rowing home two and one-third lengths ahead of Syrasuse on the Severn River today.

Home building activity this year in Bergen County is expected to be 35 per cent ahead of 1953, according to a survey made by the North New Jersey Mortgage Associates. There were about 6,750 new dwellings constructed in the county last year.

THE story of "Confederate Agent" centers around Capt. Tom Hines, one of Morgan's Raiders. Hines was captured in 1863 when the thrust into Ohio failed so dismally. He staged a celebrated prison break and then became a secret agent, operating out of Canada all through the Northern states, but most especially in the Northwest.

Plans to give the Little Man an opportunity to invest in the American economy continue to multiply. The mutual funds -- already a $5,000,000,000 industry -- and the Monthly Investment Plan of the New York Stock Exchange have been growing.

The air-conditioning industry has come up with some statistics to support its claim that investment in an air-cooled system for the home pays off not only in added comfort but also in savings on cleaning expenses and drudgery and even in improved dispositions due to relief from summer-weather fretfulness.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, April 24 -- The somnolent Scioto River Valley of south central Ohio, which two world wars and one minor conflict had hardly touched, found itself thrust a year and a half ago into the atomic age. It is still struggling to catch up.

ALMOST twenty-five years ago amid the hostile Moros of the Philippine Islands a 40-year-old American missionary declared war on illiteracy. He's been on the winning side ever since, for through his efforts more than sixty million people have learned to read and write.
GETTING a rifle can be a boy's greatest thrill, and a sure sign of maturity. He assumes then the responsibility of learning to use it safely and sanely.
Racing away for nine goals in the second half, the touring Great Britain-Ireland women's lacrosse team defeated the 1953 United States twelve, 15 to 5, at Hunter College Field, the Bronx, yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Never classified as a power hitter, Joe DeMaestri, the Athletics' shortstop, fooled a lot of folks today when he slammed the homer that gave Eddie Joost's club a 1-0 victory over the world champion Yankees before 4,290 fans at Connie Mack Stadium.

GLADIOLUS planting generally starts in this area about May I and sueeession plantings are made until about June 1. In my experience bulbs planted before May 1 do not bloom any earlier than those set out later.

GLADIOLUS are undoubtedly the most popular bulbous plant in southern California as well as the entire Southwest. Even during the fall bulb season, when tulips, hyacinths and daffodils are grabbing all the publicity, gladiolus still out-sell tulips in many districts.

BELIZE, British Honduras, April 24 -- Unusual calm prevailed over British Honduras today as the crown colony prepared to carry out on Wednesday the most significant nation-wide election in its ninety-two-year British colonial history.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 -- A report by two members of Congress said today participation by the United States in the United Nations had more than justified its cost. It had also brought to light disillusioning evidence of unsympathetic and even inimical attitudes toward this nation among representatives of nations normally regarded as friends and allies, the report added.
The Board of Education was called upon yesterday to investigate "segregated" schools in New York City.

Workshops on the education of childrein with cerebral palsy will be held this summer at five graduate schools of education, Dr. Maurice H. Fouracre of the educational advisory board, United Cerebral Palsy, announced yesterday.
The savings and loan industry split last week on a principle of interest, advertising and Government control.

The new cargo-passener vessel Concordia Sun make her debut in this port last week. She is the second of three 6,700-deadweight-ton sister ships ordered by the Concordia Line for its cargo services from United States North Atlantic ports to the Mediterranean and the Persian Gulf.

MILWAUKEE, April 14 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, today dismissed the current Army-McCarthy committee hearings in Washington as "a waste of time." He said the inquiry was a "red winnow burlesque." He declared we hoped the hearings would end son so that he and the Army brass" could get back to their inspective jobs.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Capt. Frank LeCates held Penn to two hits today as Army capitalized on five Quaker errors for a 5-1 victory in its Ivy League opener. Penn's loss was its first after one victory and one tie in league play.

" SHILOH" and other works have given Shelby Foote a firm place among younger Deep South writers. The present volume is a collection of four short stories and three short novels, having a Faulknerian unity of locale and mood, but otherwise unrelated and sharply varying in quality.
For those who will soon be vacation-bound a check list of last-minute things to be done in closing the house, issued by the Minneapolis-Honeywell Company, may be helpful.

ADVENTUROUS rock gardeners now and then like to find something new to tuck between the crevices or on the flat areas of their rockery. And perhaps one of the most delightful and easy-to-establish groups of flowers are the tiny species iris, either the Iris pumila or some of the other kinds.

AFTER an uncertain beginning, "Anniversary Waltz" has started to pack them in. Every evening hundreds of theatregoers roar with delight when father and mother Walters scream at each other, yell at their impertinent children, bicker with their in-laws and smash the furniture.

Families in New York City bought 94,310 room air-conditioners last summer, according to reports from manufacturers to James O. Covington, manager of the adequate-wiring bureau of Consolidated Edison Company of New York.

Two unearned runs in the bottom of the eighth inning gave New York University a 5-4 baseball victory over its traditional rival, Fordham, yesterday at Ohio Field, the Bronx. It marked the winners' sixth triumph in eight starts.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 24 -- Work has started on a pump-turbine to be installed in the Hiwassee Dam on the Hiwassee River in the mountains of Western North Carolina.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 16 -- The Swedes and the Danes have agreed on the desirability of linking their countries by bridge or tunnel.

IF Kentuckians drank mint juleps as much as they talk about them, the world beyond our borders would be a sadder place. The state that makes most of the nation's bourbon (and claims it isn't really bourbon unless it comes from Kentucky) would have none left to export.

Somewhere in the Soviet Foreign Office there sits an unsung genius whose brilliant light has too long been hidden under a pud, the Russian equivalent of a bushel. He is a master of fantasy. One can only wonder whether he achieves his effects without using hasheesh or some similar aid.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A "point or order," under parliamentary procedure, is a means of calling the presiding officers' attention to some violation of the rules for carrying on the business at hand.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Expansion of industrial plants in the Chicago area continued to outpace last year's investment programs during March. For the third month announced projects topped plans projected in the same period last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 -- Except in parts of the Pacific Northwest the Army-McCarthy hearing fascinated the West Coast this week to a degree that appeared to make it at least a runner-up in interest to a national political convention.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox hammered out a 14-4 victory over Baltimore before 9,038 fans today to spoil Vern Bickford's first start in the American League.

The operation of a coal-fired furnace, from feeding the coal to removing the ashes, recently has been made completely automatic. The problem of ash removal, the last obstacle to be met by the industry, has now been solved with the introduction earlier this month of the Vacuum Ashaway system.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- No President in recent years has faced more difficult and more desperate political problems than President Eisenhower faces in these warm Washington days.

Two major Jewish relief agencies, in separate reports yesterday, underscored the need for aiding Jewish men, women and children throughout the world. One warned that a serious lack of funds was curtailing programs of resettlement and rehabilitation among newcomers to Israel.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Major upsets by Manhattan and Cornell, both at the expense of Morgan State, and the creation of the meet's only new record, by Fordham, provided the chief items of interest today as the sixtieth annual Penn Relay carnival came to a close at Franklin Field.

Once bitten by the bug of wanting to win championships, the speed-boat daredevil, thereafter is never satisfied with mere cups, bowls, plaques and other trophy loot. He wants to be champion of something or other, if only of Mud Pond, but preferably with a national title of importance.
Three new automatic electric coffee percolators, recently introduced in the stores, make one common claim -- that of producing better coffee faster than any previous models.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Six accused "principals" in the Army-McCarthy controversy and their seven Senatorial judges went on trial all together this week before a jury of the American people.
TRENTON, April 24 -- Democratic and Republican leaders from all parts of New Jersey will come to this city Thursday for the annual state conventions of their respective parties.

OXFORD, Pa., April 24 -- Lincoln University, the first institution established to offer degrees to Negroes, will observe the 100th anniversary of the issuance of its charter on Thursday.

CLARKSBURG, W. Va. -- From now through the entire month of May the mountain sections of Virginia and West Virginia will be worth driving miles to see. PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- A billion-dollar twenty-five-year expressway plan for this metropolitan section of the Delewaye Valley was proposed today by the Greater Philadelphia - Delaware - South Jersey Council.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 24 -- The foreign ministers of the North Atlantic alliance heard some hard military facts of life in a confidential briefing here today.

THERE is no question of Gore Vidal's talent, his promise, or the possibility, still, of his development. The prelude to "Messiah" is an attractive essay on modern times, witty and discerning. But I am sorry to say that the novel itself is a flat disappointment.
Judging from the 1953 and early 1954 crop of model homes, the housing development builders are striving more and more to provide special details that will appeal to the individual family.

THE American tourist in Britain is commonly regarded by the British, and by Americans who live there, as a man who needs a friend. He is notorious for spending too much money and getting too little for it. The main reason for his footless extravagance (aside from the American habit of expecting money to work miracles) is that he doesn't know what to look for or how to get it.

IN The Sunday Times of June 8, 1952, you published a beautifully written article, "Perfect Village in Southern France," by Michael L. Hoffman. I was haunted by its appealing charm until last summer when I had the good fortune to journey to Europe and while in Nice made a special trip to Auribeau, "the perfect village."
A scientific method of estimating in advance the operating cost of an air-conditioning system in the home has been worked out by the Carrier Corporation after two years of research.

With the arrival of spring, bright yellow jonquils and red tulips many homeowners begin to think of the paint jobs that ought to be done to brighten their homes. Some of the new paints have been developed for specialized uses to help make this chore a little easier.

GLADIOLUS do well in Colorado. Any variety that can be grown in other areas flowers here too. The bulbs may be planted any time from the middle of April until the first of June. The earlier plantings should be made at least four inches deep to avoid damage from late frosts.

ONE of the most controversial figures of our time, Korean President Syngman Rhee has been freely discussed and freely denounced by a large number of persons, most of whom know little about him. It was imperative that there appear an authoritative and intimate biography that could show the man as he is.
TRENTON, April 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner will submit to the Legislature on Monday a supplemental budget message. He will deliver it in person at 4 P. M. before a joint session.
The current interest and pleasure in the use of material for material's sake in today's homes is reflected in its woven floor coverings.
Princeton's lightweight varsity crew successfully began another racing season by beating Columbia on the Harlem River yesterday. The Tigers won by more than four lengths.

OF all the many kinds of violets found throughout the world, perhaps the most appealing cultivated one is the sweet violet, Viola odorata. Its blossoms are delightfully fragrant and exquisite in form and detail.
Business has continued to improve this month, says the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

Why do Soviet citizens change sides in the Cold War though they know this means giving up family, friends, and country? This is obviously a key question raised by recent news of the voluntary surrender of Soviet spies in Germany and Australia.
The world's first aluminum smelting plant to use electric power produced in generators fueled by lignite was formally dedicated at Rockdale, Tex., yesterday.

One of the major problems of the home carpenter, the lack of a separate workroom, has been taken into consideration by the manufacturers of tools. The Delta Tool Company, for instance, at the Do-It-Yourself Show held here last month, displayed its workshop on casters that can be rolled into a closet when not in use.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- Senator Frederick G. Payne, Republican of Maine, said today Senate housing scandal investigators should find out whether there had been "manipulation" of Government loan appraisals on one-family houses.

The "Corporal" Guided Missile is the Army's newest weapon. It is equipped with either an atomic or a conventional warhead. A surface-to-surface guided missile -- capable of battering tactical targets far beyond the ranges of artillery or the new 280-mm. gun and the "Honest John" rocket -- the "Corporal" enables a field commander to strike selected targets 100 miles behind an enemy.

The sale of synthetic detergents surpassed that of soap (classed by industry as a detergent) for the first time last year. Hints on the use of the synthetic detergents or, as the public calls them, detergents are given by Mrs. Elizabeth Conrad of the College of Home Economics, Cornell University.

The National Broadcasting Company's television network beginning tomorrow will stop carrying live pickups from the Army-McCarthy hearings in Washington, because "it cost us a lot of money last week" and might cost advertising goodwill.

GENEVA, April 24 -- The foreign ministers of the Big Four will have to meet beforehand and agree on who is to preside over the Far Eastern conference if it is to open on schedule at 3 P. M. on Monday.
DES MOINES, April 24 -- A world record-breaking exhibition shot-put and the fastest distance medley relay ever run thrilled 15,000 sun-bathed tracks fans in the forty-fifth Drake Relays today.

Frank Selvy of Furman University was the top draft choice of the National Basketball Association yesterday. He was selected by the Baltimore Bullets who finished last in the Eastern Division this season.

A Federal agency to guard against letting children under the age of 16 read books by authors accused of Communist sympathy was advocated yesterday by Charles Lewis, Brooklyn County Commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

The art of painting murals will be set forth on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. in the weekly art lecture at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The lecturer, Stuyvesant Van Veen, a member of the City College faculty, is a mural painter whose New York historical scenes, decorate several buildings in the city.
Arthur S. Flemming, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, declared last night that our defense program must be kept "ongoing and expanding" as a deterrent against Soviet aggression.

A RECENT student safari of Clarence H. White's photography classes at Ohio University, Athens, Ohio, to studios, laboratories, and other places of photographic activity in Washington and New York was highlighted by a dinner meeting and "bull session" here in which the students received advice from a group of invited photographers and editors on what they could expect from the practical world they will enter upon graduation.

ON the whole, "Mine the Harvest" is the finest of Edna Millay's books. It consists of sixty-six new poems edited by her sister, Norma Millay, who also contributes an informative preface. The clear sayings, the sure and unpretentious metrical technique, the singing lines bring the poet back from death in the full stature of her genius.

DURING the Vicksburg siege a Billy Yank wrote his home folk: "Gen. Grant came along the line last night. He had on his old clothes and was alone. He sat down on the ground and talked with the boys with less reserve than many a little puppy of a Lieutenant."
LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, April 22 -- A radical experiment to head off communism and combat race prejudice is starting in the Limpopo Valley, 150 miles north of Lourenco Marques.

Rabbi Jack J. Cohen, educational director of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism, 15 West Eighty - sixth Street, preached a Passover sermon there yesterday morning on "The Desert as a Religious Symbol."

MOSCOW, April 24 -- Russian Orthodox faithful poured into churches tonight for Easter. More churches are open, more priests have been consecrated and more believers, young and old, are participating in the ceremonial than ever before since the Bolshevik Revolution.

Two little Malay tapirs made their debut yesterday in the elephant house of the Bronx Zoo and were well received by the public. Because the weather was considerably cooler than that of the tapirs' native jungles, Robert McClung, acting curator of mammals, kept the animals indoors.
Sixty million Americans moved their clocks forward one hour during the night to go on daylight saving time.

We have come a long distance since the husband's last chore of the evening was to empty the drip-pan under the icebox. That messy item long ago made way for the mechanical refrigerator, which, perfected some years back, seems currently in the state of becoming ultrarefined.

Glimpses of a new statistical study of consumer buying habits were provided last week by Arthur O. Dietz, president of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation, one of the largest specialized finance companies in the country.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Concern over the destructive threat of the hydrogen bomb was evidenced today as 3,000 delegates gathered for the forty-second annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

LONDON, April 24 -- The British delegation enters the Geneva conference with the Soviet Union and Communist China still faintly optimistic that realistic negotiations on a settlement of the Far Eastern crisis can be started. Otherwise Britain sees the conference as a chance to probe the tender spots of the Sino-Russian alliance.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Although the Eisenhower Administration is dedicated to the cause of anti-communism, it has taken a strong position against outlawing the Communist party.
TRENTON, April 24 -- The new Garden State Parkway will probably be open to traffic from Irvington in Essex County to Absecon, just west of Atlantic City, on July 14.

The placid, old, Swiss city of Geneva last week buzzed with extraordinary preparations. Sometime this week, possibly tomorrow, foreign ministers from nineteen countries including Communist China are to convene in Geneva at the invitation of the Big Four to consider the question of Korea and Indo-China.

ARBOR DAY, America's annual tree day, is observed in every state, but, owing to wide differences in climate between the North, South and West, it cannot be observed on the same day of the year throughout the nation.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 -- Organized labor in California is choosing up sides for the primary election of June 8.

Ions are always in a state of electrical, excitement. The negative ones try to cap ture an electron to make good their deficiency, the positive ones to get rid of their excess.

WHITE PLAINS -- Westchester's parkways, once considered models for all the world to copy, are outmoded. With the steady increase of traffic, mounting collision fatalities and tightening bottlenecks north of New York City pointing to a real crisis, the county has called in engineering concerns to analyze the parkway system and draft remedies.

Sixty thousand troops, several hundred aircraft and thousands of vehicles will participate this week in the main phase of Exercise Flash Burn, one of the largest Army maneuvers ever held in this country.

THE Argus 300-Watt Automatic Projector for 2x2 slides is announced by Argus Cameras, Inc., of Ann Arbor, Mich. The $66.50 projector incorporates an automatic changer that operates with one stroke to change slides and advance the magazine.

GENEVA, April 24 -- Chou En-lai, Premier and Foreign Minister of Communist China, and Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, were the first leaders of principal delegations to reach here today for the Geneva conference.

PLANTING of gladiolus starts between March 1 and March 15 in this part of the country. Succession plantings may be continued until July 1, although the majority of the professional growers believe that amateurs plant only once or twice.

At a meeting of the American Association of Anatomists at the University of Texas Medical Center in Galveston, Dr. Benton R. Lutz turned up with a paper by himself and Dr. George P. Fulton on their microscopic study at Boston University of the cheek pouch of the hamster. The pouch is so thin that when a light is placed behind it the blood can be followed.

Acting Hospitals Commissioner Maurice H. Matzkin said last week that he had asked superintendents of all the municipal hospitals for prompt reports on possible violations of the state workmen's compensation law.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 24 -- In a record vote following the most heated verbal warfare in the state's educational history, Utah residents rendered a split decision this week in balloting to raise taxes for school purposes and thereby provide salary increases for teachers.

A lovelorn 15-year-old boy threatened to leap from the roof of a five-story Bronx apartment house yesterday. He was dissuaded by a veteran police sergeant who told him over and over that "women aren't worth it."

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 24 -- The Smith College board of trustees has approved unanimously the report of a joint trustee-faculty committee that there was no evidence of subversive activity on the college's campus.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Mow the lawn and repeat on an average of once a week, particularly if it rains. From April until July set the mower to cut at a height of one and one-half inches for new and old lawns. Clippings may be left to decompose. Occasionally when they are extra long or wet, they should be raked up and added to the compost pile.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 24 -- Very little interest is manifested in the television sessions of the McCarthy-Army hearing in this largest city of the Senator's home state.

ONE of the most ambitious programs of jazz reissues ever undertaken by a major recording company has been inaugurated on Victor's new label, "X." The series is planned to run to 100 ten-inch LP's to be released over a period of three years, returning to the active catalogue much of the jazz material recorded by Victor and Bluebird during the Twenties and Thirties.
American book publishers were urged last night by Prof. Howard Mumford Jones of Harvard University to lead the publishing world out of "confusion of purpose and the climate of fear."

NICE, France, April 24 -- The need for a union of all democratic forces in France and Italy was agreed upon today by 100 European anti-Communists as the major means of effectively meeting the Communist threat to democracy.

Teachers College, Columbia University will hold an open house Friday, April 30, at 2:30 P. M., for those interested in careers in education. Dean Hollis L. Caswell will discuss job opportunities in the profession. Other teaching specialists will provide current, information about teaching private and public schools, guidance and administrative positions, and work with gifted or retarded children.
More efficient insulation methods used for medium-priced houses are helping to effect economies in air-conditioning for families that must watch their household costs carefully.

LONDON -- Third - class travel on the Continent -- by train or bus -- can be hazardous. But one thing is sure, it is never dull. One short ride on a third-class ticket can give you more of an insight into the hearts and habits of a country than ten such trips on a de luxe train.
NEW HAVEN, April 24 -- Yale University will run a "classroom" on two days of next week in the Midwest, 600 miles from its campus.

BERLIN, April 24 -- The official party newspaper of the East German Communists charged today that Nikolai E. Khokhlov, who had said he was a former Soviet secret police assasin, was in fact an emigre Russian.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Strong performances in the latter half of both races enabled Cardinal Hayes and Mount St. Michael to capture the high school two-mile and one-mile titles, respectively, as the sixtieth annual Pann Relays ended today at Franklin Field.

ST. LOUIS, April 24 (UP) -- Harvey Haddix pitched a six-hitter and Wally Moon scored Haddix twice with clutch hits as the St. Louis Cardinals coasted to a 7-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 24 -- If newspaper editorials are any criterion, then Texans are somewhat indifferent to the current hearings on the McCarthy-Army controversy.

Last summer only a handful of Peter Cooper Village's 2,700-odd families had air-conditioning. They had certificates from physicians stating that air-conditioners were essential to their health. All other tenants in the sprawling Metropolitan Life Insurance Company apartment development were denied the blessings air-conditioning brings.

ANOTHER big-game fishing season is in the offing. The giant tuna will make their appearance in southern waters next month and form the vanguard of the big-fish migrations which will sweep northward until they lure anglers to the Maritime Provinces in September.
JACK GOULD'S article in last Sunday's Times about "The Crisis in U. H. F." should bring every FM broadcaster and FM listener to the barricades, fighting mad.
