The Federal Maritime Board has taken up a rate protest with the Continental, North Atlantic Westbound Freight Conference. The protest was lodged by the National Button Association. Negotiations are on an informal basis.
The substantial eradication of polio appears to be a happy prospect, causing the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis to announce its consideration of additional lines of service to humanity.

The New York Historical Society at 170 Central Park West attracted 88,257 visitors in 1953, according to the institution's annual report, issued yesterday. This represents an increase of 17 per cent over figures for the previous year.

Two colleges with adjoining campuses in Geneva, N. Y. -- Hobart College and William Smith College -- presented a program yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The thirty-five women of the William Smith Chorus and the thirty-five men of the Hobart Chorus each sang a group by themselves, but for most of the program they sang together under the banner of the Schola Cantorum, a joint institution.

AN article entitled "Our Youngest Intellectuals" in The Times Magazine for Oct. 5, 1941, described Hunter's first experimental kindergarten class for exceptionally gifted children. There were twenty-seven of them, all aged about 5 1/2 years.

LOUIS M'HENRY HOWE had just passed 40 when he first met Franklin D. Roosevelt and decided to make him President. At the time Roosevelt was hardly 30 years old and holding his first political office as State Senator from Dutchess County.
CINCINNATI, April 24 (AP) -- Wally Post hit a home run in the last half of the ninth with two on today to give the Cincinnati Redlegs a 6-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
" The first line of defense in curbing household insects is careful housekeeping," Dr. Ralph E. Heal, executive secretary of the National Pest Control Association, said in a recent interview.

Much material from many parts of the world will be on public auction this week, but Americana will take the spotlight here in two sales at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 24 -- The first annual John Acropolis Foundation award will be presented to Supreme Court Referee Lee Parsons Davis at a dinner-meeting Thursday night in Glen Island Casino at New Rochelle.

IN tribute to Columbia University, this year celebrating its two hundredth anniversary, the Lucullus Circle recently held a dinner of gastronomic importance at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. One might comment here that any gathering of the circle makes news in the realm of the table arts, and this one especially because of its topical theme.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 24 -- Dick Savitt, former Wimbledon champion playing in his second tournament since late 1952, closed with a 6-0 fourth set against Vic Seixas today to enter the final of the River Oaks tennis tournament.

Since the bathroom is the one room in the home with stationary "furnishings," homemakers must depend upon accessories to achieve a refreshing change. Towel holders in unusual shapes, whimsical shower curtains, baskets, hampers, stools and decorated ceramic tiles are some of the items that alone or combined may achieve this end.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 24 -- President Eisenhower issued a proclamation today calling for the observance of Citizenship Day on Sept. 17.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 24 (AP) -- The French set up a new defense line today in a desperate attempt to bolster Dienbienphu's crumbling northwest barrier. Word spread that a French-Laotian column thrusting up from the south might try to relieve pressure on the embattled garrison.
Stockholders of the $38,000,000 Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway Company at the annual meeting on May 11 will vote for one of two propositions:

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Manufacturers in the Philadelphia metropolitan area still expect to spend $372,000,000 on plant and equipment during the year ending in September. This represents an increase of 18 per cent over outlays during the preceding twelve months.
An outgrown water system, receiving an inadequate dole of rainfall ever since last June, accounts for the present threat of a water shortage in New York City.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 20 -- Less than 25 per cent of the voters are expected to ballot in the May 4 primaries in Indiana.

KIRUNA, Sweden, April 12 -- The Province of Norrland, the "roof" of Sweden, has been Communist-proofed. It had long been a hotbed of Red intrigue.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- A larger number of Negro and white families live in the same blocks here as neighbors than is commonly believed, the Philadelphia Commission on Human Relations said today.
LONDON, April 24 (AP) -- Wolverhampton's Wanderers became the English Soccer League champions today for the first time in their 66 years.
Student panelists on The New York Times Youth Forum differed yesterday on whether a tough or conciliatory policy was advisable in dealing with communism at home and abroad.

TODAY, with so much attention focused on juvenile delinquency, this book offers an interesting study of a boy whose character has been shaped by life in the Toronto slums. At 15, Dave Sloane, like the other members of his gang, is a cop hater. His father dies.

SPRING bulbs are blooming in gardens everywhere throughout the country. Of the various kinds which were planted last autumn or in previous autumns, some have already finished flowering. And although daffodils and hyacinths are now making great splashes of color under trees, if they have been naturalized in quantity, there are still many more kinds of daffodils and tulips to prolong the bulb-flowering season in a perennial border.

During the next two years, the University of Pittsburgh will test a new educational program designed to provide the undergraduate student with greater intellectual skills, improve the quality of his Judgments, and increase his knowledge of the methods of science and of acquiring an understanding of man.

CAIRO, April 24 -- Two members of Egypt's most prominent publishing family were indicted today by the Revolutionary Tribunal on charges that they had committed acts against the interests of the nation and sought to corrupt the Government's machinery.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24 (AP) -- Harvard and Yale won three relays each today in the first Eastern Relay carnival in which no official team points were kept and no title awarded.

THE automotive and oil industries are looking forward to the lessons in mechanical refinements and fuel improvement expected to result from the grueling tests during the preliminaries and actual contest at the thirty-eighth annual 500-mile race at Indianapolis Motor Speedway May 31.
Eighteen American and six foreign-flag tankers have been added in the last two months to the world's growing fleet of laid-up tankers, according to a report yesterday by the Charles R. Weber Company.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24 -- Bob Kessler and Edgar Felton of Harvard combined to pitch a no-hitter today as the Crimson defeated Columbia, 1 to 0, in an Eastern League baseball game at Soldiers Field.

Apartment builders, recognizing the growing demand for air-conditioning in multi-family structures, are making provision for easy installation of individually controlled room coolers for use by prospective tenants, points out Sarah Tobias, head of the renting and management division of J. H. Taylor Management Corporation.

Homeowners or apartment dwellers planning to install window-type room air-conditioners should be certain that the type and size of the unit or units they buy are right for the job to be performed, points out L. P. Hanson, vice president in charge of sales for the United States Air Conditioning Corporation.

ROME, April 24 -- The European Defense Community Treaty is so important to Italy that if would be senseless to subordinate its ratification to the solution of the Trieste problem, Premier Mario Scelba stated today.

The Old Guard of the City of New York, bedecked in bearskin busbies and bemedaled blue and white uniforms, was reviewed yesterday afternoon at City Hall Plaza. The ceremonies marked the 128th anniversary of the formation of the first fully equipped and uniformed unit of the State Militia.

THE big retrospective exhibition at the Diploma Gallery, London, of the works of Augustus John has brought into prominence a problem that has become acute since the modern movement in art established itself about forty years ago.

YONKERS, April 24 (AP) -- Miss Mamie made her first Eastern start a winning one tonight at Yonkers Raceway. She won the $3,000 New Castle Pace in 2:05 1-5 by three quarters of a length before 29,076 spectators.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 -- For the writers of political science textbooks this week provided a classic example of the rule that anything that happens at the United Nations is tied to almost everything else that happens at the United Nations, and to a lot of things outside it.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Senate investigators have deferred until next week a decision whether to accept monitored records of telephone conversations as evidence in hearings on the McCarthy-Army controversy.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, April 25 (AP) -- President Syngman Rhee said today South Korea could accept only one solution at the Geneva conference starting tomorrow -- the withdrawal of Communist troops from North Korea and a nation-wide spring election under United Nations supervision.

RONNY GRAHAM, the young man who helped himself to fame by contributing words, music and sketches to "New Faces of 1952" -- he also was one of the revue's major comedians -- appeared to be on the verge of a new assignment at press time.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 21 -- Ohio Republicans are heading for the May 4 primaries in an increasingly bitter fight.

M. Coldstream Guards, who was stationed there.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- In spite of the more immediately pressing distractions of the Army-McCarthy feud and the tense uncertainty as to where events in Indo-China are leading, Congressional minds are heavily preoccupied these days with the approaching election campaign. All 435 seats in the House and thirty-five of those in the Senate are up for grabs.

There will be a national election in Argentina today. A Vice President, half of the members of Congress and a great many provincial and local officials will be chosen. No one expects President Peron's party to lose. The opposition Radical party has been doing its best to campaign Under the familiar restrictions: e. g., the radio is barred to all but peronista candidates.
Nineteen sporting men who set out last night by private limousine for a quiet game of craps ended up the evening with a free ride to the station house in a patrol wagon.

LONDON, April 24 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden returned to England tonight for an impromptu and urgent discussion with Prime Minister Churchill about the crisis in French foreign policy. Mr. Eden returned as the position of the French garrison at Dienbienphu in Indo-China became increasingly precarious.

WHEN mothers get together and begin comparing notes, it's a rare conversation that doesn't have its full share of concern about the children. More often than not, when some especially trying bit of behavior is under consideration, some mother in the group will comment philosophically, "Oh, well. It's just a phase. He'll grow out of it."

MIXING fact with a little fiction in an unconventional manner, Hans Baumann has written an informal account of certain paintings of the Ice Age which includes elements of anthropology, archaeology and art. MEXICO CITY, April 25 -- There has been a continuing run on the peso since it was devalued last week - end, reflecting what observers have described as he worst crisis of confidence to confront a Mexican Government in many years.
FLORENCE, April 25 -- The eighteenth annual fair and market for artisans and handicraft workers opened here today.
ROME, April 25 -- Two hundred political prisoners freed by amnesty last December will have to go back to prison, the highest Italian court has decided.
Roving squads of Sanitation Department inspectors will carry their campaign against littering into two new areas in Manhattan and the Bronx this morning.

The March 15 figures on consumer prices, as released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, show them at the lowest level since July, 1953. The latest figure is 114.8, which is two-tenths of 1 point under February and six-tenths below the all-time high of 115.4 reached in October. It is 1.2 points higher than the level of a year earlier.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 25 (AP) -- Two flying horses from California, one a long-legged husky and the other a half-pint gray midget, were the talk of the stable area today as Churchill Downs buzzed with excitement over the eightieth Kentucky Derby.
LONDON, April 25 -- Yugoslavia has made a new proposal for a division of the disputed territory of Trieste with Italy, Yugoslav circles said here today.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Washington shelled Leo Kiely for five runs in the eighth inning to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 5 -- 1, today behind the 7-hit pitching of Chuck Stobbs.

Retailers should urge mill men, manufacturers and suppliers to start a $1,000,000 public relations campaign for the men's clothing and furnishings industry, Ben Goldman, president of Eagle Clothes, Inc., said last night.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -The Census Bureau said today that President Eisenhower's proposal to lower the voting age to 18 would add about 6,330,000 voters.

The eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building for 114 families at 275 Central Park West, southwest corner of Eighty-eighth Street, has been sold by the Life Holding Corporation to an investing client of Roy Berlin, attorney, for cash over a first mortgage of $1,833,000 and a second mortgage of $46,500.

Behind gaudy pitching by Sal Maglie and Johnny Antonelli, the Giants yesterday completed a three-game whitewashing of the Phillies. The special feature of the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Dimitri Mitropoulos at Carnegie Hall Saturday night was the Concerto for Piano and Orchestra, No. 1, in G by Everett Helm. Leonid Hambro was the soloist in the work, which received its American premiere.

ST. LOUIS, April 25 (UP) -Jim Pendleton dropped Red Schoendienst's twelfth-inning fly ball with the bases loaded and two out to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 7-6 victory over the Milwaukee Braves at Busch Stadium today.
BUENOS AIRES, Monday, April 26 -- Three persons were shot to death in Corrientes Province north of here as Argentina in a nation-wide election gave President Juan D. Peron a clear-cut victory.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau today said he doesn't plan to place Red Sox pitching ace Mel Parnell on the disabled list, although the slender southpaw will be out of action for at least six weeks due to a broken ulna bone in his left forearm.

The horse racing activity in this section will be transferred today to Belmont Park. There the Westchester Racing Association will run its spring meeting of forty-two days, with the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, June 12, serving as the climax.

The raising of the money for philanthropic purposes in this city often seems to be a complex and confusing process. The appeals are many, for the need is great. One campaign that helps to simplify matters, however, is that of the Greater New York Fund, which opens its annual drive today.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Rains have been spotty in the hard winter wheat sections of the Southwest, but on the whole moisture conditions have improved to an extent that has relieved much of the anxiety.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Edmund F. Mansure's job is to get the Government to use more of what it has and buy less of what it does not need. It is a monumental job but Mr. Mansure said today he was making progress.
GENEVA, April 25 -- The world's diplomats meet here tomorrow in an atmosphere as different from Panmunjom as the summit of Mont Blanc is from the mudflats of Korea's Han River Valley.

CINCINNATI, April 25 (AP) -The Chicago Cubs and the Cincinnati Redlegs split a doubleheader today, the Cubs taking the first game, 9 -- 2, behind the six-hit pitching of Bubba Church and the Redlegs winning the second, 3 -- 2, on the four-hit hurling of a rookie righthander, Art Fowler.
ALBANY, April 25 -- Motorists will dine and dance along the New York State Thruway, when it is completed, to the tune of $21,000,000 a year.
CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- The Chicago Sun-Times and television station WBKB today announced they would share expenses of live telecasts of the remaining McCarthy-Army hearings "as a public service."
Seamen, uncertain of their future, afloat, are turning to shore-side work in increasing numbers, according to the annual report of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan said today he would ask President Eisenhower to set up a $1,000,000,000 highway construction program to provide roads for evacuating residents of large industrial areas in the event of a hydrogen bomb attack.

MURRAY HILL, N. J., April 25 -- A solar battery, the first of its kind, which converts useful amounts of the sun's radiation directly and efficiently into electricity, has been constructed here by the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

Every hour the sun pours upon the earth the energy-equivalent of twenty-one billion tons of coal. The state of New Mexico alone can supply from solar radiation over ten trillion horse-power-hours a year. The land of the temperate and tropical zones is flooded with more energy from the sun than mankind has utilized in the form of fuel, falling water, uranium and muscle since it came out of the trees a million years ago.
The champion of the United States win play the champion of Wimbledon at the Town Tennis Club tonight.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., April 25 (AP) -- Averell Harriman, former Director for Mutual Security said today "it's high time" that President Eisenhower took action to attain "domestic unity."

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, April 25 -- Britain's offer to pay u30,000,000 ($84,000,000) in gold to extreme creditors in the European Payments Union was not received with enthusiasm here. Nevertheless it will probably be accepted by Dutch authorities because Holland is anxious for prolongation of the E. P. U.
The Eintracht eleven of Astoria, L. I., nipped the New York Americans, 4 -- 3, to take the lead in the third round of the Lewis Cup soccer competition at Sterling Oval, Bronx, yesterday.

MADRID, April 24 -- United States aid to enable Spain to produce jet fighter planes was reported today to be under discussion by Spanish Air Force officers and the United States military mission here.

The complications that may result from lack of care of asthmatic conditions in childhood are discussed in a new brochure prepared by the American Foundation for Allergic Diseases. The 12-page leaflet emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and proper treatment of any allergic condition.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Experts here believe Communist China's policy at Geneva will be to avoid a settlement in Indo-China.

State Controller J. Raymond McGovern said yesterday that this city had more than $39,600,000 (rather than $30,900,000) available to avert extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services. He had estimated the lower figure April 13 in a letter to Governor Dewey.

The National Broadcasting Company and the New York Music Critics Circle united yesterday to honor the Swiss-American composer, Ernest Bloch.
FREEPORT, Tex., April 25 -Construction of a $3,000,000 plant to produce soda ash will begin here this fall, officials of the Dow Chemical Company have announced.

Two men were shot and wounded at 5 A. M. yesterday in the Trap Door, a social club at 96 Clinton Street. Subsequently, the police booked four friends of the men on malicious mischief charges growing out of an earlier fracas at the Club 176 on Worth Street.
Michael J. Quill agreed to talk peace yesterday in New York's newest transit crisis but continued to use the language of strike.

The Indian Head Knolls development for 200 families in Kings Park, L. I., was formally opened yesterday with the display of two model houses at Avenue B and East Northport Road. The houses are priced at $11,390 for ranch style and at $11,990 for split-level design.

To complete a memorial to former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, an appeal for 15,000 $1 contributions will be made here next month by the La Guardia Memorial Association.

Edward Curley, president of the New York Chapter of the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists, bestowed its Quadragesimo Anno medal posthumously on Senator Robert F. Wagner at a communion breakfast of the association at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday. Mayor Wagner, son of the Senator, accepted it.

PARIS, April 25 -- A French delegation headed by Foreign Minister Georges Bidault departed for Geneva tonight in an almost desperate state of mind. Some of the Ministers believed the delegation might seek contact with the Vietminh as soon as the conference opened with the hope of saving the situation for France by direct negotiation with her Indo-China enemies.
A 25-year-old ex-convict confessed yesterday, according to the police, the killing of a teen-age girl at an all-night party in a one-room West Side apartment.

LONDON, April 25 -- The Easter holiday has had no effect in checking the upward movement in the stock markets. Industrial ordinary shares, according to The Financial Times index, have in the last few days soared to a new high record and gilt-edge securities have reached their highest since January, 1951.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25 -- Susan Hayward, Henry King, the director, and a group of camera and sound technicians are at work on location in the Valley of a Thousand Hills in Africa, filming backgrounds for Twentieth Century-Fox' "Untamed."

The state-city debate over the question whether the city can finance a $99,000,000 budget increase for the next fiscal year without imposing some new taxes continues, and in fact grows more heated. The State Controller, J. Raymond McGovern, pointed out again yesterday the availability of certain reserve funds, as well as the habitual city underestimate of general fund yield from taxes other than real estate, as a means of avoiding new taxes.
Brightly printed summer scarves that add glamour and gaiety to simple dresses can be fashioned into amusing as well as important accessories.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The vaccination of more than half a million children in forty-five states with the new anti-polio vaccine will begin at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning in Fairfax County, Va.

The trend in cotton prices in the domestic market last week generally was firm. Final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange ended $1.45 a bale higher to 5 cents a bale lower. Cotton textile mill buying was reported to be the main factor in the higher prices.

The Municipal Art Society of New York will present on Wednesday its annual Medal of Honor to Arthur F. Brinckerhoff, landscape architect, for his "untiring devotion in encouraging and preserving the order and beauty of our city."
Moves by California growers to obtain import quotas on figs were disclosed by foreign-trade sources here last week.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today there had been a "greater than seasonal" increase in agricultural exports during February.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams declared yesterday that it was the "inescapable obligation" of the city to pay its policemen a salary high enough to provide old-age security and to attract persons of high caliber to the force.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 24 -- Turkey's fledgling labor movement has openly attacked the Government prior to the general election May 2, and has threatened to provoke "collective disputes" unless its wage demands are met.

The average man today, considering himself as a "live pawn in a chess game over which he has no control," is in danger of losing his individualism to collectivism, the Rev. Maurice A. Dawkins declared yesterday in his farewell sermon at the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.

GENEVA, April 25 -- The United States Government is prepared to go along with any French efforts to terminate the war in Indo-China if they do not demonstrably affect American interests in the western Pacific.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The United States Office of Education allotted today an additional $6,162,590 of school construction funds for "Federally affected" areas.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. urged yesterday that Secretary of State Dulles propose at the Geneva conference the withdrawal of opposing forces from Indo-China and the establishment of a United Nations trusteeship over the area.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 25 -- Riviera Mann, a 6-year-old bay gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Bernie Mann of Port Washington, L. I., was crowned open jumper champion of Boulder Brook club's annual spring horse show tonight as the two-day fixture came to a close.

As yet the moment has not come to take a stand on all the principles of scholarly veracity and integrity involved in the case of Dr. Robert Oppenheimer, but the moment has come to raise protest against the application to this case of a most revolting kind of metaphor.

MOSCOW, April 25 -- The Australian Charge d' Affaires, Brian C. Hill, and his five staff members were packed tonight and ready to leave Moscow. However, they got no exit visas from the Soviet Foreign Office and no railroad tickets from the official In-tourist travel agency.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 25 -- The United States has approved a request from Iraq for military aid and has agreed to furnish it unconditionally, the Iraqi Government announced today.

Both radio and television sales organizations began extensive promotion this week for their media following the reports of the American Newspaper Publishers Association meeting here. Most notable were the first steps for television's own advertising bureau.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Eisenhower closed out his vacation at Augusta, Ga., tonight and returned to the White House.
GENEVA, April 25 -- The foreign ministers of nineteen countries sit down at a conference table tomorrow in an effort to find a solution of the Korean problem.

The joint recital given at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon by Norma Jean, soprano, and Kenneth Lane, tenor, was interesting to observers of vocalism as exemplifying a considerable number of the faults most frequently encountered in our present age of inferior singing.
PITTSBURGH, April 25 -- Not too long ago steel people expected a moderate seasonal increase in steel activity. It did not turn out that way, so pessimism set in.

CHICAGO, April 25 (UP) -- Ferris Fain slashed a clothesline single in the last of the ninth inning with the bases loaded to give the Chicago White Sox a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles and a sweep of a double-header today in foggy Comiskey Park.

DETROIT, April 25 (AP) -- Outfielder Dave Philley broke up a three-hour and forty-five-minute struggle by slamming a two-run homer in the tenth inning today to give the Cleveland Indians a 10-9 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 25 -The latest in textile processing machinery, equipment and supplies, designed to help American mills meet global competition, with better goods at lower cost, was unveiled here today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 25 -- A series of informal talks was held in Paris last week ostensibly to simplify deliberations at the special sessions of the managing board of the European Payments Union opening on Monday. The board sessions will decide on action for enabling the E. P. U. to be prolonged beyond June 30.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said over the week-end that the American public should know the full objectives of Great Britain in reopening the London gold market and "gauge our economy accordingly."
PITTSBURGH, April 25 -- Manager Walter (Smokey) Alston gave his Dodgers the most startling shake-up they have had in years after they had lost the first game to the Pirates today by a 9-3 score.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 25 (UP) -- The Mrs. America of 1955 is Mrs. Madison Jennings, tall St. Louis blonde, who won the award over fortynine other contestants last night.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- Walter P. Reuther summoned 300 leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today to a "national full employment conference" here May 11-12.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The State Department confirmed today that an agreement had been reached through which the United States might supply military aid to Iraq.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Jim McDonald, with help from Johnny Sain, downed the Athletics, 6 -- 1, but young Bob Grim could not be saved in the second game and the Yankees had to settle for a split at Connie Mack Stadium today.

Caroline Taylor, a young pianist from North Carolina with a light, sure touch and exceptional musical sensibility, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. It proved to be one of the most successful debuts of the season.
Nine new films, including imports from France England, Italy and Russia, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

CHICAGO, April 25 -- The volume of soybean trading here last week was the heaviest on record. Purchases of soybean futures accounted for more than half of the total transactions on the Board of Trade during the week, being 168,586,000 bushels out of a gross of 303,000,000 bushels.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr. shrugged off the challenge of more famous golfers today and won the $10,000 top prize in the $35,000 tournament of champions here.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 25 -- Turkey has assured Italy that she does not intend to proceed with the conclusion of a military alliance with Yugoslavia and Greece until Rome's dispute with Belgrade over Trieste has been resolved.

GENEVA, April 25 -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden will call on Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov tomorrow morning in an attempt to end the procedural difficulties that are threatening to delay the start of the Far Eastern conference.
AMMAN, Jordan, April 25 -- Premier Fawzi el Mulki hailed today the arrival here of Gen. Sir Charles Keightley, commanding officer of British land forces in the Middle East.
LONDON, April 25 -- Actors in Europe will boycott international television programs until it is agreed that they will receive larger fees for the larger audiences such programs will reach.

The support of the Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime committee has been thrown behind a Senate bill to authorize Navy chartering of new tankers for a ten-year period, Hoyt S. Haddock, executive secretary of the committee, reported yesterday.
Pause a moment today at a red light on Fifth Avenue in midtown and note the flutter ing blue and gold banners of the Greater New York Fund.
The body of one of Albert Anastasia's closest associates who was under investigation by Federal authorities was found yesterday stuffed in the trunk of an automobile parked in the Bronx.
The Navy has alerted all ships for a "flying Panamanian" that may be drifting into the Atlantic approach to the Panama Canal

JUST before a bus was ready to pull out of La Guardia Airport with American Airlines passengers last Friday afternoon a panting A. A. man leaped aboard waving a paper bag. "Did anyone on Flight 303 from Boston forget this bag of bones in the plane?" he wanted to know.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 25 -- Hurrican's Don Juan, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York City and handled by G. Bergen, won the Rolling Rock Club Retriever Trial Trophy today by capturing the limited open of the final day of the Labrador Retriever Club's spring trial.

Roman Catholics were urged by Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell yesterday morning to give "strong support" to the International Labor Organization. He spoke at the fifth annual communion breakfast of Roman Catholic employes of McGraw-Hill at the Statler Hotel.

GENEVA, April 25 (UP) -- David A. Morse, former Under Secretary of Labor in the United States, denied any responsibility today for having given loyalty clearance to a Government employe who later joined the Communists.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 25 -- Vietminh artillery pounded Dienbiephu with new fury today. A Vietminh broadcast heard in Hanoi warned that a final assault on the battered fortress was not far away.

THE sports pages and the financial pages of this newspaper are generally typographical neighbors. But the two worlds they reflect are a couple of light years apart. Some time back, however, there was a picture and accompanying story in the financial news section, reporting the promotion of Charles Devens to the post of president of Incorporated Investors.
A seven-month-old boy was strangled last night in what the police described as a freakish accident in a large crib.
DENVER, Colo., April 25 -- The largest convention in the history of the thirty-four-year-old League of Women Voters opens here tomorrow, with 1,000 delegates attending.

Yesterday's late afternoon Aristo Artists concert in Town Hall presented, as customary, four young singers. Sharing the program were Lois McCauley, soprono; Annajean Brown, contralto; Frederick Loadwick, tenor, and Earl Lippy, baritone.
Dr. Albert C. Jacobs, president of Trinity College, Hartford, Conn., declared here yesterday that "independent Christian education is a vital necessity" for the preservation of United States freedom.

The annual service in honor of St. George, patron saint of England, at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) yesterday afternoon was attended by 5,000 persons. Among them were 1,000 members of forty-three patriotic organizations, who had paraded from 106th Street and Broadway to the cathedral.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 25 -- Delegates from eleven Moslem states representing a fourth of the world's population put under way today an ambitious quasi-religious program designed to raise the world of Islam to economic independence.

A nation-wide campaign to raise $10,000,000 toward the reconstruction of Korea will open here tonight with a dinner of the: American - Korean Foundation. The start of the drive was timed with the opening today of the Geneva Conference on Far Eastern problems.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 25 -- The Government rejected tonight the Soviet Union's demand for the surrender of Vladimir M. Petrov and his wife and denied Moscow's version of the events that led to Mme. Petrov's decision to stay in Australia.

The Federation of American Scientists, which issued a critical committee report yesterday on the Fort Monmouth, N. J., investigations, describes itself as a nation-wide organization acting on national and international issues "where the opinions of scientists are relevant."

Russ Barrica of Toronto put out George Naughton, New York A. C., former club champion, as play in the senior National Amateur Athletic Union fourwall handball singles tournament began yesterday on the city clubhouse courts of the New York A. C.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff have studied the possibility of trying to relieve the French garrison at Dienbienphu by the intervention of carrier - based United States planes. Their report to the President, however, was decidedly negative.

The Cliffs, the old Beekman estate of thirty-eight acres at Oyster Bay, L. I., has been sold by Clendenin J. Ryan to Dr. Albert R. Fritz for a country home. It is at West Shore Drive and Cleft Road and contains a seven teen-room residence, garage, superintendent's cottage and four lakes.

Anzac Day, the Memorial Day of Australia and New Zealand, was celebrated here yesterday in the Anzac Garden atop the building at 620 Fifth Avenue, in Rockefeller Center, Three hundred persons attended.
PARIS, April 25 -- French financial experts are studying a plan for advanced repayments on the large French debt to the European Payments Union.
City Administrator Luther H. Gulick has recommended to Mayor Wagner that the city establish block-by-block inspections of housing on a permanent basis.
CHICAGO, April 25 (UP) -- An Illinois Central Railroad train crashed into the rear of another suburban train at a station on the edge of the Loop today, injuring forty-six persons.

It is a tradition at the century-old Hill School of Pottstown, Pa., that boys take one week-end off in the fall and one in the spring. Seldom, if ever, had a student traveled more than a few hundred miles from the school to enjoy this week-end privilege.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Some prominent lawyers, including at least one jurist, agreed here today that transcribed telephone conversations could be admitted as evidence in the McCarthy-Army controversy with the consent of only one party.

It's springtime in Geneva, too. There are few lovelier prospects in the world than the picture framed by the glass walls of the Palais des Nations -- the sparkling waters of Lake Leman, the snowy peak of Mount Blanc, the pale greens of the garden-like landscape between. A peaceful prospect in a peaceful country.

A Federal Maritime Board examiner in Washington recommended yesterday that American President Lines receive an operating differential subsidy on its existing cargo services between United States Atlantic and Gulf ports and San Francisco to the Far East, except ports in Japan.

A swept-wing Air Force fighter plane built on Long Island has completed six weeks of testing in Alaska, where its performance under frigid conditions was rated unofficially as "far above expectation."
ATLANTIC CITY, April 26 -- The leasing of textile machinery is growing in popularity as a means of stepping up the much-needed modernization of the textile industry.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- Makers of airplane bodies piled up peacetime records for sales and earnings last year, the Aircraft Industries Association reported today.

DETROIT, April 26 (AP) -- Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., praised Administration tax revision proposals today, but said they were only a "beginning" on the whole problem.

There are times -- and this is one of them -- when the earning of money by a junior member of the family appears to be especially difficult. This, for example, is a sort of in-between season; profitable garden chores are yet a little way off.
LONDON, April 26 -- Uncertainty over the situation in Indo-China cast a shodow over the recently buoyant stock market here today and prices declined in vertually all sections.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Eisenhower expressed hope today that the Geneva Conference might be able to arrange at least a temporary arrangement among the warring powers in Asia.

THE new season has not yet produced any seismic disturbances of earthquake proportions. But it has set in motion the doggondest series of peculiar little tremors that are enough to make folks blink in surprise. Here are just a few samples:
ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 26 -- A secret command exercise for military leaders of the North Atlantic alliance got underway here today under the direction of Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery.

The first signer of this letter recently wrote The Times objecting to the special relief given to receivers of dividends in the Administration's current tax bill. The second signer replied, pointing to the fact that corporation income pays a 52 per cent tax even before any dividends are paid out.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Whatever may be the factual findings or the inferences drawn by the Senate subcommittee that is investigating the cross-charges in the case of Private Schine, it is already evident that national estimates of the caliber of others than Senator McCarthy and Roy Cohn will be the result of the televised hearings.

The Army was disclosed yesterday to be still pursuing alleged security risks at the Fort Monmouth, N. J., Signal Corps Center. It has suspended one more employe and is reported to have deprived at least two others of clearance this month.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, which is celebrating its fortieth anniversary this year, has pioneered in many fields, including housing, banking for the wage-earner and health, welfare and pension programs. In these activities it has won distinction without in any way neglecting a union's main objective, collective bargaining for the improvement of wages and working conditions for its members.

Commodity prices soared yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee and cocoa led the rise, both climbing the daily limit. Rubber also jumped up sharply. Trading in all markets was influenced by the situation in Indo-China.

Being a member of any Board of Education is no bed of roses, and to serve in this policy-making position in New York City's overwhelmingly large school system is a responsibility and a burden not to be undertaken lightly. Andrew G. Clauson Jr. of Staten Island was sworn in yesterday at City Hall for a new seven-year term as a board member.
Both parties to the dispute over control of the vast New York Central Railroad Company now have engaged professional proxy solicitors.
With an eye toward June, McCutcheon's is now displaying coordinated bedroom, bath and table furnishings for the bride.
GENEVA, April 26--Foreign Cmister Georges Bidault made a dramatic appeal here today in behalf of the French Union's wounded soldiers now desperately suffering at besieged Dienbienphu.
DANVILLE, Va., April 26 -- Southern tobacco exporters, who normally do a large business with the United Kingdom, Europe and many tropical countries, are taking a bright view of prospects.

Gross operating revenues of the Illinois Central Railroad Company dipped in the first quarter this year to $68,823,920 from $75,056,576. The decline was attributed by Wayne A. Johnston, president, largely to lower coal loadings.
WEST POINT, N. Y., April 26 -- Behind the five-hit pitching of Sophomore Ed Vallentiny, Army beat Hofstra College, 5 to 0, at Doubleday Field today.

MOSCOW, April 26 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov warned today that any senseless atomic aggression directed at the Soviet Union would "without doubt" lead the aggressor to defeat by means of his own chosen weapon -- atomic arms.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 26 (AP) -- Ben Goodes of Reidsville, N. C., bettered par by 4 strokes today with a 33, 35 -- 68 to win the medal by 3 shots in the fifty-fourth North and South amateur golf tournament.

HAVANA, April 26 -- The right to dismiss workers, long denied to employers in Cuba, will soon be restored, Dr. Carlos Saladrigas, Minister of Labor, said today. He has proposed revolutionary modificatins of existing labor legislation.

BUENOS AIRES, April 26 -- Four opposition leaders, including the Radical party's candidate for Vice President in yesterday's elections, were arrested today. It was understood that they would be charged with "desacato," the crime of talking disrespectfully about President Juan D. Peron.
CHICAGO, April 26 -- The American Nurses Association reported today that its affiliate in Georgia is the only state group that still bars Negroes from membership.

A series of "paintings" on glass makes up the unusual art exhibition now on view at Steuben. 718 Fifth Avenue. Called "British Artists in Crystal," it is composed of twenty crystal objects, each etched with an original and especially commissioned design by an outstanding contemporary British artist.
A 7-year-old girl was burned to death early today and a woman was injured in a four-story leap in a Brooklyn tenement fire.
Greeley Square, the heart of the busiest retail center in the world, became temporarily "Brand Names Square" yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Governors of five Southwestern states recommended to President Eisenhower today that $15,000,000 in Federal money be made available immediately to combat another "dust bowl."

Operations last year of the N. V. Koninklijke Nederlandsche Petroleum Maatschappij (Royal Dutch Petroleum Company) produced a net income of $364,000,000, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $350,000,000 cleared in 1952.
CHICAGO, April 26 -- Board of Trade future markets here had price movements of about every description today.
TRENTON, April 26 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner recommended today that New Jersey's major fiscal problems be submitted directly to the electorate for solution.

Vista Vision, Paramount's new wide-screen photographic and projection process, will be demonstrated this morning at the Radio City Music Hall for representatives of the film industry and the press. . . . Montgomery Clift has received a special plaque from the Inter-State Circuit of Thea tres, which cites him for his acting talents, "as a result of which you have become one of the box-office champions of the industry."

Several dinner parties were given last night in advance of the opening of a display of works of art in glass, known as "British Artists in Crystal." The event was held last night at Steuben Glass, 718 Fifth Avenue, for the benefit of the English-Speaking Union.
The Uniformed Fire Officers Association charged yesterday that the scarcity of officers in the New York Fire Department was "jeopardizing the lives and property of our citizens."
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- An Army court-martial today threw out one of three remaining charges against Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson, the former Korean war prisoner.

ABOARD THE LINER Gothic, April 26 (Reuters) -- Queen Elizabeth II honored tonight members of the crew who have served her during the 19,000-mile journey that she and the Duke of Edinburgh have made in this liner since Nov. 25.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Pioneer studies providing an insight into the chemistry of heredity were described here today at the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.
Tony Trabert of Cincinnati won the opening match in the National Round Robin tennis championship last night.
Vincent (Jim) Macri, underworld victim of a "ride" murder, was as much a mystery yesterday to the police as he had been in life to his wife.

The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $26,582,231 for the twelve months to March 31, 1954. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.05 a common share, and compares with $24,050,754, or $1.96 a share, in the year to March 31, 1953. Gross revenues advanced to $208,430,238 from $493,207,520 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee set out today to document the charge last fall by Herbert R. Brownell Jr., Attorney General, that alleged subversives had stayed in key Government jobs and had won promotions during the Truman Administration.

LONDON, April 26 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, conferred here today with Prime Minister Churchill and the British Chiefs on Staff on the military situation in Indo-China.

LIMA, Peru, April 26 -- The head of the United States Agricultural Trade Mission to Latin America denied vehemently today that -- as Latin Americans fear the United States contemplated a campaign to "dump" surplus farm products at prices below the world market.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear an appeal in which the principal question is whether the theatrical business and organized baseball are on the same footing in interstate commerce.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States Ambassador to the United Nations, said today the United States would not permit the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

A higher base wage for masters and mates on the new Mariner class of cargo ships than for those on slower and smaller freighters was demanded yesterday by the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L.

A Moreland Act Commissioner threatened yesterday to expose hospitals and seek the withdrawal of licenses of physicians who collected fees in workmen's compensation cases for services they had not actually performed.

A banking syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. and C. C. Coilings Co., Inc., will place on the market today a new issue of $5,000,000 of preferred stock of I. T. E. Circuit Breaker Company, manufacturer of equipment used in the transmission of electrical energy.
BERLIN, April 26 -- The Soviet Union was reported to have agreed in general this afternoon to a Western plan to ease conditions for the seven surviving top Nazis in Spandau Prison.
BERLIN, April 26 -- The East German Interior Ministry asserted tonight that another anti-Soviet resistance leader had defected to the East.

HARTFORD, April 26 -- Thousands of city children, many of them for the first time, saw today how life is on the farm. Nine thousand children and 3,000 adults flocked to Elizabeth Park here for the annual "Farm Day" program held jointly by the Children's Museum of Hartford and the Glastonbury Chapter of the Future Farmers of America.

Donations on Friday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program totaled 638 pints of blood. Included were 222 at Columbia University, bringing the total in a two-day donation at the university to 369 pints: 214 at Levittown, L. I., and 138 by Masons in Flushing, Queens.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of testimony today in the third day of hearings by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which is considering the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. The hearing began at 10:31 A. M.

MONTREAL, April 26 (UP) -- Camille Henry, 139-pound utility forward for the New York Rangers -- the National Hockey League's lightest player -- today was named winner of the Calder Memorial Trophy as the outstanding rookie for the 1953-54 season.
GENEVA, April 26 -- David A. Morse, Director General of the International Labor Organization, announced today that the Soviet Union had applied for membership.
CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) -- Producers unloaded 10,000 salable hogs, largest receipts since Feb. 1, on the livestock market today and prices dropped in all weight classifications.

SLOWLY but inevitably, the fly fisherman is coming into his own on many of the Catskill streams, and although most of the big fish taken over the week-end succumbed to bait, there were several areas where flies produced more trout than the worm.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- The formation of Leonard Goldstein Productions, Inc., to produce a program of ten pictures for release by United Artists was announced today. The producer, using the trade name of Panoramic Productions, is filming the last of ten pictures on a partnership agreement with Twentieth Century-Fox for which he formerly worked as a staff producer.

Although it was the earliest opening date of the Westchester Racing Association's spring meeting at Belmont Park, many members of society attended yesterday the first of the forty-two programs. The Turf and Field Club in the old Manice House, the restaurant in the track enclosure and the mezzanine dining room above the stands were the sites of luncheon parties before the first post time.

A thirty-month investigation into bookmaking and police corruption on Staten Island ended yesterday with the sentencing of five former plainclothes men and fourteen bookmakers. They had been convicted of conspiracy to violate the gambling law.

Japan under occupation is the subject of two books scheduled for publication next month. On May 18 Macmillan will publish "Typhoon in Tokyo" by Harry Emerson Wildes. The author, a Visiting Professor of Economies and Social Sciences at Keio University, Tokyo, before the war, served as a regional specialist for Japan in the Office of War Information.

Bevo Francis, the 6-foot 8 1/2-inch basketball player who set several scoring records at little Rio Grande (Ohio) College, signed as a professional here yesterday along with his coach, Newt Oliver. It was a package deal said to involve approximately $30,000 a year.

Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx is catching its staff young these days. Its youngest "doctors" and "nurses" have an average age of 3 years and are the occupants of its new Day Care Center, which cares for pre-school children while their mothers, all nurses, work at the hospital.

The new twenty-three-story office building at 477 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-first Street, was dedicated and formally opened yesterday by Francis Cardinal Spellman. The building is owned and was constructed by Simon Brothers, builders.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, with active months up 5 to 20 points.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon appealed before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today against any cutback in the State Department's international educational exchange program.
GENEVA, April 26 -- The people of the world are getting their news of the Geneva conference through a kind of strainer or several strainers.

The Jarka Corporation, one of the largest stevedoring companies in the world, was fined $2,000 and its president, Frank W. Nolan, received a six-month suspended sentence yesterday on pleas of guilty to commercial bribery.
A project that holds the hope of wiping out poliomyelitis -- the inoculation of hundreds of thousands of school children with the new Salk vaccine -- began yesterday in eight states.
The city of Philadelphia announced yesterday that it would receive bids May 19 on refunding bonds totaling $43,520,000. Dated June 15, 1954, the obligations will come due serially from 1955 to 1980.
City officials seeking new revenue sources prepared data for Mayor Wagner yesterday on two possible imposts -- the payroll tax and the charge for overnight parking of automobiles.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- The Senate Republican Leader, William F. Knowland, declared today that the McCarthy-Army hearings had not delayed Senate action on President Eisenhower's legislative program.

Yesterday's speeches in Moscow by probably the two most important men in Russia, Georgi M. Malenkov and Nikita S. Khrushchev, add a dour note to the current international scene. Premier Malenkov has taken a significant step backward from his statement last month that a future war with modern weapons would mean the end of world civilization.

CLEVELAND, April 26 -- Wage incentive systems of many companies are not functioning and a re-evaluation is long overdue, delegates to the conference of the American Management Association were told today.

IN Kyung Mu Dai, his official residence in the city of Seoul in South Korea, an elderly man is waiting with ill-concealed impatience for the rest of the free world to match his uncompromising allegiance to a principle. His name is Syngman Rhee. He is 79 years old, the same age as Winston Churchill. For nearly fifty years he has devoted his life to the cause of freedom for his people.

At the annual meeting of Revere Copper Brass, Inc. in Baltimore yesterday, Albert E. McCormick was elected a director. Treasurer and assistant secretary of the company, Mr. McCormick has been with Revere since its formation in 1929 as a consolidation of six copper and brass manufacturing concerns.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the New York State Education Law under which the license of Dr. Edward K. Barsky to practice medicine was suspended.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Business leaders voiced confidence here today that there would be a business upturn in the fall, if not by midsummer.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 26 -- Turkish officials believe that Iraq is moving toward participation in the Turkish-Pakistani pact.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 26 -- Mme. Ana Pauker, former Communist Foreign Minister of Rumania, has lost her struggle for a comeback and will pay for her defeat by being placed on trial, according to reports reaching here.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Secretary of the Army conceded today that he had tried to get Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and his associates to suspend hearings and halt bad publicity for the Army over alleged espionage at Fort Monmouth, N. J.

The eight-story loft building on plot 25 by 95 feet at 39 East Nineteenth Street has been purchased by Joseph Ludlow from the Lanmor Realty Corporation, represented by Alfert Schwartz, attorneys. M. . S. Gaumont were the brokers ill the sale of the property which is assessed at $60,000.

BRISBANE, Australia, April 26 -- At the first wool sales since severance of Australian-Russian diplomatic relations, the international demand for Queensland merino wool was sufficiently powerful today to offset Russia's withdrawal from the market.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Abba Eban, Israeli Ambassador, protested today against the United States agreement to give arms to Iraq.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Supreme Court refused today to grant Alabama and Rhode Island a rehearing on the offshore oil land case.
LONDON, April 26 (AP) -- Excerpts from the speech of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov before the Supreme Soviet today as broadcast by the Moscow radio:

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 26 -- Two Arab infiltrators from Syria were reported to have been killed this morning in a clash with Israelis near the place where the upper Jordan river flows into the Sea of Galilee.
Andrew G. Clauson Jr. of Richmond was sworn in yesterday by Mayor Wagner to his second seven-year term as a member of the Board of Education.

In his testimony at the McCarthy inquiry yesterday Secretary Stevens at last made public official figures concerning the Fort Monmouth employes suspended as security risks. This information is of interest because of the repeated suggestions by Ray H. Jenkins, committee counsel, that Senator McCarthy's much-publicized investigation into Fort Monmouth had produced significant results in protecting the nation against subversion.
ST. LOUIS, April 26 -- Roy Campanella, who has made only one hit in his last twenty times at bat and whose batting average now is .163, has a chip fracture in his left hand, it was revealed today.
BALTIMORE, April 26 -- An abnormally large volume of export freight is still flowing through the port of Baltimore as a result of the recent New York dock strike.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 26 -- Rita Hayworth came to town today to regain custody of her two daughters. In the resulting stampede, hundreds of curious on-lookers fought ran and screamed for a glimpse of the principals in and around the eight-story County Office Building.
Jose Greco brought his company into the Broadway Theatre last night for a two-week season of Spanish dancing.
Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday that net assets, shares outstanding and the number of shareholders all reached high records during the first quarter.
The Clinton Trust Company, at Fifty-seventh Street just west of Tenth Avenue, was robbed of $35,755.78 yesterday morning. The robbery was faultlessly timed and executed in about three minutes.
William F. Buckley Jr., coauthor of the book, "McCarthy and His Enemies," last night defended the Senator from Wisconsin in an address that followed a clash among Republican clubwomen.
Beginning tomorrow, the Museum of Modern Art will again have a restaurant in its garden, open to visitors with tickets of admission to the museum.
Ernest Ulmer, pianist, played his first Town Hall recital last evening. His recital debut was made at Times Hall in 1950.
The American-Korean Foundation formally opened its national campaign yesterday for $10,000,000 to help the Korean people help themselves in the vast struggle of reconstruction.

NIVOLA'S semi-abstract bas-reliefs, at the Peridot Gallery, are created by means of a technique that is original with him. It is "reverse" sculpture. A mold, made in sand on the seashore, is filled with cement, Technical difficulties must be considerable; for one thing, the cement must be hard enough to remove whole within a given time or else the rising tide engulfs it.

A new dessert-mix called Py-O-My pudding is being introduced by Kitchen Arts Foods of Chicago in chain stores here, including Bohack's, King Kullen and Peter Reeves. Requiring no more than thirty minutes for preparation, including cooking time, the packaged product comes in three flavors, vanilla, chocolate and caramel.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Following is a White House transcription of President Eisenhower's remarks today to the United States Chamber of Commerce:
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26 -- Cuba hurled back a Communist allegation of slave labor practices today and invited United Nations delegates to go to Cuba and see for themselves.
Net profit of the Armco Steel Corporation in the first quarter of this year rose to $9,137,226 from $7,767,045 in the initial three months of last year, Charles R. Hook, chairman, reported yesterday.
GENEVA, April 26 -- Hostile nations of the East and the West began their conference today in an effort to restore peace to Asia.

LONDON, April 26 -- The Jordanian Government has received assurance that Britain will observe her treaty obligations to defend Jordan in the event of an Israeli attack without waiting for United Nations consultation.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- The West Coast premiere of Honegger's music-drama, "Joan of Arc at the Stake," is included in the plans for the 1954 season of the San Francisco Opera Association. It is to be presented in English.

LONDON, April 26 -- A forty-two-nation conference whose task the abatement of oil pollution at sea was brought up sharply on its opening day by a Soviet demand that Communist China be invited to attend.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 26 -- Indonesia is expected to propose a delay in United States military aid to Pakistan at the Asian Prime Ministers' Conference, which opens Wednesday in Colombo, Ceylon.
The gravity with which Washington views the Indo-China situation appeared to be reflected in stock trading yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 26 -- Believing that the likeliest explanation of the Soviet Government's delay in issuing exit visas to the Australian embassy staff in Moscow is that it will not let them leave till it is sure its own diplomats in Canberra can return to Russia, the Commonwealth Government is doing its best to help the Russians to depart as soon as possible.
Famous French wines flowed like water at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

The managing board of the European Payments Union has begun deliberations on the basic problems facing that foreign exchange group of eighteen countries, now in its fourth year. The outcome of these discussions could conceivably decide the future of the E. P. U., whose life, unless extended by positive action of the members, is scheduled to expire automatically on June 30.

GENEVA, April 26 -- Britain has rejected, as premature and hasty, a United States proposal for immediate talks in Washington by representatives of ten nations for an Asian collective security organization.

United States intelligence agents have reported a "mounting tempo" of Communist activity in the twenty other hemisphere republics, despite a decline in party membership since World War II. The data are to be used by official United States information channels abroad.
Margaret Truman gave a practical demonstration yesterday of two of her best-known attributes: her devotion to her father, former President Harry S. Truman, and her acting ability.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- For those inside the hearing room, there was an important new development today in the Army-McCarthy dispute.
LOUISVILLE, April 26 -- These were today's chief items of news at Churchill Downs, where the eightieth Kentucky Derby is to be run on Saturday:

The machine age received a legal setback yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Maximilian Moss ruled in Brooklyn that a recording machine could not be used to take down testimony in an eximation before trial.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Secretary of Defense suggested today that a second "new look" at military plans and expenditures might be forced upon the United States by events in Europe and Asia.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- More than 150 railroads in the East and South asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for a larger share of the revenue on transcontinental shipments of freight.

BOSTON, April 26 -- A strike of 3,000 workers of the American Woolen Company opened today on a peaceful note, with token picket lines established around eight mills. The workers, members of the Textile Workers Union of America, C.I.O., are protesting a proposed wage cut of 21 1/2 cents an hour.
The fashion world has come into conflict with the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., April 26 -- Some 8,650 parachutists floated to the red sun-baked earth in the Camp Mackall area near here today in the largest airborne operation since the Rhine River crossing in World War II.

Grants totaling $1,469,074 were made by the Rockefeller Foundation in the first quarter of this year, it was announced yesterday. The funds are to be used for educational, scientific, cultural and research purposes.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had dropped to the lowest level in nearly six and one half years.

The Federal Communications Commission announced yesterday that it had dismissed the application of WHOV-TV, Inc., for a television station here to operate on Channel 31. The dismissal was made at the request of the applicants, who said that economic problems involved in starting an ultra-high-frequency station in New York appeared "insurmountable" at this time.

The American Social Hygiene Association awarded its William Freeman Snow medal yesterday to Miss Lida J. Usilton as a "pioneer, explorer, inventor, guide, teacher and worker in the field of venereal disease control."

After sixty-four years of successful financial operation in the public utility field the North American Company is getting ready to close its books. Stockholders of the once dominant utility holding company held their last annual meeting yesterday at 60 Broadway, North American's headquarters.
"Visit-Your-College-Week -- a higher education adaptation of "Open School Week" -- will begin today and continue through May 5 at the four municipal colleges, Brooklyn, Hunter, City and Queens.
Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson's rapid rise in the heavyweight ranks was halted abruptly last night at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 26 (AP) -- Corsair fighter-bombers supplied by the United States went into action over Indo-China for the first time today.
GENEVA, April 26 -- Britain has reluctantly agreed to support South Korea's program for the unification of Korea.

GUATEMALA, April 26 -- The Government "emphatically and categorically" rejected today a United States note conveying a formal claim on behalf of the United Fruit Company for expropriated land. Guatemala's reply said the State Department action was "a new attempt at intervention" in her internal affairs.
The seventeenth game of the match for the world chess championship between Mikhail Botvinnik and Vassily Smyslov in Moscow ended in a draw after thirty-one moves, according to a report from London.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt told the public today that the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations was not to blame for a reduction in the country-wide television coverage of the McCarthy-Army hearings.

John Forsythe, the amiable Captain Fisby in "The Teahouse of the August Moon," and William Hammerstein, son of Oscar Hammerstein 2d, will turn producers next season with a new play called "The Geep," written by Vincent J. Longhi.
MEXICO CITY, April 25 -- The Government's plans for economic development center on hopes that private enterprise will take the initiative energetically.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Mrs. Eva Bowring, 62-year-old range-riding grandmother from Nebraska, was sworn in today as a member of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Rowland R. Hughes, Director of the Budget Bureau, announced today the appointment of Harold L. Pearson, until recently deputy under secretary of the Army, as assistant director of the Budget Bureau.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 26 -- R. K. O. Pictures, Inc., and the Independent Theatre Owners of Ohio today filed suit here challenging the right of the State Division of Film Censorship to collect fees amounting to $300,000 a year.

Composers of Today, the recently incorporated organization, which has evolved from the evenings of contemporary music that the pianist, Rosalyn Tureck, started at her home two seasons ago, presented the first of this seasons three concerts last night. It was at the Town Hall Club, where the group moved last season after having grown too large for Miss Tureck's seven-room apartment on Riverside Drive.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26 -- The Franco Government of Spain was accused in the United Nations today of abolishing free trade unions and arresting and torturing labor leaders.
BROOKLINE, Mass., April 26 -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, said tonight that the national security was being threatened by an "alarming" drop in re-enlistment rates.

DENVER, April 26 -- President Eisenhower, in a recorded interview at the opening session of the biennial convention of the National League of Women Voters, praised the contribution of women to government and politics.

After the word had been given out in Paris that Bao Dai and the Vietnamese on the one hand and France on the other had reached complete agreement on the independence treaties for Vietnam there has been an eleventh-hour interruption of the negotiation. This is a deplorable political setback and must inevitably weaken the hand of the French at Geneva.

GENEVA, April 26 -- Prince Wan Waithayakon, Foreign Minister of Thailand and one of the co-chairmen of the Geneva conference, urged the Big Four tonight to get started on arrangements for discussing Indo-China.

The appointment of a seven-member scientific advisory board was announced yesterday by O. Parker McComas, chairman of the Tobacco Industry Research Committee. The group was organized early this year to foster research into "all phases of tobacco use and health."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 26 -- A statement by Dr. Daniel F. Malan, South African Prime Minister, that barbarism would result in the Gold Coast if the people received democratic rights was disputed today. In reply to the statement, made April 13, Dr. Kwame Nkrumah said in a message to the Bantu World, leading Negro newspaper:
A few weeks ago a 10-year-old boy, eyes gleaming, shook his dozing father awake as dawn hit their suburban home. He shouted: "Dad, did you hear the geese honking?

White Skies, William M. Wickham's excellent campaigner, carried 132 pounds to victory in the Toboggan Handicap, the six-furlong dash that served as the feature attraction at the Belmont Park opening yesterday. The accomplishment met with the approval of the greater part of the crowd of 27,387, for the 5-year-old son of Sun Again was odds-on and paid $3.70.
The City Council has been placed on notice that the state law reallocating legislative seats contains a clerical error that will be corrected at the next session of the Legislature.

Events tonight: Toronto Mendelssohn Choir, Sir Ernest MacMillan, conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8 o'clock; Festival of the Arts, Town Hall, 8:15; Washington Square College Chorus and Orchestra, New York University School of Education Auditorium, West Fourth and Greene Streets, 8:30; Madeleine Foley, 'cellist, Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street, 8:30.

SEOUL, Korea, April 26 -- Political opponents of President Syngman Rhee charged that police pressure and intimidation were destroying the "free and democratic atmosphere" of the election campaign that began officially today.

Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. issued a consent inunction yesterday barring Ben Guy Phillips, Wall Street broker, from dealing in securities within this state. The court designated Abraham Grenthal as receiver to liquidate the brokerage house at 44 Wall Street that bears Phillip's name.

HAMILTON, Bermuda April 26 -- Bermuda's International One Design yacht team started its best-of-seven series for the Amorita Cup in Great Sound today with an impressive victory over the United States, 23 1/4 points to 13.
(The subcommittee reconvened at 2:40 P. M. and continued with the testimony of Secretary of the Army Stevens.)
The Brooklyn rackets grand jury went on record yesterday as "unalterably opposed" to legalized off-track betting.
The dispute between Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and two bus companies moved toward a showdown yesterday.
The Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $8,372,105 in the first three months this year, compared with $13,257,756 in the 1953 first quarter.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26 -- For thirty-seven years, Prince Wan Waithayakon has been part of professional diplomacy in half a dozen world capitals and two world organizations.
Newspapers will get slightly more and magazines a bit less of the record-breaking $3,000,000 the Florida Citrus Commission will spend in its 1954-55 advertising campaign.

The Easter vacation ended yesterday for most of the city's youngsters. At least two, however, took an extra day off from school. At 10 A. M., June Martinez, 10 years old, of 1145 Fox Street, the Bronx, and her brother, Robert, 8, were supposed to be at Public School 66, Longfellow and Jennings Avenues, the Bronx.

Arrangements are almost concluded for Edgar Lee Masters' "Domesday Book" to reach the stage. The possibility wasn't denied yesterday by Oliver M. Sayler, who will be associated with Sam Byrd and Marjorie Barkentin in the venture.
FORT BRAGG, N. C., April 27 -- An airhead with a 47,000-yard perimeter, five drop zones and an established airfield was consolidated by United States forces in the Camp Mackall area tonight.

BELIZE, British Honduras, April 27 -- Leigh I. Richardson, president of the anti-colonial People's United party, pledged his organization today to "intelligent opposition" toward the Colonial Government should his candidates win a majority in Wednesday's Legislative Council election.

LONDON, April 27 -- The De Havilland Aircraft Company acknowleged today that production of the Comet, the only jet airliner now flying, had been suspended pending an investigation of crashes that have plagued the model.
The roster of the sixteen professional golfers who will participate in the thirteenth Palm Beach round-robin tourney at the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L. I., next month was announced yesterday.

BONN, Germany, April 27 (AP) -- Nikolai E. Khokhlov, the Soviet secret police captain who deserted to the West, appealed to President Eisenhower and Pope Pius XII today for aid in saving his wife and child from Soviet revenge.

Net earnings of the Boeing Airplane Company in the first quarter of this year spurted to $8,378,442, after taxes of $9,140,000, from the $3,467,845 earned in the 1953 period, when taxes were $8,100.000.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Marine Corps announced today that Col. Frank H. Schwable would not be disciplined for having falsely confessed to germ warfare in Korea. His future as a career officer of twenty-five years' service was clouded, however.

Fresh herbs are coming into season. Bunches of them are offered in open air markets along Ninth Avenue south of Forty-second Street. Throughout the city certain grocery stores have on hand, or will order, fresh-cut tarragon, chervil, mint, chives and dill.
The National Labor Relations Board ordered yesterday a new union election on or before May 26 among longshoremen in the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd called upon the Justice Department today to begin immediate prosecution of all "who may be criminally liable" in the current housing scandals.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission granted to Seatrain Lines, Inc., today permanent authority to operate ocean-going freight car ferry service between Savannah, Ga., and New York.

Empire of inspired evening dresses were presented yesterday in a fashion show by the Tailored Woman honoring the current Paris in New York Festival. Highlighting the collection of elegant fashions were precious jewels by Van Cleef Arpels.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is attending the hearings on his dispute with the Army with a police escort.

Many reservations have been made for the tea dance and fashion show, an annual entertainment known as the "Bustles and Bonnets Party," to be held tomorrow afternoon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for the benefit of the Bargain Box.

No reputable charitable organization or professional fundraiser can properly object to the principles of the new laws curbing charity abuses, Keith S. McHugh, president of the New York Telephone Company, declared last night.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, decided today that many hours in the witness chair could weaken his memory.

BOWIE, Md., April 27 (AP) -- Fortunate in finding racing room along the inside rail, Nick Shuk drove Leslie Jane Stable's Freedom Parley to a nose victory over Mrs. R. C. Hodge's Esmero in the featured sixth race today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 -Four persons found guilty last night of harboring a high Communist party functionary in a California mountain cabin face maximum sentences of ten to eleven years in prison and fines of $15,000 to $17,000 each.
An employe of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus was clawed so badly by a huge royal Bengal tiger in Madison Square Garden yesterday that his left arm had to be amputated.

The new seventy-acre $30,000,000 Cross County Center in lower Westchester near the New York City line, which is being dedicated today, is something extraordinary even in this era of the automobile, which has made the large suburban cluster of stores a convenient commonplace.

The New York Yankees yesterday added William O. DeWitt to their organization to serve as assistant to General Manager George M. Weiss. DeWitt, 51, takes the place of Roy Hamey, who recently signed to become general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies.

THE best-known dog around Times Square, not counting those that guide blind persons, is a 14-year-old chowcollie with the interminable name Spunky Wunky Oliver Handsome Man Laughing Tail -- all that S.W.'s diet is no less astonishing.

OTTAWA, April 27 (Canadian Press) -- Spokesmen for a Toronto Negro association said today that Canada discriminated against Negroes who wanted to immigrate here. They urged that restrictions be lifted on immigration of Negroes from Commonwealth countries.
YONKERS, April 27 -- The Cross County Center, the largest shopping center in the East, will open here tomorrow on a site where Indian tribes once bartered their goods.

Supreme Court Justice S. Samuel Di Falco reserved decision yesterday on objections by both sides to pre-trial examination in a suit brought by financier Robert R. Young against the New York Central Railroad Company and its directors.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 27 -Progress toward new political and economic solidarity among the free Asian nations was foreshadowed today as the Prime Ministers of five South Asian countries, representing onefourth of the world's population, met on this rain-drenched island.
