The Appellate Division, Second Department, adopted a rule yesterday prohibiting the taking of pictures in a courtroom even when it was being used for nontrial work, unless the division granted specific permission.

There's a resourceful group of early rising nature lovers in New York who use the city's parks for other than constitutionals or morning work-outs. Officially, the group is called the Natural Science for the Layman.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of the National Academy of Sciences, said today that "exploitation of fear and misunderstanding by those who seek selfish or unwholesome ends are creating an environment unsuitable for the furtherance of science."

ST. LOUIS, April 27 -- The Dodgers cooled off with the weather tonight and the St. Louis Cardinals took the opening engagement at Busch Stadium by a score of 7 -- 3, to move one game over the 500 mark. The defeat dropped the Brooks to second place, one-half game behind the Cincinnati Redlegs.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 27 (AP) -- Bermuda's team of International One-Designs made it three in a row today in the best-of-seven series for the Amorita Cup.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- For courses in moral training many colleges and universities now are turning to the Army and Air Force.

PARIS, April 27 -- France and West Germany will resume negotiations for a settlement of the status of the Saar Monday. This was announced today as a committee of fifteen European nations issued the text of its plan for a Saar agreement.

The Robinson-Patman Act can be invoked by the Federal Trade Commission to insure that apparel manufacturers receive guarantees that textiles are flame-proof, an apparel industry official said yesterday.
The former Landia property comprising 630 acres in Jericho, L. I., has been purchased by Morris Sosnow and Leonard Schwartz from George M. and Alfred Gross and Lawrence Morton.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 27 (AP) -- Under pelting rains and despite heavy rebel mortar and artillery fire, the French flung up new fortifications today in the heart of Dienbienphu.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- Rowland R. Hughes, Director of the Budget, said today that the Eisenhower Administration was determined to make further tax cuts as soon as the budget warranted them.

DENVER, April 27 -- Mrs. John G. Lee, national president of the League of Women Voters, in her report to the biennial convention here today, reaffirmed the league's support of international cooperation.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 27 (AP) -- The Studebaker Corporation reported today a net loss of $6,431,671 in the first quarter of 1954, more than six times that for the same period last year.
Electric equipments provided a brake yesterday for what otherwise would have been an almost general stock market decline.
An explosion and flash fire in a Long Island City factory yesterday injured eleven persons, two of them seriously, and frightened residents of the neighborhood.
Two men held as material witnesses for nearly two years in the slaying of Arnold Schuster received limited freedom yesterday in Kings County Court.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 27 -- Judge John J. Francis today granted defense counsel's motions for dismissal of two more of the fifteen charges of failing to suppress gambling under which Walter G. Winne, superseded Prosecutor of Bergen County, is being tried here.

May I add to your record of William S. Newell, whose long, interesting life came to an end on Easter Sunday. Captain "Pete" was known on the seven seas, for he "did business in great waters with a great boat." His name will be remembered and hailed by seafaring America for the varied fleets he built for our own and other nations.
The television receiver business picture became snowier than ever yesterday.
BALBOA, C. Z., April 27 -- Maintenance crews dug around the clock today to avert the danger of a landslide that could block the Panama Canal.

WINNIPEG, Man., April 27 (AP) -- A spokesman for six Soviet concert artists touring Canada says the group has canceled performances in Quebec because auditorium owners are afraid of Premier Maurice Duplessis. The Provincial Government chief is an avowed anti-Communist.
A six-room prefabricated house, constructed in a television studio, was introduced to the public on television last night.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Army offered pictorial evidence today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's associates had "doctored" and "shamefully cut down" a photograph presented yesterday before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

Frank Costello's charity donations and enterprises were discussed yesterday at his income tax evasion trial in Federal Court Costello is accused of having evaded $73,437 in taxes from 1946 through 1949.

YONKERS, April 27 -- Bids for the construction of the controversial Central Park Avenue segment of the New York-Buffalo Thruway were sought today by the state. They will be opened May 20 in Albany, and work could start by July.
The Senate defeated yesterday by a vote of 48 -- 40 an amendment to the so-called Wool Aid Bill which would have continued through 1955 the rigid 90 per cent of parity supports for basic commodities.

Remington Rand, Inc., in its preliminary statement covering the fiscal year ended last March 31, disclosed yesterday that it had an estimated net income of $12,211,170. This compared with $14,150,842 in the preceding fiscal year.

CINCINNATI, April 27 (UP) -Ted Kluszewski hit a pair of homers and Jim Greengrass hit one tonight to pace Cincinnati to an 8-to-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, who made it close on two homers apiece by Rookie Jerry Lynch and Toby Atwell.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Following are the roll-call votes by which the Senate passed, 69 to 17, the wool subsidy bill and defeated, 48 to 40, an amendment to extend mandatory 90 per cent farm price support on basic commodities for a year:

Sherman Solomon, top seeded player from the Brooklyn Central Young Men's Christian Association, advanced to the quarter-final round of the National Amateur Athletic Union four-wall handball tournament at the New York Athletic Club last night. He defeated Dave Cohen, Lone Star Boat Club, 21 -- 8, 21 -- 6.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 27 -- The annual threat of trouble in the building trades has arrived in town. The Greenwich Contractors Association met today to consider strategy in meeting the expected demands of the three unions.

Hospitable as ever to visiting men in uniform, New York's clubs and service centers now must finance the customary welcome out of their own pockets, not through support of the United Service Organizations.

BUENOS AIRES, April 27 -President Juan D. Peron ordered the release from jail today of a former Presidential candidate of the opposition Radical party and the party's Vice Presidential nominee in Sunday's elections.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 27 -- Britain made another attempt today to work out an acceptable formula for debating Israeli-Jordanian border problems in the United Nations Security Council.

The Toronto Mendelssohn Choir, directed by Sir Ernest MacMillan, and assisted by a solo quartet of singers of high prevailing excellence, interpreted Handel's "Messiah" last night in Carnegie Hall. This evening the choir will present the Bach St. Matthew Passion.

BERLIN, April 27 -- Attempts to solve the reported abduction from West Berlin of Mr. Trushnovich have been complicated by the receipt of four letters that, if genuine, would indicate that he went east voluntarily.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of testimony today on the fourth day of hearings by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which is considering the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. The hearing began at 10:35 A.M.:

That morning cup of hot beverage is responsible for more and more advertising and the prospect is for newer heights as makers of coffee preparations, regular coffee, tea and other beverages fight to fill the consumer's cup.

Plans for remodeling the three buildings at 160-62 Ninth Avenue, southeast corner of Twentieth Street, a realty holding in the heart of the Chelsea district, were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by Mrs. Mary A. Wagner to a syndicate in a deal negotiated by Morris Balahan, broker.
The General American Transportation Corporation has elected several new officers -- among them William J. Stebler as president -- and announced increased earnings for the March quarter this year.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Administration drew another ace today in its play for a new farm program.
A major reorganization of the Carl Reimers Company, Inc., the first in the advertising agency's twenty-nine years, was announced yesterday by Carl Reimers, president.

THE eighth National Print Annual opens today at the Brooklyn Museum with 150 examples of work by as many artists from 1,100 submitted to the jury from all parts of the country. Thirteen purchase awards are announced by the museum for its permanent collections.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- A study of nursing functions by the American Nurses Association shows that the average general duty nurse spends only from 37.9 per cent to 55.5 per cent of her time in direct nursing care.
Nassau County, L. I., borrowed $17,078,000 in the public market yesterday to finance public improvements by the sale of serial bonds maturing annually over twenty-nine years.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 27 (UP) -- Finance Minister Oswaldo Aranha moved today to eliminate what he called the basis for the "speculative and fictitious" drop in green coffee prices last week.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 27 (AP) -- Upsets occurred early today as match play began in the North and South amateur golf tournament. Two former champions, Frank Stranahan and Mal Galletta, were shunted to the sidelines by outsiders.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A floor fight over the merits of general excise or sales taxes as a means of raising Federal revenue is threatened at the closing session tomorrow of the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

DETROIT, April 27 -- Seven men from New York City, one from Long Island, one from Miami Beach and four from Montreal were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of defrauding investors in Canada and the United States of an estimated $300,000.

Edmond J. Moran, president of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, Inc., was re-elected yesterday as president of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York at the annual meeting in the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street. Mr. Moran has headed the association for the last two years.

Maj. Gen. Arthur R. Wilson (retired) has apologized to Pvt. G. David Schine and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for "any embarrassment" he had caused them with his offer to give $100 to any non - commissioned officer who would "sock" Private Schine, The United Press reports.

BORNEMOUTH, England, April 27 (AP) -- Doris Hart of Miami, Fla., former Wimbbledon tennis champion and a Wightman Cup star, opened defense of her British hard courts title today with an easy victory. She reached here yesterday too late to play.

Five apartment house properties in Brooklyn have been purchased by William B. Gladstone from the Schirr Realty Corporation, represented by Sidney Pielte, attorney, in a transaction negotiated by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., as broker.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 27 -- Despite cold winds and rain, the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its 1954 season, over the Fenway Golf Club course today. Sixty-two Class A players turned out and, as happened last year. Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis won low gross honors with 43, 41 -- 84.
NEW DELHI, India, April 27 (AP) -- India has asked the Chinese Communist regime to pay her 1,080,103 rupees ($227,901) she says Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Government owes her.
The New York Electrical Society, which has been presenting lectures once a month for seventy-two years on electricity and other scientific subjects, has reluctantly decided to go out of business.

The three-story industrial building at 99 Frelinghuysen Avenue in Newark, N. J., has been leased by the Formula Floor Products, Inc., through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. The lessee, a representative for manufacturers of janitorial and building supplies and equipment, will have about three times the amount of space it now occupies on Elizabeth Avenue in Newark.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, returned from Europe today to signal a reappraisal of United States policy toward Indo-China.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- One question of the ArmyMcCarthy hearings today was "when is a point of order a point of order!"

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today to give the states more leeway in the use of Federal grants in aid for public health services, including those on cancer, tuberculosis, heart disease, venereal disease and mental health.

In Hoc Signo Crede Spring is here, we have been told already in this corner. And we have felt it in the air even in the built-up city. From people who live out in the country or take to the more or less open road to get there we have heard about the new dress the fields and the woods are putting on.

It will cost the fans a few cents more to see the East's big three football games next fall, although the Federal tax on college sports events has been eliminated. But in general Ivy League football ticket prices will run about the same as they were last year or a trifle lower, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 27 -- The use of forced labor for political coercion or economic exploitation was condemned today by the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

THAT fine acting and sensitive writing can combine to lend distinction to even the most familiar of plots was illustrated on Monday evening over N. B. C.-TV in Robert Montgomery's presentation of "No Need of Fear," a love story from the pen of Gail Ingram.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Despite the price cut of April 1, real earnings of workers in the Soviet Union in terms of food purchasing power are still considerably below the 1928 level.
Reflecting record sales in the fiscal year ended last January, the City Stores Company and its subsidiaries increased net income to $4,986,805 from $4,217,137 earned in the preceding year.

BOSTON, April 27 (AP) -- Norm Johnson, a 132-pound slugger from Milwaukee, scored two victories tonight to gain the final of the National Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships for the second straight year.

The World Jewish Congress reported here yesterday that Rumania began last month a series of secret trials involving more than 100 Jewish leaders, several of whom have already been sentenced to long imprisonment.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 -- David O. Selznick may be swinging back into film production in Hollywood sooner than even he anticipates at the moment. Three major film companies have presented propositions to finance him in the making of a picture that would be his own independent creation artistically.
The Texas Company had a net profit of $50,848,438, equal to $1.85 a share, in the March quarter, J. S. Leach, chairman, informed stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

The election of Robert Rankin as executive director of the American Association of Theological Schools Fund, Inc., was announced yesterday after the organization's first board meeting. Mr. Rankin, who is chaplain of the Associated Colleges at Claremont, Calif., will take a one-year leave of absence from that post, beginning July 1, to serve with the fund.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The entire philosophy of American government in respect to public services and the distribution of taxation may be affected by the conclusions of a Presidential commission now studying these matters, a member of the group said today.
PARIS, April 27 -- Bloused windbreak jackets in sheer silk organdy, matching pleated frocks, were proposed for formal summer occasions by Jean Patou at his mid-season opening today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The Justice Department announced today the Government would offer two properties in Manhattan at a public auction at the United States Court House in New York City on May 19.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield asked Congress today to increase the salaries of postal employes by $80,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives will reopen hearings tomorrow on the Administration bill authorizing United States participation with Canada in the building of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

As the Board of Estimate adopted a $1,639,438,325 record budget for 1954-55, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that the 3 per cent sales tax on commercial services was "still under serious discussion." The board's approval of the budget was voted unanimously at a brief formal session early in the afternoon.
The Freedoms Foundation at Valley Forge yesterday made its 1953 awards to 103 residents of the New York area for helping to "further an understanding of the American way of life."

Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Some items were hit by the defeat of the Senate rider extending the 90 per cent of parity supports on basic farm commodities. Others reflected the Indo-China situation.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today rejected a proposal by North American Airlines, Inc., a nonscheduled network, for a shuttle air-coach service between New York and Washington.

A major preoccupation with the teen-ager -- clothing -- is, because of its expense, likely to be one also with parents, according to Miss Mary S. Ryan of the College of Home Economics at Cornell University.

Daniel J. Riesner was elected president of the National Republican Club last night. As one of his first acts in office he called for drafting Governor Dewey to head the Republican State ticket again this fall.
MILWAUKEE, April 27 -- Leo Durocher's Giants got off on the wrong foot tonight as they set out on their first Western invasion of the year.

SEOUL, Korea, April 27 -- An official spokesman for the South Korean Government denied tonight charges by opposition politicians that they had been subjected to undue pressure in the national election campaign now underway here.

TRENTON, April 27 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, and leaders of the Republicancontrolled State Assembly have reached agreement on a program designed to double the present water supply of New Jersey.
Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church said yesterday he believed "people are getting fed up" with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

LONDON, April 27 -- The stock markets here, which had been slow to react last week to the crisis in Indo-China, are undergoing an abrupt change in sentiment. Today brought a continuation of yesterday's sharp fall in British funds and industrial shares.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 27 -Connecticut's largest bond issue will be authorized tomorrow by Gov. John Lodge.

MONTEREY, Calif., April 27 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Robert B. McClure, post commander at Fort Ord, has recommended against a hardship discharge for Billy Martin, former second baseman for the New York Yankees.

GENEVA, April 27 (AP) -- Following are the text of the proposals of North Korean Foreign Minister Nam Il on Korean elections and excerpts from the speech of South Korean Foreign Minister Pyun Yung Tai:
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A Constitutional amendment to set a general ceiling of 25 per cent on individual and corporation income tax rates was urged at a Senate hearing today.

Two major efforts were begun yesterday to force insurance companies to pay back $29,000,000 in special premiums collected from employers and union-management welfare funds under the State Disability Benefits Act. One move involved a court action, the other a direct appeal to Alfred J. Bohlinger, State Superintendent of Insurance.

" IOLANTHE" contains a libretto and melodies that are among the most charming ever created by Gilbert and Sullivan. And since the delightful pixies, peers and other creatures of the operetta were impersonated with tender care by the American Savoyards last night- at the President Theatre, the results were most gratifying.

LOUISVILLE, April 27 -- If Correlation had not won the Wood Memorial in such authoritative fashion the other day, the hardboots would be in a dither of uncertainty. They wouldn't know which way to jump in trying to alight on a winner for Saturday's eightieth Kentucky Derby.

Monday's total of 672 pints of blood given to the New York Regional Red Cross blood program included 331 pints taken at Ruppert's Brewery, 1639 Third Avenue, and 185 at the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street, as a part of the two-week insurance donation that will continue through Friday.
GENEVA, April 27 -- Diplomatic efforts to explore the possibilities for peace in Indo-China were begun today by France and the Soviet Union.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady at the close yesterday. Prices declined 2 to 14 points on the day.

THIRTY years ago Edna St. Vincent Millay sang of love, beauty youth's perennial rebellion with such exquisite skill that her name meant poetry itself to all who were young in the Nineteen Twenties. Miss Millay died in October, 1950, long after the generation that had adored her had ceased to adore her, cherishing her only as a symbol of lost youth.

The world champion New York Yankees are still looking for their first victory of the season over a right - handed pitcher. Harry Dorish saved the day for the Chicago White Sox as the American League pace-setters topped the Bombers, 4 -- 3, at the Stadium yesterday.
Your article of April 16 headed "Mrs, Hobby Fights for Rise in Funds" is nothing novel in the bureaucratic and creeping socialistic program which has prevailed in this country since 1933.
MOSCOW, April 27 -- The Supreme Soviet approved today a substantial reorganization of the Soviet Council of Ministers.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -Pakistan's food situation has improved to such an extent that it will not need all of the United States' gift of 700,000 tons of wheat.
Steel orders have picked up recently and are expected to show continued improvement during the next three months, the head of the nation's largest steel company said yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 27 -- The entire staff of the Soviet Embassy with their wives and families, numbering about fifty persons, will leave late this week aboard the liner New Australia from Fremantle.

Mental health was called the nation's No. 1 health problem at a reception in Gracie Mansion yesterday that served as a preliminary to the opening next Monday of the New York Mental Health Fund campaign for $1,000,000.

At the rate the McCarthy hearings are moving it looks as though it will be weeks before they can be concluded. Four days of testimony have now gone by, and only the first of the several principals in the case has been thoroughly interrogated.

World merchant ship construction, which reached a post-war high of 6,294,876 gross tons at the end of last year, dropped 127,874 tons to a total of 6,167,002 in the first three months of 1954, according to Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

Chou En-lai looked on "benevolently," it is reported from Geneva, while the representatives of North and South Korea exchanged statements on "free elections" as a preliminary to the "unification" of the country. The Foreign Minister of Communist China is the unknown figure at the conference, and in the opening sessions, at least, replaces Mr. Molotov as the center of public curiosity.

LONDON, April 27 -- Sir Winston Churchill today dashed French hopes of immediate British aid in Indo-China. In a statement attuned to the mood of his listeners in the House of Commons and in the country the Prime Minister declared:

THE Woodchuck season is advancing as rapidly as the grass is growing, for the varmint moves farther from his burrow as the cover increases. He provides an increasingly greater challenge to the shooter, until the first mowing, however, for he is difficult to locate on the lush pastures and slopes.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, outlined to the Governors in conference today the Administration's program for less Federal supervision and more state flexibility in handling Government aid funds.
LOUISVILLE, April 27 -- A superlative performance was given by the Hasty House Farms' Hasty Road in winning the $15,350 Derby Trial at Churchill Downs today.
A reliable barometer indicates that Austria is becoming more and more prosperous. The little country has increased its foreign travel allowances the second time in five months.

A consolidated net income of $10,959,077 was realized last year by W. R. Grace Co. This exceeded the 1952 net of $7,882,878 by 39 per cent, the annual report of the international industrial and trading concern noted yesterday.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 27 -- Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, earned $2,989,478 or 89 cents a share on revenues of $105,863,413, in the first quarter.

Open Show of the Lester Manor Stable scored a thrilling victory in the Eight Thirty Handicap, the classified event that served as the feature at Belmont Park yesterday. The race, over a distance of a mile, attracted fifteen starters. For most of the going the competition was so close that any one of ten horses had a chance for the major share of the gross purse of $15,285.
New issues of public utility securities totaling more than $62,000,000 will be offered to investors today.

The American Legion's national commander said last night that the press and many pulpits were doing a "poor job" of portraying the nation. They are accenting crisis, challenge and "great threats to the American people and American society," and may have "lost touch with the public pulse," he said.
Public service is a trust that requires open-mindedness and tolerance, Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams told 200 probationary patrolmen yesterday.

PARIS, April 27 -- A French Government announcement late tonight indicated that agreement had been reached with the Vietnamese Government and that a joint declaration covering pending treaties between France and Vietnam would be signed tomorrow.
April has been the best comparative month since last October that the Southern Railway Company has experienced "on the revenue side," according to Harry A. DeButts, president.
Headquarters of New York Board Is Named Berg Hall in Memory of the Donor

The disgraceful post-electoral developments in Argentina should remind any who have tended to forget that the Peron regime is still tough, fearful, ruthless and capable of unspeakable reprisals against those who oppose its leader.

I have noted in the April 15 issue of The New York Times a letter from Nathan M. Klein of the North Shore Commuter Association relative to fares on the Long Island Rail Road. This letter is an important contribution to the matter, because it illustrates the muddle-headed thinking which seems to overtake commuter-group presidents and public officials whenever the subject is discussed.
At one of the smaller community agencies a visitor who works in New York and lives in the suburbs inquired recently as to what part the Greater New York Fund played in supporting this agency.
JERUSALEM, April 27 -- Authorities here described as inaccurate a statement published in The New York Times April 16 about Father Eugene Hoade, superior of the Franciscan monastery at Gethsemane.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -Following is the text of the findings and recommendations by a Marine Corps court of inquiry in the case of Col. Frank H. Schwable with comments from the Marine Corps commandant, Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr.; the Secretary of the Navy, Robert B. Anderson, and the Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson, released today:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 27 (UP) -- Trustees of the First Unitarian Church said today they would show the old silent film, "Carmen," and defied this city's chief movie censor to stop them. The film will be shown publicly Sunday night.
MOSCOW, April 27 -- Soviet consumers have been told that there will be shortages of meat this spring and summer.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Defense Department officials have tentatively rejected as too "expensive" the offers of some non-scheduled airlines to operate a supply "airlift" into Indo-China.

Whether Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens was smiling "Grimly" or otherwise at Pvt., G. David Schine in a controversial photograph of the two men was a moot point in yesterday's testimony before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations in Washington.

YONKERS, April 27 (AP) -- David Caudle, 5-year-old gelding owned by the Harris Stables of Massapequa, L. I., won his first start of the season tonight at Yonkers Raceway, taking the $3,500 Somers Pace. Bill Haughton drove David Caudle over the slow track in 2:07 3/5 for a payoff of $25.50,$ 10.30 and $4.80 for $2.
An advertising agency executive said yesterday that retail discount operations were here to stay.
The fashion industry's spotlight will be turned on in Washington tonight, where Harvey Berin, leading New York manufacturer-designer, will receive the second annual Cotton Fashion Award.

HONG KONG, April 27 (UP) -- Comunist gunfire seriously wounded an American civilian pilot last Saturday in the first United States bloodshed of the airlift to Dienbienphu, the Civil Air Transport line announced today.

The fifth annual Emily James Putnam Award for creative writing was presented yesterday to Miss Audrey Gellen at the fourth annual honors assembly at Barnard College. Mis Gellen received the $400 prize for a novel in progress.
GENEVA, April 27 -- The Soviet Union replied today to a United States proposal for pooling the world's atomic energy for peaceful purposes.
First, second and third grade school children lined up like soldiers yesterday for the first tests here of the new Salk vaccine against polio. The bite of the needle caused a few whim-...
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Indo-China crisis is not the first and it won't be the last of the "cold war," but Washington has never gone through one under more peculiar circumstances.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)--One of the prosecution's star witnesses against Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson swore today that he was so confused he wanted to have all his testimony thrown out of Corporal Dickenson's court-martial.

For the city administration to turn away from a proposed sales tax on commercial services and then substitute a payroll tax paid equally by employers and employes would be out of the kettle into the fire with a vengeance. We opposed this payroll tax when Governor Dewey proposed to make it available to the city, on his own motion, in March, 1953.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- With fears of involvement in the Indo-China war reduced, the demand for grain and soybean futures was slack at the opening this morning, and before the close wheat and soybean futures were in a slump, with rather panicky selling indicated.

GENEVA, April 27 -- South Korea and North Korea presented today their diametrically opposed plans for the unification of the war-torn peninsula. Each stood pat on the proposals submitted before the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -The Army maintained in testimony today, that the celebrated picture of Army Secretary Robert T. Stevens and Pvt. G. David Schine was "doctored."
Hundreds of American fliers with considerable wartime experience are willing to fly fighter and bomber planes in Indo-China for about $25,000 a year.
J. J. Del Castillo in his letter in The Times questions Dr. Oppenheimer's right, as an appointed official, to oppose the decision to produce the H-bomb.
The Transport Workers Union. C. I. O., called off a strike last night that had been threatened for 12:01 A. M. today against the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.
A fortune of $1,500,000 was offered yesterday to 4-year-old Yasmin Khan, who had been adjudged a neglected child only the day before.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 27 -- The nation's leading textile machine mill executives are showing high enthusiasm in the modern equipment on display here at the quadrennial exhibition of the American Textile Machinery Association.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., April 27 -- A sterling early season effort of 40, 36 -- 76 enabled Mrs. Saul Weinsier of Fresh Meadow to score a seven-stroke victory in the gross play during the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association medal play tournament at the Rockville Club today.

An American edition of "The Seven Men of Spandau," by Jack Fishman, will be published May 27 by Rinehart. It is an account of the seven Nazi leaders who escaped the gallows at Nuremberg: Doenitz, Hess, von Shirach, Funk, Raeder, Speer and von Neurath.
" Negotiation," Vice President Nixon was quoted as saying in his supposedly anonymous speech, "means Communist domination of Indo-China."
GENEVA, April 28 -- Communist China accused the United States today of having violated China's territorial integrity and warned that this would not be "tolerated."
A conspiracy to monopolize vending-machine sales of cigarettes in the metropolitan area was charged yesterday.

Plans for altering the five-story limestone dwelling at 17 East Seventy-ninth Street into doctor's offices and two duplex apartments were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by the Manfred Sakel Foundation to Fred H. Hill, realty operator.

CINCINNATI, April 28 (UP) -- Jackie Collum pitched one hit-ball for 6 1/3 innings in relief today to notch his first victory of the season as the first-place Cincinnati Redlegs downed the last-place Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 -- 4.
HOBOKEN, N. J., April 28 -- One of Holland's best known carillonneurs, Ferdinand Timmermans, arrived here today aboard the Holland-America Line steamer, Ryndam.

The swift rise of Nikita S. Khrushchev in the last year seems to have reached a new high with his appearance before the Supreme Soviet Monday in a role apparently on a par with that of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov.

BERLIN, April 28 -- British business men are signing new trade agreements here with the Chinese Communists although the Allied embargo on strategic goods forced them to default on 60 per cent of the contracts they made in Peiping last June.

Thirty archdiocesan regional directors met yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Chancery to outline the campaign for the Bishops' Fund for the Victims of War. Collections for the fund's annual appeal will be taken up on May 16 in all archdiocesan churches.

The first round of inoculations in local trials of the Salk polio vaccine was successfully completed in three health districts yesterday. The Health Department reported that 93 per cent of the children who were signed up actually received their shots yesterday and the day before.
A Bowery business man charged yesterday that he had been the $29,990 victim of a horse race bet swindle.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Eisenhower sent to the Senate today the nomination of a West Point classmate, Lieut. Gen. Joseph M. Swing, to be Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization.
The American Museum of Natural History has introduced a device designed to help museum visitors understand the exhibits.
If all amateur athletes were to turn professional "it would be a tragedy too deep for words and too devastating to contemplate," Park Commissioner Robert Moses said last night.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Physicians were able to prevent illness and fear among workers on early atomic energy projects without disclosing the nature of the program, an Atomic Energy Commission official asserted today.
ROME --Tke Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office has placed oR the index of forbidden books a novel by. the Greek author Nikos Kazantzakis.
Last month millions of TV watchers of the Robert Montgomery hour (NBC) saw San dra Michale's play, "Such a Busy Day Tomorrow," the poignant story of an elderly widower, as played by Walter Hampden.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 28 -- Unexplained ringing of the church bell as the pastor proclaimed the resurrection on Sunday was described today by parishioners of St. James Rumanian Greek Orthodox Church. Easter was observed last Sunday by Eastern Orthodox churches.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of Manhattan, urged House members today to sign a petition to force a vote on his proposal to create a joint Congressional committee to investigate subversion.

BONN, Germany, April 28 -- Capt. Nikolai Evgenyevich Khokhlov, Soviet secret agent whose reasons for defecting to the West are being questioned by an increasing number of persons in Bonn, said today he had implicated his wife in the hope that world opinion would save her from the Ministry of the Interior.
The Clarence Derwent Awards for the best supporting performances by a non-featured actress and actor during the current season have been won by Vilma Kurer and David Lewis.
"Avoid fads when you are selecting your clothes." This is the advice that Mollie Parnis gives to women when she discusses the problems of dress with them.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., April 28 -- Heredity, glandular disturbances and lack of exercise are being stressed in discussions of obesity at a unique program conducted this week for members of the Nassau County Nutrition Council.
HACKENSACK, N. J., April 28 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge John J. Francis left today only two of the original fifteen counts of a misconduct - in - office indictment against Walter G. Winne.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 28 (AP) -- French troops hammered back today attempts by Vietminh rebels to crack western barricades within 600 yards of the command headquarters of besieged Dienbienphu.
YONKERS, April 28 (AP) -- Royal Mist rallied to win the Tappan race at Yonkers Raceway tonight by a neck over Direct Sun. Hi Handy was third.
MOSCOW, April 28 -- Portraits of Soviet Government leaders were put up on important buildings in the center of the city today as part of the traditional decoration for the May Day holiday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Senate and House sponsors of wiretapping legislation found themselves so much at odds today that they decided to call in Department of Justice advisers to help them work out a compromise.

The General Motors Corporation, world's largest manufacturing enterprise, achieved the second highest first-quarter earnings and dollar sales volume for civilian products in its history. It also set a new record in the number of passenger cars it had sold in any first quarter.
The toys that all good children and some of the others will get next Christmas will be heavily promoted (to their parents and friends) starting in another week or two.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 28 (UP) -- Two prominent North Carolina amateurs, Billy Joe Patton of Morganton and Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, today led the field into the quarter-final round of the North and South amateur golf tournament.
BELIZE, British Honduras, April 28 -- A turnout of voters beyond the most optimistic hope was apparently shaping up in British Honduras' first general election in its colonial history today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- Dr. Morris Kleinerman, Washington psychiatrist, told an Army court-martial today that Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson was "basically emotionally unstable" and might be an easy prey for Communist bullies.

Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, asserted last night that it was not the function of the State Department to advise Jews outside of Israel on their relations to the new state.

Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said here last night that gains for the United States economy had outweighed the great cost in money and materials of the peace-time development program for atomic energy.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Argentina today made the highest bid, $9,000,000, for a Czech-owned steel mill being sold by the United States Government.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- John J. Muccio, a career diplomat of the highest rank, faces Congressional opposition that may bar him from any assignment requiring Senate confirmation.

The three-man Special Sessions bench that presided in the commercial bribery case of the Jarka Corporation and its president, Frank W. Nolan, reconvened yesterday to clarify the sentences imposed on Monday.

Les Amis d'Escoffier (Friends of Escoffier) tied napkins under their chins last night and sat down to a dinner at the Pierre Hotel that had been prepared under the supervision of Manuel Orta, chef. The company numbered about a hundred members and guests, all men.
The coastal tanker S. E. Graham is back at work plying between Chester, Pa., and New England ports after undergoing a major operation in one of the most unusual ship conversion jobs ever recorded.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- The Senate voted $15,000,000 to fight wind erosion in the "dust bowl" today after urgent new warnings that millions more acres were "ready to blow."
A thousand persons attended a special mass meeting last night of the New York Protestant Episcopal Diocese at New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) in preparation for a campaign to raise $600,000.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that it was a major aim of the Administration to avoid direct United States intervention in the Indo-China war, Mr. Nixon offered no assurance that this policy would succeed.

GENEVA, April 28 -- Secretary of State Dulles and his top United States advisers at the Far East conference here were working hard today to create even the bare framework for the proposed Southeast Asian defense organization -- but their chances of success were diminishing.
FORT BRAGG, N. C., April 28 -- The age of the push button and of atomic arms has come in the Army.

Settlement of a dispute over pensions led the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., to cancel yesterday a threatened strike against the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.

Reports of increased narcotics smuggling through the nation's ports were given credence yesterday with the announcement by the Customs Service of a reward for original information leading to the seizure in a United States port of smuggled heroin.
Plants and seedlings grown by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden went on sale yesterday and the borough's gardeners turned out in strength, despite the rain.

The New York State Athletic Commission suspended Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, Rockaway Beach (Queens) heavyweight, for thirty days yesterday upon the recommendation of three physicians. The reason was a right forearm swelling caused by a blood clot suffered in Jackson's losing bout with Jimmy Slade of the Bronx at Brooklyn's Eastern Parkway Arena on Monday night.

Fordham University will be represented in an athletic contest on the Pacific Coast for the first time next month. An invitation to the Maroon's two-mile relay team to participate in the Los Angeles Coliseum Relays the night of Friday, May 21, has been accepted, Jack Coffey, graduate manager of athletics, said yesterday.
LONDON, April 28 (UP) -- Prime Minister Churchill said tonight that the "hideous apparitions" of modern warfare offered new hope of outlawing war.
The Columbia track team's superiority in the field events carried the Lions to an 82-58 victory over New York University yesterday at Baker Field.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday, closing unchanged to 10 points up. Movements were in a narrow range all day.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, told the White House Conference of Governors today that favorable economic signs led him to the conclusion that "we are not now headed for a depression."
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Federal Reserve Board must have a free hand in determining credit policies necessary for economic stability, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States said today.
GENEVA, April 28 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from speeches today by Secretary of State Dulles and Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China at the Geneva conference:

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, April 28 (AP) -- Forty Americans, including two former British champions, Frank Stranahan and Bob Sweeny, have entered the British amateur golf championship, the Royal and Ancient Golf Club disclosed today.

GENEVA, April 28 -- Military, political and geographic complexities are viewed in informed Western quarters at Geneva as presenting almost insuperable obstacles to the realization of a cease-fire in the Indo-Chinese war.

CAIRO, April 28 -- The revolutionary rulers of Egypt early this morning arrested twelve army officers and forty civilians accused of plotting May Day disorders with Communists and other dissident elements.

CLEVELAND, April 28 (UP) -- Outfielder Harry Simpson vowed today he'd one day be back with the Cleveland Indians, but said he had "no complaint" about being sold to Indianapolis of the American Association.
Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday that the Board of Education's policy on its employes' membership in the Communist party was reasonable and would not be altered.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Gov. John D. Lodge of Connecticut said here today that the $398,000,000, 129-mile expressway his state was planning to build "will be one of the greatest highway engineering achievements in the country."
TRENTON, April 28 -- Thirty-three Rider College students were arrested here last night for operating a slot machine in a fraternity house one block from the New Jersey State House.

Capt. Fermon Stone, Eastern Air Lines director of flight operations, estimates that during the twenty years he was making daily flights as a pilot he was asked by 10,000 different passengers just how far they could see from various altitudes.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 28 -- This city today became the first in Connecticut to receive an allocation of Federal funds for a slum clearance and redevelopment project under provisions of the Housing Act of 1949:
PARIS, April 28 -- The Communists failed to produce a general strike in France today.

A census of persons suffering from muscular dystrophy in the city was proposed yesterday. The plan was discussed by representatives of local chapters of the Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America, meeting at the Health Department auditorium at 125 Worth Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 (UP) -- Lieut. Bobby Brown, former third baseman with the New York Yankees, made a surprise return home today from the Far East and announced that he would join the staff of the San Francisco City and County Hospital on July 1.

Directors of the Studebaker Corporation voted yesterday to omit action on the dividend on the common stock ordinarily declared at this time. A dividend of 40 cents a share was distributed in March. The company paid dividends of 75 cents in each quarter of 1953.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt had just called today's session of the Army-McCarthy hearing to order when Senator Joseph R. McCarthy broke in with: "Mr. Chairman?"

Buried down at the bottom of the page and almost lost amid the volume of news the other day was a small item of eight lines. The one-line "head" announced "Noise Annoyed 288,595 in '53." That is probably a magnificent understatement, since noise annoys everyone at one time or another.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Pvt. G. David Schine spent about an hour late today with the McCarthy subcommittee staff with which he once worked, but brushed past reporters in tightlipped silence.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Senators investigating the Army-McCarthy dispute are disturbed about the possible duration of the hearing. And they are becoming increasingly impatient with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's "point of order" interruptions.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. John Seybold, Governor of the Panama Canal Zone, said here tonight "there is no need for alarm" about a crack in a rock ledge on one cut of the Panama Canal.
The Army opened a new line of attack yesterday on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigations of Fort Monmouth, N. J.

THE pollock are making an effort to crowd the snowshoe flounders out of the angling picture in Montauk waters. Reports indicate the week-end should provide good fishing in the Rip, both for trollers and those who prefer fishing "on top."

A jeweler was robbed of more than $190,000 in set and unset diamonds in the midtown area last evening. He made a desperate but futile effort to trap the thieves by hopping on bound feet to notify the elevator operator in his building.
PARIS, April 28 -- France and Vietnam signed today a joint declaration of agreement for the "total independence" of Vietnam.
Seldom-heard works by three composers were presented last night by the Juilliard Orchestra and Chorus in a special concert at the Juilliard Concert Hall.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas has been chosen to receive the 1954 award of the American Foot Health Foundation, it was announced here today.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation has agreed not to oppose conversion of Seventh and Eighth Avenues to one-way operation. The company acted after it had received assurance that bus franchise taxes would be modified to enable the operators to recoup losses they expect to suffer as the result of the new traffic pattern.

The one-story factory building at 36-18 Greenpoint Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by Dispensers, Inc., from Koral Casten. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker in the transaction. The lessee will use the building as a factory and a warehouse.

Borough President Hulan E. Jack changed the signpost at the northeast corner of Union Square and Seventeenth Street yesterday to "Union Square, U. S. A." in preparation for patriotic May Day ceremonies to be held there Saturday.

Sofarsogood was good enough to win the Fashion at Belmont Park yesterday. The Hal Price Headley color-bearer, overlooked by most of the 16,062 fans, ran in front all the way in the four and a half furlong dash on the Widener course.
YONKERS, April 28 -- With the fanfare and showmanship of a state fair premiere, the $30,000,000 Cross County Center on Central Park Avenue here opened today.

The Las Vegas Valley Water District, Nevada, received bids yesterday on a new issue of $8,700,000 of waterworks bonds maturing serially from 1957 to 1990. The best bid was an interest cost of 3.9704 per cent, submitted by Ira Haupt Co. and Cruttenden Co. and associates.
Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced last night that the Department of Justice was making an anti-trust investigation of the automobile industry.

PITTSBURGH, April 28 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steel Company began formal operation today of its new cold-rolled sheet mill at the Allenport, Pa., plant. It marked the completion of a $65,000,000 expansion program.
ST. LOUIS, April 28 -- With two out in the tenth inning today, the Cardinals pushed over the run that gave them a 6-5 victory over the Dodgers, who had tied the score in the ninth, also with two out.

At 12:01 A. M. yesterday the Twenty-sixth Precinct of the Police Department, a secluded but active unit, ceased to function. The precinct's work -along the Hudson River has been apportioned among four other station houses, with accompanying transfer of personnel.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A film of an eruption of a cloud of hydrogen gas on the surface of the sun that burst with an energy equal to 100,000 billion twenty-megaton hydrogen bombs was shown here today at the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 28 -- The Social Committee of the Economic and Social Council urged non-member as well as member governments today to give the United Nations full information on the extent of slavery and similar practices still existing within their borders.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The question of the loyalty of scientists working on research projects under the Department of Health, Education and Welfare has resulted in the cancellation of grants or the refusal of grants to nearly thirty persons since June, 1952.

Israeli fall fashions previewed for the press yesterday showed the influence of the American consumer's demand for casual, practical styles at moderate prices. Sweaters, separates, coats and accessories that had been designed expressly for American consumption were presented in a fashion show and series of exhibits at the McAlpin Hotel.

The rules drawn up by the National Labor Relations Board for a new collective bargaining representation election by May 26 among longshoremen in the Port of New York seem sensible and fair. The board's regional officers have a month in which to complete their preparations.

By coincidence and other circumstances voters at next November's election will be acting upon an unusually large number of positions in New York State's highest law tribunal, the seven-member Court of Appeals. Four seats must be acted on. Chief Judge Edmund H. Lewis will be retiring for statutory reasons of age.

Assurance that 4,000 dock workers who are not legally required to register with the Waterfront Commission would be permitted to vote in next month's pier union election was given yesterday by Charles T. Douds, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

The Board of Hospitals recommended yesterday that $6,842,711 of new projects be deferred and that the money be used instead to raise salaries of nurses and other professional workers in existing facilities.

Today's new film is "Angels One Five," a British-made drama of World War II starring Jack Hawkins, Michael Denison and Dulcie Gray, at the Beekman, Gramercy and Eighth Street Playhouse. The Templar Production was produced by John W. Gossage and Derek Twist and directed by George More O'Ferrall. Mr. Twist also wrote the screen play from an original story by Pelham Groom.
Not only can business men talk about the weather; they can also do something about it, by using it to their advantage.

A color television picture tube, said to be more than twice as large in viewing area and considerably cheaper than earlier tubes, was demonstrated yesterday by the Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories in Passaic, N. J.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 21, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

Public housing tends to fill the vacuum that exists in the housing situation, Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, told members of the Real Estate Board of New York yesterday at their monthly meeting at the Brass Rail Restaurant, 100 Park Avenue.
Dr. John F. Thompson, chairman of the International Nickel Company of Canada, stressed the importance of keeping the price of nickel stable at the annual shareholders' meeting in Toronto yesterday.

Only a Saar settlement remains to fulfill French conditions for opening the parliamentary debate that will decide the fate of the European Defense Community. The British have done their part in pledging an association with the European Army so close and definite that the latest French complaint is that Britain will have too much voice in the E. D. C. for a nonmember.

JERUSALEM, April 28 -- Maj. Gen Vagn Bennike, chief of the United Nations truce supervision organization, joined Jordan today in condemning Israel in the "strongest terms" for an all-day siege of Budrus village Monday. Military forces of Israel were accused of having kept up heavy machine-gun and rifle fire on the community from across the frontier.
JERUSALEM, April 27 -- Five years after the armistice agreements between Israel and her Arab neighbors, gunfire still crackles along the border.

The Yiddish Culture Chorus, with the assistance of the Cantors Concert Ensemble and eight soloists, will present at Town Hall on Sunday afternoon what is believed to be the first New York performance of Sigismund Neukomm's oratorio, "Mount Sinai; or, The Ten Commandments."

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Sales and earnings of the Inland Steel Company reached near-record levels in the first quarter this year and the second-quarter outlook is for an operating rate at or near capacity, Clarence B. Randall, chairman, said today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 28 -- Delay in completing the reconstruction of the Bronx River Parkway between Bronxville and the Bronx, including a new over-pass for the Cross County Parkway at Fleetwood, drew a protest today from the Westchester County Park Commission.

THE charge of the Light Brigade took place in the same decade as most of the main battles of the Civil War. It lasted just twenty minutes, that cavalry action at Balaclava in the Crimean War on a suicidal afternoon in 1854. Then, with the help of Lord Tennyson, it became immortal.
TOKYO, April 28 -- Japan ratified today the long-debated Mutual Defense Assistance Treaty with the United States and agreed to limited rearmament by land, sea and air with American aid.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Three former officials of the Federal Housing Administration defended the agency's policies today in the face of new attacks.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- Louis F. Budenz, former Communist party official and editor of The Daily Worker, testified to day that in 1945 the Communist party had its own loyalty review board.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) estimated yesterday its consolidated net earnings for the quarter ended on March 31 at $146,000,000, or $2,41 a share on the outstanding stock.

The American designer's pre-occupation with surface appearance rather than structural form is evident in a small collection introduced yesterday by William Armbruster. Most of the pieces, which are on view at the Edgewood Furniture Company, 334 East Seventy-fifth Street, and available there through decorators, are variations on Mr. Armbruster's earlier designs.
CHICAGO, April 28 -- Heavy long liquidation cut wheat futures sharply in the early trade today. However, buying resistance developed on the setbacks, and there was a partial recovery.

Quite early in the McCarthy hearings yesterday Senators Potter and Symington stressed the point already made by this newspaper, that at the rate the proceedings were dragging on the committee would be in session for weeks to come. Both Senators pleaded for more expeditious handling of the testimony; but during the course of the day we were unable to observe much quickening of the snail's pace at which the hearings are being conducted.
CAIRO, April 28 -- The United States decision to give arms to Iraq has produced a reaction of mingled surprise, puzzlement and pleasure in the Arab press and Government circles.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- Acting Chairman Karl E. Mundt said today he did not know when the Senate Subcommittee on Investigations would pursue its inquiry into a hotly disputed photograph in the Army-McCarthy hearings.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UP) -- News photographers' backs do not make particularly interesting viewing for the television audience tuning in the McCarthy-Army hearings, Senator Karl E. Mundt said today.
The New York Central Railroad Company filed suit yesterday to block another avenue whereby 800,000 shares -- 12.4 per cent -- of the road's stock might be voted against the management.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The scheduled airlines set traffic records last year.

The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, which produces the Nash passenger automobile and a line of electric household and commercial appliances through two major divisions, experienced sharp reverses in the first quarter of this year.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of testimony today on the fifth day of hearings by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which is considering the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. The hearing began at 10:42 A. M.

LONDON, April 28 -- The Gold Coast is to take another big step toward self-rule. The British Government has accepted proposals from Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah and his Government under which the last three British Cabinet Ministers will be replaced by natives.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 28 -- Marshal Tito assuerd Yugoslavia's peasants today that their holdings would not be further curtailed. The Yugoslav President promised that the Government would not return to forced collectivization.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The inquiry which the Senate subcommittee is making into charges by the Department of the Army involving its permanent chairman and members of its staff has already demonstrated the soundness of a criticism cited before the hearings began.

Commodity prices on the New York exchanges closed irregularly lower yesterday in generaly light trading. However, coffee had its most active day since Jan. 13 and the world sugar market registered the greatest sales since March 22.
Counsel for Joseph P. Ryan, accused of stealing $48,000 from the old International Longshoremen's Association, which he formerly headed, asserted yesterday he had spent the money to combat communism.
The outlook is good that labor and management will bargain collectively during 1954 without major strikes, A. H. Raskin, labor reporter for The New York Times, said yesterday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 28 (AP) -- Bermuda scored a clean sweep in the International One-Design yachting competition against the United States, taking the fourth race today to finish with 25 1/4 points. Undine, Ariel and Maya took the first three places for the victors in choppy seas whipped by an 18-mile-an-hour wind.

LOUISVILLE, April 28 -- Boston Mandel, who draws up the probable odds for the Churchill Downs racing program, was asked today to figure out a line for Saturday's Kentucky Derby. Mandel was happy to oblige.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson is almost fully recovered from a serious kidney operation and is dictating outlines for four speeches he is scheduled to make in the next six weeks, his aides reported tonight.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 28 -- A six-point proposal by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India for settlement of the war in Indo-China failed to win the endorsement of the Asian Prime Ministers conference in the opening sessions today.

Rain and cold weather caused the postponement of the scheduled second contest of the three-game Yankee-White Sox series at the Stadium yesterday. However, it was not altogether a lost day for the world champion Bombers.
For a while yesterday the stock market seemed to be in the initial stage of an important decline. Losses for recent favorites ranged between 1 and 3 points and some extended to 5.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A steady increase in national willingness to face and solve the problem of disability was reported today by Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

One of the nation's largest electric utility companies, the seven-state American Gas and Electric Company, reported yesterday that its assets would reach the one-billion dollar mark in the middle of this year. The company and its subsidiaries operate in the territory extending from Michigan to the Appalachian region.

A decline last week of 890,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 178,033,000 barrels, compared with 178,923,000 a week earlier and 156,747,000 a year ago.

Walt Whitman used to go to Coney Island to enjoy solitude. In the poet's days the resort offered much space where one could be alone, even though 300 carriages and more would roll up of a Sunday to the Coney Island House.

The Toronto Mendelssohn Choir has completed one of the biggest undertakings of its fifty-eight-year history. Having presented Handel's "Messiah" at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, it presented there last night a second of the giant works of the choral repertory, Bach's "Passion of Our Lord According to St. Matthew."
New issues of corporate debt securities and preferred stock totaling $34,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates.

LONDON, April 28 -- The stock markets here closed generally dull again today after prices had been marked up on the strength of Sir Winston Churchill's statement that Britain had given no pledge of aid to the French in Indo-China. The volume of trading was down.

Maj. Gen. Kirke B. Lawton, commanding general of Fort Monmouth, has been quoted by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, as having declared it "did no good" to suspend security risks at the post in years past because a Pentagon appeals board would reinstate them.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Preferential treatment allegedly enjoyed by Pvt. G. David Schine in the Army was outlined today by Ray H. Jenkins, special counsel to the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

Net income and net sales of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in the first quarter of 1954 were 55.9 per cent and 6.4 per cent respectively, above the results achieved in the corresponding three months of 1953.

A new volume in Dutton's Advanced Geographic Series entitled "India and Pakistan: A Social and Regional Geography' .vill be issued May 17., The author is O. H. K. Spate of the Australian National University, who spent six years compiling the' material fop the book.

LONDON, April 28 -- The British Labor party welcomed today a supporter of Aneurin Bevan to its "shadow cabinet" and adopted a resolution on policy in Southeast Asia that embodied many of Mr. Bevan's ideas.

The United States and Communist China clashed yesterday for the first time in open debate at the Geneva conference. Speaking with the arrogance of a conqueror laying down his terms. Premier Chou En-lai in effect called on the Western Powers to get out of Asia and leave him a free hand to apply the Communist program.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Farmers producing some major crops may get an opportunity to vote on Federal price support programs.

The new Cross Country Center in Yonkers will not walk away with all the shopping business in Westchester and the North Bronx if Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., can help it. Alexander's struck its first successful blow yesterday in what should become a continuing battle for customers.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 28 (UP) -- Doris Hart, Coral Gables (Fla.) star trying to win the women's singles title in the British hard courts tennis championships for the fourth straight year, gained the quarter-finals today with a 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3 victory over Britain's Kathleen Stott.

NEW MARKET, England, April 28 (AP) -- Darius went under a heavy whip a furlong from home, took the lead from a field today and won the Two Thousand Guineas -- first British classic of the turf season.
The Commerce and Labor Departments have agreed to get together on their employment and unemployment statistics.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- The House of Delegates of the American Nurses Association unanimously backed today the refusal of its board of directors to endorse the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution of the United States.
DENVER, April 28 -- The League of Women Voters has more than doubled its membership in the last ten years, the organization's biennial convention heard today.

The case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer epitomizes the problem of a whole nation obsessed with a feeling of guilt arising from past association with Communists at home and abroad. I know nothing about Dr. Oppenheimer as a person except what I read in the papers, but I know a great deal about the conditions which swept many thousands of similar persons into association with the Communists during the Nineteen Thirties and up to 1945.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- George Glass, newly established as an independent producer, has taken an option on "Father Come Home," a recent magazine story by Robert Carson.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- At the insistence of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, the Army produced a list of its uniformed personnel attending today's McCarthy-Pentagon hearing.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 -- Interest in community property estimated at $500,000 was waived today by Mrs. Shelagh Mary Packard, 31 yearsold, daughter of J. Arthur Rank, British film producer, when she was divorced from Fred M. Packard, 35, a Hollywood producer.

Despite the delay in getting a license for the 150-seat arena theatre at 83 East Fourth Street, Macdonald Eaton, one of the four organizers of the new stage group called Two-by-Four Productions, praised yesterday the cooperation of the various municipal departments involved.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest transportation system, reported today a net loss of $1,588,000 in March, bringing the loss for the first quarter to $9,975,000.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 27 -- An outsider could not deduce from his first impressions here that there was anything special happening in Indo-China. While the military situation at Dienbienphu remains grave and the over-all Indo-China problem agitates the chancellories of the West, life in this capital city of Vietnam continues about as usual.
The Democratic State Committee voted unanimously yesterday to hold the Democratic state convention in Manhattan, beginning Sept. 21.

MILWAUKEE, April 28 -- Ruben Gomez, who made a habit of tripping the Braves in his freshman year in the National League last season, revealed today he still retained the knack, whatever else his difficulties might be this spring.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., April 28 -- Eight hundred persons in this community, who had paid $1 each to hear a debate Friday night on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, will have to accept a substitute champion for the Wisconsin Republican.

This is a democracy, not a totalitarian regime. It is as legitimate for loyal Americans to challenge the policy of Secretary Dulles as it was for loyal Americans to criticize the policies of President Roosevelt, President Truman or Secretary Acheson. The attitude of Secretary Dulles means not the peril of war but the certainty of war.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., April 28 -- Fifty years ago, when Charles F. Delano became the owner, publisher, editor and general energizing force of The Amityville Record, he planned to make the position permanent. He hasn't changed his plan, except by enlarging his staff, principally by the addition of his son-in-law and daughter, Walter and Jessie Gunnison.

Imports of knitted wool outerwear in 1953 amounted to almost $15,000,000 as against $12,617,000 in 1952, according to Sidney Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the National Knitted Outerwear Association.
GENEVA, April 28 -- The Soviet Union rejected today a French request that it intervene with the Vietminh to make possible the evacuation of the thousand wounded men in Dienbienphu.

ENTEBBE, Uganda, April 28 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth II defied a Mau Mau death threat and flew to Uganda today on her world tour. Thousands of Buganda tribesmen, ignoring Nationalist demands that they stay away, turned out in a tremendous welcome to the young monarch.
The coming week will see the peak of the California carrot crol. The Golden State sends five times as many here as any other state. And swelling the supplies are carrots from Arizona and Texas.
The "abject surrender" of shipping and stevedoring company executives to waterfront racketeers was blamed yesterday by the Brooklyn rackets grand jury for present conditions on the city's piers.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, April 28 (UP) -- United States forces in Western Germany have been bolstered by a third United States battalion of six 280-mm. "atomic" cannon, the United States Army European headquarters disclosed today.

LOUISVILLE, April 28 -- When dawn broke at a disgustingly early hour over the barn area at Churchill Downs today, it ushered in a cold, bleak day. The little gray colt from California, Determine, stirred in his stall and dived for the feed box. Not only is he the smallest horse in Saturday's Kentucky Derby but he also is the hungriest.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Reported threats by the Secretary of the Army to relieve a general after he had praised Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Communist-hunting methods stirred new controversy before a Senate investigating subcommittee today.

The National Cash Register Company achieved the highest first quarter sales in its history in the three months ended with March. The aggregate was $60,198,476, or an increase of 4.04 per cent over the $57,858,471 volume transacted in the 'corresponding three months of last year.

Three five-story dwellings occupying a frontage of seventy-three and one-half feet at 284-86-88 Lexington Avenue between Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets have been purchased for cash by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators in a deal negotiated by Horace S. Ely Co., brokers.

The safety of 5 per cent borated baby powders, confirmed by clinical research studies made public yesterday and given a clean bill of health Jan. 30 by the Food and Drug Administration, is almost an academic subject today.

DOVER, Del., April 29 (UP) -- The merger of General Dynamics Corporation and Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation -- two major defense producers -- was approved today by stockholders of both concerns at separate meetings here.

LOUISVILLE, April 29 -- It probably didn't mean a thing, but Correlation, the California-bred favorite for Saturday's eightieth Kentucky Derby, had a workout at Churchill Downs this morning that was not as frisky as the trainer wanted it to be.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., April 29 -- Giant Douglas C-124 troop transports, gliding down out of a murky sky onto the Camp Mackall Airfield today, emphasized the increasing airlift capabilities of the United States.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 29 -Asian Prime Ministers, meeting here, argued heatedly today on resolutions bracketing communism with colonialism as equal threats to democratic freedoms.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- A device capable of storing "magnetic memories" has been perfected by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to "raise the speed and reliability of today's high-speed automatic computers."
A Connecticut fishing-reel manufacturer who looks for uranium in his spare time has put in a claim to the mineral rights of about two-thirds of Camp Smith, near Peekskill, N. Y.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- An appeal to the American Nurses Association to help make nursing in Korea the honored profession it is in the United States was made today.

Arlington, Va., borrowed $4,047,000 yesterday on issues of bonds to finance various improvements. The securities were sold at competitive bidding to a syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. at an interest cost of 2.5186 per cent. The bonds will mature from 1955 to 1980, and will bear interest rates of 5 per cent, 2 1/2 per cent and 1 per cent.

Republic Steel Corporation, third largest steel producer, has entered the field of atomic energy. This was disclosed yesterday by Charles M. White, president of Republic, at a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts here.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 29 -- Dr. Harold L. Cross of New York, author of "The People's Right to Know," received the annual research award of Kappa Tau Alpha, national journalistic scholarship society, at the fifth annual Rutgers University School of Journalism awards dinner tonight.
LONDON, April 29 -- Sir Oliver Franks, former British Ambassador to the United States, today opened a photo-panel display marking Columbia University's bicentennial celebration.
TETERBORO, N. J., April 29 -- Men from all branches of the aviation industry continued yesterday to deluge a small office here with offers to volunteer for air service in Indo-China.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Eisenhower covered these main points at his news conference today:

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 29 -- Bert Darrell's craft Teaser, Bermuda entry in the King Edward VII Gold Cup race, defeated the United States yacht, Coquette, sailed by Don Mackenzie of Larchmont, N. Y., in both races today to retain the trophy and score a sweep in the series.

WASHINGTON, April 29 --Senate investigators established today that a New York group advised the Federal Housing Administration that it had split $800,000 in "windfall profits" made on a Government-insured mortgage.
ROME, April 29 -- Dawn Addams, a 23-year-old Hollywood actress who was born in Britain, became a Roman Princess today by her marriage to Vittorio Emanuele Massimo. Prince of Roccasecca dei Volsci.

With obvious reference to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Carmine G. DeSapio, the leader of Tammany Hall, attacked last night Republicans who exploit the issue of communism to confuse the American people and conceal "the real issues."

The cultural as well as political importance of establishing a permanent American theatre devoted to Shakespearean drama was stressed yesterday by Lewis W. Douglas, former Ambassador to Great Britain.
Here's a quick summary of what Robert Whitehead, who has just returned from a mission abroad, is pondering:
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 29 (UP) -- Col. K. H. Leitch, California Selective Service Director, has locked up the draft file on Pvt. G. David Schine for "safekeeping."

WASHINGTON, April 29 -Colleagues of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer in the American Physical Society, are divided in their views as to whether the war-time scientific director of the atomic bomb project should have been subjected to a hearing on his being a possible "security risk."

The Brooklyn rackets grand jury is entitled to the thanks of the community for its four years of patient investigation into waterfront conditions in the Port of New York. In clear, vigorous language its presentment reminds us that the waterfront situation is still deplorable.

BONN, Germany, April 29 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer began today his fight to stem the growing demand for an alternative to his policy of Western integration. This policy has been blocked by the French delay in ratifying the European Defense Community Treaty.
Some time ago you published a letter which was critical of the Randall Commission's Merchant Marine recommendations.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -Manufacturers' shipments and new orders were both higher in March than in February on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.

LONDON, April 29 (Reuters) -- The Government tonight rejected suggestions that an inquiry should be held into the running of the Grand National, in which four of this year's twenty-nine starters had to be killed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- Harry Belafonte, now appearing in the Broadway musical review, "Almanac," staged by the late John Murray Anderson, has been signed for the film version of "Carmen Jones."
WASHINGTON, April 29 -Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 626,181 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Five horses were entered for the six-furlong sixth race at Belmont yesterday when the programs were printed. G. C. Antre's gelding Virtuous was withdrawn at the last minute and only four went into the starting gate. A moment after the gate was opened there were only three.

The tea industry is making gains, but not at the expense of coffee, and is avoiding any action that would hurt coffee's competitive position.
