This assurance was given yesterday by Samuel Winokur, president of the Tea Association of the U. S. A. and vice president of the Seeman Brothers, Inc., at the tea group's mid-year meeting at the Biltmore Hotel.

MONTREAL, April 29 (UP) -Len (Red) Kelly, Detroit Red Wing defenseman, today increased his 1953-54 National Hockey League bonus earnings to $6,000 by winning the James Norris and Lady Byng Memorial Trophies.
Fourteen teachers and a clerk were dismissed by the Board of Education yesterday for failing to cooperate in the drive against subversives.
Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of the "King of Hearts" on Thursday night at the Lyceum Theatre for the benefit of the Catholic Center for the Blind.
A New York minister recently urged us not to let New York cynicism hide the warm heart of its inhabitants. "True Glory," he said, "dwells where good deeds are done."

Fifteen years ago the world was, for all practical purposes, innocent of global war, atomic weapons and television. People in this country were rather pleased with themselves for having come through a historic depression and many looked hopefully toward the future as an era of peace, prosperity and general goodwill.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 28 -Nguyen Huu Tri, Governor of North Vietnam, said today the Vietnamese people would "never accept" partition of Vietnam.
One hundred and eighteen of the nation's outstanding merchants were on their way home yesterday, replete with honors and three days of New York hospitality.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., had net earnings in the first quarter of about $46,000,000, or some $2,000,000 more than in the similar period last year, B. Brewster Jennings, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.

Bonds on the New York Stock Exchange on March 31 stood at the highest month-end average price since February, 1951, the exchange reported yesterday. The price was $100.64, against $100.28 at the end of February and $100.90 on Feb. 28, 1951.
LONDON, April 29 -- Hoboes, who in civil service terminology are "persons without a settled way of living," are turning their backs on Britain's welfare state and moving to the Continent.

LOUISVILLE, April 29 -- There was a now historic headline in a local gazette just before the Kentucky Derby some years ago. It read: "Derby Field Grows as Horses Drop Out." To the uninitiated this had to be a contradiction in terms. But the hardboots accepted it as an obvious statement of fact.
The city's measles epidemic is continuing to run its course. A total of 29,152 cases and fourteen deaths have been reported so far this year, the Health Department disclosed yesterday.

A New York County grand jury yesterday criticized the Police Department's personnel recruitment program for "disappointing inefficiencies." However, it said it had been unable to find evidence to support charges that there had been improper appointments to the force.

MOSCOW, April 29 (AP) -- The Literary Gazette published today a letter to the editor denouncing two Western diplomats as "provocateurs." It said they posed as French actors to put across capitalist propaganda in a theatrical restaurant.

A series of reorganization moves were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams as part of his plans to streamline the department and increase efficiency. They will take effect tomorrow.

DENVER, April 29 -- Delegates of the non-partisan League of Women Voters voted overwhelmingly today to concentrate on the subject of individual liberties in the United States during the next two years.

LIMA, Peru, April 29 -- A military court today sentenced thirty-nine Peruvians to terms ranging up to seven years for subversive activities in connection with strike movements in late 1952 and early last year.
To open the forthcoming season-in-the-sun, Ohrbach's presented yesterday to the press a collection of bathing suits and summer separates in its properly named "Sun Shop."

The final Thursday night subscription concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society took place under Mr. Mitropoulos' direction last night in Carnegie Hall, and the occasion proved a triumph for conductor and orchestra.

Charges brought by Joseph Anthony Maggio that the book and movie, "From Here to Eternity," invaded his privacy by allegedly making him one of the story's characters were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Arthur Dunaif in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn.
This port's rival longshore unions agreed yesterday on May 26 as the date for their second battle of ballots.
GENEVA, April 29 -- The Soviet Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, accused the United States today of threatening China with invasion from Formosa and Korea.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 2 points higher to 6 points lower than on Wednesday. The market held within a narrow range all day.
RICHMOND, Va., April 29 -Stockholders of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway applauded today defense of the company's controversial sale its holdings of New York Central stock for $20,000,000.

Leaders of social agencies were called upon yesterday to examine carefully the work being done by their professional personnel with an eye to defining those parts of the job that could be carried out just as successfully by volunteers. Unless such analyses are made and more volunteer help is recruited, social agencies will never be able to meet community needs, Frederick I. Daniels declared.
CAIRO, April 29 -- Egypt's former Queen Narriman, divorced wife of exiled King Farouk, has revealed plans to marry the son of a man who was one of the closest associates of her first husband.
The worth of the pound sterling in American money is pressing against the upper limit of the trading range permitted by the Bank of England.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -President Eisenhower's distaste for the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was made clear at his news conference today.
Gen Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, said yesterday he had attended a hearing of the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations last week solely for his own information.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -President Eisenhower charted today a cautious middle course for the United States in the battle for Indo-China.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 29 -No old house in Westchester ever had as many girl friends as the historic Wayside Inn at Post Road and Wayside Lane here.
DETROIT, April 29 -- A complete "packaged" layaway tank plant was unveiled today by the Ford Motor Company and the United States Army. It is valued at $40,000,000.

The twenty-year history of the Federal Housing Administration should show beyond question that Government guarantees are absolutely essential if we are to obtain a substantial volume of home building in this country.
Greenwich Village is one of the target areas for next week in the Sanitation Department's anti-litter campaign, Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain announced yesterday.

WITH the water temperatures on some stretches of the popular Catskill streams hovering around the 50-degree mark, the "Iron Fraudator" is emerging from its watery habitat, which should banish the frowns of the dry fly enthusiasts.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP) -- Joseph M. Bransky, district supervisor of the Federal Narcotics Bureau, has asked that the Pennsylvania Board of Censors ban on the film "She Shoulda Said No" be sustained.

Mystery Writers of America, Inc., last night announced the award of a ceramic bust of Edgar Allan Poe to Charlotte Jay, Australian novelist, for writing "Beat Not the Bones," adjudged the best mystery novel published in America during 1953.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A "big three" meeting calculated to start talk of new labor alliances is set for tomorrow.

GENEVA, April 29 -- Vietnam's Chief of State agreed today to the participation of Vietminh representatives in the Geneva conference on Far Eastern affairs. French and United States officials here said Bao Dai attached certain reservations to his agreement but confidence was expressed that any difficulties in this connection could be ironed out.
MOSCOW, April 29 -- A glimpse has been provided into the research program of Soviet scientists below and above the great Arctic ice cap.

ST. LOUIS, April 29 (UP) -- Dick Cole, a former member of the St. Louis Cardinals, delivered a bases-loaded, two-out single in the ninth inning tonight to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-3 victory over St. Louis.

DAN LUTZ' lively paintings at the Milch Galleries are divided, by subject matter, into two groups: "Michigan Summer" and "Mexican Sojourn," titles that indicate the artist's lot may not be such a bad one after all.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Department store sales last week were 2 per cent below those of the corresponding week of last year.

Frankie Frisch will be the new host and chief instructor, beginning tomorrow, on "Junior Sports Session" over Channel 2 from 8 to 8:30 A. M. He replaces Tommy Henrich, who has left broadcasting to enter business in Cincinnati.

WHEN the last customer leaves Macy's tomorrow night at 6 o'clock, 200 men will start to change the store inside and out into a tremendous bower. They must hang, plant and bank 2,500,000 blossoms before the store opens Monday morning.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson used the words of Maj. Gen. William F. Dean today to complete his defense against court-martial charges that he collaborated with his Communist captors while a prisoner in Korea.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that the first thing a sailor wanted when he "hit the beach" aftera tour of duty at sea was -- a glass of milk.

NEW DELHI, India, April 29 -India and Communist China concluded an agreement on Tibet today guaranteeing "mutual nonaggression" and recognizing the principle of "peaceful co-existence" of the two nations.

Millions of leaflets borne by high-altitude balloons began dropping into Czechoslovakia yesterday, according to a message received by the Free Europe Committee, Inc., here from the Crusade for Freedom in Munich, Germany.
YONKERS, April 29 (AP) -Yonkers Raceway said today owners and drivers were threatening to strike over demands for a greater share of the harness racing track's proceeds.
YONKERS, April 29 (AP) -- For the second time in three nights Billy Haughton drove four winners at Yonkers Raceway tonight, including Florita in the Saw Mill Pace.
St. John's University retained its hold on first place in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference yesterday by defeating New York University, 5 -- 2, at Ohio Field in the Bronx.

BUFFALO, N. Y., April 29 (AP) -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation today reported net earnings of $1,699,069 for the three months ended April 3. This was an increase of 96 per cent over the 1953 first quarter figure of $866,692.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 29 -- Israel and Egypt were censured by the United Nations Mixed Armistice Commission today for border clashes along the truce demarcation line of the Gaza strip last Sunday and Monday.

Another voice has been raised in support of the campaign by the American Newspaper Publishers Association and its Bureau of Advertising to make summer slumps in all kinds of business a mere state of mind.
A $2,700,000 decrease in its Federal income tax bill helped the Union Pacific Railroad limit a decline in earnings in the first quarter this year.

The prosecution in the grand larceny trial of Joseph P. Ryan, former president of the old International Longshoremen's Association, presented testimony and evidence yesterday to show that he spent $460 from a union account to pay for a cruise to Guatemala in 1950.
The steamship conference system was condemned yesterday by a shipping executive as a prime contributor to unsettled rate conditions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 29 -- The Economic and Social Council called today for a world-wide survey by the United Nations on press censorship of foreign correspondents.

JOHNSON CITY, N. Y., April 29 -- The removal of Dr. D. Elton Trueblood from the post of chief of religious policy of the United States Information Service was demanded here today by the American Council of Christian Churches.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 -- Frank N. Belgrano Jr., president and chairman of Transamerica Corporation, told stockholders today that this would be a better year for them "than the satisfactory results attained in 1953."

Sneak atomic attacks on this country could be seriously weakened and possibly turned back if the United States and Canada entered into defensive alliance, Representative W. Sterling Cole said last night.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- President Eisenhower, Cardinal Spellman and Gen. Omar N. Bradley called today for national support of the United Defense Fund as a moral obligation to the 3,000,000 Americans in the armed forces.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey voted yesterday to increase the cash dividend on the capital stock by 15 per cent.

A Board of Education official whose department replaces broken windows in schools clashed yesterday with the president of the United Parents Association over the responsibility of parents for juvenile vandalism.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A group of American Zionists voiced "grave concern" today over the recent United States decision to send arms to Iraq.
JINJA, Uganda, April 29 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth opened today the new u20,000,000 ($56,000,000) Owen Falls Dam near here, at the headwaters of the Nile.

An accusation that eighteen insurance companies collected excessive premiums from employers and union-management welfare funds under the state disability law, was denied yesterday by The Bureau of Accident and Health Underwriters.
Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley asserted yesterday that fare increases on the city's transit lines have added to traffic congestion by encouraging greater use of private automobiles.
The Transit Authority approved conditionally yesterday a proposal by Webb Knapp, real estate agents of 383 Madison Avenue, to provide a new bus terminal in Flushing, Queens.

The recent expressions of American policy relative to the use of force to deter, prevent or punish physical aggression against the defensive forces of the "free world" lead one to reexamine the possible or probable use of the A or H bombs and other weapons by the United Nations or the American Government.
GENEVA, April 29 -- The similarity between the Communist proposals for Korean and German unification is being scrutinized by United States experts on Soviet tactics.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The House defeated today, 214 to 37, a proposal to limit the use of United States troops in combat zones.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The revision of the immigration laws of Israel and the reconstruction of the Jewish Agency for Palestine were proposed tonight as means of clarifying the relationship of United States Jews to Israel.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -During the week ended April 28, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, member bank reserves increased $133,000,000.
LONDON, April 29 -- The Labor party split sharply in a vote on atomic energy tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- Bob Turley made his first start tonight since his near no-hitter against Cleveland last week, limited Washington to five hits, and gained a 2-1 decision for the Baltimore Orioles in a duel with Lefty Mickey McDermott.
Repayments of $34,000,000 by sales finance companies were the largest factor in a $74,000,000 decline in New York bank loans to business last week.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- All the physicians who pioneered the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York will be honored by having their names in the record of the current health hearings before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 30 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen tonight authorized a strike against the New York Central Railroad east of Buffalo for 8 A. M. Monday.

Amateur artists from the staff of Lenox Hill Hospital received ribbon prizes yesterday at the opening of their first public art showing. The exhibition, one of the judges said, displayed "unusual professional competence."

United Cerebral Palsy Association opened its 1954 campaign for $8,500,000 yesterday with a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel honoring its national chairman, William Clay Ford, vice president of the Ford Motor Company.

When young city farmers swarmed into the Children's Gardens at York Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street yesterday for spring planting, they found one gardener already calmly weeding flourishing radish and onion shoots.

MONTREAL, April 29 (AP) -- Increasing uses for aluminum promises to sustain present production facilities and justify further expansion. Nathanael V. Dalvis, president of Aluminium. Ltd., told the annual meeting today.
BOSTON, April 29 (UP) -- Mike Garcia won for the first time this season today in pitching the Cleveland Indians to a 6-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox before a Ladies' Day crowd of 6,595.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse, as required by conference rules:
SELECTED paintings by Vuillard and his closest friend and brother-in-law, Ker-Xavier Roussel, are being shown at the Cadby-Birch Gallery.
The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to ban motels from residential and retail districts in spite of an attack by Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons on the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Federal Housing Administration has had to take over Government-insured mortgages on eighteen apartment projects in New York and New Jersey at a cost of $15,422,387.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The British newspaper correspondent who, after looking on at the inquiry of the Mundt subcommittee, expressed "alarm over the behavior of our closest ally in the conduct of their domestic affairs" reflected what must also be a widespread critical attitude in the United States toward the subcommittee's procedure.

MILWAUKEE, April 29 (AP) -Robin Roberts of the Phillies tonight blanked the Milwaukee Braves on one hit, a crashing double off the left-field fence by Del Crandall in the third inning. Philadelphia snapped a long scoring slump with a 4-0 victory.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Pvt. G. David Schine confirmed under oath today that a picture he gave to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's staff had been altered before the staff presented it to the Senate committee investigating the Army-McCarthy dispute.

The Park Association of New York City is speaking for the whole community when it awards today to Carl M. Loeb and the late Mrs. Loeb the association's 1953 citation for outstanding service to the city's park system. Mr. and Mrs. Loeb gave the money to build the graceful and useful new boathouse, completed this spring, at the eastern bank of the Seventy-second Street lake in Central Park.

LONDON, April 29 -- A rally by British Government securities reversed today the decline in the securities markets here that had arisen from the Indo-China situation. Industrials followed lead of the gilt-edge issues.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of testimony today on the sixth day of hearings by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which is considering the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. The hearing began at 10:45 A. M.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday he was considering sending all future traffic scofflaws to jail, as "there are too many drivers refusing to come into court with scofflaw tickets."
Net profit of $27,802,938 was reported yesterday by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for the first quarter this year, compared with $30,961,033 for the yearearlier period.
Senate endorsement of a House-approved bill to simplify methods of determining customs valuation of imports was urged yesterday by a top Customs Service official.

Strength in the stock market helped to steady prices on the New York commodity futures exchanges yesterday, but the closing pattern was irregular. Sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc, wool, silk and rubber, ended mixed; cocoa, hides, potatoes and copper were up and coffee, burlap, tin and lead down.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 29 (UP) -- Doris Hart, the defending champion from Coral Gables, Fla., easily gained the women's singles semi-finals in the British hard courts tennis championships today by defeating Britain's Shirley Bloomer 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The conventional bookkeeping cost of the Army-McCarthy hearing is likely to be small for a spectacle of its size, importance and interest.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -When the testimony of Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, entered its sixth day today, some of the Capitol old-timers were sure it was a record for the length of time a witness underwent questioning in such a hearing.

The addition of a vice president and the creation of the new office of controller were announced yesterday by A. P. Timmerman, president and chairman of the board of the Bush Terminal Company. Mr. Timmerman said John C. Hilly had been elected vice president and Edward W. Hain named controller at a board meeting Wednesday afternoon.
Rails smashed through their 1954 highs yesterday and the rest of the market followed them in a strong upward movement, making the best gains since July, 1951.
BOSTON, April 20 -- Gov. Christian A. Herter signed into law today a bill repealing the Massachusetts stock transfer tax. The measure will become effective on Saturday.

Four new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "River of No Return," a Twentieth Century-Fox outdoor drama in CinemaScope and Technicolor starring Robert Mitchum and Marilyn Monroe, is at the Roxy. Stanley Rubin produced and Otto Preminger directed from a screen play by Frank Fenton and a story by Louis Lantz.

In order to maintain his twopoint lead over Vassily Smyslov in their 24-game match for the world chess championship in Moscow, Mikheil Botvinnik played with great caution in conducting the black pieces in the seventeenth game, the details of which reached here by airmail yesterday.
Representatives of the Publishers Association of New York City and of newspaper machinists agreed yesterday on a three-man fact-finding panel to make recommendations in a wage-and-hours dispute.

NORMAN LEWIS, a versatile, daring and fiercely mustached Englishman, writes travel books with something of the creative artistry of a fine novelist and novels with all the exotic factual interest of good travel books. Mr. Lewis has been a soldier, a secret agent and a singularly reckless and joyful traveler in Africa, Arabia and all the troubled countries of Southeast Asia.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- The National Safety Council said today that 2,550 persons were killed last month in United States traffic accidents. This was a reduction of 9 per cent from March, 1953.

Philippa Duke Schuyler, an altogether talented young lady, gave a piano recital in Town Hall last night. But her talent inclines more toward music than toward the instrument. That is, her musical ideas and inclinations were healthy, she had spirit and vitality, but she did not have the pianistic discipline to put those ideas into controlled effect.

GENEVA, April 29 -- A spokesman for the Chinese Communist Government said today that when Foreign Minister Chou En-lai said all foreign troops should leave Asia he was not referring to Soviet troops in China.

Year in and year out, bananas have sold in most markets at a steady 15 cents a pound. This week, changing for the first time in five years, according to the City Department of Markets, the price fell. Bananas can now be purchased generally at two pounds for a quarter.

The Upper House of the Japanese Diet has now ratified the Mutual Defense Assistance Treaty with the United States and the pact has thus become effective. The Lower House had previously endorsed the agreement. The way is now open for limited rearmament in Japan with American assistance.
Your obituary of Joseph P. Tumulty contained an error that would, I believe, have deeply disturbed Mr. Tumulty.
Maj. Gen. Kirke B. Lawton, Fort Monmouth, N. J., commander, has been on sick leave since April 15, with a circulatory ailment.

Prominent speakers at a forum here appealed last night to both houses of Congress to take immediate action to protect the civil rights of witnesses who appear before Congressional investigating committees.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a year's trial of one-way traffic on congested sections of Seventh and Eighth Avenues, starting June 1.
A landlord sought to have a sentence for housing violations reduced yesterday from ninety days to thirty on the ground that the term was longer than that allowed for a first offense.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- Choppy fluctuations were the rule in grain and soybean futures on the Board of Trade today
PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (UP) -- The Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. announced today a record enrollment of 2,581,580 members following a 55,408-membership increase during 1953.

BOSTON, April 29 (AP) -- Garnett Hart, a 19-year-old knockout artist from Philadelphia, got off the floor tonight to win the 132-pound title and the award as the best fighter in the sixty-sixth National Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 29 (AP) -- Billy Joe Patton shot two-under-par golf today, trounced Curtis Person of Memphis, 6 and 5, and gained the semi-finals in the North and South amateur golf tournament.

TELEVISION has been asked to do many things, but never before has the medium been put to the severe test imposed by two new programs. In order, the assignments are: (1) Find some "angels" for Broadway plays; (2) bring back the game of tennis.

BERLIN, April 29 -- The Big Four powers decided today to ease the terms under which they have imprisoned the seven surviving leaders of the regime that was their common enemy in World War II -- Nazi Germany.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company plans to build a $75,000,000 refinery somewhere on the Eastern Seaboard. In a letter yesterday to stockholders, D. T. Staples, president, said the new plant would have a capacity of 100,000 barrels of crude oil daily and would supplant the Bayonne, N. J. refinery.

Indian Head Mills, Inc., reported earnings of $107,432 for the six months ended April 3 and the unaudited profit and loss statement showed net earnings of 63 cents a share on 170,000 shares of common stock outstanding. This compares with a net profit of $335.76 for the eight-month period ended last Oct. 3.

An American edition of Johannes Hohlenberg's "Soren Kierkegaard," a biography of the Danish philosopher and religious thinker, is planned for May 14 publication by Pantheon Books. The work was first published in Copenhagen in 1940.

GENEVEVA, April 29 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speeches today by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, and Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister for External Affairs, at the Geneva conference.

Events today: PhilharmonicSymphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Michael Rabin, soloist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; program of old and new English music, Temple Emanu-E1, 5:15; Down Town Glee Club, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Equitable Life Assurance Society Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30; Carmel Alcaro, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
MONTREAL, April 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Dutch tug Hudson will leave here tomorrow, towing the collision-damaged German freighter Wallschiff on a 3,500-mile voyage to Hamburg.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -President Eisenhower expressed today his admiration and respect for the professional attainments of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer. However, the President said the allegations against the scientist as a security risk made necessary the new investigation of him.

MOUNT HAMILTON, Calif., April 29 (AP) -- An enormous photograph of the night sky, which in a few years will begin to tell astronomers how the Milky Way galaxy rotates, has been completed at Lick Observatory.

For the seventh successive year tomorrow the patriotic organizations that took May Day from Communist control and renamed it Loyalty Day will march down Fifth Avenue. Some 250,000 marchers are expected. The parade will start at 1 P. M. and continue for five hours.

BELIZE, April 29 -- Nationalist and anti-colonial sentiment in this colony has asserted itself. In the election for Legislative Council seats yesterday, the People's United party and General Workers Union apparently have won a majority, if not a sweep.

Irving Enkells, operator, has resold the three-story dwelling on lot 17 by 100 feet at 33 Harrison Avenue, in Brooklyn, after a brief ownership. The buyer is an investing client of H. Lawrence, attorney.

Capt. Johan McLamore of the Women Officer Procurement Office of the United States Marine Corps announced yesterday that the corps would start a women officer training class for college students and graduates on June 17.
CINCINNATI, April 29 -- The Dodgers hit five home runs tonight to win their opening engagement at Crosley Field, 7 -- 5. But the Redlegs carried them right down to the wire before subsiding.

Supreme Court Justice S. Samuel Di Falco upheld yesterday a previous order that financier Robert R. Young must undergo examination by New York Central Railroad attorneys. The questioning, which will be conducted before special referee Harry Grossman, a member of the law firm of Grossman Grossman, will be part of pretrial testimony in a suit brought last month by Mr. Young against the Central and its directors.

ANKAR,A Turkey, April 28 -Turkey's political parties wound up a calm, orderly pre-election campaign tonight with final appeals to voters over the state radio and at a thousand local meetings. A three-day moratorium of all political propaganda precedes the nation-wide voting Sunday for a new Parliament.
TRENTON, April 29 -- Democratic and Republican leaders from all of New Jersey's twenty-one counties gathered here today for the annual state conventions of their respective parties.
A ten-round bout between Orlando Zulueta of Havana and Paolo Rosi of Rieti, Italy, lightweights, is the main event tonight at the St. Nicholas Arena.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- The new president of Mandel Brothers, Inc., charted yesterday the course by which the company expects to return to profitable operation after three consecutive years of losses.
The effect of the investigation of communism at Fort Monmouth, N. J., was debated last night on the WABD television program "Between the Lines."
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- The controversial St. Lawrence Seaway project was sent to the House of Representatives floor today for the first time in the three decades it has been before Congress.

It is not at all surprising that Mr. Molotov should declare himself in full agreement with Premier Chou En-lai's program to drive the Western Powers out of Asia. At Berlin the Soviet spokesman sought to banish the United States from the continent of Europe, and it is logical that at Geneva he should heartily second Communist China's proposal to get us out of Asia as well.
The Allied Stores Corporation completed its first quarter-century with sales for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 at $515,829,695, an increase of $13,989,048, or 2.8 per cent, from the year before.

The Southern Pacific Company borrowed $7,905,000 in the public market yesterday to help finance the purchase of new equipment. The money was raised by the sale of equipment trust certificates maturing serially from April 1, 1955, to April 1, 1969, to a syndicate headed by Salomon Bros. Hutzler at a cost of 2.66 per cent.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 28 -- One of Asia's arch-criminals was hanged today. Rahim Hingoro, 45 years old, known as the "Terror of Sind," had been convicted on one of 250 charges of murder in a ten-year reign of looting, kidnapping and death in Pakistan and India.
Saks 34th, after its showing of summer fashions yesterday, should be the mecca for career girls who have a large flair for fashion but a small budget.

Members of the Fortuna Duesseldorf Football Club of West Germany, accompanied by officials and trainer, arrived yesterday by plane at the International Airport, Idlewild. They were welcomed by representatives of the German-American Football Association, which will stage it annual sports carnival at Triboro Stadium, Randalls Island, on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UP) -- An official of the Auto Workers Union, C. I. O., refused today to give a House of Representatives inquiry information about more than thirty persons accused of being Communists.

The six-day ordeal of Secretary Stevens has exposed the heart of the controversy between Senator McCarthy and the Army. We believe that the hearings have been of some value if certain fundamental points are not lost amid the welter of digressions, irrelevancies and repetitive questioning in which the participants have been allowed to indulge in their examination of this decent, honorable and patriotic citizen.

NEW HAVEN, April 29 -- The movement to de-emphasize secret societies on the Yale campus gained impetus today. The editor of The Yale Daily News said it would no longer publish the names of students "tapped" for membership in the societies and the university's radio station, WYBC, announced that it would not broadcast the names.
ALBANY, April 29 (AP) -- The old witch in Mother Goose needs a new figure, State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh suggested today.

PARIS, April 29 -- Side by side with accounts of Communist onslaughts in Indo-China, the Paris press for the last three weeks has carried stories about an unexpected evidence of Soviet sympathy for French culture.

The men's clothing business has improved this month and will continue to gain, according to Jerome I. Udell, chairman of the board of Max Udell Sons Co., producer of men's suits. Retail sales picked up a few weeks before Easter and inventories have been depleted, he said.

The Yankees, who previously this season had displayed only a haunting resemblance to the team that won five straight world series, were more readily recognizable yesterday to 9,943 fans at the Stadium, where they beat the Chicago White Sox, 5 -- 4. Afterward, even Casey Stengel was moved to say, "That was more like it!"

Six painters and sculptors, six authors and three composers have been chosen to receive the annual $1,000 grants of the Institute of Arts and Letters, Marc Connelly, president of the institute, announced yesterday.

Most Americans who consider New England cooking a part of their heritage will welcome a new and colorful collection of traditional Yankee recipes to be published next Friday by Random House under the title "New England Cookbook."

A lively lady of the air, who has trouble keeping track of what makes her go, rested yesterday after an unusual experience. She had been taken up on a flight away from her home base powered simultaneously by three different types of aircraft engines.

MANCHESTER, N. H., April 29 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur called tonight for increasing vigilance against "adventurers in our midst who travel along" with those whose evil purpose was to tear down this country's free institutions.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago reported yesterday a net income of $11,601,132 for the first three months of this year. This is equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 73 cents a share on the common stock.
Parents of 60 per cent of the eligible children in the Flushing and Corona health districts in Queens have signed them up for the Salk polio vaccine trials starting there on Tuesday.
The Brooklyn rackets grand jury was discharged yesterday after four years and five minths of investigating police-protected gambling and waterfront crime and corruption.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The General Motors Corporation received a patent this week for a combined clothes drier and room air-dehumidifier, invented by Ralph K. Shewmon of Dayton, Ohio. The appliance contains a rotary drum into which wet clothing can be put, a dehumidifier with mechanical refrigeration and a fan.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Three labor unions that normally hold divergent points of view made an informal alliance today at a luncheon conference here.
JERUSALEM, Jordanian Sector, April 30 -- The Arab farmer of Jordan thinks of his Israeli counterpart in the communal settlements across the frontier as a barbarian in khaki shorts.

CONCORD, N. H., April 30 (UP) -- The New Hampshire Supreme Court today sanctioned the right of Attorney General Louis C. Wyman to question witnesses about Communism. The high court's unanimous ruling upheld the constitutionality of the 1951 and 1953 laws setting up New Hampshire's investigation into subversive activities.

The six-story store and apartment building at 872 Madison Avenue, northwest corner of Seventy-first Street, has been purchased by Paul Hitlin, builder and realty investor from Stephen I. Stephanidis, chairman of the board of the Prudential Steamship Corporation. The property, fronting 102 feet on Madison Avenue, is assessed at $220,000. Pease Elliman, Inc., were the brokers.

HANOI, April 30 -- The lull continued today at besieged Dienbienphu, where rebel Vietminh troops were reported holding to advance positions about 700 yards from the command post of Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries.
Public offering of more than a billion dollars worth of bonds and a decline in stock flotations featured new financing operations here in April.
The Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church elected Bishop Charles Wesley Brashares of the Chicago area as president yesterday morning.

Joseph P. Ryan, on trial for grand larceny in General Sessions Court, paid for dues and other costs at the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck in 1948 with a check drawn on a special magazine account of the International Longshoremen's Association, according to testimony yesterday.

" Elihu Root and the Conservative Tradition," by Richard W. Leopold, will be issued Monday by Little, Brown as the third volume in the concern's Library of American Biography. The author, Professor of History at Northwestern University, traces Mr. Root's career from his early success as a corporation lawyer through his years in the United States Senate.

LONDON, April 30 -- The Government announced today it was lifting control on the quantity of rubber that might be exported to the Soviet Union and Soviet bloc countries. The relaxation will not apply to Communist China, Hong Kong, Macao and Tibet.

What will go into the history of yachting and pleasure boating as an important milestone was the formal organization in an all-day meeting at the Hotel Lexington yesterday of the American Boat and Yacht Council.
The Jacques Fath showing, a high spot in the Paris-in-New York week celebrations, was full of thrills from start to finish. It took place yesterday noon in the crowded ballroom of the Plaza Hotel.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- Spencer Tracy is taking a vacation in England, but before leaving here last week he made a long-range commitment with Paramount to star in "The Mountain."
British sterling sold in the market here yesterday at $2.82 1/32, the highest point since devaluation of the pound in 1949 from $4.03 to $2.80.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Scott McLeod, State Department security and consular affairs administrator, left today for an extended tour of Europe to consult on problems related to the Refugee Relief Act which he directs.

DENVER, April 30 -- The League of Women Voters closed its weeklong biennial convention here today with the re-election of Mrs. John G. Lee of Farmington, Conn., for a third term as president and the adoption of a resolution reaffirming support of the United Nations.

" THE tourist is part of the landscape of our civilization, as the pilgrim was in the Middle Ages," V. S. Pritchett, the distinguished British critic, says in his thoughtful and penetrating new book, "The Spanish Temper."* May they not sometimes be combined, even today? For it is as both pilgrim and tourist, it seems to me, that Mr. Pritchett has most successfully returned, time and time again, to that proud and magnificent land.
The results of a project to "cut down economic illiteracy in women" were described yesterday at a luncheon of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.
ROME, April 30 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, and Mario Scelba, Italian Premier, are going to meet in Milan Monday, it was announced tonight.

THE annual show, "Portraits in Review," at Portraits, Inc., is always a pleasant occasion. And a reassuring one, too, for those who are only too aware of life's seamier sides, so rigorously excluded from this parade of health and wealth and fashion.

THE New England fishing seems to be improving daily, and with the opening of the trout season in New Hampshire and Vermont today, and almost all of the central and southern Maine waters free of ice, the middle of the month should find the trout and salmon fishing in full swing.

The nation's schools not only are short of classroom teachers, but also are in acute need of specialists, according to Willis J. Black, executive assistant in the Office of Field Relations and Placement at Teachers College, Columbia University.

Robert Moses combined yesterday a tribute to those who work for improvement of the city's parks with an attack on "goo-goos and uplifters." He described the latter as persons who hamper the fight against vandalism and crime in the recreation areas.
Patriotic organizations will march down Fifth Avenue for five hours today in the seventh annual Loyalty Day parade sponsored by the New York County Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

The building at 37-75 Sixty-third Street in Woodside, Queens, containing eight stores and forty-one apartments, has been purchased by Samuel Lane from a syndicate of investors represented by Julian Bernstein, attorney. David Applebaum and Martin Treitel were the brokers and Sam Marcus was attorney for the buyer.

There is a race for 3-year-old horses scheduled for today. It won't steal much of the newspaper space from another race for horses of the same age, which is being held in Kentucky, but it will be run before a sizable "live" gallery of 50,000 -- weather, of course, permitting.
GENEVA, April 29 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles has organized his diplomatic staff for the Geneva conference with military precision.

Television audiences tuning into the current Washington hearings have slipped a little in the last week, but audience interest is still considerable. This was the judgment of ratings reported yesterday by C. E. Hooper, Inc.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 (UP) -- A Kentucky carpenter who died trying to save a trucker from a sixteen-foot-deep cistern was among nineteen persons cited today by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission for outstanding bravery.

Two indecisive court skirmishes were fought yesterday over whether 800,000 disputed shares of stock in the New York Central Railroad Company are to be voted for Robert R. Young at the company's annual meeting on May 26.

BOSTON, April 30 (UP) -- Bob Keegan won his third victory of the year today as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Boston Red Sox, 5 to 0, before 4,199 fans. The crowd was the smallest at Fenway Park this season.

Events today: Symphony Orchestra of Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; "Fledermaus," City Center, 2:30; "Carmen," City Center, 8:15; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos 'conducting, Michael Rabin, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Upsala College Choir, Town Hall, 5:30; Pushkin Society Concert, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; "La Boheme," Joan of Arc Auditorium, 154 West Ninety-third Street, 7:30.

LONDON, April 30 -- The recovery in the stock markets was extended today. It was influenced by high industrial output figures for March and yesterday's strength on Wall Street, as well as a rise in sterling.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 30 -- The textile machinery show closed on a successful note here today but manufacturers said the economic health of the industry was dependent upon a "realistic" depreciation write-off for tax purposes.

BERLIN, April 30 -- The British commandant in Berlin asked his Soviet counterpart today to allow Dr. Alexander Trushnovich, who the British say was abducted into East Berlin April 13, to return to the British sector for an interview.

Tom Morgan and Whitey Ford, the foundation stones in Casey Stengel's plan to rebuild the Yankee pitching staff along more youthful lines, crumbled under the pressure of Cleveland's slugging at the Stadium yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (UP) -- Bob Trice, a rookie right-hander, tonight gained his third victory in a row by limiting the Baltimore Orioles to three hits as the Philadelphia Athletics scored a 5-1 triumph at Connie Mack Stadium.

Throughout that part of the postwar era during which Stalin reigned meetings of the Supreme Soviet, or legislature, of the Soviet Union were normally perfunctory affairs. They were occupied mainly with routine unanimous approval of the budget and speeches by secondary figures vying with each other in tributes to Stalin.

Terry Rosenbaum, a history teacher at the Samuel J. Tilden High School, Brooklyn, was notified yesterday by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, that he was without a job because he had invoked the Fifth Amendment.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Sales of The Fair this spring compared with last spring are down in the State Street store in Chicago, unchanged in suburban Oak Park, and "substantially" higher in suburban Evergreen Park, Hector Suyker, president, reported at the annual meeting.

COLOMBO, Ceylon April 30 -- Unable to agree on a formula for an Indo-China settlement and also on the threat of international communism, the Prime Ministers of the five Asian countries meeting here have extended their conference an extra day to try to find common ground.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Chicago Corporation plans to spend $4,000,000 to $5,000,000 for improvements to its recently acquired oil refining facilities, Richard Wagner, president, said today at the annual shareholders' meeting.
CHICAGO, April 30 -- Grain futures displayed considerable strength in the forepart of the session, but there was little follow-up buying, while selling pressure increased.
COLUMBIA, Mo., April 30 -- Explanation and interpretation are necessary in a newspaper that wants to do a good job today, Turner Catledge, managing editor of The New York Times, said here tonight.
The Port Stewards Association of New York will cast its highly critical collective eye over the service at the Statler Hotel this evening.

Large bond refundings by finance companies lifted the total of bonds called for redemption in April before maturity to $88,122,000. This was the largest amount for any month since January, 1953, and for an April since 1951. The total compared with $22,806,000 in the preceding month and $28,423,000 in April, 1953.

Imperial Oil, Ltd., cleared $13,665,310, equal to 45 cents a share in the first three months of 1954, J. R. White, president, told stockholders in Toronto yesterday. This was about 40 per cent more than the 1953 first quarter results of $9,776,089, or 33 cents a share.

A sharp debate that has arisen in the conference of five Asian Prime Ministers in Ceylon illustrates a vital difference in the attitudes of some Asian leaders on questions of freedom and the threats to it. All five are agreed that "colonialism" is a threat to freedom and are ready to go on record condemning it.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams promoted fourteen men yesterday and remarked at the ceremony at police headquarters that he sometimes thought the department was "run by the Budget Director" because "we don't always have the money to do what we want."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 30 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold intervened today in the final meeting of the Economic and Social Council. His purpose was to defend the right of the United States to issue visas to observers, restricting their movements to specified areas in Manhattan.

In many dark corners of the globe today, May 1 is a date twisted by word and deed into demonstrations against principles of society precious to Americans. Sneers are flung at the right to freedom of worship, speech, press and movement.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- A grain trade advisory committee of exporters told the Department of Agriculture that "give-away" programs often kill the possibilities of selling United States farm commodities abroad.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Bernard M. Baruch hailed today the rise of physical medicine and rehabilitation from "semi-quackery to an accredited part of the medical profession."

Stock prices extended their gains yesterday to new tops for the current upward movement but profit taking in the late trading gave the market a rather ragged appearance at the close. Final quotations were much below the best levels for the session.

LONDON, April 30 -- Poet-playwright Christopher Fry's new play, "The Dark Is Light Enough," impressed critics tonight with the beauty of its prose-poetry and an enchanting performance by Dame Edith Evans. However, they were less sure that the play was as technically perfect as its prose-poetry or the acting of Dame Edith.
A strike scheduled for Monday against the New York Central Railroad east of Buffalo was postponed yesterday to permit mediation of the dispute.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products rose four-tenths of one per cent between mid-March and mid-April, halting a two-month decline.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said today a question he put to Pvt. G. David Schine during hearings into the McCarthy-Army controversy was based on a telephone call from an anonymous tipster.
CINCINNATI, April 30 -- The Dodgers moved back into first place in the National League tonight when they ousted the Redlegs from the lead with a 6-3 victory under the Crosley Field lights.

CHICAGO, April 30 (UP) -- Radiation injury to pregnant women in an atomic bomb explosion apparently causes a high incidence of birth failures, or death and damage to the offspring, three doctors reported today.
Amateur uranium hunters were warned yesterday that they might find lead rather than uranium if they went prospecting on the gunnery range of Camp Smith near Peekskill this week-end.

The two-week mass donation of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program by employes of 100 insurance companies ended yesterday with a total of 2,067 pints given. The donation center was the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street. Yesterday's donation was 218 pints.

GENEVA, April 30 -- The first round of discussion of the Korean question at the Geneva Conference ended today without a word on the issue by representatives of Britain, France and eight other allies. The other nations are Canada, New Zealand, the Philippines, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Ethiopia and Greece.

Sharply reduced taxes enabled E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. to increase net income to $73,793,248, or $1.56 a common share, in the first quarter. Last year, the company earned $56,721,002, or $1.19 a share, in the initial three months on lower sales.
The motorman's cab of his I. R. T. subway train has been a rose-hued mansion this week for Adam Paul Salkind.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- The American Council for Judaism authorized tonight the establishment of a special fund to be used for "any charitable or philanthropic purposes in the United States or abroad which does not advance or benefit 'Jewish' national interests."
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent to 111.1 over the week ended Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 30 (UP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., scored an easy 6-2, 6-2 victory over Britain's Helen Fletcher today in the women's singles semi-finals at the British hard court tennis championships.
PINEHURST, N. C., April 30 (AP) -- Billy Joe Patton and Alex Welsh today gained the final of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 30 -- Frank LeCates, captain and ace right-hander, hurled a two-hit shutout as Army registered its second Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League victory by defeating Columbia, 2 to 0, at Doubleday Field today.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 4.1 per cent below the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 5.6 per cent and orders 5.9 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet.

TOKYO, April 30 -- Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki told the Cabinet today that reparations negotiations with the Philippines had "reached a deadlock" and the special mission to Manila would be withdrawn.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Treasury proposed today to borrow $2,000,000,000 in cash next Tuesday at terms refletcing what officials called reasonable confidence in the country's economic condition.
FORT BRAGG., N. C., April 30 -- Nerve gases and biological agents, as well as missies and atomic weapons, are in simulated use in Exercise Flash Burn, the largest Army maneuver since World War II.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 30 -- The New Jersey State Bar Association was urged tonight to set up a special seven-man committee to study the manner in which Congressional investigating committees conduct hearings and treat counsel for witnesses appearing before them.

It is gratifying to know that Pakistan will not require the remaining 90,000 tons of American wheat of the 700,000 tons authorized as food relief in June of last year. The crisis has been passed, thanks both to timely aid and to the intensive local program for more cultivation.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Since May Day falls on Saturday this year, the Children's Bureau has called on the nation to make it family play day.

JERSEY CITY, April 30 -- Opposing counsel in the Superior Court's investigation of municipal finances here disagreed today on whether it was proper for a man to get paid for unperformed tasks while receiving no reward for work done elsewhere.
The Army is scheduled to review once again the feasibility of a bridge across the Narrows from Brooklyn to Staten Island.

LONDON, April 30 -- Prime Minister Churchill suggested today the establishment of links with the Soviet Union through which the Russians and their Government would be convinced that Britons wish them peace, happiness and prosperity.

Directors of the General Dynamics Corporation, into which Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation was merged last Thursday, yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 87 1/2 cents a share. It is payable on June 10.

Two new films open at first run theatres this morning. At Loew's State is "Flame and the Flesh," a drama starring Lana Turner, Pier Angeli and Carlos Thompson, with Bonar Colleano, Charles Goldner and Peter Illing heading the supporting cast.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Consumer installment credit outstanding dropped $251,000,000 in March to an estimated $20,900,000,000, the Federal Reserve reported tonight.

The Board of Higher Education yesterday asked Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Education Commissioner, to reject the appeal filed by Nat Holman, suspended basketball coach at City College. The veteran coach had asked the Commissioner on March 25 to overrule the board on his dismissal.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of testimony today on the seventh day of hearings by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which is considering the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. The hearing began at 10:41 A. M.:

ROME, April 30 -- An encyclical praising priestly celibacy and pleading for a larger consecration of modern youth to the vocation of priesthood and religious orders was published here today. Dated March 25, it is the first encyclical of Pope Pius XII since his illness.

BONN, Germany, April 30 -- The Government coalition parties voted today to grant another lease on life for Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's policy of West European integration. This action was taken despite a growing feeling that the policy already had failed or was on the brink of failure.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower revisited the Pentagon today to attend a farewell luncheon for Roger M. Kyes, outgoing Deputy Secretary of Defense.
The following is a round-up of recent booklets of interest to the homemaker:
LOUISVILLE, April 30 -- It's time for the annual manning of battle stations at Churchill Downs.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Vincent Massey, Governor General of Canada, will address a joint session of Congress next Tuesday during a three-day state visit here, the State Department announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Ben Gold, fur union leader, was sentenced today to one to three years in prison for falsely swearing he had no ties to the Communist party.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 30 -- Thousands of Vietnamese gathered today around Little Lake, in the heart of Hanoi, and demonstrated against any plan that may arise at the Geneva conference to partition their country.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The French Government is pressing the United States to consider attempting to form a Southeast Asian alliance without Britain, diplomatic sources reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Sound engineers found a way today to keep Ray H. Jenkins' booming voice from overwhelming the electronics equipment.

Bruce Smith, replying to a grand jury charge that his criticism of Police Department administrative affairs was "completely misleading," said yesterday that the panel had been "bamboozled" by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

GENEVA, April 30 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State told the delegates to the Inter - Governmental Committee for European Migration today that he hoped the conference on Asian affairs would be able to make decisions as constructive as those reached by the committee.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Federal spending dropped by $1,578,000,000 in the first seven months of the current financial year from the total of the same period a year ago, a Senate-House committee reported today.

The city administration has at last taken the cold plunge and will try one-way traffic on congested sections of Seventh and Eighth Avenues for a year beginning about June 1. Eighth Avenue will be northbound from far downtown to Columbus Circle, while Seventh Avenue will be southbound from about Forty-sixth Street in upper Times Square.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Lindsay C. Warren cleaned up his desk today and closed it on a public service career of forty-three years. He was credited with saving the Government almost a billion dollars.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 30 -- The Soviet Union today invited all the Latin-American states to send representatives to Moscow for talks in September on wider trade.

BELIZE, British Honduras, April 30 -- This crown colony is entering a new phase in its history. While the newly elected representatives of the People's United party, which won a majority in the Legislative Council, will not take office until June.
Ralph T. McElvenny has been elected chief executive officer of the American Natural Gas Company.
Public demonstrations of color television will be conducted throughout this month by the Radio Corporation of America in the R. C. A. Exhibition Hall at 40 West Forty-ninth Street.

Although modern convoy dispersal techniques can protect ships effectively from thermonuclear bombs, it is uncertain whether they can protect vessels from attack by atomic-powered submarines, according to James R. Wilson Jr., an American Legion official.
PARIS, April 30 -- Maurice Schumann, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, told the Cabinet tonight that the situation at the Geneva conference was now grave for France.

A new study of an extension of water metering to residential multiple dwellings is under way by the city. Metering, if adopted, would be designed to cut down water waste and increase the city's revenues. At present, metering of water here is largely limited to commercial properties.

The success of Philadelphia's Playhouse-in-the-Park as a full-scale municipal theatrical venture has prompted Actors Equity Association to suggest similar projects to sixty-five cities with populations of 300,000 or more.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Eisenhower will inaugurate tomorrow a campaign by eight national veteran organizations to help raise $10,000,000 for the people of Korea.

Prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York commodities markets, reflecting continued firmness in securities. Volume was light, following the normal week-end pattern. Coffee, soybean oil, hides, rubber, zinc, lead, silk and potatoes were stronger; cocoa, sugar, cottonseed oil, wool, burlap and copper ended mixed and only tin was lower.
The advertising that suggests a man can make a fortune by operating an automatic vending device got an official reprimand yesterday.

International brotherhood, human freedom, respect for the sacredness of human personality and "the transcendence of the moral and spiritual over the material" were emphasized last night by Francis B. Sayre, former Assistant Secretary of State, as factors needed to solve world problems.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Sal Maglie gained his fourth mound triumph of the season today against no defeats. But it took a deal of doing, plus a fourteenth-inning home run by Willie Mays before it could be achieved by 4 to 2.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 4 points up yesterday. The volume of business was small.
DALLAS, Tex., April 30 (UP) -- Nearly a score of tornadoes spread death and destruction throughout the south, southwest and midwest today. Property damage ran into the millions of dollars.

LONDON, April 21 -- The City of London, which is the crowded downtown heart of the Greater London everybody knows, was the worst blitzed single area in Britain, and it has waited long for its chance to rebuild.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 30 (UP) -- The University of Minnesota reported tonight it had performed "impossible" heart operations with a new technique that enables a healthy person to "loan" his heart and lungs to the patient on the operating table.
ALBANY, April 30 (UP) -- New York State closed the 1953-54 fiscal year with an operating surplus of $15,610,893 -- about one-third more than Governor Dewey had anticipated.
A thousand persons, commemorating George Washington's inauguration to the Presidency 165 years ago, gathered yesterday noon in two memorial ceremonies.
All the world's a stage, William Shakespeare noted some centuries ago, but 137 aspiring young thespians yesterday hardly expected to find the rear outdoor alley of the Martin Beck Theatre included.

NEWMARKET, England, April 30 (UP) -- Festoon, a chestnut filly carrying the colors of James (Lucky) Dewar and Arthur Breasley, an Australian jockey, scored a two-length victory today in the One Thousand Guineas -- the second of Britain's five classic horse races -- on the Newmarket course.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Julius C. Holmes, former minister in the United States Embassy in London, asked the Federal District Court today for an early trial on charges of conspiracy to defraud the Government in surplus ship sales.
VIENNA, April 30 (AP) -- Poland's Communist Government announced today extensive price reductions in consumer goods and public services in its campaign to improve living standards.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 30 -- The State Political Science Association got an unexpected capsule preview of next fall's Gubernatorial campaign today from leading spokesmen for the Republican and Democratic parties.
TUCKAHOE, N. Y., April 30 -- Two record-equaling rounds featured the opening of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association tournament season at the Vernon Hills Country Club today.
Oregon The State of Oregon announced yesterday that it would receive bids May 20 on $10,000,000 of veterans' bonus bonds dated July 1, 1954, and due on April 1, 1968.
Bakery workers went on strike early today against the city's five major producers of bread and cake.
Emphasis on ways to improve family life will be made in National Family Week programs for religious organizations starting tomorrow and ending on Mothers Day, May 9.

For two successive days (April 24 and 25) The Times has carried stories stating that the three Republican leaders in the Senate have suggested the withdrawal or reduction of economic and technical assistance to India in response to Nehru's refusal to allow United States transport planes passage through India en route to Indo-China.

YONKERS, April 30 -- The Yonkers Trotting Association, facing a possible strike by the Standard-bred Owners Association, posted a schedule of raised minimum purses today. The increase, which had been rejected by the owners' executive committee on Wednesday as inadequate, will take effect Monday, the earliest day the owners could undertake a strike.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 30 -- Command Post Exercise No. 4, the secret exercise that the military chiefs of the North Atlantic Alliance finished here today, introduced for the first time in such a war game the tactical problem of the atomic weapon.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, said today "there is nothing to it," when asked whether anyone at the White House had tried to halt the McCarthy-Army hearings.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Two officials of the Federal Housing Administration were suspended today in a widening investigation of scandals in the Government's housing program.

GENEVA, April 30 -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden made his first direct contact with Communist China's Foreign Minister Chou En-lai here today at a private luncheon given by Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov.
Plans to erect a $25,000,000 Hall of Our History on a mountain plateau in Georgia have been abandoned because of the failure of an initial fund-raising campaign.

Columbia University and Clarence R. Randall, president of the Inland Steel Company of Chicago, received citations of merit yesterday from the Colonial Dames of America at the sixty-fourth annual luncheon of the society in the Colony Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (UP) -- Dr. Cary Middlecoff battled 40-mile-an-hour winds and the Lake Merced Country Club course today as he posted the only sub-par round -- a 69 -- to take the first day lead in the $10,000 San Francisco pro-amateur tournament.

VIENNA, April 30 -- Soviet occupation authorities refused today to grant Austria the right to establish civil aviation or even an air rescue service. They also implied they would bar nationals of eight West European countries from their zone even if the Austrian Government exempted them from visa requirements.

Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan said yesterday that the Algam Corporation, owner of Yonkers Raceway, had terminated its retainer of Edward C. Maguire as labor relations attorney. Mr. Monaghan said also that Conrad H. Rothengast would devote his full time as chief of police at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson's defense charged in its final argument today that he was used as a "Judas goat" in the Korean prisoner exchange.
A split between Republican Assemblymen representing rural and big city districts came into the open yesterday. It has been several months in the making.

The following exchange, in scientific deadpan, brought down the house yesterday afternoon in the middle of a weighty scientific session on a new cancer drug sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences:

There has been within the last few years much agitation to restore gold redeemability of American currency. W. Randolph Burgess of the Treasury and William McC. Martin, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, have recently explained why that measure would serve no good purpose at the present time.

Orlando Zulueta, Havana lightweight, opened a cut above the bridge of Paolo Rosi's nose in the second round of a scheduled ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. In the eighth the cut led to the Italian's downfall.
Somewhere in Brooklyn are two frustrated hold-up men. They won't know until they read about it why Joseph Rosenberg didn't have that $3,000 payroll with him yesterday in his company's jeep.
NEW ORLEANS, April 30 -- This city will conduct a colorful civic ceremony tomorrow to mark the dedication of its new $16,000,000 Union Passenger Terminal.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Ambassador Henri Bonnet of France presented today his Government's award of Commander of the Legion of Honor to Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, vice president and general manager of The New York Times.

Ever since the beginning of Creation the world has been steadily moving out of darkness. The development of light has provided an illuminated path for man's own history -- the pre-historic campfire built for warmth and protection, the candle and the friendly hearth, the whale oil lamps and kerosene lanterns, the incandescent, carbon arcs and neon tubes have served their ages.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 1 -- The South Korean Government is of the opinion that the first week of the Geneva conference fully substantiates this Government's position that there can be no peaceful solution of Korea's problems.

We learn from its annual report that the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York has an enrollment of 400,000 after seven years of operation, a record which testifies to the merit of properly managed prepaid group medical practice and to a high quality of service.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 30 -- Barilea, with DeForest Trimingham at the tiller, sailed to victory today to capture the Princess Elizabeth Cup series. It was the fourth triumph for the craft in the five races held.
While trading on the New York Stock Exchange receded slightly in April from the month before, it was the largest for a corresponding month since 1950.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass, April 30 -- Williams edged Dartmouth, 1 to 0, today with a ninth-inning rally on Weston Field.

Clarifying an issue repeatedly raised in recent years, the House of Representatives has defeated by the decisive vote of 214 to 37 a proposal by Representative Coudert to limit the President's power of ordering American troops into armed conflict "anywhere in the world," even in self-defense, except with Congressional approval.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Discovery that epileptic seizures are associated with the faulty utilization of two basic substances that occur normally in the body was reported here today.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, April 30 -- Jordan appears to the people of neighboring Israel as their greatest source of trouble, and at the same time one of their principal hopes for a peaceful future.
CHICAGO, April 30 -- Miss Agnes Ohlson of Hartford, Conn., today was elected president of the American Nurses Association.

The alarming developments relating to communism and national security suggest that the Government should now make an explicit declaration of policy respecting the employment in Government of persons whose records contain evidence of past Communist or Leftist associations.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A McCarthy committee staff investigator assumed full responsibility today for altering "a hot picture" that has become a cause celebre in the Senate investigation of the controversy between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., April 30 -- This community's first craft fair opened last night at the town hall under the auspices of the Levittown branch of the American Association of University Women. It will continue through Sunday. The exhibits range from the professional to the amateur.
Slightly reduced sales and earnings for the first quarter were reported at the annual meeting of the Ruberoid Company in South Bound Brook, N. J., yesterday.

Peter P. Spinelli, former chief assistant district attorney of Richmond County, pleaded guilty yesterday to illegally soliciting a $20 political contribution from a borough office-holder. The offense is a misdemeanor.
Brooklyn celebrated a new channel cut deep in the heart of Gowanus yesterday.

Nutrition Week, which starts tomorrow under the sponsorship of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City, is built this year around the theme of "Don't munch -- eat lunch." Three hundred community agencies have been asked to plan at least one activity around the noon meal.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UP) -- The Detroit Tigers punched out three singles in the twelfth inning tonight to defeat the Washington Senators, 2 -- 1, after tying the score in the ninth with two men out.
ATHENS, April 30 -- Greece's second major earthquake in less than a year brought destruction and death in the central mountainous area today.

The summoning to court of fifty Harlem tenants for throwing rubbish out of windows was announced yesterday by Mrs. Bernice P. Rogers, Deputy Housing Commissioner. She said that the summonses, returnable Tuesday before Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh in Housing and Buildings Court, had resulted from a three-day check-up this week by three inspectors in the areas bounded by Lenox and Fifth Avenues, 111th and 112th Streets and 128th and 129th Streets.

As the Bards of the Bluegrass like to tell us, the Kentucky Derby is not just a horse race -- and we have had eloquent evidence from outside confirming that view. But today, as has happened every year since another day in May fourscore years ago, the horses are running on Churchill Downs at Louisville. Back there in the year 1875 the winner was a little red horse called Aristides, son of Leamington.

MILWAUKEE, April 30 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies made it two in a row over the Milwaukee Braves tonight with a 5-2 victory as a result of a four-run sixth inning against Gene Conley, rookie pitcher.
Harry B. Gideonse, Brooklyn College president, said yesterday the Kingsmen would field a football team next fall.
GENEVA, April 30 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the addresses by Prince Wan Waithayakon of Thailand and Cevat Ackalin of Turkey at the Geneva conference today:
PARIS, April 30 -- In the wake of Dior's sailor-collared collection, a collection of sailor-collared blouses has arrived in smart shops on and off the Faubourg Saint Honore.

HARRISON, N. Y., April 30 -- A postcard campaign to induce the members of the Senate to remove Senator Joseph R. McCarthy from committee positions has been put in motion by Mrs. Andrew Winton Roth of this community.

The Eastern Parkway Arena of Brooklyn was fined a total of $1,400 by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday for boxing tax deficiencies extending back to May 12, 1952. The club was ordered to pay the fine and the delinquent taxes to the Department of State by Monday.

Two anniversaries are being celebrated today by J. W. Seligman Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. On May 1, 1864, Joseph Seligman and his brothers founded the firm. Five years later, again on May 1, it was admitted to the Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The House Un-American Activities Committee voted today to cite five witnesses for contempt of Congress on the ground they had refused to answer questions during investigations of communism.

HERBS are the answer to a lazy gardener's prayer. Most of the popular culinary herbs will grow in poor, dry soil in full sun -- the kind of location where few other plants will thrive. And it takes no more effort to get them started than it does marigolds.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1 -- Princeton won its fourth Ivy League game in as many starts by defeating Harvard, 5 -- 1, behind the two-hit pitching of Dick Emery today at Soldiers Field.

Ten business and civic leaders will receive plaques from the Horatio Alger Awards Committee of the American Schools and Colleges Association. The presentation will be made at 10 A. M. Thursday in the Rainbow Room lounge, R. C. A. Building, 30 Rockefeller Center.
THE job here is to teach a pilot how to use his plane as a weapon." This is an officer's summing up of the mission of Luke Air Force Base, a few miles outside Phoenix.
A hooded and shoeless bandit held up the paymaster of the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday morning and stole $10,000 in cash from a desk drawer. In his haste he left $25,000 behind.

ONLY a dozen opening lines are required to introduce this novel's protagonist, set forth her early circumstances and launch her life story. Her mother has died at her birth and her father very shortly thereafter -- whether from heartbreak or as the immediate result of a dinner consisting of, among other items, pork pie, deviled crabs, cucumbers and peach fritters.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 1 -- Yale University took first place in every field event and went on to defeat Princeton, 89 1/2 to 50 1/2, in a dual track meet today.

A new curriculum designed to prepare men for careers in the distribution areas of modern industry will be initiated next fall at Clarkson College of Technology, Potsdam, N. Y. The four-year course, combining the essential elements of the engineering sciences with those of business administration, will lead to the degree of Bachelor of Science.

City College will present the sixth annual John H. Finley series of public lectures on "The Newspaper and Society" next week, it was announced today by Prof. Edgar Johnson, chairman of the English Department.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 1 -- Cornell's track forces defeated Pennsylvania, 95 1/2 to 44 1/2, on Schoellkopf Field today.

THE authors of "The Art of Hungarian Cooking" have done an excellent job in bringing us the story as well as the recipes of Magyar cuisine. Their enthusiasm for the gently spiced and warmly flavored dishes so dear to the Hungarians who take a pride in their food and wine is warranted by the recipes they present.
HARTFORD, May 1 -- Indications are growing in Connecticut that Gov. John Davis Lodge soon will disclose his intention to seek renomination and re-election to a second term.

UNITED NATIONS, April 29 -- Twenty-five experts from fifteen countries will meet on Monday in Saigon, Vietnam, for a five-day conference on problems connected with the projected improvement of utilization of inland waterways in Asia.

COPENHAGEN -- As a lure to spring tourists, a new motorcoach service between Paris and Copenhagen is scheduled to get under way on May 27, with operation by Viking Continentbus. These coaches will carry attentive hostesses, refreshment bars and toilets.

Operating on the heart is a difficult and bloody business because the surgeon must feel his way in a pool of blood and because he has only a few minutes. Hence the many machines that have been invented to do the work of the heart and lungs while the surgeon is operating.
WOODBURY HEIGHTS, N. J., May 1 -- Three men were killed and another seriously injured near here today when a four-seater Piper plane crashed and burned in a wooded area.

An exhibit of semi-precious stones and specimens of precious gems from Brazilian mines will open Wednesday. The First International Semi-precious Stones and Minerals Exhibition of Brazil will run five or six weeks at the Brazilian Trade Bureau, 551 Fifth Avenue.
