ATHENS, May 1 -- The military authorities in the town of Larissa, center of the area of the earthquake that struck Thessaly and the Pindus Mountain region yesterday, reported today that twenty-six persons had been killed and 170 injured.

YONKERS, May 1 -- Don R. Millar, executive vice president of the United States Trotting Association, arrived at Yonkers Raceway today to act as mediator in the dispute between the track and the Standardbred Owners Association.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- The Soviet Union unveiled at a May Day celebration today its new four- jet inter continental bomber. It is big enough and has enough range to deliver the latest nuclear weapons to far distant points.

" HOW'S the hole in your leg?" Paul Griffin Jr., a recent West Point graduate and every inch a future general, asks his 16-year-old brother Dick at a Los Angeles dinner table, on one of the early pages of Frank Rooney's first novel.

TOKYO, May 1 (AP) -- Communist China's boss, Mao Tse-tung, made one of his rare public appearances today to watch 500,000 May Day marchers stream through Peiping's Tienanmen Square while artillery salvos roared in the background, a Communist broadcast said.

With Mikhail Botvinnik, world chess champion, holding a 10-8 lead in his match with Vassily Smyslov in Moscow, the nineteenth game of the series was adjourned after forty-one moves, according to reports received from London yesterday.

OUTSIDE regular sea lanes, some 1,500 miles west of Hawaii, the sidewheeler U. S. S. Saginaw broke on a reef off a little-known atoll. All ninety-three men aboard managed to get ashore. Few supplies were salvaged, and the immediate future held little more than an abundance of seals, gooney birds, salt water and prayers.

A SMALL 3-cent purple stamp in the Statue of Liberty design, which was introduced on the recent bicolored 8c, will be issued at Albany on June 24 as the second in the new ordinary series for the United States.

Many parties will be given at the annual luncheon for the benefit of the Lots for Little Thrift Shop on Tuesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Alexander J. McDonnell is president of the beneficiary, and Mrs. Richard E. Edmonson heads the benefit committee.

A WRITER new to the American scene, Jan Van Dorp is more than likely to win a large audience on this side of the Atlantic. His tale of seventeenth -century Flemish corsairs has been acclaimed in his native Belgium and other European lands -- and deservedly so.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Democrats will attempt to deal sudden death to Taft-Hartley Law amendments when they come up in the Senate on Monday.

CARDIFF -- Wales, "The Land of Song," has always been recognized as a fine country for mountaineers and ramblers. More and more it is becoming a happy hunting ground of tourists of all kinds. A recent survey of the Welsh tourist industry, carried out by the British Travel and Holidays Association in cooperation with the Welsh Tourist Board, revealed that of the 80,000 overseas visitors to Wales in 1953, 51 per cent were American.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 1 (AP) -- A mammoth storm jolted Oklahoma from noon until midnight today. Tornadoes slammed into eighteen towns leaving two dead, at least forty-eight injured and an uncounted amount of property damage.
BURLINGTON, Wisc., May 1 -- This Wisconsin farm community of 5,000 today celebrated "May Day, U. S. Way."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 -- A cost estimate of $9,000,000 for the building of Disneyland was made today with the announcement that a 160-acre site had been selected for the ambitious amusement center and living museum of Americana conceived by Walt Disney.
LOS ANGELES, May 1 -- Two branches of the Los Angeles city government are at loggerheads over the segregation of Negroes in the Fire department.
Winners of the 1954 Pulitzer Prizes in journalism, letters and music will be announced tomorrow by the trustees of Columbia University.

THE "final secret" that Admiral Robert A. Theobald would have his countrymen and the world believe is that President Franklin D. Roosevelt purposefully enticed the Japanese to attack Pearl Harbor in order to unite the American people behind him in a war that he was provoking with Germany and Japan.
FORT BRAGG, N. C., May 1 -- In Washington and in the pine forests and on the sand hills of North Carolina the nation's "new look" military policies were under debate and test this week.

The Soviet Union, after an absence of fifteen years, has now decided to rejoin the International Labor Organization. Last November its application was rejected because it refused to accept fully all the obligations of the I. L. O.'s constitution. It has now backed down.

PHOTOGRAPHIC BOOK HEADQUARTERS, a bookstore devoted exclusively to the sale of photographic books of all publishers, both domestic and foreign, currently in print in English, will open Wednesday on the tenth floor of 33 West Sixtieth Street.
ST. LOUIS, May 1 (UP) -- Rip Repulski's bases-loaded sacrifice fly broke a tenth-inning tie and enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to score a 5-to-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 1 -- Basins in which to store the precious waters of the Mianus River will have to be scoured out of more and more wooded back-country valleys if the water supply of Greenwich is to meet the demand twenty years hence, it was predicted here today.

Through all the debates and maneuvers at the Geneva conference there emerges one phenomenon of ominous significance to the free world. That is the unity and determination with which the Communists try to apply their now classic pattern of conquest to all nations and all situations in all parts of the world.

Wilson College (Chambersburg, Pa.) will begin in the fall a new program of elementary teacher training within its liberal arts framework, which will lead to certification in Pennsylvania. The new program is an outgrowth of the work in this field which Wilson began three years ago and which was expanded last year to include practice teaching.

PINEHURST, N. C., May 1 -Miracle shots on the last three holes and a missed two-foot putt by his opponent gave Billy Joe Patton a 1-up victory on the thirty-seventh hole today in the final of the North and South amateur golf tournament over Alex Welsh of Rockford, Ill.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Botrytis disease, which reduces bloom on peonies, is controlled by spraying every ten days with bordeaux mixture. Thinning stems to stand two inches apart before they are a foot tall also reduces spread of disease. Disbud promptly, pinching off all the little flower buds below the terminal one. Disbudding is desirable, even though the flowers are not wanted for show competition.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., May 1 (AP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Rdigway said today that the Army's new atomic cannon could fire a shell with nearly as much destructive power as the bomb that was dropped on Hiroshima in 1945.
A growing demand among Democratic leaders for the nomination of Mayor Wagner for the Governorship was reported yesterday.

IN 1948, in his introduction to "A Long Fourth and Other Stories," Robert Penn Warren predicted that Peter Taylor would probably write stories "deeper, fuller, richer and wiser than these." "A Woman of Means," Mr. Taylor's short novel of 1950, and "The Widows of Thornton," his second collection of stories, are impressive fulfillments of this prediction.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- Assistant Secretary of State Henry A. Byroade warned tonight that continued turmoil in the Middle East could result in loss of that region to "the control and influence" of the Soviet Union.

The annual Belmont Ball will be held on the night of June 11 -- the eve of the running of the Belmont Stakes -- at the Turf and Field Club at Belmont Park. Mrs. Conrad W. Thibault is chairman of the executive committee for the fete, which will serve as a benefit for the Travelers Aid Society of New York.

IF critics took the author of "Never Victorious, Never Defeated" as seriously as she takes herself, articles would have long since appeared on "The World of Taylor Caldwell." Fourteen of the sixteen novels she has published in less than two decades portray important aspects of American life in the period from the middle of the nineteenth century to the present time, most of them concerned with families of great wealth and power.
A Geriatric Rehabilitation Center to put elderly patients back on their feet, socially as well as physically, is scheduled to open early this summer at the Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn.

GEN. MARK WAYNE CLARK, who ended forty years of military service last year to become president of The Citadel, the Military College of South Carolina, has a deserved reputation, inside and outside the Army, for forthrightness.

IF crabgrass raised its ugly head in the lawn last summer, the gardener can be assured that he had plenty of company. For controlling crabgrass is the most common problem that faces home owners summer after summer.
This is the week when speed-boat regattas are resumed on both coasts after the long months of fail, winter and early spring.

WARRENTON, Va., May 1 (AP) -- An amateur rider, F. A. Bonsal Jr. of Maryland, won the first official race he had ever ridden when he guided Hugh J. Donovan's Lancrel to victory in the twenty-ninth running of the Virginia Gold Cup today.

The Geneva conference and the events in Indo-China have largely obscured the significant news of the American loan of $100 millions to the European Coal and Steel Community. Yet, in a sense, this loan represents an instance of economic aid to Europe which in long-range significance is second only to the Marshall Plan itself.

THIS is a story of passion and revenge in the mainstream of the Italian peasant novel. Yet it is as fresh as if it were the first of its kind. The narrative gift of young Paride Rombi, a magistrate by profession, won him the prize awarded in commemoration of Grazia Deledda, the great writer of his native island, Sardinia.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 1(AP) -- Taking the lead shortly after the break and holding it stubbornly, Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Pet Bully raced to a thrilling half-length victory today at Garden State Park in the $30,000 added Valley Forge Handicap before 35,412 turf enthusiasts largest opening day crowd in the 13-year history of the track.
KANDY, Ceylon, Sunday, May 2 -- The Prime Ministers of the five South Asian states meeting here have agreed upon a formula for peace in Indo-China to be placed before the Geneva conference.

A REDESIGNED Robot Royal, the automatic rapid sequence 35mm camera which takes one-inch-square pictures on 35mm film, is announced by the American importers and distributors, Intercontinental Marketing Corporation, 251 Fourth Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- Employment in Pennsylvania factories continued downward in March, but an encouraging sign was seen in the fact that the rate of decline was smaller than in any month since last October. The number of production-worker employment dropped to about 1,075,000 in March, a decline of 14,000, or 1 per cent, since February, according to figures compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.
GENEVA, May 1 -- The South Korean Government has never placed any faith in the ability the Geneva conference or, indeed, any conference to settle anything in Korea.

HANOI, Vietnam, Sunday, May 2 -- Tens of thousands of Vietminh troops smashed at the defenders of Dienbienphu last night in the third and mightiest attempt to overwhelm and destroy the Indo- China fortress.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1 (AP) -- President Juan D. Peron told the opening session of Congress today he wanted Argentine courts to punish his political opponents for "insults and calumny" in the recent political campaign.

ROME, May I (AP) -- Britain's Randy Turpin, who defends his Euroepan middleweight boxing crown here tomorrow, took a sight-seeing holiday today and nearly broke up a Communist May Day rally in the Colosseum.
Too little attention is being paid in the United States to crucial problems that need solving at home and abroad. Rabbi David J. Seligson declared yesterday.

THE International Conference on Twentieth Century Music, held in Rome April 4-15, provided an occasion for about 200 composers, performers and critics, that had gathered from twenty-five countries on five continents, to hear fifteen concerts, see two operas, and to discuss in formal debates as well as privately some of the problems on the minds of musicians today.

TOURS to California are again a seasonal offering. A fourteen-day round trip from Chicago is one package listed at $259 plus tax. Travel is by coach train with sight-seeing by motor at many points. West through Omaha and Salt Lake City to San Francisco, the itinerary continues down the Pacific Coast to Hollywood and Los Angeles.
Six student panelists on The New York Times Youth Forum agreed yesterday that the Taft-Hartley Law was fair and needed only a few changes.
A LETTER from Robert Bresson, director of "Diary of a Country Priest," the mystical French film now showing at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, brings up a delicate subject in connection with imported films.

DETROIT, May 1 -- Four top officials of the United Automobile Workers today labeled the hearings opening here Monday by the House Un-American Activities Committee a fishing expedition for votes in the November elections.

Sumner Slichter in "A Business Upturn Should Come Soon" (April 11 ) explains why he thinks the present recession will be short-lived. From certain facts about business conditions and their analysis he comes to the above rather optimistic conclusion. But, while I should like to share his optimism, I think a more doubtful outlook is justified: Three cases are pertinent here:
Columbia's track team took first places in all sixteen events to crush Rutgers, 100 1/3 -- 39 2/3, yesterday at Baker Field.
ERNEST LA PRADE'S charming tale, Alice in Orchestralia, now can be heard in a dramatization brought out by Records of Knowledge (three ten-inch 78 r. p. m. disks).

JERUSALEM, May 1 -- Dr. Hussein Fakhry el Khalidy, Jordanian Foreign Minister, said in Amman today that Israeli "maltreatment and desecration of Moslem religious property in Palestine" would be laid before the delegates at the forthcoming Arab and Moslem conference on the Palestine question to be held in Jerusalem.
KANDY, Ceylon, Sunday, May 2 -- The text of the communique of the five South Asian Prime Ministers, issued here today, follows:

CINCINNATI, May 1 -- Johnny Temple's low line single to center in the eleventh inning today gave the Cincinnati Redlegs a 7-6 triumph over the Dodgers and repossession of first place in the National League.

GUATEMALA, May 1 -- Guatemala celebrated May Day here today with a huge Communist-organized parade and highly nationalistic speeches by President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman and Victor Manuel Gutierrez, secretary of the Labor Federation and one of Guatemala's leading Communists.

The legal talent in the Police Department is increasing. In Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams' little army of 20,000 policemen there are about 600 who have had legal training, and of these 150 have been admitted to the bar.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- Steve Gromek, 34-year-old right hander, became the first American League pitcher to win four games when he threw a fourhitter at the Washington Senators today as the Detroit Tigers pounded out 16 hits to triumph, 6 -- 1.

There have been sharp criticisms, both in and out of Congress, of the lease-purchase bill for acquiring Government buildings on the ground that it will be wasteful, that it is a "grab-bag" and a "steal" for the benefit of money lenders and real estate men. But some more important implications of the measure seem to have passed practically unnoticed.

ONCE upon a time, the average home owner may have thought that a "rabbet" was a four-legged mammal with an insatiable appetite for his tenderest garden greens, that "chiseling" was distinctly an unfair practice, and that a "Yankee" screw driver was utilized only by carpenters residing north of the Mason-Dixon Line.

Fortuna of Duesseldorf, Germany, and Borussia of Dortmund, Germany, will meet in a soccer match at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, today. The game will highlight the annual field and sports day of the German American Soccer League.
City officials, civic associations and the police put final touches yesterday on ceremonial plans for the second opening of the Brooklyn Bridge.

WHILE other producers complain about the scarcity of story material and actors, Leonard Goldstein goes merrily about the business of turning out pictures. Mr. Goldstein, who won his spurs as a producer of money-making, if not Academy Award, films at Universal, is an extraordinary man in many ways. For one thing, he has no pretentions about what he is doing. He is in the movie business because he likes it. because he finds it profitable.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles is returning to Washington next week to get to work on the formation of a Southeast Asian alliance--with the British if possible, but without them if necessary.
David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the National Broadcasting Company, Inc., has refused to accept a program of news discussion proposed by Facts Forum, it became known yesterday.
Out of the massive record of the ease of Army v. McCarthy (33 hours of sessions held, 10 witnesses heard, 160,000 words of testimony taken) these broad impressions have emerged:
CINCINNATI, May 1 (UP) -- Johnny Gonsalves, California lightweight, earned a ten-round decision over Cincinnati's Wallace (Bud) Smit in a televised fight before 2,300 tonight.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 1 -- The Turks and the principal Western powers hold conflicting views on the question whether Greece and Turkey may conclude a binding alliance with Yugoslavia before obtaining the approval of their allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Grand Central Palace, the last place to which an alien goes to register before leaving the country, is expecting a record rush this year.

Argentina's electoral law provides for "free, democratic elections." Argentina's President, Juan D. Peron, and his regime have pledged that during election campaigns all parties shall have "all the liberty imaginable."

Re that story about the snake, frog and flask of whisky in Murray Schumach's "New Life on the Mississippi" (April 18): It was being bandied about in Hartford almost sixty years ago, and dealt with a trout fisherman on the west branch of the Farmington River.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 1 -- It was No. 23 for Navy's champion crew today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 -- Previews of the type of programs to be presented by KQED, the bay area's educational television station, were being presented this week-end. The station is non-commercial and community-sponsored.

HANDICAPPING the Kentucky Derby is a picnic compared to analyzing television program ratings, which made news last week because of public interest in the size of the audience for the Army-McCarthy hearings.

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, April 20 -- Famous as the site of the assassination of the Austrian Archduke Ferdinand, which set off the World War I, forty years ago, now Sarajevo is the capital of Yugoslavia's most energetic efforts at industrializing the still-extensive backward areas of the country.

THE statement of your reviewer Donald Barr in reference to Vernon Lee's collection of tales "The Snake Lady and Other Stories": "All of them are good, palpably good, better than Poe," seems to me to constitute intellectual disgrace.

AS Tennyson remarked, and as every schoolboy knows -- if schoolboys still get their noses dipped into declamatory verse the way they used to -- it was obvious all along that someone had blundered. But military blunders are seldom corrected on the spot. They provide the data for courts of inquiry, which dig for the truth at their leisure a great deal later. Meanwhile, the soldier will do as he is told.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., May 1 -- The adaptation of airborne tactics to the atomic age and the integration of atomic arms and guided missiles into the tactical structure of the Army are unresolved problems.
BERLIN, May 1 -- May Day, which in West Berlin has for years been a symbol of resistance against communism, today dramatized a change in the mood of the city.

THE long battle to preserve the Calaveras South Grove, one of the finest primeval stands of redwood and sugar pine in California, has been won at last. A gift of $1,000,000 from John D. Rockefeller Jr. has enabled the state to purchase the 2,155-acre tract in Tuolumne County from private owners who would otherwise have logged it off.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., April 27 -- On Mother's Day, May 9, President Eisenhower will place a wreath at the base of the fifty- foot granite shaft here that honors Mary Washington, mother of George Washington.

Women headed by Mrs. Peter C. A. Carpenter and Mrs. J. Truman Bidwell are aiding in the plans for the cocktail party and entertainment to be held on May 25 at the River Club for the benefit of the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.

DETROIT, May 1 -- Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri predicted at a $25-a-plate dinner of Michigan Democrats tonight that the party would win a comfortable majority in the Senate and a large majority in the House in the November elections.

TO Christophilos and his people "the world" meant their village on Pyrgos on Athos, the famous Greek peninsula stretching out into the Aegean Sea. It was a small world, remote, primitive and so poor that boys had time only for work -- "Are you a little goat, that you play!" said his mother to Christophilos.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Unemployment compensation beneficiaries in Illinois dropped 14 per cent in 1953 to 242,422, the State Department of Labor reported. The report added that an additional 140,000 claimants did not receive benefits last year because of reemployment within six days or because of ineligibility caused by wage credits of less than the $400 minimum.

LONDON, May 1 -- Nearly 700 Jamaicans who hope to get work in Britain landed at Southampton today. They formed the largest group of Jamaicans ever to come to Britain at once. No such mass debarkation has occurred since 400 arrived in one vessel in 1948.
Mental Health Week will be started here today and in communities across the country with special church sermons and other ceremonies, according to the National Association for Mental Health.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 1 (Reuters) -- The executive committee of the Liberal International today ended a three-day meeting here with adoption of a resolution that the free world "should continue to build up its strength and unity in every possible way."

I feel bound to answer a letter from Arnold Levy which appeared in your section on April 11. Like Mr. Levy, I bewail the practice of converting theatres into parking lots, but I'm afraid he has missed the mark in searching for a reason.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 1 -- The test of Texas as a two-party state will get under way early in the week.
BONN, Germany, April 27 -The gold and foreign exchange holdings of the West German Central Bank reached a new high at the beginning of this month: the equivalent of $2,165,300,000.

DALLAS, Tex., May 1 (UP) -- Dean Smith, the Olympic sprinter from Texas, tied the world record for the 100-yard dash at 9.3 seconds with the aid of a slight tailwind tonight as Southern California rolled to its sixty-seventh straight triumph in a collegiate track meet.

WHEN the collection of garden equipment in the garage reaches that precise point where it becomes impossible to close the door with the car inside, then a tool house is clearly indicated. Now there are probably as many types of tool houses as there are tools.

BOSTON, May 1 -- Some bank executives in this area have recently expressed the opinion that the contraction in business activity has gone about as far as it is going. Statistically, it is impossible to point to much change one way or the other in the last several weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Two teen-age Rumanian boys got a chance today to extend their personal thanks to the man whose intervention helped bring them from behind the Iron Curtain. The two boys, Constantin Georgescu, 19 years old, and his brother Peter, 15, were received by President Eisenhower at the White House and thanked him for a letter he had written early this year.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 1 -- New York Athletic Club rowers won three of the five events today in an invitation regatta sponsored by the New York Rowing Association over the Orchard Beach Lagoon course.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- Ray York, a 22-year-old kid out of Gloucester, Mass., went on an emotional jag as he jogged back from the first turn after riding the little gray colt, Determine, to victory in the Kentucky Derby today. He stood proudly aloft in his stirrups and waved his cap at the cheering thousands.

AN English village is as full of character -- and characters -- as an African kraal, and, at her listening post in the center of Bramton Wick, Miss Fair is kept busy as the bush telegraph signals the news from Bank Cottage and the big house at Endbury and other points north, south, east and west.
MEXICO CITY, April 30 -- The Government has decided to reduce the 25 per cent export tax decreed after devaluation of the peso April 17.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 1 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche warned today that there was "a very grave danger" that the drive for independence by colonial peoples in Africa would bring a repetition of the recent international crises in Southeast Asia.

THE records of the 112th season of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Society are imposing, if only as witness to the extraordinary industry and productiveness of this historic organization in the performance and dissemination of an immense literature of orchestral music.
ANKARA, Turkey,. May 1 -- More than 80 per cent of Turkey's 10,259,452 registered voters are expected to go to the polls tomorrow.

MANCHESTER, N. H., May 1 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran said tonight the Communist party had been working constantly toward the perfection of a "highly developed underground apparatus," and the decentralization of party operations.
The oil industry is deeply concerned over the proposal to cut the tax allowance granted to off-set depletion of oil and gas reserves.

THE Communist drive for Asia has reached a post-war climax now at the Geneva Conference. In part, as the war in Indo-China demonstrates, the Kremlin relies on guns and bullets. But no less vital is the propaganda side of the Communist effort, the massive campaign to capture the hearts and minds of the masses who live on the most poverty-stricken of the world's continents.

JACKSON, Miss., May 1 -- The Mississippi Legislature ended a session of four months and adjourned last night after adopting a public school equalization program. It seeks to give Negro pupils the same kind of schooling as whites, but in separate schools.

The weather turned against retailers last week, and affected their sales. It was rainy early in the week and cooler than average and followed a week of good, hot weather when sales exceeded expectations. Retailers thought that a certain amount of buying that would ordinarily be done last week had taken place the week before.

Mr. Barr's description of Vernon Lee as a "pro-German propagandist" is a thorough misrepresentation, not to be supported by anything in her writing or the memory of her friends, and in fairness to herself and her political ideas it should be retracted.

TAORMINA, Sicily -- Americans traveling to Sicily will certainly be interested in a building project that is rapidly nearing completion here. It is a new non-profit bungalow development, which hangs over the sea near Mazzaro beach.

A man retired from Federal service last week who during his long Washington career has earned and received the respect of Congress, the Administration and the public. The man is Lindsay C. Warren, former Representative from North Carolina and, for the last thirteen and a half years, Comptroller General of the United States.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, April 20 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar's austere ideas of what is needed to regenerate Portugal at home and overseas have destroyed Lourenco Marques' chances of becoming the Reno of the African subcontinent.

BEERSHEBA, Israel, April 21 -- The sixty-six settlements in the Negev made rapid progress this year, but the plague of infiltration has worsened and strained the morale of the 12,800 pioneer settlers. This was the consensus among farmers interviewed during a recent tour of the area on the occasion of the fifth anniversary of the joint Government-Jewish Agency program for Negev agricultural development.

One supermarket chain is doing something about the "buyers market." The Grand Union Company last week sent off for a tour of its 300 stores a thirty-three-foot trailer designed to teach everyone, from the men who fill from stock its "food-o-matic" racks to the checkers at the cash registers, the latest wrinkle in pleasing the customer and inducing him or her to put an ever larger share of the household budget into food.
Consulting engineers to the Transit Authority have recommended higher fares and cuts in service to reduce deficits on transportation lines on Staten Island.

THE irresistible mouse who first appeared in "Willie Goes to School" now discovers the pleasures of the beach. For an entire summer Willie explores the shore with his new friends, plays and picnics and goes fishing with Daddy.
GENEVA, May 1 -- The deadlock on the Korean question at the Far East conference here was confirmed today at a meeting of Western and Communist foreign ministers.

WEMBLEY, England, May 1 -- The belief that the English are phlegmatic, dignified and reserved took its annual beating today at Wembley Stadium where West Bromwich Albion whipped Preston North End, 3 -- 2, and won the Football Association Cup.
Fire Department regulations applying to 1,000 civilian employes have been ordered revised by Fire Commissioner Edward J. Cavanagh Jr. The changes will be the first since 1946.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 1 -- Franklin T. McClintock has been named chairman of Princeton University's annual giving program, which will seek $1,000,000 in unrestricted funds in 1954-55.
MANHATTAN, Kan., May 1 (AP) -- An angry Wes Santee, who said he had been upset by the official referee and starter, won his slowest half-mile of the season on a wet, sloppy track today.

JOSE GRECO and his company today begin the second and last week of their engagement at the Broadway Theatre. Otherwise the week has only three concerts and two lectures on its schedule. The complete list is as follows:
Determine won the eightieth Kentucky Derby at Louisville yesterday and paid $10.60 for $2. Hasty Road was second and Hasseyampa third. Gigantic, $59, captured the Swift Stakes at Belmont by a nose.

TOBRUK, Libya, May 1 (AP) -- Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh, reunited with their two children after an absence of more than five months, headed for home tonight aboard the royal yacht Britannia.

MANILA, Sunday, May 2 (AP) -The Asiatic counterpart of the world Olympic Games, bringing together some 1,000 athletes of eighteen countries, gets down to serious business today after yesterday's colorful parade before 30,000 sweltering spectators in Rizal Stadium.

Interesting selections of furniture in traditional styles will be on sale in several of the auction galleries this week, together with paintings, rugs and other decorations and furnishings suitable for the period home.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, April 29 -- The International Court of Justice will open hearings May 10 in a dispute over $2,880,000 worth of gold.

IN 1886, James E. Scripps, then publisher of The Detroit Tribune (later to become The Detroit Times), looked into what turned out to be a somewhat cloudy crystal ball. The Great Lakes city in which he lived was then a quiet, almost idyllic place, with traces of French-Canadian influences still discernible and the lumber-rich and navigation men living a leisurely life.

ON May 7, the New York Society Library will celebrate its 200th birthday. There will be no dancing in the streets, nor will there be that jubilant upending of parked automobiles to mark the celebration. Instead, and indeed consonant with its temper and tone, there will be on that historic day a decorous reception in the Library for its members and friends.

The formal opening of WNYC's educational Institute of the Air will take place tomorrow, with a talk by Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, United States Commissioner of Education. A New York City-owned radio station, WNYC has scheduled a full week's program dealing with school and college problems.
Final approval by the city last week of the $6,460,000 development of South Beach along the southeast shore of Staten Island has paved the way for an early start on the project.
Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein accused Governor Dewey by implication yesterday of mishandling the waterfront labor troubles that recently tied up the Port of New York for a month.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Defense Department still lacks a uniform policy for dealing with al-almost 200 American servicemen suspected of collaboration, in greater or lesser degree, with their Communist captors in Korea.
The Second International Conference of Manufacturers will hold regional meetings throughout the British Isles and Europe May 15 through 25.
Plans to build a large maintenance base at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, were announced yesterday by American Airlines.
Americans from Iron Curtain countries, reflecting the heritage of freedom that is now theirs, marched down Fifth Avenue yesterday alongside thousands re-attesting their loyalty to this nation.
GREENFIELD VILLAGE, Mich. -- Because Henry Ford admired Thomas A. Edison above most other men, the most complete visual history of an invention ever presented was opened to the public here yesterday.
Five hundred of the 20,000 stockholders of the International Business Machines Corporation gathered last Tuesday at the company's offices at 590 Madison Avenue for the annual meeting.

ORIGINALLY printed at Cheyenne, Wyo., in 1894, "The Banditti of the Plains," was so thoroughly suppressed that even the copyright copies disappeared from the Library of Congress. The latest (1954) offering of a first edition of the book is at $250.

THE Greeks, I am told, had no such thing as an encyclopedia or even a word for it, the passion for assembling large amounts of diversified knowledge being a relatively late development.* We are, I take it, making up for lost time.

OF the many delightful common names given to plants by generations of nature lovers in America and England, none is more popular than May flower. In northern sections of the United States more than fifteen different species are familiarly called May flower.

LAST week we transformed ourselves into a bookworm and we promised to do so again this week. We have; and we offer up the important forth-coming fiction, with this rider: it does not follow as closely, as it does in non-fiction, that a fellow who performed ably will perform ably the next time out or, for that matter, ever again.

ON a pleasant rise of ground overlooking the Schuylkill is a park known as Bartram's Garden. In it stands a house of strange and serious beauty, built by John Bartram (1699-1777) -- in the opinion of Linnaeus, the greatest "natural botanist" of his time -- and the hero of the present unusual study, Josephine Herbst's "New Green World.
MONTREAL, May 1 (Canadian Press) -- A Superior Court justice has ruled that the Seafarer's' International Union (AFL) has no right to ban members in disfavor from working on union-manned vessels.

IZMIR, Turkey, April 24 -- This beautiful port city, settled more than a thousand years before Christ by Aeolian Greeks, has enhanced its historical role to become the principal export outlet for booming Anatolia.

THROUGHOUT the country many garden clubs and organizations have initiated community planting projects that have since become well established and successful. And thereby not only has the local landscape been beautified but the citizens have been given a sense of working together.

WASHINGTON, May 1--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's threat to reclaim his place on the committee investigating his dispute with the Army is not "practical," in the opinion of Senator Karl E. Mundt, acting chairman of the Senate hearings.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., May 1 -- An unusual May Day parade took place here this afternoon. Five hundred Boy Scouts, Cubs, Explorers and their leaders marched through the streets of this 314-year-old town accompanied by the Southampton and Hampton Bays High School bands.

In "The Magic Mountain," Thomas Mann's powerful novel about a tuberculosis sanatorium, there is a beautiful passage concerning the strange and elusive quality of the passage of time and how it holds different meanings for different people.

LONDON, May 1 (AP) -- Spain and Egypt advanced to the second round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition today, while Brazil and Ireland held 2-1 leads and Yugoslavia led Monaco, 2 -- 0, in the first-round series.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (UP) -- Rookie Jim Finigan's two-out single in the tenth inning scored Don Bollweg from second base today to give the Philadelphia Athletics a 2-1 victory over Baltimore at Connie Mack Stadium.
CAIRO, April 17 -- The Bernheim family of New York and Paris left here today on the last leg of a 13,000-mile auto trek across Africa that has been half fun, half anthropology.

Matching of paint colors, always a difficu t problem, became more complex with the introduction of new rubber and resin base paints. Colors which could be applied to oil bases, for instance, needed a different medium when mixed with the so-called water or latex base paints.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1 -- Argentina's voters reaffirmed their faith in Peronism last Sunday. In nation-wide elections, they returned President Juan D. Peron's candidates to Congress and municipal posts, outvoting the chief Opposition party, the Union Civica Radical, by two and a half million votes.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 1 (UP) -- Doris Hart won the women's singles title for the fourth straight year in the British hard court championships by defeating Britain's Mrs. Joy Mottram, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, in the final today.

A DECADE ago William Sansom made his debut in England as an unusually promising short-story writer with an obvious debt to Kafka. The debt was rapidly paid off, and Mr. Sansom has since displayed a growing mastery of his highly individual gifts and a growing versatility.

A UNIQUE international automotive contest is in the making with aged American cars matched against British counterparts, and the outcome depending on performance of wheezing engines and creaking frames over an exacting road run of more than 850 miles.

THE complaint of the performing musician that the recordings he makes are used to deprive him of employment in radio and television is both familiar and justified. There is another victim scarcely ever mentioned -- the composer. Whether he gets paid or not depends presumably on his ASCAP affiliation and rating, but one thing is certain -- he gets no credit and is performed piecemeal.

Travel the country roads on a weekend, when school is not in session, particularly the hill roads beside the brooks, and you will see him. The boy beside the brook, the boy with a bait rod or a fly rod and a special light in his eye. Note that it isn't a willow pole he has, nor a twine string with a bent pin.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 1 -- Dr. Ralph G. Wright, who was chairman of the chemistry department at Rutgers University from 1907 until his retirement in 1930, received the Rutgers University Medal this week.

BOSTON, May 1 -- The State Board of Registration in Medicine has scheduled a decision on complaints of fee-splitting against a group of eleven physicians for next Tuesday, Dr. Robert C. Cochrane, secretary of the state board, has announced.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- There are three constants in the otherwise varying estimates of many practical politicians as to the political effect of the McCarthyArmy hearings so far.

VENTRILLOQUIST Edgar Bergen and his troupe of dummies, including Charlie McCarthy and Mortimer Snerd, will celebrate the start of their eighteenth season for the C. B. S. radio network on Sunday, Sept. 5, by introducing a completely new format and broadcasting at a new time.

Women headed by Mrs. Jean-Pierre Millon and Mrs. James Cash Penney, co-chairmen, are serving on the International Hospitality Committee for the annual American Mothers' Award Luncheon to be held on Friday, May 7, in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Fordham chased five pitchers in the second inning yesterday while scoring sixteen runs and gained a 25-1 victory over Kings Point at Coffey Field in the Bronx. The second-inning scoring was accomplished on five hits, nine walk and three errors.
National security is a problem that needs two approaches. Both are exceptionally involved in the continuing case of the Army Signal Corps Center at Fort Monmouth, N. J.

THIS is a searching novel about a mean lady novelist writing a mean novel about a college where she is spending a year teaching creative writing. It portrays a savage, lethal-tongued bluestocking, pitilessly intent on pinning down her colleagues as specimens for her already gruesome collection, while remaining insensitive to much that Randall Jarrell, as narrator, finds genuine and fine in the community.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 (UP) -- Cary Middlecoff retained his lead in the $10,000 San Francisco open golf tournament today by breaking par for the second straight afternoon as he carded a 36, 34 -- 70 over the tricky Lake Merced course for a thirty-six-hole total of 139.

GENEVA, May 1 -- The United States delegation to the International Far Eastern Conference here was reported today still divided on what policy to adopt toward a French Union-Vietminh settlement of the war in Indo-China.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The late Harold L. Ickes wrote in 1938 that President Franklin D. Roosevelt feared the possibility of a revolution if he followed "conservative" Democratic advice to halt relief spending and farm aid in an effort to balance the budget.

The slump-shackled Yankees absorbed another cruel pounding from the Indians yesterday. Behind the six-hit pitching of Early Wynn, the contenders from Cleveland battered Bill Miller, Tom Gorman and Bob Grim for twelve safeties in romping to a 10 -- 2 triumph before 20,938 paying spectators and 5,067 Ladies Day guests at the Stadium.

THERE was a time when two-piano recitals consisted mostly of fancy salon transcriptions, with Mozart's Sonata in D thrown in as a sop to the intelligentsia. The way the old two-piano ensembles used to operate, you'd think that there was virtually no original literature for the combination.

LOOKING at the domestic scene, business men do not see anything that is likely to change the economic picture in the next few months. It is the consensus that the recession is scraping bottom and the outlook therefore can be viewed with more optimism on the theory that if conditions aren't going to improve, at least they won't get worse.

FROM now on, New York City's inflowing tourist tide will rise steadily, all through spring, summer and fall, into bleak November. Then it will begin to ebb until it is almost nothing. The visitors start coming when Rockefeller Center Gardens wear their first lovely plantings; they move out again when the leaves have fled and fall flowers have withered and died.

The main distinction between the taxation of sales of property as ordinary income and as capital gain is that property "used in a trade or business," or "held by the taxpayer primarily for sale to customers in the ordinary course of his trade or business," does not qualify for treatment as capital gain.

CAIRO, May 1 -- Egypt's press and Government spokesmen have taken the discovery of a Communist-led plot against the military regime as a cue for a campaign of denunciation of both Soviet and Western "imperialism."

ITALY'S first annual of photography, "Foto Annuario Italiano 1954" (New York: Museum Books, Inc., 48 East Forty-third Street. $10), with text in English as well as in Italian, has just reached this country.

A BIT of the Netherlands tradition will reign at the annual Tulip Festival which is under way at North Tarrytown, N. Y., this week-end. Thousands of Dutch tulip bulbs are at their prime on the grounds of the Philipse Castle as well as other springblooming flowers and shrubs.
Cornell unleashed a thirteenhit attack off two Columbia pitchers to hand the Lions their fourth consecutive Ivy League loss, 13 -- 5, yesterday at Baker Field.

DURING the past few weeks, or more than half a century after she first captivated screen audiences, Lillian Gish again is playing a persuasive role. Under the aegis of United Artists, distributors of some of her best-known vehicles, the actress is "performing" as good-will ambassador for the company's current celebration of its thirty-fifth anniversary. Neither would appear to be withering on the vine.

DENVER, May 1 -- The National Jewish Hospital, one of the nation's outstanding pioneers in tuberculosis treatment and research, will expand its surgical and clinical facilities in a $750,000 building program.

THE sauce-cook, next in command to the chef in a fine kitchen, could no more do without butter than without his high snowy hat. That table fat gives its excellent flavor to sauces that bring out the best in fish, meats, vegetables, desserts.
Jo Sullivan, who made her debut with the New York City Opera as Magnolia in "Show Boat," assumed her second role with the company yesterday afternoon when she sang Adele in Strauss "Die Fledermaus."

ZELL AM SEE, Austria -- Glaciers are fascinating wonders of nature, but unfortunately they are usually accessible only to the experienced and well-equipped mountain climber after a dangerous ascent. One of the largest and most majestic European glaciers, however, can be visited easily and comfortably by any one with a few extra schillings to spend.

THIS remarkable book belongs to a genre, the philosophy of history. That genre runs to length, discursiveness and, since Spengler at least, pessimism about man's fate. William H. McNeill, however, is brief, pointed, and by contrast with Spengler, Toynbee, Sorokin and their fellow prophets of doom, almost optimistic.

MARCHES AROUND THE WORLD: Vanguard Military Band, Hans Ahninger conducting (Vanguard, ten-inch). Strauss' Radetzky March is possibly the most familiar of works heard on this disk, which also offers marches by Ganne, Cekal, Novacek, Meissner, Lehar and Marchesini.
FOLLOWING are excerpts from comments on some of the exhibitions reviewed in The Times during the week just closed.
BOSTON, May 1 -- Virgil Oliver (Fire) Trucks pitched a masterly one-hit 3-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox today before 14,932 Fenway Park fans to keep Chicago in front in the American League race.

WHEN a talented novelist addresses himself to children, they may expect enjoyment of a special caliber; so may the elders who read aloud to them. Marcel Ayme's "The Wonderful Farm," one of the most refreshing and distinctive children's books of recent years, proved a case in point when it appeared in this country in 1951.
A medical advance in the treatment of leukemia, an excess of white corpuscles in the blood. has heartened researchers although so far it has added only a few months to children's lives.

CLEVELAND, May 1 -- The industrial picture in the Cleveland area brightened this week as the Republic Steel Corporation continued to step up production. With three additional open-hearth furnaces in blast, operations at the plant, largest of eight operated by Republic, are scheduled at 77.3 per cent of rated capacity.

DICHONDRA repens, the "wonder lawn" of the Southwest, is fast spreading to the North, East and South and especially in those states bordering the Gulf of Mexico. During the past year the demand for dichondra seed in Florida has mushroomed. Thousands of new lawns have been sown with this plant.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The irony of American policy in Indo-China is that officials in Washington are now longing for the kind of solution they had the power to impose ten years ago.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Twenty or more major airports will soon employ "electronic weathermen" to stand near runways in rain or shine to report ceiling and visibility conditions.
Carol Lyttle has been elected vice president in charge of sales of the Dictaphone Corporation.

WITHIN the marble halls of Washington's National Gallery are million-dollar masterpieces by the greatest names in art. Next Sunday paintings by Raphael, Rembrandt and Renoir will be confronted by works by such unpretentious and forgotten Americans as A. Logan, Susane Walters and, above all, that most prolific and versatile of all artists, "Anonymous."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 1 -The only important contest in the Ohio primary election Tuesday will be that for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat held for so long by Robert Alonso Taft.

Our hats are off to the Drama Mailbag which was the spur initiating the campaign resulting in License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey's recent order. It requires the legitimate theatres to post diagrams of seat locations and to stamp tickets which only afford an obstructed view of the stage.

J. R. (Jack) Poppele of South Orange, N. J., former vice president in charge of engineering for the Mutual Broadcasting System, confirmed yesterday reports that he had been appointed director of the Voice of America. He said he had accepted the appointment, effective Monday, but would not actively take over the office in New York until later in the month.

A united approach to the problems of scholarship awards has been announced by thirteen West Coast colleges and universities in an unusual joint agreement designed to assure that appropriate awards go to students who most deserve them. Groundcovers on the property not only add interest to the landscape but serve a functional capacity as well. For example, the lawn itself is a groundcover, although it is rarely thought of as such. It does nevertheless have both a functional and esthetic use similar to that of other groundcovers.

Geneva, for fifteen years a monument to the pre-war failure of collective security, last week was a world diplomatic capital once more. In the setting of a sparkling springtime there began in Geneva on Monday a crucial conference. It will test the capacity of the free world to maintain a front of collective security against the expansive forces of communism.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 1 -- Bob Feltman, Dartmouth junior, hurled a no-hit, no-run game at Doubleday Field today as the Big Green defeated Army, 6 to 0, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game. It was Dartmouth's first victory in five games this season.

CHAPALULU, an ancient Moro pirate king, was supposed to have been a devil man. The legend around the Sula Islands was that Chapalulu still lived and still jealously watched over his fabulous plunder. The captain of the motor schooner Hukapuka and his young diver Nick Masters laughed at such tales when they set out from Macassar in quest of the treasure.

Contrary to the trend in the jewelry industry, sales of cultured pearls have been running ahead of the 1953 volume. An additional boost resulted early in April when the excise tax was cut from 20 to 10 per cent.

In a fifteen-minute episode early yesterday a robber in Brooklyn held up and injured a taxi driver, wounded a policeman in a pistol duel, evaded a dozen other patrolmen in a chase and frightened a woman from her apartment. In the end, he surrendered meekly, trapped under a bed.

A small gold bar that symbolizes an unusual aspect of the California gold-rush days will be sold at public auction during the concluding session of the sale of American and foreign coins from the Davis-Graves collection next Friday and Saturday.

TORONTO, May 1 -- The value of manufacturing production in the Province of Ontario rose in 1953 to a record of $8,867,000,000 according to the trade and industry branch of the Provincial Department of Planning and Development.

They laugh at a play because it is funny and the characters and situations reflect their own ordinary lives.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- New York's back-door playground, the seventy-two square miles of lakes and woodlands that make up the Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park, has already begun to make the transition from a winter to a summer recreation center.

The domestic steel industry, a key barometer of general business activity, fared rather well financially in the first quarter this year, when the recession of the last nine months reached a point that may have been the bottom of the economy's "rolling readjustment."

" AMERICAN democracy has produced the largest group of outstanding Negroes in the world," says Langston Hughes who is himself an outstanding American Negro writer. "They have worked in almost all fields of human endeavor from the sciences to politics, the arts to sports, religion to business."
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 1 -- A record-breaking effort in the one-mile relay brought a 72-68 victory to Manhattan in an exciting track and field meet with Army today.

CAIRO, May 1 -- Tension between Israel and her Arab neighbors, arising from a wave of frontier incidents, continues high, but there are many sound indications that the Arabs are as unlikely to launch a new attack as they are to conclude a real peace.
CHICAGO, May 1 -- The Giants ran afoul Hank Sauer's booming bat today with damaging results.

Rhine (Duke University) found that under the influence of sodium amytal (a sleeping compound) the scores of gifted sensitives dropped in clairvoyance card tests, but rose again when caffein was given.

Wall Street's chart readers for the first time this year had the cards stacked mostly in their favor last week. Rail stocks, the laggards of recent markets, broke out of their restricted trading range, passing their previous 1954 highs with a comfortable margin to spare.

TRENTON, May 1 -- When the Senate and Assembly reconvene here on Monday, each legislator will find on his desk a copy of the Appropriations Bill for 1954-55. It will call for record expenditures of $235,000,000.
Today marks the beginning of Mental Health Week. Of the various "weeks" observed each year to focus attention on health problems, no other affects so many persons in our population.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 1 -A sweet-swinging Harvard crew rounded out an even dozen victories for the Compton Cup on Carnegie Lake today.

WHEN classical tragedy is presented in an English garb that is skimpy or shoddy or overornate the effect may be ludicrous, but the discerning eye can perceive the essential nobility beneath the ill-fitting dress. Aristophanes is wholly at the mercy of his translator; a dull version, like the anonymous prose generally current, is a dreary stretch of heavy mud varied only by pools of more noisome muck.

STATESMEN have boulevards named after them; First Ladies have roses named after them; but here's a new one -- there's a girl at C. B. S.-Television who has a camera angle named after her. They call it "Mill's angle."

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce, while renewing opposition to union proposals for a guaranteed annual wage, urged employers today to give "serious study" to ways of providing workers with steadier jobs and income security.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)--The Association of American Railroads said today that atomic locomotives had a good chance of becoming a reality when nuclear energy was finally made available to the civilian world in an economical form.

Another of the important projects in the $9,600,000 rebuilding program of the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be opened to the public on May 12. It is a handsome new auditorium with a stage that can accommodate a full symphony orchestra and chorus.

MIAMI -- One of the major airlines is taking a step that may well evolve as an outstanding contribution to the comfort of the persons who travel by air. Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra) is equipping its fleet of Douglas airliners with new airborne radar which will be used for storm detection, and the use of the complex electronic apparatus will probably take almost all the bad bumps out of air travel.
HARRY S. TRUMAN will reach the Biblical age this Saturday, but seeing him in his office here you get the impression that time, at this important bench mark, will pass him by.

The school superintendent's lot is not a happy one. He is hounded on all sides by parents, school board members, political leaders, teachers, and others in the community. To some he is too progressive, to others he is too hide bound. He is accused of being autocratic by some and by others of letting the schools run away with him.

One of the colorful events of the spring season here is the annual tour of gardens and penthouse terraces under the auspices of the City Gardens Club. The tour will be held on two afternoons, the first on Tuesday and the second on May 11. Mrs. Roger B. Hull is president of the City Gardens Club.

SAN MATEO, Calif., May 1 -Andrew J. Crevolin of Covina, Calif., completed one of the great "doubles" in racing history today when his Imbros won the $100,000 William P. Kyne Handicap just three hours after his Determine had captured the Kentucky Derby.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., -- Visitors lucky enough to crowd into the environs of this colonial capitol a fortnight hence will witness the conjunction of two significant events spanning almost two centuries of national history.
President Franklin D. Roosevelt's war-time policy of aid to the Soviet Union was defended last night by Averell Harriman.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., May 1 (AP) -- A shot-put attempt greater than the official world record was registered by a 25-year-old New York University graduate today but may not go into the record books because of an even longer unverified toss last week.
DERBY, Conn., May 1 -- Penn's varsity crew gained further laurels on the calm Housatonic River today by beating Yale and Columbia to win the Blackwell Cup.

CRITICS and the public in London have welcomed "The Teahouse of the August Moon" with a warmth which owes nearly as much to their relief in the discovery that, despite the current political hysteria, Americans retain their ability to laugh at themselves as it does to their appreciation of this scampering and hilarious comedy.

THE aridly beautiful Santa Cruz valley was one of the earliest sections of the continental United States to feel the weight of a European foot. In 1539, Fray Marcos de Niza arrived from Mexico and, upon his return to Mexico City, reported he had seen the fabled Seven Cities of Cibola. Inspired by this account, Coronado plunged through the valley in pursuit of this mirage which disappeared only in the fertile plains of Kansas.

Charlie Kilkuskie of St. Francis Prep turned in the upset of the day when he beat Tom Sheehan, a schoolmate, by ten yards to win the one-mile run in the seventh annual Brooklyn College interscholastic track and field championships on the Kingsmen's campus yesterday.

Gigantic won a big race by a small margin at Belmont Park yesterday. Competing in the fifty-third running of the $27,350 Swift Stakes, Joe W. Brown's campaigner scored by a nose over the Wheatley Stable's Quick Lunch in the seven-furlong test. William Haggin Perry's Remand was third.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 1 -- A scramble for the Republican nomination for Representative in the Twenty-sixth District is splitting the Westchester Republican organization into three factions. The nomination is traditionally tantamount to election.

THE exhibition of engraved glass at Steuben Glass is in the grand manner. Twenty British artists of international reputation were asked to submit designs and these have been incorporated into crystal objects, resplendently decorative and more or less practical.

The scientists who attended the meeting of the National Academy of Sciences last week in Washington, D. C., saw a "solar battery" at work. With nothing but light as the source of power, a toy ferris wheel was made to turn and enough power was supplied for a telephone conversation.
St. John's leader in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference, turned back Hofstra, 5 -- 0, yesterday at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens.
A goodwill mission arranged by the World Parliament of Religions has received from the Soviet Embassy a promise of a week-long sojourn in Moscow this summer, it was learned yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, May 1 -- The California Republican State Central Committee, surveying the political situation in the state's thirty Congressional districts this week, found only one in which it would acknowledge that Republican chances were really bad.

MOBILE, Ala., May 1 -- Senator John J. Sparkman, accused of double talking during his unsuccessful Vice Presidential campaign two years ago, faces stiff opposition in Tuesday's Democratic primary. A record vote of 550,000 is expected.
An enlightened leadership for the free world was called for yesterday by Dr. Harry D. Cavallaro, chairman of the Board of Higher Education of New York City.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 1 -- Employment in Minnesota appeared to be approaching a plateau that "encouraging prospects" in the construction industry should be able to hold through the summer months, the State Employment Service reported.

MILWAUKEE, May 1 (AP) -- Granny Hamner clouted a 400-foot double to the left center field fence with two on the bases in the top of the tenth inning today to give Philadelphia a 4-3 victory over Milwaukee and a sweep of their three-game series.

There is a peculiar appropriateness in the step that eight national veterans' organizations have taken under the leadership of President Eisenhower. They have united in a Veterans' March for Korea, to bring in some 60,000 posts throughout the country in support of the American-Korean Foundation's fund that is designed to "help Koreans to help themselves."

Bernard M. Baruch will deliver tomorrow the first of a series of three lectures on major contemporary problems at City College's Baruch School of Business and Public Administration, 17 Lexingto Avenue.
