ANY angler can find interest, excitement and satisfaction through the hooking, playing and landing of a big fish. However, as there are at least a thousand small ones for every big one, anglers have faced the problem of deriving a maximum in sport from a minimum in size.

An experiment in education which may be of great significance is taking place this year on the campus of Dartmouth College and thirteen other institutions. At Dartmouth, six promising young teachers, all beginners in the profession, are starting their careers as educational interns under a grant from the Fund for the Advancement of Education, established by the Ford Foundation.
A "live" concert at 3 P.M. today at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, will be composed entirely of selections by American composers of Austrian origin.
NORFOLK, Va., May 1 -- Vice Admiral John J. Ballentine, pioneer naval aviator who made the early tests on the Norden bombsight in 1924, retired from active naval service today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 1 -- As thousands of workers contemplated plated the possibilities of a general strike next week, President Juan D. Peron declared today he would not impose any arbitrary wage decisions upon business and labor. He called such a step dictatorial.

DALLAS, Tex., May 1 -- Easter buying at department stores in this Federal Reserve District equaled or exceeded the comparable 1953 buying season and was substantially above any other year of record, the Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank reported in its monthly business summary; but total department-store sales for the three weeks preceding Easter were 4 per cent below those in comparable weeks last year, the report noted.

LABELED a "criminal genius," the author of this deeply disquieting personal story is scheduled to die on May 14 in San Quentin's gas chamber at the age of 32 for two kidnap- robberies and attempted rapes in violation of California's "Little Lindbergh" law.

On a recent trip to the capital for the Cherry Blossom Festival I visited for the first time the lovely memorial to Thomas Jefferson, placed among the flowering trees on the shore of the Tidal Basin. In standing before the monumental statue I found my eyes drawn upward to the words boldly inscribed in a band circling the inside of the dome:
A strike that began early yesterday against thirteen local bakeries -- including five of New York's largest -- appeared almost certain to run through the weekend.

Banking's "score" at this year's session of the New York Legislature shows fifteen bills enacted out of forty-four introduced. Analysis of the new legislation indicates that as in the preceding years, the enactments as a percentage of introductions declined. In 1952 the percentage was 62 per cent; in 1953, 35 per cent, and this year, 34 per cent.

CAP'N ANDY, the Cotton Blossom and Ol' Man River will be rolling into West Fifty-fifth Street on Wednesday night, carrying with them the same familiar, cherished crew and cargo but, this time, some new dreams.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UP) -- A House of Representatives Investigating subcommittee has turned up evidence of what members term the widespread coddling of G. I. athletes by the Army.
Union Square, the traditional gathering place for revolutionary groups on International Labor Day, was the scene yesterday of both left-wing and anti-Communist rallies.

WANAQUE, N. J., May 1 -- Rains of the last week have improved conditions at Northern New Jersey reservoirs but the North Jersey District Water Supply Commission reservoir here is still far below normal. Usually at this time of year the spillway has an overflow from the capacity volume of 29,500,000,000 gallons of water.

IN the early days of the century a vaudeville joke linked the Washington Senators with the Father of Our Country. It's outdated by now, of course, but it then was reasonably correct to say that Washington was first in peace, first in war and last in the American League.
MIAMI, May 1 -- The Democratic contest for the nomination for Governor provides the chief interest in Florida's primary Tuesday.

The New York division of the Woman's National Farm and Garden Association, Inc., will hold its annual luncheon Thursday at the Town Hall Club. Handicraft of consignors also will be on sale at the event. Mrs. Robert H. Woody, president of the division, will preside at the luncheon.

RANDALL JARRELL'S "Pictures From an Institution" is reviewed only today, (see page 4), and so the extent of its possible impact lies in the future. However, Kenyon Review published some sections of it a year ago and Mr. Jarrell, at least, already is feeling a certain groundswell of impact.
The Canadian Woman's Club of New York has arranged a cocktail dance for Friday evening in the Gold Room of the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. Mrs. Leonard Dalsemer is chairman of the committee for the event.

EVIDENTLY Augusta Walker regards goats with the reverence they received in Arcadia: for her purposes Arcadia becomes an idyllic village in South China in the days before the warlords came to wreck the land. Her heroes are two black goats presented to a peasant boy by a local schoolmaster.

Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, said yesterday that recent investigations of colleges and universities had demonstrated the "substantial and pervasive" loyalty of the reaching profession. The inquiries have not shown a need for censorship and restraint within American education, he added.
LUANDA, Angola, April 16 -- The Portuguese are confident that the example of Angola will prove that assimilation is the best answer to the race problem in Africa.

THOSE concerned with the welfare of musicians have been wondering what will happen to the ninety musicians of the N. B. C. Symphony. Since the disbanding notice came only on April 12, and a number of the men still have contracts with the National Broadcasting Company, it is too soon for most of them to have found new berths.

OKRA, chloroform, squid, lye, mustard plasters, scrapple, cyanide, hominy, asphalt, horsemeat, deodorants, caulking, fish balls -- along with the usual pork and beans -- will be among the 1,500 things Americans put into 35 billion cans this year. So the American Can Institute has proclaimed May 2 to 8 National Can Opener Week.
YONKERS, May 1 (AP) -- Lady Dunn, piloted by Harry Miller, won the Thornwood Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway in 2:05 1/5.

Astronomers of Yerkes Observatory have been discussing a 500-inch telescope, which would cost not less than $15,000,000 and possibly as much as $50,000,000. They have decided that the construction of such an instrument is technically feasible if instead of relying on a single mirror, many small mirrors are pieced together to obtain the total effect of one with a diameter of 500 inches.

THERE are, as we have already seen, various reasons why the United States is less of a book-reading country than many others. Chief among these, perhaps, is our greater addiction to newspapers and magazines. Most of us have only a limited amount of reading time, and we devote an inordinate amount of ours to periodicals.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 1 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said here tonight that improved law enforcement in the state would be his "principal administrative endeavor."
DETROIT, May 1 -- A seventy- year-old dream will begin to assume reality next Friday.

HAVANA, May 1 -- President Fulgencio Batista announced today the establishment of the Cuban Bank of Foreign Commerce, designed primarily to open up new markets for Cuban exports, particularly in soft currency countries.
CARACAS Venezuela April 23 -- A $40,000,000, three-year program to increase farm production was announced this week by Dr. Armando Tomayo Suarez, Minister of Agriculture.

LOUISVILLE, May 1 -- The first gray winner in the history of the Kentucky Derby flashed under the finish line, kicking dust back at sixteen other 3-yearolds, in the eightieth and richest running of the Julep Belt's big horse race today.

HANOI, May 1 -- Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries, commander of French Union troops at Dienbienphu, has protested against gloomy picture painting in the world press and particularly in the French press, about the situation confronting his garrison.

TWO rooms of the Budd Company's proposed Siesta Coach, a room-type sleeping car designed for low-tariff coach traffic, were hidden away last week in a corner of Grand Central Terminal for display to railroad officials interested in inspecting the mock-up and, perhaps, ordering a few for their lines.

AT their annual Awards Banquet last Thursday, the Mystery Writers of America bestowed Edgars under a new system, in which the final decision is made, not by MWA, but by outside committees of distinguished bookmen.

A system by which Government and business may jointly offer low-cost export credit insurance and foreign investment guarantees was urged last week by Dr. Julius Hirsch, internationally noted economist.
It takes more than engineering skill and craftsmanship to build a ship. Sometimes it takes a bit of applied psychology.
Mother will receive flowers and candy on her Day next week. She also will beam on more practical and durable gifts, like toasters, if a big promotion is successful.

The rehabilitation fund of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church-in-the-Bouwerie will be the beneficiary of the performance next Saturday night of "The Sea Gull," which is playing at the Phoenix Theatre. Mrs. Vance M. Morton heads the benefit committee of the church's women's association, of which Mrs. Arthur A. Atha is president.

GENEVA, May 1 -- Sources connected with the Communist Chinese delegation to the Geneva conference say the Vietminh will oppose the partition of Vietnam as a solution for the war in Indo-China. These sources emphasize they are not speaking with the knowledge of any specific proposals the Vietminh may make when formal conference sessions on Indo-China begin here.

Steadily increasing business has brightened the retail picture, resident buying offices report. There have been good sales on dresses, with sportswear and casual clothes particularly popular. Easter business was above expectations, and merchants are looking for excellent Mother's Day volume.

THE way of life which the machine imposes on us, replacing the rhythmical recurrences of Nature by mathematically identical "soulless" repetitions, has developed in us a horror of all recurrence and a corresponding obsession with novelty.

THE television coverage of the Senate subcommittee hearings on the Army-McCarthy dispute has stirred up a lively row in its own right. Involved are two interlocking matters: (1) The size of the audience and (2) the economics of television in relation to a public service assignment that probably is going to last for many weeks.

THIS afternoon at 4:30 the "Quem Quaeritis" miracle play will be performed at Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street. The following notes are based on the performance last Sunday at St. Bartholomew's.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Administration has. decided to move ahead on Libby Dam in northwestern Montana.

GENEVA, May 1 -- Just before they came to this famous city of negotiation the leading statesmen of the Western world, Messrs. John Foster Dulles, Anthony Eden and Georges Bidault, agreed, "It appears that the Geneva conference will test Western unity more severely than Berlin."

HANOI, May 2 (UP) -- The central defense complex of Dienbienphu includes four major centers of resistance. In the current assault, the Vietminh has penetrated Dominique on the northeast, Eliane on the southeast and Huguette on the northwest.
A Serbian Orthodox hierarch yesterday morning attributed the courage of the pioneer fathers of the United States to a deep and abiding faith in "the risen Christ."

The Yiddish Culture Chorus, under Vladimir Heifetz, gave its twenty-fourth annual concert yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Featured on the program was part of a long-forgotten oratorio, "Mount Sinai, or The Ten Commandments" by Sigismund Neukomm.

Production of men's clothing during the first quarter was about 13 per cent below that of the corresponding 1953 period, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States of America.

The local art season continues its pace as the month of May begins with some forty exhibitions scheduled to open in galleries and museums this week. Group shows and exhibitions of sculpture make up a considerable part of the events.

HOW-TO-DO-IT BOOKS, by Robert E. Kingery. 262 pp. R. R. Bowker Company, New York $4.50. Those legendary how-todo-it books, "The ABC of Midwifery," "Handy Guide to Alligator Wrestling" and "How to Make a Hydrogen Bomb in Your Own Cellar," are omitted in Mr. Kingery's revised second edition, but everything else appears to be here.
TRENTON, May 2 -- New Jersey has taken action to join New York to reduce smoke and air pollution in the metropolitan area.

PHILADELPHA, May 2 (UP) -- Elmer Valo's pinch-hit single with one out in the ninth inning drove home Bill Renna with the winning run today as the Philadelphia Athletics scored a 2-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox after dropping the first game of the double-header, 4 -- 0.
Diplomatic analysts studying the new Soviet budget are disturbed over unexplained residuals in the Kremlin figures.
The British pound sterling, historic trade money of the modern world, is back again at the old stand after years of reduced prestige caused by the war.

The New York City Opera completed its six-week spring season yesterday at the City Center. The work in the afternoon was Puccini's "Tosca." The musical comedy in the evening was "Show Boat." The hard-working Julius Rudel conducted both.

The dour Mr. Andrei Gromyko, Soviet Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, was in the news recently for wearing a dinner jacket. Harrison Salisbury, this newspaper's correspondent in Moscow, reported that Mr. Gromyko has been sporting such finery at Western diplomatic, black-tie functions in the Russian capital.

A cookbook devoted exclusively to meat, another on beer as a flavoring for food and a third on summer menus and recipes are among the most recent additions to the ever-expanding list of titles in the culinary field. They indicate that the trend to specialized cookbooks continues.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 2 -- Vietminh insurgents wrested three strong points from the French today in their third major assault in besieged Dienbienphu.

TRENTON, May 2 -- Gov. Robert H. Meyner told the people of New Jersey tonight that the state must have $82,000,000 in additional revenue and suggested a gasoline tax increase as the first step in that direction.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 -- The executive council of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., declared today that a current depression in the textile industry should be a warning to the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -The Council of State Chambers of Commerce today urged Congress to abandon President Eisenhower's proposals to broaden Social Security and suggested that the program be put on a "pay-as-you-go basis."

James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, cautioned yesterday against "another Munich" in the Far East. He voiced the hope that those charged with responsibility in the Government would not surrender to the demands of the Communists.
The Rev. Donald Harrington outlined in his sermon yesterday steps that should be taken to meet the challenge of the hydroden bomb.
GENEVA, May 2 -- The Western powers submitted to the Soviet Union today their suggested list of participants in the Indo-China phase of the Far Eastern conference.

WASHINGTON. May 2 (UP) -A House of Representatives subcommittee investigating alleged coddling of Army athletes is ready to make public the service records of ten big-name sports figures, including Willie Mays and Whitey Ford, baseball stars, and Chico Vejar, prize fighter.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Every Sunday Lindsay C. Warren works the crossword puzzle in The New York Times Magazine with a fountain pen. Each Monday he has taken it to the General Accounting Office and had it "audited."

HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 2 -Miss Susan Findlay's gray mare Torn Pages, from New York, won the green working hunter championship and the working hunter championship during the Rice Farms spring horse show today.

Rarely has the news brought into closer juxtaposition, and therefore into clearer contrast, in the past few days than two outstanding examples of the two major methods of approaching the problem of Federal taxation -- the wrong method, and the right method.
ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP) -- The Stan Musial story of Sunday, May 2, 1954:

BRESCIA, Italy, May 2 (AP) -- One French driver and two spectators were killed today as Alberto Ascari, Italy's world champion auto driver, piloted his red Lancia to victory today in Italy's 1,000-mile classic. Twelve other drivers were injured and thirteen spectators were hurt.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- Steel output last month was quite a disappointment in view of earlier expectations. Not only did significant recovery factors fail to materialize, but seasonal factors were missing at the beginning of April.

LOUISVILLE, May 2 -- Eddie Arcaro swung jauntily out of the jockey room yesterday a relatively short time after the running of the Kentucky Derby. Eddie had showered and dressed. His black hair was slicked down until it had a patent leather gleam. In his hand was a suitcase and in his eye was a twinkle.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 (UP) -- Shelley Mayfield, the young golfer from Chicopee, Mass., won the $10,000 San Francisco open golf tournament today when Dr. Cary Middlecoff blew sky high on the last two holes.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- A crowd of 60,000 watched Bill Spear of Palm Beach, Fla., drive his Italian Ferrari at an average speed of 81.85 miles an hour today to win the 200-mile President's Cup race at the Andrews Air Force base.
NEW YORK will give Brooklyn Bridge back to the populace today with $7,000,000 worth of new motor roadways and a new center promenade. For four years it has been restricted to one-way traffic.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Secretary of State Dulles has reported to the State Department that he has been unable to detect any differences of policy or attitude between the Soviet Union and Communist China at the Geneva Far Eastern conference.
MANILA, Monday, May 3 (AP) -- Japan's track team led secondplace India by 19 points today as 1,000 athletes of eighteen nations began the second full day of competition in the Asian games.
I must take umbrage at H. W. Hart's proposal to "abolish the thirdclass mailing privilege covering circulars, samples, reports, free offers, etc."

BOSTON, May 2 -- Dr. Harold C. Case, president of Boston University, said here tonight that the hydrogen bomb had become an "evangelistic instrument" and that a "new concern" about religion was arising.

In the 1952 and 1953 New York legislative sessions bills were passed inviting New Jersey to join in a cooperative study of air pollution in the New York City area. Nothing came of the 1952 bill because New Jersey failed to pass a matching measure. Governor Dewey on March 30 signed the 1953 measure, and favorable action by New Jersey's Legislature is again awaited.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -The Committee on Federal Tax Policy, a private organization, urged today a program of tax cuts across the board.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- The American Council for Judaism declared today that American officials should be "free from pressure groups" in formulating foreign policy "in the best interests of all the people of the United States and the free world."
An employer engaged in defense production does not have the right to declare a worker a security risk and suspend him without pay.

ATHENS, May 2 -- The number killed in Friday's earthquake in Thessaly was officially fixed today as thirty-one, with 160 injured, 2,166 collapsed buildings and 2,722 buildings heavily damaged and adjudged uninhabitable. About 10,000 were said to be homeless.

The six-story apartment house at 35 Clark Street, northwest corner of Hicks Street, in the Brooklyn Heights section, has been sold by Kummel Hirsch to an investing client of Riker Co., brokers in the deal. It houses thirty-two families and occupies a plot 75 by 100 feet. Milton Miller was the attorney for the sellers.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 2 -Tense deliberations at the South Asian prime ministers' conference, which ended early today, appeared to observers here to indicate a healthy independence of views among the smaller countries of the region.

ST. LOUIS, May 2 -- Stan Musial set one major league record and tied another today as he walloped five home runs in the course of a double-header. But all it got the Cardinals was an even break with the Giants in a bruising twin bill that kept 26,662 roaring fans in a dither for the better part of seven hours.

There is a way in which real independence could be granted to IndoChina now without its immediately falling out of the frying pan of French colonialism into the fire of Communist imperialism, and that is through the application in Indo-China of the process by which Libya became independent.

The distinguished American ballerina, Nora Kaye, has settled her differences with the Ballet Theatre, with which she severed her connections late in 1950, and will return to that company next season. In the intervening years she has appeared as a leading artist with the New York City Ballet Company and as featured dancer in the Bette Davis revue, "Two's Company."
WASHINGTON, May 2(UP) -The Armed Forces have decided against raising mental requirements for draftees and volunteers despite strong pressure from within the individual services.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 2 (AP) -- Dr. C. E. Moore of Harrisburg, Pa., defeated Jack Brittain Sr. of Hempstead, L. I., 2 up, today to win the Campbell Cup seniors invitation golf tournament.

Five hundred tenants of Glen Oaks Village in Bellerose, Queens, approved yesterday a resolution stipulating that they withhold 25 per cent of their rent in protest against "overcharges" by the landlord-builder.

An unusual art display opens today in Greenwich Village. Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Didisheim of 48 West Tenth Street have turned their small rear garden into a modern sculpture gallery for a free public showing from 2 to 6 P. M. every day through May 16.

It will be well if every American citizen understands the magnitude and significance of the Soviet warning that has been given to us during this past week. The intended import of that warning is simple, that the Soviet Union is capable of winning a nuclear war with the United States.
LOOKING at a television test pattern is not normally the most rewarding of pursuits, but there has just been a delightful exception.

The United States was not a party to "Munich," yet Washington came nearer learning the lesson of that tragic essay in appeasement than any of the participants. When Secretary Dulles issued his call for "united action'' to save Indo-China from falling under Communist control it was in the hope of inducing the democratic Allies to take a united stand and preventing the kind of panicky negotiations that now loom at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Stephen F. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said tonight that even if James Roosevelt was nominated as Democratic candidate for Congress in California the national party would not support him.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has purchased "The Greatest Story Ever Told," the life of Christ written by the late Fulton Oursler, under a profit-participation arrangement that eventually could bring to the author's estate payments totaling more than $2,000,000.
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates exploded for eighteen hits to rout the Chicago Cubs, 18 -- 10, in the second game of a double-header before 7,636 today, after a 5-3 loss in the opener.

" THE COURTS OF MEMORY,"* by Frank Rooney, is an excitingly well-written novel about as insufferable a family as I ever read about with a mixture of fascination and repulsion. The Griffins of Los Angeles are a sad lot. Father is a good business man when he puts his mind to it, but in his relations with his wife and children he is pompous, stupid and idiotic.
GROTON, Conn., May 2 -- Slim, silent and deadly, two new submarines now are making trial runs here before delivery to the Peruvian Navy.

PARIS, May 2 -- The soft texture of velvet against crisp summer fabrics is one of the pleasing features of Jacques Griffe's mid-season collection distinguished for finesse and delicacy and continuing his favorite theme of a mock high waistline.
Whether Mayor Wagner will press for enactment of the pending bill to extend the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services remained undecided yesterday.
LONDON, May 2 -- The United States was pictured by three Laborite members of Parliament today as an obstacle to peace in Indo-China.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 (AP) -- The seventh annual Boardwalk Mile today produced two winners.

To previous accomplishments in improving their neighborhood physically and socially the thirteen religious, educational and medical institutions that have banded together as Morningside Heights, Inc., have now added the publication of an eighty-two-page Source Book of agency and group programs that is so unusual as to deserve comment.

The heads of city departments and agencies were warned yesterday that their requests for capital funds for new projects in 1955 must be confined to "vital" public works upon which work could actually be started during the year.

Forty delegates of the New York Commandery of the Knights of St. John and 100 members of their women's auxiliary from eight cities in this state attended the solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 2 (UP) -- New tornadoes and storms swept Texas for the third straight day today and a freakish mixture of snow, rain and floods battered the Midwest.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $79,749,387,440. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
The Kings County grand jury was accused yesterday of drawing an "unfounded" conclusion in charging the shipping industry with turning a "blind eye" to waterfront thievery.

A five-story building housing twenty families at 1382 Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Estate Securities Company, operators. The apartment occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet and was bought by the seller about two years ago.

With its week-end pair of concerts, the New York Philharmonic-Symphony brought to a conclusion its 112th season. Dimitri Mitropoulos was the conductor, and Michael Rabin was the violin soloist in Glazunoff's Violin Concerto in A minor.
BERKELEY, Calif., May 2 (AP) -- University of California astronomers disclosed today they were taking a chemical inventory of the universe.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 2 -- A sharpened air watch has been ordered within the Swedish Air Force following last week's violations of Scandinavian territory by unidentified foreign planes. Another such repetition will bring up Swedish fighters with instructions to force down the intruders.
JERUSALEM, May 2 -- Premier Moshe Sharett and Finance Minister Levi Eshkol joined today in public recognition of the part that United States aid has played in the economic development of Israel.
MILAN, Italy, May 2 -- The thirty-second Milan Trade Fair that closed last week was a marked success, judged by the amount of business done.

President Eisenhower yesterday presented his five-star flag, the insignia of a General of the Army, as the first gift to the projected American wing of the National Museum of Korea. Dr. Howard A. Rusk, president of the American-Korean Foundation, conducting a campaign for $10,000,000 "to help the Korean people to help themselves," said the flag would be presented for temporary custody to President Syngman Rhee of Korea.

SPARROWS POINT, Md., May 2 -- Last year the world's leading producer of merchant ships and this year only three vessels to build, then nothing -- that is today's picture of he Bethlehem-Sparrows Point Shipyard.
Twenty thousand persons gathered yesterday on the campus of Fordham University to celebrate World Sodality Day with a recitation of the rosary and consecration to the Virgin Mary.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 2 (AP) -- The first day leaders maintained their form as George Washington won the Middle Atlantic Dinghy championship elimination regatta today on the Severn River.
GENEVA, May 2 -- Secretary of State Dulles will leave Geneva tomorrow without having been introduced, or spoken a word to Chou En-lai, Foreign Minister of Communist China.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Congress is faced today with an unusual question. It is this:

If the account executive has to learn to play the piano, he can blame a modest man named Sigmund Gottlober, president of the rapidly growing National Theatre and Concert Magazines, Inc. This company publishes programs for touring orchestras, artists and opera troupes in some three dozen cities.

" The time has come when you must make up your mind whether you want to be an artist or a dress designer." These words were spoken about ten years ago by the writer to the designer of today's American Design Patterns.

ROME, May 2 (AP) -- Fausto Gardini and Giuseppe Merlo, Italy's two top Davis Cup players, were suspended today because, an offical of the Italian Tennis Federation said, "They asked for money to compete in the Davis Cup tournament."

WIESBADEN, Germany, May 2 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly, the American and Wimbledon champion, today won the singles and mixed doubles finals, but was beaten in the doubles of the Wiesbaden international tennis tournament.

Some falling-off in the work load of the Semen's Church Institute, 25 South Street, New York 4, as shown in the 119th annual report of the Institute just published, obviously stems from the slump in the maritime industry that began in the second quarter of 1952 with the lay-up of vessels that had been carrying Marshall Plan aid to Europe.

Details of the new ownership and names for Sherman Marquette, Inc., seventeen-year-old advertising agency with more than $20,000,000 annual billings, were made public over the week-end. The changes are effective today.

In Controller J. Raymond McGovern's letter appearing in your column of April 29 he protests too much that the state is not "trying to mandate or superimpose its will on the city" in the use of certain reserve funds. This statement is at complete variance with the record.
Thirty-five hundred postal employes bearing signs and banners crowded into a school auditorium and lobby yesterday afternoon to urge salary increases for post office workers.

The Committee on Federal Tax Policy publishes today a study titled "The Tax Program." This paper is a comprehensive one, and needless to say it reflects the unvaryingly high standards of scholarship and realism that have come to be identified with the work of this eminent group.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -President Eisenhower's proposal to share United States atomic secrets with allied countries comes up for public scrutiny in Congress this week.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Monday, May 3 -- The Democratic party of President Celal Bayar took a commanding lead early today in more than fifty of Turkey's sixty-four provinces on the basis of returns from yesterday's general election.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Joseph Nye Welch, the courtly Army counsel, has evolved as one of the most colorful characters in the Army-McCarthy dispute.

It has been brought to our attention by Egyptian authorities that at a press conference held in Cairo recently there was apparently some misunderstanding of remarks made by Premier Nasser with regard to the American Point Four program in our country.

Shoppers weaving their way this week through pots and pans, sporting goods and dresses in Macy's will examine the wares to the tune of warbling vireos and rose-breasted grosbeaks. Package toting will be less irksome in an atmosphere perfumed by 2,500,000 lilacs, snapdragons, azaleas, orchids and exotic blooms.

The representatives of the Republic of Korea will, to a certain extent, play right into Communist hands at Geneva if they appear to insist that the only possible election plan for the peninsula must concern merely the 100 vacant Assembly seats that have been reserved for the North Koreans.

PARIS, May 2 -- After a recess of more than three weeks, the French National Assembly will resume its session Tuesday with its agenda overshadowed by the situation in Indo-China and by the Geneva conference.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., May 2 (UP) -- Troops from the main battle area linked up with reinforced paratroopers in an airhead ten miles behind "aggressor" lines today as heavy fighting continued in the Army's giant Exercise Flash Burn.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP) -The 170-member Wage Policy Committee of the United Steelworkers Unions, C. I. O., meets here Thursday and Friday to plan strategy for coming negotiations with the nation's steel industry.
GENEVA, May 2 -- The South Koreans will lay before the Geneva conference on Asian affairs tomorrow their formal proposal for bringing about peaceful unification of Korea.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 2 -- The technical position of the guilder no longer stands in the way of restoration of convertibility for all current account transactions, according to Dr. Marius W. Holtrop, president of The Netherlands Bank.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2 -- Rising birth rates and lowered death rates may raise the world's population from 2,500,000,000 to 4,000,000,000 in thirty years, United Nations experts have calculated.

The Big Show has its unobtrusive and unsung heroes. For instance, there is Herbert (Slats) Beeson -- a "twenty-four-hour man" for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Barley Circus. Slats never sees the magic of the three rings while the circus is on the road. He's always twenty-four hours ahead, paving the way for the show.
Considerable strength and activity in the British pound sterling highlighted an otherwise dull foreign exchange market during the past week.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The month of decision -- and the White House itself sees it this way -- has now opened for the Eisenhower legislative program.

GENEVA, May 2 -- The United States delegation to the Far Eastern conference now concedes that several months will be required to negotiate the Southeast Asia defense pact that was proposed by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles before the start of the conference.

The two-story building with basement and penthouse at 716 Fifth Avenue, near Fifty-sixth Street, has been sold by Countess Mara, Inc., to The Custom Shop for the principal store in a chain of more than twenty haberdashery shops throughout the country. The parcel is 18 by 100 feet and is assessed at $330,000.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 2 -- Sir Philip McBride, acting Minister of External Affairs, said tonight that the Soviet withholding of exit visas to the Australian Embassy staff told to get out of Moscow was a clear violation of diplomatic immunity.
Reason and calmness have adjusted the differences between the League of New York Theatres and J. J. Shubert.
The New York Shipping Association announced yesterday the establishment of a new welfare fund for longshoremen in the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The Administration is prepared to act to dispose of Government-held stocks of surplus food and fiber.

Harry Byrd is not complaining, but the side-arming right-hander of the Yankees must be wondering whatever happened to the Yankee power he used to hear about when he was pitching for the Athletics. Yesterday at the Stadium Byrd made his third start for the Bombers and suffered his third defeat, a 4-0 setback by the Tigers in a dramatic five-inning contest that was called on account of darkness.

ROME, May 2 (AP) -- Italy's Tiberio Mitri connected with just two punches tonight to stop England's Randy Turpin, former world middleweight champion, in 28 seconds of the first round of their scheduled fifteen-round bout for the European 160-pound title.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 2 -- The Government of Premier Fawzi el-Mulki fell today on the issue of foreign attempts to modify its policy toward Israel.
The West Coast which in recent months has been lagging in the ship charter market, set the pace last week as some ten cargoes of grain for Japan were transacted for shipment.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee will begin considering tomorrow whether the United States should continue aid to India in spite of India's neutralism and opposition to many United States policies.

James Patton Humphreys, Kent School's tennis coach, seemed to be walking on air. He probably could have been floored with only a light lob. That's how pleased he was when members of the touring Presbyterian College net team praised Kent's courts.

The life of Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower will be the subject of two books this year. On May 17, Scribners will issue Dorothy Brandon's "Mamie Doud Eisenhower." Then in September, Holt will publish Alden Hatch's "Red Carpet for Mamie."

LOUISVILLE, May 2 (AP) -- The owner and trainer of Kentucky Derby winner, Determine, finally saw eye to eye today on plans for the tough little gray colt, agreeing he would go to Baltimore for the Preakness May 22.

CINCINATTI, May 2 (UP) -- Excellent relief pitching by Bob Miller, who throttled a potential Redlegs rally with the bases full land none out in the fifth inning, gave the Phillies a 4-3 victory today.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Cleveland rallied with two out in the ninth inning to score the tying run, then made three runs with two out in the tenth to defeat Washington, 6 -- 3, in the second game of a double-header today. Cleveland also beat the Senators, 6 -- 4, in the opener.

Although taxes were only about a third of the total a year ago, the net income of the National Steel Corporation declined to $6,420,225 in the first quarter of 1954 from $11,084,933 realized in last year's period.

DETROIT, May 2 -- Industries that look longingly toward the South in the belief they will find lower wage rates and lower taxes there had better take a second look, industrial realty men were told last week.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Heavy long liquidation in wheat on the Board of Trade last week forced prices down to the lowest level in several weeks. May wheat was especially weak, there being but little support at times as holders unloaded in a big way owing to discouragement over the fact that the expected tight situation in cash wheat did not develop according to expectations.

Fortuna of Duesseldorf overwhelmed Borussia of Dortmund by 6 -- 0 before a crowd of 18,000 at Triborough Stadium. Randalls Island, yesterday. The meeting of the soccer visitors from Germany marked a six-hour program of games and exhibitions in the German American Football Association's annual field day.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- This is the season when the hoppers for the filing of bills and resolutions in the Senate and House of Representatives are glutted with old and beaten-up proposals demanding "immediate enactment."
The Society of the Silurians, Inc., will hold its thirtieth anniversary dinner next Monday night at the New York Athletic Club.
LONDON, May 2 (AP) -- Brazil, Austria, Egypt and Spain completed their sweep into the second round of the European zone Davis Cup tennis competition today.

TB still is a killer and has to be watched constantly. When forty-seven youngsters in Queens schools showed a positive reaction to patch tests last year, they and their families were invited to take free chest X-rays.
The theme that the nation's war dead are honored not by words alone but also by deeds ran through a memorial service held yesterday at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street.

Harry F. Guggenheim announced yesterday that this summer the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation again would give the people of New York fifty free concerts by the Goldman Band, under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman.

According to a dispatch from Havana, President Fulgencio Batista of Cuba says it is .the Government, not the employers or workers, that must decide labor relations policies. His regime plans to sweep out certain labor laws inherited from his predecessors in order to attract foreign investments.

Fortuna of Duesseldorf overwhelmed Borussia of Dortmund by 6 -- 0 before a crowd of 18,000 at Triborough Stadium. Randalls Island, yesterday. The meeting of the soccer visitors from Germany marked a six-hour program of games and exhibitions in the German American Football Association's annual field day.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- This is the season when the hoppers for the filing of bills and resolutions in the Senate and House of Representatives are glutted with old and beaten-up proposals demanding "immediate enactment."
The Society of the Silurians, Inc., will hold its thirtieth anniversary dinner next Monday night at the New York Athletic Club.

According to a dispatch from Havana, President Fulgencio Batista of Cuba says it is .the Government, not the employers or workers, that must decide labor relations policies. His regime plans to sweep out certain labor laws inherited from his predecessors in order to attract foreign investments.
The city's 240 policewomen are demanding equality with the men on the force.

BIRMINGHAM, England, May 2 -- A vast range of items, from cotter pins and frying pans to generators and scales for weights up to 200 tons, will be displayed at the British Industries Fair that opens here and in London tomorrow.

MILWAUKEE, May 2 -- Gil Hodges and Don Newcombe were added to the list of ailing and injured Dodgers today. Hodges, the Brooks' star first baseman, is not expected to play against the Braves tomorrow.

The Reid Foundation offered fellowships of $5,000 each yesterday to American newspaper men and women for study abroad in 1955. Applicants must have had five years of experience with daily newspapers or press associations in the United States.
Elimination of two traffic bottlenecks here through use of $100 worth of paint and additional signs was reported yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York.
Shipping interests here breathed easier over the week-end when they learned through private advices that the vital Panama Canal was not in any immediate danger of being blocked by a rock slide.

The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation announced yesterday the award of fellowship grants totaling more than $1,000,000. They will help 243 Americans pursue their studies in various fields of cultural endeavor.

Election of Charles W. Perelle as president, chief executive officer and director of American Bosch Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, Arma Corporation, was announced over the week-end by Joseph E. Ridder, retiring chairman.
MELTON MOWBRAY, England, April 28 -- The Conservative party in the parliamentary division of Melton is a good example of modern Toryism.
HANOI, May 2 (AP) -- Thousands of Vietminh attackers charged into savage hand-to-hand fighting with the French defenders of the fortress. The rebels stabbed deeply toward the heart of Dienbienphu.

BANGKOK, May 2 (AP) -- Undefeated Jimmy Carruthers of Australia retained his world bantamweight title tonight by outpointing Chamreon Songkitrat, Thailand police lieutenant, in a gruelling twelve - round bout fought in a driving rainstorm.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today the Senate Internal Security subcommittee had produced "no evidence" last summer to support its charge that two Soviet spy rings still were operating in the Government.
Harold E. Stassen, director of the Foreign Operations Administration, posted a "help wanted" advertisement last night at a $100-a-plate dinner at which he was a guest of honor.
The traditional sequence of "special nights" will be continued this summer at the Stadium Concerts in Lewisohn Stadium, it was announced yesterday.
Five new films, including imports from England and Israel, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Cotton futures prices moved within a narrow range last week on the New York Cotton Exchange. At the close Friday active contracts were up 10 to 80 cents a bale, or 2 to 16 points, compared with the previous week's close.

LONDON, May 2 -- For the first time since the stock markets began their rise weeks ago, international politics successfully intervened to halt the upward movement. Events in Indo-China introduced something of the old Korean pattern in the markets, with security prices declining and commodity prices rising.
SAN DIEGO, Tex., May 2 (AP) -George B. Parr, the controversial political leader of South Texas' turbulent Duval County, announced today he was a candidate for judge of the Seventy-ninth District.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- A reduction in television coverage is being considered as a means for speeding the Senate hearings into the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.

When the Guggenheim Awards are announced even the most casual observer must be struck by the scope of the projects these grants subsidize. Year after year the list reminds one, in a fashion, of a large modern university's catalogue. Again, like the faculty of a university, the names of the recipients, in range of national origin, read like a cross-section of America.
BOWIE, Md., May 3 (AP) -- Capping an afternoon of upsets here today was the $160.80-for-$2 mutuel posted by the Emerald Hill Stable's Blue Volt, two-length winner of the $6,000 Exterminator Purse.

Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Salomon Bros. Hutzler will place on the market today a new issue of $10,000,000 of Delaware Power and Light Company first mortgage and collateral trust 3 per cent bonds due on May 1, 1984.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 3 -- The last active ace of World War I has retired after taking a demotion from the rank of colonel to master sergeant in order to complete thirty years of service.

Labeled "Young Couture" because of their youthful outlook and flair for high fashion, five of top designers in this country, were represented yesterday in a summer fashions at Bonwit Teller. The designers were Mollie Parnis, Adele Simpson, Harvey Berin, Larry Aldrich and Herbert Sondheim.
James Dillon has been elected vice president of National Starch Products, Inc., and S. A. Segal replaces Mr. Dillon as secretary.

The forty-family apartment house at 145 Franklin Avenue in New Rochelle, N. Y., has been purchased by Phillip P. Zipes, operator, from a client of Paul Miller, lawyer, through William Granberg, broker.
CHICAGO, May 3 -- Long liquidation in grain and soybean futures was again the order of the I day on the Board of Trade, and rallies were hard to maintain in the absence of normal buying demand.

Ordinarily when a merchant extends credit he wants the customer to stay within easy reach. Customers are urged to leave at once for long trips by Pan American World Airways, which offers credit to help them and is running heavy newspaper advertising throughout the country to say so.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 -- Three men and a woman received prison terms today for harboring Robert Thompson, a New York Communist leader, in a mountain cabin in California last summer.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (UP) -- Former United States District Judge Simon H. Rifkind of New York said tonight Americans must decide whether the Fifth Amendment, which says a witness may not be required to give self-incriminatory evidence, "has lost all significance" or will continue as "one of the most cherished provisions of the Constitution."
GENEVA, May 3 -- Chou Enlai, Foreign Minister of Communist China, intervened unexpectedly in the Korean debate today to bring up the prisoner-of-war question.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 3 -- The Dutch Government took the initiative today in an attempt to solve the problem of Europe's "hard core" of refugees.
SEATTLE, Wash, May 3 (UP) -- Roy Ah Nee of Honolulu bowled a 705 series today to take over fourth place in the final singles standing as the 1954 American Bowling Congress tournament came to an end.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) -- Letters from Indonesia reported today that Sampih, Bali's most famous male dancer, had been murdered.
The real point and issue in the hearings of the Army vs. McCarthy seem to have been washed overboard in the storm of charges and countercharges.
In a city as big and complex as New York anything can happen. The Women's Prison Association of New York attests to this story. Nancy, a young girl, lived with her grandfather, her sole relative.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 3 -- Observers were predicting the second lightest vote in fourteen years in the Ohio primary election tomorrow with only one elector in five going to the polls.

An old ghost of the 1949-50 water shortage returned here yesterday. The city's hotels were urged to serve water with meals only when customers asked for it. Arthur C. Ford, Com missioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, passed along the water-restriction proposal to the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc.
YONKERS, May 3 (AP) -- Fred Bradbury drove Vonian Chief to a wire-to-wire victory in the Arraonk Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

Palm Tree grew to more important stature in winning the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. Competing against five other 3-year-olds, including an odds-on favorite, the Greentree Stable's colt scored decisively, and demonstrated that he is to be considered seriously for the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes.
ROME, May 3 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, and Mario Scelba, Premier of Italy, had an "ample exchange of views" on the international situation in Milan this afternoon.

Radio station WNBC has decided to discontinue its all-night program of popular music and return to the classics. Beginning Monday, its "Music Through the Night" series from 12:05 to 6 A. M. nightly will feature recorded symphonic music, with Fleetwood as the commentator.

CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) -- Four sisters, one a Roman Catholic nun, told a Congressional committee today about their bitter experiences in the Soviet Union after having been uprooted from their home in Poland.
A woman who had been described by a witness at a Senate Internal Security Committee hearing last May as a Communist was ruled off the ballot in a Yorkville parents association election last night.

The six-story apartment house accommodating fifty-nine families at 43-31 Ithaca Street in Elmhurst, Queens, has been purchased by Jacob Glass Sons from Charles and Irving Bernstein. Samuel Rothstein was attorney for the buyer and Max H. Levine acted for the sellers.
Butterfly decorations predominate in a small collection of new lamps at Lord Taylor.
A quick look at New York cured the wanderlust of two 13-year-old orphans from Tennessee yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Dr. Anthony J. Cincotta of Fulton, N. Y., who sought to block an income-tax investigation by asserting the "sacredness" of communications between physician and patient, lost out in the Supreme Court today.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 3 -- A new Jordanian Government was formed today by Premier-designate Tewfik Abul Huda. A royal decree installing the Government is expected to be published late tonight or tomorrow.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 3 -- Adrian L. Shuford Jr., president of Conover Knitting Company, Conover, N. C., was elected chairman of the board of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers at the fiftieth annual meeting at the Claridge Hotel here today. He succeeds Henry A. Lineberger of Belmont, N. C.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 3 -- Maj. Edwin Lyons of the Nassau Civil Air Patrol, whose loyalty was challenged last November, has been cleared by the Air Force and the Federal Bureau of Investigation for duty with the C. A. P., and the Nassau Civil Defense organization.

In a day of stock-taking and consolidation, only the leading rails showed consistent strength in yesterday's market. As a result, The New York Times combined average made no change whatever, but considerably more stock declined than rose.

The merry month of May has arrived, but there is little to be merry about along the Potomac. The cherry blossoms have come and gone; the blistering heat of summer is not far off. And still the legislative program has made but slight visible progress.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Representative Henderson Lanham, Democrat of Georgia, today called the McCarthy-Army hearing "the sorriest spectacle of our generation" and said it was obscuring the fact that "Indo-China and all of Southeast Asia are being lost to the free world."
LOUISVILLE, May 3 (AP) -- Determine, winner of the eightieth Kentucky Derby, will head back to California Wednesday, skipping the Preakness at Pimlico on May 22.

The sweeping election victory of President Celal Bayar's Democratic party in Turkey will cause general satisfaction in this country. President Bayar made many friends both for himself and for Turkey on his recent visit to the United States, and they will be glad that the Turkish electorate has chosen to endorse strongly the positions and policies of the President.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3 -- Van Johnson, who began to climb the ladder to screen stardom in 1942 at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, will no longer work exclusively for that studio after the completion of his current assignment in "The Last Time I Saw Paris."

A mistrial was declared yesterday in the first-degree murder trial of William Howell because of the illness of Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett. Howell is charged with complicity in the slaying last Aug. 28 of Thomas F. Lewis, Bronx labor leader.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 3 -- The first step toward modernization of the hazardous Hutchinson River and Cross County Parkways was taken today by the Westchester Board of Supervisors.

THE next two weeks should find the spring salmon fishing at its peak on the New Brunswick waters where this fishing is permitted. Reports from the Miramichi River show that the majority of the anglers fishing the Boiestown, Doaktown and Ludlow areas are taking plenty of salmon.
LONDON, May 3 -- Britain has accepted an invitation from the European Coal and Steel Community to discuss closer association with it.

Patrice Munsel, Metropolitan Opera star, who recently voiced her determination to "definitely do a Broadway musical," may appear next fall in "Reuben, Reuben," Marc Blitzstein's new musical on which he has been at work for several years.

HARTFORD, May 3 -- One of the three possibilities for the Democratic nomination for Governor will speak tomorrow night at the annual Jackson-Jefferson Day fund-raising dinner here. The two others have turned down invitations to speak.
Attorneys for Robert R. Young spent four and a half hours yesterday in proving that it costs a lot of money to conduct a proxy fight.
The producers of the "Strike It Rich" radio-television programs lost yesterday their action for a declaratory judgment that no soliciting was involved.
Mayor Wagner swore into office a new Commissioner of Hospitals yesterday and pledged his "full cooperation to see that this department is the very best in the United States."

THE ailing Yankees didn't send for the doctor. He came to them. He took his first look at the patient at the Stadium on Sunday, rolled up his sleeves and promptly went to work. The preliminary diagnosis revealed an obvious lassitude in the hitting reflexes, a disease in which Dr. Robert W. Brown has always specialized.
WASHINGTON, May 3--Senatorial efforts to speed the hearings on the Army-McCarthy controversy failed today, but new attempts were being made.
ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP) -- A new "mood-lifter" pill pulls people out of the "blues and woes," three physicians said today.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The United States has agreed to fly more French Union paratroops to Indo-China as reinforcements for Gen. Henri Eugene Navarre's expeditionary corps.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 3 -- The Arabs hinted tonight that Jordan's complaint of Israeli border violations might be withdrawn.
The cotton futures market onI the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 2 points higher to 9 points lower than on Friday. The volume of business was small.

Animal and human subjects inspire the white jade carvings now on display at China House, 125 East Sixty-fifth Street. The collection of thirty-six objects, lent by an anonymous collector to the China Institute, will be on view to the public through June 23.

MILWAUKEE, May 3 -- Roy Campanella, star catcher of the Dodgers, will undergo surgery at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn tomorrow for the removal of a bone chip from his left wrist. Campy, the National League's most valuable player and runs-batted-in leader last year, boarded a 2 o'clock plane today for New York. He intended to enter the hospital on arrival.

I do not dispute the fact as stated in your editorial of April 30, "The Stevens Testimony," that the McCarthy method, full of sound and fury, has done grave damage to the sanity and security of the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower reported to Congress today that the United States had collected $48,374,745 during 1953 on Lend-Lease debts, including an interest payment of $2,800,343 by the Soviet Union.
Walter Cartier, Greenwich Village middleweight. gained a split decision over Bobby Dykes of Miami in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena last night.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 3 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies announced the terms of reference for the royal commission on Communist espionage in Australia after meeting with the Federal Executive Council in Melbourne today.

DURBAN, South Africa, May 3 -- A new industrial conciliation bill drafted by the Malan Government to enforce race separation in trade unions has caused a clash between the Government and a powerful block of trade unions.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program announced yesterday a goal of 14,000 pints of blood to be collected this month for local use.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed generally lower yesterday in light volume. Potatoes however registered the most sales since l[arch 30. Coffee, cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, rubber, wool, hides, burlap and tin ended lower; sugar, potatoes, silk and copper moved mixed, and lead and zinc were higher.

The retirement in June of Miss Grace Spofford after nineteen years as director of the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement was announced yesterday by Miss Helen Hall, director of the settlement.

Nearly 150 baroque musical instruments, which were played during the lifetimes of Monteverdi, Lully, Handel, Bach and Rameau, will go on display tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in a special exhibition, "The Baroque Orchestra."

ST. LOUIS, May 3 -- The world is hurrying toward the insanity of war by trying to solve the problems of the atomic age with "horse and buggy methods and concepts," a meeting of psychiatrists heard here today.
The public is not sufficiently aware of the nation's grave educational problems. Dr. Samuel Miller Brownell, United States Commissioner of Education, said yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP) -- Righthander Sandy Consuegra retired the first nineteen Philadelphia batters to face him today before giving up the only two Athletic hits to Spook Jacobs.
About 150 stands operated by the Union News Company in railroad terminals between New York, Harmon, N. Y., and Stamford, Conn., and on Long Island were shut down yesterday by a strike of personnel.

NORFOLK, Va., May 3--The discharge of 200 to 300 civilian employes at the Norfolk Naval Shipyard in Portsmouth by June 30 will increase the total cutback to 1,700 since the Korean War ended. A thousand men were dismissed last August and 500 more on Feb. 19.
BOSTON, May 3 -- James M. Curley, who has been in and out of the political spotlight in Massachusetts for more than fifty years, became today a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

The east side of Fifth Avenue between Eighth Street and Ninth now looks like Nagasaki after the burst of the atom bomb. Last month the Brevoort was leveled. Now the site of the old house at No. 21 is a melancholy rubble heap and a bonfire of kindling wood.

When Robert F. Wagner was asked during the Mayoral campaign last fall if he favored water metering, at least for all multiple dwellings, he replied that "water metering should be put into use." The Water Commissioner whom he as Mayor appointed, Arthur C. Ford, declared on taking office that he was a "water-meter man."
Despite a strike that began Saturday against five major producers of wrapped white bread there was no shortage of that commodity in the city yesterday.
Members of the American Management Association agreed yesterday that the nation's economy would expand and manufacturers must invest in more efficient machinery to hold prices and costs in line.
The long, slender, pungent green onions known as scallions are coming to us now from near by. They will be here through most of the summer. Their general price is 10 cents a bunch.
