Rain and fog played a gloomy game of hide-and-seek with the New York area yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Three officials of the Department of Defense were promoted today as a result of White House observation of their abilities and records.

The National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers, sponsoring its first trade show and the first all-inclusive showing of men's sportswear, has what appears to be a "smash hit." Fall lines are being exhibited.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- A Republican-Democratic controversy developed tonight over the possibility of limiting testimony in the Army-McCarthy hearings to the two main principals -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Robert T. Stevens, the Secretary of the Army.
WASHINGTON, May 3--The House of Representatives approved today a bill authorizing the Department of the Interior to look into the possibility of a Revolutionary War monument in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Maritime Administration urged Congress today to subsidize the construction of sixty merchant ships each year to keep the ship-building industry in operation against possible future war needs.

Record sales and earnings of the Permanente Cement Company and its subsidiaries were achieved in the fiscal year ended with last January, according to the annual report yesterday of Henry J. Kaiser, president.
Primaries in five states today will select nominees to run in the off-year Congressional elections next November.
Brooklyn Bridge, which is not the oldest or shiniest or biggest of New York's treasures, but one of the best loved, was restored to full use yesterday.
TRENTON, May 3 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, suffered two admittedly serious defeats today in the Legislature.

ST. LOUIS, May 3 -- The Giants managed, after a fashion, to check Stan Musial tonight. But they made no great headway themselves with the result they dropped the final game of their series to the Cardinals, 8 to 2 before a chilled crowd of 5,480.
Thirty-two retired seamen of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., received $55 checks yesterday, the first payments under a pension arrangement reached by the union and ship operators last year.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- Forty-two per cent less steel will be allotted for military and atomic energy requirements in the quarter starting July 1 than in the current quarter, the Office of Defense Mobilization announced today.

GENEVA, May 3 -- At a meeting of the sixteen nations that fought on the United Nations side in the Korean War, it was agreed this morning that South Korean Foreign Minister Pyun Yung Tai should eliminate from his speech the concrete proposals he had drawn up for settling the Korean question.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 3 -- The Soviet Union accepted today the terms of a United Nations pact outlawing genocide as an international crime. The genocide convention bans the destruction of religious, racial, ethnical or national groups.
A gunman accompanied by a woman bound and gagged a guest in her room at the St. Moritz Hotel yesterday morning and escaped with a mink stole and jewelry valued at $8,000.

Retail shoe inventories are low and merchants are ready to buy, according to industry leaders. Good business during the two weeks preceding Easter cleared inventories and in some cases stocks are dangerously low, it was said yesterday at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America which opened on Sunday for a five-day run at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels.
SYDNEY, Australia, May 3 (AP) -- A small boy visiting the United States destroyer O'Bannon took only three minutes today to throw the warship into turmoil.
LONDON, May 3 -- Criticism in the United States of Britain's refusal to join in military action in Indo-China before the end of the Geneva conference has disturbed the Cabinet.
BOSTON, May 3 -- The giant World Glory, the queen of American-built tankers, made her first port here this afternoon after a seven-hour deep-sea trial run from near-by Quincy.
Maureen Connolly will again head the United States team that will defend the Wightman Cup against England.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 3--Turkey has been assured another four years of stable, pro-Western government by yesterday's general legislative election. The results were a landslide victory for the regime of President Celal Bayar and Premier Adnan Menderes.

Ashley Trimble Cole, chairman of the State Racing Commission, cleared up informally yesterday the status of three Republican party officials whose right to race horses at thoroughbred tracks was in doubt.

The 173d annual communication (meeting) of the Grand Lodge of Masons of the State of New York will open today at 10 A. M. at the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street. Grand Master Ward B. Arbury of Buffalo will preside at the three-day session of 3,000 Masons.

Selvage, Lee Chase, public relations and advertising, in 500 5th Ave; John E. Pearson Co, radio and television station representative, in 444 Madison Ave through Cross Brown Co; Forms Co, in 11 W 42d St -- Cushman Wakefield Inc, brokers.
GENEVA, May 3 -- Formal invitations to the Vietnamese Government and the Communist-led Vietminh to attend the Geneva conference talks on Indo-China were sent from here today.
DETROIT, May 3 (UP) -- Two Wayne University professors who did secret work for the Army and Navy refused today to say whether they were or ever had been Communists.

BONN, Germany, May 3 -- Leaders of the West German steel industry have indicated they are at the parting of the ways with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government on the question of the European Coal and Steel Community.
President Eisenhower's proposal for an international stockpile of nuclear fuel for peacetime purposes cannot solve the basic problem of atomic control, Bernard M. Baruch declared yesterday.

Revisions of the Taft-Hartley Act which substantially carry out President Eisenhower's recommendations are now being debated in the Senate. That is as it should be. It is high time that Congress faced up to a vote on issues which have been discussed again and again in committee.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 -- An overhauling of power and water resources policies of the Federal Government was recommended by witnesses today at the first of a nation-wide series of public hearings.

BOSTON, May 3 -- Ora A. Spaid, religion editor of The Louisville (Ky.) Courier Journal, was named winner here tonight of the second annual James O. Supple Memorial Award for distinguished reporting in the field of religious journalism.

The Commercial Credit Company had a consolidated net income in the first quarter of $5,608,069, equal to $1.22 a common share, against $5,482,472 or $1.20 a share for the similar period last year, it was announced yesterday.
Forty thousand children attending 193 public and parochial schools are scheduled to receive inoculations today and tomorrow in the test here of the Salk vaccine against poliomyelitis.

Morels, a rare kind of mushroom that Europeans regard as the finest of all varieties, grow wild in parts of this country. But only recently have efforts to cultivate them commercially been successful (only cultivated mushrooms can be sold in the United States).
LONDON, May 3 -- The Labor party's regular leadership took the offensive against its insurgent left-wingers and pacifists tonight with two stiff and challenging blows.
AMERICAN art as illustrating various chapters in American history is much to the foreground in current exhibitions.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington on the hearings by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee is considering the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 3 -- The "alarming" instability of rubber trade was keynoted at the eleventh session of the International Rubber Study Group opening in Colombo today.

HOBOKEN, N. J., May 3 -- Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, endorsed today legislation now pending in the Senate that would reduce taxes stockholders pay on corporate dividends.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 3 -- The South's explosive race issue will be a major factor in tomorrow's state-wide Democratic primary. One of the region's foremost political liberals and nine Negroes will bid for public offices ranging from United States Senator to county school board.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles will face the most serious criticism of his career tomorrow when he returns from the Geneva conference.

BOSTON, May 3 (AP) -- Ted Williams went through his first heavy batting practice with the Boston Red Sox today amid hints that the injured slugger may be ready to pinch hit in games with Washington this week-end.
Easter buying pushed sales last month in New York City's department stores a substantial 8 per cent ahead of those of April, 1953.

JERUSALEM, May 3 -- The Israeli Government informed the United States tonight that a recent speech by Henry A. Byroade, Assistant Secretary of State, "is liable to impose a severe strain on Israel-American friendship."

Net earnings of Motorola, Inc., in the first quarter this year were $1,644,084, or 85 cents a share, on sales of $48,006,800, Paul V. Galvin, president, reported at the annual shareholder meeting in Chicago yesterday. In the similar three-month period last year, net earnings were $3,174,208, or $1.64 a share, on sales of $64,857,867.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 3 (AP) -- Governor Dewey has spread a "thick smog" in an effort to "camouflage both his lack of constructive programs for the people and the malfeasance and corruption in his administration," Carmine G. DeSapio, Tammany leader, contended tonight.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 3 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India called today for greater international tolerance and sounded a warning against interference in the internal affairs of Asian countries.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 3 -- The Vietminh insurgents failed last night to follow up the general attack that they launched Saturday night against Dienbienphu.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Eisenhower today presented the President's Cup to William C. Spear of Southport, Conn., the winner of the national sports car race yesterday.

LONDON, May 3 -- A spurt in British Government securities cast cheerfulness over most of the stock market today. The only section moving against the buoyant trend was South African gold mining issues, which were lower all around.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 3 -- Art and nature are combined to their mutual benefit in the newest edition of the Eastern States Antiques Fair, which opened today for its usual six-day run at the Westchester County Center.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that systematic exclusion from jury service in Texas of persons of Mexican descent was discrimination within the meaning of the Fourteenth Amendment.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation said today it might buy United States planes to supplant its grounded Comet jetliners.

First joint efforts by Irish manufacturers of women's ready-to-wear apparel to promote exports to the United States were announced here yesterday. The move will be part of the Irish Dollar Export Board's continuing drive to expand sales of Irish products in the American market.

YONKERS, May 3 -- The refusal of a majority of the owners at Yonkers Raceway to submit entries for Thursday night's program placed the dispute over purses at the Westchester oval in the shadow of a strike today.
WASHINGTON, May 3--The Senate took up today the bill to revise the Taft-Hartley Act and almost at once found itself involved in heated debate.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 3 (UP)--The executive committee of the International Olympic Committee today voted to recomment to the I. O. C. Congress in Athens next week that the 1956 games definitely be held in Melbourne as planned.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- An eight-man military court deliberated for 5 hours and 22 minutes today on charges that Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson collaborated with the enemy. It then recessed until tomorrow without reaching a decision.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- To the accompaniment of lightning, thunder and a downpour, Vincent Massey, Governor General of Canada, arrived this afternoon for a three-day state visit as guest of President Eisenhower. meeting of the Senate and the House of Representatives. He will be the first Governor General of Canada to speak at such an occasion. Peals of thunder competed with a twenty-one-gun salute as the Governor General stood at attention.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 3 -- The twenty-fourth annual Festival of American Music, originated and conducted by Dr. Howard Hanson, director of the Eastman School of Music, opened tonight with a production of George Antheil's opera, "Volpone," by the Eastman School opera workshop.

LOS ANGELES, May 3 -- A man and a woman filed suit against the United States Government for $200,000 in Federal District Court today, alleging they had been injured by radiation from last spring's Nevada atomic tests.
Acquisition by the Stanley Warner Corporation of the International Latex Corporation was announced yesterday. The purchase represents Stanley Warner's first move outside the entertainment field.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Soil Conservation Service questioned today whether Federal and private loans, subsidies and other aids should be granted on cash crops in the southern Great Plains where another dust bowl threatens.
LOS ANGELES, May 3 -- A group of New York educators, probably quite unwittingly, are the centers of the latest cause celebre to rock the stormy Los Angeles public school system.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 3 -- A new chemical for reducing high blood pressure holds out promise of becoming the most efficacious agent of its kind found so far for combating this serious disorder.

Spokesmen at a public hearing before the City Council's Committee on Buildings yesterday argued for some restrictions on an Administration-sponsored bill to prohibit future conversion of apartments and homes to so- called "single-room occupancy."

A taxpayer building containing thirteen stores and the former Park motion picture theatre at 705-23 Morris Park Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Sanrene Realty Company, which took a purchase money mortgage on the Bronx property and real estate in Mount Vernon, N. Y., in payment.

I have read with surprise and regret your editorial comment of May 1 on my proposal to impose some limitation upon the de facto Presidential power to initiate foreign wars without Congressional authorization.
MANILA, Tuesday, May 4 (AP) -- Japan began clamping a headlock on the second Asian games title yesterday with a near sweep in wrestling and a record smashing performance on the track.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- When the Mundt subcommittee makes its findings in the McCarthy-Stevens controversy, and the unofficial multitude which is reading and watching the proceedings checks that verdict with its own, the conclusions are bound to pivot largely on the credibility of the witnesses.

PITTSBURGH, May 3 -- Bands of 800 United Mine Workers pickets closed the Shanksville mines of the Cambria Fuel Company and twenty-one other pits today in a drive to halt open-hope operations in the Somerset County coal field.

Joseph P. Ryan, former head of the old International Longshoremen's Association, used union bank funds to pay premiums on a life insurance policy and to supply his personal account, according to testimony and evidence yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 3--Separate Congressional committees acted today to prevent a spread of housing scandals.
Sketches of the winners of Pulitzer Prizes follow:

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The Women's Division of the Republican National Committee today tallied a total of thirty-one women, from all parties, who have announced their candidacy for the eighty-fourth Congress.

Philadelphia in the next three or four months will become the headquarters for the huge purchasing operation conducted by the New York Quartermaster Purchasing Agency. The New York agency will be relocated in the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot from whence it came in 1945.

The Pulitzer Prize for drama was awarded yesterday to "The Teahouse of the August Moon." This gives a clean sweep of the year's three top drama awards to John Patrick's light satire of the American occupation of Okinawa. The play has already won the Antoinette Perry and New York Drama Critics Circle awards.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 3 -- Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., reported today that the union had successfully withstood a secessionist movement in the last two years, but not without suffering serious damage.
LONDON, May 3 -- Maupygernon, a medieval snack so rigorous that even Charles II, a bold man, avoided it, was kept off the Parliamentary menu today.

PARIS, Tuesday, May 4 -- After a four-hour discussion with leaders of his Cabinet last night, Premier Joseph Laniel decided early today to ask the National Assembly to defer questioning on Indo-China and on the Geneva conference when it ends its recess later today.

Pink and white flowering dogwood trees and tulips in varying hues of pink provided a garden setting last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldof-Astoria for the annual spring dinner dance for the benefit of the New York Infirmary.

LANCASTER, Pa., May 3 (AP) -- The Hamilton Watch Company said today that because of large inventories resulting from a poor market since Jan. 1, all its watch making departments will be closed for one week in May and another week in June.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) -- The sterling area's gold and dollar reserves jumped by 135,000,000 during April -- the biggest month's increase in more than two years, the Treasury announced today.

Final plans were made at the American Geographical Society here yesterday to bring all available scientific "know-how" to bear in observations of a total solar eclipse next June 30. Military and scientific specialists in geodesy -- the size and shape of the earth -- shared in the task.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Negotiations are under way for several big sales of Government-held surpluses abroad, including 40,000,000 pounds of butter to Great Britain.

PARIS, May 3 -- The West German Government handed in new proposals today to the French for a settlement of the Saar problem. The proposals were given to Maurice Schumann, Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, by his West German equivalent, Prof. Walter Hallstein, during a two-hour meeting here.

Three organizations that are "helping to develop human beings better able to cope with the emotional, intellectual and social demands of our times" were cited yesterday by Lord Taylor as winner of the store's seventeenth annual awards.
Fifteen thousand handicapped and underprivileged children filled Madison Square Garden yesterday for the annual benefit performance of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.

A panel of experts viewed the probable medical picture of ten years from now with mixed reactions yesterday. They declared that polio probably would have disappeared by 1964, but that cerebral palsy probably would not, and that new virus complications might appear.

The second of several nationwide demonstrations of Vista Vision, Paramount's new wide screen method, will take place tomorrow at the Capitol Theatre in Washington. The first showing took place here last week.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- The Lehigh Navigation Coal Company, producing subsidiary of Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, announced here today .ran indefinite shutdown on all coal mining operations because of "excessive losses."

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UP) -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today to save the frigate Constellation, America's oldest fighting ship, and the steam sloop Hartford, of Civil War fame, from the scrap heap.

Weaving and bobbing of bond syndicate men in and out of downtown elevators yesterday might have looked like a game of musical chairs. Actually, it was competition in investment banking refined to the last limits of remorselessness.
Sometimes a surprising variety of talents goes into the making of a fashion designer.

Inasmuch as Pentagon personnel prepared and leaked to the press the anti-McCarthy preliminary report, which they subsequently confirmed with the formal charges which resulted in the open hearings which were instigated in behalf of the Army, the organized propaganda to discredit Senator McCarthy and destroy the effectiveness of the Senate investigating committees becomes evident.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3 (AP) Josey Barthel, Luxembourg's 1,500-meter Olympic champion, will make his only competitive appearance at Harvard Stadium on May 15 in a four-man invitation mile.

A burglary suspect was found hiding under a bed with a bullet wound in his chest early today after a police chase in Chelsea in which several shots were fired. The fugitive was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital, where it was said his condition was critical.
City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday that May 12 has been decided upon as the date of sale for issues of New York City bonds totaling $79,200,000.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Short-term borrowing costs of the Treasury continued their descent today, falling to the lowest level in more than six years and seven months.

A general open forum to discuss the problems and future of CinemaScope, the wide - screen process owned by Twentieth Century-Fox, will be held tomorrow at 10:30 A. M. at the home office of the company.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer officials confirmed yesterday a recent announcement that the company's Cinema Scope productions, heretofore offered only to theatres with stereophonic sound equipment, would be made available also to showcases using the single channel track.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy said yesterday that he was studying expansion of the department's rehabilitation program. Since Sept. 1, 1951, the project has placed in self-supporting private jobs 551 so-called "hard-core" relief clients, some of whom had been on relief as much as eight and twelve years.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 4 -- Restoration of useful vision in victims of acute and chronic diseases of the optic nerve and the retina by the administration of the hormone of the pituitary gland named corticotropin (formerly known as ACTH) was reported here today before the annual meeting of the Association of American Physicians.

LONDON, May 4 -- A prediction that two to six hydrogen bombs would be "quite adequate" to break British resistance in a third world war spurred agitation today for an international agreement to ban nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- The Alleghany Corporation, a holding company controlled by Robert R. Young and his associates, complained today against the latest reorganization proposal for the Missouri Pacific Railroad System.
More American companies are expected to participate in the Netherlands drive to expand industrial production and export trade, a Dutch official said here yesterday.

The Newport Music Club will sponsor a music festival on Aug. 20, 21 and 22 at the Rhode Island resort. The series will consist of three open-air concerts in the horseshoe area of the Newport Casino. Remus Tzincoca, who was the musical director of the club's festival last year, will also be the conductor this summer.

"STUDIO ONE" undertook on Monday evening one of its more ambitious productions of the season -- a drama on the life of Cardinal Mindszenty, the Hungarian prelate who was jailed first by the Nazis and then by the Communists.
With William Hammerstein, son of Oscar Hammerstein 2d, at the helm, the New York City Light Opera Company will be introduced at 8 o'clock tonight at the City Center.

ROME, May 4 (UP) -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas, America's two top-ranked tennis players, began their European tour today by scoring straight-set victories in first-round men's singles matches at Rome's international championships.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 4 (UP) -- Willie Hartack, who moved here from Bowie on Saturday, booted home four straight winners, including the Brookfield Farm's I Geegee, the 13-10 favorite, in the feature race at Garden State Park today.

No two persons who apply to marriage counseling services for help are alike, three speakers said yesterday at seminars of the Planned Parenthood Federation, Inc. The sessions were part of the federation's thirty-fourth annual conference at the Waldorf-Astoria and New Weston Hotels, which will continue through Friday.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art gave a preview yesterday afternoon of the 150 ancient musical instruments that will go on view next Wednesday in a summer-long exhibition, "The Baroque Orchestra."

Paced by Bob Hazzard, Riverdale Country School successfully defended its title yesterday in the fifth annual Van Cortlandt Pentagonal track and field championships at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium. The Indians tallied 61 points, with nine firsts in the thirteen-event program.
The Government instituted yesterday in Federal Court denaturalization suits against two alleged Communists and James Plumeri, described as a "garment industry racketeer."

Two leaders of the Lithuanian Government-in-Exile arrived here yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth. They will appear on Friday and Saturday in New York before a House committee investigating Communist aggression.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- How to expedite the consideration of ways to expedite the McCarthy- Army hearing became somewhat of a problem today.
Minnesota borrowed $9,800,000 in the public market yesterday to continue its farm improvement program.

The busiest person behind the scenes yesterday morning, in the Gold Room of the Savoy-Plaza, was Irene Gilbert, Tipperary-born couturier. She was tense and perhaps a bit nervous because she was about to present her first fashion show in the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 4 -- Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., asserted yesterday that the proposed Goldwater amendment to the Taft-Hartley Act amounted to tyranny and neo-fascism.

There was not much on the program at Belmont Park yesterday, and the weather was pretty bad for May. Nevertheless 17,735 fans turned out, and those who had the further hardihood to shy away from the favorites probably enjoyed themselves.
Leaders of the tugboat local of the International Longshoremen's Association have recommended that the group secede from the old dock union and join John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 4 -- French Union troops counter-attacked this morning in an attempt to recover a strong point overrun last night in a Vietminh assault against the western perimeter of besieged Dienbienphu.

ON THE jacket of Randall Jarrell's first novel, "Pictures From an Institution," are printed no less than eleven extravagant tributes from other literary intellectuals of varying degrees of fame. Such a bombardment of advance praise makes wonderfully eloquent advertising copy. It may even awe timid readers into such humility that they won't dare admit to a dissenting opinion.
JERUSALEM, May 4 -- A rash of telegrams and clandestine leaflets today indicated considerable organized antipathy to Jordan's new Government.

GENEVA, May 4 -- The Far Eastern conference recessed today for two days pending the outcome of a United States attempt to persuade President Syngman Rhee of South Korea to modify his proposal for a unified Korea.

BOSTON -- May 4 -- The Right Rev. Raymond A. Heron, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts, will retire after the election of a successor on June 29. He is 68 years old.

Affirmation that the outstanding developments in homefurnishings in 1953 were in the fields of fabrics and wall coverings was offered in a series of design awards announced here Tuesday. Of eighteen citations given by the American Institute of Decorators in their eighth annual homefurnishings design competition, twelve went to designs in those two categories.

Mrs. Bertha Singer, a grade teacher at Public School 213 in Brooklyn, who had invoked the Fifth Amendment when questioned last November before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, resigned her job last Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday.
GENEVA, May 4 -- The United States and British foreign ministers have agreed to start political-military talks on the defense of Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, May 4--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's possession of a classified Federal Bureau of Investigation report posed a new and absorbing mystery tonight for Senate investigators of his dispute with the Army.

THE gentlemen who own the seventy-five-foot, seventy-ton exhibit whale that attracted thousands to Broadway and Sixty-ninth Street a few weeks ago ran into difficulties when they decided to haul it to Coney Island last week.
Net income of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the first quarter increased to $4,812,000 from $3,501,000 in the corresponding three months last year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 4 -- Although more motorists are using the 118-mile New Jersey Turnpike, the accident rate has decreased, the Turnpike Authority reported today. Last March was the first month without a fatality since full operation of the highway began.

Three different phases of the federal housing program have successively been in the news. Although each is part of a carefully guarded legislative framework, there are bound to be disparities between the actual results and original legislative intent.
Reconstruction of the exits and approaches of the Sixty-fifth Street transverse road through Central Park to eliminate traffic bottlenecks will start today.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- Minnie Minoso hit the first grand slam home run of the American League season tonight as the Chicago White Sox gained an 8-6 victory over the Washington Senators.

NEW DELHI, India, May 4 -- The presence of large numbers of foreign Christian missionaries throughout India has become the subject of recurrent controversy and debate in Parliament. Members of Parliament from various parts of the subcontinent constantly make serious allegations of spying, harassment of the ignorant and poor and forcible conversion.
Shellric Corp. television program producers headed by Sid Caesar, floor and penthouse in 6 W 57th St -- Cross Brown Co, brokers.
Taxpayers in school districts in four New York State counties went to the polls yesterday to elect school board members, decide on budgets and special propositions for the coming year.
TOKYO, May 4 -- Japan indicated today she would propose repayment of less than one-third of the aid received from the United States during the early years of the Allied occupation.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 4 (AP) -- An injunction was issued today by Federal Judge Gunnar H. Nordbye prohibiting Cargill, Inc., of Minneapolis, one of the largest grain concerns in the world, and its chief Canadian subsidiary, the Cargill Grain Company, Ltd., of Winnipeg, from trading in oats futures from May 14 to the end of this year.

The Glenn L. Martin Company of Baltimore announced yesterday that it soon would begin delivery of a new seaplane to the Navy. It is called the P5M-2 Martin Marlin and is the largest aircraft to be use by the Navy for anti-submarine warfare.

A statement that Canada is entering an era in which advertising may be needed more and more to assist its development was made yesterday by Frederic R. Gamble, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
Two bronze sculptures by illustrious French artists were acquired recently by the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. The works are now on view in the lushly-green museum garden.

The Harvey Radio Company, Inc., supplier and distributor of electronic equipment, has purchased the four-story commercial building at 1123 Avenue of the Americas for an expansion of its present quarters at 103 and 105 West Forty-third Street.
Aided by a three-run homer in the seventh, Yale scored a 3-to-1 triumph over Columbia in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game at Baker Field yesterday.

The farm program outlined by President Eisenhower in his special message to Congress last January contained three major provisions. The first of these called for the termination of high, rigid price supports for the so-called "basic" commodities by the end of 1954.

ST. LOUIS, May 4 -- Juvenile delinquency and criminal behavior are often caused by unrecognized physical illnesses contracted in early childhood, a former chief psychiatrist at Sing Sing Prison said here today.

Roy Campanella underwent an operation for the removal of a bone chip from his left hand yesterday. Dr. Herbert Fette, who performed the surgery on the star Dodger catcher at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, termed the operation a "success."
On a Sunday afternoon in September, the day before the 1854 school year was to open, officials of the Board of Education gathered in the auditorium of a new building and dedicated Primary School 56.
ALBANY, May 4 (AP) -- Betting dropped a shade but the state's take from pari-mutuel wagering went up 11.1 per cent at Jamaica race track's opening meeting of the year.

WASHINGTON May 4 -- The Federal Court of Appeals ordered the Attorney General today to take no further steps to list the National Lawyers Guild as a subversive organization pending a full hearing by a Federal District Court.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 4 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan branded Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today "the enemy of the white man." He said Mr. Nehru had his eyes on Africa and wanted the white man out of Africa.

John Patrick's gently beguiling comedy, "The Teahouse of the August Moon," has so completely won over audiences in New York, London and Okinawa itself that it is small wonder the Pulitzer Prize jury succumbed also. The play, adapted from a novel by Vern Sneider, tells a story of American occupation, of blueprints drawn in Washington to teach democracy to an oriental village, and how the planned society goes askew and its agents go native.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Eisenhower authorized today the use of $10,000,000 from his disaster relief fund to fight wind erosion in the Southwestern dust bowl emergency.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington in the ninth day of hearings before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee is considering the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.
The Massachusetts Turnpike Authority arranged yesterday to finance construction of a 123-mile toll expressway from the outskirts of Boston to the New York State line.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Wednesday, May 5 -- Senator John J. Sparkman, the Democratic nominee for Vice President in 1952, maintained a steady lead early this morning in his bid for re-nomination in yesterday's statewide Democratic primary elections.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Administration apparently is ready to take United States agricultural representatives now overseas out of the diplomatic set and put them on the road to help sell Government-held farm surpluses.

LONDON, May 4 -- The rise in gold and dollar reserves last month and continued strength of sterling made for a confident stock market today. British Government securities again led the advance, although less vigorously than yesterday. Some buying was stimulated by hopes of an early reduction in the bank rate.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Business will be good this year and promises continued expansion in the years ahead, Lothair Teetor, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Domestic Affairs, said today.
Almost all the children who received their first shots in the Salk polio vaccine trials here last Tuesday turned up yesterday for their second inoculation.

A forty-five minute film summary titled "The Murrow-McCarthy Debate" was made available yesterday to organizations and forums by Freedom House, an educational organization devoted to the goals of a free society.

Bing Bing, Inc., and others have sold the twelve-story loft building on plot 106 by 92 feet at 37 to 47 West Twentieth Street to a manufacturer of boys' clothing. The sale was negotiated by Williams Co., brokers, and was the first involving the property in more than twenty-five years.

LONDON, May 5 -- The Press Council, guardian of ethics of the British press, censured today the editor of the national tabloid Daily Sketch for having distorted a motion picture review written for his paper.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- An Army court-martial sentenced Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson today to ten years' imprisonment at hard labor for collaboration with the enemy while a prisoner of war in Korea.
An 11 per cent rise in operating expenses, against only a one per cent gain in operating revenues, resulted in a net loss of $1,069,611 for United Airlines, Inc., in the first quarter.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 4 -- Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County who was in the third month of trial on charges of having failed to suppress gambling, went on the stand today in his own defense in Superior Court.

The delegations representing the United Nations at Geneva are wisely moving toward a compromise plan to permit the unification of Korea on the basis of free elections held throughout the country rather than in North Korea alone. The latter plan has been proposed by South Korea and endorsed, presumably for bargaining purposes, by Secretary Dulles.

BONN, Germany, May 4 -- A number of young officers have abandoned their posts in the West German Defense Commissioner's office in the belief that all hope for the creation of a European army within the proposed European Defense Community has been lost.

The Appellate Division canceled yesterday a $498,482 tax bill by the City of New York against the Bethlehem Steel Company. It also ruled that materials furnished by the company in handling contracts with the Navy and the United States Maritime Commission were exempt from city sales and use taxes.

Volunteer singers making a tour of Westchester County stopped in at Irvington House several years ago. As they finished a number before a happy-eyed group of boys and girls, one of the singers remarked to a companion:
Elements of design for surface decoration of fabrics are explained in a new exhibit by the American Craftsmen's Educational Council, opening today at America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.

HARTFORD, May 4 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey declared tonight "the country must be feeling sorry for President Eisenhower, who has shown himself unable to discipline the stampeding mavericks of his own party."
PARIS, May 4 -- Scarves that slot through the bodices of cotton or linen frocks play both functional and ornamental roles in the design of Lanvin-Castillo midsummer models.
YONKERS, May 4 (AP) -- Russ Valles Key took the lead with Power Chief at the half-mile and scored a length-and-a-quarter victory with the 7-year-old pacer in tonight's feature at Yonkers Raceway.
New issues of public utility securities valued at more than $88,000,000 were priced for public marketing by investment banking syndicates yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 4 (UP) -- Carroll E. Mealey, former head of the Alcohol Tax Unit of the United States Internal Revenue Service, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on four counts of income tax evasion.
The police began grappling in the Passaic River at Harrison, N. J., yesterday afternoon for the body of Benedetto Macri, gangster, who is believed to have been murdered last week.

ST. LOUIS, Wednesday, May 5 (UP) -- Del Ennis' sacrifice fly in the eleventh inning provided the clinching run tonight as the Philadelphia Phils outslugged the St. Louis Cardinals, 14 -- 10, in a game that lasted four hours and thirty-one minutes.
BOWIE, Md., May 4 (UP) -- Eric Nelson of Chicago moved into second place in the race for riding honors at Bowie today by booting home four winners on the eight-race program before a crowd of 7,785.

MILWAUKEE, May 4 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves teed off on a former team-mate, Max Surkont, tonight to snap a four-game losing streak with a 6-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. The game was interrupted for eleven minutes by heavy snow flurries as the 12,383 fans sang "Jingle Bells."

MINEOLA, L. I., May 4 -- Rockville Centre won the first round in Supreme Court here today in a battle to use its Municipal Park for night baseball despite the fact that home plate lies in the village of East Rockaway, where night baseball is prohibited by ordinance.

An 84-year-old doctor died in the witness chair yesterday while testifying in a civil suit in the Richmond County Supreme Court, St. George, S. I. He was Dr. Sidney O. Jacobson of the Bretton Hall Hotel, Eighty-sixth Street and Broadway, a surgeon with offices at 75 East Fifty-fifth Street.
Camp Wapanacki is a mountain-lake camp in Vermont especially designed for all of the blind children of our great city.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) Gus Zernial's eighth inning single, after Joe Demaestri singled and Spook Jacob walked, broke up a tie ball game and gave the Philadelphia Athletics a 3-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight, Bob Trice gained the triumph, his fourth against no losses this season.
Thomas J. Watson, chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, was honored by New York State Masons last night. He received the Grand Lodge Medal for Distinguished Achievement.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Vincent Massey, Governor General of Canada, told a warm and enthusiastic joint session of Congress today that it could depend on his people as faithful friends and comrades.
A steamship line official took the stand yesterday as the first witness for the defense in the grand larceny trial of Joseph P. Ryan, former head of the old International Longshoremen's Association.

Summer separates in bright colors and designs that were imaginative and amusing but never classic were shown yesterday afternoon by Russeks on its seventh floor. Ken Barr of Casino, designer of the play clothes, likes brilliant color, mushroom pleating, graduated sizes of printed polka dots, and khaki outlined boldly with black braid.

CHICAGO May 4 -- Grain and soybean futures had an erratic price course today. An overnight accumulation of selling orders resulted in initial losses in all pits. Buying resistance stiffened, however, and these were important recoveries, indicating fairly substantial absorption on resting orders.

TRENTON, May 4 -- Bishop Wallace J. Gardner of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey declared here tonight that gambling in any form as a means to raise funds for the support of church activities is a "most dangerous practice."
MANILA, Wednesday, May 5 (AP) -- Japan's athletes, led by a young woman sprinter, swept so far out in front in the second Asian Games yesterday that rivals despaired of overhauling them.

The two-story business building at the southeast corner of Jamaica Avenue and Sutphin Boulevard in Jamaica, Queens, has been resold by I. Jerome Riker to Bertelle Gardens, Inc. Held at $500,000, the property was sold subject to mortgages of $375,000.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. will announce soon the establishment of a Division of Internal Security in the Department of Justice.
GUATEMALA, May 4 -- It was acknowledged officially today that a clandestine radio station was broadcasting anti-Communist material and exhorting the country to revolution.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed somewhat irregular yesterday, 2 points up to 8 points off on active months, with a moderate volume of business.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Representative William E. Hess, Republican of Ohio, chairman of a House Armed Services subcommittee, today listed ten new names, including Ollie Matson, former All-America football player, as figures in an investigation of alleged "coddling" of athletes in the Army.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP)--I 'the states paid out a record] $552,950,329 in unemployment in-] suranee benefits in the first three] months of this year to an aver-I age weekly number of 1.807,000/ Jobless, the Labor Department l aid today.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Ray H. Jenkins said today he was not even thinking "at this time" about becoming a Republican candidate for the Senate.
David Wayne received here yesterday an acre of land, a ham, an inscribed platter and warm praise for the authenticity of his oriental characterization in "The Teahouse of the August Moon."

GENEVA, May 4 -- The United States delegation was surprised to learn from reporters today that Communist China had succeeded, after all, in issuing an invitation to the Vietminh for the Indo-China phase of the Far Eastern conference. However, there does not seem to be much that the delegation can do about it.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A proposed states' rights amendment to the Taft-Hartley Labor Law is almost certain to be changed to safeguard employe rights now contained in the Federal law.

Charles George (Chinese) Gordon, who, with his garrison was massacred at Khartoum in the Egyptian Sudan in 1885, is the subject of a biography by Lawrence and Elisabeth Hanson. They explain that Gordon has been described as "a great soldier and Christian hero," as well as "a religious fanatic and unquenchable egotist who recklessly disregarded authority."

Futures prices closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, zinc and wool eased; sugar, potatoes, rubber, silk, copper and lead were mixed, and burlap and tin ended higher.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- Kid Gavilan will defend his welterweight boxing championship against Johnny Saxton in late June or early July in Philadelphia under a contract that does not assure him a return bout should he lose.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- John Foster Dulles returned tonight for consultations with the President and Congressional leaders over the military and diplomatic crisis in Asia.

Well-known women of society, headed by Mrs. Jarvis Cromwell, chairman, and Mrs. Madison H. Lewis, vice chairman, are active in the arrangements for the entertainment known as the "Gay Thirties" dinner dance. The fete will be held tonight in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York.
CONCORD, N. H., May 4 (UP) -- Gov. Hugh Gregg of New Hampshire today urged President Eisenhower to change the "degenerating nature" of the McCarthy-Army hearings.

In a market full of jagged changes, stocks yesterday pushed to the best closing levels since September, 1930. Rails were especially strong and made a high since May, 1953. The industrials, at their high of 342.95, were at their best since April 30, 1930.
GENEVA, May 4 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from speeches today by Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, and Joseph M. A. H. Luns, Netherlands Co-Foreign Minister:

Four apartment houses in the Bronx have been sold by William Eggers and others to the 2247 Webster Avenue Corporation. They are 507 East 179th Street; 813 Elton Avenue; 428 East 159th Street and 379 East l56th Street. Each one contains about twenty-five apartments.

Good-by, old hat. They say that, come about May 15, they'll put you away carefully until fall, but don't believe a word of it. You've been a good and faithful friend lo, these several years, in all kinds of weather.
The fragrance of fine cooking again drifts through Bloomingdale's Au Gourmet kitchen, where culinary demonstrations by professional and amateur chefs have resumed after a lapse of six months.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches, with more than six hundred contestants braving the cold and wet grounds, opened yesterday with two district champions starting out well. The third district, Long Island, once again got off to a slow start.

ALBANY, May 4 -- Governor Dewey's program to keep horseracing and government in separate stalls has scratched a $7,000 a-year state publicity writer from a bid for glory in the sport of kings -- in New York, anyway.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 4 -- Col. Gen. Koca Popovic, State Secretary for Foreign Affairs, explained today why Yugoslavia was interested ultimately in joining the European Defense Community.
The Senate investigation of counter-charges about Fort Monmouth, N. J., ran into a good deal of confusion and misunderstanding in Washington yesterday.
A strike that had closed 150 newsstands of the Union News Company in railroad terminals in the metropolitan area since mid-afternoon Monday was ended yesterday, and the stands reopened for business.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 4 -- The United States accused the Foreign Ministry of Communist China today of directing a campaign to spread drug addiction in the Western world.
William White, president of the New York Central Railroad, spent another three hours yesterday undergoing direct examination by attorneys for Robert R. Young.

A Coast Guard helicopter reluctantly gave up a mercy mission yesterday evening when the object of its hovering solicitude flatly refused to be flown ashore after undergoing a series of untoward air-sea experiences.
A New Jersey bakery workers union local last night settled its contract dispute with five big Newark area baking plants by accepting an 8 3/4-cent-an-hour wage increase.

LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- Lloyd's Register of shipping reported today that forty-four vessels totaling 45,847 tons were lost in the period from July 1 to Sept. 30, 1953. The largest loser was the United States, which had to write off eight ships totaling 18,353 tons.

Many people walking around without jobs now would be in the employ of the electronics industry if certain "roadblocks" were removed, Benjamin Abrams said yesterday. He is president of Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, a leading radio and television set manufacturer.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The nation's insured commercial banks had their first billion-dollar-profit year in 1953, H. E. Cook, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today.

Local maritime trade groups have urged all members of the House of Representatives to vote against passage of the controversial St. Lawrence Seaway legislation, which is scheduled to come to a vote on the House floor today or tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Navy agreed today to grant a new hearing in the case of Abraham Chasanow, an employe of the Hydrographic Office who was dismissed last April 7 as a security risk.

HAVANA, May 4 -- The Government repealed the drastic Public Order Law today and appealed to exiles to return to Cuba. The action was taken in an effort to persuade opposition parties to participate in the general elections next November.
CHICAGO, May 4 -- Pasteurization of meat through exposure to gamma rays emitted by atomic fission products was reported today to have been accomplished on a laboratory scale.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Following is the text of an address by Vincent Massey, Governor General of Canada, before a joint session of the Senate and the House of Representatives today:

Net earnings of the Sinclair Oil Corporation and subsidiaries for the first quarter amounted to $19,738,586, or $1.60 a share, P. C. Spencer, president, reported yesterday. This was 18.4 per cent above the results of the similar period last year, when earnings were $16,667,502, or $1.36 a share.
JERSEY CITY, May 4 -- Hudson County, known for many years as the heart of New Jersey's bingo belt, suffers today from illegal competition in New York.

Secretary Dulles' return to Washington after only a week at Geneva has been interpreted as a tactical withdrawal from the diplomatic arena while the alternative to his policy is tried out. Having failed to get British support for the American proposal of "united action" to halt Communist aggression in Indo-China, his absence has the effect of leaving the field open to those who are determined to see what can be accomplished by negotiation.
The main issues in the Army-McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

Garden State Plaza Corporation has been incorporated to operate and assume the ownership of the shopping center that will be located at the junction of Routes 4 and 17 in Bergen County, N. J., it was announced yesterday. It will be a subsidiary of R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

PHILIP BARRY'S "Here Come the Clowns" of 1938 is having a second chance at the Cherry Lane Theatre, where it opened last evening. Put this down as an excellent idea. For the actors appreciate both the nature and the earnestness of Mr. Barry's inquiry into the causes of human suffering.

Because of recent improvement in demand for its metal, the Kennecott Copper Corporation, the largest domestic copper producer, is going back to a six-day work week at all four of its domestic mines beginning on May 16.

Representatives of the Standardbred Owners Association and the Yonkers Trotting Association met at the office of George P. Monaghan, State Harness Racing Commissioner, at 135 Broadway yesterday in an attempt to settle the dispute over purses at the Westchester track.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 4 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies, in his first speech of the campaign for the May 29 general elections for a new House of Representatives, said the Government wished to be judged not on new promises but on past promises faithfully fulfilled.
With a goal of 14,000 pints of blood to be collected by the end of this month, the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program reported yesterday that 303 pints were received on Monday.

Special agents of the Treasury Department investigating Frank Costello's finances since 1952 failed to find any "specific source" of income that was not reflected in the gambler's tax returns for the years 1946 through 1949.

The recent furor among top Republican leaders about India's refusal to allow United States planes and French troops to fly over that country is disheartening. The United States has had a history of neutrality itself, and should respect the importance of the part of neutral countries in these precarious times.

CAIRO, Wednesday, May 5 -- Egypt's military regime has disposed of two of its most outspoken press critics by sentencing the owner and publisher of the Cairo daily Al Misri to ten and fifteen years in prison and confiscating from them assets worth more than $1,000,000.
The man who a decade ago guessed correctly that the Forties along Fifth Avenue would be succeessful as a retail center for men's wear is making the same guess now about the Fifties.
MADRID, May 4 -- The Spanish Government has issued strict orders to prevent popular manifestations of protest against Queen Elizabeth II during her visit to Gibraltar May 10.

The City Council received yesterday from the Board of Estimate the record $1,639,438,325 budget for 1954-55. It also doomed the old-fashioned rooming house and approved the use of civilian guards for school crossings.
A clean sweep of an East Harlem block was made last night by fifty residents of 109th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues.
The consumer is continuing to buy merchandise to satisfy his desire for leisurely living.
A mother of two, who also is a foster parent of three, was named "Foster Mother of 1954" yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 4 -- The United Nations Security Council voted today to permit full debate on the entire situation along the Israeli-Jordanian borders.
The Radio Corporation of America, the country's largest electronics producer, achieved record sales and profits in the first quarter of this year.

There is much tragic irony in the news that the Soviet Union has ratified the United Nations pact outlawing genocide. If Al Capone had joined the Anti-Saloon League we might have a domestic parallel for this action, though even Capone's crimes pale into insignificance beside the Soviet record.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- A one-year extension of corporation tax rates in effect before April 1 was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee. The committee started voting today on the Administration's omnibus tax reform bill.
Unions and their leaders can be persuaded of the desirability of new, more efficient machines, even though they cut down on labor, an industrialist asserted yesterday.
PARIS, May 4 -- The foreign ministers of the six countries in the proposed European Defense Community agreed today that the community's assembly should be elected by universal suffrage.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- The United States has formally condemned the "frightful massacre" of more than 100 train passengers in Indo-China as another example of "Communist depravity."
All America is aware of the dangers facing the world as a result of the invention of the H-bomb.

SINCE Tuesday evenings have come to belong to Dorothy Raedler's American Savoyards, the Gilbert and Sullivan votaries reported as usual last night to the President Theatre. There the stalwart members of "The Yeomen of the Guard" assumed their dignified posts and appeared to have complete control of the situation.

Charges that the city was defrauded of $74,232 in the construction of the faulty Laurelton sewer in 1951 and 1952 were outlined in Queens County Court yesterday. The prosecution opened its case against Victor Clemente and seven others responsible for the drainage project.

The riverside gardens around Gracie Mansion drew several hundred visitors yesterday. Making a tour arranged by the City Gardens Club, they also remained to inspect the main living rooms of the Mayor's official residence.
The Jarka Corporation, largest stevedoring company in the world, is being taken over by the International Terminal Operating Company, Inc., a recently organized concern.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (UP) -- Mrs. Elizabeth S. Carpenter, half of the news correspondents' team of "Les" and "Liz" Carpenter, was nominated without opposition tonight to be president of the Women's National Press Club for the coming year.

Ray H. Jenkins has been carrying out his job as counsel for the committee in the McCarthy hearings with great diligence and almost inexhaustible patience. He is in an unenviable position; and we would say that he has conducted the interrogation with a genuine, and on the whole successful, attempt to be impartial.

PARIS, May 4 -- Premier Joseph Laniel was obliged to ask for a vote of confidence tonight to prevent a full-dress debate on Indo-China during the negotiations at the Geneva confer ence. The vote will be taken Thursday after the National Assembly has had a day to reflect on the consequences in the event that the Cabinet should be overturned.
MOSCOW, May 4 (Reuters) -- Pakistan rejected today a Soviet protest that had stated that acceptance of United States military aid meant that the Pakistani Army would be placed under foreign command.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Termination of subsidies to the aviation transport industry in an orderly manner and the merging or trunk lines into fewer systems was advocated in a report submitted to the White House by the Air Coordinating Committee.
MR. JAMES JOSEPH DYKES, manager of the Baltimore Orioles, and Mr. Clarence Miles, president of the ball club, were ambushed at breakfast yesterday.

LONDON, May 4 -- Herbert Morrison, deputy leader of the Labor party, widened the split tonight between the party's regular leadership and its left wing with a sharp, contemptuous attack on Aneurin Bevan.
The rate of teen-age crimes in the borough of Manhattan is more than three times that of the average for all cities in the nation, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Highway expenditures excel any national public service outlay except that of defense, Clem D. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today. However, he declared, the country is thousands of miles behind road requirements.
A group of squash racquets and lawn tennis players from Yale and Princeton met yesterday in the first intercollegiate court tennis match to be held in this country.
An unusual developement for a crowded week in the waning art season is the coincidence of five sculpture shows and several other exhibitions that include sculpture.
ANOTHER week should find the early weakfish schools moving into Peconic Bay, along with the porgies and, undoubtedly, enough sea robins and blowfish to provide the nuisance factor.

The possibility that the Russians might be able to fire into the skies an artificial satellite of the earth that would appear as a "red star" symbolic of Soviet superiority in the upper atmosphere, was presented here yesterday.
An amateur uranium prospector, who claims mineral rights under most of Camp Smith near Peekskill, won limited permission yesterday to drill for ore in one corner of the reservation.

The Army is ready to start construction on forty "Nike" guided missile anti-aircraft installations for the protection of fourteen critical defense areas in this country, The Engineering News-Record reveals in its May 6 issue.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- The life story of Jean Harlow, Hollywood's original platinum blond bombshell, will be dramatized in a motion picture to be made by Samuel Bischoff, independent producer.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 4 -- All eleven Indiana members of the House of Representatives tonight appeared certain of renomination. Four Republicans and one Democrat whose renominations were contested appeared to have handily defeated their primary opposition.
The five-story apartment house at 642 East Fifth Street has been purchased by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, from Michael and David Zwerling in a deal negotiated by Mylton L. Meltzer, broker.

A dentist who takes his work home with him and is never far from his portable dentist's drill will exhibit his guaranteed painless form of dentistry to disbelievers at the Eighth Annual Hobby Show for Older Persons.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 5 -Senator John J. Sparkman, nominee for Vice President in 1952, was renominated to a full six-year term on the basis of nearly completed returns in yesterday's state-wide Democratic primary election.

Like the all but vanished "matched sets" that rigidly held the stage of home or apartment living room, the all-period decor is succumbing to the new informality in decoration, the "casual" period, as it was called yesterday.
Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, said here yesterday that Mr. Byroade's speech "may have gravely prejudiced efforts to rescue Jews from troubled areas."

Coffee prices opened steady to firm on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday, but fell the 2-cents-a-pound limit from the highs of the day in several positions. Short covering lifted the market from the lows at the close.
A Congressional subcommittee ended yesterday two months of hearings on the value of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, at Kings Point, L. I., to the nation.

In his State of the Union message last January President Eisenhower told the Congress that both the United States and Canada "now need the St. Lawrence Seaway for security as well as for economic reasons." He explicitly urged prompt approval of our participation in its construction.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- Red Skelton will undertake to portray the late W. C. Fields on the screen in a picture to be made this summer under the title of "The W. C. Fields Story." Frank Borzage will direct from a screen play to be written by Gene Fowler, a close friend of both Mr. Fields and Mr. Skelton.
SEVERAL weeks ago when "Show Boat" was introduced as part of the New York City Opera Company's spring program an esteemed colleague of this newspaper's music department greeted it with delight.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- It is unusual for a Senator to give sworn testimony in a Senate investigation, as Senator Joseph R. McCarthy did this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Eisenhower said today that Secretary of State Dulles had his unqualified support in the Administration's efforts to create a security arrangement for Southeast Asia.

The defense of Victor Clemente, contractor of the much-criticized Laurelton sewer, and that of the inspector who supervised the construction will differ widely, it became apparent yesterday at their trial in Queens County Court.

CLORINDA, Argentina, May 5 -- Paraguayan Army forces revolted today against the Government of President Federico Chaves. They were reported tonight to be in control of several districts of Asuncion, the Paraguayan capital.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Investigation into alleged "coddling" by the Army of big-name athletes in uniform was started by a House of Representatives Armed Services subcommittee today, but cautiously.
YONKERS, May 5 (AP) -- A spokesman for Yonkers Raceway said tonight "there will be no racing at Yonkers tomorrow unless less there are a bunch of last-day entries."
CAMDEN, N. J., May 5 (AP) -- Sidney Jacobs' Right Down won the $15,000 added William Penn Stakes at Garden State Park today. The victor earned $12,825 for the run of five furlongs in 0:59 2-5.

Officers and directors of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club will give a reception this afternoon in the clubhouse of the organization, 283 Lexington Avenue. Mrs. Francis Rogers, vice president of the club and its founder and a former president, heads the reception committee.

Faculty wives were singled out by Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, here last night as a type of "disturbing influence" in a college community that can impede the entire learning process.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- Delegates to the 170th annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania were on record today with a protest against several publications of the National Council of Churches.

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -- Holly Mims of Washington, outboxed and outpunched George Johnson tonight, snapping the seventeen-victory streak of the 23-year-old Trenton (N. J.) middleweight with a knockout in the ninth round.

I am seriously disturbed by the article written by Peter D. Whitney, from London, and published in The Times of April 18. I fear that Oliver Lyttelton and the British Government approached the problem of group relationships in Kenya with a predetermination to avoid a realistic appraisal.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union left for home today.

It was a warm and eloquent speech that the Governor General of Canada, Vincent Massey, delivered before the joint session of Congress in Washington on Tuesday. One hundred and sixty years ago, he reminded us, the first formal treaty between the United States and Canada sought to "promote a disposition favorable to friendship and good neighborhood."

Directors of the General Foods Corporation increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock by 10 cents yesterday and increased the board from sixteen to twenty members with the election of four directors, all vice presidents of the company.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 5 (AP) -Edward Lamb, newspaper publisher, broadcaster and manufacturer, today issued a challenge, backed up with an offer of $10,000, to anyone who would disprove his non-Communist affidavits.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 5 (UP) -- The Government today voided the credentials of the Guatemalan consuls general in Puerto Cortes and San Pedro Sula. It accused them of spreading doctrines and practices aimed at the overthrow of the country's democratic government and to disturb public order.

DALLAS, Tex., May 5 -- Last week's windstorm damage to State Fair Auditorium, which was estimated at more than $200,000, will have no effect on the Metropolitan Opera Company's annual three-day appearance here beginning Saturday, officials said today.

Two employes of the Food Fair store at Forty-first Street and Ninth Avenue, in the Port Authority Bus Terminal building, were held up near the terminal last night by three young men who escaped with $7,900 in store receipts.

JERUSALEM, May 1 -- A Socialist Labor party representative in Israel's Parliament is on trial for his political life because he lives in a five-room house. The prevailing opinion in his party, Mapai, which is the nation's dominant political group, is that he is living on too grand a scale.
ALBANY, May 5 (AP) -- The number of patients in the state's mental hospitals, doubled in the last twenty years, goes on climbing at the rate of 3,000 a year.

KFAR VITKIN, Israel, May 5 -- Mrs. Golda Myerson, Minister of Labor, yesterday told an audience of Israeli and American members of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization, that her country wanted peace, but would not buy it at the cost of the life of a single Jewish person who wanted to imigrate here.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -The president of the New Jersey Bankers Association declared today that the present readjustment was "normal" for the economy. Assumption that it "presages a calamity" is unwarranted, John P. Poe said.
PARIS, May 5 -- Resistance and veterans' organizations of two World Wars will attend a silent demonstrations to be conducted Sunday at the Arc de Triomphe by Gen. Charles de Gaulle.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 5 -- Patrick B. McGinnis, newly elected president of the New Haven Railroad, said today he expected to complete "trial" reorganization of the management within a week. Then, he said, he will begin at once a survey of through-line, commuter and branch line passenger potential throughout the territory.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, May 5 (AP) -- An attack on racial discrimination was made at the convention session today of the United Packinghouse Workers, C. I. O.

A decline last week of 975,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 177,058,000 barrels, compared with 178,033,000 a week earlier and 156,391,000 a year ago.

School district elections in Nassau County and Westchester were ended last night in the second successive day of public polling in the two counties. School board members were elected, and taxpayer decisions were cast on budgets and special outlays.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission today discussed plans for a "more vigorous enforcement" of its regulations with its nine regional directors, here for a one-week briefing.

TORONTO, May 5 (UP) -- Carrol M. Shanks, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, today scored talk of a recession and predicted that business activity in Canada and the United States would top 1958's record level.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 5 (UP) -- Antonio Cerda of Argentina shot a second-round 72 for a total of 138 and retained his three-stroke lead today in the ninety-hole Dunlop 2,000 guineas golf tournament.
The standardization of a new Army rifle capable of fully automatic fire appears to be far in the future, judging by reports from Washington.
The Third Street Music School Settlement presented its annual spring concert at Town Hall last evening.
In commemoration of National Can Opener Week, May 2 to 8, The Times Magazine ran a little one-column piece about this almost-indispensable tool and the containers it is intended to violate.

ALBANY, May 5 (AP) -- The State Thruway Authority today received high bids from the Sinclair Refining Company and the Esso Standard Oil Company for leases on the last two of the twenty-seven gasoline stations planned for the cross-state expressway.

Community efforts on behalf of mentally retarded children -- and the need for more such efforts -- were stressed last night by Miss Vincentz Cianci, supervisor of home training of the New Jersey Department of Institutions and Agencies. Miss Gianci spoke at a meeting of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, held at the Mabel Dean Bacon Vocational High School, 129 East Twenty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A rapid increase in highway construction was forecast today by Albert Bradley, chairman of the National Highway Users Conference.
PARIS, May 5 -- Satin-finished cotton prints in luscious floral designs, trimmed in plain silk taffeta or velvet, are offered by Maggy Rouff for formal summer afternoon wear.

GENEVA, May 5 (AP) -- Mahmoud Abul Fath, an Egyptian publisher, said today that the suppression of his Cairo newspaper Al Misri "reveals to the outside world the totalitarian concepts and methods of the present Egyptian regime."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy testified under oath today that a still highly classified document from J. Edgar Hoover had been handed him last spring in altered and condensed form, by an Army Intelligence officer whom he refused to name.

New issues of public utility bonds totaling $60,000,000 will be offered today by underwriting syndicates. Money raised will be used for the most part to finance construction and to pay off bank loans incurred in temporary financing of plant expansion.
The managements guarantee that there'll be eight winners a day at the New York tracks. There were nine at Belmont Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said today he had not found a suitable plan for disposing of 360 million pounds of surplus Government-owned butter. He asked Congress for help.

Joseph Rumshinsky, who has provided hundreds of scores for the Yiddish theatre, and Julie Berns, radio and stage writer, have combined their talents to write a play with music called "The Young Again."

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Russ Meyer, the pitcher who doesn't like cold weather, ignored a temperature in the low 40's today and shut out the Cubs on six scattered singles. That performance gave the Dodgers a 7-0 victory.

The pink shirt, along with he-I lio, canary and others with names such as TV blue, blue coal, charcoal brown, ember red and I charcoal grey, win be heavily promoted in a national advertisLug drive planned for fall selling by the dVfanhattan Shirt Com[nany.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 5 -- The Republican party was busy examining its scars today after the bitterest primary fight it had gone through in years.
A thirty-year, on-again-off-again campaign to persuade the city to become the landlord of a historic but neglected soldiers' cemetery in the Bronx is coming to an end.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- Hogs declined again today but demand was a little more active than in yesterday's slow session. Department of Agriculture reports of today's livestock trading:

ROME, May 5 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, United States champion, swept into the third round of Italy's international tennis tournament today, but his Davis Cup team-mate, Vic Seixas, was having trouble when rain stopped play.
PITTSBURGH, May 5 (AP) -- Dr. Rollin D. Hotchkiss, an associate member of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, was honored tonight by the Society of American Bacteriologists.

Mayor Wagner pledged the support of his administration yesterday to the alleviation of problems involving juvenile delinquency. He gave the pledge as he accepted a gold medal from the Florence Crittenton League for distinguished service in this field.
THE early arrival of several species of salt water migrants, including blackfish, porgies, fluke and bluefish, is causing some angling prophets to forecast an active and productive season.
MANILA, Thursday, May 6 (AP) -- Japan scored overwhelming victories in the Asian Games track and field events, which ended yesterday, and its swimmers began a clean-up in their division last night.

Six hundred Hunter College students will participate in the thirty-eighth annual "Sing" competition at 1:30 P. M. tomorrow in the assembly hall at 695 Park Avenue. Choruses from the four classes will compete for a silver baton presented annually by the class of 1918.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that the United States had lost self-respect at home and prestige abroad as a result of the public airing of the McCarthy-Army dispute. He expressed the hope that in resolving the quarrel the nation might gain advantages to compensate for this loss.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 5 (AP) -Vietminh troops dug new trenches and foxholes today within forty yards of Dienbienphu's dwindling barricades.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to act on the Pennsylvania Railroad's petition for immediate increases in commutation fares on the Long Island Rail Road.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Wheat futures today showed the most strength they have had in some time. Long liquidated pressure was a minor consideration and there appeared to be straight commission buying, which kept short sellers on the defensive.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- While Senator Joseph R. McCarthy waived his "Senatorial immunity" on taking the stand today, he automatically acquired the same sort of immunity from any libel or slander action by becoming a witness in a Congressional hearing.

Fordham University announced yesterday that Andrew B. Shea, president of Pan American-Grace Airways, Inc. Panagra), had accepted the chairmanship of a new fund-raising group to be known as the Fordham Council.

PARIS, May 5 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin of France, who was publicly rebuked by the North Atlantic Council a month ago for speaking against the European army treaty, will retain his post as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's commander of the central European area.

LONDON, May 5 (AP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., was carried to three sets today by Angela Buxton of England in the fourth round of the Shirley Park tennis tournament before winning, 5 -- 7, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

After early gains yesterday, stocks lost strength and declined until the close. The rails managed to break even on the day, but aircrafts, electrical equipments, chemicals and several other large groups ended with losses.

A number of special events will be highlights of the 113th season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, beginning Oct. 7, 1954, and ending April 17, 1955. This became known yesterday when the society released its prospectus for the coming musical year.

In an effort to strengthen free world unity President Eisenhower at his press conference yesterday gave unqualified backing to the plan for a collective security arrangement for Southeast Asia proposed by Secretary Dulles and in effect appealed for the support of all free nations, East and West.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 5 (AP) -- Pham Cong Tac, Pope of Indo-China's Cao Dai religious sect, appealed today to Ho Chi Minh, Vietminh leader, for a reconciliation between Indo-Chinese nationalists and Communists.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., May 5 -- John H. von Hartz of 29 Washington Square, New York City, has been named co-chairman of the Middlebury College Conference for next year.

Radio Station WNEW withdrew its application yesterday to operate a television station here on Channel 31. The only remaining application before the Federal Communications Commission for the ultra-high-frequency channel is that of WNYC, the city-owned radio station.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -Bob Porterfield threw a four-hit shutout at the league-leading Chicago White Sox tonight as the Washington Senators broke a six-game losing streak by winning, 1 -- 0. The lone run was scored when Bob Keegan walked Roy Sievers with the bases filled in the eighth.
