BOWIE, Md., May 5 (AP) -- Track stewards today took away the first-place purse won by Will See in the $10,000 added Kindergarten Stakes at Bowie last Saturday. They said the horse, who set a new track record, showed evidence of having been stimulated.
The season for the annual pastime of poking around in other people's houses will be opened on Saturday by the first of this spring's local "Modern House Tours."
Plans for a third international year of cooperation among scientists of many specialties studying the earth were discussed here yesterday by Prof. Sydney Chapman of Queen's College, Oxford.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The trustees of the National Geographic Society today elected Dr. John Oliver La Gorce as president of the society and editor of the National Geographic Magazine.

The Maritime Administration announced yesterday that it was trying to sell a ferryboat, had received bids for the sale of eight ships sunk offshore and had lent its maritime training station in Florida to the city of St. Petersburg.

GENEVA, May 5 -- The United States and Britain completed plans today to hold military talks on the means of guaranteeing any Indo - China settlement reached at the Geneva conference. France, Australia and New Zealand also will participate in the discussions, which are expected to start at Singapore later this month.

As one-time chairman of the Central Group of the International Materials Conference, which was set up at the beginning of 1951 in Washington to deal with the international allocation of raw materials in scarce supply during the Korean crisis, I should like to pay a tribute to Charles W. Jeffers, whose work in other fields was praised in W. W. Rostow's letter in your issue of April 24.

The May Department Stores Company, which operates ten downtown department stores and fifteen branches, achieved the highest sales in its seventy-sixth year history in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31. The volume -- $454,148,661 -- compares with $447,547,666, the previous record, in the preceding fiscal year.

LONDON, May 5 -- The stock markets improved after a quiet start today and by the close both British funds and industrial shares showed long lists of fresh gains. South African gold minings also were firmer.
Three thousand Brooklyn school children have transformed a museum sculpture court into an international fair.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington in the tenth day of hearings before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee is considering the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 5 -Maurice Weed of Kalamazoo, Mich., a student at the Eastman School, received tonight the Edward Benjamin Award for the best original composition of a "reposeful" nature by an Eastman School student, as judged by the faculty.
The Omaha Metropolitan Utilities District, Nebraska, sold $6,000,000 of water bonds due from 1957 to 1979 in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.38122 percent.

ST. LOUIS, May 5 (AP) -- Robin Roberts, who had lasted only two innings in his starting effort twenty-four hours earlier, came back to pitch the Philadelphia Phillies to a 10-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight. The Redbirds, held to seven hits, used home runs by Joe Frazier and Rip Repulski to score their only runs.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Senator Eugene D. Millikin, Republican of Colorado, said today the group had passed over for the time being a controversial provision in the tax revision bill that would give a tax cut to stockholders on their dividend income.
PARIS, May 5 -- European economic experts declared today that the United States recession was nearing its end and that it had not affected Europe's economy.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 -- Harry Bridges and his West Coast dock union are supporting the old International Longshoremen's Association in its New York waterfront battle with the American Federation of Labor.
ALBANY, May 5 -- A second effort to organize a bargaining bloc of upstate Republican Assemblymen from rural areas came to light today.

The Government abandoned temporarily yesterday its plan to prosecute William Z. Foster, 73-year-old national chairman of the Communist party. The decision was taken as a result of a physician's report that Foster was physically incapable of standing trial.

MILWAUKEE, May 5 (AP) -Gene Conley, towering rookie right-hander, scattered six hits for his first major league victory tonight as the Milwaukee Braves beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 -- 1, before an amazing turnout of 13,194 fans in 37-degree temperature.

As a private citizen I would like to raise my voice, small and insignificant though it may be, to state most emphatically that despite any other business, the importance of which I believe I am fully aware, I do not regard the Army-McCarthy hearings as a waste of time.
Paced by surprising sales of tailored clothing, March-April sales of boys wear topped 1953's Eastern season, and for the fall, all-wool flannel suits promise to be the best seller.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The ninth anniversary of the Netherlands' liberation from the Nazis brought a new and joyful kind of music to the capital today. A forty-nine-bell carillon rang out the thanks of a grateful people for help from the United States in their darkness hour.

GENEVA, May 5 -- President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles are directing the United States delegation here by a system of trans-Atlantic messages so ingeniously coded that the Russians are believed to have adopted a similar method themselves.

BERLIN, May 5 -- A spokesman of the German Evangelical Church in West Berlin said today that Bishop Otto Dibelius, leader of the church in Germany, had unwittingly signed a plea for the withdrawal of the United States atomic cannon from West Germany.

BALTIMORE, May 5 -- Robert R. Young, re-elected chairman of the board of the Alleghany Corporation today, told the annual stockholders' meeting that the management was confident of winning its fight for control of the New York Central Railroad.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Democratic National Committee members wrangled today over support of James Roosevelt in his race for a California Congressional seat.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The opinion for a unanimous Supreme Court by the Chief Justice Monday in the Texas case involving racially based exclusion from juries has been closely but vainly searched for a clue to the court's decision on the constitutional issue of public school segregation.
BONN, Germany, May 5 -- The Allied High Commission and the West German Government are exploring the question whether the latter is to pay occupation costs beyond July 1.

One of the younger and more important corporation executives in New York, making a "Come - and- See Tour" of agencies helped by the Greater New York Fund, stopped in front of an elderly woman whose fingers flew over a piece of lace work. This was at the Swedish Home for Aged People on Staten Island.

MARSEILLES, France, May 5 (UP) -- Five C-124 Globemaster transports of the United States Air Force left Istres Naval air station near here today with 450 French paratroop reinforcements on the second United States airlift of troops to Indo-China.

A VERY BRUNDAGE is such an idealist that it wouldn't be surprising if he still believed in Santa Claus. The president of the International Olympic Committee always insisted that sports and politics were totally unrelated worlds. Therefore they should never be permitted to intrude on each other. It's a charming theory but totally impractical.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse, as required by conference rules:
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 5 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today named Col. Alfred G. Katzin of the Union of South Africa to take charge of the United Nations' personnel offices.
Net income of the Bendix Aviation Corporation in the quarter ended on March 31 was $6,359,188, compared with $4,721,962 in the similar three months last year, it was reported yesterday.

A plea to guard America's unsubsidized fleet of tramp cargo ships from competition with Government-owned ships was made in Washington yesterday by James B. Stuart, president of the American Tramp Shipowners Association.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The text of President Eisenhower's statement today on the Geneva conference follows:
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 5 -- Israeli leaders criticized the United States today on the ground that it was courting the Arabs at Israel's expense.
EXTREMES are represented in both the group and one-man shows of the week.
John David, Inc., opened a new store at the northwest corner of Fifty-sixth Street and Fifth Avenue yesterday to brisk business.
With civilization hanging in the balance, the American people seem more concerned about "a game of who-done-it" in Washington than with the problem of Indo-China, Mayor Wagner declared last night.

The regional Red Cross Blood Program received 654 pints of blood Tuesday, including 242 at the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, East Eighty-third Street and Ditmas Avenue, and 203 from St. John's University, 75 Lewis Avenue, Brooklyn.
Two new classes will be presented during the summer term at the Museum of Modern Art People's Art Center, 21 West Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The State Department brushed aside today what is termed a protest by Israel against a speech delivered Saturday by Henry A. Byroade Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern, South Asian and African Affairs.
NEWARK, May 5 -- Reports that buses are being used extensively to transport bingo players from New Jersey to New York are being investigated by the Interstate Commerce Commission office here.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP) -Bob Lemon scored his fourth victory without a loss as the Cleveland Indians trounced the Philadelphia Athletics, 7 -- 2, at Connie Mack Stadium tonight. Dave Philley's sixth inning three-run homer helped Lemon to an easy triumph.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, called on the Administration today to name the builders who had collected up to half a billion dollars in "windfall" profits on Government-insured apartment projects.

GENEVA, May 5 -- The South Korean Government will assent to all-Korean elections provided assurances are given that the legal and moral basis for the Government of the Republic of Korea is not thus being surrendered.
The Citizens Union criticized yesterday the practice of city officials appointing honorary commissioners, which it described as establishing an "order of city knighthood."
TORONTO, May 5 -- "Haste to the Wedding," a racy farce in the Restoration manner by Tyrone Guthrie, the noted British Director, was given its world premiere here last night at the Crest Theatre.
ST. LOUIS, May 5 -- Parents may come to have a better understanding of their children by play-acting the games and experiences of childhood.

Exhibits ranged from a giant piston and jet engine display by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation to the miniscule tubes and circuits of Remington Rand's electronic brain for controlling air traffic at the opening yesterday of the third Aircraft Trade Show here.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The issue of United States participation in the St. Lawrence Seaway project approached a climax in Congress today.

There is no reason why civilians, including women, cannot do a good job protecting the safety of children at street crossings near schools. It works well elsewhere, but New York, as in many other opportunities for reform, has been slow to accept example.
Thirteen policemen joined forces last night to subdue a former mental patient in a battle fought by flashlight on the roof of a six-story East Side tenement.
The apparent "abdication" by the Administration in Washington of its role in Indian affairs was attacked yesterday at the annual meeting of the Association on American Indian Affairs.

A few months ago it was an unheard-of point in a far-away valley in the jungles of Southeastern Asia. Today Dienbienphu rings around the world as one of the epic battles of history. It is a name pronounced -- or mispronounced -- on every lip as a synonym for the qualities of courage and stamina that glorify the human race.

BERLIN, May 5 -- Berlin's most mysterious postwar abduction became even more tangled tonight when East Germany contended the man suspected by the West as a kidnapper had confessed to being a West German agent assigned to spy on the British.

The Voice of America is handling the story of the McCarthy-Army hearings as it would any other news story, officials of the broadcasting branch of the United States Information Service reported yesterday.
BOSTON, May 5 (AP) -- The Massachusetts House voted today to ban television, radio broadcasting or motion - picture cameras from any public hearing in which testimony was being taken under oath.

ORIANA ATKINSON'S "Manhattan and Me"* does for the wonderful town what Parkman did for the Oregon Trail, what Margaret Mead did for the bright young people of Samoa, what a sprig of mint does for a julep. It is an angrily amiable garrulity of reminiscences in homage to the tall village between the rivers.
GENEVA, May 5 -- The Assembly of the United Nations World Health Organization was told by its Director General today that it had a long job ahead.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses had some sensible down-to-earth things to say the other day about vandalism. To combat such willful destruction, which despoils the parks and causes damage into the millions of dollars elsewhere, "you've got to get at the parents, and you've got to get at them by fines, if you're going to realize anything in our lifetime."

An investment banking group headed jointly by Kidder, Peabody Co., Smith Barney Co. and Blyth Co., Inc., placed on the market yesterday 60,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of the Montana Power Company.

An informal chronicle of almost fifty years of service and observation with the New York Society Library will be published tomorrow by Macmillan entitled "Books and People." Marion King, the author, presents in her book a survey of American reading taste and comments on persons who have used the library.
Three of the six local health districts taking part in trials of the Salk polio vaccine completed the second round of inoculations yesterday.

With approximately a million and a quarter high school seniors soon to graduate it seems important to call attention to the dearth of trained personnel in the field of health rehabilitation. Recently held national health and medical conferences have stressed the need for persons competent to work with the nation's aged, chronically ill and physically handicapped citizens.

An informal chronicle of almost fifty years of service and observation with the New York Society Library will be published tomorrow by Macmillan entitled "Books and People." Marion King, the author, presents in her book a survey of American reading taste and comments on persons who have used the library.
Three of the six local health districts taking part in trials of the Salk polio vaccine completed the second round of inoculations yesterday.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 5 (AP) -- Finland's Government crisis ended today with the formation of a coalition Cabinet headed by Half Toerngren. Mr. Toerngren is leader of the Swedish People's Party, which represents the Swedish-speaking minority in Finland.
The trustee's reorganization plan for the bankrupt Missouri Pacific Railroad was commended yesterday by T. C. Davis, chairman of the road's board.

Accessory garages and parking spaces would be permitted in residence districts, regardless of proximity to schools, under a zoning amendment approved yesterday at City Hall by the City Planning Commission.
Raymond Daniell, former chief of the London bureau of The New York Times, said here yesterday that Britain, for all her faults and weaknesses, was one of this country's strongest allies.

Your editorial of May 4 entitled "Taft-Hartley in the Senate" is inconsistent with the provisions of Senator Smith's bill, S. 2650. The proposed bill, and especially Senator Goldwater's state's rights bill, would result in greater Government intervention in labor relations.
An effort to rid the city school system of "cultural inbreeding" has failed.

The multitude of rank-and-file employes who would like to be bosses if only for a month will envy nineteen salesmen for Armour Co.'s New York district. The nineteen will run the local branch plants and sales offices this month while their chiefs go out and sell.

MADRID, May 5 -- Circles close to the Spanish Government said today that the United States economic aid to Spain reported to have been proposed by the Foreign Operations Administration for the next fiscal year would be inadequate.

With approximately a million and a quarter high school seniors soon to graduate it seems important to call attention to the dearth of trained personnel in the field of health rehabilitation. Recently held national health and medical conferences have stressed the need for persons competent to work with the nation's aged, chronically ill and physically handicapped citizens.

SCHEVENINGEN the Netherlands, May 5 -- Five of the world's best test pilots defended themselves and their military confreres today against a suggestion voiced by scientists that they should be replaced by machines.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- Joe Castle tossed a three-hitter against Pennsylvania to help Princeton score a 9-3 victory at Franklin Field today. The Tigers retained first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League with a record of five victories and no defeats.
Manhattan College's nine scored three runs in the fifth inning to break a 1-1 tie and gained a 4-1 victory over Brooklyn College in a Metropolitan Conference game at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
GENEVA, May 5 -- Fear that a French Cabinet crisis would delay the opening of the Geneva conference talks on Indo-China pervaded conference circles here today.

LIMA, Peru, May 5 -- The cavalry division that revolted in Paraguay today constitutes nearly half the total strength of the country's army. It is the only large concentration of forces and the garrison of the capital.
Robert R. Young obtained yesterday another stay of his pretrial examination by attorneys of New York Central Railroad.

To provide "desperately needed services" to the 70,000 blind persons of South Korea, the American Foundation for Overseas Blind, 22 West Seventeenth Street, will finance a full-time mission to the war-torn republic, the organization announced yesterday.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday a proposed new schedule of salary classifications for 80,000 of the city's 167,000 civil service employes. The new scales range from a minimum of $2,000 a year to a maximum of $11,640.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 5 -- Malayan production of tin concentrates in March was 4,977 long tons, compared with 4,277 in February, the International Tin Study Group reported today. The Belgian Congo total in March was 902 tons, well above the February figure, but substantially below last year's monthly average of 1,429.
CHICAGO, May 5 (AP) -- Ralph A. Tudor, undersecretary of the Department of the Interior, said today "there is room in this nation for both public and private power."

The development of a new type of blood plasma expander which, it is hoped, will greatly improve the use of substitutes for blood in shock as a result of burns, bleeding, accidents and some diseases was announced here yesterday by the Veterans Administration.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 5 -- Behind the four-hit pitching of a sophomore hurler, Ken Mackenzie, the Yale varsity baseball team defeated Dartmouth, 10-2, today.

Jacob W. Heller and Sidney Landes, real estate operators, have purchased the ten-family apartment house at 68 Middagh Street in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn from Atlantic Equities, Inc., represented by Thomas A. Sully, attorney. The buyers paid cash above a mortgage of $20,000 for the property which occupies a plot 25 by 100 feet.

A women's division was added yesterday to the building fund campaign of St. Luke's Hospital. Nearly $3,400,000 is still needed to meet the total cost of $7,125,000 of a nine-story building that is to be opened early next fall in Amsterdam Avenue between 113th and 114th Streets.

The Most Rev. Joseph Maria Pernicone was consecrated as an Auxiliary Bishop of the New York Archdiocese and titular Bishop of Hadrianopolis, Turkey, by Cardinal Spellman in a colorful service in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Eisenhower gave limited support today to states' rights in the field of labor law but no more, it appeared, than the Administration bill in the Senate now contained.

For the first time in its history the Metropolitan Opera House was the scene yesterday of a fashion show. It was by the Merrimack Manufacturing Company to present its fall fabrics in velveteen and corduroy.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Eisenhower reported with evident relish today that business and economic conditions generally appeared to have taken a turn for the better. But he cautioned against over-confidence that might aggravate any later reversal of the present trends.
CINCINNATI, May 5 -- The Giants, a singularly well behaved group of young men, are still finding night life a perplexing problem. Even Sal Maglie could not help them solve their dilemma tonight.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 5 -- The Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., proposed today a broad program of Federal action calculated to breathe new life into a gasping textile industry.

Two hits won't win many ball games but the Yankees made them do in defeating the Orioles, 4 -- 2, at the Stadium yesterday. The game turned on a triple by Joe Collins with the bases filled in the fifth, when the Bombers did all their scoring.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy asserted today that no Presidential directive would keep him from examining any documents "bearing upon the security of this nation."

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles met with a bipartisan group of two dozen Congressional leaders tonight. He told them that any action involving this country in Indo - China would be united action.

In contrast to fluctuating conditions in other areas of Latin America, the economy of Ecuador remains continuously stable, it was asserted yesterday by Dr. Clemente Duran-Ballen, Ecuadorian Consul General in New York.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 -- Pennsylvania advised the United States Supreme Court today that it would not object to New York's diverting 800,000,000 gallons of water daily from the Delaware River provided several binding conditions were met.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said tonight that a bitter Communist attack now was being waged "often in subtle forms" against all religions and denominations.

Methods that simplify preparation of gelatin desserts have been devised recently by home economists working on behalf of a leading manufacturer of unflavored gelatin. These new techniques apply to snows and the chiffon-like Bavarians, Spanish creams, charlottes and mousses.

BAD KISSINGEN, Germany, May 6 (Reuters) -- Members of the Hohenzollern family said today that the burial of Princess Cecilie would take place next Wednesday if Mrs. Clyde Harris, one of the Princess' married daughters, was able to come to Germany, in time, from the United States, where she lives.

If the proper "assurances" are given to Seoul, it is now reported from Geneva, the Republic of Korea will have no objection to an allKorean election under objective and free supervision. This is a sensible course to take. The request for "assurances" is also sensible and the United Nations members who have fought for a free Korea will be well advised to give it prompt and sympathetic support.

Elections of Thomas F. Fitzgerald as president of Edison Wood Products, Inc., and of Harry W. Houck as president of Measurements Corporation, both wholly owned subsidiaries of Thomas A. Edison, Inc., were announced yesterday by Charles Edison, chairman of the board.

The Popular Price Shoe Show of America, which completed its five-day run at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels yesterday, was described as a "buying show" by manufacturers. Most exhibitors booked more business than they had expected.
Mayor Stowell T. Fournia sounded the victory note in Massena with the order to the Fire Department: "Blast the whistle until the air runs out."

PARIS, May 6 -- Jean Desses designs midsummer frocks with fan fullness at the back of skirts. Made up of a few wide-rolled box pleats or rippling godets, this fullness increases toward late day until, for the ball gowns, the back is like a great open inverted fan.
LONDON, May 6 -- Lloyd's of London has added another valuable item to its fabulous collection of Lord Nelson memorabilia.

Roger Bannister's feat of cracking the 4-minute barrier for the mile run is more than just an epic sports achievement. It dramatizes man's eternal efforts to run longer distances in faster times, to leap higher and to throw farther.

IF the threatened change to bad weather will hold off until Monday the prospects for good fly fishing in most of the Catskill streams, and a few in the Adirondacks, are excellent. Although many streams are rather high they are expected to be in good shape by tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- During the week ended May 5, member bank reserves decreased $492,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 6 -- Eric A. Johnston, President Eisenhower's special Ambassador to the Middle East, said here this evening that the United States' program of "sympathetic and impartial friendship" to Israel and the Arab states must be made at bringing about not only a final peace to the area but also at reducing present points of controversy.

Joe Laurie Jr., the vaudeville comedian who had top billing for many years before his death last week, had asked that his ashes be cast into a roaring fire some winter's day in the fireplace at the Lambs Club.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 6 -- Troop reinforcements were rushed by air today to the northwest coast as the general strike that had shut down the ports of Tela and Puerto Cortes and the town of La Lima spread to the town of Progreso.

ROME, May 6 (UP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia returned to a soggy clay court to complete a 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1 victory over Brazil's P. F. Guimaraes today in the Rome international tennis tournament.

LONDON, May 6 -- Prime Minister Churchill, although hard pressed by the Laborite Opposition, refused to discuss policy "divergencies" between Britain and the United States in the House of Commons today.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- A special three-man security board investigating Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer recessed today "to review the record" and possibly report its findings on the atomic scientist.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, predicted today that the nation's economy would "fall on its face later in the summer or early in the fall" unless the Republican Administration in Washington took positive steps to increase consumer purchasing power.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 6 (UP) -- Joe Taylor of Clarleston, W. Va., shot a five-under-par 65 today to take a one-stroke lead over Sam Snead, the defending champion, in the opening round of the Greenbrier open golf tournament.
BOSTON, May 6 -- Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff said tonight that the world must move swiftly to "bring men together in spirit, just as modern science has brought us close together physically."
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The United States, Britain and France are now in substantial agreement on a compromise plan for a "protected armistice" in Indo-China.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Democrats lashed President Eisenhower and his Administration tonight as being on dead center.

SCHEVENINGEN, the Netherlands, May 6 -- Jet turbines with ceramic blades that would increase aircraft performance by 25 per cent should receive the attention of engine designers, Dr. Duwez, metallurgist of the California Institute of Technology, said here today.

MOSCOW, May 6 -- Two prominent young Soviet playwrights, Nikolai Virta and Anatoly Surov, and two other writers were expelled from the Union of Soviet Writers April 28 on charges of "amoral and anti-social conduct," the Pravda Literary Gazette, organ of the Writers' Union, announced today.

It is always a pleasure to take note of significant anniversaries of local institutions which through their sturdiness, continuing usefulness, pride of tradition and vigor of leadership have been able to achieve longevity. This is certainly true of the New York Society Library which today, with a reception to be held in its quarters at 53 East Seventy-ninth Street for members and friends, will celebrate its 200th birthday.

Events tonight: Brahms Requiem, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 8; Marymount College Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; Earl Rogers, tenor, Greenwich House Music School, 8:30; Juilliard String Quartet, Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:30; Elvira Helal, soprano, Brooklyn Academy of Music 8:30.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., May 6 (AP) -- A draft board member here resigned over the court-martial conviction of Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson on charges of helping the Communists while a prisoner of war in North Korea.

The 173d annual communication (meeting) of the Grand Lodge of Masons of the State of New York ended yesterday with the unanimous election and installation of Raymond C. Ellis of this city as Grand Master for a one-year term.
NEW DELHI, India, May 6 -India and France will open discussions in Paris on May 14 on the status of four French possessions along the Indian coast.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- Since the end of World War II, the nearest approach in history to a complete global census has been provided through population counts in fifty-four separate areas, the United Nations May Bulletin of Statistics discloses.
PASADENA, Calif., May 6 -The California Institute of Technology reported tonight the discovery of a new supernova -- or exploding star -- a fairly rare astronomical event.

The Korean Children's Choir, wearing native costumes, serenaded commuters in the Greyhound Bus Terminal, 245 West Fiftieth Street, yesterday before 9 A. M. with a rendition of "O Susannah." Then they took a bus for Hartford, Conn., where they will begin a concert tour of New England cities as part of a $10,000,000 fund drive for the rehabilitation of Korea.

YONKERS, May 6 -- Yonkers Raceway was closed tonight as a result of the dispute between the track management and the horsemen over prize money. Attempts to resolve the disagreement were being continued by Don R. Millard, executive vice president of the United States Trotting Association.
The American Labor party decided last night to run its own candidates for Governor and other state offices this year in an effort to retain its place as a legally recognized political party.

In observance of International Red Cross Day, a special radio program, titled "The Day It Happened," will be presented tomorrow from 7 to 7:30 P. M. by the N. B. C. network in cooperation with United Nations Radio.

Despite a 68.6 per cent drop in first-quarter earnings, the Chrysler Corporation, nation's third largest automotive producer, voted yesterday to pay the regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 a common share on June 12.

DENVER, Col., May 6 (UP) -Seventy or more employes of the Rocky Mountain Arsenal here received mild doses of a deadly nerve gas, the Army disclosed today. All recovered without permanent injury within five days.

A concert performance of "Die Fledermaus," conducted by Tibor Kozma, will take place at Lewisohn Stadium on Thursday evening, July 1, as the first of eight "special nights" to be presented during this year's Stadium season.

James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said yesterday that Government's role in labor-management relations should be to serve both parties and help them to help themselves. He spoke at a luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York at the Commodore Hotel at which Roger W. Burman presided.

Borrowings by sales finance companies lifted New York bank loans to business by $26,000,000 net in the week ended on Wednesday. The advance in business credits was the first in seven weeks and the fourth so far this year.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington in the eleventh day of hearings before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee is considering the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.
PARIS, May 6 -- Premier Joseph Laniel won a vote of confidence today on his refusal to hold a debate on the Indo-China war. The vote was 311 to 262.
It is the job of underwear producers to build up a demand for their product, knit wear executives were told yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) in the first quarter of this year had consolidated net earnings of $27,706,000, or $1.80 a share on the capital stock, Dr. Robert E. Wilson, chairman, reported at the annual meeting yesterday at Hammond, Ind. This compares with $28,050,000, or $1.83 a share, in the similar period of 1953.
Most persons welcome police protection. But such is not the case with two men receiving a twenty-four-hour police guard as material witnesses in the still unsolved slaying of Arnold Schuster in 1952.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 6 -Critics of the Eisenhower Administration's foreign policy were challenged tonight by Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, "to come up with a better set of blueprints or help execute those we have."
The scientific search for better and simpler methods of birth control should be pressed as a corollary to efforts to prevent a hydrogen bomb war, it was suggested here yesterday.

The Burroughs Corporation, producer of business machines, received $42,214,623 in revenues from its world-wide operations in the first quarter this year, or 10 per cent above the $38,255,731 of a year earlier.

A snorkel started out in life as a breathing device for a submarine. Nowadays it's also a trade name for a fountain pen manufactured by the W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company of Fort Madison, Iowa. A year ago Sheaffer ran a spot survey of what the word meant to Chicagoans.

Handel's oratorio, "Israel in Egypt," which in the great days of nineteenth-century choral societies used to be done by massive orchestras and choristers running into the hundreds, was presented by the considerably more modest forces of the Cantata Singers, Alfred Mann conducting, at St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church last evening.
With few exceptions the directional signs on and abutting the arterial highway system in and around the city confuse rather than help motorists.
LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- Roger Bannister is a strange athlete -slender, tall, boyish, studious and supremely confident.

The projected conference on IndoChina was saved from possible collapse or indefinite delay yesterday when the French National Assembly shrank from the responsibility of precipitating a Cabinet crisis at this precise moment and gave Premier Laniel the confidence vote he had demanded.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The St. Lawrence River will be developed concurrently, but in separate projects, for commerce and hydroelectric power.

B. Altman Co. has leased a fourteen-acre site at the junction of Morris Turnpike and River Road in Millburn, N. J., and plans to build a 110,000-square-foot store there. The lessor is The Prudential Insurance Company of America. It is planned to build a shopping center at the site.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Men of the Fighting Lady," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama in Technicolor of the Korean war, with Van Johnson, Walter Pidgeon, Louis Calhern, Dewey Martin and Keenan Wynn, is at the Globe. Henry Berman produced and Andrew Marton directed, from a screen play by Art Cohn.

Japanese wool goods are being offered in the United States at $1.50 to $2 a yard less than comparable American goods, according to E. D. Walen, new president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

SELLAFIELD, England, May 6 -- Britain's plutonium piles are so massive that atomic engineers are unable to break down the excessive radiation shielding and fit atomic power generators to the existing plant.

This fall an important election occurs in New York State. Under the leadership of Mayor Wagner, National Committeeman De Sapio and State Chairman Balch, the Democratic party has regained stature and is presented with the opportunity to elect its candidate Governor.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 6 -- The battle of Dienbienphu has over-shadowed the long and frustrating war that continues without let-up in Tonkin's Red River Delta. This triangular paddyfield area, which is about 8,000 square miles in size and contains about 7,000,000 people, is one of the most important military and political regions in all Indo-China.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's new management withdrew yesterday a proposal its predecessor had made for a 24 to 30 per cent commutation fare increase.

For years the big question has been whether anybody would ever run a four-minute mile. It was good for an argument anytime. Now that question is disposed of, and we can turn to other questions, such as whether it will ever be run again.

A new water rate tariff for the trailership service of the American and Overseas Chartering Corporation, which is expected to be filed next week, will bring to an end a six-month court fight instituted by truckers against the New York-Albany service, it was predicted yesterday.
DETROIT, May 6 (AP) -- A highranking Girl Scout official recommended today suspension of a troop leader who declined to tell a House subcommittee whether she ever had been a Communist.

Following is the text of the exchange of messages between Mayor Wagner and Harold W. McGraw, chairman of the Joint Conference for Better Government, representing various groups opposing extension of the city sales tax:

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -The league-leading Chicago White Sox rallied for two runs with two out in the ninth inning to defeat the Washington Senators, 5 -- 4, today. Orestes Minoso led Chicago's eleven-hit attack with four singles, driving across four runs.
The appointment of three newspaper men to the advisory board of the American Press Institute was announced yesterday by the trustees of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire and chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, announced today the Defense Department had asked for money to build two additional atomic-powered submarines in the year beginning July 1.
The average American family had $5,173 to spend last year after its income taxes were paid. This figure was $86 more than in 1952. It was a new high record.

Anne O'Hare McCormick's column on May Day was a powerful plea for sanity. Here we are sitting glued to our television sets, absorbed in the strange game of Schine vs. Stevens, while the world crumbles under our feet.

The Army's Counter Intelligence Corps is "highly respected among the troop and [bears] no taint of an M. V. D. [the Russian secret police]," a correspondent who has had experience with the corps insists.

CINCINNATI, May 6 -- A couple of two-run homers -- one by Willie Mays, the other by Henry Thompson -- twice put the Giants back in the ball game today. But even that failed to keep Manager Leo Durocher's Polo Grounders from sinking a little deeper into the second division.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Following is the text of the directive issued by President Truman on March 15, 1948, prohibiting executive departments from giving loyalty files to members of Congress and directing that all requests for such data be referred for decision to the White House. This was a leading point of discussion in today's sessions of the Army-McCarthy inquiry:

B. C. Forbes, business and financial writer and publisher of a semi-monthly business magazine bearing his name, died yesterday in his office at 80 Fifth Avenue. Mr. Forbes, who lived at Fountain Road, Englewood, N. J., would have been 74 years old next Friday.

A revealing straw in the economic wind was released yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. The chemical colossus announced it would increase its output of cellophane considerably this year. Since cellophane is used for so many different business purposes, it doesn't look as though this country is coming apart at the commercial seams.

A marked increase in new commercial trailer orders will be reflected in improved sales and earnings in the second quarter, Roy Fruehauf, president of the Fruehauf Trailer Company reported at the thirty-fifth annual stockholder meeting held in Detroit, Mich., yesterday.
A former railroad man, bank clerk, farmer, artillery officer, storekeeper, judge, Senator, Vice President and President of the United States is celebrating his seventieth birthday today.

LONDON, May 6 -- The advance in stock prices continued today, stimulated by a series of announcements of increased dividends, including those of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company and Dunlop Rubber Company.
The annual spring festival of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, which opened yesterday in the parish house at Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, will continue there today.

Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services was "seemingly" inevitable. Nothing else can be done, he said, unless a "practical" substitute source of revenue is made possible at a special session of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay told Congress today that synthetic fuels processes demonstrated at Bureau of Mines plants "might have immediate economic value . . . for producing chemicals."
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Eisenhower ceremonially approved today the Federal-aid highway bill providing $1,932,000,000 for building and maintaining state and Federal highways.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Highway Transportation Congress heard a plea today that more traffic violators be required to "face the judge" in the handling of their cases.

Thomas Francis Maloney sorrowfully told the Brooklyn police yesterday that unwise bets on unworthy race horses had drained him of $6,000 he had extorted from unwary Brooklyn liquor sellers while posing as a State Liquor Authority inspector.

GENEVA, May 6 -- The outlook for progress in the conference on Far Eastern affairs improved today as a result of the vote of confidence given the French Government and South Korea's agreement in principle to drop its demand for elections in North Korea only.
All the fresh, colorful originality that is so much a part of Claire McCardell's designing was in evidence yesterday in her presentation of summer fashions at the Plaza Hotel.
JERUSALEM, May 6 -- From Dan to Beersheba and from Acre to Elath the blue and white flag of independence was flying today.

The large dwelling at 123 Greenway North in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, which was the home of Trygve Lie, former Secretary General of the United Nations has been purchased by a customer of Walter Scott Co. Victor Spitzer was the broker.
The foods that people eat dictate the design of their dinnerware, judging from two groups of ceramics now on view here.
Chicken went on holiday last evening at the McAlpin Hotel.
GENEVA, May 6 -- The Chinese Communists had their coming out party this evening.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 6 (AP) -- Otto Mayer, chancellor of the International Olympic Committee, said today it was "absolutely out of the question" that the committee would transfer the 1956 Olympic Games from Melbourne.
Tenant selection by income for public housing is creating "economic ghettos" and levying a penalty for financial success, according to a nation-wide study of public housing now under way.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregularly lower yesterday in generally dull trading. Coffee, sugar, soybean oil, potatoes, burlap, silk, tin and lead were off; cottonseed oil, rubber, wool, zinc and copper ended mixed, and cocoa and hides closed higher.

WHEN Public School 127 was new 100 years ago this week, it stood in a green meadow on the old Bloomingdale Farm. Boys came to it barefoot through dewy grass, watched white sails tacking down the Hudson River and heard the lark through open windows on dreamy spring afternoons.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- An all-out Democratic attack on the Eisenhower Administration's foreign policy, the first such attack since the President took office, was opened tonight.

As the years pass the New York Community Trust, 250 Park Avenue, New York 17, becomes more and more useful. According to this agency's annual report, just published, the trust is now administering community trust funds totaling $21,423,329.

OTTAWA, May 6 (AP) -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent said tonight that the Canadian Government was still ready to undertake construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway alone, but would discuss any "specific proposal" made by the United States.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 6 (UP) -- Russia has served the International Basketball Federation with an ultimatum, threatening to set up a dissident federation and stage its own world tournament if it is not invited to the world championships in Brazil this summer, it was revealed today.

Hofstra College virtually eliminate C. C. N. Y., the defending champion, from the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference race yesterday by defeating the Beavers, 6 to 2, at Ohio Field in the Bronx.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 6 -Business men are reluctant, but still willing, to fill upper echelon Government jobs despite what they term the "shabby" treatment accorded Robert T. Stevens.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A suggestion that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy may have violated the law in accepting material officially classified as confidential was put up to the Department of Justice today.

The New York Times last night received the first international award of the William the Silent Foundation for Journalism as the American newspaper or magazine "contributing most to the understanding of international problems."

An American Federation of Labor victory in the May 26 dock workers' election would enable the city's port to regain its preeminence, Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Canada built the first canal along the St Lawrence River in 1783. Today, 171 years later she stands ready to open the full length of the river and the Great Lakes beyond, with United States help, to ocean commerce.

It was not until after the intermission, when a group of LatinAmerican songs appeared on the program, that Lucila Montoya began to sing with the ease and flexibility that she previously had only hinted at. The soprano, who comes from New Mexico, had opened her program last night in Carnegie Hall with standard works by Bach, Mozart, Mendelssohn, Schumann and Debussy.

The return of Native Dancer will take place at Belmont Park today. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's big gray with a record of eighteen victories in nineteen races, will make his first start as a 4-year-old, participating in a six-furlong event on the main course.

Three thousand students of Catholic elementary and high schools will participate as members of choruses, orchestras, bands and instrumental ensembles in the finals of the nineteenth annual Catholic School Music Festival, which opens in Town Hall Monday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -Attorney General Herbert Brownell announced an anti-trust consent judgment today described as ending restraints of trade in the nation-wide distribution and sale of automobile parts.

IT finally happened. The 4-minute mile no longer is an impenetrable barrier. Roger Bannister of England burst through it and beyond with his electrifying 3:59.4 yesterday under conditions that would seem to make its acceptance as a world record a formality. From an athletic standpoint this is as historic as the breaking of the sound barrier.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 6 -Southpaw Jack Morra hurled a four-hitter to help Navy record its sixth straight triumph and fifth against one defeat in Eastern Intercollegiate League play today. The home team beat Penn's nine, 2 -- 1.

Somewhere tomorrow morning it will be raining. Saturday in the spring is no time for rain. Friday, yes. Saturday, no. Somewhere people will wake up to the steady drum of rain on the roof, to the sight of little drops rolling down the window panes, and they will groan mightily.

Plans are being formulated for the performance of the Old Vic's production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" on the night of Oct. 5 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Child Study Association of America.

LONDON, May 6 (Reuters) -Dr. G. M. Lees, former chief geologist of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, said today that in twenty years more than half the world's oil probably will have to come from the Middle East.

Impersonating a woman of 83 in "The Southwest Corner," John Cecil Holm's dramatization of the Mildred Walker novel, intrigues Eva Le Gallienne. Yesterday she recalled that the last time she had such an assignment was at the age of 29 in "Improvisations in June." Miss Le Gallienne is willing to act in Mr. Holm's play, to be staged by him, but hasn't signed contracts yet with John Huntington, who controls the script.

Net earnings of the New York Telephone Company, largest operating unit in the Bell Telephone System, declined slightly in the first quarter of this year. Keith S. McHugh, president, reported yesterday that earnings for the period were $15,420,681, compared with $15,850,893 in the first quarter of 1953.
The world's track stars paid tribute to Roger Bannister last night and said they hoped to follow soon in his footsteps.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -Senator Berry M. Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, today softened his proposed states' rights amendment to the TaftHartley Law in an effort to meet charges it would impair labor's "fundamental" rights.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 -The New Jersey Bankers Association has begun a "comprehensive study" of branch banking restrictions.

SEONG MOY'S recent paintings at the New Gallery employ even more brilliant and well-harmonized color than one has learned to expect from him. Emphasis is always on the color and lyric spirit of the Orient. With flashing areas of reds, yellows and blues he suggests the gorgeous robes of Oriental actors, swirling in a kaleidoscopic movement of changign hues and planes.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 -Harvard University received gifts totaling $3,793,401 during the first quarter of 1954. These included two fellowship funds for United States and foreign students.
MANILA, Friday, May 7 (AP) -Two world weightlifting records were broken at the second Asian Games yesterday.

Fashion designs by Pratt Institute pupils who, judging from their work, are budding award winners, were shown to a group of fashion experts yesterday at Midston House, Madison Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

WALLINGTON, N. J., May 7 -Miss Theresa Rak has led a rather peaceful existence for the last twenty-five years, during which she has been employed at the E. I. du Pont Company's Arlington works. Before that she was killing Russian soldiers invading her homeland of Poland.

MOSCOW, May 6 -- The Soviet Army newspaper Red Star said today that an underground explosion of a hydrogen bomb would produce a blast like the volcanic eruption that destroyed the island of Krakatoa in Sunda Strait in 1883.
GENEVA, May 6 -- Plenary sessions of the conference on Asian affairs will be resumed here tomorrow after a two-day recess.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -The Agriculture Department reversed itself today and offered to sell up to a third of a billion pounds of Government-owned butter to friendly foreign countries at bargain prices.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet but steady yesterday and prices moved 8 points higher to 1 point lower than on Wednesday.

In a superb show of airmanship, a Pan American World Airways pilot brought a Boeing Stratocruiser -- the world's largest and heaviest commercial transport -- in to a safe landing here yesterday in spite of a damaged nosewheel.

National Airlines announced last night that, on or about May 15, it would transfer one of its Douglas DC-7's to low-fare tourist service on its New YorkMiami run. The non-stop flight is scheduled to take three-andone-hafl hours.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters has selected a 33-year-old New York-born poet, Richard Wilbur, for its annual $3,000 Prix de Rome fellowship, Archibald MacLeish, president of the academy, announced yesterday.
After two years and eight months of experience with the pass-type commutation ticket, the Long Island Rail Road will go back to the classic, punchtype on May 15.
PITTSBURGH, May 6 -- The steel industry was put on notice today that its unionized employes wanted higher pay, a guaranteed annual wage and liberalized welfare provisions this year.
PARIS, May 6 -- The finance ministers of West Europe agreed today to continue the operation of the European Payments Union for another year from July 1.

Joseph P. Ryan, the former head of the old International Longshoremen's Association on trial for theft of union funds, paid expenses of secreting anti-Communist literature in cargoes destined for European and Asian ports, a defense witness testified yesterday.
Although he had to retire at the start of the eighth inning because of a cramp in the calf muscle of his right leg, Allie Reynolds made an impressive 1954 debut as a starter yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Customers are buying automobiles at a rate the confirms the forecast that 5,000,000 cars would be sold this year, George P. Mitchings, manager of the economic analysis department of Ford Motor Company, said today. He spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Investment Analysts Society of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 1 per cent bellow those of the corresponding 1953 week, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
CHICAGO, May 6 -- Wheat futures were as weak today as they had been strong yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The inquiry into alleged pampering of big-name athletes heard today that Sandy Saddler had been granted extensions of leave from European duty to defend his boxing title.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- The Northern States Power Company reported today that operating revenues of the company and subsidiaries in the first quarter of 1954 were $32,146,481, up 9.7 per cent to $2,841,378 from the 1953 level.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter K. Grimes of Belmont, Mass., returned to the United States yesterday with the two children they had smuggled from behind the Iron Curtain. It was the end of a three-year struggle when they landed at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, early in the morning.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- Don Hartman, Paramount production chief, combined business with pleasure on the way home from Europe last week when he met Irving Berlin, a fellow passenger on the Il de France.

Under the leadership of some of the rail, steel, copper, oil and aircraft issues, the stock market recovered from a shaky opening yesterday and made a good gain.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy threw down the gauntlet today to President Eisenhower and the entire Executive Branch of Government.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 -- Two defendants in the Jan. 16 kidnapping of Leonard Moskovitz, a San Francisco real estate dealer, were found guilty today. The jury did not recommend mercy.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -The Senate Finance Committee agreed tentatively today to give a better tax break to parents whose children earned their own money.

Schools should be expected to provide "emotional education" for youngsters, just as they are now required to offer intelectual any physical education, Dr. Robert M. Goldenson said yesterday. Dr. Goldenson, Assistant Professor of Psychology at Hunter College, spoke at the annual meeting of the Women's Auxiliary of Congregation Emanu-El, meeting in the community house, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Exactly 42,783 children have completed the first of three injections in local trials of the Salko polio vaccine, the Health Department announced yesterday after Staten Island, last of six health districts to begin the tests, reported its total.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Army-McCarthy hearings, in the eleventh day, remained the top attraction on Capitol Hill today.
GENEVA, May 6 (UP) -- The Russian bear and the Communist Chinese dragon walk together at the Geneva peace conference, but apparently each is wary.
The Pennsylvania Highway and Bridge Authority borrowed $20,000,000 in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.109 per cent.

ARDMORE, Okla., May 6 (AP) -- A sensational barrage of birdies produced a two-under-par 68 today and carried Julius Boros, former national open champion, into the first-round lead of the $15,000 Ardmore open golf tournament over the Dornick Hills course.
LONDON, May 6 -- A resolution opposing the rearmament of West Germany was approved unanimously by the National Executive Committee of Britain's second largest union today.

Housewives are paying more for frozen orange juice concentrate. The price of a six-ounce can has risen 3 to 5 cents, depending on brand, in the last few weeks. At one chain, for example, the cans selling two for 27 cents three weeks ago are now two for 37 cents.

Again we are threatened with the wanton destruction of a precious piece of the architectural heritage of our region, the superb mansion Boscobel, on the banks of the Hudson near Croton. Boscobel was built about 1795 by Staats Morris Dyckman, and was later owned by the famous Cruger family.
Early action by the United States and Philippine Governments to develop a broad new program for expansion of trade and private investment was urged yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 6 -- A parade of the armed forces and an passive defense services along a five-mile stretch of highway between Jerusalem and the coastal plain brought the celebration of the sixth anniversary of Israel's independence to a climax today.
ALBANY, May 6 (AP) -- The clang of bells and shriek of whistles filled the air in Massena and Ogdensburg today as residents of the St. Lawrence River communities celebrated "Seaway Day."

The name of Lillian D. Wald is revered wherever intelligent community service is discussed. Sixty years ago, Miss Wald and a friend, Miss Mary Brewster, founded the Visiting Nurse Service of New York in a small East Side apartment.

THE treasured story of "Alice in Wonderland" was shockingly desecrated on Wednesday evening on the Kraft Television Theatre over N. B. C. For what was done to the beloved classic there can be neither excuse nor justification.
IN his paintings of landscape, figures and still-life at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, Bernard Chaet reveals himself as a poet-painter.

MILWAUKEE, May 6 -- The executive board of the United Automobile Workers International Union, A. F. L., ordered today the reinstatement of the charters of Locals 214, 227 and 228 in New York and 225 in Philadelphia.
TOKYO, May 6 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Diet (Parliament) today the Communists might launch a surprise attack on Japan similar to that against South Korea four years ago.
LONDON, May 6 -- Roger Gilbert Bannister ran a mile in 3 minutes 59.4 seconds tonight to reach one of man's hitherto unattainable goals.

A dividend of 12 per cent and an extra dividend of 2 per cent have been recommended for payment by the Dunlop Rubber Company, Ltd. After deducting British taxes of 45 per cent on dividends, the disbursement will be equivalent to 10.8 cents a share in American funds.

The National Dairy Products Corporation set a new high record for any first quarter earnings in its history with a net of $7,462,969 in the quarter ended on March 31. This is an increase of $1,068,184, or 16.7 per cent over the $6,394,785 earned in the initial three months of last year, E. E. Stewart, president, reported yesterday.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, last night defended the right of Democratic county leaders to advise members of the Wagner Administration on tax and fiscal problems. He asserted that the Democratic county leaders knew what the people wanted.

Harold Vanderbilt, chairman of the executive committee of the New York Central Railroad, yesterday moved to postpone the May 26 stockholders' meeting scheduled to decide the battle for control of the road.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP)--The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that union-sponsored work slowdowns, partial strikes and refusal to work overtime were unfair labor practices.

Mayors of sixteen of the nation's principal cities joined yesterday in demanding that Congress enlarge its Federal Housing program. The Mayors expressed themselves as "deeply concerned with the housing program now pending before Congress."
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -Following is the roll-call vote on House passage of the St. Lawrence Seaway measure.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The proposed amendment to the Taft-Hartley Act by Senator Goldwater of Arizona, now modified in an effort to meet the criticism that it could invade existing federal protection of collective bargaining, is designed to specify powers to states confronted with strike-produced public emergencies.

A story of women's struggle for recognition in American public life, entitled "Ladies of Courage," will be published May 18 by Putnam. The authors are Eleanor Roosevelt and Lorena Hickok. Among the scores of women the authors write about are Clare Booth Luce, Frances Perkins, Senator Margaret Chase Smith and Judge Florence Allen.
PARIS, May 6 -- New instructions concerning cease-fire negotiations at Geneva were framed by a restricted Cabinet meeting here today.

MILWAUKEE, May 6 (AP) -Lew Burdette threw only ninetyfive pitches today as he shut out the Pittsburgh Pirates on five hits, 3 -- 0. The victory, third straight for the Milwaukee Braves, moved them into fifth place in the National League pennant race.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6 -- The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace announced today the election of two members of the Board of Trustees: Dr. George N Shuster, president of Hunter College, and Charles A. Sprague, former Governor of Oregon.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- George Shuba allowed a double by Ernie Banks to skip through him for an error in the eleventh inning and Ransom Jackson scampered home with the unearned run for an 8-7 Cub victory over the Dodgers today.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The House of Representatives voted today, 241 to 158, to authorize the United States to join Canada in constructing the St. Lawrence Seaway.

The regional Red Cross Blood Program received 773 pints of blood Wednesday, including 215 from inmates of City Prison, Rikers Island. The United Merchants and Manufacturers, 1412 Broadway, gave 210 pints, and the community of Rockville Centre, L. I., 142 at a mass donation in Temple B'nai Sholom there.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The aodption of a Government coal policy to increase coal consumption by 50,000,000 tons a year was urged today as a step toward relieving the economic plight of the coal industry.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 6 -- A junta took over the government today following an uprising by army cavalry forces that deposed President Federico Chaves yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, May 6 (UP) -- The Argentine Telephone Administration reported today that communication with Asuncion had been restored but was subject to long delays and to priority for official traffic.

WASHIGTON, May 6 (AP) -Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, predicted the Senate would accept the House version without further ado, which could place the completed bill before President Eisenhower by Tuesday.

GENEVA, May 6 (AP) -- Huang Hua, a Communist China spokesman, said tonight three Americans seized more than a year ago in a yacht off the China coast, were being held on charges of "violating Chinese law."

GENEVA, May 6 -- Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, is believed in some quarters to be under increased pressure from Paris to agree to a settlement in Indo-China as a result of today's challenge to the French Government.
LONDON, May 6 -- Sir David Maxwell-Fyfe, Home Secretary, rejected today demands by members of both parties in the House of Commons for special police measures against teen-age "Edwardian" gangs.

Landlocked in the heart of South America, the Republic of Paraguay is the least accessible, the poorest and one of the most charming of the Latin lands. Its people are goodhumored but quick-tempered; they have intense political loyalties and great physical courage.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 6 -- Two cousins tied for low gross honors in the opening one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association over the Montclair course today.

A syndicate headed by Harvey Sorkin has purchased five fourstory garden-type apartment buildings at 8-10-12 South Fifteenth Avenue and 8-16 East Fourth Street in Mount Vernon, N.Y. The property was sold subject to mortgages of $343,000. Joseph H. Schindler, lawyer, represented the buyers and Milton Herman was the broker.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The United States Court of Military Appeals ruled today that the continental United States was "at war," for purposes of the Administration military justice, while the fighting was going on in Korea.

I was most interested in your excellent editorial of April 21 entitled "Policing Obscene Comics," but I was somewhat disappointed to see that you did not mention the name of the individual responsible for the unusual and excellent job that is being done on this problem.

NEW DELHI, India, May 6 -India has replied cautiously to the invitation of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, to associate the New Delhi Government with possible guarantees relating to any Indo-China settlement emerging from the Geneva conference on Far-Eastern affairs.

Members and guests of the Park Association of New York City will tour the parks, playgrounds and places of historic interest in Queens May 18, it was announced yesterday at the organization's headquarters, 119 East Nineteenth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -A lead-off homer by Al Smith in the eighth inning brought a 3-to-2 victory to the Cleveland Indians land Early Wynn over the Philadelphia Athletics tonight. Smith's drive offset a singleton homer in the same inning by Vic Power.
The Parks Department announced yesterday the opening of its 600th playground, a one-anda-quarter-acre area at Barnes Avenue and East 215th Street, the Bronx.
BOWIE, Md., May 6 (AP) -- Alfred Roberts' Eatontown set a seven-furlong track record today in winning the $10,000-added Bowie Handicap on the closingday card before 9,854 fans.
The Society for Seamen's Children in Staten Island, cared for 170 boys and girls last year, according to the group's 107th annual report issued here yesterday by Louise H. Irving, president.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (UP) -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers and once a target for an "insult" by former President Truman, today paid a compliment to his one-time antagonist.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 -- Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey charged here tonight that religious and other groups were exerting pressure on Indiana University and the Rockefeller Foundation to end their support of his studies in human sexuality.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy will not speak in next fall's election campaign under sponsorship of the Republican National Committee, according to present plans.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 647,925 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 21,744 cars or 3.5 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 133,574 cars or 17.1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 96,799 cars or 13 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Joseph N. Welch, counsel for the Army in the McCarthy hearings, managed to get into the record yesterday a statement with which we believe most persons who have closely followed the course of the investigation would concur. Senator McCarthy, said Mr. Welch, is conducting a "filibuster by cross-examination."

THE new film called "Khamishia -- Five Tales from Israel," which opened yesterday at the Midtown, Ascot. Carroll and Supreme Theatres, does nothing to dim the sixth anniversary of the founding of the Free State. Sadly, it does little to enhance the occasion, either.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 7 -- A virtual Tower of Babel in this geographically divided nation of nine languages was envisioned today after a historic decision by the national legislature.
