Securities with an aggregate value of at least $380,000,000 are tentatively scheduled for offering to investors next week. The major portion consists of municipal bonds.

" The Minotaur," a new play by Robert Thom, a 24-year-old playwright never represented hereabouts, has been purchased by the Circle in the Square producers, Jose Quintero, Ted Mann, Emilie Stevens and Jason Wingreen.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 7 -- Herbert H. Maass, president and chairman of the board of trustees of the Institute for Advanced Study, made public here today comprehensive report of scientific studies at the institute during the six academic years from 1947-48 through 1952-53.
Following is the text of the radio-television address to the nation last night by Secretary of State Dulles on "The Issues at Geneva," as recorded by The New York Times:
A harrowing tale that had landed a Brooklyn landlord in prison because a jury believed it, failed to hold up on a second telling yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, May 7 -- Two deputy United States marshals arrived here from Newark this afternoon with subpoenas to serve on thirty persons who were actively connected with the 1949 Jersey City election campaign.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today a proposed relaxation of the rules under which gold may be acquired and used in this country.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Chief Justice of the United States, who once sought the Republican Presidential nomination, wished Harry S. Truman a happy birthday tonight.
The annual incursion of summer sailors will be met by the Third Coast Guard District with the reactivation of two shore stations and the special assignment of six rescue craft.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 736 pints of blood Thursday. The Mid-Bronx community, at mass donations in Public School 104, 1449 Shakespeare Avenue, and P. S. 90, Sheridan Avenue and East 166th Street, gave 219 pints. At New York Telephone Company offices, 104 Broad Street, 156 pints were donated, and at Remington Rand, Inc., 315 Fourth Avenue 131 pints.
CINCINNATI, May 7 -- Recommendations for the protection of the nation's internal security and safeguarding of individual civil liberties were released here today by the American Jewish Committee.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York will be asked at its annual meeting next Tuesday evening to approve a report of its Committee on the Bill of Rights, of which George S. Leisure is chairman, dealing with publication of comment on pending litigation.

REPORTS from the Canadian prairie provinces indicate that although an extremely heavy spring migration had been noted in these "duck factories," abnormally low temperatures and harsh weather forced many ducks and geese to return southward to await more favorable conditions.

GENEVA, May 7 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from addresses today at the Geneva conference on Korea by Carlos P. Garcia, Vice President of the Philippines, T. Clifton Webb, External Affairs Minister of New Zealand, and Eduardo Zuleta Angel, Colombian Ambassador to the United States:
Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer made a triumphant return to race-running at Belmont Park yesterday.
The main issues in the Army-McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

Mayor Wagner in his letter to the Joint Conference for Better Government oversimplifies his budget-balancing dilemma. He acknowledges "hating" to impose the extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to business services. He and his advisers have "spent the last few weeks canvassing the field of legalized substitutes."
Seven persons were injured and traffic pouring into Manhattan's Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive was disrupted yesterday when a police van overturned on the drive near 118th Street.

One of the most celebrated collections of American antiques will be auctioned next week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. Collected by Mr. and Mrs. Luke Vincent Lockwood beginning with the turn of the century, the items include furniture, paintings and a large variety of American, English and Oriental art and decorative objects.

With four more games to be contested, Mikhail Botvinnik's lead in the defense of his world chess championship against Vassily Smyslov in Moscow has been reduced to one point after the latter's victory in the twentieth game of the series, according to a report received yesterday from London.
ROANOKE, Va., May 7 (UP) -- The Southern Conference today turned over to the executive committee the problem of post-season football games and lifted its ban on freshmen in varsity athletics.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 7 -- The Founders Day program at the Eastman School of Music's twenty-fourth Festival of American Music tonight comprised a "Poem and Dance" by Quincy Porter, Symphony No. 3 by Walter Piston, "Artik" Concerto for horn and strings by Alan Hovhaness and "Cherubic Hymn" for chorus and orchestra by Dr. Howard Hanson, director of the school.

The plan to merge American Woolen Company and Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted Corporation has been altered to eliminate the necessity of getting approval from American Woolen's stockholders, according to Royal Little, chairman of the board of Textron Incorporated.

BELGRADE, May 7 -- An entirely new plan to solve one of Europe's most difficult problems, the bitter contest for Trieste between Italy and Yugoslavia, is being studied by diplomatic experts. There is some hope that a settlement may be reached doing away with Zone A of the Free Territory, now occupied by the United States, British and Yugoslav troops.
Stocks, advancing for the seventh time in nine trading sessions, made new highs yesterday for the year and for the upward movement.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A Wall Street lawyer received a patent this week for an invention that should prove a boon to the housewife -- a self-threading needle.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington in the twelfth day of hearings before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee is considering the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.

Canned purple plums are the basis for a delicious pie that might be served to advantage this week-end. Required for the pastry is one No. 2 1/2 or thirty-ounce tin of the fruit. One chain now offers purple plums in a can of this size for 27 cents.
HEWLETT, L. I., May 7 -- A 5-under-par 67 enabled Mal Galletta to lead the qualifiers in the seventh William D. Richardson memorial golf tournament at the Seawane Harbor Club today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 7 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today the banker who tries to beat his competitors to a fat savings account by offering a higher interest rate may knock himself out of business.

Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries, the French commander whose fate has not been revealed with the capture of Dienbienphu, became the symbol throughout the anti-Communist world of the gallant last stand at the Indo-China fortress.
Whitley P. McCoy, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said yesterday that the Government had a proper role to play in the mediation of labor disputes.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Secretary of the Army testified today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and his key aides had mixed, in the same conversations, repeated requests for favored treatment for Pvt. G. David Schine with "threats" of continued exposure of alleged Communists in the Army.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 7 (AP) -- Jack Burke's putts fell almost as steadily as the rain today and he took only 63 strokes, 7 under par and 1 over the old White course record, to gain the halfway lead in the Greenbrier open golf tournament.

GENEVA, May 7 -- New Zealand, Colombia and the Philippines criticized Communist China this afternoon as the debate in the Far Eastern conference was resumed after a two-day recess. No progress was made toward any substantive solution of the Korean problem.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The United States rejected today the Soviet Union's proposal of March 31 that the "cold war" be ended by formation of a new European security organization and its suggestion for Soviet admissionto the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

BUENOS AIRES, May 7 (UP) -- Air passengers arriving from Paraguay tonight reported that fighting still was raging in Asuncion between rebel cavalry troops and forces loyal to army commander in chief Gen. Alfredo Stroener.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- For those who wonder what it's costing the taxpayer to stage the Army-McCarthy hearings, there are two ways of looking at it.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Senate today killed amendments to the Taft-Hartley Law for the 1954 session of Congress.

" Newsmen Speak," edited by Edmond D. Coblentz, brings together the concepts, formulas and philosophies of some of America's outstanding newspaper men. Scheduled for May 22 publication by the University of California Press, the volume presents in the words of the men themselves -- among them Adolph S. Ochs, Arthur Brisbane and William Allen White -- the theories, knowledge and techniques that go into making newspapers.
CLEVELAND, May 7 (AP) -- Cleveland's Mayor and the City Manager of Toledo welcomed the Congressional decision to join with Canada in constructing the St. Lawrence Seaway.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 7 (AP) -- Labor leaders who have called out 12,000 workers of the United Fruit Company and crippled the Honduras operations of the United States-owned company, threatened today to extend the strike.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- Following is the vote by which the Senate, 50 to 42, agreed today to send the Administration's Taft - Hartley amendment bill back to committee:

ST. LOUIS, May 7 -- Efforts to clear up arrearage on Missouri-Kansa-Texas Railroad stock are being deferred until the pending tax measure in Congress is enacted, Donald V. Fraser, president, said today.
PITTSBURGH, May 7 -- Strong indications that steel labor and industry hoped to set a 1954 wage, pattern without a strike developed here today.

LONDON, May 7 -- Oliver Lyttelton, the Colonial Secretary, has decided to nationalize the European-owned land in Nyasaland that is occupied by Negro tenants. They would then become tenants of the Nyasaland Government.

Speaking under the shadow of the tragedy at Dienbienphu, Secretary Dulles last night broadcast to this nation and the whole free world a new call to join together in a united front and, if necessary, to undertake "serious commitments" to save Southeast Asia from being overrun by the Communists.
LONDON, May 7 (AP) -- Roger Bannister's whirlwind mile kept Britain at home tonight.

The fall of Dienbienphu induced speculator buying on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday. Prices closed generally higher. Volume was light, influenced by the usual week-end evening of positions. Cocoa, coffee, soybean oil, wool, rubber, burlap, lead and zinc ended higher; sugar, cottonseed oil, potatoes, copper and tin were mixed, and hides and silk moved lower.

Prison cells didn't bar Hunter College juniors from emerging victorious at the college's thirty-eighth annual "Sing" competitition yesterday when they sang of the "Bars and Stripes" of prison life. They bewailed having to pound the kind of rocks that aren't "A Girl's Best Friend."

It still takes longer to cross the Atlantic Ocean by even the fastest planes than it does to get one s baggage through the customs after one arrives. However, the margin is being narrowed. Year by year man's ingenuity increases the speed of his travel and, despite some setbacks, speed is not necessarily dangerous.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) -- Judge Gerald F. Flood today issued an injunction against mass picketing at twelve Philco Corporation plants in the Philadelphia area.
Scholars and skippers will start learning a little more about each other this autumn when a new "adopt-a-ship" plan gets under way.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of an affidavit made by Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker on Feb. 20, as made public by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations after striking its "confidential" label:

GENEVA, May 7 -- French and Communist bloc officials exchanged bitter recriminations here today over who was responsible for the delays that had prevented the evacuation of French Union wounded from Dienbienphu before the isolated jungle outpost fell.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Army today announced rejection of all six bids, including the Japanese low offer, for construction of sixteen hydraulic turbine governors for The Dalles dam in Oregon.

The New York City Housing Authority was cautioned yesterday against setting itself up as the keeper of its tenants' morals. The warning was sounded by Justice Maxwell Shapiro as he dismissed an eviction petition filed by the authority.
MOSCOW, Saturday, May 8 -- The Soviet Government in a statement by the Tass news agency today expressed an interest in the improvement of relations with Britain.

Penelope, the platypus who once almost convinced the Bronx Zoo that there would be a need for tiny platypusian garments, met her mate, Cecil, for the first time yesterday since she was exposed as a clever little actress last November. The meeting was not harmonious.

DURING this month, New York University's Catholic Center will honor the Marian Year by showing, at Sixty-nine Washington Square South, an exhibition of art objects, from the Middle Ages to the present, portraying the Madonna.
TOKYO, May 7 (AP) -- Two Japanese scientists said today that the United States apparently had exploded a fourth hydrogen bomb at Bikini between April 25 and 27.
The need for slum clearance and public housing is being obscured by national real estate interests, it was charged last night by Ira S. Robbins, president of the National Housing Conference.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) -- First Baseman Rocky Nelson, obtained from the Dodgers' Montreal farm last October by the Cleveland Indians, was sold back to that International League Club by the Tribe today.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., May 7 -- Express, 17-month-old orange and white pointer owned by Alfred Scarenellie of Rutherford, N. J., and handled by George Stymiest of Lambertville, won the open derby stake as the twenty-seventh spring program of the Southern New York Field Trial Club started today.

GENEVA, May 7 -- The United States, Britain and France decided tonight to go ahead with the opening of the Indo-China negotiations here tomorrow despite the capture of Dienbienphu. Their decision, however, was made subject to the action of the French Cabinet.
Improved communications between the nutrition educator and the public was discussed yesterday at the first session of a two-day meeting at New York University.

Advertising for Old Stagg Bourbon, a Kentucky straight whisky, will be stepped up sharply late this month, with color copy going into national magazines in addition to a regular schedule in daily newspapers and other media. The expanded list will be used throughout the year, according to Jerry Eisnitz, Old Stagg advertising manager for Schenley Distributors, Inc.

Police protection for city subway riders and career protection for policewomen were the main subjects for discussion yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, Inc.
VANCOUVER, B. C., May 7 (Canadian Press) -- Sugar Ray Robinson said today that he was not "coddled" in the Air Corps.
When the second week of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches was completed yesterday, in one district only the champion remained in front.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, today denied reports that he had blocked a new diplomatic assignment for John J. Muccio, former United States Ambassador to Korea and veteran Foreign Service officer.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of the United States note delivered in Moscow today in reply to the Soviet note of March 31 on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (similar notes were sent by Britain and France):

Drastic changes in the operation of Columbia College's two secret societies were demanded by the student body in a referendum, the results of which were made public yesterday. The balloting, in which 55 per cent of the students voted, took place Wednesday and Thursday.

Outerwear manufacturers, generally, sold more goods in 1953 but failed to make more money than in the previous year. Looking ahead, they are pretty evenly divided as to whether 1954 will be better, worse, or the same as 1953.
FORT WORTH, Tex., May 7 (AP) -- The Air Force put into effect today a policy outlawing the sonic boom.

The police and prosecuting attorneys are privileged to refuse to disclose the identity of informers. The reason for this privilege is that it tends to help the police and prosecuting attorneys to apprehend and punish law violators. A legislator, neither individually nor in his capacity as representative of an investigating committee, has the duty to apprehend and prosecute law violators
The following is a round-up of household hints that may be of interest to the homemaker.

Women headed by Mrs. H. Oothout-Milliken are aiding in the sale of tickets for a party in behalf of the Social Service Auxiliary to Bellevue Hospital, Inc., to be held at the concert on June 28 at the Lewisohn Stadium.

The Collegiate Chorale, augmented by the New Haven Chorale to the impressive number of some 175 voices, performed Brahms' "German" Requiem last night at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine). Robert Shaw conducted.
CHICAGO, May 7 -- An organization called "For America" was founded today to combat "super-internationalism and interventionism" in both political parties and work for political realignment.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State predicted tonight that the current efforts toward collective defense in Southeast Asia ultimately would halt Communist aggression short of its aims.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Eisenhower assured President Rene Coty of France today that "the free world will remain faithful to the causes" for which French soldiers fought in Dienbienphu.

HAVING measured up to the protective standards of Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., a man to conjure with these days in off-Broadway circles, the Two By Four Productions opened for business Thursday night at 83 East Fourth Street with a presentation of "Building Blocks," a new drama by Eugene Feist.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 7 -- The Flying Boxcar reported earlier today to be missing blew up yesterday on a supply drop mission to Dienbienphu, killing its two United States civilian pilots and the French crew chief.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., May 7 (AP) -- Ellis Taylor, of Wilmington, Del., the 1953 victor, and Frank Allen, of Pittston, Pa., a two-time winner, passed their first-round tests in the thirty-first annual Shawnee invitation golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The rather long, thin face of a mild-looking man approaching middle age, with sparse blondish hair, has become one of the most frequently seen countenances on the screens of those watching the McCarthy-Army hearings by television.

Charles C. Parlin, a New York attorney and prominent Methodist layman, criticized sharply last night the practices of some Congressional investigating committees. He said they were "indefensible, inconsistent with the traditional rights of free citizens, and do violence to the principles of fair treatment which a citizen has a right to expect from his Government."

Zinc shipments last month were at the highest level since July, and smelters' stocks of unsold metal, after climbing for ten consecutive months, finally leveled off and then declined by a small amount.

PARIS, May 7 -- The French Assembly heard Premier Joseph Laniel's statement on the fall of Dienbienphu in utter silence and adjourned for half an hour late this afternoon as a sign of mourning and respect for the valiant dead.

Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker, commandant at Camp Kilmer, N. J., whose name figured prominently at yesterday's session of the McCarthy-Army hearings, testified at a closed hearing of the McCarthy investigating subcommittee the afternoon of Feb. 18 in the United States Court House in Foley Square.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Eisenhower presented American Automobile Association gold medals today to eight teen-agers who had risked death to save lives.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture, in a final report today, said the 1953 cotton crop totaled 16,465,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight with a farm value of $2,651,675,000.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 7. -- Four hundred Greenwich carpenters, who struck Monday in a demand for a $1 a day wage increase, won their fight late last night. The Greenwich Building Industries Association granted the rise and signed a one-year contract.
The Association for the Help of Retarded Children will honor Arthur Levitt, Brooklyn member of the Board of Education, at its annual dinner in the Astor Hotel on May 22.

The Hancock Oil Company, in its report yesterday covering the nine months ended March 31, showed an increase in net income to $5,131,566 from $3,048,433 earned in the similar period of the previous year.

Today's new film is "Prisoner of War," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama of the recent Korean conflict, at the Victoria Theatre. Ronald Reagan, Steve Forrest, Dewey Martin, Oscar Homolka, Robert Horton and Paul Stewart head the cast. Henry Berman produced and Andrew Marton directed, from a screen play by Allen Rivkin.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 7 -- The Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., today approved the no-raiding pact between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
LONDON, May 7 (AP) -- The International Sugar Council today estimated free market requirements this year for raw sugar at 3,864,000 metric tons and cut all exports quotas by 5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, said today that practically no immigrants had been admitted under the emergency immigration program and it "is in danger of complete disintegration."
A Greenwich Village gunsmith collapsed in General Sessions yesterday as he was sentenced to an indeterminate term in the penitentiary for the sale of an unregistered weapon.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Senate passed and sent to President Eisenhower today a $505,218,000 appropriations bill carrrying $15,000,000 to help combat dust storms in the Southwest.
ARDMORE, Okla., May 7 (AP) -- Julius Boros of Mid Pines, N. C., maintained his lead in the Ardmore open golf tournament today with his second sub-par round.
PARIS, May 7 -- The fall of Dienbienphu was announced today by Premier Joseph Laniel.
ALBANY, May 7 -- Of 990 who took the March examination for admission to the bar, 410 passed, the State Board of Law Examiners announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A Missouri Democrat told the Senate today that President Eisenhower must assume full responsibility for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's "attacks, threats and pressures" on Administration officials.
Mrs. Wheeler H. Tolbert of Columbus, Ga., 65-year-old mother of five sons, was saluted here yesterday as "The American Mother of the Year."
LONDON, May 7 (UP) -- Roger Bannister, Britain's fabulous foot racer, said today he would try soon to break his new world mile record before someone else did.

BOSTON, May 7 (UP) -- The Boston Red Sox weathered a homer barrage by the Washington Senators tonight to take a 7-6 victory that ended a four-game losing streak and a twenty-one inning scoring drought.

CINCINNATI, May 7 (AP) -- Johnny Temple, Cincinnati second baseman, stole home tonight -- the third time he's turned the trick this season -- to give the Redlegs their last run as they routed the St. Louis Cardinals, 10 -- 3.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 7 -- Declines in business and in employment are at an end, the Business Advisory Council informed Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, today.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee said today communism was on the wane in most of the free world but wields a strong influence at the polls in France and Italy and poses a danger to Guatemala.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) The Army regulation cited by Brig. Gen. Ralph Zwicker in declining to answer some questions asked by Senator Joseph R. McCarty in New York hearings several months ago is based upon an Executive directive by former President Truman on March 13, 1948.
The Yankees still are in their batting slump. They made only three hits off Morrie Martin at the Stadium yesterday.

LONDON, May 7 -- Industrial shares took over from Government issues as the pacemaker in a continued advance by the stock markets here today. The Financial Times industrial ordinary share index regained the peak level of 147.1, last touched on April 23, as a result of widespread gains, generally of about one shilling threepence (17 1/2 cents).
A strong protest was sent yesterday to Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina by the American Society of Civil Engineers against a proposal to obtain engineering services through competitive bids.

A bill to deny second and third-class mailing privileges to mailers of Communist and other subversive propaganda will be introduced in Congress next week, according to its author, Representative Katharine St. George, Republican of New York.
Church women in the United States met in hundreds of communities yesterday to consider their roles in the nation's economic life.

Princess Ileana of Rumania told a Congressional committee yesterday that as early as 1946 Ana Pauker, later Communist foreign minister of Rumania, had anticipated a Red attempt to infiltrate the American electrical industry.
YONKERS, May 7 -- The strike of horsemen that shut down the Yonkers Raceway last night was settled early today and tonight the trotters and pacers were in action again.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- Announcement that the French had lost the long besieged fort in Indo-China turned a weak market into a strong one in Board of Trade operations today. Traders feared this development might have more war-like significance.
MONTREAL, May 7 -- This port, Canada's largest, had mixed feelings today over the ultimate effects of the St. Lawrence Seaway project.

BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP) -- Roaring Bull, with Nick Shuk aboard, drove to a length-and-a-quarter victory in the $4,000 Homeland Purse today at Pimlico as the Maryland Jockey Club track opened its eighteen-day spring meeting.

ST. LOUIS, May 7 -- Chinese Communist attempts to create confusion, disloyalty and doubts about this country's role were highly effective among American prisoners captured during the Korean war, an Army psychiatrist said here today.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Representatives of the United States, Britain, France, Australia and New Zealand will meet next week at a place still undesignated to chart "united action" in Southeast Asia, State Department officials disclosed today.
LONDON, May 7 -- The Chinese-Soviet alliance was reported hare today to be showing signs of strain both at the Geneva conference and in China.
The American Hotel Association says that public acceptance of its new "universal" type credit plan has reached a peak of 1,500 applications a week.

ROME, May 7 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, Wimbledon champion, had to call upon all of his resources today to halt Australia's Jack Arkinstall in a two and one-half hour match in gaining the quarter-finals of Italy's international tennis tournament.
" Grow your own lemons!" the advertisement in the magazine shouted. "Grow a lemon plant in a pot, right in your own home! Beautiful plants, only two dollars each!"
BEACONSFIELD, England, May 7 -- Aneurin Bevan, leader of the Labor party's Leftists, was found guilty today of dangerous driving and of having failed to stop after his car had collided with a bus.

SAN LEANDRO, Calif., May 7 -- The Chrysler Corporation announced today it would close its multi-million dollar assembly and body plant here by the end of the year. It plans to consolidate all of its West Coast passenger car assembly and body operations in its Los Angeles plant.
OTTAWA, May 7 (Canadian Press) -- The flow of capital into Canada through international securities trading rose sharply in February as sales by Canadians increased and purchases declined.

John and Alexander Dalessio, who were reputed to have run a bookmaking syndicate on Staten Island with police protection, were sentenced yesterday to eighteen-month penitentiary terms by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court. They had pleaded guilty to income tax evasion charges on April 4.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, said today that any newspaper men called as witnesses in the Army-McCarthy hearings would not be pressed to disclose their sources of information.

HANOI, Vienam, May 7 -- The Vietminh insurgents punched a hole into the southwest sector of Dienbienphu last night and artillery overran two positions on the northeastern and eastern sides of the French perimeter.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 3 points lower than on Thursday to 16 points higher yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Unemployment declined in April and employment rose, but the changes were attributed to seasonal factors.

GUATEMALA, May 7 -- Guatemalan Roman Catholics have been showering Archbishop Mariano Rossell y Arellano with letters of support and solidarity for his recent pastoral letter condemning communism and appealing to Guatemalan Catholics to rise as one man against it as an enemy of God and country.

Hats, which have sometimes been considered by the uninformed man as the true reason for clubwomen's meetings, have no bearing on matters conducted by one woman's group in town.
OTTAWA, May 7 -- Official Ottawa did not share today in the rejoicing of many Canadian cities and inland harbors over the final approval by Congress of its St. Lawrence Seaway bill.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to the St. Lawrence Seaway bill.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 7 -- M. D Clark, a Woodbury, Conn., mink rancher, won the doubles trapshooting title today after a shoot-off with H. L. McKinley of Harrisburg, Ohio, as the Amateur Championships of America got under way at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island traps.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 -- Frank Sinatra and Doris Day will be teamed by Warner Brothers in a musical inspired by the current song hit, "Young at Heart," recorded by Mr. Sinatra and composed by Johnny Richards and Carolyn Leigh.
The growth of airline cargo operations during the postwar years is now lagging behind that of passenger traffic. So the International Air Transport Association is backing a drive to re-stimulate it.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 7 -- Dick Allsbrook, an unrated pitcher in Brown's pre-season estimates, stopped Columbia, 1 -- 0, on one hit today and faced twenty-eight batters in doing so.

Events today: Queens College Orchestral Society, Jamaica High School Auditorium, Jamaica N. Y., 2:30 P. M.; Hilda Gailans soprano, and Vsevolod Karaghioz tenor, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; Fordham University School of Education Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; Harry Mayer, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 7 -- Richard G. Casey, Minister for External Affairs, said today the only long-range hope for world peace was for communism and the democracies to live side by side in peaceful coexistence. He made the statement as he returned from the Geneva conference.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The House of Representatives subcommittee investigating alleged "coddling" of athletes by the Army was left confused tonight over a former welterweight and middleweight boxing champion, Sugar Ray Robinson.

Walter B. Holt, first vice president of the old International Longshoreman's Association, testified yesterday that it was not his understanding that the union's executive council had authorized Joseph P. Ryan, former I. L. A. president, to use the I. L. A. Journal's funds for personal matters.
Carloadings on the Pennsylvania Railroad's lines in April ran 22 per cent behind those of the like month of 1953, David C. Bevan, vice president in charge of finance, estimated yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Don Newcombe tonight ended a six-game winning streak for the Phillies when he pitched the Dodgers to a 3-1 triumph before 14,743 chilled and damp fans at Connie Mack Stadium.

BAYONNE, N. J., May 7 -- The announcement by the Tide Water Associated Oil Company that it plans to build a new $75,000,000 refinery elsewhere on the East Coast to replace the company's local Constable Hook plant has city officials and the refinery's 1,200 employes here both puzzled and worried today.
Some people still have money to save and others just want free ball point pens and plastic "piggy" banks. Both types were accomodated yesterday and the day before by the Union Dime Savings Bank.
A traveling centenarian, just returned from his winter holiday in the South, has decided he doesn't like Florida any more. Next year, he's going to Arizona for a real vacation.

Edward C. Bonia has been appointed manager of dealer relations for the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation.

The Cities Service Company and its subsidiaries had a net income of $15,612,623 in the first quarter this year, compared with $16,227,734 for the corresponding 1953 period, W. Alton Jones, chairman, reported yesterday.
ALBANY, May 7 -- The Public Works Department estimated today that New York would get $113,000,000 of the $1,932,000,000 in Federal highway grants authorized by President Eisenhower yesterday.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 7 -- A pipe of peace will be smoked in the Town Hall here tomorrow morning when Fairfield County commuters meet formally with executives of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

The difficulty that the City of New York has in balancing its budget can be partially attributed to those properties which do not pay their full share of real estate taxes. Often the waiver or reduction of real estate taxes is justified by social, religious or charitable reasons.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 7 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, arrived here tonight with Mrs. Stevens for a week-end of relaxation after his repeated appearances on the stand before the Senate subcommittee investigating the controversy between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and his department.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is apparently the only "principal" in the current Senate hearings on his dispute with the Army who feels the need of a bodyguard.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The White House today announced the appointment of Rear Admiral Alfred C. Richmond as Commandant of the United States Coast Guard. He has been Assistant Commandant.

PITTSBURGH, May 7 -- The 1,250,000-member United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., intends to boycott the no-raiding pact between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

NEW HAVEN, May 7 -- The 1,200-page manuscript of Alexis de Tocqueville's "Democracy in America," considered by some authorities to be the most famous commentary on democracy in the United States has been given to the Yale University Library.

An unscheduled performance by a Shakespeare-loving barge captain disrupted the annual meeting of the Shakespeare Club of New York last night. The meeting, in the paneled library of the sedate old National Arts Club at 15 Gramercy Park, opened quietly enough. On the agenda were the election of officers, the selection of four plays to be read next year, and the repair of Shakespeare's bust in Central Park.
Spring has come and with it another attempt at Pop concerts in Carnegie Hall. The opening concert of a series embracing three week-ends took place last night under unusual circumstances.
The liner Homeric, most recent addition to the fleet of the Home Lines, is now on her way to Monfalcone, Italy, on the Adriatic for the final phase of her rebuilding into a de luxe cruise liner.

YONKERS, May 7 (AP) -- Scotch Spencer won the $6,000 Concourse free-for-all pace tonight in 2:03 3/5. Cecil Champion piloted Scotch Spencer to a nose victory over Prince Adios. Irish Hal was third. The winner returned $18.90, $7.30 and $4.40 for $2.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Norman P. Mason, acting Federal Housing Administrator, charged today that the agency's counsel, Burton C. Bovard, had failed to do his job "satisfactorily" and gave him fourteen days to answer the charges or be dismissed.
A police sergeant who had pounded the pavement for many wearisome hours objected yesterday to someone else tearing it up.

Mayor Wagner was asked yesterday to discuss with a "top committee" of outstanding business men next Wednesday a "sound nonpartisan" proposal for added city revenue. The adoption of it would make unnecessary the extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services, the civic group said.

Supermarkets are strong advocates of prepackaged produce because this type of merchandising lends itself to self-service operations. But two recently conducted studies indicate that shoppers are not entirely in favor of vegetables sold ready packed in polyethylene bags, cardboard cartons or other containers.

The fifth annual Armed Forces Day, that occasion on which the United States shows its steel and atomic muscles to impress both friends and enemies throughout the world, will be celebrated next Saturday.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Ants have found peony buds, and aphids the new leaves of roses, hawthorn and crabapple trees and some perennials. Ants do not harm peonies, but aphids reduce a plant's vigor. The standard control for aphids is spraying with nicotine sulfate, according to manufacturer's directions.

EXPERIMENT stations, particularly in New England, have been warning for months about the expected outbreak of gypsy moth this spring. The forecast is that it will be the greatest in years and, therefore, control measures should start in early May.
American business as a whole did surprisingly well in the first quarter of this year.

BY its decision to make the long-anticipated "Harvard Guide to American History" the first imprint of the Belknap Press, the Harvard University Press made a wise choice and has set a very high standard for future publications.

BOSTON -- Tourists heading into New England during the 1954 vacation season will benefit from a lively competition that has developed between the burgeoning motel business and the standard hotels. Handy to almost every key city in the region, the luxury motel has finally come into its own.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 8 -The Egyptian Government is reported to have demanded that Lebanon extradite or expel Mahmoud Abul Fath, convicted Cairo newspaper owner, or face serious economic sanctions.
QUEEN ELIZABETH'S visit this week to her Crown Colony of Gibraltar once again is provoking manifestations of Spanish displeasure over the presence of the British enclave in the Iberian Peninsula.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 -The establishment of an official labor-management committee to help revive San Francisco's waterfront industry was urged this week by George Christopher, president of the city-county Board of Supervisors.
PARIS, May 8 -- The ninth anniversary of victory over Germany was observed here today by Frenchmen too struck by the defeat at Dienbienphu to feel any joy.
ROME, May 8 -- Premier Mario Scelba barred Communist newspaper men from his own office and from all ministries today.

CLIMBING roses, long-time favorites, will be useful in many ways to the new home owner. Whether trained along a rustic fence or stone wall, grown over an arbor for shade or planted simply to climb over a well house, trellis or embankment, this type of rose is most satisfactory.

MIAMI BEACH -- The pace has eased off in this great big resort which is famous for the drive and bustle and excitement of its peak seasons. The February season (which now runs through March and into April) is officially ended and the summer traffic does not pick up heavily until June.

SEOUL, Korea, May 8 -- Indo-China has become the focal point in the struggle between democracy and communism, and the fate of all Southeast Asia hangs in the balance. THE English Royal Academy of Arts still trails clouds of ritualistic glory from its own past. The headlines which caught my eye read: "Father No Longer King in His Castle, Sociologist Tells Catholic Parley -- Success Often Leads to Failure as Family Head."

PROFESSOR of Political Science at Vanderbilt University, Alex N. Dragnich served with the United States Information Service in Belgrade during three critical years ending in 1950. He returned to Yugoslavia in the summer of 1952, after he had left government service.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 8 -- Lester Washburn, international president of the United Automobile Workers Union, A. F. L., resigned today in protest over the failure of a majority of his union's executive board to support him "in cleaning up the New York situation."

Vinylite record manufacturers and producers of raw film are uneasy. A competitive upstart, magnetic tape, is rapidly catching on in many fields heretofore believed by the makers of the relatively older products to be exclusively their own.

THE time is midway of World War II. The oil-tanker Richard, steaming sluggishly from Australia to Iran, is sighted by a Jap submarine. A torpedo attack, followed by shelling, sends her to the bottom. Forty men have somehow miraculously survived. They pile into a 24-foot lifeboat built to accommodate thirty-three passengers in emergency and head for Africa, 1,500 miles to the west.

BALBOA, C. Z., May 8 -- Threatened for the first time since its official completion in 1920 with serious misfortune not of military origin, the Panama Canal this week quietly passed its fiftieth anniversary as a United States enterprise.

TULIP time is here and, of course, festivities are planned. The one that is closest to metropolitan New York dwellers is the fifth annual bulb festival at the Queens Botanical Garden, in Flushing Meadow Park.
ALBANY, May 8 (AP) -- The New York National Guard said today that a ceiling might be clamped on its enlistments because of budgetary limitations.

ASIDE from the actual deliberations of the Big Four and Communist China, the Swiss in Geneva have not experienced such a flurry of community comings and goings since the days when the old League of Nations convened in the same impressive Palais des Nations in which the fate of Asia is being deliberated today.
YONKERS, May 8 (AP) -- Andrew Patch, driven by Stan Adams, won the $5,000 pacing feature over a slow track at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -Representative W. Sterling Cole said today that tight new restrictions on the dissemination of atomic information had been added to a bill that is before Congress.

MOSCOW, May 8 -- Despite cordial expressions by both the Soviet Union and Britain, diplomatic observers in Moscow remained skeptical that any general relaxation of tension between the two powers was possible at this time.

COLDITZ CASTLE, some twenty miles southeast of Leipzig, was a very special prisoner -of-war camp. Its inmates were Allied officers whom the Nazis considered particularly troublesome -- men who had attempted at least once to escape from less well-protected camps and who were finally sent off to Colditz because its grim and towering walls seemed reasonably impervious to any but the most harebrained escape attempts.
GIBRALTAR, May 8 -- This usually bleak, forbidding British fortress is today the brightest spot in the Mediterranean.

IT is not surprising that golfer Jimmy Demaret, three-time winner of the Masters Tournament, decided to set down some thoughts about Ben Hogan, who won the Masters, the U. S. Open and the British Open in 1953.

Most seagoing freighters when laden draw twenty or more feet of water. Between Duluth on Lake Superior at the western end of the Great Lakes chain and Ogdensburg, 1,200 miles away on the St. Lawrence River, there is, or soon will be, at least twenty-five feet of water throughout the entire route.

HANOVER, N. H., May 8 (AP) -- Yale won the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association team title for the second straight year today. The Elis had a fourteen stroke margin and a 603 total on the Hanover Country Club's 5,290-yard, par-70 layout.

THERE was a three-hour session in a sixth-floor studio on West Forty-ninth Street last Tuesday that cast a revealing light both on our musical riches and on our failure to make the most effective use of them.

PERHAPS this should be called "The Diary of a City Exhibitor." In any case, I wish to state my position concerning L'Affaire Bresson and the American editing of that director's film, "The Diary of a Country Priest."

A draw was recorded for the eighth time in the match for the chess championship of the world between Mikhail Botvinnik, the titleholder, and Vassily Smyslov in Moscow when they completed the twenty-first game of the series, according to a report received yesterday from London.

A MONTH-TO-MONTH study of the record catalogues shows how one consequence of the LP process has been the filling in of the lesser known areas in the outputs of the great composers. More and more, the listings of recordings available are coming to resemble the complete catalogues of the works of the major composers.

JERUSALEM, May 2 -- A revolution in the schooling of Israel's children has taken place in the last seven months. The change from the "trend" system to public education involved strongly held social and religious convictions, but there has been almost no controversy.

What makes the streets of one city safer than another? The Associated Press asked several of the cities cited for outstanding traffic safety campaigns at a White House conference for the answer. Here is a summary of their reports:
COLUMBIA, S. C., May 8 -- The State Highway Department announced today that competitive bids for engineering services on $3,500,000 worth of proposed bridges would be accepted Tuesday as requested.
Vertical flight for passengers aboard commercial aircraft will be studied soon.
CHICAGO, May 8 -- Six Eastern daily newspapers and one weekly have been named by the National Safety Council as recipients of its 1953 Public Interest Award.

IT is safe to say that vegetables have streaks of popularity. For in the past certain ones have been grown on gardens and farms throughout the world and then gradually faded into obscurity. Often a revival occurs.

MR. WEST labels certain inconsistencies and inaccuracies in the book as "too trivial" to discuss. I might suggest that Mr. West tabulate the unusually large number of proper names misspelled in the book. * * * Is it too trivial to indicate that Mr. Panikkar's book cites a notorious forger as authority?
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -Senator Wayne L. Morse charged today that the Administration had decided to put "working people, family farmers and small business men * * * through an economic wringer."

The United States lost the MIG-15 jet fighter plane to the Russians, it was testified here yesterday, because a skeptical Army officer refused in 1946 to grant political asylum to a German aircraft designer.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- Seeing even the most important points of interest in areas as large as the Southwest poses a problem to tourists traveling on a rigid time schedule but wishing to absorb as much as they can of the culture of the regions they traverse.

ABUNDANCE is the dominant impression one gets of the Northwest. Everything is in profusion -- trees, wildlife, water, flowered orchards, leaping salmon in the rivers. Even the vast interior desert of sagebrush is split by the mighty Columbia, champing in a deep lava gorge.

THE world of 2020, governed by a revamped and strengthened United Nations dubbed InterCos, somehow fails in this novel to generate any sustained reader interest. While handled ably enough, the ingredients of the story are all too familiar; there are the usual invaders from outer space, toting their invincible weapons, and there's the usual lone Terran scientist whose Cassandra voice goes unheeded while the delegates to InterCos play an intricate game of power politics.
LOUISVILLE, May 8 (UP) -The commanding general of Fort Knox was ordered yesterday to appear in Federal court Monday to show cause why a New York Army private should not be released from service.

ST. PETERSBURG -- For many, many years tourist Florida advertised itself as a place for Northerners to thaw out in winter; the switch to inducing these same Northerners to come here in summer because it is cooler than many places above the Mason and Dixon Line presented difficulties, even for the natives.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 8 -Bank robbers sent up their own smoke signals tonight in a local bank when their acetylene torch burned into canvas money bags and bellowed wisps of tell-tale gray into the street.

VERY near the end of her long life Ninon de Lenclos, heroine of this first novel, imagines herself conversing with God. She is relieved to learn that Hell will not, after all, be the penalty for her many amorous adventures. A compassionate Voice persuades her that her life has been commendable -- for, passion aside, it has been rich with kindness and a sense of humor.

There is so much good sense in the program of the two-day water safety conference to be held later this month in Illinois, that a hundred -- perhaps thousands -- of municipalities, counties, states, park departments, and boating groups elsewhere could with profit plan something similar.

GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., May 8 -- Steady rain hampered the bird work for the open all-age stake which marked the second day of the Southern New York Field Trial Club's twenty-seventh annual spring trials today.

No matter where they go this week - end -- north, south, east or west -- motorists will see a fine display of blossoms. To begin with, dogwood is "all around" and azaleas and tulips are coming to the fore.

LOTS of people who vacation on a Caribbean island call what they are doing "getting away from it all." But it is one thing to stay in a hotel, drink rum punches and read "Robinson Crusoe." It is quite another actually to live the part.

PARIS, May 8 -- The fall of Dienbienphu has deepened the feeling among the French that they have been seriously "let down" by their Allies. But the French have been just as much at sea about their own Government's policy as they are about what Washington has promised or what Britain plans.
From the low point registered in mid-September of last year, the stock market has risen between 20 and 24 per cent, according to the measuring rods used.

CHICAGO -- While Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Minnesota are offering improved facilities, new motels and refurbished parks, Wisconsin still appears to hold the edge for the region in vacation offerings.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Defense Department has this much in common with the average American housewife: It can't help snatching a few minutes from routine chores to watch the Army-McCarthy show on television.

MONTICELLO -- In an admirable tribute to the Jones brothers -- Samuel Frisbee and John Paul, who founded Monticello exactly 150 years ago -- the menfolk of this outsize Catskill village have taken en masse to emulating, of all people, the Smith Brothers.
Respect for parents is akin to respect for God, Rabbi O. Asher Reichel said yesterday in a Mother's Day sermon at the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street.

MILWAUKEE, May 8 (UP) -Chet Nichols, back with the Milwaukee Braves after two years in the Army, pitched almost perfect ball for six innings today and then held on to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 3 -- 2, on eight hits.

A STANDARD list of composers is represented on a pair of ten-inch LPs by George Byron, Rediscovered Gershwin (Atlantic) and A Memo From Jerome Kern (Atlantic). Byron has a pleasant, carefully articulated baritone which is at its best in the Gershwin numbers, particularly The Half of It Dearie Blues, Back Bay Polka and Lorelei.

PARIS -- Visitors to France who want to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the country's liberation from the Nazis can do it virtually any time from June 5 to next February 12. Driving the Germans out of France took slightly more than ight months, and almost every community from Cherbourg to Metz and from Marseille to Strasbourg has decided to celebrate the anniversary of its own deliverance.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Ever since the Republic was founded, controversy has arisen from time to time over the right of the Executive Branch to deny information to the Legislative Branch.

DURING the three years in which the fate of Maj. Gen. William Dean was a distressing mystery to the American people (though it was known in official circles that he was still alive), there was hot argument in the Army about the circumstance attending his disappearance.
MOSCOW, May 8 (AP) -- The first Soviet press comment today hailed the fall of the Indo-China fortress of Dienbienphu as a great setback for the French "colonizers" and "American aggressive circles."

PUBLIC opinion, we are told, inclines strongly to the idea that the repute of the United States Senate has gone into a decline. It is said that it has lost much of its prestige and dignity in the public eye and there is a feeling that it must radically change its procedures.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Holiday travel, not political problems, will occupy scores of Government officials this week here at the world capitol on the East River. The visiting officials have been called together for a world parley on tourism. Its purpose is to cut through the web of customs regulations and red tape which seem to confront the traveler -- and particularly the motorist -- at almost every frontier.

Business in the city's department stores in the past week was better than expected but the strength did not come from Mother's Day promotions. In such items as summer furniture and white goods results were unexpected good.

MORE than twenty years ago, a remarkable bridge hand was dealt, bid and played in a casual game of rubber bridge at a New York club. It resulted in a zero score (declarer went down one, not vulnerable, and offset the loss with 100 for honors), so it should not have been very significant.

MOSCOW, May 8 -- The first ten days of the Geneva conference, in the opinion of the Russian press, have gone badly for the United States. One Pravda headline summed up the American position after more than a week of discussions as "policy doomed to defeat."
HARTFORD, May 8 -- The Connecticut Democrats will hold their state nominating convention in Hartford late in June or early in July.

EDWARD ELY was a versatile young American -- a physician who turned sailor and returned to medicine while serving as United States Consul at Bombay, India, where cholera ended his career at the age of 31.

The Brooklyn Council for Social Planning, 30 Third Avenue, yesterday urged establishment of a recreation planning division within the City Planning Commission and modifications in the plans of the $3,000,000 St. John's Recreation Center in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn.

The deep-throated whistles of outbound ocean liners were very much audible last week as eleven passenger ships, carrying 9,500 Europe-bound tourists, headed out to sea in the first heavy week of the annual travel exodus.

CONTRARY to popular misconception, the Midwest, from the lakes of Minnesota and Wisconsin and the Great Lakes down through Illinois and Indiana and Ohio, is not barren flat land, always more of the same.

IF the economic indicators are considered, most business men are willing to concede that a slight upturn is evident, as pointed out by President Eisenhower last week. The improvement however, is not reflected in increased sales for the average merchant or manufacturer.
LONDON, May 8 -- The British Government has demanded the recall of two military air attaches of the Soviet Embassy here on the ground of attempted espionage in this country.

MOOSE, Wyo. -- The more you see of Grand Teton National Park, which this year is observing the twenty-fifth anniversary of its establishment, the more you want to linger. For the Grand Teton country of Alpine peaks, gleaming glaciers, sparkling lakes and fragrant forests captures your fancy and imagination immediately, and makes you want to stay indefinitely to enjoy its wealth of scenic beauty, wholesome recreation and fine amenities.

Pledges of unity in the struggle against the spread of Communist dictatorship were exchanged yesterday by representatives of Great Britain, France and the United States at a ceremony opening the fifth annual Armed Forces Week in New York.

WATERTON PARK, Canada -- At the entrance to Glacier Park the little settlement of Saint Mary nestles on the shore of Saint Mary Lake among high, evergreenclad mountains. It has somehow a hidden atmosphere, yet it is cozy too.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 8 -- The New York State College of Agriculture at Cornell University will observe its fiftieth anniversary tomorrow.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 8 -Army's track and field team compiled 93 1/3 points to win a triangular meet from Pennsylvania and the Quantico Marine Corps today. The Quakers finished second with 50 points while the Marines were limited to 28 2/3.

DALLAS, May 8 -- Employment in the Southwest registered its usual seasonal rise in April. Although the hiring of new workers in some areas set high marks for the year, placements were still well below year-ago figures, Texas Employment Commission officials reported.
FOLLOWING are excerpts from comments on some of the exhibitions reviewed in The Times during the week just closed:
LONDON, May 8 -- The plodding, earnest, moderate leadership of Britain's Labor party this week turned sharply on its most persistent heckler, Aneurin Bevan.

EVEN a quick tour through New York will reveal to the family with an eye on its budget that if it isn't altogether averse to roughing it a bit, the state parks are the place to vacation. While the cabins or tents in the parks are not the most luxurious living quarters in the world, they can be comfortable and, for the city dweller, much fun.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 8 -- The Chief Minister of East Pakistan has brought a storm of denunciation down upon himself by criticizing the partition of Pakistan from India.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 8 -Dr. Albert Einstein, world-renowned physicist, emerged from his usual seclusion briefly this week to accept a gift on behalf of the Elsa and Albert Einstein School in Ben Shemen, Israel.

MAY is the hospitable month, a season of open house and garden. The City Gardens Club of New York, 829 Madison Avenue, will again open a series of Manhattan gardens to the public on Tuesday from 2:30 to 6 P. M. Admission to the six terrace or court gardens to be visited goes toward the fund for the furtherance of natural science study in public schools.
In celebration of Hospital Week, officially announced by Mayor Wagner, several municipal hospitals will be staging "at homes" for the public this week.

GENEVA, May 8 -- The United States delegation wishes to break off negotiations with the Communists here on the question of Korea unless the Communists accept United Nations supervision of elections in North Korea, American sources said today.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy struck on a variety of fronts this week in defending himself and two key aides against Army charges they had improperly used the investigative power of the Senate to seek special treatment for an Army private.

CROYDON, England, May 8 (UP) -- Doris Hart, the slender Florida player captured her second British tennis title in a week today by defeating England's Shirley Bloomer, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, in the women's singles final at the Shirley Park tournament.

Improved management of city departments and services in 195: resulted in money savings of $2,770,551, potential savings of $3,639,754 and increased revenue of $2,777,134, according to a report issued yesterday by the city's Board of Management Improvement.

Columbia's heavyweight varsity crew made its best showing of the season yesterday in defeating Boston University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology eights on the Harlem. Rowing two miles downstream in a rain that drenched the oarsmen and a handful of spectators on the river's banks, the Lions, stroked by John Pepas, made it an allthe-way-in-front victory.

The introduction of the first mercury in glass thermometers (generally credited to Fahrenheit in the year 1794) was undoubtedly one of the historic contributions to science. It doesn't follow from that fact, however, that everyone should carry a thermometer with him at all times as he goes about his affairs, stopping once every hour, on the hour, to take his temperature.
Much slum property is so weighted down with mortgages that the owner has little incentive to pay for needed repairs, according to Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh.

WINDOW ROCK, Ariz. -"Roads impassable in wet weather. Make local inquiry." -- "Navajo Indian Reservation. Proceed at your own risk." -- Those ominous signs at the gateway to the fascinating Navajo-Hopi country in Arizona, New Mexico and Utah have deterred and disappointed countless motorists.

FRANK SINATRA is back on cloud eight, bouncing around as jauntily as ever. Outwardly, at least, he shows no signs of the buffeting he has weathered since 1951 when his career appeared to be slipping away.
GENEVA, May 8 (AP) -- Excerpts from an unofficial translation of the speech by Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, and the text of his Indo-China proposal at the Geneva conference today follow:
DETROIT, May 8 (AP) -- Major divisions of the auto industry are rolling along at a rate that will make possible close to three million car assemblies in the JanuaryJune period.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The IndoChina crisis is fortunately not as serious as the headlines and political oratory of the past week would suggest.

WILMIMGTON, N. C., May 8 -- Miss Lillian Maxwell Bellamy, daughter of Mrs. Emmett Hargrove Bellamy and the late Mr. Bellamy, was married here this afternoon to Leslie N. Boney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Boney.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Industrial plant facilities will soon take another stride ahead in the Chicago area as announced programs get under way. During April planned investment in new plants and purchase of property of expansion totaled $18,813,000, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported.

TELA, Honduras, May 8 -- Virtually all commerce and most transportation and communications were at a standstill along the north Honduran coast today as the result of a general United Fruit Company strike involving 25,000 workers.

THE outstanding event of the week is the single appearance of the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday. Heading the cast will be Alicia Alonso, Igor Youskevitch, John Kriza, Melissa Hayden, Lupe Serrano, Ruth Ann Koesun, Lillian Lanese, Barbara Lloyd, Liane Plane, Eric Braun, Scott Douglas, Roy Fitzell, Job Sanders and Adriano Vitale.

JON GODDEN'S new novel, written with an almost classical simplicity that recalls the best of Pushkin, displays no artifices. This, she says, is an account of a few months in the life of an entirely unimportant man in Calcutta.

Job prospects for June graduates at Barnard College are excellent despite the nation-wide dip in employment, according to Miss Ruth Houghton, director of the Barnard Placement Office. This year the same number of employers have asked to interview members of the graduating class as in recent years, and the salaries offered are as good as or better than in the past, ranging from $45 to $80 a week, with $50 as the average.
Rain starting at 1:10 A. M. yesterday brought .97 of an inch to the city by 8 P. M., but it was doubted that this would materially affect the city's slim water supply.

LAWRENCE, Kan., May 8 (AP) -- Wes Santee ran two miles in 8 minutes, 58 seconds, three-tenths of a second under the intercollegiate record, as Kansas swamped Drake and Arkansas in a triangular track meet today.

TODAY, from radio and television sets, from the text of greeting cards, from her husband and even occasionally from the lips of her offspring, come messages every mother wants to hear -- that her problems are understood, that she is appreciated, that she is loved.

RICHMOND, Va. -- No general price increases, more and better tourist facilities with a marked increase in tourist courts and expanded free public recreation areas -- that's the summer vacation outlook in the Midsouth.
Mayor Wagner said last night that being the city's chief executive had brought under control any urges he might have had to break things.
The Park Department announced yesterday publication of the 1954 edition of its booklet. "Recreational Facilities for New Yorkers," giving data about the city's parks and playgrounds.

Maremont Automotive Products, Inc., is an old-line metal working firm that throughout its seventy-seven-year history has managed to keep abreast of the changing economy by switching from one product to another. It leaped from horseshoes to custommade truck and auto bodies to parts -- particularly mufflers and springs -- for most major auto and truck manufacturers.
CHICAGO, May 8 -- Seven member colleges and one member conference were penalized by the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council today, chiefly for trying out prospective athletes.

CELOSIA has proved to be one of the most fascinating and rewarding of recently grown annuals. Some years ago the listings of newer celosias or cockscombs sounded good enough to be worth trying at least a few in my West Virginia garden.

NOWADAYS it's a rare historical novel that draws a smile on purpose. Donald Barr Chidsey's "Lord of the Isles" is one of the welcome realities -- a genial romp through the grass-skirted Graustark that was the Kingdom of Hawaii, circa 1820.
DANDELIONS are the most pestiferous weed in the lawn and garden or one of the most useful plants that grow. The point of view depends on who is talking about them.

BUFFALO, May 8 (AP) -- Cisco Andrade, an undefeated, sharppunching boxer from Compton, Calif., won a unanimous tenround decision tonight over Armand Savoie of Montreal in a nationally-televised lightweight fight in Memorial Auditorium. Each weighed 136 pounds.

Several notable gardens in Greenwich, Conn., and Purchase, N. Y., will be opened to the public on the afternoon of May 20. In case of rain, the tour will be held on May 21. Proceeds from the event will be donated to the Patients' Welfare Fund of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of New York UniversityBellevue Medical Center.

" Creative Photography" will be discussed with an "artistic" approach Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Room 213, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Fred Stein, photographer and writer on this subject, will lecture. The talk is one of a series of free art lectures.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Renewed efforts to curtail the Senate hearings on the Army-McCarthy controversy were under way today, but prospects for success were not bright.

THE altitude gives a special quality to the whole vast beautiful region of the Rocky Mountain States, from Colorado to the Sierras, from New Mexico to Montana. Life is simpler here, for one thing. The mountains are simple, majestic forms, easy on the eye and mind.

* * * Wherever there is an actor performing, there is the theatre. The theatre for those auditioning for the Barter Theatre recently was under a fire escape and on the sidewalk outside the Martin Beck Theatre. The stagehands' union would not permit the inside of the theatre to be used.

IN reviewing K. M. Panikkar's "Asia and Western Dominance," Henry H. Hart states as an example of its inaccuracy that "he gives the date of Commodore Perry's arrival in Japan as 1752 instead of 1853." At least three references to the occasion are made, correctly dated, in the text.

NORA KAYE is to return to the Ballet Theatre next season, after an absence of something over three years, and that may well be cause for rejoicing all around. It will be especially so if it stimulates the management to restore to the repertory the full list of ballets by Antony Tudor with which she has been so closely associated.

A symposium on space travel was held at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History, New York, last week. It was the third of its kind. If it was not as exciting as its predecessors it was because the Jules Verne-H. G. Wells aspects of space travel are exhausted.

The Farrell liner African Endeavor has won the first annual Ship Safety Achievement Award for passenger ships, Capt. Jones F. Devlin Jr., chairman of the award committee of the National Safety Council's marine section, announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 8 -- Differences over policy such as those now basetting the United States, Britain and France cannot obscure the great number of policy issues on which the three nations are agreed. But the differences are pertinent, and so are their links with certain basic circumstances affecting each nation.

The idea expressed by Milton M. Gordon and John P. Roche -- that segregation harms the segregator as well as the segregated -- is not new, but we owe the writers much for making this concept such a pointed one in their article "Segregation -- Two-Edged Sword" (April 25).

ETHEL LINDER REINER, whose last challenge to Broadway was Tennessee Williams' "Camino Real," which she produced with Cheryl Crawford, came home the other day from a four-month trip abroad to flash the green light signalizing readiness for another tussle with the local madness -this time alone.

THERE took place, over the week-end of April 23, 24 and 25, the fifth Regional Composers Forum now held annually at Tuscaloosa under the sponsorship of the Albama Composers League, the Southeastern Composers League, and the Department of Music, College of Arts and Sciences, through the facilities of the Extension Division of the University of Alabama.

IT may be momentarily bewildering to the casual moviegoer to be told that those two celebrated screen beauties, Lana Turner and Marilyn Monroe, presently have much in common with the creature from the Black Lagoon, a conspicuously loathesome monster now holding forth on the Paramount's screen.

SINGAPORE, May 8 -- General John E. Hull, United States Commander in the Far East, said today, "I have examined your security set-up here [in Malaya] and I am favorably impressed. I have no fears as far as Malaya is concerned," General Hull spoke as he and his wife boarded a plane at Kuala Lumpur on their way to Tokyo.

THE vacation-bound rail traveler this summer will find improved equipment and faster schedules on many long-distance trains, and his pocketbook will be aided by a slight lowering of fares caused by the reduction from 15 to 10 per cent in the transportation tax.

A stroll down the street in 1919 changed the course of his life for Ralph E. Ladue. On such a walk he met John David, then head of a single store bearing his name which enjoyed gross sales of about $500,000 a year.

READERS who rejoice in Claudia will also succumb to the generous heart of Josephine Benoit, heroine of this pleasantly old-fashioned, sentimental novel. The time is now, the place chiefly the cobble-stoned village of Eze in the south of France, the problems those of love. "Rendezvous" will transport you from an atmosphere of bombs to one of berets.

TODAY'S mystery novel lays more stress upon suspense than upon plotting. But two recent imports, one British and one French, offer striking new surprises which may catch unaware even the veteran reader.

TRENTON, May 8 -- The Democratic party in New Jersey called upon President Eisenhower today to restore true bipartisanship in foreign affairs.

FIGHTER of grizzly bears. Indians, blizzards and starvation in the early days of the West, Joe Meek was anything but what his name implies. This well-documented biography shows the Territorial Government of Oregon's first United States marshal as a man of incredible bravery and endurance.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 8 -- Cornell's varsity crew, wet as so any mackerels, completed a successful defense of the Carnegie Cup in a two-mile race held hear nightfall today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 -- Demands for more and bigger Federal power systems and appeals for curtailment of the Government's role in power development and distribution were received here this week at a hearing on water and power resources.

A GROWING trend in summertime television programming has been toward more and more sponsors who elect "to hold the franchise" on a given time period. They do this by scheduling reruns of the best of their winter programs through the hot weather months.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Thirty years ago -- on May 10, 1924 -- Attorney General Harlan Fiske Stone summoned a dark-haired young lawyer into his office, peered at him over his glasses and said gruffly:

EARL CONRAD turns away in this book from his previous shock-treatment style of writing about segregation and racial discrimination in America. He retains his preoccupation with the Negro in "Gulf Stream North," but he avoids the controversial nature of his "Jim Crow America" (1947), "Scottsboro Boy" (with the late Haywood Patterson, 1950), and "Rock Bottom" (1952), a story of a Negro woman's problems.

UNDOUBTEDLY the most un-American American business firm in the country is the Amtorg Trading Corporation of 49 West Thirty-seventh Street, New York City. Incorporated under the laws of the State of New York, Amtorg's frank mission is to buy goods for the Soviet Union and to sell commodities to Americans.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 8 -Paced by MacAllister Booth's double victories in the hurdles, Cornell's track team topped Princeton, 78 3/4 to 61 1/4, in Palmer Stadium today.
Jet Action won the Withers Stakes and Extra Points captured the International Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. Straight Face was home first in the Dixie Handicap at Pimlico.

An unusual project in American business education will provide thirty high school seniors who show promise of becoming business executives of the future with $2,500 four-year fulltuition scholarships to New York University's business school. The scholarships are to be available each year to outstanding students from thirty different communities in the United States, at an annual cost of $80,000.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., May 8 (AP) -- Four players from as many states reached the semi-finals today in the thirtyfirst annual Shawnee invitation golf tournament at the Shawnee Inn and Country Club.

CINCINNATI, May 8 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals made seven hits good for seven runs in the first three innings today as they pounded out a 7-3 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs. Stan Musial's ninth home run of the season drove in three runs.

TURF diseases are quite often responsible for the destruction of many lawns each spring and summer. In many instances gardeners are unaware of them but none the less there are at least fifty distinct diseases of grasses mostly caused by fungi.
The rolling recession, the period of inventory readjustment, or whatever the phrase, is over as far as the shoe industry is concerned.

Lincoln University, in Chester County, Pa., the first institution in the world founded to provide higher education for Negroes, is now celebrating its 100th anniversary. The centennial activities began last September, and will continue through this month.

HEWLETT, L. I., May 8 -Frank Strafaci, former metropolitan amateur golf champion and winner of the William D. Richardson memorial tourney for the last two years, bowed out today in the second round at the Seawane Harbor Club course.
The appointment of Prof. Henry Roberts as director of Columbia University's newly-created Program of East European Studies was announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia.

BOSTON, May 8 -- A Norwegian mariner who settled down to build ship models for a living in East Boston thirty years ago, is working on his third in a series for the "History of Marine Transportation" exhibit at the Boston Museum of Science.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Democrats who gathered here this week in national conclave gave every evidence of real belief in their public forecast that a majority of their candidates for Congress will be elected next November, thus taking over control of its machinery from the Republicans in President Eisenhower's mid-term. Such public forecasts are normal in the circumstances, even when a political party's prospects are dim and growing dimmer.

Whether the free world can hold one embattled bastion, such as Dienbienphu, can be important. It can have meaning because of the gallant men who died there for freedom. It can have import because there are still heroes who prefer death to slavery.

Brazil wants a new Federal District. Rio de Janeiro is hemmed in by mountains and seashore. Its climate is not what it ought to be, and it is not centrally located. But before deciding where to establish a new Federal District the Government turned to Prof. Donald J. Belcher of Cornell.

Martin Engel of New York University triumphed in the varsity event as rain forced postponement of all but the varsity and freshman hammer throws in the twenty-first annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association championships at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

GROWING annuals can be an adventure, especially for those gardeners who are brave enough to stray from the tried and true plants to try some of the new kinds heretofore unknown to them. Often the results are quite rewarding and new annual favorites are discovered.

The N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre ended its fifth season yesterday afternoon with a brilliant production of Richard Strauss' "Salome." Theatrical and musical values were fused into the kind of artistic unity that can make opera the most elusive and most exciting stage form.

SEVILLE, Spain, May 2 -- The state authorities in this city are not on speaking terms with Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz. The reason for official resentment, people here say, is that when in April, 1953, Generalissimo Francisco Franco visited Seville, the Cardinal snubbed him.
PHOENIX, Ariz., May 8 -- An announcement by Gov. Howard Pyle that he will run for a third term is expected any day to signalize the unofficial opening of Arizona's 1954 political race.

ROME, May 8 -- Budge Patty, the American who spends most of his time in Paris, swept into the semi-finals of Rome's international tennis tournament today, defeating Vic Seixas, 1953 Wimbledon titleholder, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 10 -- 8, in the best match played so far in the championship.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 8 -- Jack Burke Jr., shot a par 70 today, but he held his three-stroke lead in the Greenbrier Open with 201 for 54 holes.
MONTREAL -- If you have dreamed of a freighter trip around the world, you might, pending accumulation of enough cash, first try a week or two on a passengerfreighter in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.

NEW DELHI, May 8 -- Asian nations recently under colonial dominance served notice on the world from Ceylon last week that they are capable of acting as a unit in affairs of mutual concern.
