Political observers here consider this the real significance of the conference held in Colombo and Kandy by the Prime Ministers of India, Pakistan, Indonesia, Burma and Ceylon.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -Representative Harold D. Cooley forecast today overwhelming committee defeat for the Administration's flexible farm price support plan.
LINCOLN, Neb., May 8 -- The Nebraska legislature adjourned yesterday after placing on the November general election ballot five constitutional amendment proposals on taxation.
The fifty-seventh annual dinner of the Citizens Union will be held May 19 at the Biltmore Hotel, Milton M. Bergerman, its chairman, announced yesterday.
WHEN Sandy Smith shifts from New Mexican ranch boy to New York apartment dweller some of his problems are monumental and all of them true to life.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- An additional $9,000,000 in emergency financial aid has been granted to Iran by the United States.

YORKTOWN, Va. -- Long overdue plans are happily under way to make historic Yorktown, port city of the early Virginia colony and scene of the ultimate military victory of the colonists over King George III, something more than an inconspicuous pinpoint on the tourist's road map.

The continued decline of United States exports, exclusive of military aid, was shown last week to be in sharp contrast to rising exports by two other major trading nations, Great Britain and West Germany.

Despite the unseasonal weather in many sections of the country last week, resident buying offices reported business continuing at a good pace. For the remainder of the spring season they foresee more promotions. It is also expected that buying in June will be substantial, when buyers are expected in New York in large numbers.

NOW dress shops are filled with the end products of the Spring Collections -- copies of models, from costly facsimiles to little numbers which are only token reminders of the real thing. Our appetites have been whetted. All we have to do is choose (and pay).

OFTENTIMES some unusual items, gadgets or knicknacks around the house become topics of conversation. And even in the garden this can hold true, although there it will be plants rather than objets d'art. For gardeners can choose those plants that might be a little out of the ordinary because of their leaf shapes, a slightly different flower color or just a curious habit of growth.

THE Midsouth is New England with the corners rounded. It is more Colonial than Confederate, and this in spite of the fact that roadside markers recall Manassas and Appomattox. Perhaps it would be fairer to call New England a rough-edged Midsouth, for the adventurous business men of Jamestown did beat the Puritans to the New World by a few years.

Congress ended hearings last week on a bill that would require every American deep-sea merchant ship to carry a device that could automatically notify an offduty radio officer when his ship was being paged by another station.

NEWARK, May 8 -- The sixtieth annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, opening in Atlantic City Tuesday night, will have as its theme Daniel Webster's "If the True Spark of Religious and Civil Liberty Be Kindled, It Will Burn." The conclave will continue through Friday morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 -Contract awards on engineering projects in the eleven Western states were $42,723,002 in the week ended May 1, The Daily Construction Service reported. This brought the sum for the year to date to $696,847,973, compared with $1,343,088,783 at the like date last year.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 8 -- The battle lines of Texas Democrats in this summer's primary are being sharply drawn, with complications such as the activities of the controversial figure, George Parr, and the growing strength of the Republicans.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (UP) -- The nation's population crossed the 162,000,000 mark this week, but the Census Bureau lost track of a vital million for a few hours in the excitement.
TORONTO -- A variety of attractions ranging from new hybrid fish to Shakespearean festivals is expected to bring even more American summer vacationists to Ontario than in the record summer of 1953.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 8 -The entire garrison of 10,000 men had been killed, wounded or captured when the fall of Dienbienphu to the Communist-led Vietminh was completed today.

When the Rev. William J. Finn founded the Paulist Choristers a half century ago, his parish was the southern end of Chicago's Loop, on Wabash Avenue, where the priests generally were accompanied by a husky policeman or two when they made their calls.

THE westward migration across America opened new lands and new vistas for a growing population. Among the pioneers who opened the new country were Yankees. But sooner or later the Yankees' descendants come back to New England, if only for a visit.

GENEVA, May 8 -- Britain and her Commonwealth partners, Australia, Canada and New Zealand, agreed today to continue their close liaison and policy coordination here throughout the nine-nation talks on an Indo-Chinese settlement.

THE "S" in Southern California is always capitalized in Southern California. It is climatically and culturally quite different from northern California, spelled with a small "n," which enjoys approximately the same relationship as Albany does to New York City: the Legislature meets there.

SINCE most young children cling closely to familiar things, Aaron Fine's picture story of a school bus ride and an unscheduled picnic should be popular with that matter-of-fact age group. Gus, the amiable driver, shares with the young passengers his enthusiasm for the signs of spring and encourages them to talk to traffic lights ("Turn green, turn green!") and to railroad gates ("Up, gate! We've got to get home").

ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 7 (Delayed) -- According to unofficial estimates approximately twenty-five persons have been killed in several clashes since the first attack of the revolt here was made against Police Head quarters last Tuesday night, when the former Police Chief, Dr. Roberto L. Petit, and an inspector were shot fatally. The injured and wounded were estimated at less than 100.

WE approach the vinegar season -- the four hot-weather months when its use is greater than during the remaining eight months of the year. Salads, barbecue sauces and pickling, all associated with summer, depend for their effect on vinegar, which, in the case of a salad, is a condiment and, in the case of pickles, a preservative.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 8 (AP) -- Five Illinois Memorial Stadium relay records and two individual marks were smashed today in the first annual Big Ten outdoor relays.

WHO should pay the bill for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's reply to Edward R. Murrow has assumed the proportions of quite a fuss. While no one has been in a hurry to pick up the tab, estimated to run between $5,000 and $7,000, everyone has been eager to make a point of order.

GENEVA, May 8 -- France proposed today a truce in the fighting in Vietnam. Under it Communist guerrilla forces there would be disarmed and regular units of both the French Union and Vietminh rebel forces grouped in assembly zones.

MARK TWAIN called Helen Keller and Napoleon "the two most interesting figures of the nineteenth century." There is little doubt that she remains one of the most unusual and inspiring figures of our age, too.

MYSTIC, Conn. -- There probably will be no busier community in New England this summer than the seaside village of Mystic, which this year is observing its tercentenary. The town itself is planning many activities to mark its 300th anniversary, and Mystic Seaport, the reconstructed waterfront area depicting a typical port of call for the whalers and clipper ships of a century ago, is preparing to celebrate simultaneously its twentyfifth anniversary.

Mayor Wagner has urged reviison of the Federal law governing disposal of surplus property to permit designated agencies of the city and state to benefit. The benefit would be either by donations or by low-cost purchases of surplus equipment and supplies.

WAUSAU, Wis., May 8 (AP) -- For the second time within twenty-four hours, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy refused to be interviewed by a reporter for The Milwaukee Journal while talking to other newspaper men. The newspaper opposes him editorially.
LONDON, May 8 -- Hugh Dalton, former Laborite Chancellor of the Exchequer, today joined the rapidly increasing number of Labor party veterans opposing German rearmament.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The foreign policy of the United States seems about to reach a phase of crisis and so, in a less decisive sense, does the career of John Foster Dulles as chief enunciator of that policy.

THE next time they lay the cornerstone of one of our skyscrapers they won't have to waste a second puzzling over whether a subway token or a ticket to the World's Series should be sealed inside. If they simply slip in a copy of "Manhattan and Me" the problem of the time capsule will be neatly solved.

IN the years 1790-91 the mining village of Sawle in the County of Cornwall has a peaceful air, but under its quiet surface feelings run high, particularly in the Poldark Family. In "Venture Once More," Winston Graham continues the narrative of this family to whom he has devoted two previous novels.

PERHAPS the most important literary event of 1954 will prove to be that England has now two reviews, John Lehmann's The London Magazine and the Anglo-American Encounter, edited by Irving Kristol and myself, in addition to the improved and extended The Twentieth Century, edited by George Arnold.

What happens to the millions of copies of American magazines once they are read? Perhaps some, especially those devoted to technical subjects, are preserved, but the rest are discarded. These discards could do a great service for the United States as well as the entire free world.
New York City is about to go to the public market to borrow money on bonds for the first time in more than nine years.
Maj. Gen. L. P. Whitten, commanding the Middletown Air Materiel Area for the Air Force, has proved himself not only one of the world's biggest buyers, but one of the shrewdest.

CHICAGO, May 8 -- Sharppitching Ned Garver, who now has yielded only three runs in thirty-seven innings, hurled the Detroit Tigers into the American League lead behind an eighteen-hit assult which blasted the Chicago White Sox, 12 -- 1, today.

THE everyday household articles of a country quite clearly reflect the taste, temperament and the way of life of its inhabitants. That this is particularly true of ceramics was emphasized by the work of the Japanese potter, Kitaoji Rosanjin, shown here last month. These ceramics, exhibited both in the penthouse of the Museum of Modern Art and at the Grace Borgenicht Galleries, were peculiarly Japanese in content.

In cases of severe shock caused by burns, excessive bleeding and injuries, there is a loss of blood through the walls of blood vessels. In such cases plasma or blood is passed into the blood stream. Since plasma and blood are not always easy to obtain, especially in a catastrophe, surgeons have been looking for what they call an "expander" of blood volume.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -Pennsylvania candidates for the Republican and Democratic nominations for Governor and other public office completed plans today for a final week of intensive campaigning for votes in the primary election.

THE sturdy young hero of this engaging tale is a devotee of the library's weekly picture-book hour. He enjoys listening to all the stories, but his particular favorite is "Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel" which is not surprising, for Miss Burton's book is a favorite with many youngsters.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y. -The United States and Canadian Governments are at work on a project to alter the present appearance and preserve the beauty of Niagara Falls, one of the continent's most impressive scenic spectacles.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Alumni of Columbia University living in the Washington area will hold a dinner here in the fall in connection with the bicentennial celebration of the university.

ICA, Peru, May 8 -- The expedition took to the air to get a condor'seye view of the Inca road as it snakes along Peru's desert coast. We had crawled on the ground for months and now we would lay down by air the pattern of research for the next six months.

The chemical 6-mercaptopurine, which is used in treating leukemia, may check brain tumors. So reported Drs. Alfred Gellhorn, Edith Petersen and Margaret Murray of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons before the New York Academy of Sciences.

The press a few weeks ago carries an account of the imminent resignation of Dr. Alberto Lleras as Secretary General of the Organization of American States, in effect the executive officer of the Pan American Union at Washington.
BALTIMORE, May 8 (UP) -Hal Naragon's three-run double in the fourth inning gave the Cleveland Indians a 5-to-3 victory over the last-place Baltimore Orioles tonight before a crowd of 20,341.

LAMBERTVILLE, N. J., May 8 -- A well being dug here on a site picked by dowsers using forked branches cut from fruit trees has begun to produce water. Workmen have been obliged to use a gasoline-powered pump to drain off the water while they continue with the excavating operation.
NEWARK, May 8 -- This city's first election under its new charter holds the center of interest in the municipal balloting in New Jersey next Tuesday.

BACH: Now let every tongue adore thee, Hosanna to the Living Lord; GRETCHANINOFF: Credo, Nunc Dimittis; VIRGIL THOMSON: Two Antiphonal Psalms; and other a cappella liturgical selections; Divinity School Choir of Yale University, James Borden, conductor (Overtone). Church singing that is both quietly devout and musically sensitive.

NOW that the fishing season has been officially launched on fresh and salt water, several million anglers are engaged in individual surveys to determine where they can find the best fishing for the minimum expenditure in time, effort and expense.

AFTER an uninterrupted engagement of fifteen months, "Wonderful Town." is still the gayest musical comedy on Broadway. None of the other gestures toward hilarity that has opened since Feb. 25, 1953, has been half so integrated and funny.

I want to thank you and congratulate you for the illuminating article "Segregation -- Two Edged Sword." In June I will face the prospect of moving to Charleston, S. C., a move which will be the first to take me away from northeastern United States.

ELSIE THE COW is an LL. D. Ball-point pens, which a few years back sold as phenomenally well as stilts in Basque sheep country, were popular despite a tendency in some of them to goop (drop globs of ink on paper) and to dye their owners' clothes with a nearly unremovable dye.

THE one thing above all others which becomes increasingly clear with the publication of this second volume of the secret diaries of pugnacious and painstaking old Harold Ickes is that in overwhelming measure they are being kept secret still.

WAUSAU, Wis., May 8 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy tonight accused the Democratic members of the Senate subcommittee hearing the McCarthy-Army charges with deliberately attempting to prolong the hearing to "prevent us from rooting out Communists."

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- The recession, or readjustment in business, has reached a point in Pennsylvania that is beyond the decline reported in this state during the 1949-50 recession. The Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University made that observation in reporting that industrial activity during March continued the steady decline that began last July.

THE invasion of Europe by American singers and, to a lesser extent, by American conductors and instrumentalists, is a much publicized story. Almost overlooked is the more spectacular and, with the Europeans, far more popular invasion of Europe by American jazz bands.

TORONTO, May 8 (Canadian Press) -- Fleet Manufacturing, Ltd., of Fort Erie, Ont., and Doman Helicopters, Inc., of Danbury, Conn., have announced arrangements to form a jointly owned Canadian subsidiary to be known as Doman-Fleet Helicopters, Ltd., with head office at Fort Erie.

In the last century every physicist believed in the ether, a purely hypothetical medium that transmitted electromagnetic waves, such as light -- a medium so tenuous that it filled every vacuum. Yet it was stronger than steel. As more and more physical discoveries were made it was endowed with vortices and a dozen other mechanical devices so that it could fulfill its imaginary function of a transmitting medium.

The New York annual conference of the Methodist Church unanimously adopted yesterday a resolution calling upon the Federal Government to join other nations in an effort to outlaw the atom and hydrogen bombs as instruments of warfare.
Although the stock market edged upward to a new twentyfour-year high, the first week in May found traders quite cautious and price movements were somewhat confused.

PICTURE judging by stereo- typed methods and resistance to new ideas were blamed here last week for the steady decline in the pictorial salons in the past two decades. The statement was made by A. Aubrey Bodine, veteran salon exhibitor of Baltimore, in the principal address at the annual "Tops in Photography" show at Town Hall.

WHEN an actor or a director approaches the revival of a classic he must be prepared for the question of friends and critics: "What is your interpretation going to be?" -- the implication being that there is no point in doing the play unless you can bring something new to it.

HARRISBURG -- Pennsylvania is ready this year to play host to millions of vacationists and it would surprise no one if the figure topped 10,000,000. Many, of course, will be Pennsylvanians, who need not go far from home to visit places that also lure tourists from all parts of the country.
A total of 502,184 children have been inoculated in the nationwide trial of the new anti-polio myelitis vaccine.

VACATIONISTS who remain on this side of the Atlantic this summer will still have a wide range of holiday choices. Whether it be a tour of considerable length or a few weeks' loafing at a luxury hotel, they are likely to find something to their taste. Prices are no higher than last year; in some cases they are lower, and in Florida and the Caribbean, the off-season rates are a special inducement.
Two men drowned yesterday in Jamaica Bay after a two-and-ahalf-hour ordeal in which they saved the lives of a woman and a boy. The body of one of the drowned men was recovered.

Eric Ashby's article, "Soviet Science Is a Challenge to Us" April 18) ought to be read by every American citizen. Mr. Ashby recognizes, and must make every reader recognize, the danger to the free world involved in the cleverness and diligence with which the Russian Government is going about the business of developing a generation of competent scientists.

THE moment a traveler crosses the Mississippi River and heads west he begins to encounter the one dominant quality of the Plains States -space. Starting with the rolling, compact corn fields and pasture lands of Iowa, and extending beyond the Missouri River to the great wheat plains and ranges of Nebraska, Kansas, and the Dakotas, his horizon broadens until it is almost limitless.

PITTSBURGH, May 8 -- Johnny Antonelli, overcoming innumerable obstacles, not the least of them being continued lapses by his colleagues, tonight finally led the Giants out of a maze of nocurnal defeats.

At the Berlin Big Four meeting the three Western Foreign Ministers burst into spontaneous laughter when the Russians proposed an all-European non-aggression treaty with the U. S. excluded. Later the Russians modified the proposal to include the U. S., provided Russia was taken into NATO.

Knickerbocker Hospital, 70 Convent Avenue, treated more than 1,000 alcoholics last year, continuing its cooperation with Alcoholics Anonymous, Murray Sargent, president of the hospital, said in his annual report last week.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 8 -- The Waldenmark Kennels of Newtown, Bucks County, Pa., took both the best of breed and the opposite sex prizes during the sixth annual specialty show and fourth obedience trial of the German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island at the Garden City Hotel today. Rain fell through most of the show.

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, April -- Many members of the Jewish community here believe that in not many years to come "finis" will have been written to the saga of the Jews of Sarajevo, one of the oldest and most famous Jewish communities in the Balkans.

Eighteen American high school teachers have been selected by the John Hay Whitney Foundation as recipients of awards for study in the humanities at Columbia and Yale Universities, it was announced last week. The teachers will get an opportunity to study under nationally known scholars and to explore various fields of knowledge.

MARK TWAIN once ruefully observed that the first time he ever saw St. Louis he could have bought the place for $6,000,000 and that it was the mistake of his life he did not do so. But another grievous error which he did make was to spend considerably more than $100,000 in backing a hapless genius called James W. Paige, a rival of Ottmar Mergenthaler.
LONDON, May 8 (AP) -- Roger Bannister's next race is expected to be in the June 12 Anglo-American university meet at London's White City Stadium.

THE South is a kaleidoscopic parade of natural scenery and human attitudes, both of them etched sharply. The land and the people are undergoing great economic and social changes. The past and the present tilt lances in a setting as colorful as any pageantry in history.

JERUSALEM, May 8 -- When Israel on Thursday celebrated six years as a nation, her leaders could predict the future in certain fields. It was apparent, for example, that the new public school system and universal military service were molding the Israeli population into a single people.

FOR those who enjoy American history, and particularly that part of American history which deals with the Revolution, David Taylor provides a fictional account with an unusual twist. The heroine, a courageous patriot lass, Phoebe Runnels, loves not, as might be expected, a handsome Tory, but a noncombatant "neutralist"
A Brooklyn jury yesterday acquitted a policeman who previously had been sentenced to a prison term of eight to ten years on a manslaughter charge.

THE nation's highways are broken out with a veritable rash of "Slow -- Construction Ahead" signs, an indication of a better tomorrow for the motoring vacationist but an indication also of delays, detours and inconvenience ahead for this summer.

See the pretty dandelions, blooming everywhere. Is there a finer yellow to be seen anywhere around? The answer, though not-exactly responsive, is that the dandelion is a pest, a nuisance, an interloper and several other things, all preceded by adjectives. Especially if the answerer is a man with a cherished lawn.
MINEOLA, L. I., May 8 -- A man who went to jail yesterday in a fight to win school bus service for his two daughters is back home with his family today.
IZMIR, Turkey, April 27 -- Today Greek and Turkish sentries mount guard outside this headquarters on a quay where thirty-one years ago Turkish forces drove the invading Greeks into the sea.

BOSTON, May 8 -- Democratic politicians in Massachusetts are facing their pre-primary convention at Worcester, less than a month hence, with most of their established stars voluntarily on the side lines.

In his stimulating essay, "X-ray of the Scientific Mind" (April 25), Waldemar Kaempffert discusses such characteristics as objectivity, curiosity, skepticism. The main point does not come out quite clearly, however: the fact that these qualities are less characteristics of an individual scientist than components of the whole scientific discourse.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 8 -Grants and awards totaling $44,500 were announced tonight by the Sidney Hllman Foundation, established in memory of the late president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O.

NASHVILLE, May 8 -- Tennessee's Old Guard Republican leaders are waging a campaign to build up Ray H. Jenkins, now special counsel for the McCarthyArmy inquiry, into a candidate for the Senate next November.

LOS ANGELES, May 8 -Parry O'Brien of Los Angeles made a shambles of the supposedly unattainable 60-foot mark in the shot-put today. He twice officially surpassed the distance and wound up a record-shattering day with an amazing put of 60 feet 5 1/4 inches.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- White House hopes for enactment of a substantial portion of the President's legislative program soared this week with the attainment of two important measures.
Local shipping interests asked yesterday for the repeal of municipal legislation -- scheduled to become effective on July 1 -- that would permit the operation of smaller taxicabs.
GENEVA, May 9 (UP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by the United States Under Secretary of State, Gen. Walter Bedell Smith:
PARIS, Monday, May 10 -- The Vietminh radio was reported today to have announced the capture of Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries, commander of the heroic French Union garrison at Dienbienphu.

AUBURN, N. Y., May 9 -- Republican Assemblymen from some forty rural counties met here tonight to press their demand for a major voice in the formulation of party policy after the fall state election.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art disclosed yesterday that it expected color television would "revolutionize" its educational activities and introduce a new era in nation-wide appreciation of art.

In a pastoral letter describing the plight of the "multitudes of hapless victims of merciless war" witnessed on journeys to Korea and other countries, Cardinal Spellman asked yesterday for contributions to the Bishops Fund for Victims of War and Oppression.

TRENTON, May 9 -- A white and liver 2 1/2-year-old pointer became best in show today in the large event of the Trenton Kennel Club. She was J. D. Rementer Jr.'s Ch. Finefields' Cover Girl from Skippack, Pa.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 -- The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., began its fortieth anniversary celebration here today with an attack on President Eisenhower's economic policies.
CHICAGO, May 9 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy caused political speculation today when he altered his plans for returning to Washington from Wausau, Wis., last night and made a ten-hour visit here.

A bronze bust of the nation's twenty-sixth President, Theodore Roosevelt, was unveiled yesterday on New York University's Bronx campus. Today it will be enshrined in the N. Y. U. Hall of Fame for Great Americans.

MILWAUKEE, May 9 (UP) -- Hank Sauer and Ralph Kiner of Chicago lifted two of Warren Spahn's pitches over the left field fence today as the Cubs defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 5 -- 3, before 28,411 fans in the County Stadium.

Did you ever notice the elderly men and women who sit on the benches of our parks, Prospect and Central, Battery and Van Cortlandt? Many sit there because the four walls of their little rooms become unbearable. In the park they fall into conversation, discuss whatever became of the hurdy-gurdys, and when will the city build the Second Avenue subway.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 9--The bodies of two Philadelphia men, members of a party of four missing since last Sunday when they left for a day's fishing from near-by Brigantine Island, were washed ashore today.

Now and then a reviewer picks up a book with the happy expectation that this will be It. Such was the approach to "Determining the Business Outlook,"*edited by Herbert V. Prochnow, a vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The National Park Service and the military are planning to dedicate a reconstruction of Fort Necessity in Pennsylvania on July 4, and Pennsylvania's Senator Edward Martin, Republican, thinks that would be a fine time to raise the rank of Gen. George Washington.
PARIS, May 9 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle was acclaimed today in Paris as he has not been since the Gaullist organization began losing strength a year or two ago.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 9 -- Nick Egan, a 14-year-old school boy from Flushing, broke ninety-six of 100 targets today to win the distance handicap championship as the amateur trap shooting championships of America came to a close at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island range.

BONN, Germany, May 9 (AP) -- Britain has agreed to pay off about half of her $800,000,000 debt to the European Payments Union and settle the rest within seven years, British officials said here today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A recent United States Government study showed that Communist activity in the Near East was increasing and might pose long-run dangers to that part of the world, the United States Information Agency said today.
LARGE exhibitions are features of this week's art program.

By voting to send the Administration's Taft-Hartley Law amendments back to committee the Senate has deprived the nation of the benefit of a full floor discussion of President Eisenhower's proposals. This is unfortunate. After nearly seven years' experience with the present law some changes are in order.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 9 (AP) -- Herman Scharlau of Boca Raton, Fla., won his first major golf tournament today, taking a three-way sudden death play-off in the Greenbrier Open on the third hole where Sam Snead missed a two-foot putt.

This newspaper recently carried a story describing the rapid expansion of Nassau County since 1947. Nassau's growth, it was pointed out, has been featured not only by an amazing increase in population and residential construction but also by industrial development.

NEWARK, May 9 -- New Jersey tops all states in travel density and there are insufficient funds to combat the problem, state highway officials reported tonight on Gov. Robert B. Meyner's weekly television program.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 9 -- Three members of the Israeli armed forces were killed and two wounded in sporadic fighting with Jordanians southwest of Jerusalem today.

The monthly statistics on employment and unemployment released in Washington at the end of last week revealed a decline in the number of the nation's unemployed from 3,725,000 in mid-March to 3,465,000 in mid-April, a drop of 260,000.
The ship charter market showed little change last week from the course it has followed in the last month.

MANHASSET, L. I., May 9 -- Mr. and Mrs. Bernie Mann's Riviera Mann, ridden by Sonny Brooks, scored 12 points to win the jumper championship in the eighteenth annual Oaks Hunt Horse Show at Jock Whitney's Greentree estate today.
James Reston deserves commendation for his outspoken and wise column on Indo-China in your issue of May 2.
MARY ELIZABETH BANTA can knock on any door in Chinatown and after the tenant's "Bing gaw lai?" ("Who comes?") gain swift entry with her soft answer, "Sing Sang Paw," which means "The Teacher Lady."

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers maintained their American League lead today as Steve Gromek pitched an eleven-inning 3-2 triumph in the first game of a scheduled double-header with the Chicago White Sox. The second game ended in a 0-0 tie after ten innings.

GENEVA, May 9 -- The United States, Britain and France and the three Associated States of Indo-China have agreed to oppose Communist demands that the "resistance governments" of Cambodia and Laos be invited to the Geneva conference.
A modified Chinese water-torture treatment is being applied to Queens Democrats by Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, Mayor Wagner and other prominent Democrats.
CINCINNATI, May 9 -- Condemnation of "hate groups" was voiced here today by the American Jewish Committee.
CRANSTON, R. I., May 9 -- An imported wirehaired fox terrier, Ch. Travella Superman of Harham was named best in show at the Golden Anniversary event of the Rhode Island Kennel Club today.

VIENNA, May 9 -- The continued launching of propaganda balloons from Bavaria by the Free Europe Committee of New York, despite last week's note of protest by the Czechoslovak Government to the United States, brought another protest today.

Because in many lands hungry men, orphan children and aged women by the millions desperately need help the Bishops' Fund Appeal is now (May 9 to 16) engaged in its once-a-year, one-week drive to finance the worldwide programs of overseas relief and services of the Catholic Church in America.

A kit of six advertisements designed to fight "the psychology of depression" by reaffirming, with facts and figures, this country's continuing growth, will go out this week to more than 9,000 United States daily, weekly and special-interest newspapers.

HANOVER, N. H., May 9 (AP) -- Fred Hovde of Princeton, Murray Vernon of Yale, Ed Wallace of Pennsylvania and John Tosca of Holy Cross today gained the semi-final round of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association individual championships on the rainswept Hanover Country Club course.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses the other day continued his vendetta against social workers, judges, psychiatrists, psychologists, recreation workers, teachers and members of every other profession dealing with children in his apparently unquenchable desire to punish parents for acts of vandalism committed by their children.
A five-month tanker reconstruction job -- one of the largest ever undertaken on the West Coast -- has just been completed by the Los Angeles Division of the Todd Shipyards Corporation.

Lace can be synonymous with grace, delicacy and charm when correctly used. Once a luxury item, it is easily available because of the great advances made in reproducing some of the most beautiful types by machinery.
" THAT feller throws lightnin' bolts," said Casey Stengel, sagely nodding his head.
Seven new films, including importations from France and Ireland, are slated to arrive in firstrun theatres this week. The programs follow:

The League of Composers completed its 1953-54 season last night with a program at Carnegie Recital Hall that presented contemporary chamber music at its most ingratiating. This was partly because of the works performed, partly because of the performances.

Plans for altering the five-story brownstone dwelling at 107 East Thirty-seventh Street into seventeen one-and-one-half-room apartments have been announced in connection with the sale of the property by the Uckiss Realty Corporation to a client of Milton Weisenberger. William Alfred White was the broker.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 9 -- Once upon a time there were eighty Long Island children who thought it would be fun to make costumes for their pets and have a Storybook Pet Show.
Four Zionist organizations held meetings yesterday at which the State Department was criticized for deciding to send arms to Iraq and for its Middle East policy.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 9 -- Turkey has told the Soviet Union that she will refuse to engage in diplomatic wrangles. She charged a systematic Soviet campaign to put the free countries on the defensive concerning their security policies.

ROME, May 9 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, nearing peak form, crushed Orlando Sirola, young Italian Davis Cup player, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, today to reach the semi-finals of Italy's international tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on major roll-calls in Congress during the period May 2 through May 8:
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- A racket-busting United States Attorney from New Jersey was picked today to head a new Justice Department division charged with intensifying the fight on spies and traitors.

BONN, Germany, May 9 (AP)--West Germany's 6,000,000 organized workers are clamoring for a five-day, forty-hour work week. They argue that United States experience shows that the forty-hour week increases, rather than decreases, production.

ALAIN GHEERBRANT, a young French poet, magazine editor, publisher and student of ethnology and anthropology, may soon be as famous in this country as Thor Heyerdahl who wrote "Kon-Tiki" and Maurice Herzog who wrote "Annapurna." Like those brave men and able writers, M. Gheerbrant risked his life to go where no white men had been before and, like them, he has written a notable account of his perilous penetration of wilds.
LONDON, May 9 -- A large proportion of United States airmen serving in Britain find the British people indifferent or even hostile to them, according to a sampling made by The London Daily Mirror.

The apparent collapse of negotiations to sell any or all of the city-owned power generating plants to Consolidated Edison is disappointing. There are three of these plants, used to supply a considerable part of the power to run the subway trains, and Consolidated Edison had offered $8,000,000 for the Kent Avenue plant in Brooklyn, which is carried on the city's assessment rolls (though tax-exempt, of course) for $18,000,000.
Harry S. Truman departed for Washington last night with one souvenir of his latest visit that came not from New York but from Yorkshire, England.

The Public Service Commission told Long Island gas consumers yesterday they could expect no downward revision in their present rates. The state body based its conclusion on an examiner's report that showed earnings of the Long Island Lighting Company to have been less than 4 per cent in 1953 and viewed as "clouded with uncertainty" the company's future rates.
Briefs submitted to the United States Supreme Court indicate that New York City virtually has overcome all opposition to taking additional water from tributaries of the Delaware River.
Plans for two major conferences to continue the observance of Columbia University's 200th anniversary were announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia.
ARDMORE, Okla., May 9 (AP) -- Julius Boros, the former National Open golf champion from Mid Pines, N. C., won the rich Ardmore open tournament today with a seventy-two-hole score of 279.

Increasing anti-American sentiment in Mexico has emphasized a need for American enterprises to publicize their constructive role in the Mexican economy, a Mexico City representative of United States business concerns asserted last week.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 6 -- A two-year self-evaluation study has shown that St. John's College is successfully conducting its Great Books Program.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $79,537,562,962. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
New emphasis on the old adage, "Don't put all your eggs in one basket," has led an increasing number of companies to seek wider diversification.
The 3,900-ton cargo ship Charis, latest addition to the fleet of the Royal Netherlands Steamship Company, will make her first appearance here May 25.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- A line double to left center by Sandy Amoros broke a scoreless tie in the seventh inning today and the Dodgers went on to beat the Phils, 2 -- 1, for a sweep of the three-game series at Connie Mack Stadium before 13,818 fans.

Athletic directors all seem to come from the same stock. In keeping with their varied interests, they talk baseball, football, hockey and basketball in season. But let them get wind that a new gymnasium is being contemplated and the pattern changes.
ROME, May 9 -- There is renewed anxiety for the health of Pope Pius XII.
A multitude of noisy youngsters at Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx learned yesterday what it feels like to operate military equipment.

BONN, Germany, May 9 -- Die Zeit, an independent weekly of Hamburg, asserts that only six Soviet Army men defected in 1953 compared with 200 to 300 men who deserted annually in the early years after the war.

Mayor Wagner's apparent intention to press for extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services was assailed yesterday by a group of Republicans. They called it an abject surrender to political expediency dictated by the city's most powerful Democratic leaders.
LONDON, May 9 -- One of the Labor party's most influential leaders vigorously defended today the necessity for permitting Western Germany to rearm under the proposed European Defense Community.

One of the finest editorials I can recall having read anywhere appeared recently in The New York Times under the heading "Higher Pay, Higher Taxes." The editorial related the campaign for higher teachers' salaries to the continuing threat of an increase in New York's sales tax and took the laudable view that in any choice between higher taxes and "underpaying teachers and other city employes, the choice is quickly made."
The Chelsea Football Club of London defeated the Fortuna eleven of Duesseldorf, Germany, 3 -- 2, in a soccer match at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday.

The recent Czechoslovak note protesting against the balloon-borne leaflets which have been sent into that country is impressive evidence of the worth of this means of breaking through the Iron Curtain. The Crusade for Freedom, which is sponsoring this balloon barrage, calls this new effort "Operation Veto" and has coordinated it with numerous broadcasts in Czech and Slovak by Radio Free Europe.

MOSCOW, May 9 -- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov paid tribute today to the role of the United States and General Dwight D. Eisenhower in the war against Germany, but warned that the present United States foreign policy was "playing with dangerous fire."

The Fifth Avenue scene at Fortieth Street last night had a tinge of the unreal and the bizarre about it. Its ingredients were a seven-man art show in windows usually reserved for fashions at Lane Bryant's, a sidewalk preview and a queen in regal robes.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., May 9 -- Piloting a new Maserati, Bill Eager of Newark captured the 150-mile featured Suffolk County Trophy event today at the sports car races conducted on the runways of the Suffolk County Air Force Base. The co-sponsors of the program were the New York Region Sports Car Club of America and this air base.
PORTLAND, Me., May 9 -- (UP) -- Flood warnings were issued in southern Maine today as a torrential downpour swept up the New England coast.
FORT DIX, N. J., May 9 -- A mock battle will be staged before the families of troops here Saturday during an Armed Forces Day celebration.

Being invited to question publicly the composers whose works they hear, the audiences of the Composers Forum are always more articulate than ordinary audiences. And on Saturday night, at the eighth and final forum of the season at Columbia's McMillin Theatre, the audience, accustomed to conventional modern music, revealed it was considerably flurried by a jazz composer.
The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, said yesterday that "sentimentalism and commercialism" had corrupted the true spirit of Mother's Day.

As a member of the Assembly of the State of New York I have been fighting for four years for the creation of a nonpolitical commission consisting of an equal number of appointees to be designated by the Governor of the State of New York and the Mayor of the City of New York to solve the state-city financial dispute which appears endless and leaves the New York City taxpayer frustrated and confused as usual.

BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) -- Gil Coan's run-scoring single in the tenth gave the Orioles a 2-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians today. Bob Turley turned in a four-hit pitching effort to end a five-game losing streak, for Baltimore.

GENEVA, May 9--The Soviet Union has notified the United States that it will not take part in the international atomic energy pool proposed by President Eisenhower unless there is a prior agreement to prohibit atomic weapons.

PELHAM, N. Y., May 9 -- In the Eighteen Nineties New York whittled off parts of southern Westchester County to add to the Bronx. Today, one of the larger parts, City Island, was talking of seceding to return to Westchester.

The public has been watching coffee prices soar but generally has been unaware of a parallel movement in cocoa. The consumer drinks quantities of coffee and the price rise affects him directly, while it is relatively seldom that he buys cocoa under its own name.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 9 -- Pro-French tribesmen in Vietminh territory in northwestern Vietnam were on the lookout today for French Union soldiers who might have escaped from fallen Dienbienphu.

We often say of something that it is "too good to be true." This saying could now aptly be paraphrased in relation to the proposal for a peace in Indo-China that French Foreign Minister Bidault made at Geneva on Saturday. It is "too good to be accepted by the Communists."
All but a hard core of the customers of Frederick Loeser Co., Inc., Brooklyn department store, had disappeared by the time it closed its doors in 1952.

Barnard College has sold the block between 119th and 120th Streets from Riverside Drive to Claremont Avenue to John D. Rockefeller Jr. The transfer was announced yesterday by Mrs. Ogden Reid, chairman of the college's board of trustees.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP) -- Eight members of Congress and the chairmen of the Republican and Democratic National Committees met in a televised political round robin today that ranged from "scandals" to "McCarthy" and Indo-China.

MAXWELL AIR FORCE BASE, Montgomery, Ala. -- May 8 -- Here at this base, where some of the tactical and strategic concepts of the Air Force were born two decades ago, is the cradle of Air Force and its hope for the future.
ALBANY, May 9 (AP) -- A state study group urged today a fresh look at state and city taxes on private bus companies lest the taxes "kill the goose that laid the golden egg."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 -- The Indo-China war will be the subject of a motion picture to be produced by Warner Brothers under the title of "Jump Into Hell."

HEWLETT, L. I., May 9--Tim Holland, 24-year-old Rockville Country Club golfer, won the William D. Richardson Memorial Trophy at the Seawane Harbor Club today. He turned back Fred Lazard, 41-year-old Cherry Valley Club champion, by 5 and 4.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 -- Americans are losing faith in each other through the efforts of "a small group of paranoid persons who hold in contempt the basic principles of personal liberty," a nation-wide meeting of social workers was told here tonight.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., May 9 -- President Eisenhower extolled the attributes of the First President this afternoon in a Mother's Day ceremony at the grave of Mary Ball Washington, "who gave us the greatest American of them all."
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey predicted today the Senate would approve lowering the voting age from 21 to 18.
CHICAGO, May 9 -- Rallies in wheat were hard to maintain in grain trading here last week. Corn and oats also failed to enlist sustained buying support. Soybeans dropped on heavy profit-taking sales.

TELA, Honduras, May 9 -- Representatives of labor and management are scheduled to meet here Tuesday morning in a first conference to try to settle the strike affecting most of the 25,000 United Fruit Company employes in the country.
PITTSBURGH, May 8 -- One of the sickest of the country's sick industries is getting sicker.
PITTSBURGH, May 9 -- The Giants brought a troublesome tour to a triumphant close today by deftly polishing off Fred Haney's Pirates, 5 to 1, for a clean sweep of the two-game series.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Secret Service investigated a story of a plot to kill President Eisenhower on his visit to Fredericksburg, Va., today and discounted it.

One of the truisms of political life is that nothing happens until it happens. Governments that depend on public opinion are never quite prepared for the event. No matter how clearly the occurrence is foreseen, even planned for, the impact is startling and the consequences unexpected.

Not all the news from the Far East is grim. The second series of post-war Asian Games has just been concluded in Manila. This is a revival of the old pre-war "Far Eastern Olympics," but on a much larger scale. About a thousand athletes took part, representing the Philippines, Japan, Nationalist China, South Korea, Singapore, India, Pakistan, Burma, Indonesia, Hong Kong, Israel, Ceylon, Afghanistan and Malaya.

Craig Claiborne, a fresh-faced young man who has just completed ten months of study in a hotel school in Switzerland, enthusiastically talked to us about French cooking the other day. He was eating a lunch that included, among other things, a Martini and a shrimp cocktail.

Five major bread and cake concerns that have had 60 per cent of their production curtailed by a nine-day strike offered yesterday to increase workers' wages and employer contributions to the union health and welfare fund.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 9 -- It is understood here that the board of Unilever is negotiating for official listing on the New York Stock Exchange, following the visit of Keith Funston, president of the exchange.
WASHINGTON, May 9--Senator John L. McClellan said tonight that the Republicans would be responsible if the McCarthy-Army hearings were cut off without taking public testimony from all the principals.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- In the light of the grave situation in Indo-China and plans for a Southeast Asian alliance, President Eisenhower is expected to consider increases in the defense budget for 1955.

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 9 -- The outcome of long negotiations aimed at untangling Swiss-French economic relations has produced acrid comment here. The results of two sets of talks, which ended at about the same time, are regarded in Swiss business circles as being exceedingly favorable to the French. They are as follows:

PITTSBURGH, May 9 -- Steel traders expect no surge in production during the second quarter but they do believe that the trend will be slowly upward. The fractional decline last week was not believed to have been significant or to presage a reversal in the trend of the past several weeks.

CINCINNATI, May 9 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski, Cincinnati's powerhouse, hammered three home runs over the right-field screen today as the St. Louis Cardinals won the first game of a double-header, 10 -- 7, and the Redlegs came back in the afterpiece for a 6-5 victory.

SAUK CITY, Wis., May 9 (AP) -- Leroy Gore, founder of the "Joe Must Go" movement, said tonight he and the club's treasurer had been subpoenaed to appear at a Sauk County John Doe investigation Wednesday.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 9 -- The Internationals unfurled their new dacron sails for the first race of the Sparkman Trophy series today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

A four-game winning streak is not so bad, so the Yankees were not too unhappy that darkness halted yesterday's nightcap with the Athletics at a 1-1 nine-inning standstill before 23,909 fans at the Stadium.

GREAT RIVER, L. I., May 9 -- The Long Island State Park Commission will open the Bayard Cutting Arboretum to the public next Saturday. The 643-acre tract was deeded to the state by Mrs. Bayard James, in memory of her father, W. Bayard Cutting.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday the award of medals to thirty-three members of the Police Department for outstanding acts of heroism during 1953.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Bachman's Warbler, regarded as the rarest songbird in America, was sighted for the first time in more than sixteen years in near-by Virginia yesterday.

An easier undertone for the British pound sterling marked the trading in foreign exchanges this last week. Canadian dollar recorded only minor fluctuations as the volume of business dropped off considerably.

Prices of cotton futures held in a narrow range again last week. At the close Friday active contracts were up 25 to 70 cents a bale, or 5 to 14 points, compared with the previous week's close. Only the current May delivery lost ground.
Something new has been added on Lord Taylor's main floor. A "fashion bazaar," featuring unusual fashion and gift accessories, is opening today to the public.

High on a hill overlooking a busy parkway that runs through the suburb of Mount Vernon, N. Y., is a house that has been standing there for 200 years. It has been completely renovated, and in the process the owner found that his life had been changed.

The Brazilian Coffee Institute officially denied here yesterday recent reports of a carryover of as much as 4,000,000 bags of 132 pounds each. Horacio Cintra Leite, representative of the institute, said it would be the smallest carryover in recent years and not more than 1,765,000 bags.
LONDON, May 9 -- The setback in the stock markets recorded a week ago has, as expected, proved of short duration.

" Journey Without End," Manes Sperber's final novel in a trilogy, will be issued May 24 by Doubleday. In "The Burned Bramble" and "The Abyss" Mr. Sperber told about the Communist movement in Western Europe and the party's betrayal of its heroes.

Perhaps next season will mark Rose Franken's return to Broadway as a dramatist. Remembered for "Another Language" and "Claudia," Miss Franken hasn't been represented on the local stage since "The Hallams" (1948).

Bishop Frederick Buckley Newell yesterday described two forces present in the world today -- the power to move things and the power to transform men -- both of which, he said, were essential in building an expanding civilization.
GENEVA, May 9 -- The Geneva conference's plenary session on Korea scheduled for tomorrow afternoon was canceled today.

Special Sessions Justice John E. Cone Jr. told members of the Catholic Guild of the Department of Health yesterday that parental control and affection and the guidance of church and synagogue were basic in combating juvenile delinquency.

The Household Finance Corporation reported yesterday that its net income for the March quarter had totaled $4,371,998, equal to $1.31 a common share, as compared with $4,066,915, or $1.21 a share, in the corresponding period last year.
The British cable-laying ship Monarch is being refitted to spin the first submarine telephone cable under the Atlantic Ocean.
Following is a round-up by The United Press of foreign editorial comment on the hearings by the Permanent Senate Subcommittee on Investigations in the Army-McCarthy case:

JERUSALEM, May 9 -- A chorus of voices calling for mass immigration to Israel arose in meetings around the nation over the week-end. Almost drowned out were reminders that several more years of work and outside financial aid were needed before Israel could take care of her present population.

Mr. Truman did his countrymen a service at his birthday party in this city on Saturday evening by speaking for a group much larger and a group infinitely smaller than the Democratic party. He spoke for all Americans who might find themselves less free or less well governed if the legitimate power of the Executive were usurped by Congress.

The pungent aroma of brewing coffee pervades Altman's housewares department this week. More effectively than a circus barker, it draws shoppers every day from 9:30 A. M. to 5:30 P.M. to a demonstration of devices for preparing and serving America's favorite brew.

An account of the "continuous fight" for civil liberties in the United States in the past three decades will be issued Saturday by Horizon Press under the title "The Education of an American Liberal." The author is Lucille B. Milner, former secretary of the American Civil Liberties Union.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The European Travel Commission, composed of representatives of twenty-one countries of Western Europe, presented to President Eisenhower today a scroll honoring him for his aid to world travel and understanding.
JERUSALEM, May 10 -- Prime Minister Moshe Sharett said today that Israel was ready at any time to begin peace negotiations with any of the neighboring Arab states.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- A "protective committee for leased lines and bond holders" today asked permission to take part in the fight over control of the New York Central Railroad, siding with the present management.

Beacon Village, a rental housing project for sixty-eight families, at 728 East Front Street in Plainfield, N. J., has changed ownership through the sale of stock by Max J. Levine to the 500 Brunswick Avenue Corporation.

Arthur Godfrey told his television and radio audience yesterday that he would undergo surgery again in the hope of correcting a hip injury suffered years ago in an automobile accident. He said that his first hip operation a year ago had failed to relieve the trouble.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 10 -- The Times of Ceylon reported today that the United States had suggested that Ceylon should terminate her rubber contract with Red China in exchange for United States assistance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- The stage was set today for the showdown between Richard F. Walsh, president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, and Roy M. Brewer, former official of the A. F. L. union, for control over 80,000 stage and motion-picture industry workers.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., May 10 -- Mal Galletta, North Hills, and Henry Castillo, Fresh Meadow, clipped 6 strokes from par with 32, 34 -- 66 to take the first Long Island professional Golfers amateur-pro tournament of the season at the Brookville Country Club today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10 -Far from becoming a "welfare state," this country has spent a smaller proportion of its income for welfare in recent years than in the depression period of the early 1930's, it was contended here today.
ATLANTA, May 10 (AP) -- A weeping group of fifty white and Negro women made another appeal to the Georgia Board of Pardons and paroles today for the freedom of Mrs. Rosa Lee Ingram.

NEW DELHI, India, May 10 -While praising President Eisenhower's plan for exploitation and control of atomic energy for peaceful purposes, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that an earlier United States proposal for an international atomic policing agency outside the United Nations was "absurd."
Harold W. Scott yesterday was elected chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange, succeeding Richard M. Crooks.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., May 10 -- The Westchester County Golf Association opened its pro-amateur best-ball one-day tournament season over the hilly Leewood Course today. Despite the rain, sixty-nine turned out for the competition.

LONDON, May 10 -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, United States Ambassador, told British business men today that he had found no one in United States business or Government circles who felt a serious depression was due.
A juror was dismissed in the Queens sewer fraud trial yesterday after he and the chief assistant district attorney discovered that they had been living in the same apartment house for several years.
ALBANY, May 10 -- The State Education Department announced today the names of 1,694 high school students who had won this year's state college scholarships.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -Former President Truman did not ask to see President Eisenhower when he was in Washington today.

An exhibition of unpublished letters and other personal possessions of Florence Nightingale will go on display tomorrow at Teachers College, Columbia University. The display is in observance of the nursing pioneer's 134th birthday and the 100th anniversary of her work in the Crimean War.

FOR fifteen years, from 1932 to 1947, Lucien Price played a modest and gentlemanly Boswell to Alfred North Whitehead's serene and kindly Johnson. Mr. Price was an affectionate and admiring disciple of the great English mathematician and philosopher, but he was unawed by him. Mr. Price is a learned man himself, an editorial writer on The Boston Globe, a student of music, of Greek literature and philosophy and of classic civilization.

A new plan to insure blood donors against their families' need for blood and a daily clearinghouse inventory of surpluses and rare types in New York State were announced yesterday. The two programs were described by officials of the Blood Banks Association of New York State at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Old Greenwich Village will be refurbished with the finery of Manhattan's brash midtown.

The Canadian province of Saskatchewan has borrowed privately about $18,800,000 through two issues of debentures in the New York and Canadian markets. The purpose of the financing was to refund debt into obligations bearing lower interest rates.

Foul weather between here and Westover Air Force Base, Mass., prevented the Air Force yesterday from carrying out maneuvers by jet fighter planes from Westover over Battery Park. The small crowd that braved the local weather saw brief demonstrations by a big Navy helicopter and a smaller Army one.
Members of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York held their annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the York Club.

Spring continued to play hard to get with New Yorkers and their neighbors yesterday. While rainclouds occasionally let the sun flicker through in the city, the elements were harsher on suburbanites. Residents in various sections of New Jersey and Westchester were pelted with intermittent haft, heavy rain and even snow.
Seaboard and Western Airlines, the largest United States all-freight carrier flying the North Atlantic completed seven years of transoceanic operations yesterday.
TOKYO, Tuesday, May 11 (AP) -- A Vietminh broadcast heard here today for the first time mentioned General de Castries by name and confirmed previous reports that he had been made a prisoner.

The possibility was raised here yesterday that Federal reinsurance for voluntary health insurance plans might be given a trial for a few years if the program was placed in the control of organized medicine. The question was discussed at the opening session of the 148th annual meeting of the New York State Medical Society.
The defense rested yesterday in the grand larceny trial of Joseph P. Ryan, former president of the old International Longshoremen's Association.
HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., May 10 -A strike of cement workers may upset plans to open the first toll section of the New York-Buffalo Thruway on June 24.

Cotton, a miracle of nature rather than of the laboratory, is the subject of heavy advertising throughout the country this week. Yesterday was the official start of National Cotton Week, and stores and communities are celebrating.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -President Eisenhower told a group of Hawaiians today that he was very eager that the Hawaiian statehood bill be passed but that the matter was in the hands of Congress.
GENEVA, May 10 -- The Vietminh brushed aside the French proposal for halting the fighting in Indo-China today and offered its own.
Cotton futures closed steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Final prices were 1 to 13 points above those on last Friday.

WHEN Marse Joe McCarthy was managing the Yankees, his conversational footwork was superb. He could sidestep more direct questions than any other man in the business. A fellow who sparred with him often enough always knew which stock answer to expect.
The Board of Education will meet today to elect a president and vice president for the coming year.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Eisenhower Administration proposed to Congress today that Communist-dominated labor unions or business concerns be outlawed. At the same time,...
FOR the first time in four years Arnold Blanch is holding a one-man show of his recent paintings at Associated American Artists.
NEW HAVEN, May 10 -- A faculty report today said that $30,000,000 was needed for a construction and renovation program to end overcrowding at Yale University.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- Allan E. Sloane, author of the film biography of Martin Luther, has told Houses of Representatives' investigators he is a former Communist who quit the party because officials tried to slant his writing.

THERE are volumes on every phase of angling but one -- what to do when a persistent rain raises the trout stream, discolors the water and imprisons you in a camp or hostelry on the margin of the stream.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $4,775,000 yesterday on temporary short-term notes at a cost of about 1/27th of one per cent. This represents a saving of more than 5/8 of one per cent over current interest yields on short-term borrowings.

Dr. Alfred Schattner has terminated an ownership of thirty years in the sale of the three-story dwelling at 308 West Forty-eighth Street, near Eighth Avenue. The buyer is Nicolette Proscia, who acquired the property for all cash in a stransaction negotiated by L. J. Phillips Co. as brokers.
The election of Harold A. Rousselot and Douglas Leigh as directors of the Montauk Beach Company, developer of Montauk, L. L., was announced yesterday by Lindsey Hopkins, president of the company.
The Policewomen's Endowment Association denied yesterday that it was seeking to supplant men officers in its fight for equal rights.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Hogs declined 25 to 50 cents today, heavy weight offerings falling the most. The top of $27.10 paid for one load, was the lowest since March 23 and a good $1.65 under the high set April 22.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 10 (AP) -Democratic National Committeeman Carmine G. DeSapio said tonight "an absurd offshoot of a self-assumed crusade" had this nation's Government "virtually at a standstill."
M. W. Grober has been elected president and general manager of the Condenser Service and Engineering Co., Inc., to succeed Herman Kahn, who has been elected chairman.

MILWAUKEE, May 10 (AP) -- Milwaukee's Eddie Mathews, a young man with a problem at the plate, provided himself with a couple of pocketbook penalties today when he tried to outrun a suburban police squad car at 3 A. M.
PARIS, May 10 -- Madeleine de Rauch fashions smart beach and sport clothes of coarse sacking, but the garments show finesse in color and fabric contrast.
May I comment on your editorial of May 4 entitled "Water Metering at Last."
Frank Costello's finances were bounced around like a pin ball yesterday at the 61-year-old gambler's income tax evasion trial in Federal Court.

LONDON, May 10 -- The Government emphasized today that it was not committed to any course of action by the staff talks on the future of Indo-China in which the British, United States and other officers were engaged.

YONKERS, May 10 (AP) -- Bill Haughton, leading driver at Yonkers Raceway, came through in the mud tonight with Florita to win the $4,500 Briarcliff mile pace in 2:13 as the Grand Circuit meeting got underway.
LOUISVILLE, May 10 (AP) -- A New York optometrist has demonstrated a new clear-image lens that he says will enable persons with only 2 per cent vision to read with ease.

Any lingering hope for positive results from the Geneva conference began to fade when the Communists totally rejected the French plan for cessation of hostilities in Indo-China and submitted a "peace" plan of their own which goes even beyond the pattern of conquest they advanced for Germany and Korea and demands in effect complete French and free world capitulation.

Good bookings at the boys' and children's wear shows here yesterday put manufacturers in an optimistic mood. The two shows reported sizable orders for back-to-school apparel and requests for immediate delivery to fill depleted shelves.

BALTIMORE, May 10 (UP) -- A four-run ninth-inning splurge off relief pitcher Bob Trice gave a 7-to-6 victory to the Baltimore Orioles over the Philadelphia Athletics tonight before a chilled gathering of 7,887. It was Baltimore's second straight triumph.
LONDON, May 10 -- Dainty filigree jewelry and sturdy household appliances are among the hundreds of displays calculated to catch the eyes of women visitors to the British Industries Fair.

Mayor Wagner issued a proclamation yesterday setting May 17 to 23 as "Letters from America Week," as he greeted representatives of the sponsoring Common Council for American Unity in City Hall. They were:
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Former President Truman today urged President Eisenhower to disavow "political assassins" in the Republican party to make possible bipartisan cooperation in foreign policy.

ROME, May 10 -- Maureen Connolly added a new championship to her long list of titles today when she won the Rome international tournament women's singles. The American girl defeated Pat Ward of England, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

A blockfront site in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been purchased for immediate improvement with a shopping center. The land is at West 235th Street and Johnson Avenue and comprises 72,500 square feet. Completion is scheduled before the end of the year on the project, which will contain a super market, a variety store and sixteen other retail outlets.

Last summer I spent some time in London and was astonished at the almost total absence of horn blowing London does not have as many automobiles as New York, but it has much narrower streets, and in many sections of London the traffic is at least as bad as anything in New York.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -A union official today defied a National Labor Relations Board subpoena requiring him to appear at a hearing questioning the truthfulness of his non-Communist affadavit.

There Are No Tools The gardening season has come around again, and it is clear that as usual no one has any tools. All day long small emissaries from remote neighbors skip up the front walk, knock upon the door and then ask whether it would be all right to borrow a spade.

The outlook for the anthracite coal industry for the balance of this year has improved as a result of the production allocation program that went into effect on March 29, Edward G. Fox, president of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, told stockholders yesterday in Philadelphia.

BEIRA, Mozambique, May 10 -- The fight against racial segregation and the creation of white reserves shutting out the African Negro from parts of his native land are being led here by a Roman Catholic bishop.

The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is opening an exhibition of American paintings tomorrow that points up the profound change in policy of the institution since it was known as the Museum of Non-Objective Painting.

As the Army-McCarthy hearings continue, Senator McCarthy develops with increasing clarity his theory of government. This theory, Legislative supremacy, violates our constitutional principle of separation of powers. Legislative supremacy is compatible with, and may even be conducive to, democracy.
OTTAWA, May 10 (UP) -- Thirteen Canadian football games will be televised nationally in the United States this fall, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation announced today.

The Navy varsity and junior varsity and the Cornell freshman eight were seeded first yesterday for the heavyweight regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges. The races will be held Saturday over a 2,000-meter course on the Potomac at Washington.
A new express bus plan to encourage patronage of New York theatres by residents of New Jersey was inaugurated in Newark last night.

" Parents have the experts at their mercy" when it comes to encouraging a child to read and guiding his growth in the world of books, Miss Margaret Martignoni said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Parents League of New York.

Playclothes created for children this season are practical, comfortable, amusing and fashion-right. There is great diversity in the various types of dress and undress that youngsters will wear outdoors this summer on beaches and lawns for their tireless activities.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- All grain futures were weak and sharply lower in the early trade, reversing the trend of late Friday. Soybeans were higher early in contrast to the weak grain markets but later showed substantial declines.

New issues of natural gas and public utility company debt securities totaling $47,500,000 and bearing interest of 3 1/4 per cent and 3 per cent will be placed on the market today by banking syndicates. Most of the money raised will be used to retire by call outstanding debt bearing higher interest charges.

It is clear from interviews that Foreign Minister Popovich and Marshal Tito gave to C. L. Sulzberger of this newspaper in Belgrade last weekend that one more plan to solve the Trieste dilemma is close to formulation. What comes as a surprise is that the Yugoslav Foreign Minister should have discussed so openly negotiations that had been kept in the strictest secrecy.
The Opera Players produced three contemporary operas at the Provincetown Playhouse down in the Village last night, and it all seemed to prove that in numbers there is not necessarily strength.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A cloak-and-dagger man from Moscow is scheduled to expose secrets on Capitol Hill tomorrow.
The Navy chartered ten vessels last month to bring the total of privately owned and operated American-flag cargo ships and tankers under charter at the end of April to fifty-five.

The St. Joseph Lead Company, largest United States mine producer of lead and a leading zinc producer, expects results for the balance of the year to be better than its first-quarter net of 40 cents a share, whch compared with 74 cents a year ago.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 10 -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay tonight gave support to the construction of another big multipurpose dam on the main stem of the Columbia River.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations decided today to go ahead with its no-raiding pact with the American Federation of Labor without the United Steelworkers.

PARIS, May 10 -- Three more questions concerning the establishment of blame for the French defeat at Dienbienphu were filed with the National Assembly today. They came from different parties and insured that there would be a debate tomorrow on setting a date for discussion.
TRENTON, May 10 -- The Republican majority in the New Jersey Legislature today postponed for two weeks further action on bills designed to increase by $28,500,000 state aid to schools.
Twenty feet beneath a major intersection, a wall away from the tracks of a subway express, a 15-year-old Brooklyn boy slept in a manhole for twelve nights ending at 1 A. M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today sales of series "E" and "H" savings bonds in April were higher than in any April since 1945 and were 11 per cent higher than sales in April, 1953. Earl O. Shreve, national director of the savings bond program, said April sales were $390,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Civilian officials of the Army and Senate Democrats appeared tonight to have beaten a plan by Senate Republican leaders for swift termination of the public hearings on the Army-McCarthy controversy.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its thirteenth day of considering the dispute between Senator Joseph E. McCarthy and the Army.
Puerto Rico recently made a generous gesture of friendship for the Belgian Congo providing a welcome change from general international ill will.
Directors of the Mathieson Chemical Corporation and Olin Industries, Inc., voted unanimously yesterday to merge the two concerns.

Composers of Today presented an opera preview last night in the Town Hall Club at its third and final program of the season. It consisted of the first two scenes of "Bartleby," an opera by William Flanagan, with a libretto by James Hinton Jr., based on a story by Herman Melville.

Commodity prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee led the rises, closing up the 2 cents a pound daily limit in all position. Cocoa was up the 1-cent limit in most positions during the day but eased slightly at the close.

Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey, U. S. N. retired, was chosen president of the Propeller Club, Port of New York, at the annual membership meeting yesterday afternoon at the Downtown Athletic Club, 19 West Street.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that April showers improved wheat crop prospects in much of the drought-plagued Great Plains and got the 1954 planting and growing season for other crops off to an encouraging start.

The United States would have come under an atom bomb attack by now if it were not for the Tennessee Valley Authority and its ability to produce an extraordinary amount of electric power, according to Mayor George R. Dempster of Knoxville, Tenn.
JERUSALEM, May 10 -- Israeli forces opened fire along a twelve-mile sector of the armistice line today, according to Jordanian charges filed with the United Nations Mixed Armistice Commission.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 10 -- The closing event of the twenty-fourth annual Eastman School of Music Festival of American Music was a concert tonight by the Eastman Symphonic Wind Ensemble, conducted by Frederick Fennell. This had been scheduled for last week, but was postponed because of the death of Dr. Howard Hanson's mother.

A continuing upward trend in Italian motion-picture production and box-office receipts has been reported by Italian Films Export. The figures are soon to be published in Cinemundus, the Italian producers' publication.

GENEVA, May 10 -- A plenary session to discuss the Korean phase of the Far Eastern conference has been called for tomorhow afternoon. Georges Bidault, Foreign Minister of France, and Paul-Henry Spaak of Belgium are tentatively scheduled to speak.

SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras, May 10 -- The inability of striking United Fruit Company laborers to agree on representatives in wage negotiations apparently is hindering Government efforts to bring together employes and management for talks.

Ben W. Heineman, Chicago attorney who has been waging a proxy battle for control of the $38,000,000 Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway Company, predicted yesterday an "overwhelming victory" for his group. The dispute is to be settled today at the annual meeting of stockholders at the Chanin Auditorium.

Hosiery shipments in the first quarter dipped from the first quarter of 1953, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reported. In this year's three-month period 40,103,633 dozen pairs were shipped, against 41,638,123 dozen last year.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 10 -- The International Court of Justice opened hearings today in the case of $2,880,000 worth of gold awarded to Britain and claimed by Italy.

The New York Shipping Association would be well advised to take to heart the courageous words of Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority. In a speech before the New York Chamber of Commerce he reviewed the negative attitude of the association toward waterfront reform.
Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., won the second match in the national round-robin tennis tournament last night.
