WASHINGTON, May 10 -- J. Edgar Hoover -- who has been exposing Communists and Red operations for more than thirty years -- is convinced today the hunt for spies and subversives is a job for professionals such as the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 10 -- Proper deployment of troops will limit field casualties of nuclear warfare to slightly more than twice those of conventional warfare, a United States expert said today.
Directors of the Standard Oil Company of Kentucky declared an extra dividend of 20 cents yesterday along with the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, both payable June 10.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short term borrowing costs have increased slightly above the six-year-seven-months low reported last week.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 9 -- The new Government of Paraguay, headed by Tomas Romero Pereira, Provisional President, will receive automatic recognition from other countries, foreign diplomats said today.

Events today: Walter Baker, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; Wheeler Beckett Orchestra Youth Concert, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "The Sorrows of Orpheus," "The Way to Happy Town" and "Edgar and Emily," Provincetown Playhouse, 8:30; Dessoff Choirs, Town Hall, 8:45; Bach's B Minor Mass., St. Thomas Church, 8:15.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Republican Congressional leaders said after a White House conference today they had abandoned "temporarily at least" any plan to revise the Taft-Hartley Labor Law at this session of Congress.
More realism in the treatment of foreign students here and in programs taken abroad in the field of home economics was urged yesterday.

The city can be proud of the 42,873 youngsters who have bravely accepted the needle to help the scientists determine whether the new Salk vaccine is a practical and effective way of preventing poliomyelitis.
LONDON, May 10 -- The advance in the stock markets slowed today, British Government securities slipped quietly and the rise in industrials was not as vigorous as at the end of last week.
PARIS, May 10 -- A troupe of the Soviet Union's best ballet dancers fell an unexpected victim today to the Communist military victory at Dienbienphu in Indo-China.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- For a second time in two years, a special committee of the House of Representatives began today public investigation into the expenditures by philanthropic and educational foundations.
LIMA, Peru, May 10 -- President Manuel A. Odria opened a new irrigation system today that will guarantee a livelihood for 1,000 Peruvians and help raise living standards by increased food production.

William E. Boss has been appointed vice president of the R. C. A. Victor Distributing Corporation in charge of the Buffalo-Rochester branch. The company is a subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America.

LOS ANGELES, May 10 -- Labor leaders of the United States and Mexico will hold a three-day conference in Laredo, Tex., starting tomorrow to plan joint action on the importation of seasonal Mexican farm labor into this country.

Albert Thompson of Columbia set a Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association record for the discus throw yesterday. The Lion senior also won the shot-put test as the throwing events of the association's twenty-first annual championship games were completed at Baker Field.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 10. The former Brazilian military attache in the United States, Col. Juracy Magalhaes, was inducted today as president of the Brazilian Petroleum Corporation, better known as Petrobras, a Government petroleum monopoly.
One of the most frequent questions asked about the network of 423 agencies helped by the Greater New York Fund is, "Can't these agencies support themselves?"
General Mills, Inc., has sold its home appliance business to the Illinois McGraw Electric Company, Elgin, Ill.
Mayor Wagner has received recommendations from one of his own advisory groups favoring revenue sources that he or his top fiscal aides already have rejected.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Industrialists said today the time and the opportunity to get a new atomic power industry "off the ground" was at hand.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 10 -- The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., announced today that it was worth more than $250,000,000.

Plans are being formulated for a garden party in behalf of the Army Young Men's Christian Association at Governors Island. The party will be given on the afternoon of May 19 at Fort Jay, Governors Island, by members of the board of governors of the Army Y. M. C. A.

Frantz Casseus, Haitian guitarist, made his debut in a recital at Town Hall last evening. A native of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, Mr. Casseus is a self-taught guitarist who has appeared at concerts in Haiti and Latin America since 1941.

CLEVELAND, May 10 -- Eight Indians, seven before an out was made, scored in the first inning tonight. That's how the Cleveland club downed the Yankees, 8 -- 7, before 22,456 fans, who shivered through 3 hours and 1 minute of action that turned from farcical face-making and arguing to sensible, serious struggling with a dramatic ninth-inning finish.

GENEVA, May 10 (AP) -Following is the text of a proposal presented today by the Communist-led Vietminh in Indo-China, which calls itself the "Democratic Republic of Vietnam," plus excerpts from speech by Pham Van Dong, Vietminh Foreign Minister. and the speeches of Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Under Secretary of State, and Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary:

A $100,000 damage claim against the city and a Police Department investigation resulted yesterday from a beating incident in which a policeman is accused. A former Fordham University student who recently took the Civil Service examinations for policeman was the victim.
The New York Giants and the Boston Red Sox will play an exhibition game at the Polo Grounds Monday night, June 28, under the sponsorship of the American Red Cross.

The appointment of H. Charles Bartlett as senior vice president in charge of merchandising and sales promotion for Macy's Kansas City was announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

NEW DELHI, India, May 10 -- India has protested the exclusion of the New Delhi Government from further Far East war criminal proceedings as a nonsignatory of the San Francisco treaty of peace with Japan.

Lower taxes in the first quarter this year enabled the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company and its subsidiaries to report yesterday an increase in its net income to $5,354,866, from $4,354,859 earned in the initial three months last year.
Household scissors, used almost daily by the average housewife, are in the news today.

Cardinal Spellman dedicated yesterday afternoon the Lieut. Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Memorial Community Center at 34 West 134th Street. The center, formerly the Harlem Boys Club, was purchased by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York with funds supplied by the Lieut. Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 (AP) -- This steel city's estimated 200,000 commuters crowded into the Golden Triangle today, most of them in time for work, despite a strike of 2,700 trolley and bus operators.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- A banker today called for "downward adjustments" in Federal bank reserve requirements to loosen up credit.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee today approved extension of the suspension of tariffs on copepr imports for another two years, starting June 30, the expiration date of the present suspension.
BOSTON, May 10 -- New legal entanglements forced the American Woolen Company today to postpone the completion of the annual meeting for another forty-eight hours.

Floyd Patterson, unbeaten Brooklyn light heavyweight, notched his thirteenth triumph last night by winning a unanimous decision over Jesse Turner of St. Louis in the eight-round feature bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn. Patterson weighed 165 1/2 pounds, Turner 157 3/4.

The Society of the Silurians, an association of newspaper veterans, last night assailed efforts to penalize lawyers and law-enforcement officials who make public information to be used in forthcoming criminal trials.

AUBURN, N. Y., May 10 -- Republican Assemblymen from thirty-six rural counties went as far as they dared today in calling for the renomination of Governor Dewey and the selection of Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck of Schenectady for Lieutenant Governor.

The Phoenix Theatre, operating successfully this season as an off-Broadway playhouse under the expert ministrations of T. Edward Hambleton and Norris Houghton, presents Chekhov's "The Sea Gull" tonight at 8 o'clock.

The new Division of Internal Security in the Justice Department has been established to emphasize and to expedite the Government's continuing program against subversives. Prosecutions in this field have up to now been undertaken by a special section of the Criminal Division, which reportedly has not been able to keep up with the work load.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- The business decline "thus far has not been serious" and there are indications it may be slowing to a halt, Meyer Kestnbaum, chairman of President Eisenhower's Study Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, said today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The urgency with which the Administration is studying revision of defense policy was dramatized this afternoon by an unscheduled conference called by President Eisenhower with military and foreign policy aides.
I was much interested in a news dispatch article in your issue of April 24 in which you gave the salient points of Dr Hans Kraus' report on the muscular fitness of American school children.

The steamship company members of the New York Shipping Association declared yesterday that Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, had made an "unwarranted, malicious and untruthful attack" on the association.
The Port of New York rebounded sharply last month from the idleness caused by the twenty-five-day longshoremen's strike, Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs here, reported yesterday.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 10 -The number of handicapped persons not receiving rehabilitation treatment in the United States is increasing at an alarming rate.
ATHENS, May 10 (UP) -- Gun Son-hoh of Nationalist China and Russia's Konstantin Andrianov engaged in a sharp exchange today during a meeting of the International Olympic committee.

DURBAN, South Africa, May 5 -- The South African Government has asked the Scandinavian, Israeli and Netherlands air lines to curtail their services to Johannesburg. The request is said to be part of a new policy toward foreign-scheduled airlines operating to South Africa.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Sharp attacks on the Administration's foreign policy put new strains on bipartisanship today as the Senate faced the Indo-China crisis with troubled debate.

Lack of any Communist attempt at violent overthrow of the French and Italian Governments was offered here yesterday as proof that there was "no clear and present danger" from the American Communist party.

GENEVA, May 10 -- The Geneva conference appeared today to have reached a concrete agreement on evacuation of the seriously wounded French Union and anti-Communist Vietnamese prisoners from Dienbienphu.

Harold Vanderbilt and the New York Central Railroad Company renewed their request yesterday that the New York Supreme Court postpone the May 26 stockholders' meeting scheduled to decide the proxy battle for control of the road.

For the first handicap race of his career, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer will carry 130 pounds. The 4-year-old son of Polynesian has drawn that impost for the Metropolitan Handicap, the one-mile race that will be contested at Belmont Park Saturday.
Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas proposed last night that the United States set up an atomic plant in Asia dedicated to peace.
Karl Robbins, chairman of the board of Robbins Mills, Inc., textile manufacturer, has arranged to sell his interest in the company to an undisclosed purchaser.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 10 -- French and Laotian battalions defeated several battalions of Vietminh troops today near Muongkhoua, thirty-five miles southwest of fallen Dienbienphu.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- An important patent issued recently to a New York physician has precipitated a court contest over royalties on the major part of this country's penicillin production.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address today by former President Truman before the National Press Club and his replies to written questions:

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UP) -- The Army has drafted a two-part program -- including a modified universal military training plan -- to strenghten the Reserves and force veterans to fulfill their reserve obligations.

Today's new film is "Rails into Laramie," a Universal Western adventure in Technicolor, with John Payne, Mari Blanchard and Dan Duryea, at the Holiday Theatre. Ted Richmond produced and Jesse Hibbs directed from a screen play by D. D. Beauchamp and Joseph Hoffman.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- James M. Symes, executive vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad since January, 1952, will succeed Walter S. Franklin as president of the world's largest transportation system on June 1.
Cleveland sold $15,726,000 of tax bonds in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 1.96795 per cent.
A 17-year-old German girl, who has been in the United States as an exchange student, left New York for home by plane yesterday without knowing that doctors give her only one month to live.
CHICAGO, May 11 -- The Government's May report estimating a winter wheat crop almost 30,000,000 bushels above the April forecast, touched off another wave of long liquidation of heavy volume.

Connecticut started the first public financing yesterday for the state's projected $398,000,000 toll expressway by selling $100,000,000 of bonds to a group of investment bankers at an interest cost of 2.8569 per cent.

JERUSALEM, Jordanian Sector, May 11 -- The United Nations Jordanian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission condemned Israel today in the strongest terms for invading Jordanian territory in platoon strength and bringing United Nations observers under mortar fire.
Whimsy marks the exhibit of the Nymolle faienceware opening today at Georg Jensen, 667 Fifth Avenue. Sketches by leading Danish artists decorate the ceramic pieces.
LONDON, May 11 -- A Foreign Office spokesman took the unusual step today of expressing official regret that Marshal Tito had disclosed a new plan for settling the Trieste dispute.

A General Sessions jury yesterday convicted Edmund C. Buehler, former chief of the investigating unit of the State Temporary Rent Commission, of extortion and conspiracy in a $9,500 shakedown of Manhattan rooming house operators.
BONN, Germany, May 11 -- The possibility of establishing diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union is being discussed with increasing favor by right-wing legislators.
OMAHA, Neb., May 11 (UP) -- People aren't taking their lunch to work with them any more, and that's one reason why there is a surplus of wheat, a New Jersey market expert believes.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's proceedings in Washington of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its fourteenth day of considering the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 11 -- The role of the United States in helping rebuild Europe's economy was praised today by Gunnar Myrdal, one of the United Nations' top economists.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 11 (AP) -- Mary Mills, an eighth grader from Gulfport, Miss., upset Mrs. Maurice Glick of Baltimore, 1 up, on the twenty-third hole today in the women's southern golf tournament.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange opened irregularly yesterday, 5 points lower to 8 points higher than on Monday, and closed barely steady and very uneven, 26 points lower to 15 points higher.

Mayor Wagner said last night he was still looking for a way to avoid extending the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services. He expressed the hope that if no other way were found, the sales tax extension would be temporary -- either until the city got added financial help from the state or until long-range economies in municipal housekeeping were effected.

Initial orders at the show conducted by the Boys' Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association at the New Yorker Hotel have been larger than during recent seasons. Buyers were reported to have more confidence and are covering a greater part of their fall needs at the show.

JOLLY CHOLLY GRIMM was discovered in a rather pensive mood. Since his Milwaukee Braves were dragging along near the bottom of the standings, it had not been expected that Jolly Cholly would be found doing cartwheels in great jubilation. So he was invited to tell about his troubles.
LONDON, May 11 -- Industrial shares resumed their climb on the stock markets today, but British Government securities weakened slightly.
VIENNA, May 11 -- Is public opinion really informed on important international subjects?

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that Indo-China was extremely important but not essential to the preservation of the rest of Southeast Asia from Communist control.
Ship construction in this country's private yards last month continued its slump -- going well below the "desperate" mark, with only thirty-two vessels being built.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 11 -- Fifty B-26 bombers and Privateers were officially reported today to have destroyed three villages from which the Vietminh was harassing the Hanoi-Haiphong communications east of Hanoi.
A new detergent designed to produce more suds than other types prepared for automatic washers is being tested in Cleveland and Boston.

Two television networks carrying the McCarthy-Army hearings, faced with the possibility of night hearings, were about as uncertain on the issue yesterday as was the Senate committee hearing the dispute.

ROME, May 11 -- Italian official circles refused to be ruffled today by what is considered here to be a trap laid for them by the Yugoslav Government in connection with the Trieste issue. The pros and cons of establishing a Central Relocation Agency operating under a single set of regulations for all slum clearance throughout the city have been argued back and forth. In January of this year the City Planning Commission adopted by a vote of four to three a Tenant Relocation Report that favored, among other things, the continuance of piecemeal relocation by the respective agency or developer concerned.

A well-dressed and considerate young man held up an automobile finance company office at Broadway and Fifty-fifth Street last night. After discussing the robbery with two clerks, he walked out with only 50 cents.

The Bach B Minor Mass was performed last evening by the Oratorio Society of New York, with Frederick Heyne as guest conductor, at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church. It was the twenty-seventh complete performance by the Oratorio Society of the B Minor Mass since it first presented the work in 1927.

Salesmen's "aids" are often salesmen's "hindrances," and bulky presentations are left in the car when the salesman calls on a prospect. Herbert D. Bissell, director of merchandising for the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, thus assessed today's selling problem before the American Management Association's four hundred members in the Commodore Hotel yesterday.
DETROIT, May 11 (AP) -- Washington's Bob Porterfield downed the league-leading Detroit Tigers with a strong four-hitter today and nailed down a 5-3 victory with a home run in the ninth inning.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 (AP) -- Undersecretary of Agriculture True D. Morse said today that renewed dust storms in the West were a penalty the nation is paying for "high rigid price supports."

Cold winds swept the Mall in Central Park yesterday afternoon as 2,500 girls, representing thirty-four public schools in Manhattan, celebrated the arrival of spring and the forthcoming end of the school year.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Following is the transcript of remarks by Secretary of State Dulles at his news conference today:

Leo P. Carlin, Democrat, last night became the first elected Mayor of Newark since 1915. He defeated two Republican opponents by a plurality of substantial proportions. The 45-year-old labor leader had the endorsement of Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

Monty Irvin's eighth-inning triple, in the wake of a single by Alvin Dark, gave the Giants a 5 -- 4 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The pay-off wallop culminated an uphill struggle by the New Yorkers against Fred Baczewski, who had beaten them five times in as many tries over the past two seasons.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 11 -- Plans for a merger of the Hartford-Connecticut Trust Company and the Phoenix State Bank and Trust Company, two of the city's largest and oldest banks, were approved by officials of both institutions today.

ATHENS, May 11 (AP) -- The last obstacle was cleared today for holding the 1956 Olympic Games in Melbourne, Australia, when the International Olympic Committee voted, 30 -- 13, to select a new site for the equestrian events.
THE weakfish schools are moving into Peconic Bay and although the majority of the fish are in the one-pound class, a few weaks up to four pounds were taken by those chumming with grass shrimp.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

Prentiss M. Brown has been elected a director of Parke, Davis Co., manufacturer of pharmaceuticals. Mr. Brown, a former United States Senator, will retire on July 1 as chairman of the Detroit Edison Company but will continue as a director.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- A biography of John Paul Jones, father of the United States Navy, as outlined by the late Franklin D. Roosevelt, will be available shortly for motion-picture dramatization and book publication under the title, "I Have Not Yet Begun to Fight."
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 11 -- Representatives of natural rubber producing countries asked the United States again today to increase the price of synthetic rubber.
LONDON, May 11 -- Wilfred Kitching, 61, was elected general of the Salvation Army today to succeed Albert Orsborn, who retires June 30.
There was sadness on East Fifty-first Street last night when word came that Charlie the Bootblack was dead.

Events tonight: "The Sorrows of Orpheus," "The Way to Happy Town" and "Edgar and Emily," Provincetown Playhouse, 8:30 P. M.; "Down in the Valley" and "R. S. V. P.," Finch Junior College, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street, 8:40; student concert, New York College of Music, 8:30; "Lohengrin," Dorelle Opera Cameo Series, Studio 73. Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30.

GENEVA, May 11 -- A French delegation source said today that maximum application of the armistice plan proposed by Foreign Minister Georges Bidault for Indo-China would eliminate Vietminh armed forces not only in Cambodia and Laos but in part of the Tonkin Delta and the southern two-thirds of Vietnam.

YONKERS, May 11 (AP) -- Piney Fingo, rushing through the stretch with Bill Haughton driving, won the $4,000 Broadway Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway in 2:07. A neck behind was Hannah Rosecroft, driven by George Phalen.

The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York voted unanimously yesterday to reject the city of Houston, Texas, as a site for the church's next triennial general convention unless an immediate guarantee of a completely non-segregated meeting can be given.

BALTIMORE, May 11 (AP) -- Joe Coleman, 31-year-old right-hander the Orioles acquired from the Philadelphia Athletics last December, beat his former teammates, 2 -- 0, with a brilliant two- hitter tonight. The victory, the third straight for the improving Orioles, enabled them to sweep the two-game series.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The State Department said it had not yet received the Thai offer reported from Bangkok.
BOSTON, May 11 -- The Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination announced a conciliation agreement today that could place white porters and Negro conductors on Pullman trains.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 11 -- The defense rested its case today, the fiftieth day of the trial of Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County, who is charged with having willfully failed to suppress gambling.

Representatives of leading business concerns and cultural institutions in New York have organized to promote "New York Summer Festival, 1954," a project to overcome any hot weather slump in trade by daily bargain sales and frequent public events.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Eisenhower dedicated today the Capitol's processional frieze of more than 400 years of American history.
BANGKOK, Thailand, May 11 (Reuters) -- The Government offered today to grant military bases in Thailand to the free world to aid in resistance against a further Communist advance in southeast Asia.

Orlandus Lassus, Josquin des Pres, Perotinus, Machaut and Monteverdi are among the early composers the Dessoff Choirs have brought off the shelves and into New York's concert life. And now the name of Claude Le Jeune should be added to the honorable list.

In the fall of 1945 the Russians gave a great party at their headquarters in Potsdam to celebrate the anniversary of the Soviet revolution. All the representatives of the occupying Powers in Berlin were present, everybody congratulating everybody else in the happy mood of victors and friends.

State Republican leaders are seeking an agreement with their Democratic counterparts to promote Supreme Court Justice Sidney F. Foster of Liberty to the Court of Appeals, highest tribunal in the state.
Arthur Levitt, a member of the Board of Education for less than two and a half years, became its new president yesterday.
A pro-celebrity golf tournament will highlight the preliminaries today of the Palm Beach round-robin competition, which will start at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury, L. I., tomorrow.
LONDON, May 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that he still believed in high-level talks with the Soviet Union, but that "unhappily" his opinion was not decisive.

Net income of the Admiral Corporation in the first quarter of this year was $1,504,044, equal to 64 cents a share, the company announced yesterday. This compares with $3,056,878, or $1.30 a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1953.

J. LEONARD REINSCH, a soft-spoken individual of many television interests, was in town yesterday on one of his periodic visits and gently made known his conclusion. The game of baseball has got to go. The time has come for television speedball.

The annual meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night condemned as unprofessional any press releases or public statements by lawyers that interfere with fair trials or the due administration of justice.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Defense Department announced tonight the existence in "advanced status" of the supersonic Sperry "Sparrow I" guided missile system.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A special House committee was told in a staff report today that traditional American education of the individual was in danger of giving way to "mass educa tion" through tax-exempt foundations "contrary to the public interest."

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court reserved decision yesterday on a move made last week by Robert R. Young to eliminate or curtail a pre-trial examination of him by attorneys of the New York Central Railroad Company.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 11 -- A memorial forest for Jewish volunteers from the United States who were killed fighting for Israel in the war against the Arab states was planted today in the Judean hills.
An Australian tag-team wrestling exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night ended in favor of Antonino Rocca, 225, South America, and Pat O'Connor, 230, New Zealand.

SAN QUENTON, Calif., May 11 (AP) -- Caryl Chessman talked about reviews of his new book today while a prison doctor, an author and a criminologist tried to save hmi from death in the gas chamber Friday.

The decision taken yesterday, after a day of wrangling, to examine in public all principals in the McCarthy dispute doubtless means that the inquiry will continue for a longer time than would otherwise have been the case. Much as we would like to see the hearings expedited, we feel that this decision, reflecting the position of Secretary Stevens, is sound.
Manhattan College won its fifth straight metropolitan college track and field championship yesterday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

The New York regional blood program of the American Red Cross reported yesterday that 612 pints of blood had been collected on Monday. Of this total, 326 pints were donated by persons working in offices at 444 Madison Avenue and 125 pints by employes of Liebman's Brewery in the Bronx.

Station WOR, which dropped its staff of musicians last February, has offered to spend $200,000 a year for "live" music if the local musicians' union will agree to a new contract and withdraw its pickets from the station's studios.

In a session of quiet readjustment and reappraisal, the stock market started firm yesterday, moved irregularly lower, then steadied before the close. Rails, steels and chemicals were among the biggest losers.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized a three-man "Protective Committee for Leased Lines and Bondholders of the New York Central Railroad" to intervene in the fight over control of the Central.
Domestic steel production last month was slightly more than 4 per cent below that of March and the lowest for any month since the steel strike in the summer of 1952.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 11 (AP) -- An Army major died of a heart ailment at nearby Camp Kilmer early this morning after lying stricken for more than an hour within sight of a sentry, Army authorities reported.
DALLAS, Tex., May 11 (AP) -- Two brothers were arrested and charged today in a bizarre extortion plot to collect $200,000 from twenty of Dallas' top Jewish families.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CLEVELAND, May 11 -- Lady Luck smiled on the Yankees tonight, bringing the New Yorkers a 5-3 victory over the Indians. To win this one the champions needed a couple of lucky breaks in the right spots. They got 'em.

The Janus-faced nature of communism has rarely been more apparent than in matters surrounding France these last few days. On the one hand there has been the Communist "human sea" attack which overwhelmed the heroes of Dienbienphu after pounding them with Soviet artillery which brought death to many.

Perhaps as the weather grows warmer and the daylight longer, inviting one and all to leave the house, a certain young member of the family will be encouraged to spend more time outdoors and less indoors, at her desk.

TORONTO, May 11 (Canadian Press) -- The Toronto Telegram said today that if certain large entertainment organizations in Toronto, Hamilton and London, Ont., did not come to terms on a new contract with the American Guild of Variety Artists, A. F. L., an entertainment "blackout" would be imposed.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad operated in the black for each of the first four months this year, with net income approximating $850,000 before capital and sinking funds, or about 52 cents a share, P. M. Shoemaker, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday. In the corresponding period of 1953 the road's net was $2,001,605, or $1.18 a share.

Twenty-five American authors, Illustrators and book designers of contemporary America were honored last night as the literary figures whose work was judged "most likely to endure as the classics of our time." They or their representatives received silver medals at the twenty-fifth anniversary dinner of the Limited Editions Club, a publishing house, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., will place on the market today a new issue of $35,000,000 of convertible preferred stock of Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of machinery.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today signed a bill appropriating $505,218,741 more, including $15,000,000 for work to combat dust storms in drought areas.

The accumulation of advice that Mayor Wagner is getting against extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services grows more impressive daily. The latest testimony comes from the subcommittee on business and finance of the Mayor's own Advisory Council.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved generally lower yesterday in dull trading. Coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, rubber, silk, zinc and lead were off; cocoa, sugar, wool, burlap and tin ended mixed, and potatoes and copper closed higher.

LANSING, Mich., May 11 (UP) -- A witness at a House Un-American Activities subcommittee hearing caused turmoil briefly today when he shouted at the chairman, Representative Kit Clardy of Michigan, "You're liar."

Resilient of the Killian Farms bounced to victory in the Oyster Bay, the classified handicap that served as the feature attraction at Belmont Park yesterday. The mile-and-a-furlong race attracted only four contestants. It shared interest with the riding exploits of Ted Atkinson, who had three winners.

MUNSAN, Korea, Wednesday, May 12 (UP) -- The United States charged today that the Communists had seized three Colombian officers, including Lieut. Col. Carlos Ortiz-Torres, commander of the Colombian forces serving in Korea under the United Nations.

With the Geneva conference deadlocked on both Korea and Indo-China there is growing apprehension that this conference is likewise doomed to failure or to such an unsatisfactory conclusion as to increase rather than diminish the chances of further conflict.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland of California, formally repudiated today all accusations against the patriotism and honor of the Demo crats. In a major Senate speech he appealed for a new national unity in a period of world crisis that, he said, might involve the "very life of the Republic."

LONDON, May 11 -- The bishops of the Church of England adopted at the Convocation of Canterbury here today a resolution denouncing the hydrogen bomb as "a grievous enlargement of the evils inherent in all war and a threat to the basic obligations of humanity and civilization."

Vassily Smyslov, challenger for the chess championship of the world, forced a draw by repetition in the twenty-second game of his match with Mikhail Botvinnik in Moscow, according to a report received yesterday from London.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Senate approved with unusual dispatch today a proposed amendment to the Constitution designed to prevent any future attempt to "pack" the United States Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Federal Trade Commission directed its hearing examiners today to write reports that anyone could understand.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Two leaders of For America denied today the statement of Stephen A. Mitchell that the newly formed organization opposing international and communism indicated a split in the Republican party.
The Hammond Organ Company attained the highest earnings in its twenty-six-year history with a net income of $2,499,409 in the fiscal year ended on March 31.

LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- Roger Bannister, the British medical student who broke the four-minute-mile barrier at Oxford last Thursday, left for New York by plane tonight. He will tell America about the race on television and radio.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Retail volume in April, matching that of a year earlier, exceeded March sales by 3 per cent, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, told the National Retail Dry Goods Association today.

GUATEMALA, May 11 -- Union workers of Empresa Electrica, North American - owned power company, have threatened a general strike unless the company removes its American superintendent and orders him to leave the country.
GENEVA, May 11 -- The official Communist Chinese spokesman heaped bitter criticism on the United States today.

LONDON, May 11 -- Measured criticism of what he called "this recent display of injustice, intolerance, vituperation and invective" in the United States was voiced tonight by former Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas at the annual dinner of the English-Speaking Union.
CAIRO, May 11 -- The National Consultative Assembly, promised to the Egyptian people two months ago will be limited to an advisory role, according to a draft law published today.
GIBRALTAR, May 11 -- Queen Elizabeth II sailed for home today after her last stop-over on her six-month Commonwealth tour.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A Republican effort to cut short public hearings on the Army-McCarthy controversy and take them into closed session was beaten today.

There was 600 - mile - an - hour artistry in the air over Brooklyn yesterday. The Blue Angels, the Navy's jet exhibition team, churned the air high and low over Floyd Bennett Field as the Navy took its turn in the celebration of Armed Forces Week in New York.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, May 11 -- Israel has been asked by the chief of the United Nations Truce Organization in Palestine to return to the deliberations of the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission.
MOSCOW, April 24 -- The Soviet Government this year is spending considerable amounts to restore and rehabilitate some of Moscow's most famous churches.
The Dodgers suffered their first shutout of the season last night. Gene Conley, a 6-foot 8-inch right-hander, downed the Brooks, 2 -- 0, for the Milwaukee Braves at Ebbets Field.

The formation of a citizens' committee to "correct the wrong" done to Nat Holman, suspended basketball coach at City College, was announced yesterday. It will be headed by Dr. William Bradley Otis, a professor emeritus of the college.
Rabbi Elmer Berger, executive director of the American Council for Judaism, challenged last night the right of Israel's Prime Minister, Moshe Sharett, to classify the Jews as "one people."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 11 -- An appeal was made today to the United States Congress to remove a "crippling" financial restriction on a $13,500,000 appropriation requested for the United Nations Children's Fund -- the welfare agency known as UNICEF.

As reported in your news columns a resolution passed by the American Council for Judaism stated that the Jewish Agency for Palestine was registered as an agent of the Israeli Government. The Jewish Agency in this country is registered as a branch of the Jewish Agency for Palestine in Jerusalem, a non-governmental humanitarian organization.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 -- Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O., asserted today that President Eisenhower "is not the boss."
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- One of the most sensitive problems posed today in the Administration's proposed revision of atomic energy law came down to this:

The gold and dollar stocks of the sterling area, of which London is the custodian, rose during April by $135 millions, the largest monthly increment in the last two years. As a result, the reserves of Britain and her associates in the sterling currency union stood on April 30 at $2,820 millions.

THE good people in Hunts Point in the Bronx started calling the police and the Consolidated Edison Company the other day when a heavy cooking-gas odor hung heavily in the neighborhood. They figured there was a tremendous gas leak somewhere and that it was dangerous.

A cook hook is the most recent thing to come from that historic bit of New England known as Cape Cod. Peter Hunt, a New Yorker by birth and a devoted Cape Codder by virtue of thirty years of residence in Province-town, has written the volume with the assistance of a cook book editor.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations assailed the Administration's economic thinking in a day-long meeting today.

The American woman's love for mixing and matching clothes and her appreciation of European design and workmanship will both be gratified in the Piazza del Mare (Square of the Sea), the new "downstairs foreign shop" that opened yesterday at Bloomingdale's.

John Ryan drove in the winning run in the top of the tenth inning yesterday as City College downed Wagner, 7 -- 6, at Grymes Hill, Staten Island. The loss dropped Wagner into last place in the Metropolitan Conference with a record of two victories and six defeats.
Brown Bigelow is taking vigorous action to meet today's economic adjustment, Charles A. Ward, president and general manager, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in St. Paul, Minn.

Bernard M. Baruch charged yesterday that World War II had continued for a year longer and cost $100,000,000,000 more than it should have. He said economic policies we learned in World War I, if applied promptly in World War II, could have shortened the later conflict.

GENEVA, May 11 -- The United States and Britain were reported tonight to be fast narrowing their differences over the location, scope and composition of the projected military talks on Southeast Asian defense.

CHEKHOV'S "The Sea Gull," an incomparably beautiful play, has fallen heir to an interesting performance, which opened at the Phoenix last evening. Obviously, the group performance ought to be more integrated and luminous, and only a permanent company could achieve that perfection.

HAVING put on a show of work by more than thirty "Younger European Painters" earlier in the season, James Johnson Sweeney, director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, is opening today an exhibition of work by fifty-seven "Younger American Painters."

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Following is the 58-to-19 roll-call by which the Senate passed today a proposed constitutional amendment that would fix the size of the Supreme Court at nine and require all Federal judges to retire when they reached 75 years of age (a two-thirds majority vote was required):
State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein threatened yesterday to dissolve a "small but powerful" segment of the storm window industry for mulcting the public through "bait" advertising.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it would support grower prices for 1954 hard amber durum, amber durum and No. 1 heavy hard red spring wheat at higher rates than last year. Support rates for soft wheat will be reduced.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP) -- Del Ennis' tenth-inning single, driving in Richie Ashburn, gave the Philadelphia Phillles an 8-7 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 11 -- Frederic G. Elton, director of the American Rehabilitation Committee, Inc., sounded a warning today against the threat of "socialized medicine" in connection with the Government's rehabilitation program.
ROME, May 11 -- Budge Patty of the United States won the men's singles of the Italian international tennis championship today, beating Enrique Morea of Argentina, 11 -- 9, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.
MINEOLA, L. I., May 11 -- J. Russel Sprague charged today that Tammany had made an alliance with Michael J. Quill to try to wrest control of the state from the Republicans.
BOSTON, May 11 -- A Suffolk County Superior Court Judge today refused to block the American Woolen Company from acquiring the assets of the Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted Company.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 11 -- United States envoys from thirteen Middle Eastern countries are meeting at this crossroads city to discuss pressing regional problems with Henry A. Byroade, Assistant Secretary of State. His jurisdiction is Middle Eastern, South Asian and African affairs.
GENEVA, May 11 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, bitterly attacked the United States-proposed Southeast Asian defense pact today.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 11 -- United States prestige and control of world events have fallen to "a dangerous low," Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, charged tonight in a speech at Princeton University.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The White House said today that it knew of no Administration investigation to determine how to keep Government employes from giving classified information to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy without authorization.
TOKYO, May 11 -- The Japanese Cabinet approved an arrangement today with the United States for the lend lease of four United States warships.
An air purifier, similar to those used in Madison Square Garden, Macy's and other large buildings, will be available for the first time next fall for the home or office.
LONDON, May 11 -- The results of the urban district council elections in England and Wales announced today showed a slight trend toward the Labor party.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson said today he would push for quick Senate approval of more than $29,000,000,000 of defense funds to carry out President Eisenhower's "new look" for the nation's armed forces.

The profusion and confusion of a market in Mexico may be missing from a restrained version of a Mexican market now open to New Yorkers, but the objects in it come from more varied and widespread sources. For the contemporary crafts on display at the Carnegie Endowment International Center, 345 East Forty-sixth Street, were assembled by Fred Leighton from all over Mexico.

PARIS, Wednesday, May 12 -- The statement by John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, yesterday to the effect that Southeast Asia could be defended without Indo-China kept the French Cabinet sitting until 2 A. M. today.

A novel by William L. Shirer, author of "Berlin Diary," is planned for May 27 publication by Little, Brown. Entitled "Stranger Come Home," the story concerns a prominent foreign correspondent turned radio commentator, who returns after a long absence and finds himself confronted with the political pressures of our times.

A $1,528,000 contract to convert two 6,000-deadweight-ton cargo ships into powerful heavy-lift vessels has been awarded to the Todd Shipyards Corporation by the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 11 -- United States attempts to stop the spread of communism are being handicapped by our immigration policy, it was asserted here today.

A five-year study to determine the most effective method to curb rheumatic fever in children got under way yesterday at the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, Thirty-fourth Street and First Avenue.

Prospective hotel guests no longer fight each other and clerks for rooms as they did in World War II days but the country's hostelries remain in very good shape. In fact they are generally in better financial condition than at any time in the last thirty years, according to Conrad N. Hilton.

Too little is being done to "educate educators" as well as parents in the handling of sex questions and problems of growing children, Dr. Milton I. Levine declared last night. Dr. Levine, a pediatrician and child psychiatrist, addressed members of the parent-teacher association at the East Side Branch of the Bentley School, 112 East Seventy-first Street.
The Federal Government contended here yesterday that it had insured an "objective atmosphere" and a fair jury trial for thirteen second-string Communist leaders.
MONTREAL, May 11 (Canadian Press) -- Crew members of the British collier Cibou continued a wage-sympathy strike today despite a request by the captain that the ship be made ready for sea.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., has decided to shut its Olean, N. Y., refinery, one of the oldest in the United States. In making the announcement, George S. Dunham, director in charge of manufacturing for the company, said the decision resulted from the plant's continuing operating losses.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- The House, after more than an hour's argument, decided today to legalize a three-eighths-bushel basket for fruits and vegetables. On the voice vote the House passed and sent to the Senate a bill to amend a twenty-six-year-old law which bars the making or use of baskets except in nine specified sizes ranging from one-eighth to two bushels.

Dwight Cooke, radio correspondent of C. B. S., speaking at a Women's Council meeting in New York, said: "You know, I think if older people had been consulted on the name of the science of taking care of older peo ple there's no word they could have selected as bad as geriatrics.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The House of Representatives voted unanimously today to cite nine witnesses for contempt of Congress.

CHICAGO, May 11 (UP) -- Pitcher Bob Keegan won his fourth game of the season tonight, scoring the winning run after a seventh inning triple as the Chicago White Sox rallied to beat the Boston Red Sox, 2 -- 1, before 20,090 Comiskey Park fans.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 11 -- The most controversial route for the Cross Westchester Expressway has become the official choice. While the final decision still is to be made by Bertram D. Tallamy, State Superintendent of Public Works, he is expected to approve the link through central Westchester on the ground that any route selected will engender some hostility.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 11 -- The world's most powerful electron miscroscope -- a sort of push-button super-eye -- was turned over here today to a Swedish institute that will use it in cancer research.
A cast of nineteen policewomen and women detectives went through the paces at a laborious dress rehearsal yesterday afternoon in preparation for "Murder at the Astor."

The stockholders of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway reached no decision yesterday at their annual meeting on whether to continue the present management's eleven-man board or to replace it partly with seven nominees of an opposition group. The latter is headed by Ben W. Heineman, Chicago attorney.

Representative Francis E. Walter, co-author of the McCarran-Walter Immigration law said yesterday that plans to move 10,000 persons a month from overpopulated areas to other countries had been worked out at the recently concluded Geneva conference of the Intergovernmental Commission for European Migration.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., said tonight that America never had been stronger but would stay that way only if individual rights were "safeguarded and recognized."

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- In a sprawling building near the Nation's Capitol, there is a huge room that is the repository of more confidential information than probably could be found in any other spot in the United States.
The old International Longshoremen's Association was fined $50,000 last night for criminal contempt of court as a result of the paralyzing waterfront strike that ended last month.

Among the Administration's bills dealing with subversion is one sent to the Senate and the House by Attorney General Brownell proposing to end Communist control of labor unions. The "Communist-Infiltrated Organizations Act" is a substitute for the Taft-Hartley Law's non-Communist affidavit section, which has outlived its usefulness.

During the slack summer months, Wolcott Gibbs, drama critic of The New Yorker, will double as editor of The Fire Islander, a weekly chronicle devoted to Fire Island, where Mr. Gibbs and about 10,000 others maintain beach homes.

THE worship of false gods has always been a popular pursuit. Since the children of Israel fell down before their golden calf, men and women have been diligent in their prostrations before idols. The most popular have always been power, wealth and fame. But success, William James' "bitch goddess," has had a tremendous vogue for a century now and more recently a new one has appeared, inspiring the most servile devotion.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby emphatically denied today that the Administration was "shoving $25,000,000 down the protesting throats of the private insurance companies" in its health insurance plan.
The Federal Food and Drug Administration was charged yesterday with going to "absurd" lengths to prohibit use of certain dyes as potentially harmful.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Robert T. Stevens seems to have developed something like a horrified fascination for the Senate hearings on the Army-McCarthy dispute.

The House of Delegates of the New York State Medical Society voted yesterday afternoon to approve a stand of the Kings County Medical Society that has been interpreted as spelling trouble for prepayment medical service plans.

CLEVELAND, Miss., May 11 -- John S. Coleman, president of the Burroughs Corporation of Detroit, said today that this country's high standard of living had resulted from a historical acceptance of free trade practices at home and willingness to risk economic dislocations that promised greater rewards.

Scudder Fund of Canada, Ltd., a newly organized investment company, filed yesterday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed public offering of 800,000 shares of common stock.
Stanley Clifford Weyman, a champion among modern impostors, pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge that he had cheated a Long Island bank out of $5,000.

GENEVA, May 12 (AP) -- Following are statements by Nguyen Quec Dinh, Vietnamese Foreign Minister; Chou En-lai, Communist China's Foreign Minister; Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Under Secretary of State, and Vietnam's terms for ending the war in Indo-China:

BY taking advantage of the public campsites operated by several states, or by setting up a private campsite through arrangement with a landowner, many anglers have been able to enjoy the fishing on distant waters, and provide a pleasant vacation for the entire family at a cost well within any budget.

The lack of adequate channels of communication between schools and the community can have "disastrous consequences for the democratic way of life," the Public Education Association was told yesterday.

Roger Bannister, Great Britain's author of the 3:59.4 mile, arrived in New York yesterday at the invitation of a network television show. On arrival he unexpectedly found himself obliged to do some fast and fancy stepping to keep from running afoul of the strict rules against the exploitation of amateur athletes by commercial interests.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 12 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Sir John Kotelawala declared today it was "a damn lie" that the United States had offered economic aid to Ceylon if she stopped sending rubber to Communist China.

CAIRO, May 12 -- A 3,000-year-old temple containing a room full of charred animal bones, which is expected to furnish clues to the sacrificial rites of the New Empire dynasties, was discovered last week at Abydos, holiest city of ancient Egypt. The modern name of the site is Araba el Madfuna.

PITTSBURGH, May 12 (AP) -- Wally Moon hit five safeties and Red Schoendienst got four, as the St. Louis Cardinals registered a 13 -- 5 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today. The Cards racked up twenty-one hits and the Bucs fourteen.

LONDON, May 12 -- British shipowners protested tonight against an agreement between the Saudi Arabian Government and Aristotle Socrates Onassis, a Greek-born Argentine shipowner, that eventually would give him monopoly rights to transport Saudi Arabian oil.

JUST in case you haven't noticed it, one of the better managerial jobs of this still young season is that being done by George Robert Tebbetts, the freshman skipper of the Cincinnati Redlegs. He's had his muscular heroes making a bold challenge ever since the campaign began. What's more, he thinks they'll continue to do so.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- A Congressional hearing on a bill to ban racial segregation on trains, planes and buses temporarily broke off today in furor.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- The United Nations debate on Palestine ran into a major political and legal roadblock today.

Events today: Paul J. Stifler, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; Paulist Choristers, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Armor Musicae Ensemble, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Stradivarius Society, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 8:30;

Diplomatic sources predicted yesterday that the death last Sunday of the head of the Armenian Church, Catholicos Kevork VI (Georg VI), would set off a struggle for control of the church among anti-Communist, neutral, and pro-Communist elements in Armenian communities over the world.

Patricia Barry of Brookline, Mass., has been elected alumnae president of the senior class at Barnard College. Serving with Miss Barry for a three-year term will be Pamela Lewis of Manhattan, vice president, and Caroline Look of Brookside, N. J., secretary-treasurer.

Net income of the United Aircraft Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries, but excluding Chance Vought Aircraft, Inc., for the March quarter was $6,509,059, or $1.92 a common share, it was announced yesterday. Operations of Chance Vought yielded $1,293,000, equal to 40 cents a share on the outstanding common stock of United Aircraft.

First-quarter sales of $88,257,660 by the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., were the highest for any similar period in its history. Net earnings of $16,046,937 were just short of the record $16,346,318 set in the initial three months of 1952.
GENEVA, May 12 -- Nguyen Quoc Dinh, Foreign Minister of Vietnam, rejected today the Vietminh's proposals for an Indo-China peace.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., May 12 -- After seven generations of continuous occupancy of the John Jay home, the descendants of the first Chief Justice are moving. Historians plan to convert the place into a public shrine.
The biggest meat supply in ten years and the second largest in our industry will be available for Americans this year, the American Meat Institute predicted yesterday.

MOSCOW, Thursday, May 13 (AP) -- The Soviet Government in a note sent to the United States Embassy yesterday rejected a United States accusation that American prisoners had been transferred to the Soviet Union from Korea.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Business groups, formerly allied in a common fight against Federal interference, are now devoting their energies to fighting each other, Ralph R. Crosby, president of the United States Savings and Loan League, said today.

An address by former President Harry S. Truman on "The Economic Issues Facing Us Today" will be broadcast by the N. B. C. radio network tonight from 10:30 to 11 o'clock. The address will be recorded earlier today at the annual convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union in Atlantic City.
Pennsylvania defeated Columbia, 4 to 3, at Baker Field yesterday in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game.
JERUSALEM, May 12 -- Israel was blamed today for two more violations of the armistice agreement with Jordan.
Two companies submitted concrete offers yesterday for the private operation of the Brooklyn-Staten Island ferries.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Eisenhower denounced as reprehensible today the unofficial disclosure to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of an extract from the files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

" THE HEART IN THE DESERT,"* by Gilbert Phelps, is a happily murderous satirical novel in the tradition of "Cakes and Ale" and "Gin and Bitters." They order these things expertly in England. There must be something in the perpetual teatime atmosphere that inspires authors to boil one another cannibalistically in the kettle of a novel.

A plot 140 by 292 feet at the southeast corner of Twenty-eighth Avenue and 120th Street in College Point, Queens, has been purchased by the Prosperity Construction Corporation for improvement with a one-story industrial building to contain 40,000 square feet of space.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Senate Finance Committee said today that it had tentatively approved substantial tax reductions for retired persons and various other features of the Administration's omnibus tax reform bill.

April shipments of rayon and acetate yarn and staple were 90,600,000 pounds, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. The shipments, including exports of 1,300,000 pounds, were well above the average of several preceding months.
The rider of the second finisher bobbed up with a point of order after the running of the Juvenile Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. It was not upheld.

SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, May 13 -- President Rhee was reported today to have rejected a United States compromise plan for nation-wide elections that would unify the Korean peninsula under one Government.

Clarifying some unwarranted interpretations of American policy in the Far East, President Eisenhower has again emphasized that "of course" we do not, and the free world should not, write off Indo-China as lost, and that we shall continue to do everything possible to save this gateway to Southeast Asia from being overrun by the Communists.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy nosy before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:
NEW HAVEN, May 12 -- Two bandits committed suicide here today after critically wounding Detective Ralph Palma, when they were trapped in a midtown movie theatre.
MOSCOW, May 12 -- New and serious shortcomings on the Soviet Union's agricultural front were exposed today.

The Danish Ministry of Finance has set aside $11,000,000 for retirement of dollar bonds of several Danish loans during the next twelve months. Most of the money will be used to end amortization payment arrears of the Kingdom of Denmark 4 1/2 per cent loan due in 1962.

GENEVA, May 12 -- Nguyen Quoc Dinh, Foreign Minister of Vietnam revealed today the texts of the two treaties that have been drawn up to govern the relationships between Vietnam and France. He disclosed the drafts of the treaties in affirming the independence of Vietnam during his statement at today's session of the conference on Far Eastern affairs.

ATHENS, May 12 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee rejected repeated efforts today to enlarge Olympic programs and began seeking a formula to relieve political pressure on various national committees.

The ownership of Elm Towers, a five-story apartment house at 30 East Elm Street in Linden, N. J., has changed through the sale of stock of Elm Towers, Inc., by Chester Robbins, Louis Slater and Maxwell M. Plotkin to an investment group represented by Carl Nitto, attorney. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
That May 4 editorial of yours on the value of water metering in New York made welcome reading for us who have an engineering understanding of water supply. Let's have more of the same.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- John G. Adams today directly linked the White House with the development of the controversy between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
Stocks gathered strength after a careful start yesterday and made a solid advance over a broad front.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- Don Johnson's second two-hitter of the season beat a brilliant but erratic three-hit effort by Rookie Tom Brewer to give the Chicago White Sox a 1-- 0 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.

ATHENS, May 12 (UP) -- An earthquake today shattered whole villages in the Western Peloponnesus region [cross on map]. One person was killed and twenty-four persons were injured. Officals reported 163 buildings destroyed or damaged.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- Paramount has purchased motion- picture rights to Eugene O'Neill's play, "Desire Under the Elms," and has arranged with H. L. Davis, the Pulitzer Prize- winning novelist, to write the screen adaption.

" Caroline Cherie," a French- made romantic drama starring Martine Carol, has been scheduled to have its American premiere on Monday, May 24, at the Paris Theatre. It will precede "Bread, Love and Dreams," previously announced by the management.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 12 (AP) -- Three international negotiators struggling to get Iran's oil back on the market will fly to London in an effort to break a deadlock over operation of the Abadan refinery.

IT has been eight years since Louis Ribak held his last New York show. He has been living in the Southwest in the meantime to conquer an illness and the canvases in this exhibition at the Salpeter Gallery would lead one to conclude that he has regained his health and added strength and color to his work.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 12 (AP) -- Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., cleared the major hurdle to a record fifth women's Southern golf title today when she defeated Mary Lena Faulk, 3 and 2, in a second round match.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- It comes as no surprise to Senator Mundt of South Dakota that the hearings of the Stevens-McCarthy controversy by the Senate subcommittee have evoked public disfavor by their confusion, repetition and delay; and that a lack of firmness on his part has been assigned by many as a principal cause.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The State Department omitted from its public transcript of excerpts from statements by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles at his news conference yesterday the one question and answer that caused most of the reaction abroad.
YONKERS, May 12 (AP) -- Noble Dean, racing almost two full seconds faster than he ever had before, won tonight's $4,500 Empire Pace at Yonkers Raceway in 2:03 3-5.

Two twenty-story apartment houses to contain about 400 suites are planned for the plots at 408-18 and 442-46 West Fifty-seventh Street which have been purchased by the Cross Island Realty Corporation, of which George Rabinor is president. Clira, Inc., headed by Ira Berne, was the seller.
You are to be congratulated for Joseph C. Ingraham's article on misleading road signs.

LIMA, Peru, May 12 -- Peru formally celebrated Mining Day today. It was the fourth anniversary of the mining law that has encouraged foreign investors to put more and more capital into development of the country.

Roy Campanella, Dodger catcher who had a bone chip removed from his left wrist on Tuesday, May 4, may not be back in the line-up in the predicted "three and a half weeks." The hard-hitting receiver said yesterday that Dr. Herbert Fett, the orthopedic surgeon who operated on him, had declared that Roy would "be lucky to be back in two months."
Mayor Wagner announced last night an inquiry to determine how municipal hospital services can best be strengthened.

GENEVA, May 12 -- Despite a statement in Seoul to the contrary, the South Korean Foreign Minister, Pyun Yung Tai, still is under instructions from his Government to assent at the Far Eastern conference to all-Korean elections.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 12 -- The state's adoption of the central route for the projected $40,000,000 Cross Westchester Expressway drew quick criticism today from community officials and civic leaders.

A decrease last week of 1,184,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 175,874,000 barrels, compared with 177,058,000 a week earlier and 156,025,000 a year ago.

The Foreign Operations Administration was urged yesterday to set up an office of home economics. The recommendation was made at a conference on international service of the American Home Economics Association at the end of a three-day session at Teachers College, Columbia University.

BONN, May 12 -- The economic advisers of the Allied High Commission met today with the West German Finance Minister to establish procedures for renegotiation of Bonn's eventual Western defense contribution.

Paper, Fixes, Washes Spring weather belongs as much to photographers as anyone. "Photographers" includes a lot of people. They say there are just about a million serious photographers in the country, arriving at that figure by counting all the picture-snappers who process their own film and prints.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Coley Wallace of New York punched out a dull ten-round split-decision victory over Billy Gilliam of Orange, N. J., tonight in a nationally televised fight that drew boos from the fans for the last five rounds.

The International Paper Company increased its first-quarter net profit to $15,360,968 from $13,795,977 a year ago, shareholders were told at their annual meeting yesterday. Later, directors elected John H. Hinman to the new office of chairman, the company's chief executive office, and Richard C. Doane, vice president and general sales manager, to succeed him as president.
New York City received permission yesterday to build its own television station.
VIENNA, May 12 -- Former President Vincent Auriol of France, speaking as a newspaperman to his colleagues of the International Press Institute here today, defended France's role in Indo-China.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) -- Southpaw Curt Simmons survived a ninth-inning rally tonight as the Phillies fumbled their way to a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs at Connie Mack Stadium. Simmons chalked up his fourth triumph against two losses despite four Philly fielding miscues.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- Army Secretary Robert T. Stevens, who spent most of the last three weeks telling his side of the Army-McCarthy controversy, returned today to his full-time job of running the Army.

Mrs. Edward Nicholson, an attractive blonde who up until last night was cagy about telling her right age, could have kept right on hiding her years, so far as three Special Sessions justices were concerned.
Health service administration should be studied with "the same objectivity and vigor that we scientists apply to testing out a new antibiotic," New York City's Health Commissioner said yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 12 (AP) -- A strong demand sent hog prices rolling upward today despite the fact salable receipts at 7,000 head were 1,000 above the advance estimate.

The federal court jury's verdict against the old International Longshoremen's Association, eight locals and three officials should encourage all forces fighting for waterfront reform. The jury, before Federal Judge Harold P. Burke, found the defendants guilty of criminal contempt of court as a result of the paralyzing waterfront strike that ended last month.
Bob Hofman crashed a pinch-hit two-run homer with one out in the ninth inning to give the Giants a thrilling 2-1 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Lieut. Noh Kum Sok, pilot in the North Korean Air Force, knew only one word of English, "motorcar," when he delivered a Russian-built MIG-15 fighter plane to Americans at Seoul eight months ago.
Dr. George H. Rue, a medical missionary for twenty-five years in Korea and now home on furlough, made a plea yesterday for more relief goods for war-destroyed Seoul.
The increasingly important role of the Soviet Union's military forces in the world conflict and in the struggle for power within that country is indicated by recent information from Moscow.

ALBANY, May 12 -- The Associated Industries of New York State, Inc., asserted today that there was "glaring inconsistency between the announced intention of the Republican [Federal] Administration and its actual action."

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations today made public the stenographic record of its March 16 closed- door meeting that led to the decision to start its public McCarthy- Amy hearings.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 12 (AP) -- Gov. George N. Craig succeeded today in wresting control of the Indiana Republican organization from Senators Homer E. Capehart and William E. Jenner.

The Roman Catholic Church in the United States has received 1,097,771 converts in the last decade, the Official Catholic Directory for 1954 reports. The tabulation for 1953 shows a total of 116,696 listed as "adult baptisms."

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., May 12 -- Twenty-five persons were injured in a collision of two Public Service Coordinated Transport buses that tied up traffic for twenty-five minutes during the height of the morning rush hour at the Lincoln Tunnel exit here.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today he had some sleepless nights over wartime leaks. There was nothing that ever would get him to agree to releasing some Government information, he added.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 12 -- Army tripped Yale, 6 to 5, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game at Doubleday Field today. It was the cadets' fourth league victory in five games.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 12 -- An international convention avowing man's determination to preserve his cultural treasures in wartime was approved here today.

WALTHAM, Mass., May 12 -- The construction of an interfaith center, consisting of separate Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish chapels, is to be undertaken immediately on the campus of Brandeis University.
CHICAGO, May 12 -- Resistance stiffened in all grain futures today, with substantial recoveries from the initial low points.
The cotton futures market was quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange most of yesterday. Final prices were 6 points lower to 4 points higher than on Tuesday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12 -- Diplomatic smokers won a victory today that had been more than eight years in the making.

A luncheon party for children attending Finch College Nursery School and their parents was held yesterday as part of the school's specially planned activities this week marking the close of its first season of operation.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Differences developed today in the second House of Representatives investigation of tax-exempt educational and philanthropic foundations.
The House of Delegates of the New York State Medical Society took two moves yesterday at a heated session that may be sufficient to destroy the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- Soviet leaders have made frequent appearances at public functions in the ten-day period since May 1st, when virtually the entire Government group appeared on the reviewing stand of Red Square.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Eisenhower renewed his assurances today that the economy was under constant study, so the Government might be prepared for any eventuality.
The Government announced plans yesterday for a nation-wide investigation of trade practices in the cosmetics and toiletries industry.
ALBANY, May 12 -- The State Education Department announced today 150 winners of state tuition-paying schoarships at Cornell University.

In the election of Arthur Levitt as president of the Board of Education the school system of this city has obtained an able administrator. Although the junior member of the board in point of service, he has already shown himself to be highly competent.

Frank Costello's income tax evasion case will be given to a Federal Court jury of five women and seven men today immediately after Judge John F. X. McGohey gives the charge. Costello is accused of evading $52,239 in taxes from 1946 through 1949.

James Amarante, 42-year-old convicted gambler whose operations in 1950 disclosed that he was paying for police protection, was sentenced yesterday in Brooklyn Gamblers' Court to pay a $500 fine or serve ninety days in jail, plus four months in the workhouse.

Claude G. Bowers, historian and former United States Ambassador to Spain, has written an account of his ambassadorship of fifteen years ago in "My Mission to Spain: Watching the Rehearsal for World War II." The book presents a portrait of the life and art of Spain and casts "new light" on many of the struggles that resulted "in the extermination of Spanish democracy."

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 5:
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Eisenhower dissociated himself today from attacks on the loyalty of Democrats, and restated his belief in the need for a bipartisan foreign policy.

PARIS, May 12 -- Premier Joseph Laniel failed today to obtain a promise from French party leaders to sustain him in refusing to give the Assembly full information on the political and military situations in Indo-China.

The problem of checking Communist expansion in Europe by creating a unified, democratic Germany allied with the Western Powers was discussed yesterday by Clifton Daniel, chief of The New York Times bureau in Germany.

FLINT Mich., May 12 (AP) -- A college-trained electrical engineer refused to tell Congressional investigators today whether he had done production work at an auto plant for five years to hely "colonize" -- organize -- for the Communist party.
NEWARK, Del., May 12 -- The Army took some of the wraps today off the long secret T-43 heavy tank, rated as the mightiest armored vehicle in the nation's military arsenal.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Eisenhower indicatedtoday he might be willing to accept a proposal for reducing the voting age to 19 years instead of 18.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Senate subcommittee considering a bill to liberalize use of telephone wiretaps was urged instead today to outlaw all such activities.

ROME, May 12 -- Italian determination to prevent the formation of a Balkan military alliance was clearly expressed today when Foreign Minister Attilio Piccioni made a report to the Foreign Affairs Commission of the Chamber of Deputies.

President Eisenhower has again declined to approve a recommendation by the Tariff Commission for an increase in import duties. His latest decision was rendered on an application by the cutlery industry for an increase of 100 per cent in the duties on certain types of scissors and shears.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administration called on the housing industry today to help it find soft spots in F. H. A. programs "that might be susceptible to abuses."

The enterprising producers Helen Beatty Clarke and Bob L. Roberts, apparently reasoning that what Liberace can do five planists can do five times as well, opened a divertissement called "Pianorama World" at the Broadway Theatre last evening.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Sales and net income of the United States Gypsum Company increased in the first quarter of this year, C. H. Shaver, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting today. He said the company will conduct seismographic tests for oil on property it owns in Texas.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 12 -- As a preliminary to the Palm Beach round-robin tournament at the Meadow Brook club, a pro-celebrity golf competition was held here today.

The Philip Murray Memorial Foundation presented $75,000 yesterday to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for use in promoting full acceptance of civil rights guaranteed by the Constitution.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 12 -- A message from Gen. Rene Cogny, commander of French Union ground forces in North Vietnam, was air-dropped at Dienbienphu at noon today. The message informed the Vietminh that a French delegation would arrive there by helicopter at 1 P. M. tomorrow (2 A. M. Thursday, Eastern daylight time) to discuss evacuation of the seriously wounded.

In its first borrowing on bonds in the public market in nine years, New York City raised $79,200,000 for hospital and school construction and for other purposes yesterday at an interest cost of 1.894 per cent.
