ATLANTIC CITY, May 12 -- Senator Wayne Morse accused the Republican party today of "fast becoming a war party" under the leadership of President Eisenhower, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Admiral Arthur E. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
The home furnishings industry was urged yesterday by W. E. S. Griswold Jr., president of W. J. Sloane, to unite in an effort to capture a greater share of the consumer's dollar.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- John Foster Dulles, the Secretary of State, was a weary and depressed man today when he appeared before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
MOSCOW, May 12 -- The Supreme Soviet of the Karelo-Finnish Soviet Socialist Republic has approved the appointment of Nikolai Gusev as chairman of the Karelo-Finnish Committee on State Security.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- The whereabouts of Army Counselor John G. Adams one night last October prompted a good deal of hilarity at the Army-McCarthy hearings today -- but not to Mr. Adams.
Record high prices for bacon have prompted leading meat packers to develop a cheaper edition of that favorite breakfast food.

Serge Rubinstein, international financier whom the Government is seeking to deport, was charged yesterday with conspiracy to commit fraud, in a $5,000,000 damage suite fried in Federal Court here by the Blair Holdings Corporation of 44 Wall Street.
The practices of the discount houses, which undercut the fair trade suggested retail prices of various products, were attacked sharply yesterday by Emanuel Katz, president of Doeskin Products, Inc.
SYRACUSE, May 12 -- Some of the state's top industrial engineers pondered today on the cherished dream of an automatic factory.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its fifteenth day of considering the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.
PARIS, May 12 -- Fashions for the summer nights, by Jacques Fath, and those for its days, by Jacques Heim, are shown in two new collections.
CLEVELAND, May 12 -- The Yankees nipped the Indians, 5 -- 4, in Municipal Stadium today. Eddie Lopat was credited with his fifth straight victory, and he has Johnny Sain to thank for it.

BARABOO, Wis., May 12 (UP) -- Leroy Gore, a newspaper editor who founded the "Joe Must Go" movement to recall Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, won a delay today in a hearing into alleged violations of the state corrupt practices law.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 1,371 pints of blood Tuesday. Included were 425 pints from employes of the Arma Corporation, Mineola, L. I.; 235 from New York Central Railroad and Pullman Company employes, and 209 in Great Neck, L. I., at a mass donation in Temple Beth El.
The police here and in New Jersey pooled their talents yesterday to unravel the murder of the estranged wife of a New York patrolman.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 12 -- The Soviet Union has recently intensified its propaganda and political activity throughout the Middle East, Henry A. Byroade, United States Assistant Secretary of State for the Near East, South Asia and Africa, said here today.

Lew Burdette, one of half a dozen pitchers who beat the Dodgers three times last year, did it again yesterday at Ebbets Field. Behind Burdette, the Milwaukee Braves downed the Dodgers, 5 -- 1, for their second straight in the first series between the teams this season.

ALBANY, May 12 -- Milk, "healthier, cheaper, and more plentiful" was offered today as "the perfect answer" to the coffee shortage by Governor Dewey. Urging New Yorkers to drink more of the beverage in place of coffee, he said increased consumption offered "a golden opportunity" to solve the problems of the state's milk surplus and the coffee shortage with one action.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Statehood-seeking Alaskans obtained today appointments with President Eisenhower and the House of Representatives Rules Committee.

The Newark City Commission tentatively approved yesterday an appropriation of $58,000 for a run-off election on June 15. This will be necessary because no candidate for the new City Council received a clear majority in Tuesday's municipal election.
Macy's buyers seem to have a special ability for picking fashions in current trends at moderate prices when it comes to clothes for the vacation-bound junior and miss.
GENEVA, May. 12 (Reuters) -- The draft texts of the proposed treaties of independence and association between Vietnam and France, as disclosed today by Vietnam Foreign Minister Nguyen Quoc Dinh:

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Friends of John G. Adams, a self-assured South Dakota lawyer with nine years of Washington experience, find him oddly miscast in the role of antagonist to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, or any other member of the Congress.

Stockholders of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., exercised warrants to purchase $46,120,800 of debentures of the $50,000,000 issue of 3 1/2 per cent subordinated debentures. Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates, who were underwriters for the offering, took up the $3,879,200 of unsubscribed debentures.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, in an apparent slap at Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, tonight praised investigating committee chairmen "who go after facts rather than headlines."

AS American students of political science doing research in India we have been uneasy witnesses during the last six months to a progressive deterioration of Indo-American relations. We gather that there is growing sentiment in Congress for substantially diminishing aid to India.

DETROIT, May 12 (AP) -- Ted Gray, a losing pitcher for the last three years, protected the Detroit Tigers' league lead today by beating the Washington Senators, 4 -- 2, for his first victory of the season.
LONDON, May 12 -- The rise in stock prices here slackened today although most sections of the market remained firm.

LONDON, May 12 -- A convention that would require all oil-burning vessels and all tankers to keep comprehensive records of oil discharged at sea was voted by the forty-two-nation International Conference on Oil Pollution today.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 12 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. declared here tonight that thirty Moreland Act Commissions could not whitewash the harness-track scandals that led to the resignation of J. Russel Sprague as Republican National Committeeman.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The House Agriculture Committee decided today to write an omnibus farm bill.

Mayor Wagner's opinion that extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services was "seemingly" inevitable remained unchanged yesterday. He held to this stand after an hour's conference at City Hall with spokesmen for sixty-seven business and trade groups opposed to such a levy.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Administration and foreign trade sources indicated today they had abandoned hope of persuading Congress to approve a three-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 12 -- Sidik Kertaptai, a member of Parliament's Progressive faction, has been arrested by the Army here on the ground of allegedly being a leader of the Bamboo Spear organization.

Our national park system was established to preserve some small areas of unique American scenery in relatively undisturbed, primitive condition, as well as archaeological and historical sites. Over many years the Department of the Interior and Congress have resisted attempts to exploit these areas, which are visited by an increasing number of people every year.
Washington Suburban Sanitary District, in Maryland, plans to sell $7,600,000 of various-purpose bonds dated June 1 on May 25. The bonds mature from 1955 to 1994.
Antiquated public schools and poor teaching programs are blighting the growth of Greenwich Village, in the opinion of a group of New York University educators.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Eisenhower rejected today a recommendation to authorize doubling the duty on scissors and shears.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Eisenhower covered these major topics in his news conference today:
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Defense Department will send to the White House on Friday a new military Reserve plan embodying a modified form of Universal Military Training.

Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, charged yesterday that the New York Shipping Association had been derelict regarding crime, corruption and racketeering along the waterfront.
LA CEIBA, Honduras, May 12 -- This important northern port of 15,000 population is almost completely strike-bound.

Consumption figures made public by the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity yesterday showed that New Yorker were giving heed to the city's plea for conservation of water Average daily consumption last week was 996,000,000 gallons

Members of the Sunday School of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity will present performances of "The Prodigal Triplets," a play by Miss Diane Michele Fryburg with original music by Bronson Ragan, organist and choirmaster of the church.

Ben W. Heineman, 40-year-old Chicago attorney, led a group of seven investors yesterday in unseating the directorate of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway Company. The old board had been headed by Lucian W. Sprague for eleven years.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 12 -- A "philosophical apparatus," once the pride of generations of Princeton University students, has been restored to a place of honor in an exhibition by the university library.

American merchant ships will break out their brightest colors and flags will fly on Government buildings and homes over the nation on May 22, which has been proclaimed by President Eisenhower as National Maritime Day.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 12 (AP) -- On Your Own, a full sister of the great Assault, scored by two lengths in the $30,000-added Betsy Ross Stakes at Garden State Park today, earning $27,150 for the King Ranch.

New York City's memorial to selfless devotion to duty at sea, the Marine Wireless Operators Monument, was restored to its place of honor in Battery Park yesterday. It had been dedicated thirty-nine years ago in honor of Jack Phillips, heroic "Sparks" of the British liner Titanic, lost at sea in 1912.

Trading in most of the New York commodity futures markets was dull and featureless yesterday. Prices closed irregularly higher with potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, rubber, burlap, silk, tin and lead stronger; coffee and hides lower, and sugar, cocoa, zinc, copper and wool mixed.

The Public Service Commission denied yesterday a fare increase of 5 cents for the Westchester Electric Railroad Company on its bus routes. At the same time, the commission granted an increase of 1 cent to the Westchester Street Transportation Company instead of the 3-cent rise sought by that company.

New York City's retailers can look forward to good business in 1954 but the long-term outlook is not as encouraging, William Zucker, director of studies of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., said yesterday.

Start out early on any promising spring day for a visit to the country. Bring along the wife and children, pack a little lunch and look forward to a carefree day under the sky. Then, in a matter of hours, you'll still be searching for the right road while wondering where you could have made the wrong turn.

One of the pet communist theses is that economic planning in the Soviet Union foresees all and takes everything into account beforehand, unlike the "anarchy" of the "bourgeois market place." The latest news about the Soviet grain situation provides an interesting contradiction to this propaganda.

A new musical comedy, "The Pajama Game," will open tonight at the St. James Theatre under the combined auspices of Frederick Brisson, Robert E. Griffith and Harold S. Prince. The curtain will go up at 8 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Eisenhower called on the free world today not to write off French Indo-China. He declared that country was very important to the defense of Southeast Asia.

OPENING today at the National Academy of Design is one of the season's hardiest annuals, that of painting and sculpture by members of the National Association of Women Artists. This group, which now numbers more than 800 members, has come a long way from its first exhibition in a Washington Square studio in 1889.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A 35-year-old atomic scientist said today he would rather have the right to patent one idea of his own in nuclear development than have access to 1,000 ideas patented by large corporations.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse, as required by conference rules:

THE Ballet Theatre offered a one-night spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, treating New York for the second time this year as just another town on tour. And like any other town, New York turned out in numbers and filled the house to capacity.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today that subscriptions for its current exchange offering amount to about $2,889,000,000 for the new four-year, nine month 1 7/8 per cent Treasury notes and $3,881,000,000 for the new one-year 1 5/8 per cent certificates, both to be dated May 17, 1954.

Lehman Brothers and underwriting associates will place on the market today a new issue of $18,000,000 of sinking fund debentures of Montana Power Company due May 1, 1979, at a price to yield 3.15 per cent to investors.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., May 12 (AP) -- "The current year will be a good one," Tom M. Girdler, chairman of Republic Steel Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting today.

Two five-story apartment buildings at 224-30 West Eighteenth Street have been sold by Irving Rathaus to Joseph Meriman for investment in a deal negotiated by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., broker. The property is assessed at $93,000 and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $85,000.

Rita Hayworth, film actress, wife of Dick Haymes, filed suit here yesterday in Federal Court for a financial accounting by Columbia Pictures and Columbia International Pictures Corporation of their dealings with Beckworth Corporation, of which she holds 450 shares of common stock.

A constant question during the current campaign of the Greater New York Fund is: "What about religious groups?" The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn, the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York all are in the fund together, with the majority of their member agencies.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 12 -- Mayor Joseph S. Clark Jr. of Philadelphia and Nelson A. Rockefeller, Under Secretary of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare, are related by marriage but not by politics.
GENEVA, May 12 -- The United States has not abandoned hope of giving the Communist powers a demonstration of Western unity before the Far Eastern conference tries to reach a decision on Indo-China.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman said today that the Administration could prove its sincerity in effecting a bipartisan foreign policy by calling in Dean Acheson, former Secretary of State, for consultation.

The moppets, three girls and two boys, carried off the honors at Bergdorf Goodman's special showing of summer fashions yesterday morning. Theirs was the stellar role, not only because they were adorable youngsters delightfully dressed, but because for the first time tiny feet trod the carpet in the fourth-floor show room, where for the past generation some of New York's most glamorous models have displayed leading fashions from New York and Paris.

Men's wear stores count on excellent business at Easter when the American man puts his best foot forward, sartorially (and spiritually) speaking. But a good many merchants did not realize their hopes this year.
BALTIMORE, May 13 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox, plagued by weak hitting previously, exploded an eleven-hit attack on unsuspecting Baltimore and trounced the Orioles, 9 to 1, tonight.
The Royal Dutch Petroleum Company may make sweeping changes in its articles of association to qualify for listing on the New York Stock Exchange.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 13 (AP) -- The Army said today that no disciplinary action had been recommended concerning the death of a 40-year-old major after he lay stricken with a heart ailment for more than an hour within sight of a sentry.

The new commissioner of Hospitals said yesterday that nursing salaries could be increased without the sweeping $6,842,711 moratorium on new facilities recommended by the Board of Hospitals on April 28.
The world's most powerful electronic vacuum tube -- now in use by the United States Navy for long-distance radio transmission -- represents a success based on 2,000 failures in the last ten years.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., May 13 (UP) -- A convicted rapist and kidnapper, who became an author ten days ago with publication of his life story, won a stay of execution today less than twenty-four hours before he was scheduled to die in the gas chamber.
CLEVELAND, May 13 (AP) -- The retail market for automobiles is now running about 8 per cent under that of last year but it is on a sounder basis, a Ford Motor Company economist said here today.

Four new films will arrive at first-run theatres this morning. "The French Line," an R. K. O. Technicolor musical comedy in 3-D with Jane Russell, Gilbert Roland, Arthur Hunnicutt and Mary McCarty, is at the Criterion.

CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- Demand continued strong for hogs today, and prices of butcheds bounded up 50 cents or more while sows gained 25 to 50 cents. Salable receipts at 7,000 head were in line with the advance estimate.
Amateur athletic officials, who have been having a battle on their hands to see that the miracle miler, Roger Bannister, keeps clear of professionalism, scored another victory yesterday.

The price of eggs is down again. Two weeks ago they were selling generally at 63 cents a dozen for large Grade A's, the lowest level in two years. Now, at 59 cents a dozen for the same quality, they are the cheapest they have been in four years.

The Committee for Jewish Claims on Austria announced yesterday it would reopen negotiations with Austria June 1 in Vienna for the settlement of Jewish claims arising out of losses suffered by Jews under Nazi rule.

When President Eisenhower signed the St. Lawrence Seaway bill yesterday he used nine pens. This sort of thing is customary. No President dreams of signing any important bill with one pen. But there was one compelling symbol in the pens the President used yesterday.

The medical staff of St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Brooklyn honored Dr. Merrill N. Foote and Dr. Charles W. Mueller last night for their many years of professional endeavors. The staff presented portraits of the two doctors to the hospital at the annual staff dinner at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

Norman M. Fair has been named market planning supervisor for the northeastern region of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. L. M. Henderson has been appointed manager of operations and H. R. Arnold, manager of foreign relations and administrative assistant for the aviation gas turbine division of Westinghouse in Philadelphia.
Merger of the Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., with the McBee Company has been approved by directors of both concerns. The proposal will be presented to stockholders at special meetings on July 1.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- The Senate today passed its first regular money bill of the session -- a $3,332,732,700 measure to operate the Treasury and Post Office Departments in the fiscal year to start July 1.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its sixteenth day of considering the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.
Mayor Wagner and his fiscal aides are restudying the city's available revenue sources in an effort to balance the city's 1954-55 budget without imposing a 3 per cent sales tax on commercial services.

T. R. Dreyer has been appointed divisional vice president and general manager of American Machine Foundry Company's manufacturing division. He formerly was director of manufacturing of five A. M. F. plants.
LONDON, Friday, May 14 -- The Labor party scored substantial gains yesterday as voters in England and Wales went to the polls to elect councils in 367 cities and towns.

ATHENS, May 13 (UP) -- The International Olympic Committee voted today to stage the 1956 Olympic equestrian events at Stockholm and then girded for the next battle on the agenda -- the admission of Communist China.

Dr. George Baehr, president of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, criticized last night two resolutions on group health plans that had been adopted Wednesday by the New York State Medical Society. He said they would severely hamper the rights of physicians and of the public to select freely the type of medical care program in which they desired to participate.

PARIS, May 13 (AP) -- The appointment of Marcel Dupre, one of the world's most famous organists, to be director of the Paris Conservatory, was announced yesterday. He succeeds the late Claude Delvincourt

ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 12 -- Apparently concerned about future loans to bolster Paraguay's economy, Provisional President Tomas Romero Pereira insisted today that constitutional methods had been followed in setting up his Government last week.
It was the Coast Guard's turn yesterday in the week-long observance of Armed Forces Week, and the service demonstrated the most "comfortable" method to pluck a man from the water by helicopter.

Season subscription books to the summer concert series at Lewisohn Stadium, selling at $10 each, will again be available this year through department stores as well as at the Stadium Concerts office at 50 West Fifty-Seventh Street, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Sophie G. Untermeyer, subscription chairman.
CHICAGO, May 13 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics rallied for two runs in the ninth inning today to trip the Chicago White Sox, 3 to 2. It was Virgil Trucks' third defeat of the season.
The cotton futures market opened yesterday 2 points higher to 4 points lower than on Wednesday. It closed 1 point lower to 10 points higher. Business on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet.

If there is a low point in the week it is not on Monday morning, when the week-end is over and five dreary days of the same old work at the same old desk loom forbiddingly ahead. That vista is bad enough. But Monday morning is not the week's lowest point -- that which corresponds to a day's 3 o'clock in the morning.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 13 -- The Netherlands and Belgian Governments published today their joint plans for major waterways projects. The plans provide for the following:
American business men will spend more money to advertise products and services abroad this year than in 1953, when such expenditures were estimated at $280,000,000.

United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc., and New York Medical College signed a contract yesterday for the joint sponsorship of a new in-patient rehabilitation center for cerebral-palsied children at Bird S. Coler Hospital on Welfare Island.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams urged yesterday that the city reduce the trial period for small taxicabs from thirty to nineteen months.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 13 -- The head of the country's oldest and largest school of social work today charged President Eisenhower with failing to use his executive powers to curb Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

" Grand National Night" is coming to the fore again. Produced in London in 1946 for a run of 268 performances, the Dorothy and Campbell Christie collaboration was experimented with at New Hope, Pa., in 1947 with Bramwell Fletcher heading the cast.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP) -- Robin Roberts, the Phillies' ace right-hander, gave up a lead-off homer to Bobby Adams in the first inning tonight and then mowed down the next twenty-seven batters as the Philadelphia club trounced the Cincinnati Redlegs, 8 -- 1.

GUATEMALA, May 13 -- An editorial in last night's issue of the official Government newspaper, Diario de Centro America strongly attacked Secretary of States Dulles. It charged that he was ill-disposed toward the Guatemalan regime and that he sought the abolition of the October, 1944, revolution that overthrew fourteen years of dictatorship.
City department heads were put on notice by Mayor Wagner yesterday to be on hand at Board of Estimate meetings when questions concerning their departments are due.

THE paintings of George Bellows, a selection of which is being shown at the Allison Gallery, have a fresh and glistening appearance that belies their having been painted more than a generation ago. Their old-fashioned look is due only to their being joyful and direct presentations of the external world, a kind of painting with which we have unfortunately become less accustomed since Bellows' time.
While two young drivers were racing last night on the Boston Post Road in the Bronx, one suddenly drew a pistol and fired at the other car. Two occupants of the second vehicle were injured seriously.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Congress received today a proposal that more than 3,000,000 service men and women be added to the Federal Social Security coverage.
Boxing returns to Madison Square Garden tonight for the first time since March 26.

NEW YORK'S effects on the human nerve system is explained to some extent by a Western Union report that 150,000 heavy sleepers use the company's Wake-up Service each year. Ralph D. Saylor, Western Union's general manager in the metropolitan area, thinks townsfolk sleep harder because they work and play harder, but that's only his guess.
CHICAGO, May 13 -- The right of Selective Service to draft displaced persons or any "treaty nation'' aliens here for permanent residence was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals.

LONDON, May 13 -- The United Nations subcommittee on disarmament opened its sessions here in a blaze of klieg lights today, but promptly went into secret session after the formalities had been recorded on film.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Pvt. G. David Schine got permission today to get out of the limelight and watch discussion of his case on television.
Following is the text of the speech by former President Harry S. Truman before the Amalgamated Clothing Workers' convention at Atlantic City:
The Paulist Choristers last evening commemorated the fiftieth anniversary of their founding with a concert in the Town Hall.

BUFFALO, May 13 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said here tonight that a policy of "pledging and hedging" was characteristic of the Republican administrations in Washington and in Albany.

Industrialization and tourism are stimulating the economy of Kentucky in such a way as to make the proposed forty-mile toll expressway from Elizabethtown to Louisville a good investment, Governor Lawrence W. Wetherby said here yesterday.

Theoretically it was new methods and new materials for home furnishings that were commended yesterday when the Home Fashions League announced seven winners of the annual Trail Blazer Awards. Actually only four of the award winners seem apt to blaze a trail.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Senators William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, and Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, introduced a resolution today to sever diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and all other Communist countries.
Directors of the R. K. O. Theatres Corporation yester-l day asked stockholders to ender common shares for purchase by the corporation at prices up to $6.50 a share.
Lower capital costs and taxes in the first quarter this year enabled Aluminium, Ltd., to improve earnings despite lower sales, the quarterly report disclosed yesterday.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 13 -- The Netherlands has one museum devoted to the animate rather than the inanimate -- the Museum for Parents and Educators.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 13 -- Paul Kelly of Rutgers won the fifth annual metropolitan intercollegiate golf championships today over the Rock Spring course with an even par 68, 74 -- 142.

LIDO BEACH, L. I., May 13 -- Arthur Golder, a Nassau County patrolman, rode a Fire Department aerial ladder ninety feet up the side of a brick chimney, carrying a hypodermic syringe of morphine, to save workman stricken by a heart attack today.
OTTAWA, May 13 -- President Eisenhower's signature on the St. Lawrence Seaway Bill does not automatically insure that Canada will accept United States participation in the project.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- John A. Hannah, Assistant Defense Secretary, denied today that the Administration was planning to increase military spending because of Communist successes in Indo-China.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday numbered 647,954 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- During the week ended May 12, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, member bank reserves increased $274,000,000.

TOKYO, May 13 -- The Swiss and Swedish members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission in Korea complained today that they were "hampered" in their efforts to enforce the truce terms. They blamed the Poles and Czechoslovaks on the commission for the obstruction.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved a bill authorizing the Navy to charter twenty big new tankers to be built and operated by private concerns.

New York bank loans to business resumed their decline during the week ended on Wednesday. After advancing $26,000,000 in the previous week, they dropped $84,000,000. The latest decline was the seventh to be registered in the past eight weeks.
LONDON, May 13 -- T. Clifton Webb, New Zealand's Minister of External Affairs, said today his country hoped the proposed defensive alliance for Southeast Asia would come into being.
BONN, Germany, May 13 -- The West German Government sought today to head off a movement among its parliamentary supporters to initiate contacts with the Soviet Government.

LA LIMA, Honduras, May 13 -- The Standard Fruit Company at La Ceiba has notified the Honduran Government that the situation there is getting out of hand. It has requested military assistance from President Juan Manuel Galvez.
GENEVA, May 13 -- Differences among the United Nations delegates over the unification of Korea came into the open today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Albert M. Cole, Housing and Home Finance Administrator, has been asked to give Congressional investigators more information on policies and operations that permitted the recently disclosed housing scandals.
New York University avenged an early-season 7-to-1 defeat at the hands of City College by blanking the Beavers, 1 to 0, yesterday at Babe Ruth Field in the Bronx.
WILMINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- A high Treasury official said today it would be "absolutely necessary" for Congress to raise the $275,000,000,000 limit on the national debt before adjourning this year.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 13-- 1N[iss Vivien Kellems of Stonington announced today that she would be a. candidate for Governor this year, either on the Republican ticket or as an independent Republican.

MIAMI, Fla., May 13 (AP) -- Gar Wood, speedboat racer, and eight other persons were rescued today after Mr. Wood's "unsinkable" twin-hulled yacht Venturi broke up in heavy seas and sank in the Bahamas near Great Isaac Light.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 13 -- Yugoslav officials have given the Western powers assurances that, according to Western sources, may at last clinch a settlement in the Trieste dispute.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Sen. Lester C. Hunt, Republican of Wyoming, said today natural gas from foreign fields should be excluded from the United States if it would injure the domestic industry. He addressed a Senate Interior subcommittee in support of a bill, of which he is author, to amend the Natural Gas Act.

Helped by a later Easter this year, sales of forty-four chain store and mail order companies in April were 4.4 per cent heavier than in April of last year, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., May 13 -- This section of the North Shore's "Gold Coast" has seen a more opulent era. But houses still stand amid spreading acres, even though in many cases their grandiose proportions have shrunk in recent times.

The 14-day-old strike of 1,500 bakery workers against five major companies appeared early today to be near a settlement after the employers' negotiators reportedly had accepted a "final" offer by the union.
" IT'S strange," said Valerius, the Roman centurion, "just as the world begins to learn something about civilization, some nation or some catastrophe comes along and destroys the knowledge."
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- The House overrode Democratic opposition today and approved a request to give Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby a new nine-member advisory committee on education.
New York shipping interests yesterday made varying estimates of the effect on the port as President Eisenhower signed the St. Lawrence Seaway bill.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Treasury and the Federal Reserve Board asked today for a two-year extension of the board's authority to buy up to $5,000,000,000 worth of United States securities directly from the Treasury.

We take the greatest pleasure in extending our heartiest congratulations to The New York Times upon the passage of the joint Congressional bill authorizing the construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway. Your fine editorials were a valuable contribution in helping to establish the inestimable value of this project.
Frank Costello was convicted last night of income tax evasion and faced the prospect of going back to prison, from which he emerged six months ago.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The United States announced tonight the successful completion of its 1954 series of hydrogen explosions in the Pacific.

So many comments have recently been published by pseudo-historians to the effect that Senator McCarthy's investigation of the Army was in some way a violation of the letter or the spirit of the Constitution of the United States that the following historical data may be of interest.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor approved unanimously today a plan for the peaceful settlement of jurisdictional disputes involving the Federation's 10,000,000 members.

YONKERS, May 13 (AP) -- Leading all the way, the 13-to-10 favorite, Patrick Song, was driven to victory by Jimmy Jordan in the $4,000 Fleetwood Pace on the Grand Circuit card tonight at Yonkers Raceway. Mighty Jet was second, one and one-half lengths behind. The summaries:
WESTBURY, L. I., May 13 -- Jimmy Demaret proved the leading point-winner as the Palm Beach round-robin golf tournament got under way today at the Meadow Brook Club.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- The Senate blocked a bill to authorize temporary railroad rate increases by voting today to send it back to committee.
Baltimore County, Md., announced plans yesterday to sell $22,000,000 of various-purpose bonds on May 26.

Harry S. Truman's use yesterday of the phrase "creeping McKinleyism" was both a play on the frequent Republican use of "creeping Socialism" and a reference to the policies of William McKinley, Republican President from 1897 until his assassination in 1901.

THE last new musical of the season is the best. It is "The Pajama Game," which opened at the St. James last evening with all the uproar of a George Abbott show. He and Richard Bissell put the book together out of Mr. Bissell's recent novel, "7 1/2 Cents."

" Freedom Against Itself," Clarence Streit's new book, will be issued by Harper on May 26 east of the Mississippi River and on June 9 in the Western states. In his work, Mr. Streit contends that "liberty is the mother of invention, but it is also a dangerous source of division and isolation among free countries.

The prevailing concepts that a good father must be a "real pal" and an ideal mother "just like a sister" were criticized last night by Dr. Robert Goldenson. Dr. Goldenson, a Professor of Psychology at Hunter College, spoke at a meeting of parents and teachers at the West Side Branch of the Bentley School, 48 West Eighty-sixth Street.

BARCELONA, May 13 (UP) -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati led the American players in a steady advance in the Barcelona international tennis tournament today. He scored a second-round singles victory and joined Vic Seixas of Philadelphia for a doubles triumph.

GENEVA, Friday, May 14 -- Official sources said today the French Foreign Minister, Georges Bidault, would present France's position on the Indo-China question before the Far Eastern conference this afternoon.
Stocks marched into higher ground yesterday, establishing new highs for the upward movement, and then marched back down.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Alaskans asked President Eisenhower today to urge the House of Representatives to vote on Alaskan statehood legislation.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 13 (AP) -- French efforts to bolster Indo-China's key Red River Delta -- possibly the Communist-led Vieminh's next target -- are being hampered by the general apathy of the Vientnamese inhabitants.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (UP) -- The round - robin football schedule for the Ivy League was announced today by Jerry Ford, athletic director of the University of Pennsylvania and secretory of the Ivy group's administrative committee.

ROGER BANNISTER lounged carelessly in a chair at the Yale Club yesterday and talked with rare graciousness, penetration and charm. He is sandy-haired, tall, slim and ever-smiling. Pictures of him in action while running a mile in 3:59.4 are a mite flattering. When he strides in a track suit, he looks barrel-chested and overpowering. Street clothes make him shrink to more boyish proportions.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 13 -- John W. McGeehan, counsel for Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County who has been on trial for fifty-two days on charges of having failed to suppress gambling, gave a five-hour summing up today.

BALTIMORE, May 13 -- Although some local business and shipping leaders think Baltimore will lose through construction of the Seaway, others believe it might gain in the aggregate through expansion of world trade. The city generally opposed the Seaway.

IT may not be a political trend of any momentous significance, but comedians apparently have reached the conclusion that it is safe to spoof the Senate subcommittee hearings into the controversy between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army. Heretofore the Wisconsin Senator has been very much a privileged character and virtually immune to TV quips.
VIENNA, May 13 -- A British nuclear scientist said today that the hydrogen bomb was "absolutely crazy as a weapon" and a possible form of world suicide.

The first outlines of a practical plan for the unification of Korea in conformity with United Nations principles have been presented to the Geneva conference by Secretary Eden and Foreign Minister Bidault. Their proposal is based on the General Assembly resolution of Oct. 7, 1950, already cited as a workable program by Secretary Dulles.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Under pounding cross-examination today John G. Adams, Army Counselor, denied having first appeased and later threatened Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and his staff to dissuade them from investigating the Army.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 13 -- The Byelorussian and Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republics have become the sixty-eighth and sixty-ninth member states of the International Labor Organization, the agency announced today.
Roger Bannister, English medical student who is the first athlete to run the mile in less than four minutes, expressed gratitude yesterday for the hearty reception he has received in this country.

Three men were found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of knowingly supplying gamblers with horse racing information. Assistant District Attorney William Fitts Ryan said he believed the conviction was the first of its kind in the country.
CHICAGO, May 13 -- Samuel Cardinal Stritch put stress tonight on the importance of the "printed word" of the newspaper and other journals.
Governor Dewey directed the Long Island Transit Authority yesterday to submit a plan for rehabilitating the Long Island Rail Road and ending its bankruptcy.
Hospital volunteers with thousands of hours to their credit were praised and awarded honors yesterday afternoon by the United Hospital Fund at the Astor Hotel.

DETROIT, May 13 -- Yogi Berra, who can't recall when he enjoyed a better spring, smashed a two-run homer in the tenth inning tonight and gave the Yankees a 5-3 victory over the league-leading Tigers. The largest turnout of the major-league season, 50,916 fans, saw Tom Morgan go all the way for his third straight triumph.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- International Harvester Company's sales picked up, beginning in January, to reverse the sharp down turn which set in a year ago, John L. McCaffrey, president, told stockholders at their meeting today.

The blue-ribbon jury considering the fate of Joseph P. Ryan, former president of the old International Longshoremen's Association, who is charged with stealing union funds, failed to reach agreement early today and retired to a hotel for the night.
New York is showing no loss of its importance as the money and banking center of the nation and the world, William A. Lyon, State Superintendent of Banks, declared last night.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Dr. Howard A. Rusk reported tonight that the American people were giving splendid support to the American-Korean Foundation.

In an editorial on May 8, criticizing the proposed sales tax on services, you argued effectively for taxes on overnight parking, automobile use and sales of beer. I was especially pleased, since I would not pay any of them. Although I can think of taxes that would hit me, it might seem officious if I mentioned them.

Chou En-lai, the Foreign Minister of the Peiping regime, is possibly the ablest and certainly the most urbane of the Chinese Communist inner circle. The persons who suggest that the United States can and should reach some sort of accommodation with Red China usually have him in mind as a person with whom it is possible to talk reasonably.

The first public showing of "Yorkville, New York -- the Neighborhood Way," a documentary film, was the feature of a meeting of the Yorkville Youth Council held yesterday at Brearley School, 610 East Eighty-third Street.

NEW CITY, N. Y., May 13 -- Rockland County Treasurer S. J. Ciancimino has refused to disclose to the Soviet Government the Russian heirs to a $45,000 estate left by a resident of this county because he does not want Communists to get the money.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UP) -- A Mississippi Representative in Congress and a Negro colleague from Illinois agreed today there should be no "second class" citizens of the United States but disputed the need for Federal action to wipe out racial barriers.

Doing all their scoring on home runs, the Giants defeated the Cubs, 6 -- 3, for their fifth straight victory yesterday. The New Yorkers blasted the ball into the Polo Grounds stands five times. Monty Irvin connected twice and Henry Thompson, Willie Mays and Ebba St. Claire once apiece.
The Dodgers had their biggest inning of the season yesterday -- a six-run sixth -- in riding to a 10-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals at Ebbets Field.

PARIS, May 13 -- By a margin of only two votes Premier Joseph Laniel obtained the confidence of the National Assembly today to go on directing France's policies in the Indo-China emergency. The vote was 289 to 287.

The construction of two new bauxite carriers, said to be the largest of their kind in the world, is now under way in two European yards. The vessels -- one of 33,000 deadweight tons and the other of 26,000 tons -- will dwarf any ship now being used to transport bauxite ore, which is the principal ingredient of aluminum.

It is always reassuring when the judiciary confirms a truth that unsophisticated laymen knew all along -- in this case, that a lady does no wrong in abiding not by the Julian or the Gregorian but the Sliding Calendar. Thus the Court of Special Sessions absolved Mrs. Edward Nicholson from any criminal action in stating her date of birth variously on auto registration forms.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 13 -- The Chinese Nationalist Government will undergo a major reorganization after the Presidential inauguration next Thursday. The entire Nationalist cabinet decided today to resign in a bloc.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The United States was producing goods and services at an annual rate of $358,000,000,000 in the first quarter of this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 13 -- Former President Harry S. Truman asserted here today that the nation was suffering from Republican policies of "creeping McKinleyism." He charged that as a result it was floundering in a recession that could well become a real depression.

The Port of New York Authority received yesterday the National Safety Council Award of Honor for industrial safety in 1953. The presentation was made by Harold K. Kramer, past president of the Greater New York Safety Council. Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency, accepted the honor for the commission.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Eisenhower today signed the St. Lawrence Seaway bill, authorizing the United States to join Canada in building the waterway. His action brought closer to reality a dream of fifty years.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Development of a new clinical thermometer described as more accurate and much faster than the present mercury type was announced today by the Army.
NEWARK, May 15 -- Three thousand persons were affected today when the power in the thirty-four-story National Newark and Essex Bank Building failed for seventy minutes.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Key House Republicans have paved the way for early favorable action on President Eisenhower's recommendations for expanding the Social Security insurance system.

WITH water levels dropping quite rapidly and temperatures rising in most of the Catskill streams, there is every possibility that the week-end will provide the best fly fishing of the season. Even the weather forecast is encouraging.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13 -- William Wyler's next production for Paramount will be "The Desperate Hours," based on the novel by Joseph Hayes.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Telecasts of the Army-McCarthy hearings may now be commercially sponsored. However, advertisements must not interrupt the testimony.
ROME, May 13 -- American tourists visiting Milan this year will see Leonardo da Vinci's fresco of "The Last Supper" as it has not been seen in generations.
Dr. Jacome Baggi de Berenguer Cesar, Brazilian Consul General in New York, praised the "tremendous growth of trade" between the nations of the Americas.
LONDON, May 13 -- The Foreign Office rejected Soviet charges that Maj. Charles R. D. Landon, assistant military attache in the British Embassy in Moscow, had engaged in espionage.

Much may be said about the whiting, and all in its favor. John Von Glahn of the Fishery Council reports it is generally the cheapest fish in the market month in and month out. He says one can add to its thriftiness such other virtues as year-round availability, delicate flavor and adaptability to many methods of preparation.

CLEVELAND, May 13 (UP) -- Dave Philley doubled with the bases filled in the ninth to tie the game and Al Rosen doubled in the eleventh today to win a delayed-action thriller for Cleveland over the Washington Senators, 8 -- 7.
MOSCOW, May 13 -- The Soviet Foreign Office declared the Assistant British military attache, Maj. Charles R. P. Landon, persona non grata today on charges of "general espionage."

To anyone but a hard-working young hospital physician, a round of technical lectures, pre-surgical conferences, clinical visits and the like might seem anything but inviting. But for six internes and resident physicians from Freedman's Hospital, Washington, a week of this at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx is almost like a vacation.
The Transit Authority rejected yesterday a proposal that its meetings be opened to the public.
SINGAPORE, May 13 -- Five hundred Chinese schoolboys and girls clashed twice with the police today as they tried to march to Government House to protest against military conscription.

JERUSALEM, Jordanian Sector, May 13 -- The Jordanian- Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission condemned Israel today for two truce violations in which four Jordanians were wounded. The commission is being boycotted by the Israelis.
PITTSBURGH, May 13 (AP) -- Milwaukee's Braves, behind the steady eight-hit pitching of Chet Nichols, a southpaw, whipped the Pirates, 4 -- 2, tonight.

EDMONTON, May 13 (Canadian Press) -- The Alberta Government gave its go-ahead today for export of natural gas to eastern Canada by approving the issuing of an export permit to Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd.
BOSTON, May 13 -- The best estimates are that Boston will lose about 30 per cent of its shipping business as a result of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
Dr. Samuel Winograd, City College's faculty manager of athletics from 1947 to 1952, resigned yesterday as assistant professor of hygiene.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- France has put the big question to the United States: What will you do if we cannot get an honorable cease-fire in Indo-China?

TOKYO, April 16 -- Bunka Fukuso Gakuin, an unusual school in the Far East, graduated its 100,000th student this spring and celebrated its thirty-fourth anniversary, now averaging 5,000 graduates a class.

LONDON, May 13 -- The lowering of the bank rate signaled a general raising of prices on the Stock Exchange, but advances were more moderate than last September when the rate was previously changed. Furthermore, early marking-up of prices was overdone and they reacted slightly in later dealings, though nearly all markets closed firm for fixed interest stocks and equities alike.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 13 -- Launching their heaviest attack in months in the Red River Delta, the Vietminh rebels hurled several regular battalions at Phuly, thirty-five miles south of Hanoi, early today.
Physicians were cautioned here yesterday that laboratory procedures should never be considered routine measures in diagnosis, but should be reserved for unusually difficult cases.

TRENTON, May 13 -- Commissioner Sanford Bates of the New Jersey Department of Institutions and Agencies will retire on his seventieth birthday, July 17. His decision was made public here this evening "with sincere regret" by Reeve Schley, president of the department's Board of Control.
The proposal to use civilians as school-crossing guards in New York struck a snag last night when the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association challenged its legality.

Prospects of a drop in coffee prices in the near future were crushed yesterday. A sharply reduced estimate of exportable Brazilian supplies for the twelve months beginning July 1 discourage hopes of roasters here for price slashes.

King Commander carried the colors of Lawrence R. Troiano to victory in the Belmont Spring Maiden Steeplechase, the $6,800 event that was the feature of the card at Belmont Park yesterday. The triumph was a popular one with the crowd of 19,308, for the 5-year-old son of Brown King returned $3.90 for $2. Pat Smithwick was the rider.
LONDON, May 13 -- The Labor party's failure to deal with Bevanism has produced the resignation of a former junior minister and member of Parliament.

MOSCOW, May 13 (Reuters) -- Mikhail Botvinnik retained the world chess championship tonight when the twenty-fourth and last game of the series with the contender, Vassily Smyslov, ended in a draw after the twenty-second move.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 13 -- The State Harness Racing Commission, moving to keep labor racketeering out of Roosevelt Raceway, yesterday denied job clearance to five top aides to William C. DeKoning Sr., former Long Island labor boss now in prison.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Department of Justice said today "the Attorney General [Herbert ]3rownell Jr.] is shocked by the falsity of the statement," circulated in ]Vfexico, that he suggested killing a few wetbacls to stop their influx across the border.
The New York Central Railroad will pay $5,000 in damages and $2,000 in lawyers' fees to Time, Inc., under the terms of a consent judgment signed yesterday by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger.

LANDOVER, Md., May 13 (UP) -- Betty Jameson carded a one- under-par 71 at Prince Georges Golf and Country Club today to take the first-day lead in the seventy-two-hole, $5,000 women's National Capital open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Twice within a week the Senate has returned to committee a controversial legislative item, a maneuver which usually dooms a bill to death for the remainder of a Congressional session. Both actions were consequences of the close party division in the Senate which the voters decreed at the polls of 1952.

When rights collide the solution is never easy. That is the case with the conflict between the constitutional guarantee of a fair trial, with a man presumed innocent until proved guilty, and the constitutional guarantee of a free press. The courts, the bar and conscientious journalists have all been troubled by issues raised in this conflict, and in recent months the legal profession has been advancing remedies.
Summer begins tomorrow morning for the city's short-haul tourists as the Hudson River Day Line starts its 133d season.
GENEVA, May 13 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from the speeches of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, at the Far Eastern conference today:
For several years the Greater New York Fund has escorted public groups on tours of the agencies it helps to support, to show how your dollars work for the community's benefit.
LONDON, May 13 -- For the second time in less than eight months the Bank of England has cut the bank rate.

TRENTON, May 13 -- The Democratic State Convention, in the face of strong opposition by Gov. Robert B. Meyner, tonight adopted a 1954 platform placing the party on record as opposed to a state sales or personal income tax.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Price fluctuations in wheat were choppy today. But a stronger undertone appeared with commission absorption on the dips. Short covering was responsible for a sharp closing rally. Investment buying appeared in December wheat and December corn for a six-month holding, but the trade was not active.

The Defense Department is now forwarding to the White House its recommendations for a modified form of universal military training which will ultimately come before Congress. The plan as set out does not differ in principle from that set forth by the National Security Training Commission last December, although there has been some modification of detail.

YONKERS, May 13 -- New officers and a proposed new name for the Algam Corporation, owner of the Yonkers Raceway, were announced today. The changes followed a switch in ownership control, which had resulted from the state's investigation of harness racing.
PHILADELPHIA, May 13 -- Municipal, business and shipping leaders in this area were agreed that the diversion of trade to the Seaway would be a blow to the Port of Philadelphia.
Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, warned the city's teachers yesterday against taking part in a boycott of extracurricular activities scheduled for Monday.
West Fifty-ninth Street from Columbus Circle to Ninth-Columbus Avenues has vanished unofficially from the city's street system.

HASTINGS - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., May 13 -- Clarence H. Sanford of 25 Croton Avenue, a retired educator, was found hanged today from a tree near his home. He was to have entered a hospital today for an operation. The Westchester County Medical Examiner's office listed the death as a suicide.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 13 -- J. Russel Sprague, Nassau County Republican leader, said today that he, Governor Dewey and other Republicans had been smeared by "the Three Musketeers of Tammany Hall." The smearing, he said was in speeches at the dinner of the Nassau County Democratic Committee last night.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 14 -- Governor General Ghulam Mohammed announced tonight that he had ordered the Federal Court to inquire into charges of maladministration and misappropriation of public funds by Mian Mumtaz Mohammed Daultana, former Prime Minister of Punjab Province.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 to 22 points yesterday. New crop months showed the most strengtht.

The recent article by Gladwin Hill on the school situation at Los Angeles interested me, as I had recently been present at a meeting in California where a member of the Board of Education of Los Angeles was the principal speaker.
R. K. O. Pictures Corporation no longer makes motion pictures, but it is not dead yet.

Three Brooklyn businessmen, though "touched" by the bequests of a 96-year-old former employe, have decided to enjoy the spirit of the gifts and let the legacies go. They said yesterday they would waive the right to bequests of $300 each, so the money could go to the testator's family.

" Always a Bride," a British-made comedy produced by Robert Garrett for the J. Arthur Rank Organization and featuring Peggy Cummins, Terence Morgan and Ronald Squire, will have its American premiere on Thursday, May 27, at the Art, Beekman and Gramercy Theatres.

CHICAGO, May 14 -- The know-how of managing money has to be acquired, just like the technique of driving, teen-agers are reminded in a recent publication. To help young people attain some basic management principles the Household Finance Corporation has prepared a twenty-page booklet titled "Money Management for Young Moderns."

CAIRO, May 14 -- A vast submarine temple of red granite, a smaller temple decorated with swastikas and two dozen luxurious private baths buried in Mediterranean sand dunes were uncovered this week at Canopus. The place was a pleasure resort of Egypt's Greco-Roman kings and nobles and once rivaled Pompeii in dissoluteness.
A total of $18,000,000 will be proposed for benevolence by the General Council of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. at its 166th General Assembly meeting in Detroit May 20 to 26.

Anyone with a yen for travel might satisfy it in part by a quick trip through the Thirty-fourth Street Armory next week. Monday through Thursday, from 3 P. M. to 9 P. M., the public may take a tour through the International Trade Show where the products of twenty-three countries will be displayed in 105 booths.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:
MONTREAL, May 14 (UP) -- Crewmen of the British freighter Mont Alta decided to stop work today to bring to sixty-one the number of seamen who staged a cost-of-living strike at this port.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A film producer urged today that motion pictures be dropped from the Government's overseas information program.

Harry J. Anslinger, United States Federal Narcotics Commissioner, has once more supplied the United Nations with detailed and up-to-date information about the degree to which the Communist Chinese regime in Peiping is conducting an international trade in illicit narcotics.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in its seventeenth day of considering the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14 -- American motion pictures were praised for helping to spread tolerance and understanding among peoples of the world by Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, in a brief talk at a private dinner held in his honor last night by the Association of Motion Picture Producers.
PARIS, May 14 -- French and Indian representatives sat down together here today to try to reach agreement on the future of four tiny colonies France holds in India.

With the tie match for the chess championship of the world between Mikhail Botvinnik and Vassily Smyslov, both Russians, concluded, followers of the game here are looking forward to the series of team matches between the United States and Russia at the Hotel Roosevelt from June 16 to 24.
Whether the proposed 3 per cent tax on commercial services would be pressed or abandoned remained in doubt yesterday at the end of a two-hour executive session of the Board of Estimate.
Starting today, fires to burn garbage and refuse in incinerators in buildings are forbidden in the city except from 7 A. M. to 5 P. M.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches went into the final stretch yesterday, with only one more match to be played. In only one district, Long Island, is a new champion assured. The Creek five of Mrs. Allan Ryan, Mrs. J. B. Balding, Mrs. Thomas Rudel, Mrs. Caryl Sayres and Mrs. William Stockhausen became the new winners.

Scholars and leaders in every field of endeavor continue to group and regroup on Morningside Heights for convocations, symposiums and other feasts of learning as Columbia's Bicentennial Celebration moves along through the year dedicated to the theme, "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof."
ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 14 -- The United States has recognized the new Paraguayan Government, which was established after a brief revolution last week.
The conflict of supply and demand in the market for new corporate debt securities seems likely to continue next week.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 0.2 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 6.1 per cent and orders 19.6 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet.
LONDON, May 14 -- The stock markets here were still preoccupied today with adjusting to the reduction in the bank rate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14 -- The United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs has cautioned governments that greater use of synthetic narcotics may lead to an increase in the illicit trafficking of the newly developed drugs.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 14 -- United States envoys in the Middle East and leading State Department officials concerned with the area have agreed the United States must take prompt steps to halt the deterioration of conditions along Israel's frontiers.

The Johns-Manville Corporation, manufacturer of building materials and industrial products, will spend about $18,500,000 on expansion and improvements this year, L. M. Cassidy, board chairman, declared yesterday.
BERLIN, May 14 -- Another alleged West German intelligence official has disappeared. He is Gerhard Kapahnke, who West Berlin police say, vanished April 27.
The city got 154 more policemen for patrol duty yesterday shortly after Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams had announced the men were being taken off civilian defense duty.

ALBANY, May 14 -- The State Education Department announced today 100 scholarships to children of deceased or disabled soldiers, sailors and Marines of this state. Recipients will receive $450 a year for four years toward tuition at any approved college or university in the state.
CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox took a full-game lead in the American League tonight by beating the Philadelphia Athletics, 4 -- 3, as Mass Michaels smacked the key blows.
Long Island University scored its seventh victory without a defeat in Knickerbocker Intercollegiate Baseball Conference play by beating Pace College, 8 -- 2, at the Brooklyn Parade Grounds yesterday.
In a philosophical mood, Frank Costello posted a $25,000 bond yesterday in Federal Court pending his sentencing Monday for income tax evasion.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 14 -- Sam Snead, the only player in the field who has won the event twice, moved ahead in the Palm Beach round-robin golf tourney today.

The 57th baseball meeting between Columbia and New York University at Baker Field will provide the highlight of this afternoon's local college baseball program. Four other games are listed with the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference engagement between St. John's and C. C. N. Y. the most important.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Robert B. Anderson, Deputy Secretary of Defense, called tonight for a collective security system against Communist expansion in any part of the world.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) -- Art Fowler, an eighteen-game winner with Atlanta, Ga., last season, snapped the Phillies' three-game victory streak tonight as the Cincinnati Redlegs beat the Philadelphia club, 1 -- 0.

A high-walled yard back of the old Queens City Prison in Long Island City was dedicated yesterday as an athletic field for young prisoners who are awaiting trial. Commissioner Anna M. Kross said the yard and an indoor recreation room were "only the beginning" in her Department of Correction's plans for the rehabilitation of youthful offenders.
Reflecting record sales, the California Packing Corporation and its subsidiaries increased net income to $6,676,211 in the fiscal year ended in February from $5,653,026 in the preceding year.
BOSTON, May 14 -- The third scheduled meeting of American Woolen Company stockholders to announce the results of the April 23 balloting for four directors was postponed today.

AMARILLO, Tex., May 14 (AP) -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining said today that the new Russian heavy jet bomber, comparable in size to the B-52, had been developed for the sole purpose of reaching "important targets in the United States."

NEW DELHI, India, May 14 -- In a move to strengthen India's hold on the disputed state of Jammu and Kashmir, President Rajendra Prasad today ordered the strategic northern territory brought under the Indian Union's Constitution.
Students at Finch College are furthering the success of the moonlight sail aboard the sightseeing yacht Knickerbocker, to be held tonight for the benefit of the Finch Nursery School.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Members of the American Association of English-Jewish Newspapers brought to the White House today a resolution saying "information from Congress indicates that in the last two weeks incoming mail has shown an increase in anti-Semitic propaganda pamphlets attacking the Executive branch of the Government."
Bids will be accepted by the New York State Thruway Authority on June 15 for the sale of $300,000,000 to $350,000,000 of revenue bonds in the public market.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Congress was asked today to consider Government insurance to protect private industry against a catastrophe during efforts to harness the atom for peaceful pursuits.

BONN, Germany, May 14 -- An unofficial West German organization called the East Committee was reported today to be planning to dispatch eighteen experts to Moscow to negotiate an agreement for trade totaling 250,000,000 Deutsche marks (almost $60,000,000).
England's Roger Bannister flew home yesterday, carrying a little silver bowl as a memento of two action-filled days in the United States.
Your editorial of May 10 "The City's Power Plants" should be read thoughtfully by every taxpayer.

LANDOVER, Md., May 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias took over the half-way lead in the $5,000 women's National Capital open by a five-stroke margin today by adding a 74 to her opening 73 for a 147 total.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 14 -- The ammunition stocks of the Allied forces in Europe will be great enough for forty days of war by next year, the logistics chief of the Allied command said here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14 -- Following are the texts of a petition from Marshall Islanders in the Pacific Trust Territory administered by the United States, and a reply from the United States Delegation to the United Nations:

Native Dancer will carry 130 pounds over the distance of a mile today, and the general belief is that the 4-year-old son of Polynesian will have no trouble. Winner of nineteen of twenty races since he went into competition two years ago, the powerful gray will compete in the sixty-first running of the $30,000 added Metropolitan handicap at Belmont Park.

Mikhail Botvinnik, who retained his world chess championship as a result of his 12-12 tie match with Vassily Smyslov in Moscow, was a pawn ahead in the twenty-second game when he permitted a draw by repetition, according to the score received here from London yesterday by airmail.

THOSE who have been waiting impatiently for the opening of the northern lakes can begin packing, for the majority of the Maine and New Hampshire landlocked salmon waters are now open enough for fishing, and some are producing excellent results.
RODANTHE, N. C., May 14 (UP) -- Fourteen crewmen were rescued by breeches buoy today from a grounded freighter.
A ragtag army of homeless children, some as young as 7 years old, was pictured to a panel of judges yesterday as being shunted from state to state by officials anxious to be rid of them.

The St. Louis Cardinal jinx, which had caused the Redbirds to lose twelve straight games to the Dodgers at Ebbets Field, was chased from the premises last night while 21,706 Flatbush fans sorrowfully watched its exit.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Eisenhower in a speech tonight deplored "unworthy scenes in our national capital."

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The New York Central Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to rule that control of the carrier by Robert R. Young would be illegal, whatever the stockholders decided.

A doctor's prescription to alleviate a major affliction of American society was written yesterday at the final session of the 148th annual meeting of the New York State Medical Society at the Statler Hotel.

A mistrial was called last evening in the grand larceny trial of Joseph P. Ryan, former head of the old International Longshoremen's Association. A General Sessions blue ribbon jury was dismissed after the foreman had reported the jurors were "hopelessly deadlocked."

TORONTO, May 14 (AP) -- A United States syndicate has offered to invest $75,000,000 in construction of a new fifty-story skyscraper to house municipal and court offices in place of City Hall, it was reported yesterday. The proposal took the city's Board of Control by surprise and initial reaction was cool.

WASHINGTON, May 14(UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has puzzled a good many observers in the last three days by remaining fairly quiet and subdued during the questioning of John G. Adams, Army Counselor.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, May 14 (AP) -- The Troy Methodist Conference today praised the manner in which the McCarthy-Army hearing has been conducted and declared it believed "the time and money involved are justified."

DETROIT, May 14 -- Along with Yogi Berra's batting average, the Yankees continued to climb today. They made it two straight over the Detroit Tigers with a 6-4 victory, as Berra's fifth-inning double drove in the tie-breaking run.

I think Arthur Krock, in his column appearing in The New York Times of May 6, overlooked one salient point discussed by Chief Justice Earl Warren in his opinion in the case of Pete Hernandez, involving the systematic exclusion of persons of Mexican descent from juries in Jackson County, Tex.
CHICAGO, May 14 -- A record number of babies was born in registered hospitals in the United States last year, the American Medical Association reported today.
GENEVA, May 14 -- The Soviet Union announced today changes in the Communist positions with regard to the machinery for supervising and guaranteeing an armistice in Indo-China.

Mayor Wagner will appoint three residents of Staten Island to city posts next week. This became known yesterday when two Staten Island lawyers received letters notifying them to be at City Hall on Tuesday for appointment to judgeships.
I should like to make reply to the letters on Cyprus and Greece written by C. A. Triantaphyllakos of the Royal Greek Embassy and of Aristocles E. Andreades.

ROME, May 14 -- Authorization to reconstruct the famous bridge of Santa Trinita in Florence has been granted by the Superior Council of Public Works in Rome, it was announced today. The bridge was blown up by the Germans in 1944 to hold back the Allied Fifth Army.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Signs that the business downturn may be tapering off have taken most of the steam out of a Democratic drive for a reduction in individual income taxes.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A number of companies are seeking to buy or lease the $13,000,000 tin smelting plant operated by the Government at Texas City, Tex., it was disclosed tonight.

PARIS, May 14 -- The French National Defense Council met today to outline measures for immediate reinforcement of the Indo-China expeditionary corps up to the limit of France's material and financial capacities.
TOKYO, May 14 -- The conservative Japanese Government virtually lost today the fight to curb the teaching of left-wing political theories in public schools.

THE number of Lithuanian-born artists who have made international reputations for themselves in modern art is small but distinguished. For it includes Soutine, William Zorach, Ben Shahn and, most recently, the water-colorist V. K. Jonynas, whose first American one-man show is at the Weyhe Gallery.
Hectic last minute preparations yesterday kept members of the Armed Forces busy for their "Day" today.
A bail bondsman and a man previously held in connection with the narcotics traffic were arrested yesterday on indictments resulting from District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's bail bond investigation.
LANDER, Wyo., May 14 (AP) -- Uranium hunters in this Central Wyoming area are blaming atomic dust for a sudden jump in activity on the dials of their Geiger and scintillation counters.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The number of persons receiving unemployment compensation declined 20,900 in the week ended May 1, the Labor Department reported today.
CHICAGO, May 14 -- Two steps toward the elimination of inter-union warfare were taken here today by the American Federation of Labor.

LUGANO, Switzerland, May 14 (UP) --Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., and Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., advanced to the men's doubles semi-finals in the Lugano tennis tournament today when they defeated the Italian team of Sergio Fontana and Marco Albonico, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

Jacques Royer, whose reputation rested largely upon having once held the middleweight championship of France, made his New York debut against Ralph (Tiger) Jones in Madison Square Garden last night and won. He gained a unanimous decision in ten rounds, but failed to impress.
CHICAGO, May 14 -- New crop wheat deliveries led a sharp advance in grain prices today, continuing the recovery of the past three days.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Army raised its draft call by 5,000 today, calling for the induction of 23,000 men in July.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 14 -- Governor Dewey's influence in the State Association of Young Republican Clubs was challenged here today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 14 -- Chilean workers are threatening a nation-wide one-day general strike Monday as an indirect result of the unstable economic situation. This development reflects the tension that has arisen between the workers and the Government.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 14 -- Seven persons were honored here tonight at the sixteenth annual convocation of the Rochester Museum of Arts and Sciences.

In a first hint at a possible break in the deadlock on Indo-China Foreign Minister Molotov has proposed at Geneva that any cessation of hostilities in that area should be put under the supervision of a commission of neutral nations, as is the case in Korea.
" Concert Variety Night" was given at Carnegie Hall last evening as the latest in the series of "Pop" concerts being presented there. The orchestra again was conducted by D'Artega.

The two-story business building at 148 East Fifty-seventh Street has been resold by Jack Brause, real estate developer and investor, to a client of David Fisher, attorney. A new lease for twenty-one years was arranged for the tenant, the Alder Monument Granite Works, Inc., through the Herbert Jacques Morris Corporation, broker.

Working papers are a necessity for teen-agers taking summer jobs, parents were reminded yesterday by Mrs. Emily Sims Marconnier, director of the division of industrial relations of the State Department of Labor.

NEW DELHI, India, Saturday, May 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today urged that a United Nations organization be drafted to implement whatever decision on Indo-China was reached by the Geneva conference.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- American scientists are reported to have learned so much from the just-concluded Operation Castle tests in the mid-Pacific that they are now prepared to put hydrogen bombs in a variety of sizes into standard production.
LONDON, May 14 -- John Masefield, Britain's septuagenarian Poet Laureate, celebrated Queen Elizabeth's return with a sonnet in The Times of London.

VIENNA, May 14 -- The Russians charged today that their policy of free entry of freight traffic into their zone of Austria had been misused. As a result, "Fascist militarist and pan-German literature" entered the zone since the Russians eliminated restrictions last year, they said in the Allied Council for Austria.
GENEVA, May 14 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from speeches at the Geneva conference today by Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov and French Foreign Minister Georges Bidault:
ATHENS, May 14 -- Communist China today was voted into the 1956 Olympic Games in Melbourne, Australia. The vote in the International Olympic Committee was 23 to 21.

Delegates from nineteen Western Hemisphere American central banks and five international organizations met at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria all this week. It was the fourth meeting of the Technicians of the Central Banks of the American Continent and the first to be held in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Eisenhower Administration refused today to give a Senate committee information about a high-level Administration conference at which plans were laid for dealing with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The nervous front-seat passenger who keeps pressing his right foot down on a car's floorboards has a friend in a Long Island inventor. Seymour J. Berman of Lynbrook offers him a real brake pedal.

The St. Louis Post-Dispatch became the first known television sponsor yesterday of the Army-McCarthy hearings. Its own station, KSD-TV in St. Louis, Mo., however, did not get the business. The newspaper placed its sponsorship with a competing station. WTVI.
Henry Cunningham has purchased the two-story dwelling at 189-52 Fotry-third Road in Flushing, Queens, from Sol Kleinman. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
The Evening High School Teachers Association called on its members yesterday not to accept evening summer classes until assurances had been received that current salary schedules would be readusted.
