WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Twenty-seven local housing authorities will sell $119,210,000 more of their bonds.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., May 14 -- Dr. William J. Sparks, director of the chemical division of the Standard Oil Development Company, received today the gold medal award of the American Institute of Chemists.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today an omnibus appropriations bill of $5,700,950,413.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 14 -- The first eight seriously wounded French Union soldiers to be evacuated from fallen Dienbienphu reached Hanoi tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- After months of angry argument behind closed doors, the issue of "one-man rule" in the Atomic Energy Commission promises a lively party-line battle in Congress.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., May 14 -- To enhance both Army science and security, a $20,000,000 Hexagon -- a structure having one more side than the five-sided Pentagon in Virginia -- is being built for the Signal Corps Engineering Laboratories in nearby Eatontown.

GENEVA, May 14 -- The steering committee of the United Nations powers that fought in Korea met today in closed session in an effort to re-establish their solid front. This solidarity had been somewhat disarranged by yesterday's speech by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, at the conference on Far Eastern affairs.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, by a three-to-two decision ruled yesterday that financier Robert R. Young must undergo examination by New York Central Railroad attorneys. It upheld an order handed down last month by Supreme Court Justice S. Samuel Di Falco.
With two spirited rallies, the Giants defeated the Cubs, 9 -- 6, at the Polo Grounds last night to stretch their winning streak to six games.
LONDON, May 14 -- Queen Elizabeth sailed homeward along the south coast of England today and her subjects, from the Prime Minister to grinning boys in rowboats, went down to the sea to greet her.
TRENTON, May 14 -- The powerful Democratic organization of Hudson County is preparing for what is tantamount to a revolt against the leadership of Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

BALTIMORE, May 14 (AP) -- A five-hit, five-run eighth inning carried the Baltimore Orioles to a 7-to-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox before 16.484 tonight and brought a fourth pitching triumph to Bullet Bob Turley, who struck out eleven for a season total of fifty-three in fifty-one innings.

A statement that this country "can look forward to a great reduction in taxes" because of a sharp rise in its investments abroad was made yesterday by William M. Rand, deputy director of the Foreign Operations Administration.
Six artists have been added to the roster of soloists for the six-week Berkshire Music Festival to be presented by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood, Mass., beginning July 7.

The regional Red Cross blood program announced yesterday the donation of 820 pints of blood by employes of the New York Central Railroad and the Pullman Company Tuesday through Thursday. On Thursday the program received 790 pints of blood, including 245 from the railroad men and 180 from employes of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, 463 West Street.
The election of August Heckscher as president of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation for 1954-55 was announced yesterday by its board of directors.

A local law prohibiting conversion of multiple-dwelling private homes to single-room occupancy was signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner. Exceptions include buildings used as institutional housing for nurses, internes and students.
Cardinal Spellman headed a group of Roman Catholics who sailed yesterday on the liner United States for Rome on a Marian Year pilgrimage.
CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP) -- George Strickland hit a grand-slam homer tonight as the Cleveland Indians scored all their runs in the first inning and beat the Washington Senators, 5 -- 2.

SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras, May 14 -- The labor strike in northern Honduras, hitherto confined largely to United States-owned banana companies, has been extended to a tobacco and a mining company. Indications today were that additional organizations would close by tomorrow.
The following is a round-up of new products which may be of interest to the homemaker:
CHICAGO, May 14 (AP) -- The Catholic Press Association declined today to take action on a resolution considered critical of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

State Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan has denied work permits at Roosevelt Raceway to seventeen applicants thus far in the screening of 2,000 prospective employes that began on Wednesday.

Former President Truman's address on Thursday before the Amalgamated Clothing Workers might have been any one of the speeches he delivered in the course of his whistle-stop campaign of 1948. These were the speeches, it may be recalled, when, in talking to the workers, Mr. Truman denounced the rampant inflation of the times, which, he explained, had its origin in the fact that "they" had killed price control.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The question whether confidential assistants to the President can be forced to testify never has been resolved conclusively.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP) -- Boredom, habit and keeping up with the Joneses are contributing to heart fatalities among American housewives, according to two doctors.

In the lexicon of quick dishes there are few that are quicker than the seasoned, chopped, raw beef known as steak tartare. But speed of preparation, usually of interest to Americans, appears to be a minor consideration in respect to this steak.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Public opinion polls indicate a majority of the persons questioned wished the McCarthy-Army inquiry were ended, but it is still the biggest attraction in town.

The apartment house accommodating seventy-one families at 21 Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by H. Meerbaum, Inc., to Arthur Goldberg and Sol Smith. The City Title Insurance company insured title to the property, which occupies a plot 10 by 125 feet.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 14 (AP) -- Emperor Haile Selassie has signed an agreement granting the United States military base rights in Ethiopia [cross on map] for ninety-nine years. Terms of the agreement remained secret.

The sun is shining brightly for the sunglass industry. Its trade group, the Sun Glass Institute, estimates that more than 60,000,000 persons will be in the market for the industry's products at various prices this summer.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 14 (AP) -- The forty-seventh annual Bach Musical Festival opened here today with the singing in two sections of the Passion according to St. Matthew by the 185-voice Bach Choir of Bethlehem.

LONDON, May 14 -- Herbert Morrison, the Labor party's electoral strategist, expressed cautious optimism today over his party's substantial gains in yesterday's municipal elections in England and Wales.

A barrage of cheers greeted Broadway's latest musical comedy, "The Pajama Game," yesterday. And, the signs were that the George Abbott, Richard Bissell, Richard Adler and Jerry Ross musical would most certainly prove to be a sure-fire winner.

IROQUOIS, Ont., May 13 -- The death sentence that has been hanging over this little Canadian River town for a quarter of a century moved a little nearer to execution today with the signing of the St. Lawrence Seaway Bill.

MONTREAL, May 14 (Canadian Press) -- The Tanker Transpet, which sank in the Gulf of St. Lawrence in 1951 with 1,500,000 gallons of gasoline and Kerosene aboard, has been found by a new echo-sounding device, it was announced here today.
SEATTLE, May 14 -- The Boeing Airplane Company's prototype of the 707 jet tanker-transport, the first jet liner built in this nation, was rolled from the plant at Renton near here this afternoon.

Two huge bronze sculptures, one weighing three tons and the other close to two tons, had been homeless for nearly a week when a way was found yesterday to take them into the garden of the Museum of Modern Art.
Claims to mineral rights of about 1,000 acres of the 3,400-acre Clarence Fahnestock Memorial State Park in Putnam County were filed yesterday in Albany.

The Administration won a victory and the national parks of the United States suffered a defeat when the House Interior Committee authorized by a narrow margin the construction of Echo Park Dam within Dinosaur National Monument on the Utah-Colorado border.

" Man and Beast in Africa," by Francois Sommer, an authority on African game, will be published by Citadel Press on May 24. The author traces the history of chief game areas and shows how the coming of the white man implanted mistrust in the great game herds and influenced their movements. The book has a preface by Ernest Hemingway.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 14 -- Native leaders in the Marshall Islands, a United States trust territory, have sent an urgent plea to the United Nationsfor an end to hydrogen-bomb tests near their tiny, scattered Pacific atolls.
YONKERS, May 14 (AP) -- Prince Adios, a 5-1 shot driven by Clint Hodgins, won the $6,500 Fordham free-for-all pace tonight on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway in 2:04 1-5.

Trading was active on most New York commidity exchanges yesterday. Prices closed irregular with cocoa, potatoes, wool, rubber, burlap, copper and tin higher, and coffee, sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, zinc, lead and silk lower.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 14 -- The freedom of the press is not a one-way street, but a two-way responsibility, Gov. William G. Stratton of Illinois told the first annual Freedom of Information Clinic here today.
" We live in deeds not years" is the slogan carved in dark wood above the auditorium platform of Public School 171, Manhattan.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. called today for the election of a Democratic Congress this year. He also urged the end of the Republican Administration in New York State.

Counter to the usual week-end trend, stocks yesterday pushed forward and managed to end an up-and-down week with a small gain. The closing mark for The New York Times combined average was 206.79, against 206.27 a week earlier.
The camp paper editor strode over to the G. I. from New York, a coming lightweight fighter, and asked for his "story" for Stars and Stripes.

Events tonight: Jewish People's Chorus, Town Hall; Carnegie "Pop" Concert, Carnegie Hall; Yvette Rudin, violinist, and Esther Ostroff, pianist, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, and Marilyn Dubow, violinist, New York College of Music, all at 8:30.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 14 -- About 80,000 service men, just over half of Belgium's armed forces, will be demobilized earlier than expected as result of the Government's decision today to reduce compulsory military service from twenty-one to eighteen months.

PITTSBURGH, May 14 (AP) -- Pinch-hitter Walker Cooper smashed a double in the tenth inning scoring Bob Skinner, to enable the Pittsburgh Pirates to score a 3-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.
I cannot let pass without comment the letter of Prof. Cyril Zebot on the Schuman plan, published in your column of May 2.

The "Voice of Firestone," a program of concert music, will be canceled after June 7 because the National Broadcasting Company wants to replace it with a new television program that will attract a larger audience.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- Brazil has asked the Export-Import Bank whether it wants the South American country to buy less from the United States or repay a loan within the next two years as required.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 -- United States help to the world's underdeveloped areas was defended today by Dr. Ralph J. Bunche. It is not "do-goodism" but an expression of enlightened and practical self-interest in the struggle against Communist aggression, he contended.
HACKENSACK, N. J., May 14 -- Walter G. Winne was acquitted here tonight of charges that he had willfully failed to suppress gambling while serving as Bergen County prosecutor.

This is Armed Forces Day, coming as the culmination of the series of observations of Armed Forces Week. This occasion should once more lead us to an examination of our relationship to the services and their relationship to us. They have given us an opportunity to become better acquainted with them and we want that better acquaintance.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (UP) -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, has suspended the prison sentence of Airman First Class Thomas k. Kinder, convicted of murdering a Korean civilian, and ordered his return to active duty, it was announced today.

MAY I point out in connection with the story of King George VI and Runnymede that the King was not returning from the military review in a train but in a car. What he saw was the big white sign, lettered in black, "Runnymede," which the National Trust has erected at the edge of the level mead, with the intention that those traveling along the road may see it.

The islands of the Mid-Pacific were never quite the heavenly spots that tradition made them. The white man brought disaster to them as well as the blessings of the Western culture. When the Marshall Islanders, in the petition to the United Nations which arrived Friday, said that the American administration had been "by far the most agreeable one" in their memory, they were not saying very much.

YONKERS, May 15 (AP)--A trotting record for Yonkers Raceway was set tonight as Torch Key stepped a mile in 2:024/5 in winning the $6,500 Glenwood trot on the Grand Circuit program. The clocking also was a world mark for 4-year-old geldings on a half-mile track.

THE statement of Lionel Trilling in his review of the Van Wyck Brooks' book "Scenes and Portraits" that John Butler Yeats, father of the poet, "was living in extreme but happy poverty," the center of a circle at Petipas Restaurant, will be resented by Greenwich Villagettes.

BICOLORED stamps are making news this week. A third cut-square copy of India's 1854 error, the 4-anna red and blue with Victoria's head inverted, has turned up in London. The unique plate number block of four of the United States 24c carmine rose and blue airmail stamp of 1918 with center inverted will be auctioned here Tuesday.

By mid-May you can't keep up with it. That amazing first green of willow and birch and maple is full-blown into leaf. Apple blossoms have snowed the orchards, then snowed the grass beneath them. Lilacs are at their peak, scenting the countryside. Peonies are in bud.

EAST HAMPTON L. I., May 15 -- East Hampton's Clinton Academy, built in 1784 and now used as a museum by the East Hampton Historical Society, opened today, four weeks earlier than usual, to enable school children to see the exhibits.
WITH the physical fitness of drivers becoming an increasing factor in highway accidents, New York State has decided to check the health of applicants before issuing renewal licenses after May 31.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 15 -- With Dienbienphu in their hands, Communist forces in Indo-China now have more freedom of maneuver than before. They are in a position either to push on into Laos or to turn their offensive strength against the Red River Delta of northern Vietnam.

ROME, May 15 -- The political, economic and social situation of post-war democratic Italy has now reached the stage where the greatest of all problems is the South -- roughly from Naples and the region of Foggia down.

BOSTON, May 15 -- Store sales in this area continue to hold even with a year ago despite unfavorable weather. Wednesday was the eleventh consecutive day of rain, which broke all previous Weather Bureau records. The Massachusetts Department of Commerce index of industrial activity in Massachusetts for March was nine-tenths of 1 per cent above the figure for the same month a year ago.

AFTER a century of comparative obscurity, Sacajawea, the Shoshone Indian girl who served as guide and interpreter to Lewis and Clark, is the subject of intensive historical interest. This story of her life, based on facts established by two independent investigations, gives an account of her famous journey to the Pacific and her later years.

ONE of the most enigmatic figures in the crowded pantheon of British heroes is Charles George Gordon. His boyishness masking the fervor of a fanatic, his endless energy driving him through life at a trot, his blue eyes blazing with an almost unearthly light, he baffled and maddened statesmen and diplomats by his tactlessness and his colossal cheek.

THIS novel about the Great Trek is a dark horse in the South African literary sweepstakes, which has already drawn the biggest field in years. The author, a young Englishwoman, paid a long visit to South Africa some years ago and appears to have fallen completely under its spell.
MANILA, May 15 (AP) -- President Ramon Magsaysay scored a major political victory last night by thwarting a Congressional move to amend the Philippines Constitution or adopt a new one.
KINGS POINT, L. I., May 15 -- St. John's University defeated Fordham University, 93-46, in a track and field meet on Roosevelt Field at the United States Merchant Marine Academy today.

OF all the perennials available for the garden and herbaceous border, few are more adaptable than the modern hemerocallis or daylily. The term modern is applied for the reason that too many home owners and gardeners may be unfamiliar with the daylilies in their current form.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., May 15 -- A fraternity house carnival that began with a co-ed beauty contest ended with a burst of gunfire early today in which one University of North Carolina student was killed and two wounded.

LANDOVER, Md., May 15 (UP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias posted her highest round in three days -- a 77 -- today at Prince Georges, but the Babe's 224 score for fifty-four holes was three shots ahead of her nearest competitor in the $5,000 National Capital open.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Transplant seedlings of annual flowers to the places where they are to bloom outdoors. Immediately thereafter water and, if it is sunny or windy, protect with newspaper or burlap for a day or two. A cloudy or drizzly day is best for transplanting or for thinning the seedlings sown directly outdoors.

On Dec. 13, 1577, Francis Drake, secretly financed by Elizabeth I and with her secret consent to raid Spanish holdings in the Pacific, set sail from Plymouth with five ships. Nearly three years later -- Sept. 26, 1580 -- Drake's flagship, The Golden Hind, "very richly fraught with gold, silver, silk, pearls and precious stones," dropped anchor in Plymouth.
New products and improvements on old ones are being pushed by many farm equipment manufacturers in an attempt to counter their 15 per cent decline in sales last year.

THE opening pages of this book read like a horror tale. Jim Marugg lay choking to death and dying of thirst. His limbs were useless. Masked figures held him tight to a table. They slit his throat, injected a tube into it. Then they lifted, tied, clamped and twisted his nose.
LONDON, May 15 -- There was a great deal more than affection and loyalty behind the tumultuous welcome her subjects gave Queen Elizabeth II today when she returned from her world tour.
VIENNA, May 15 -- A Czechoslovak Socialist, who fled to the West while Deputy Premier under the Communists, apparently has returned to Czechoslovakia.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 15 -- three-run outburst in the top the eighth provided the margin of victory as Navy topped Princeton, 4 -- 2, in an Eastern League baseball game today on University Field. The triumph put the Middies a full game in first place, with the Tigers dropping to second in the league.
Thousands of New Yorkers thronged yesterday to nine warships of the Atlantic Fleet docked in this port to receive visitors over the week-end in observance of Armed Forces Day.
City Councilman Irving I. Schreckinger, who spends most of his time making laws, took a half-hour fling yesterday at enforcing them.

Outmaneuvred in the twenty-third game of his recent match with Vassily Smyslov for the world chess championship in Moscow, Mikhail Botvinnik, who retained his title with a 12-12 tie, was overtaken by the challenger at the eleventh hour.

Judging from the reports, the spontaneously joyous demonstration that greeted Queen Elizabeth upon her return to Great Britain after her long world tour was much more a personal demonstration of affection than merely acclaim for what she had accomplished. The Britons wanted their Queen back and they were outspokenly delighted that she was again at home.

IN the enormous, twenty-four- foot high concrete building here which is his studio, Jacques Lipchitz is busy these days cleaning and polishing the sculptures which will be shown in the retrospective exhibition of his work opening on Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art.
Robert R. Young won an important decision yesterday in his fight to win control of the New York Central Railroad.

THE evident eagerness of audiences to have a look at "Executive Suite," the M-G-M film about big business, now showing on the Music Hall's screen, attests to the public's interest in the doings of big business men.

INTER-CITY travel by helicopter is spreading from Florida to New York. Last winter National Airlines began carrying passengers by helicopter between Miami and West Palm Beach, and last week Mohawk Airlines announced it would start regular passenger service here with its new Sikorsky on June 7.

BERLIN, May 15 -- Armed Forces Day was celebrated 100 miles behind the Iron Curtain today as the United States Sixth Infantry Regiment paraded before 45,000 Berliners and some of the top military commanders in Europe.
ROSLYN, L. I., May 15 -- A tour of fourteen historic houses ranging in antiquity from Colonial to pre-Civil War days will be conducted here June 5 for the benefit of Bryant Library.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., May 15 -- Representatives of nine villages along the Mahwah and Ramapo Rivers in New York and New Jersey have asked the New York Water Power and Control Commission to raise these two streams to the highest, purity rating possible.

RALEIGH, N. C., May 15 -- As a result of the death May 12 of Senator Clyde R. Hoey, Gov. William B. Umstead of North Carolina will become the second American Governor in modern history to appoint two Senators during his term of office.

Down over this region there has been creeping, for nearly a decade, the shadow of communism.

HACKENSACK, N. J., May 15 -- The acquittal last night of Walter G. Winne, superseded prosecutor of Bergen County, of charges of misconduct brought activity by both Republicans and Democrats here today.

FOR the amateur photographer as for the professional on a busman's holiday, vacation is the time of the year really to let himself go. With leisure, freedom from pressing routine, opportunities for relaxation, for new experiences and undisturbed contemplation, vacations would seem to supply the perfect atmosphere for good pictures.

OMAHA, Neb. -- The city of Omaha, which considers itself the principal link between the Midwest's great corn and wheat belts, is in the midst of a year-long celebration of its 100th birthday. From now until late fall, pageants, music and art festivals, parades and sporting events will commemorate the growth of the city from a Missouri River ferry stop in 1854 to the present-day commercial center with a population of 251,000.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., May 15 -- In one of the most powerful batting demonstrations since the series between the schools was begun in 1898, Lawrenceville defeated The Hill School, 13 -- 5, today.

WASHINGTON -- Faced with an anticipated record number of visitors to parks, monuments and other Federal preserves this summer, the National Park Service is worried. Deterioration of some parks has gone on at such a rapid rate because of a lack of funds in recent years that officials feel they are taking chances by keeping certain areas open.

BONN, Germany, May 10 -- Productivity and production figures in the United States have stimulated national debate on the question of introducing the five-day week in West German industry and business. The six-day, forty-eight-hour week is nominally in force in this country.

NEWARK, May 15 -- Voters in his city are preparing for their fifth election since last May. It will be a run-off contest on June 15.

C. B. S. television is planning to adopt "summer-type" programming for its religious telecasts. Under the supervision of George Crothers, C. B. S. television manager of public affairs broadcasts, the usual formal dramatic type of show will be dropped for a more casual, "lighter" approach.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 15 -- Secretary of State Dulles declared today that "co-existence" between the free and Communist worlds was impossible while Soviet leaders sought to extend their power.
PARIS, May 15 (UP) -- Isabel Patino Goldsmith gave birth to a daughter, who is "doing well," just before she died of a cerebral hemmorhage last night, a Hartman Clinic spokesman said today.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 -- Jack McGrath, a perennial contender but never in a winner, smashed all qualifying records today to take over the coveted pole position in the Memorial Day 500-mile speedway auto race.

PITTSBURGH, May 15 (UP) -- Pittsburgh scored a pair of runs in the fifth inning and added four more in the eighth today to give right-hander Vernon Law a 6-1 decision over Milwaukee's Bob Buhl.

LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- Belgium's Phillipe Washer and Jackie Brichant, defending champions in the European Zone Davis Cup play, advanced to the third round today with a straight-set doubles victory over Yugoslavia's Joseph Pellada and Vladimir Petrovic.

TOKYO, May 15 -- A fleet of twenty-four Japanese pearling luggers, accompanied by a mother ship and a 200-ton armed patrol boat, will sail tomorrow to dive off the disputed reefs of northern Australia. The first post-war trip in search of mother of pearl was made last year.

Efforts to knock down stock prices last week proved futile. In a trading pattern not unlike that of the previous week, the market gave some ground under moderate selling pressure, then rallied briskly to erase losses and lift prices to a firm closing for the period.
Dr. Ernst Waldstein, an ophthalmologist who had practiced in this city for thirty years, died yesterday after a long illness in his home at 40 East Eighty-eighth Street. His age was 75.

Hiram College (Ohio) is conducting a survey of its methods, their results and the college's indicated course for the future. This self-analysis is being made by the faculty and administrative staff, under the direction of Dr. Edgar C. Cumings, dean of the college.

PARIS, May 15 -- Never since the dark days before the fall of France in 1940 has the political outlook in Paris been so grave. The fall of Dienbienphu has revealed a situation in which obstacles and dangers upon many sides have been increasing for months.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank of South Carolina pledged today Democratic help in pushing President Eisenhower's housing bill through the Senate.
WINDOW boxes always look handsome when they have just been filled with fresh, healthy plants. The flowering plants have buds and perhaps a blossom or two and the foliage kinds fairly glisten.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Unemployment in Pennsylvania is three times as high as it was at this time a year ago. The Pennsylvania Bureau of Employment Security reported that there were 253,600 continued claims for unemployment compensation on file in the week ended May 7.

Fred Ziegler's record-breaking javelin throw of 177 feet 3 inches enabled Hofstra College to capture the Collegiate Track Conference track and field championship yesterday at Baker Field. The winners had 47 points. Adelphi College, the defending titleholder, came in second with 42.

IN most households hash is as inevitable as leftovers. That It can be pleasant is indicated by the recipes appearing here. These come from culinary experts who show that flavorful eating can be the reason for serving hash as household thrift always has been.

FOR years Nick Dorn and his family walked hand in hand with a kind of anguished tenseness and brooding defeat. By scraping together all their savings they manage to buy a house on half of an island, and their dreams of happiness and security seem finally assured.

EVERY lawyer. knows, and anyone called upon to testify before a court or jury soon discovers (sometimes with dismay). that the witness stand is an exposed position. The unaccustomed scene, the stern visage of the judge, the piercing, watchful eyes of the twelve persons in the box. the lynx-like scrutiny of counsel, the hushed attention of the spectators, all contribute to the anxiety and discomfort of the citizen who has been summoned to give evidence.

HAMLIN, West Germany -- The setting for one of the Grimm Brothers' grim fairy tales and the home of the world's most publicized spinner of outlandish yarns lie a short distance from each other in this pleasant section of Lower Saxony.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 -- Virtually all candidates with organization support for nomination to state office appeared certain tonight of victory in Pennsylvania's primary elections Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (UP) -- Gran Hamner's single scored Richie Ashburn from third base in the seventh inning today to break a 4-4 tie and carry the Phils to a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs at Connie Mack Stadium.

NEW DELHI, India, May 15 -- Prime Minister Jawahrlal Nehru appears to be trying hard to make a world issue of India's exclusion from the international clemency board for Japanese war criminals. The Indian leader's irritation, expressed publicly today for the third time this week, seems to stem in large part from a sense of injured dignity, in addition to his opinion of the legal questions involved.
The quiet controversy among members of the Open Market Committee, disclosed in the Federal Reserve System's last annual report, continues unabated.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Vacation and holiday pay concessions, along with health and welfare benefits costing railroads an estimated $150,000,000 annually for 1,000,000 of their workers. were recommended to President Eisenhower today.

In the interest of accuracy may I point out that in the feature picturing the arrival of spring -- "And Suddenly It's Spring" (April 25) -- the scenes are in Fairfax County, not Arlington County, Va., as your introduction stated.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 15 -- Department store business is holding steady and the dollar volume is running about even with a year ago. Prominent in the stores' activity is the drive for charge account business. The average credit sale, merchants say, is three to four times greater than the average cash transaction.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 15 -- Cornelius (Corny) Shields, the 1952 North American sailing champion, made his first start of the summer season today and, with his green-hulled International sloop, Aileen, won the second of the races for the Sparkman Trophy.

IN 1873 Jim Norton and his cousin Earl go to Montana Territory to visit their Uncle Henry, a prospector. In the Pioneer Mountains, Jim's discovery of rich silver deposits sets off a stampede of miners. The Johnny Cake Mine, named for Jim's favorite type of bread, is developed, and the camp of Silver Hill springs up.
The American Foundation for Allergic Diseases announced last week the establishment of a ten-man council to foster the training of allergy specialists.
GENEVA, May 15 -- The economy of Communist-China has been seriously hurt by the United States trade embargo.
Three more men were denied yesterday the right to work at Roosevelt Raceway because of alleged or suspected association with William C. De Koning Sr., convicted labor extortionist.

Native Dancer gave weight -- and a beating -- to eight other horses in Belmont Park's Metropolitan Handicap yesterday. The mile run was a five-alarm thriller.

Implants of small bits of tissue of human placenta in victims of rheumatoid arthritis has resulted in "major improvement" in sixteen out of thirty-five patients, or nearly 50 per cent of the cases. Three of these patients had been wholly incapacitated for one to twenty-one years.

Carl Erskine shut out the Cards with two hits yesterday, 1 -- 0. Brooklyn scored in the second inning on a two-base error and Billy Cox' single. KARACHI, Pakistan, May 15 -- More than ninety persons were killed and 250 injured today in a riot between rival labor groups at the Adamjee jute mills in Narayanganj in East Pakistan. The clash grew out of an argument between two laborers in the yard of the mill last night.
Mrs. Jesse Asinof will be installed on Tuesday as president of the New York Women's Division of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver.

The weather was cold in New York City this week, with intermittent rain. Temperatures averaged about 6 degrees below normal. Last year in the same week the weather was generally good and temperatures were 6 degrees above normal.

A new orientation course for freshmen, "The Individual and the College," has been approved by the Dartmouth College faculty. It will be offered for the first time in the 1954-55 academic year. WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Senator Harry Flood Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, raised two new issues today in his investigation of the housing situation.

M. Benson has announced.

ARLES, France -- To most foreigners the South of France automatically calls to mind the Riviera, but there is more to the South than a coastline lapped by the gentle waters of the Mediterranean. MEXICO CITY, May 15 -- A series of new economic measures was placed before the Mexican people today. The proposals, according to President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, were aimed at protecting the purchasing power of Mexico's poorer classes and developing the national economy.

BACH: Partita in E minor; Sonata No. 3 in E; Sonata in G minor; Isaac Stern, violinist, and Alexander Zakin, pianist (Columbia). Energetic, rhythmic, tonally gratifying fiddling. Of the three works, the E major Sonata is frequently heard; the others are rarities, and not particularly exciting ones.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I. -- Long Island is a fish with its nose nudging Manhattan and a forked tail pointed by the lighthouses at Montauk Point and Orient Point. The eastern portion is beyond comfortable commuting range, but it can be reached from New York City by rail or car in three hours or so, and by air in about half an hour from La Guardia or Teterboro.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr.'s request this week for new powers to deal with spies and saboteurs in defense facilities reflected the Eisenhower Administration's persistent concern with problems of internal security.

Members of the Standardbred Owners Association met yesterday and agreed not to enter horses in races at Roosevelt Raceway until the announced schedule of purses has been revised upward. The initial meeting of a four-month season at the Westbury (L. I.) track is scheduled to open a week from tomorrow.

THE annual contest for photographs of dogs was announced last week by the Gaines Dog Research Center. There will be a first prize of $500 in cash, a second prize of $250 and a third award of $100. The competition, which has been held for several years, has become one of the leading attractions in the contest field and has helped to bring to notice some promising talent.

Ten new members of the executive committee of For America were chosen at a meeting of the organizing committee yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel. For America was formed in Chicago May 7 as a nonpartisan organization to promote peace and "Americanism" and oppose "super - internationalism, interventionism, one-worldism and communism."

SPANISH music is becoming increasingly available to American record-buyers and in the last few months this particular branch of the repertory has been enriched by the release of six more zarzuelas not previously recorded.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 15 -- Sixty riders are expeeted to take part in a motorcycle reliability test run in Suffolk County tomorrow as part of a series of tests set up by the Suffolk Motorcycle Club, which has been designated a Courier Corps under the Suffolk Civil Defense program.

POTSDAM, N. Y., May 15 -- One of the most ambitious musical projects ever undertaken by a college group will take place tomorrow on the campus of Potsdam State Teachers College as the highlight of the school's twenty-third annual Festival of the Arts.

IN his new novel Norman Lewis, already well known for his admirable travel book, "A Dragon Apparent," has set himself the task of examining the wound created in the East by the combined impact of industrialization and Marx.

CHICAGO, May 15 (AP) -- A Texas local of the International Typographical Union has been threatened with expulsion unless it drops an injunction petition against the union president, Woodruff Randolph, a union source said today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 15 -- Gordon Clapp, whose term as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority expires Tuesday, assailed today cost-plus contracts for private supply of electricity to the Atomic Energy Commission.
United States troops and their leaders throughout the world observed Armed Forces Day yesterday with parades, speeches and displays of the latest weapons.

SHELBY, N. C., May 15 (UP) -- Senator Clyde Roark Hoey, Democrat of North Carolina, was buried today in the frocked coat and winged collar that symbolized a bygone era of flowery Senate oratory and courtly manners.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP) -- The Dartmouth eight came from behind to win the Dad Vail Trophy for small colleges on the Schuylkill river today, beating a record field in the annual event.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 15 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower visited their Gettysburg farm today. They were pleased to find that work was going along rapidly on restoration of the 170-year-old house to which they plan to retire some day.

INTRODUCING a new volume in the Yale Series of Younger Poets ("An Armada of Thirty Whales," by Daniel G. Hoffman), W. H. Auden asked himself what seemed to him a silly question. "Is there going to be a revival of 'Nature' poetry, and, if so, how will it differ from nature poetry in the past?"

THE one peculiar contribution of America to education at the university level has been the Class Reunion. Men who have studied abroad report that they do not have such things on the other side and that the annual appearance of companies of fantastically garbed business men in the same age group at Bologna, Oxford or the Sorbonne would create astonishment in those ancient institutions and produce expressions of official repugnance toward such goings on.

Valuable portraits by American eighteenth - century artists and furniture of that period were sold at auction yesterday. They were from the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Luke Vincent Lockwood, noted collectors, formerly residents of Greenwich, Conn.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 15 -- Land-locked Paraguay celebrated Wednesday the formal start of ship service between this capital, which is near the heart of the continent, and European ports.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's war which the Army appeared this week to be broadening into a struggle with the Eisenhower administration as a whole.

A GROUP of twenty-eight American film workers, headed by stars Stewart Granger, Grace Kelly and Paul Douglas, have returned to California after another of the foreign location excursions which Hollywood has been making in the past several years in the effort to bring new and unusual backgrounds to its motion pictures.

DYLAN THOMAS' "Under Milk Wood," which has been performed here three times, has just been published by New Directions. To people devoted to the theatre this is a notable event for three reasons: notable for the originality of the form in which the play is written, notable in its own right as vigorous writing and hearty characterization, notable for the contrast it makes with Thornton Wilder's "Our Town."
GENEVA, May 15 -- The evacuation of the wounded from Dienbienphu has again become a Geneva conference problem.

Henry W. Cook latched on to a good job in shoe manufacturing, the field he knew best back in 1904. At 81 he's still doing very well as president and principal owner of the A. E. Nettleton Company, manufacturers of men's shoes for seventy-five years.

OPTIMISM over the improvement in industrial production is tinged with caution. The possibility of a seasonal slump which normally can be expected in the summer months is not being overlooked by the business community.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 -- The unending influx, legal and illegal, of Mexican workers into the southwestern United States now proceeding at a rate of more than a million a year, was the focus of extraordinary attention on two fronts this week.
DETROIT, May 15 -- The cooling-off job the Yankees set out to do here Thursday night was completed today, as the champions defeated the Tigers, 7 -- 5, for a clean sweep of the three-game set.

WHEN Foch was an instructor at the Ecole de Guerre before 1914, he was a devoted, almost uncritical admirer of Napoleon. Much later, he confessed that his admiration had been considerably modified, not because he had victoriously commanded a much bigger army than Napoleon ever did, but because as the Commander in Chief of a "coalition" army he had learned how much easier was the task of the leader of a unified, national force.

Dr. Paul H. Settlage, Associate Professor of Anatomy, and George P. Bogumill, research assistant in the University of Wisconsin, put permanent windows in the skulls of monkeys. A small disk of bone is removed from the skull and a piece of transparent plastic substituted.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 -- The ultra-conservative Taft-Republican forces of the Midwest this week suffered a heavy blow in Indiana.

FOLLOWING up his selection of "Younger European Painters" with the present exhibition, "Young American Painters," James Johnson Sweeney, director of the Guggenheim Museum, has provided two of the most provocative events of the season in New York.

CHICAGO -- The purpose of a movie is to record continuous action, bringing to life a planned or spontaneous story in motion about a cinematically interesting incident or event. The movie camera therefore is designed to photograph scenes or incidents in the normal rhythm and flow of real life rather than segmented pictures, as in still photography.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 15 -- Paul Kravitz of Christopher Columbus High in the Bronx ran the 100-yard dash in 0:09.9 today, the fastest time of his career. Jim Watson of Ramsey, N. J., the defending titleholder, was fifth in the eighth annual Englewood Memorial invitation track and field championships in Winton J. Stadium today.

THE arrival in New York the other day of a white terrier-like Italian truffle-hound reminded Americans that this country possesses, hidden in its democratic soil, varieties of that aristocratic edible fungus whose delicate, faintly revolting flavor has caused gourmets since antiquity to drool.

AFRICA, in a very special sense, is both the hero and the villain of this brilliant, disturbing novel. This is the same corner that served Gerald Hanley so well in his first work of fiction, "The Consul at Sunset." It is a corner few tourists have heard of, a sun-weary enclave passed over by the Haggards and the Hemingways.

CHESHIRE, Conn., May 15 -- Senator Prescott S. Bush declared today that "the time has come when, if it is to retain its self-respect, the Senate must expedite work on a code of fair procedure for investigations and adopt such a code at the first opportunity."

LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries' officers were still throwing hand grenades as Communist-led Vietminh troops stormed into his underground command post at Dienbienphu May 7, the Peiping radio said tonight.

IN the mid-May garden azaleas, wistaria, lilacs and, where rains have not scattered petals, prized tree peonies hold court. Add to this an array of early Carolina rhododendron, double pink English hawthorn, late crabapples and a few persevering dogwood, and the week's wait for the iris siege is more than tolerable.

Louis Rosenberg, former department store advertising executive and sports writer for the old Globe, died Friday night after a long illness at the age of 73. His home was at 188-02A Seventy-first Crescent, Fresh Meadows, Queens.

BLEEDING Kansas was the portal to the Civil War. In forcing open the territorial question there in 1854, Stephen Douglas may have focused his eyes on the Presidency, but the chain of events he set in motion had by 1860 foreclosed the possibility of realizing his ambition.

Air Transport Facts and Figures, just issued by the Air Transport Association, discloses that both in the national and international fields our air carriers set all-time traffic records in 1953. They had a gain of 14 per cent in number of passengers and 16 per cent in passenger miles over the preceding year, flying 31 1/2 million passengers more than 18 billion passenger miles.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The struggle for and over bipartisanship is, next to the military crisis in Asia, perhaps the most important fact of life in Washington today.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Navy won the sprint championship of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges for the third successive year today.

DALLAS, Way 15 -- Chilly weather and heavy rains that blanketed much of the Southwest during the last week brightened farm and ranch prospects and general business considerably. One Dallas banker termed the drought-breaking rains, heaviest in Dallas since 1949, "better than a new oil field."

ONE of the prize-winning films of the recent Cannes festival is the problem picture of the moment here. It was entered at Cannes as a British film (entitled "Knave of Hearts"), which it technically is, though the producer, Paul Graetz, is a German-American, and the director and the star are Frenchmen -- Rene Clement and Gerard Philipe.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 15 (AP) -- Emperor Haile Selassie announced today in an interview that some of the best uranium ore in the world had been discovered in his remote East African realm.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 15 -- To many people who live in the western sections of the Missouri Basin, the most important man in President Eisenhower's Cabinet is Douglas McKay, the Secretary of the Interior. Mr. McKay is responsible for the administration and development of water and hydroelectrical resources, and these two items, in many of these areas, represent the difference between prosperity and bankruptcy.
Two policemen killed two civilians yesterday after alleged assaults by the victims. The shootings were separate incidents.
When Jacques Cartier sailed up the St. Lawrence River in 1535 he was looking for and thought he had found a short westward water route from Europe to China.

THE hospitable spirit for May continues as more garden tours are scheduled for the week. On Thursday several well-known gardens in Greenwich, Conn., and Purchase, N. Y., will be open to the public for the benefit of the Patient's Welfare Fund of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.

IT is flattering that Evelyn Eaton found the historical note in my novel "The Last Love of Camille" so useful in lending authority to her review. I should have been grateful as well as flattered if she had read the book with the same acquisitive attention, for then she would not have misinterpreted my purpose, particularly in my portrayal of Liszt.

St. John's University clinched at least a tie for the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference title by downing City College, 3 to 1, yesterday at Babe Ruth Field in the Bronx. It was the Redmen's ninth victory in ten league games, while C. C. N. Y., the defending champion, is resting in the second division with a 3-and-6 record.

VOLUNTARY sacrifice comes hard to children. To Catherine, who had spent most of her twelve years in an orphanage, it came even harder, but the clop-clop of 5-year-old Peter's deformed foot stirred the girl's protective instinct.

The $250,000 grant Princeton University has received from the Carnegie Corporation will be used in large part to underwrite the preliminary operating expenses of a new program of studies in the humanities, according to President Harold W. Dodds. A fund of $7,000,000 is now sought to put the program on a permanent basis.

NOT intended for scholars or students, "George Washington's America" is for the wider audience of general readers. Drawing primarily on Washington's "Diaries" and his voluminous "Writings" completely edited by John C. Fitzpatrick, Douglas S. Freeman's five published volumes of biography, William S. Baker's "Itinerary" and "Washington After the Revolution," as well as a wealth of anecdotes true and false, John Tebbel sets out to show Washington as the most indefatigable traveler in the young nation.
Despite drought and Federal controls, the nation's farmers this year again may produce a wheat surplus.

How do pigeons and other birds find their way home? Until recently the answer was believed to be keen vision and a good memory. Students of animal behavior are beginning to accept the hypothesis that sun navigation plays a large part in homing as well as in long-distance migration.

WHITE PLAINS -- A significant decision was reached last week on the controversial Cross Westchester Expressway, a twelve-mile connection to link the New York Thruway with the projected New England Thruway between Elmsford and Rye.

PICKERING announces a "reengineered" version of its Model 190 pickup arm. The new arm is said to require less mounting space while fully retaining its low vertical mass, static and dynamic balance, lack of arm resonance and low friction.

TURKEY has had a State opera since 1949 and its Government has appropriated $3,300,000 for the building of a new opera house in Istanbul Besides, this the Government gives $750,000 a year to the State Theatre and Opera in Ankara.

WE are, in these two books, confronted with an embarrassment of riches concerning the rise and development of the typewriter, the men who made it and the young girls who use it as a prime instrument of business.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- The ten-month-old strike of 1,500 hat workers of the American Federation of Labor in South Norwalk, Conn., got financial support today from the president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
New York University scored twice in the ninth inning after trailing all the way to hand Columbia its eighth straight loss, 5 -- 4, yesterday at Baker Field.

The strike that halted Pittsburgh's buses and trolleys last week was too far away from Times Square to cause New Yorkers much worry. But it served as a reminder that Michael J. Quill, union overlord of the metropolitan subway system, was likely to dish up a fresh helping of transit jitters for Gotham's underground travelers this week.

WHAT might be called "Operation Musik" began March 30 when five American musicians -- singers Carol Brice and Barbara Gibson, harmonica soloist John Sebastian, and pianists Jorge Bolet and Constance Keene -- embarked from Idlewild airport on a four-week visit to West Germany.

Secretary of Labor Mitchell has stated that job prospects for this year's high school and college graduates are not so bright as they were last year. In fact, the 1954 graduate "will more than likely have to compete with his classmates in seeking a job." Employers are more demanding and are placing greater stress on training and experience.
PARIS, May 15 -- In Strasbourg this week the acts of the first and only supranational power in Europe have been subjected to the close scrutiny of national legislative representatives.

BALTIMORE, May 15 (AP) -- Queen Hopeful, the Hasty House Farm's brilliant 3-year-old filly, turned in a courageous race today at Pimlico to win the $20,000 - added Black - Eyed Susan Stakes by a half-length from Warren P. Griffiths' Gweny G.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 15 -- New York University defeated Rutgers and Temple in track today. The Violets scored 72 1/2 points to 56 for Temple and 44 1/2 for Rutgers.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 15 -- President Eisenhower's visit to this city Tuesday will underscore political developments both old and new in the history of this Piedmont section of the South.
Manufacturers of straw hats will make hay while the sun shines, if their estimate of a 15 to 30 per cent increase in sales this year proves true.

Philip Wylie's "The Lure That Hooks Fishermen" (April 18) is not only a very pleasant essay but one containing much sound angling doctrine. With all its major points [that fishing is the individual "betting himself against the universe,'' a quest for happiness alone, a finding of one's inner self -- Editor] I am in enthusiastic agreement.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The United States Government today placed full responsibility for the Korean War upon the Soviet Union.
WACO, Tex., May 15 (AP) -- The Southwest Conference today voted against expansion, deciding not to issue invitations to Texas Tech, Oklahoma and the University of Houston to become, members.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 15 -- The Netherlands Government has withdrawn its ultimatum warning the European Coal and Steel Community to take action against cartels, it was reported here today.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 15 -- There were two winners of the Delaware Valley Stakes at Garden State Park today for the simple reason that the six-furlong event was run in two divisions.

One of the worst menaces in a complex society is the thoughtless person who turns in a false alarm. Janet, a quick -tempered and rash youngster of 16, is having a difficult time adjusting herself to an adult world.

* * * When I first arrived in the United States I was completely put off attempting to visit the theatre by the harrowing reports I heard and read about the difficulties to be encountered when one tried to get seats. My love of the theatre eventually overcoming my repugnance of inviting rebuff, I found the box-office personnel in no way rude, disagreeable or, in fact, any different from their counterparts in London.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15 -- Ken MacKenzie of Yale defeated Harvard today, 5 -- 2, with the assistance of Bob Davis.
BERLIN, May 11 -- East Germany is invading Western markets in an effort to achieve in one year a foreign trade expansion of more than 35 per cent.
Dr. Francis H. Horn was inaugurated yesterday as the fourth president of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn and took the opportunity to deliver a militant defense of vocational education.

DURING the past season I have become increasingly aware of the general carelessness which seems to obtain in the execution of scenery for Broadway productions. Whereas most settings are competently, often excellently designed and lighted, joints, hinges and "dutchmen" have become ever more apparent in "flats";

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 15 -- John Cowles, president of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, proposed here today that Congress re-examine its position on foreign policy to make possible firmer solidarity with potential allies in the free world.

LONDON, May 15 -- Borne on a high tide of affectionate loyalty, Queen Elizabeth returned up London River to her capital today. The Queen landed at Westminster Pier at 3:25 P. M. to complete a tour that had covered 50,000 miles, girdled the globe and strengthened the ties that bind Commonwealth and Empire.
Special training is needed by key personnel in American industry to meet the return to "more normal competitive business," a survey of executives in 2,450 companies has found.
COME spring, as the poet puts it, and Nature paints the landscape with a lavish hand. A somewhat mixed blessing, by the way, since this frequently compels the home owner to do some painting himself.
United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc., will be the beneficiary of a moonlight sail on Tuesday night aboard the S. S. Peter Stuyvesant.

REMEMBERED for "Private Worlds" and "The Mortal Storm." Phyllis Bottome is again at her impeccable best in this tautly written novel about life in a T. B. sanatorium in Switzerland. Descriptively or dramatically, her touch is one of assurance.
The importance of foreign trade as a creator of employment and the city's need to maintain the Port of New York's leadership in world commerce will be strongly emphasized this week.

IN the course of issuing collections of the less frequently heard works of our top-flight composers of show tunes, Walden Records has now gotten around to Rodgers and Hart. The resultant twelve-inch LP, Rodgers and Hart, is the company's best effort to date not alone because of the material, which is consistently delightful, but also because the producers have finally worked out a really satisfactory method of presentation.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 15 -- Although outhit, ten to eight, Army defeated Manhattan, 6 to 3, at Doubleday Field today. It was the cadets' tenth victory against three setbacks.

SYRACUSE, May 15 (UP) -- Carmen Basilio, the No. 1 welterweight contender, piled up an early lead and then fought off a late rally by Italo Scortichini to gain a unanimous decision over the rugged Italian tonight in a ten-round bout.

NOVARA, Italy, May 15 (AP) -- The visit of a high American Military Police officer here caused speculation today that the United States may be planning further investigation of the wartime slaying of Maj. William Holohan of New York.

NEW YORK'S 35,000 taxi-drivers are famous as over-the-shoulder Solomons, expert on any subject from the Geneva Four-Power meeting to the fourth race at Jamaica. Surely on one subject -- the city's traffic problem -- they should be wiser and more experienced than almost anybody else. But --

Bowne Gardens, an apartment house development on the west side of Bowne Street, between Thi,@y-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets, in Flushing, Queens, has been purchased, by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York, Jerome Dansker, president.
The cost of transporting a ton of general cargo by railway from Cleveland to East Coast ports is $13.

Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia will arrive in New York May 25 for his first visit to this country, it was announced yesterday by Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the city's Commission for Public Events. The monarch will be aboard the liner United States, which will dock at Pier 86, Forty-seventh Street and North River.

MELBOURNE, May 16 -- Australia has agreed to join with other countries in an examination of the possibility of a system of collective defense for Southeast Asia and the Western Pacific. Australia's Chiefs of Staff also have made an assessment of the military problems involved.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Trading on the Board of Trade here slowed down considerably last week, compared to the previous week, but total purchases of grain and soybean futures were much larger than a year ago.

On May 2 your correspondent gave a picture of the Portuguese system in Angola (Portuguese West Africa), which is said to be "proof against unrest and the rise of African nationalism.'' We read that Africans, when they are considered "civilized" by the Portuguese authorities, are admitted to "European status," and that by 1950 the number of civilized Africans had reached 30,112.

The Giants and Braves spent a long afternoon getting in each other's way yesterday to no purpose. They split a five-and-a-half hour double-header before the largest Polo Grounds gathering of the season, a crowd of 39,588.

The Long Island Jewish Hospital was dedicated yesterday by Governor Dewey. Constructed at a cost of $7,000,000, it will operate as a voluntary, nonsectarian institution serving Queens, Nassau and Western Suffolk Counties.

CHICAGO, May 16 (UP) -- Bob Porterfield pitched a five-hit, 3-to-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox today to give the Washington Senators a double-header split before 25,515 fans. The defeat knocked Chicago out of first place in the American League race.

The Interracial Fellowship Chorus, which performed Haydn's forty-minute "Pauken" Mass at its concert last year, presented an even more ambitious Haydn Mass last night at Town Hall at its spring concert for 1954 -- the St. Cecilia Mass, which takes an hour and twelve minutes to sing.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 16 -- The divot-diggers were relaxing between the rounds of the Palm Beach golf tournament at the Meadow Brook Club, exchanging small talk and tall tales.

Evil never can rule the world, however much it may seem to prosper, because "Christ has conquered Satan for all eternity," the Rev. Michael J. Deacy declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He is a member of the cathedral clergy.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Government scientists operating the nation's most unusual fertilizer plant expect to make one ton of atomic fertilizer this year at a cost of $25,000.
National Airlines, Inc., achieved record operating revenues in both the quarter and nine months ended March 31, according to the report issued for publication today.

A dual responsibility has been entrusted to Cyril Ritchard in the forthcoming musical version of "Peter Pan." Mr. Ritchard will be seen as Captain Hook and Mr. Darling. The part of Mrs. Darling has gone to Margalo Gillmore.

The 27,000-deadweight-ton tanker Flying -A- Delaware, third in a four-ship construction program of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, will be launched on Wednesday by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Newport News, Va. The vessel will be sponsored by Mrs. D. T. Staples of San Francisco, wife of the president of the oil company.

WILIMANTIC, Conn., May 16 -- Best in show at the annual fixture of the Windham County Kennel Club today went to an Irish setter, Ch. Laurel Ridge Star Rocket, owned by Merritt Swartz of Canton, Mass., and handled by Art Baines. Arnold J. Brock of Scarsdale judged. The best was the first for Star Rocket, who led the breed at Westminster.
CHICAGO, May 16 -- Following drastic declines early last week, the apparent culmination of the liquidating process in the grain and soybean markets, a steadier tone appeared.

Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin" was performed by the Manhattan Opera Guild before a large and responsive gathering Saturday night at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. This initial production of the guild commemorated the seventy-fifth anniversary of the world premiere of the masterpiece.

An agreement that is expected to lead to the thirty-five-hour week in Southern dress factories has been made by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L. The pact is with a company that has factories in both the South and the North.
ROME, May 16 -- Pope Pius XII called today for "Christian optimism" in the face of the "real dangers" of the nuclear age.

Playing heads-up soccer, the New York Americans captured the National Challenge Cup by halting the Kutis Football Club of St. Louis, 2 -- 0, in the final at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- George V. Allen, United States Ambassador to India, said today that the future of Asia might be determined by a contest between communism in China and democracy in India.

Renewed strength developed in the British pound sterling following the announcement on Thursday of the lowering of the bank rate by the Bank of England. Canadian dollar moved erratically in a market that lacked any large turnover in business.
CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP) -- Mike Garcia pitched a one-hitter today as the Cleveland Indians blanked the Philadelphia Athletics, 6 -- 0, in the second game of a double-header.

PARIS, May 16 -- Gen. Paul Ely's mission to Indo-China, on which the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff started by air from Paris early this evening, is to lay the basis for concrete proposals to be made to the United States and other French allies.
CHICAGO, May 16 -- One of the country's smaller unions began here today an experiment in labor democracy that may provide a pattern for other unions.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 16 -- The Netherlands will liberalize 92 per cent of dollar imports at the end of May.
PITTSBURGH, May 16 (AP) -- After taking a 12-3 bombardment the Pirates, sparked by Frankie Thomas' two-run homer, came back to defeat the Cubs in the second game, 5 -- 1.
A low bid of $1,956,800, or $273,200 under the advance estimate of $2,230,000 for replacing City Hall's crumbling stonework, has been received by the Department of Public Works.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 16 -- Sam Snead sealed his bid for the Palm Beach golf tourney honors today with a 65 at the Meadow Brook Club course. It was the lowest round of the four-day event and helped Snead gain a winning score of 62 points.
MANILA, May 16 -- Ramon Magsaysay is facing the most critical political fight since he assumed the Presidency.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Senator Homer Ferguson, chairman of the Republican Policy Committee in the Senate, indicated tonight that he would reject any campaign help from Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 16 -- Cornelius (Corny) Shields, winning for the second successive afternoon with his screen-hulled Aileen, captured the Sparkman Trophy at the Larchmont Yacht Club today.
Mayor Wagner was urged yesterday to have the city make a serious study of the upper Hudson River as a better future water source than the Delaware River.

Apropos the Congressional investigation of a Congressional investigation, at the moment claiming the absorbed attention of the American people, your correspondent of May 6, Marie C. Redmond, cites history in support of her contention that the importance of the Washington hearing should not be minimized.

BALTIMORE, May 16 -- A crowd of 46,796 fans at Memorial Stadium today saw Don Larsen, after seven and two-third innings of hitless, runless pitching, beat the Yankees, 6 -- 2, in the second game of a double-header and gain a split for the Orioles.
The city's high school teachers are scheduled to cease their voluntary extracurricular activities, beginning today.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, May 2 -- The Gulf Oil Corporation has been prospecting on its southern Portuguese Mozambique concession for six years. But to date it has not found much evidence of oil.

PARIS, May 16 -- The French Government is not expected to ask the National Assembly Tuesday to set a date for debate on the European army treaty unless there is a sudden agreement with West Germany in the Saar dispute.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- Senator Home Ferguson credited the Air Force today "with saving a half billion dollars a year" by reducing its manpower requirements.
GENEVA, May 16 -- The United States and Britain will start the decisive fourth week of the Far Eastern conference tomorrow more divided than when the negotiations began.
ALBANY, May 16 -- A series of changes in the top engineering posts of state highway agencies is being made.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 -- William A. Burkett, director of the State Department of Employ-[ ment, reported yesterday an 8I per cent decline in unemployment insurance claims in April, along! with a steady level of manufac-{ ituring employment from iViarcl

Senator Herbert H. Lehman charged yesterday that the Eisenhower Administration had tried to "sell" the American people the slogan of retaliation as the total basis of United States defense. He said the effort had been "a total fraud."
Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, principal director of the United Nations Department of Trusteeship, received the 1954 Williamsburg Settlement Gold Medal last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

In full view of the American people Counsel Jenkins has frequently advised the subcommittee on questions of law and rules of evidence. With rare exceptions his pronouncements are accepted as from Jehovah. I cannot understand why someone among the many lawyers at the hearings does not pull him up short when he is obviously wrong.

Alec the cat joins Smokey the bear and Sparky the dog today. Alec, "Smart Alec," is the symbol of the spring safety drive of the Advertising Council. His winking, grinning portrait, with his name on a turtleneck sweater, is going to the nation's newspapers with a kit of safety ads, like those for the council's campaigns against fires with Smokey and Sparky.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 16 -- An albino robin returned today to the back garden apple tree where for two seasons it has been trying to make friends with the conventionally colored members of the species.

Two inexpensive punches, suitable for June weddings and other festivities for which the budget is limited, were served at a recent tasting. They were among several summer drinks developed by the Paul Masson Vineyards of Saratoga, Calif., and introduced to food writers and the trade by the proprietor, Fromm Sichel, at its local office.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The eyes of the country will be on the Supreme Court, more intently than at any time in recent years, when it returns to the bench tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The only jeep ride remaining in the United States diplomatic courier service stopped last week after about ten years.

DETROIT, May 16 (AP) -- Boston's Ted Williams returned to regular action today and smashed out eight hits in nine at-bats -- including a pair of towering home runs -- in a double-header against the Tigers.

Last summer the Twentieth Century Fund published, within the space of about a fortnight, two volumes, each devoted to a different area of economics and each of them panoramic in its approach to its subject.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- A tiring Mrs. Babe Zaharias hung on gamely today to beat Betty Jameson by a stroke for the $1,000 first prize at the National Capital women's open golf tournament.
Recommendations aimed at establishing labor peace on the city-owned transit system are scheduled to be submitted to Mayor Wagner today.

Your May 7 article about inadequate and misleading direction markers on local highways covers a matter that I have repeatedly brought to the attention of the authorities. Driving about the metropolitan area one finds so many glaring instances of such neglect that it is practically impossible to list them.

GENEVA, May 16 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Under Secretary of State, called in Bao Dai, Chief of State of Vietnam, this afternoon to confirm United States assurances that it would not agree to a partition of Vietnam.

MRS. HETHERINGTON is sure, now, that Perriette is dead. Perriette, a sparrow, built her nests and raised her broods every spring for ten years on the Hetheringtons' third-floor fire escape at 3050 Grand Concourse in the Bronx.

STORRS, Conn., May 16 -- No matter how rapidly times and customs change, it is the individual family, not "society," that is expected to "adjust" to the new ways, members of the National Council on Family Relations held here this week-end.
MANILA, Monday, May 17 -- Luis Taruc, Communist leader of the Hukbalahap rebels, surrendered to the Government today.

Apropos your editorial of May 7, the McCarthy-Army hearings will be justified if they remove McCarthyism from the political scene. After seeing the Senator in action, it is my opinion that McCarthyism is on its way out.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., May 16 (UP) -- University of North Carolina officials refused today to talk about student drinking after one student was killed and two wounded at an all-night party in a fraternity house.

Opposition to the city's announced intention of establishing an ultra-high-frequency television station was expressed here over the week end. The proposal was described as "utterly fantastic in the light of the city's current financial picture."

PEABODY, Mass., May 16 (AP) -- A dam burst under the weight of waters accumulated durinng two weeks of rain tonight and flooded more than a square mile of this leather-making city of 23,000 -- causing damage estimated in the millions.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Washington is receiving increasing protests from the Virgin Islands about the new organic law Congress is writing for the area.

President Eisenhower will be host next week to one of the world's most distinctive chiefs of state, a man whose rise to leadership in a small and distant country twenty-four years ago commanded extraordinary attention everywhere.

International affairs today are so complex and encompass so many problems that it is all too easy to lose sight of the forest because of the trees. The need for perspective on our over-all situation is well met, fortunately, in the thoughtful address delivered Saturday by Secretary of State Dulles at Williamsburg.
A life of "loving the things God commands" and "desiring the things He promises" was described by Canon Edward N. West yesterday as the only path to true joy.

Perhaps the less-mentioned parleys now being held at Geneva may ultimately turn out to be of even greater significance than the much-publicized political conferences on Indo-China. These concern commercial exchanges between the free and the Marxist worlds.

Freed from restrictions imposed thirty-four years ago, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa is planning to invest some of the funds of the New York City Employes Retirement System in gilt-edged bonds of private corporations, including utility companies.

The First Boston Corporation is publishing today its biennial survey of the market for Government securities. The book contains 133 pages of text, charts and tables relating to market yields, Federal Reserve System operations, Treasury debt management and Government tax operations.

NEW DELHI, India, May 16 -- A large-scale exodus of United States technicians working on a dam in India's Punjab State indicated today that the Indian Government might be carrying out a policy to remove Americans from strategic projects near the Pakistan border.

The large English residence of! Victor H. Hansen at Beach Avenue and Brook Street in the Rye Neck section of Mamaroneek, in Westchester County, has been purchased by Dr. Norbert Sandlers of N.g. It is Lyons Falls, on a plot 100 by 100 feet and was sold through Peter C. Doern Jr., Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Congressional efforts leading toward a possible compromise between the House and Senate on Alaska and Hawaii statehood get under way this week. The House of Representatives Rules Committee will meet on Wednesday to consider a request to send a Senate-approved measure combining statehood for both Territories to a conference of Senate and House representatives.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UP) -- Dr. Gabriel Hauge, one of President Eisenhower's top economic advisers, said today the downward trend of business in recent months had been "slowed down to a stop."

HANOI, Vietnam, May 16 -- A two-man French military delegation left here by air today en route to Dienbienphu. The officers will try to straighten out with the Vietminh command the hitch in the agreement for the evacuation of the French Union wounded now in the Communist-led rebels' hands at that fallen bastion.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 16 -- A wounded evacuee said today that Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries and Lieut. Genevieve de Galard-Terraube were alive and unwounded when Communist-led Vietminh insurgents captured Dienbienphu.

Yesterday was the warmest day of the year and the first sunny Sunday of the month. It brought to New Yorkers a welcome respite from the rain, fog, cloudiness, snow and chilling temperatures that have characterized spring so far.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The United States Information Agency announced tonight a "world-wide offensive" in the "cold war" to expose the "spurious intellectual and ideological appeals" of communism.
LOS ANGELES, May 16 -- Arson investigators started an' inquiry today into a fire that burned through the parish house of the St. Thomas Episcopal Church on Hollywood Boulevard early today.
MEXICO CITY, May 13 -- A series of seemingly unrelated incidents has convinced an increasing number of United States residents here that anti-Yankeeism is on the rise in Mexico to an alarming degree.
