Roman Catholic and Protestant scholarship winners have a higher college acceptance rate than Jewish scholarship winners, according to an American Jewish Congress survey of the experiences of 1,347 high school graduates in New York State.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 16 -- The Cabinet met in a three-hour emergency session tonight and ordered an investigation into the nation's worst labor riot yesterday.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 13 -- The Eisenhower Administration still has a selling job to do in the Pacific Northwest on its partnership program for developing hydroelectric power.
Charles F. Pfiefer has been named direct sales manager of the Olin film division of the Ecusta Paper Corporation, a subsidiary of Olin Industries, Inc.
The Treasury has announced that it is relaxing the rules under which gold may be acquired and used in this country.

The public interest is directly affected by jurisdictional disputes among labor unions and by raids between rival unions. It should therefore be a source of general satisfaction that the American Federation of Labor's Executive Council and the heads of 100 affiliated unions have approved a plan for peaceful settlement of disputes among their members.

MOSCOW, May 16 -- Outside some of the twenty-four Moscow movie houses which today are showing the newest Soviet film hit, "Anna on His Neck," there were queues half a block and a block long. Not in years has there been such a sensational instant success of a Moscow-made movie as has been scored by this sensitive memory-book of old Russia based on one of Chekhov's best-known and most popular short stories.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 -- "The Quality of Mercy," a new novel by Robert Carson, has been acquired for filming by Wayne-Fellows Productions, which has just turned over its latest picture, "The High and the Mighty," to Warner Brothers for distribution.
ALPINE, N. J., May 16 - All you need if you want to have a country home built quickly at the end of a private road is the land, the material and 200 Seabees.

Prices of cotton futures showed steady improvement last week. At the close Friday active contracts were up 65 cents to $2.60 a bale, or 13 to 52 points, compared with the previous week's close. The most marked gains were in the October contract. The July contract showed no net change on the week.
Cigarette advertising came in for attack on two fronts yesterday.

ALBANY, May 16 (AP) -- The executive committee of the Affiliated Young Democrats of New York State said today that it would ask Bernard M. Baruch to bring about a meeting of minds on fiscal policies between Governor Dewey and Mayor Wagner of New York.

An apartment house site on the southwest corner of Second Avenue and East Seventieth Street has been purchased by Ira Berne, who expects to start work immediately on a sixteen-story building. The property fronts about 125 feet on Second Avenue and eighty feet on Seventieth Street.

ON various occasions the complaint has been made in this space that American novelist neglect the most representative aspect of American life -- which is business. Most of the few novels about business and business men are written by authors with little or no first-hand knowledge of their subject, and most are caustically satirical.

Found buried the other day in a yearly report of one of the 423 agencies helped by the Greater New York Fund was a notation that 187 expectant fathers had been taught how to care for their babies in organized classes.

The finance industry believes the decline in consumer installment debt since January of this year to be a sound development, according to the latest monthly study by the Standard Factors Corporation of Chicago.
YONKERS, May 16 -- Ted Corbitt of the New York Pioneer Club celebrated his son's third birthday today by winning the national Amateur Athletic Union marathon.

NEW DELHI, India, May 16 -- Parliamentary debate following Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's foreign affairs speech in the lower house yesterday served to underscore the fact that many Indians differed with his rationalization of the Chinese Communist conquest of Tibet.
CHICAGO, May 16 -- The business recession has hit the women's clothing industry so hard that one-sixth of the welfare funds covering the industry's 440,000 unionized workers are operating in the red.
MOSCOW, May 16 -- A leading Soviet polar scientist asserted today that great ice floes of the Arctic do not, as asserted by some foreign scientists, make "reliable floating fortresses."
A Brooklyn neighborhood was terrorized yesterday when a 3-year-old boy's foot became frozen to the accelerator of his father's automobile. A pedestrian was seriously injured.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Since April 22, when Harold E. Stassen, Director of the Foreign Operations Administration, appealed for recruits to fill sixty-five technical assistance jobs in Indo-China, there have been some 700 responses.

I very much appreciate your courtesy in reporting the statement made to the annual meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Council for Judaism on May 11, in which the council took issue with the Israeli Prime Minister. Moshe Sharett, on the question of the relationship to Israel of Jews who are citizens of other nations.
MADRID, May 16 -- The Roman Catholic magazine Ecclesia in its current issue sharply criticizes Government censorship of the Spanish press. It urges adoption of a law allowing freedom of information.

PLANS of the City of New York to establish a television station on the pattern of its fine noncommercial radio outlet. WNYC, face extremely formidable difficulties that cannot be ignored. Political considerations aside, the wisdom of going ahead with the outlet, at least at this time, should receive serious study.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said yesterday that he was not a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor but would run if nominated by the Democratic State Convention.

That was quite an exciting afternoon sailing enthusiasts at Portsmouth Priory went through with their craft, the Apache.

One investment house is advancing a proposal intended to give more stability to the market prices of Treasury securities and at the same time help the Federal Reserve System fulfill its responsibilities more effectively.

THIS week's most important art event is the large retrospective show, opening on Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art, of sculpture by Jacques Lipchitz. Other large shows include, today, a group of paintings at the Argent Galleries by Massachusetts members of the National Association of Women Artists and, opening tomorrow at The Stable Gallery, an exhibition of work by contemporary Belgian painters.

LONDON, May 16 -- After several weeks of disappointment at the absence of a reduction in the bank rate, the City was beginning to make up its mind that any such move would be postponed until later in the year. LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) -- The Cafe New York in Budapest, rendezvous of Hungary's intellectuals and elite for more than fifty years, is in business again -- under Communist management.
PITTSBURGH, May 16 -- In the last few weeks the steel industry has been operating at a slightly higher rate than had been estimated. This is taken in some quarters to mean that an uptrend has set in.
Their bicycle lights shining eerily in the pre-dawn darkness, a strong-legged platoon of young men and women rode out yesterday to greet the sunrise over the city.

A new group has been organized here to buy the Fifth Avenue Coach Company from the Omnibus Corporation of Chicago for $5,000,000. The price could go to $6,350,000 if options in the agreement were exercised.

WATERTOWN, Mass., May 16 -- Development of a new, lightweight titanium alloy possessing the toughness of high-strength steel was announced today by the Watertown Arsenal Laboratory, an Army center for titanium research.

A plan for rehabilitation of the Long Island Rail Road was filed May 7 with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Long Island Association, a regional chamber of commerce, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, May 16 -- Britons gave thanks today for the safe return of a Queen who had traveled farther than any other reigning sovereign and had been absent from this island longer than any for 200 years.

CAIRO, May 16 -- Mohammed Zafrulla Khan, Pakistan's Foreign Minister, left for Karachi tonight after an unheralded two-day visit. He reportedly sought to explain to the Egyptian Government of Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser the motives of Pakistan in entering into defensive arrangements with Turkey and the West.

Under the sponsorship of the Conservation Foundation, Ronald Press has published an absorbing study by Luna B. Leopold and Thomas Maddock Jr. on "The Flood Control Controversy." Three thousand persons strolled about the Manhattan College campus yesterday. They sat in on model classes and inspected engineering and scientific laboratories that buzzed and bubbled under student direction -- all part of the college's nineteenth annual Campus Day exercises.

Two American - flag Liberty ships highlighted last week's charter market activity. One brought a $44,500 monthly rate for intercoastal work, representing a substantial improvement over the $39,000 of late April.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Senator William F. Knowland said today that the United States might be obliged to commit sea and air forces in Indo-China to prevent the Communists from overrunning all of Southeast Asia.

CANBERRA, Australia, Monday, May 17 (AP) -- The Royal Commission investigating charges of Soviet spying in Australia was told today a Communist fifth column was built up in the country along the same pattern as that uncovered in Canada.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 16 -- Dr. K. C. Wu, former Governor of Formosa, said today that he had received a cablegram from his 16-year-old son, %Vu Hsui-huang,I confirming that the latter had received a passport from the Chinese Nationalist Government in Talpel, Formosa. Dr. Wu hadI charged that the boy was being held as a hostage by the Chiang Kai-shek Government.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 6 (Reuters) -- Ceylon's Commerce Minister, R. G. Senenayake, said today his country would invite an atomic "Pearl Harbor" if she offered herself as a military base.

More than 140 young string players performed in the chamber music festival presented yesterday afternoon and evening in the Salon de Musique of the Barbizon Plaza Hotel by the Violin, Viola and Violoncello Teachers Guild.

Wiser counsels have prevailed in Manila in the sidetracking of the move to rewrite the Philippine Constitution and cut down the powers of the President. This is the wrong time and the wrong President for any such experiment.
MADRID, May 16 (Reuters) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, using the pen name Macaulay, published today a blistering denunciation of British rule of Gibraltar.
Jean Morel, who conducted the N. B. C. television performance of "Pelleas et Melisande" earlier in the season, yesterday led the N. B. C. Symphony in its regular 6:30 to 7:30 broadcast.
PARIS, May 26 (Reuters) -- Knitwear is gaining importance in the fashion picture here.
VIENNA, May 17 -- The Soviet Union warned Austria today to put an end to "hostile and subversive intrigues" against the Soviet occupation forces, or Soviet authorities would do it themselves.

TORONTO, May 17 (Canadian Press) -- Ventures, Ltd., holding company with interests in many mining companies across Canada and in other parts of the world, had net profit in 1953 of $868,357, excluding items in special surplus, compared with $987,986 in 1952.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 17 -- Indonesia is considering an invitation to India and Burma to join her in signing a nonaggression pact with Communist China.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- An increase in imports by the United States will enable other nations to buy American exports and will contribute to prosperity, Charles P. Taft, president of the Committee for a National Trade Policy, said today.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- The American Federation of Labor accused President Eisenhower today of reneging on a campaign pledge to mobolize Government and industry "at the first sign of any approaching recession."

BALTIMORE, May 17 (AP) -- Robert S. Lyle's Correlation still has his habit of staggering to his left near the finish, but Jockey Willie Shoemaker managed to hold him straight enough today to win a thrilling stretch duel from Hasty Road in the Preakness Prep.

We applaud with enthusiasm the "New York Summer Festival 1954," which is described as a "voluntary project to welcome the world to our town." An enterprise of cooperation that crosses the whole business life of the community, it is organized on the sound and stimulating theory that there need be no summer slump in stores, hotels, restaurants and theatres if everybody will pitch in and determine otherwise.

Vast strides have been made in the improvement of Negro education in the South since World War II. Teachers' salaries have been raised, new buildings constructed, professional standards improved and better supervision provided.

The price of cocoa fluctuated sharply yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Opening quotations were up the 1-cent a pound limit in most months but tumbled the 1 cent limit in all positions before the close. All months closed 100 points lower except the spot May options which have no limit and were off 140 points.
PITTSBURGH, May 17 (AP) -- Hank Sauer's grand slam homer capped a seven-run fifth inning, and the Chicago Cubs added three more in the ninth to defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates today, 10 -- 6.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., May 17 -- Public interest in the historic preservation of Bedford House, the old John Jay house on Route 22 north of here, has become so widespread that owners said today they hoped to set a day soon for public inspection. The event would be for the benefit of some public cause.

The Upholsterers' International Union (A. F. L.) is marking out a path for trade unions that should long ago have been explored. It is creating an independent "court" to pass on appeals from union disciplinary orders. Any member sought to be punished by the union will have a right to put his case before an impartial nine-man board of jurists, educators and former public officials.
A "disgruntled labor force and a hapless management" were held jointly responsible yesterday for the labor chaos that threatens catastrophe for the city-owned transit system.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Supreme Court's ruling in the school segregation cases pointed up the road Negroes have traveled for more than a century toward freedom and equality.

MONTROSE, N. Y., May 17 -- It was a gloomy day at Boscobel today -- perhaps the gloomiest for the pillared mansion since Staats Morris Dyckman built it in 1795 as a gay social center of the Hudson Valley.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today decided a lower Federal court, acting on request of the National Labor Relations Board, might cancel a state court injunction banning secondary picketing by a union.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Supreme Court's action today banning segregation in public schools found the District of Columbia well prepared to make the transition to integrated schooling.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Twice during the long progress of the school segregation cases toward a decision, the United States Supreme Court has heard oral arguments and pored over ponderous briefs.

YONKERS, N. Y., May 17 -- Two drivers were spilled from their sulkies in the first race at Yonkers Raceway tonight when their horses slipped and fell. Fred Bradbury, pilot of Brown Bud, suffered a possible fracture of the right heel.

An 81-year-old Brooklyn landlord who has persisted in refusing to provide adequate heat, hot water and electricity to his tenant was sent yesterday for observation to the Kings County Hospital by thee justices of the Court of Special Sessions.

CROTONVILLE, N. Y., May 17 -- Plans of the General Electric Company to establish a management research center here for executives of all its plants and offices were made public today when rezoning proceedings were discussed with local officials.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -- Norman P. Mason, acting Federal Housing Administration Commissioner, today sent Congress specific recommendations for overhauling the Federal housing law to prevent further abuses in Government-insured F. H. A. programs.

The dispatch from Moscow published in The New York Times of May 15 ("Tarzan Postcards Sold Under Counter in Soviet") reports a Russian newspaper complaint that "while Tarzan was a big seller, no postcards of works by such Soviet artists as Repin, Surikov, Levitan or Shishkin were to be had in the Yakutsk market."

The sale of auto use tax stamps is now under way at offices of the City Collector. The stickers must be affixed to the windows of New York City cars by June 15.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 -- Stewards department employes on West Coast ships have rejected two unions.

If an artist thinks he can work somewhere for nothing, it's hard to keep him working for a fee in his studio, in the opinion of Shim Grudin, who is manager of the big annual event of Artists Equity Association's New York chapter, the Spring Fantasia masquerade ball.

Details of the twenty-fourth and final game of the world chess championship match between Mikhail Botvinnik and Vassily Smyslov in Moscow were received here yesterday by airmail. The match ended in a short draw and the series resulted in a 12-12 tie.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Although it settled the main problem of constitutionality today, the Supreme Court will have another round in the issue of school segregation when it returns in October for the 1954-1955 term.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Scientists at the National Bureau of Standards, the Government's central laboratory, have developed a device for making good pictures out of bad ones.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued quiet yesterday. Prices were 3 points lower to 11 points higher than on Friday, with new crop months showing relatively greater strength than July.

Bernard M. Baruch, in the last of three lectures at the City College School of Business and Public Administration, 17 Lexington Avenue, submitted yesterday seven "adjustments" in national defense strategy.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Five of the nine Supreme Court Justices who today outlawed race segregation in public schools were appointees of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Violla Rubber, producer and former summer stock operator, is busy these days arranging the production of a recently acquired comedy, "Put Them All Together," by Theodore Hirsh and Jeannette Patton.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 17 -- A noted British physician warned here tonight against pinning too much hope on drugs to solve the tuberculosis problem. He cited the "amazing power" of germs to develop drug resistant strains.
Within an hour after the Supreme Court decision on school segregation yesterday afternoon, the Voice of America sent a news broadcast by shortwave to Eastern Europe.

Business is brisk at the New York Stationery Show. Attendance during the first two days was heavier than expected. There were 1,435 registered on Sunday, compared with 1,063 last year. Yesterday's registration reached about 850, the same figure as on the second day of the 1953 show. More important, merchants are writing orders instead of just shopping.
DUBLIN, May 17 -- Thousands of Dubliners turned out tonight for this city's traditional pre-election rallies, but orators found it hard to stimulate enthusiasm.

A joint advertising program to point up the merits of wool is planned by the Wool Bureau and Wool, Inc., two trade groups. Executives of New York buying offices heard an outline of the consumer advertising planned for the fiber and of the retail promotional programs behind it at a luncheon at the Statler Hotel yesterday at which the Wool Bureau was host.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Two New York girls were among the first prize winners in the American Automobile Association's tenth annual National Safety Poster Contest. The awards were announced here today. There were more than 7,000 entries.

ALBANY, May 17 (UP) -- Mary Donlon, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board, said today that insurance companies would not be assessed this year for the special fund for disability benefits.

The Board of Higher Education was unable to elect a chairman at its annual meeting last night at Hunter College.

TRENTON, May 17 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered a lawyer who once had represented top Bergen County racketeers to divulge to a grand jury the substance of confidential talks with those clients.
LONDON, May 17 -- Sir Winston Churchill used golden words in moving today the House of Commons' "humble address" of welcome home to Queen Elizabeth from her six-month tour of the Commonwealth.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 17 -- The election of Mrs. Morris Hadley of New York to the board of trustees of Vassar College was announced yesterday.
ATHENS, May 17 -- A political crisis is brewing within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over the project for a military alliance among Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Few cases presented to the Supreme Court have marshaled such a formidable array of legal talent as the segregation issue.
GENEVA, May 17 -- A director of the International Monetary Fund has proposed that the organization be liquidated.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, last night called upon longshoremen to repudiate the old racket-tainted International Longshoremen's Association in the May 26 waterfront election.

GENEVA, May 17 -- Vietnam is not yet ready to promise participation in a Southeast Asian defense alliance, a source close to the Vietnamese delegation said tonight.
LONDON, May 17 -- The Foreign and Economic Affairs Ministers of Argentina arrived tonight for trade talks with the British Government. The 1949 agreement expires shortly.

TORONTO, Ont., May 17 (AP) -- Mayor Allan Lamport says a Chicago man's proposal to build Toronto a $75,000,000, fifty-story City Hall is impractical and would be ruinous to downtown real estate values. But Mr. Lamport said he would at least study any "feasible" new plan submitted to him.

AMONG the problems facing collectors of modern paintings and sculpture are those of where and how to display it, and the current exhibition at Grand Central Moderns, titled "An Architect's Choice," attempts to answer this. The architects, Allen and Edwin Kramer, have designed interiors for which they find place for works of art they consider appropriate to their settings.

Miss Henrietta Additon, superintendent of the Westfield State Farm, a female reformatory at Bedford Hills, told the Temporary State Commission on the Courts yesterday that poor planning for court handling of cases had resulted in the commitment of girls who should be cared for by the community.

Besides the seventeen states and the District of Columbia where segregation has been mandatory, four states -- Kansas, Arizona, New Mexico and Wyoming -- have laws permitting segregation on a local option basis.

The Supreme Court's action in breaking up its decision against school segregation -- leaving details of carrying out the program until later -- received the endorsement yesterday of a number of legal experts.
Sociological benefits to the nation at large as outgrowths of the Supreme Court's decision banning school segregation were envisioned throughout the country yesterday.

Orlando Zulueta of Havana, the second ranked lightweight contender, gained a unanimous decision over Percy Bassett, Philadelphia featherweight, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Supreme Court not only upheld Justice John M. Harlan's famous dictum that "the Constitution is colorblind" today but also based its decision on the primacy of the general welfare.

The Giants and Dodgers will resume action today with both clubs scheduled to play night games. Leo Durocher's Giants open a two-game series with the Cardinals at the Polo Grounds, while the Brooks begin a two- game set with the Chicago Cubs at Ebbets Field.

LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- Great Britain and Italy clinched their second-round series in the European zone Davis Cup play today, completing the line-up of eight nations for the third round to be contested in June.
Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, urged New Yorkers yesterday to contribute books to the annual spring drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 17 -- Five teams tied at 63 in the annual handicap pro-amateur golf tournament at the Piping Rock Club today. The event is staged for the benefit of the North Country Community Hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals drove Robin Roberts to cover tonight with an assortment of extra-base hits, including three homers. The barrage resulted in an 8-to-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. Earlier, the Phillies put a Sunday's suspended second game into the record books with an 8-to-4 triumph.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that industrial production held steady in April at the same level as in March. The preliminary seasonally adjusted index stood at 123 per cent of the 1947-1949 average.
LONDON, May 17 (UP) -- Following is Prime Minister Churchill's statement to the House of Commons today:
Frank Costello was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge John F. X. McGohey to five years in jail and fined $30,000 for income tax evasion.

ACCORDING to the old moss-backs, who can foresee the quality of the fishing from the color of seaweed and the growth-rings on oysters, good bluefishing off Carolina's outer banks in May is a certain "sign" of excellent bluefishing off New Jersey and New York in July.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 17 -- The Supreme Court's anti-segregation ruling today made Dr. Ralph J. Bunche a happy man but it almost cost him $35.
Ground was broken yesterday for the new home of The Brooklyn Eagle at 122-44 Johnson Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -- A magazine survey reported today that any candidate backed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, in this fall's election probably would lose more votes than he would gain.

The net earnings of the Creole Petroleum Corporation, Venezuelan affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), were about $61,800,000 in the first quarter of this year, A. T. Proud-fit, president, told stockholders at their meeting here yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 17 (UP) -- Marshall M. Smith, Deputy Assistant Commerce Secretary, said today the restrictions on trade with Communist nations might be changed "to permit a larger volume of trade in peaceful goods."
CHICAGO, May 17 -- A large part of Kansas had heavy rains today, and as a result there was free selling of wheat futures here. Prices declined as much as 2 cents a bushel.

AUSTIN, Tex., May -1 -- While Gov. Allan Shivers stressed in a statement today that it would "take years" for Texas to comply with the Supreme Court decision, there seemed no indication that this state would not ultimately comply.

ATLANTA, May 17 -- The most bitter and violent reaction throughout the South came from Georgia. Governor Talmadge declared that the Supreme Court had reduced the Constitution to a "mere scrap of paper."

George V. Allen, Ambassador to India, said here yesterday that disagreements should not be permitted to destroy United States-Indian amity or curtail the Administration's $104,500,000 program of economic aid and technical assistance.

PAT McDONALD went through life with a song in his heart, a twinkle in his eye and laughter ever bubbling within him. He won his first national championship in 1907 and his last one in 1933. In all that time and in the many years that followed he gained the love and admiration of all who knew him. And he became one of the best beloved figures in all New York.

The people who make containers for milk soon may have to take a close look at their production runs because housewives in several cities want larger-than-quart sizes, according to the Glass Container Manufacturers Institute.

Mayor Wagner was one of twelve persons honored yesterday by the People's Civic and Welfare Association for outstanding contributions to the city's well-being. The awards were announced at a luncheon in the Harlem Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, 180 West 135th Street.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 17 -- Teagle Hall, the $2,000,000 sports building for men at Cornell University, was dedicated today. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Clark Teagle of Byram, Conn., the donors, laid the cornerstone.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 17 -- The South's reaction to the Supreme Court's decision outlawing racial segregation in public schools appeared to be tempered considerably today.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The most diligent search of the records of the Supreme Court will probably not disclose more than a couple of instances, perhaps not those, in which the high tribunal disposed so simply and briefly of an issue of such magnitude as racial segregation in the public schools.
The decision of the Supreme Court banning segregation in the Southern public schools received the acclaim of prominent historians yesterday.

Two possible new revenue sources were definitely eliminated yesterday by the Board of Estimate in executive session. They were the proposed 1-cent-a-glass tax on beer and the suggestion to extend metered parking into hours now "free."

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., May 17 -- The host club team of Toney Tiso and brother Jim tied with Mike Turnesa and John Buckley of the Knollwood Country Club today for best-ball honors in the season's first pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association. The teams registered 66s over the Vernon Hills course.
R. Bruce Snow, general counsel of the American Investment Company of Illinois, has been elected a director.
LONDON, May 17 -- Britain will seek effective international guarantees for any peace settlement in Indo-China, Prime Minister Churchill declared today.

The thirtieth annual report of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., released yesterday, shows a continuation in 1953 of the steady growth that the utility has experienced in Latin America since World War II.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17 -- Nunnally Johnson, the writer-producer-director, is planning a drama of life inside a state prison which he will make for Twentieth Century-Fox sometime in the summer. He has not had sufficient time to write the screen play or to title the institutional subject.

From the very outset of the fight between Senator McCarthy and the Eisenhower Administration this newspaper has maintained that the fundamental issue is an attempt on the part of the Legislative branch in the person of Mr. McCarthy to encroach upon the Executive branch, in complete disregard of the historic and constitutional division of powers that is basic to the American system of government.
A thoroughgoing nation-wide study of the single-salary issue in the schools, particularly its effect on city high school teachers, was promised yesterday by city school officials.

The regional blood program of the American Red Cross announced yesterday that 919 pints of blood had been donated in this area last Friday. Of this total, 590 pints were given by employes of Liebmann Breweries, Inc., in the Bronx.
NEW DELHI, India, Tuesday, May 18 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru proposed today an immediate "union" of North and South Korea, leaving details for full unification to be worked out later.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 17 -- The outlook for improved nutrition throughout the world has taken on "a more cheerful aspect" according to a report issued here today by the Food and Agriculture Organization.

"Gone With the Wind" will make its fifth official appearance hereabouts since its original premiere at the Capitol in December, 1939, when it starts a revival stand at Loew's State on May 29. The David O. Selznick Technicolor production released by M-G-M with Vivien Leigh, Clark Gable, Olivia de Havilland and the late Leslie Howard among its principals, will be shown on a wide screen with stereophonic sound.
Bids will be opened today on three new security issues totaling $92,975,000.

Senator A. Willis Robertson of Virginia has introduced a bill in the Senate known as S.3158 which will eliminate cumulative voting of shares of stock in the election of directors of national banks. This bill is presently before the Senate Banking Committee.
Hoacine Khalfi, Algerian lightweight, upset Sandy Saddler, featherweight champion, by gaining a split decision in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

As part of the welcome to Elizabeth II on her return from a most successful but a highly grueling j urney, a company of Savoyards might well give a special performance of "The Gondoliers." Then the Queen could hear:

Directors of the Beech Aircraft Corporation declared yesterday two special dividends of 25 cents each, payable to common stockholders on June 9 and July 9. The last previous payment was 25 cents in August, 1953.
Mrs. Harry Richman and Miss Shirley Woolf of Miami Beach, Fla., told the police that luggage containing jewelry and clothing valued at $24,945 was stolen from them last night.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, chairman of the Senate-House Atomic Energy Committee, suggested today that the Government be allowed to take out patents on peacetime, as well as military, uses of atomic energy.

SEOUL, Korea, May 17 -- The leader of the major Opposition party in South Korea charged today that the National Government's police were exerting "heavy pressure" against his party's candidates. The election will be held Thursday.

RANGOON, Burma, May 17 (Reuters) -- Drums, gongs and wailing conch shells signaled the opening today of the Buddhist Great Council meeting. It is the sixth held since the Buddha, founder of the oriental religion named after him, died 2,498 years ago.
Mayor Wagner proclaimed May 17 to 22 as World Trade Week yesterday at a ceremony in City Hall.
The Los Angeles City School District will open bids on June 1 on $30,000,000 of bonds. The offering will be dated July 1 and will mature from 1955 to 1979.

LIVERPOOL, May 17 (Reuters) -- An old market bell clanging tomorrow will be the signal for the reopening of Liverpool's famous seventy - two - year - old cotton exchange which was shut down thirteen years ago by the wartime British Government.

More than 2,500 persons responsible for furnishing the supplies necessary to keep the machinery in the nation's factories operating met yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. They represent an industry that does a business of $4,000,000,000 a year.
It will cost the seventeen Southern States many millions of dollars to adjust from a dual to a single system of public school education.

Only seventy horses were nominated yesterday for the first week of harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway. Normally more than 100 entries are needed to plan a single eight-race card. The Standardbred Owners Association has threatened to boycott the meeting, scheduled to start at Westbury next Monday, unless the purses are increased.

Two more books on Nazi Germany will be added to library shelves next month. Scheduled for June 14 by Viking Press is V-2," by Walter Dornberger. The author was a general in the German army and directed Peenebunde, the German experimental rocket station.

GUATEMALA, May 17 -- Foreign Minister Guillermo Toriello refused to comment tonight on the State Department announcement. He said that, to avoid misunderstandings, he would have to wait until he received an official communication from the Guatemalan Embassy in Washington.

Louis Stark had been a newspaper man for forty years, and with this newspaper since 1917. For nearly twenty years, beginning with the early days of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Administration, he worked in the Washington Bureau of The Times, and since 1951 he had been a valued and respected contributor to the editorial content of this page.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Federation of American Scientists voiced concern today over a proposal to make the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission its principal officer.
SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras, May 17 -- Cerveceria Hondurena, the largest brewery and bottling works in Honduras, was closed this morning by a strike of 400 workers.

Formation of the American Synthetic Rubber Corporation, with authorized capital of $6,600,000, was announced yesterday. The company, incorporated in Delaware, was organized to bid for one of the Government-owned synthetic factories that have been offered for sale to private industry.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had decreased slightly over the past week.
CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

Sprinkled through the list of 423 agencies helped by the Greater New York Fund in the five boroughs are scores of day nurseries, happy little havens where working mothers may leave their babies, during the workday, with a sense of security and, more important, within their means.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the letter from President Eisenhower and the memorandum from Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. concerning the White House's refusal today to permit certain testimony in the McCarthy-Army dispute:

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UP) -- Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat whip, urged President Eisenhower today to rebuke Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield for blaming the Indo-China crisis on the Democrats.

A police chase that assumed the aspects of a merry-go-round wound up at 10:20 o'clock last night in the wounding of a patrolman in the hand and the capture of a suspected hit-and-run automobile thief.

ROME, May 17 -- United States consulates in Italy have rented extra office space and put additional personnel to work to screen would-be immigrants more quickly.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., May 17 -- Dr. Ira Eisenstein, president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, denounced today the "growing tendency" to reduce all issues at home and abroad to a "simple black-or-white choice."

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 17 -- Readiness to comply with the Supreme Court's ruling was expressed by both the Governor and the head of the public school system in this state, where racial segregation has been gradually breaking down.
Aircraft, steel and issues associated with uranium mining led the stock market higher yesterday but rubbers fell and most other sections of the list were mixed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- Social agencies are growing increasingly dependent on public funds for the maintenance of their services, the fifty-sixth annual National Conference of Jewish Communal Service was told here today.
All city patrolmen were instructed yesterday to be on the lookout for discarded ice boxes, refrigerators and similar containers, which are becoming a growing hazard to the lives of children at play.

LONDON, May 17 -- A sharp setback in British government securities imparted a dull tone to most section of the Stock Exchange today. Declines in gilt-edge issues ranged up to seventeen shillings sixpense ($2.45) on 100 ($280).
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 17 -- Chilean leftist workers proved today that if they could not paralyze the country completely they could seriously cripple it with a general strike.

MANILA, Tuesday, May 18 -- The Justice Department announced today that Luis Taruc, surrendered Communist leader of the Hukbalahap rebels, would face trial soon here on charges of rebellion and conspiracy to commit murder.

Last week Governor Dewey stirred up a tempest in a coffee pot by asking New Yorkers to drink over-plentiful milk as a substitute for expensive coffee. Yesterday a speaker at a June Dairy Month luncheon in the Hampshire House advocated milk drinking for enjoyment, urging a return to the "old-fashioned gustatory pleasures of drinking tall glasses of cold milk."

The seventeen states and District of Columbia where school segregation has been required by law cover 40 per cent of the nation's public school enrollment. A total of 8,200,000 white children and 2,530,000 Negro children attend elementary and high schools in the segregated states.

JERUSALEM, May 17 -- Premier Moshe Sharett reiterated today Israel's opposition to United States arms aid for Iraq. The statement wound up the foreign affairs debate that has preoccupied the Knesset (parliament) since the start of its summer session a week ago.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17 (AP) -- Leaders of the airport industry hurled accusations of buck-passing, illegality and socialism at the Civil Aeronautics Board today for appealing to them for favored treatment for the nation's smaller airlines.

JERSEY CITY, May 17 -- George W. Rogers, 57 years old, a television repair man who in 1934 was hailed as a hero of the Morro Castle disaster, went on trial for murder today. He is charged with beating William L. Hummel, 83, and Mr. Hummel's daughter, Edith, 58, to death in Bayonne last June 19.

Brazen Brat, a 4-1 shot, persisted in challenging the favored Sunshine Nell all through the $10,160 Level Best Handicap that served as the main attraction at Belmont Park yesterday. This persistence paid off, for at the finish of the six-furlong sprint Brazen Brat was a neck in front of the choice with third place going to Winning Stride.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 17 -- The District Magistrate of Karachi today announced a ban, effective at midnight, on public meetings and processions of five or more persons. The ban was imposed because of "fear of Communist activity likely to disturb the peace" in this capital city.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby today opened the "East Coast migrant project" by calling on delegates from ten states to help better the health, education and welfare services of migrant farm children.
Commisioner of Correction Anna M. Kross charged yesterday that too many judges got their jobs because of "whom". not "what" they knew.
TOKYO, May 17 -- The Socialist parties announced today they intended to question Premier Shigeru Yoshida on the floor of the Diet about his proposed trip abroad next month.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Hope for a peaceful solution of problems raised by the Supreme Court's decision against segregation in public schools was voiced today by Representative Frank E. Smith, Democrat of Mississippi.

The Day Care Council was advised yesterday that city funds will be made available this year for five new day care centers. This was disclosed by Mrs. Randolph Guggenheimer, council chairman, in her annual report at a meeting of the organization at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
The Department of Welfare yesterday designated next week as Poppy Week. Only organizations licensed by the department will be permitted to sell poppies through volunteer workers.

With Navy's champions enjoying a rest after successfully defending their sprint crown on the Potomac, two rowing regattas will be held this week in the East and one in the Middle West.

PEABODY, Mass., May 17 -- This leather manufacturing city some twelve miles north of Boston added up an estimated $1,000,000 damage today from two floods in eighteen hours. The low-lying center of the city first was hit shortly after 5:30 P. M. yesterday when a mill pond dam two miles southwest of Peabody Square collapsed under the strain of a week-end downpour.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 17 (AP) -- Premier Adnan Menderes submitted his new Cabinet to President Celal Bayar today following the Democrat party's landslide victory in the May 2 general election.

ATHENS, May 17 -- Italian press allegations that Col. Gen. Koca Popovic, Yugoslav State Secretary for Foreign Affairs, had revealed the details of a proposed solution of the Trieste problem published in The New York Times of May 8 were denied today by C. L. Sulzberger, chief foreign correspondent of The Times and author of the dispatch.

LONDON, May 17 -- Surgical knowledge derived from the Korean battlefront was among the medical information exchanged at a joint meeting of the American College of Surgeons and British Royal College of Surgeons here today.

The Virginia Electric and Power Company sold $25,000,000 of 3 1/8 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 1984 in the public market yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 17 (AP) -- A mammoth plastic balloon, possibly the largest ever made, is to be launched in this area soon.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 17 -- Soviet espionage plans for Australia included an underground to operate in time of war.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 17 -- One-sixth of the population of the Western Hemisphere is made up of racially mixed stock. This estimate was given by Dr. Harry L. Governor Dewey, laying the cornerstone of the new Hospital for Special Surgery yesterday morning, commented that the "menace of socialized medicine which has hung over us so ominously in the past is, I think, receding."

EDMONTON, May 17 (Canadian Press) -- Shareholders of Alberta Consolidated Gas Utilities, Ltd., decided at their annual meeting to change the company name to Great Northern Gas Utilities, Ltd., it was announced today.
DETROIT, May 17 (AP) -- New car sales for 1954 reached the 2,000,000 mark today, Ward's Automotive Reports said in its current issue.

OTTAWA, 5lay 17 -- Canadian ports along the St. Lawrence Seaway on the Great Lakes, which it will open to ocean shipping, are planning extensive alterations and improvements.

COLUMBIA, S. C., May 17 -- Governor Byrnes said that he was shocked to learn that "the court has reversed itself." The Governor declared that time and again the Supreme Court has held that the doctrine of separate but equal school facilities was not violative of the Constitution.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 17 -- Eight small naval vessels supplied to the Soviet Union during World War II under the Lend-Lease program arrived in the Sea of Marmara today under Soviet escort preparatory to being turned over to United States authorities tomorrow.

DETROIT, May 17 (AP) -- Detroit's strategy of intentionally walking Ted Williams in the eighth inning backfired when Jackie Jensen, hitless in nine straight times at bat, followed with a three-run homer that gave the Boston Red Sox a 4-3 victory over the Tigers today.
The world's largest electric and gas utility, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., informed stockholders yesterday that business was good and should continue so this year.

MOSCOW, May 18 -- Three more changes in Ministries of Internal Affairs of Soviet Republics are reported by the provincial press. These bring the number of shifts in such posts to seven within the past fortnight.
Field Day at Hunter College became for the first time a competition for beauty as well as brawn yesterday when a parade of floats was staged on the Bronx campus.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today American should be thankful that they lived in a country of food surpluses.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -Pan American World Airways sought permission from the Civil Aeronautics Board today to fly its trans-Pacific planes by the short Great Circle Route to the Orient, used by Northwest Airlines.

The Chase National Bank received a "green light" from an Appellate Division justice yesterday to issue after 4 P. M. today a proxy for 800,000 shares of New York Central Railroad stock to two friends of Roebrt R. Young.

ALTHOUGH it may smack of Hamlet without the Dane, the Preakness Stakes will be run at historic Pimlico on Saturday. And kindly note the use of the adjective, historic, alongside of Pimlico. A turf writer would have his union card picked up if he didn't apply it, as unthinkable a situation as saying Belmont instead of beautiful Belmont.

Manhattan College topped City College, 7 to 6, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game yesterday at Babe Ruth Field in the Bronx. Three home runs were hit in the contest called at the end of eight innings because of a Park Department ruling that no inning may start after 6 P. M.

Lord Beveridge, author of the report that spelled out the British social security program in 1942, was one of the 1,495 passengers who arrived here yesterday on the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth. He will address the National Industrial Conference Board's annual meeting tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Tax-exempt foundations, regardless of what they do with their millions of dollars, are largely free from criticism by educators, a special House of Representatives investigating committee was told today.
JERUSALEM, May 18 -- All salaried physicians in Israel began a three-day strike for higher wages today. Government officials predicted that any rise would bring on inflation.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Samuel M. Brownell, United States Commissioner of Education said today that his office stood ready to help state education authorities as much as possible in school integration problems resulting from yesterday's Supreme Court decision.

LONDON, May 18 (Reuters) -- A wildcat strike of engineers and firemen, objecting to sleeping away from home between shifts, today crippled the rail network serving the western side of England. Extension of the unofficial strike to sympathizers at depots in other parts of the country hung in the balance.

Cocoa prices recovered practically all of Monday's losses on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. Prices opened easier on over-night selling orders and profit taking. By noon quotations were rising, influenced by dealer and manufacturer buying.

The Federal Reserve System's "easy money" policy will be continued during the coming months, according to August Iblefeld, president of the Savings Banks Trust Company. He spoke at the Savings Banks Officers Forum in the Astor Hotel last night.

Mrs. George J. Leness will give a tea this afternoon in her home at 1185 Park Avenue for mothers of the debutantes who will be presented at dinner parties before the Grosvenor Debutante Ball on Nov. 27 in the ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Leness heads the committee for the ball.
Social, religious and civic groups vied with each other here yesterday in hailing the decision of the United States Supreme court outlawing racial segregation in the public schools.

NEW DELHI, May 18 -- India has accepted proposals by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for a settlement of the canal water dispute with Pakistan, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru announced today in Parliament.

A Presidential campaign has just opened in Honduras, by no means the most advanced of the Central American states. Dominant in the immediate background is a strike involving 40,000 workers, including those of American fruit, tobacco and mining interests.
CinemaScope has lifted Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation out of the doldrums, Spyros Skouras, president, told shareholders at their annual meeting, held here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Bipartisan demands were voiced today for the resumption and prompt completion of the public hearings on the controversy between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 18 -Joseph Curran of New York, president of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., promised aid here today to the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union, A. F. L., "in whatever way it's practical to support them."
CLEVELAND, May 18 (AP) -- Al Rosen drove in three runs with two homers and a double tonight as the Cleveland Indians held on to their slim first-place lead by beating Boston, 6 -- 3.
After extending gains to the highest level for the current movement, stock prices yesterday eased under profit taking, and final quotations were only irregularly higher for the session.

One essential feature of Commissioner Adams' program for maximum effective use of his police force is the substitution of civilians, including women, as school-crossing guards, relieving uniformed patrolmen for other duties. Civilians have been so used and found satisfactory for twenty years elsewhere, and three hundred cities over the country now use them.
DUBLIN, May 18 -- Clear skies and sunny dispositions prevailed throughout Ireland today as the voters elected their new Dail (parliament).

A two-stroke marine Diesel engine, developed by the Burmeister Wain Company of Denmark, permitted a saving of 6 to 8 per cent in fuel oil in a two-year practical test, Knud Kalm, executive vice president of the concern, said yesterday.

Distinguished decorating adds glamour to a builder's development house that will open to the public next Sunday. The house, designed by Rudolph Matern, built by Emil Morton and decorated by Tommi Parzinger, is in Plainview, L. I.

The Senate's Army-McCarthy hearings, by adding even further to young people's current confusion about values, will "take their toll" in increased juvenile unrest and delinquency, James R. Dumpson, a specialist in work with children, predicted yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, May 18 -- Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru professed today to see a growing attitude of conciliation on Indo-China at the Geneva conference on Far Eastern affairs. He gave as an example the willingness of the Vietminh to consider an association of free Indo-Chinese with France in the French Union, declaring it was a "remarkable" development.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18 -The world's airlines flew more passengers in 1953 than ever before. They also had the best safety record in aeronautical history, it was reported today by the International Civil Aviation Organization.
The solution of the problem of juvenile delinquency and the rehabilitation of youthful offenders was said yesterday to be largely a matter of finding the money to do the job.

YONKERS, May 18 -- Two men were bruised, seven cases of milk were destroyed and the windows of a truck were shattered at 2:40 A. M. today in violence arising from a dispute between the Beverly Milk Company here and a labor union.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team matches were completed yesterday, with the Ridgewood Country Club retaining the New Jersey district title and Century winning in Westchester.

A team can't get anywhere giving away runs to the Cardinals. The high-scoring Redbirds make too many on their own. This lesson was driven home to the Giants last night. They made a present of four markers to the visitors in the second inning and wound up being humbled, 9 -- 3, before 19,053 disgruntled onlookers at the Polo Grounds.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 18 -- The Chinese Nationalist Air Force claimed today the sinking of a 1,500-ton Communist vessel, damage to another ship and probable damage to a MIG-15 in encounters with the Communists off Chekiang coast.

A fourteen-minute motion picture short subject made by Columbia University in connection with its bicentennial celebration was presented here yesterday at a press screening held at the Johnny Victor Theatre, 40 West Forty-ninth Street.
The Aluminum Company of America expects to borrow $100,000,000 in the public market next month to help complete a five- year expansion program and increase working capital.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Gordon R. Clapp departed from Government service today without a sound in the halls of government.

PITTSBURGH, May 18 (AP) -Walter S. Hallanan, president of the Plymouth Oil Company, said today that unless voluntary or compulsory action brings about a marked reduction in imports of crude oil, the domestic oil industry will be seriously injured.
Democratic leaders are seriously considering incorporating a plank favoring the legalization of bingo and similar petty gambling games into their state platform this fall.
CHICAGO, May 18 -- Soybeans fluctuated sharply while a sustained demand for wheat lifted prices to the highest levels in a week or more on the Board of Trade here today.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- The 33-ounce bat, which Yogi Berra has been swinging so successfully this season, accounted for another Yankee victory tonight. It was his line single to center, scoring Willie Miranda from second, with two away in the ninth, that gave the champions a 4-3 decision over the White Sox and moved Casey Stengel's club into second place.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 18 -- The Soviet Union returned to the United States today the first lend-lease naval vessels since 1951. The transfer operation brought Soviet and United States seamen together for more than three hours in the Sea of Marmara.
CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Yesterday was the day on which the French Government had promised, in return for recent additional American and British security guarantees, to set the date for an "immediate" parliamentary debate on the European Defense Community Treaty, signed two years ago this month.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., May 18 -- For the first time in the history of eastern Suffolk County organized baseball, a Negro team will play in the East End Baseball League, a semi-pro circuit, when the season opens next Sunday.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 18 (AP) -- Net earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company for the first quarter of 1954 were $12,297,275, up 24 per cent from $9,916,028 in the first quarter of 1953, the company announced today after a directors' meeting.

The year's work is the theme of two fashion shows this week. One, the thirtieth annual show of students in the Parsons School Fashion Design Department, was presented to afternoon and evening audiences yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., May 18 -- For the first time in more than 1,000 years a change in the traditional Jewish marriage contract has been approved. It requires the bride and groom to agree they will not seek divorce without consulting rabbinical authorities.

HANOI, May 18 (AP) -- As the French resumed their air strikes, a High Command spokesman said Vietminh units moving east from Dienbienphu were only about fifty miles from the southwestern rim of the Red River delta's defenses.

BALTIMORE, May 18 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon's triple drove in two of Washington's three runs in the sixth inning tonight as the Senators defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 3 -- 1, before 20,596 spectators. For most of the contest it was a tight pitching duel between the winner, Maury McDermott, and Bullet Bob Turley.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 18 -- Indonesian mine production of tin in concentrates declined in April to 2,684 long tons from 2,822 tons in March, the International Tin Study Group reported here today.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 18 -- The first meeting between representatives of the Old Country Trotting Association and the Standardbred Owners Association in the dispute over the division of purses for the Roosevelt Raceway light harness meeting is planned for tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A wallet-sized report card for children to take from school to school as their migrant farm worker families travel up the East Coast was drawn up here today.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 18 -- The Government is considering plans to reduce the conscription period from twenty months to eighteen.

The Child Study Association of America said yesterday that it "regards vicious crime and horror comics as an offense against childhood." A tie-up between the association and one publisher since 1941 has been justified by improving comics, the parent education group added.
VERO BEACH, Fla., May 18 (UP) -- A fisherman out-tracked assorted big-game experts today to corner Marguerita, a one-ton "baby" elephant that slipped its chain and swam away in the Indian River.
St. John's University clinched the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference championship by defeating New York University, 4 -- 0, at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens, yesterday.

GENEVA, May 18 -- A North Korean spokesman accused the Swiss and Swedish members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission in Korea today of having lied under pressure of the United States. It was by far the most bitter Communist complaint to date against the neutrals serving on that body.

SEATTLE, May 18 (UP) -- Attorneys for the New York Giants' professional football team today attempted to prove Arnie Weinmeister was an indispensable part of their team in hearings before King County Superior Judge Lloyd Shorett.

PARIS, May 18 (UP) -- Budge Patty and Gardnar Mulloy, the only seeded Americans to see action, led seven other United States players into the second round in men's singles today as the French tennis championships began at the Roland Garros Stadium in cold, windy weather.
TRANI, Italy, May 17 -- The notoriously poor tavoliere or table land of Foggia has been transformed since thousands of American airmen and G. I.'s saw it ten years ago in World War II.

Beginning with the third quarter, American Broadcasting- Paramount Theatres, Inc., expects theatre business to improve materially, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, told the annual meeting of shareholders here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- A fractional drop in the amount of duties collected on imported merchandise would result from proposed changes in the present methods of valuing imported merchandise.
As the days grow longer and warmer, many men and women here worry unselfishly about the summer. Their problem is, "How many children will we be able to send to camp this summer?"

BOSTON, May 18 -- An apparatus that can measure distances smaller than one-trillionth of an inch, equivalent to the distance a boy grows in 1-30,000 of a second, was demonstrated here today at the Harvard Medical School.

ALBANY, May 18 -- New York City will receive about $135,000 in additional real-estate taxing power in the fiscal year that opens July 1 under new special franchise valuations approved today by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment.

The fifteen stores operated by Gimbel Brothers, Inc., had 4 per cent lower sales in the first fiscal quarter, ended on April 30, than in the same months of 1953, stockholders learned yesterday at their annual meeting, held in the New York store.
A general decline in travel curtailed operations of the Greyhound Corporation in the March quarter, O. S. Caesar, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday.

LONDON, May 18 (UP) -- European and Asiatic commentators today hailed the United States Supreme Court decision banning segregation in America's public schools as a notable advance. Some newspapers, however, said it might inspire "racial riots" in the South.
GENEVA, May 18 -- An exchange of recriminations marked the dealings today between the French and the Vietminh on the question of the evacuation of French Union wounded from Dienbienphu.

PARIS, May 18 -- Diplomatic consultations on Indo-China going on here this week between the United States and France were said today to be exploratory. They are aimed as preparation for a full-scale conference to be held here when Gen. Paul Ely, French Chief of Staff, has reported on his current mission to Indo-China.

PITTSBURGH, May 18 -- Representatives of the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., and officials of the United States Steel Corporation met for two hours today in a general discussion of the union's 1954 wage contract demands.
A group of citizens touring parks and playgrounds in Queens yesterday noted both improvement and room for it.

The incredible decision of the McCarthy investigating committee to suspend hearings becomes more incredible the longer one looks at it. We do not presume to inquire into the motives of the six members of the seven-man committee who voted for suspension; but, as we stated yesterday, their action was entirely unnecessary and it plays directly into the hands of Senator McCarthy.
Governor Dewey, who caused an international tempest in a percolator last week by urging people to switch from coffee to milk, took additional measures yesterday to stimulate fluid milk sales.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 -- The increasing use of foreign graduates on house-staff positions in this nation's hospitals is creating a situation similar to "the unsavory diploma mills of the turn of the century," the Catholic Hospital Association was told today.

President Eisenhower praised the people of Poland last night as displaying the same heroism in facing foreign oppression today as that shown by Polish soldiers who participated in the battle for Monte Cassino in the Italian campaign of World War II.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 18 -- French aircraft resumed the bombing of Provincial Route 41 east of Dienbienphu this morning following the French High Command's announcement that it would be "deneutralized."
KWANGJU, Korea, Wednesday, May 19 -- Korean politicians seeking election to the Republic's National Assembly, round out their campaigns tomorrow.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 18 -- The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, meeting here in annual convention, unanimously commended the United States Supreme Court today for declaring unconstitutional racial segregation in the public schools.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address here today:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18 -- The United States is expected to remove any legal obstacles to early United Nations discussion of a petition from the Marshall Islanders asking an end to hydrogen bomb tests near their Pacific homes.
YONKERS, May 18 (AP) -- Musician, a 7-year-old gelding, turned his first start of the season into a victory tonight by taking the Salem purse on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway in 2:03 4/5.
GENEVA, May 18 -- Hungary advised the International Labor Organization today that she was sending a "large delegation" to the world labor conference here the first week in June.

DETROIT, May 18 (UP) -- Right-hander Steve Gromek of the Detroit Tigers coasted to his seventh victory of the season against a single loss, hurling an 8-to-3 triumph over the Philadelphia Athletics today.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The United States Lines agreed today to pay an additional $4,000,000 for the superliner United States.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- A committee on foreign trade policy marked World Trade Week today with a demand that this country's international trade agreements program be allowed to expire.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted today to give President Eisenhower full authority to carry out his plans for continuation of the public housing program.

Results of a third study of public participation in the stock market were issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. They give emphasis to the importance of the institutional investor and confirm the predominantly investment character of today's market.
KENILWORTH, N. J., May 18 (AP) -- New ideas in American industry are being seen at a five-day industrial "clinic" by the Kenilworth Steel Company here today.
CHICAGO, May 18 -- Paul E. Feucht, president of the North Western Railroad, said today that there had been a slight upturn in business in recent weeks following the decline that started last August.

LONDON, May 18 -- A new era in the long history of the Liverpool cotton trade was signaled today by the ringing of a hand bell on the floor of the Liverpool Cotton Exchange. At the signal the president and vice president of the Liverpool Cotton Association made the first post-war Liverpool contract in cotton futures.

An investment syndicate headed by Stone Webster Securities Corporation is offering on a when-issued basis 480,000 shares of common stock of The Colonial Fund, Inc., a fifty-year-old investment company which is about to become a mutual fund of the open-end type.
An alley cat with an idee fixe disrupted traffic for an hour in Brooklyn last evening when it curled up for a nap in the springs of a crosstown bus.
Conditioned by twenty-four hours of sleeplessness, 186 sturdy Kentuckians arrived yesterday to begin a four-day orgy of theatre-going, shopping and sightseeing.

VIENNA, May 18 -- The Austrian Parliament will debate tomorrow the threat made yesterday by Ivan I. Ilyichev, Soviet High Commissioner, to reimpose occupation controls unless the Austrian Government put an end to "hostile intrigues" against the Soviet occupation authorities.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Senator Wallace F. Bennett, Republican of Utah, predicted today that commercial sponsorship of televised congressional committee hearings might bring Senators into competition with a chimpanzee.
FRANKFORT, Ky., May 18 -- "We don't have to change our laws when the Supreme Court has changed them for us," Kentucky First Assistant Attorney General $o 1. Ferguson, said today.
GENEVA, May 18--Secret talks today on Indo-China ran into a deadlock on the question of separating consideration of a settlement in Laos and Cambodia from that in Vietnam.
The familiar question, "Which twin has the Toni?" soon may be heard in reference to cosmetic products other than the Toni home wave set.

LONG ISLAND University in Brooklyn will confer degrees next month on two unusual candidates. Comdr. Carl Arthur Setterstrom Jr., U. S. N. retired, will receive a B. S. in accounting at about the same time that his daughter, Madelyn, will get a degree at Wheaton College in Illinois.

MARITIME arrivals are providing pleasant moments on local stages this month. A fortnight ago Cap'n Andy's "Show Boat" put into the City Center for a brief but welcome visit. And last night "H. M. S. Pinafore" arrived at the President Theatre, where it should provide enjoyment for many Gilbert and Sullivan admirers during its one-week stay.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -Seven West European countries with big merchant fleets have protested against legislation requiring that American ships must carry at least half of foreign-aid cargoes.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 18 -- The Government made its first direct intervention today in the strike situation. It took over operation of the National Railroad and warned would-be strikers that it would not tolerate interference with normal service.
The Appellate Division reversed yesterday the conviction of Minot F. Jelke for compulsory prostitution because the press and public had been excluded while the prosecution's case was being presented.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 18 (Reuters) -- A sudden gust of wind blew an American woman's carefully-saved $850 into the ocean. Mrs. Annie Lucas, 66 years old, stared in horror as her purse went over the side of the liner Queen Mary.
NEWARK, May 18 -- Inclusion of the four councilman at large seats in the June 15 run-off election in this city was ruled valid today by Superior Court Judge G. Dixon Speakman.

Whatever the cause may be for a considerable number of United States military personnel to find British people indifferent or even hostile to them, as reported in The Times of May 10, the inherent insular attitude of Britain's man in the street tends to make him regard, rightly or wrongly, large numbers of foreign troops on British soil as a kind of army of occupation.

The German soccer team, Fortuna, defeated an All-Star eleven drawn from seven German-American League clubs, 3 --1, at Eintracht Oval, Astoria, Queens, last night. Fortuna ended its tour with three victories, two defeats and one tie. The crowd was 3,322.
Three current programs will take on new sponsors this summer and move to new broadcast time periods.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -Henry and Murray Garsson, munitions makers who went to prison for bribery in a World War II contract scandal, are now asking the Government for more than $18,500,000.
At least nine stores were destroyed on Lydig Avenue in the East Bronx early today in a four-alarm fire that originated in a fabrics shop and spread rapidly to the entire block front.

BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- Mrs. J. R. H. Thouron's Royal Vale has drawn top weight of 126 pounds in his attempt for a repeat victory in the $50,000-added Massachusetts Handicap tomorrow at Suffolk Downs -- a feat accomplished only by First Fiddle in the past.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Officials of the International Monetary Fund expressed amazement today over reports from Geneva that a Fund director had proposed liquidating the organization.

AS a business man and member of several of the sixty-seven organizations "represented" by the Joint Conference for Better Government, I am confident that the open letter to the Mayor from Harold W. McGraw, its chairman, is not an accurate statement of the attitude of the business men of New York City toward the extension of the sales tax.

OTISVILLE, N. Y., May 18 -- For the best of all possible reasons -- the diminishing number of tuberculosis patients in New York City who need hospitalization -- the city is planning to close by July 1, 1955, its Municipal Sanatorium sixty miles northwest of Manhattan.

ALBERT McCLEERY is a television producer who is not afraid to experiment. As TV's most dedicated practitioner of the "cameo close-up" technique, he has made a career of attempting to bring formidable literary works within the scope of video's "live" cameras.
Twenty young artists in Westchester County have been chosen winners in the sixth annual creative art competition for high school students arranged by Lord Taylor.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., May 18 (AP) -- The Saratoga Racing Association will pass on to patrons at its August meeting here the 15 per cent tax on admissions imposed by Saratoga County.

NEW DELHI, India, May 18 -Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru told the Lower House of Parliament toady the Government would no longer permit foreign Christian missionaries to set up establishments in border areas. He said those already functioning in the Himalayan region would be brought under stricter surveillance.

LONDON, May 18 -- A rally by Government funds helped the stock markets to close reasonably firm today. The improvement was not sufficient, however, to eliminate earlier losses among industrials caused by profit-taking. Shares of companies with interests in Argentina rose on the opening of trade talks here between Britain and Argentina.

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) -- The Tribune Company, publisher of The Chicago Tribune and The New York News, reported yesterday a combined gross income of almost $250,000,000 from the two newspapers and thirteen subsidaries in 1953.

GENEVA, May 18 -- The executive committee of the World Federation of United Nations Associations has unanimously passed a resolution calling for the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 18 -- Officials in the Southern states moved cautiously today in mapping plans for accepting the Supreme Court's invitation to share the burden of blueprinting a new public education program.

Without management savings already accomplished, the New York City budget would be $25,000,000 higher than it now is, Dr. Luther H. Gulick said yesterday in his first report as City Administrator. Since 1948 -- two years before the management survey studies of city departments began under Dr. Gulick's direction in 1950 -- $56,101,453 has been cut out of "otherwise expanding expense and capital budgets," according to the report.

BALTIMORE, May 18 (UP) -- Correlation's sizzling stretch-duel victory over Hasty Road in Monday's Preakness Prep today reduced the field of probables in the Preakness stakes at Pimlico Saturday to ten.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Plans for a $66,750,000 construction and expansion program were announced here today by the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, which filed an application with the Federal Power Commission for permission to build the new facilities.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Jenner Senate Internal Security Subcommittee heard today that revolution in Russia was inevitable if the free world advised the Soviet people that it sought the overthrow of only the Kremlin tyrants.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., May 18 (AP) -- Tuskegee Institute has no plans to admit white students, although there have been applications from them, Dr. L. H. Foster, Tuskegee's president, said today.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 18 -- It's not often that a man can defeat 3,000 dogs in a showdown in this town, yet it happened today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Three proposed rules designed to advise underwriters just how far they can go in stabilizing the market for a security issue were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The new issue of Treasury 1 7/8 per cent notes due in 1959 sold at 100 yesterday, for a decline of nearly 5/8 of a point since the issue came out early this month as a combination refunding and new-money borrowing by the Government.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Republican of Oregon, told the Senate today it would be "dangerous" to give wire-tapping powers to any Attorney General with "political" tendencies.

The Greater New York Fund has raised $4,032,598 so far by voluntary subscription to meet the current need of $9,000,000 for the 423 voluntary hospitals, health and welfare services that benefit from the drive.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18 -- A spokesman for the American Association for the United Nations said today that there had been no advance indication that a resolution of Communist China would come up at the Geneva executive board meeting.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 (AP) -- Dr. Richard Overholt, a Boston chest surgeon, suggested tonight that the cigarette smokers "give up inhaling the smoke until the issue is definitely settled as to whether or not such inhalation can cause cancer of the lung."

Operating revenues and net income of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad Company for the first four months of 1954 were 16.7 per cent and 41.3 per cent, respectively, below the results posted in the 1953 period. This was reported at the annual meeting in Cleveland by Lynne L. White, president, yesterday.
One of Wall Street's oldest firms, Bache Co., observes its seventy-fifth anniversary today. The firm is a member of the New York Stock Exchange and other leading securities and commodities exchanges.

Employes of the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company of Brooklyn gave 240 pints of blood on Monday toward the 881 received by the regional Red Cross blood program. The brewery employes have given 5,000 pints of blood since 1942.
LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- Britain urged Argentina today to scrap restrictive trade agreements and clear the way for free and expanding commercial relations between the two countries.

MOSCOW, May 18 -- The Russian Army newspaper Red Star revealed today that the Arctic sea route along the northern coast of the country was now being used regularly. The movement of freight between western ports and the Far East is growing annually, according to the paper.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 18 -Guillermo del Pedregal, Minister of Finance, said today he could solve Chile's apparently hopeless financial problem permanently it the United States would put up a floating credit of $100,000,000 for the next three or four years.

With Warren Hacker turning in a superb pitching job, the Chicago Cubs halted the Dodgers, 7 -- 1, before 11,050 fans at Ebbets Field last night. Hacker notched his second victory against two setbacks as he checked the Brooks with four hits.

Following are additional editorial comments by the country's newspapers on the Supreme Court's decision outlawing racial segregation the public schools, as Fathered by The Associated Press and The New York Times:
