Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today new issues of public utility securities having a par value of nearly $90,000,000. The offerings are as follows:

"Fifty Centuries of Art," by Francis Henry Taylor, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is planned for publication on Sept. 22 by Harper. It will trace the history of art from early Egyptian times to the present. The book will have 320 illustrations in color, two-thirds of them taken from the collection at the Metropolitan.
Twenty-nine habitat groups at the American Museum of Natural History, which have taken twenty years to make, were dedicated last night as the last seven in the series were opened to preview.

"Fledermaus," the second of three fortnightly revivals to be presented by the New York City Light Opera Company under the supervision of William Hammerstein, will be trotted out at 8 o'clock tonight at the City Center. It will continue through May 30 and will be supplanted by "Carousel" on June 2.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- The American Federation of Labor called on Congress today to set up a $1,000,000,000 fund to help the South build new schools to carry out the Supreme Court's order outlawing racial segregation in public schools.
OTTAWA, May 18 -- To Canada, the importance of the St. Lawrence Seaway and power development is largely economic. For the United States, it has a strategic as well as an economic importance.

ALTHOUGH the week-end fly fishermen found the trout far from cooperative, except on a few stretches of some of the smaller streams, a number of enthusiastic reports arrived before noon yesterday, indicating that the streams had dropped their levels and increased their temperatures.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 18 -- A giant plastic balloon, the size of an 18-story building, floated to record heights over Minnesota today with a fifty-pound load of scientific instruments designed to search out the secrets of outer space.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The District of Columbia may become the trail blazer in bringing its public schools in line with yesterday's Supreme Court ruling outlawing segregation.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 18 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed his confidence today in Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Amy. The Secretary sat a few feet away as the Presi dent addressed 30,000 persons here for a celebration of a state-observed Freedom Day.
Sugar exporting countries are running into trouble attempting to do their share in maintaining the established world price of the product, according to B. W. Dyer Co., sugar brokers and economists.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The State Department indicated today that the Communist shipment of arms to Guatemala might possibly be regarded as a threat to the security of the Americas under the terms of the Treaty of Rio de Janeiro.

Consumer credit outstanding in the nation at the end of 1950 totaled $20.8 billions, and at the end of 1951 had risen only to $21.4 billions, or by $600 millions. In the next two years, however, it climbed at a spectacular rate. By the end of 1952 it had risen to $25.8 billions and by the end of 1953 had soared to $28.9 billions.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Senate Finance Committee, like the House of Representatives, feels that inventors and writers should get a better tax break to compensate for the financial ups and downs of their work.

MILWAUKEE, May 18 (AP) -- Germany's middleweight champion, Hans Stretz, made an impressive American debut tonight by gaining a unanimous decision from Billy Kilgore of Miami, before 2,819 fans at the Milwaukee Arena.

Restriction of United States imports of oil from Venezuela would deal a "mortal" blow to benefits derived by American industry and labor from $850,000,000 annual trade with that country, a Venezuelan official warned yesterday.

Sales of crude oil and petroleum products by the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company Ltd. last year aggregated 751,500 barrels a day, according to the company's annual report. This represented an increase of 91,400 barrels a day, or 14 per cent, compared with 1952, and it was the second highest in the company's history, being exceeded only by the volume in 1950.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said today he would take over Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigation of what he called a "darn smelly" case involving Government financing of tin mines in Alaska.

We can study with full sympathy the Vietnamese protests against any proposal that would involve the partition of their country. There have been popular demonstrations in Hanoi and Saigon on this issue and it is obvious that the anti-Communist Vietnamese are stirred up to resist any division.

New York citizens need not worry about littered city streets any more, at least not until after the autumn foliage dies. All the litterers, just gypsies at heart, have filled up the gas tanks and turned their attention to spoiling Connecticut with trash.
The Florida State improvement Commission sold $6,000,000 of Broward County Bridge System revenue bonds, due from 1960 to 1983, to Shields Co. and C. J. Devine Co. and associates yesterday.
Seventh and Eighth Avenues will be restricted to one-way operation starting June 6.
An official of a Queens Mothers Club charged yesterday that one Parent-Teacher Association in the city had a Communist president and that in another a Red was running for vice president.
BOSTON, May 18 -- David R. Daniel, publisher of The Hartford Times, was elected today president of the New England Daily Newspaper Association.

Nine railroads serving New York announced yesterday a new schedule of rates that offers savings for family groups. The move was made in response to a project of the New York Summer Festival to make New York a vacation mecca.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 18 -- A Canadian nutritionist who toured the world for the United Nations has found that people agree about food in one respect -- they do not have a taste for radically new dishes.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 -- The Medical Society of New Jersey decided today to devise a test for drunken drivers and recommend it to the Legislature.

In your editorial of May 10 "A Plan for Indo-China," you stated that proposals made by French Foreign Minister Georges Bidault at the Geneva Conference are "honest, sound and constructive." May I say that these proposals lack the essential magic words, which are: complete freedom of Indo-China from French colonial rule.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 18 -- The Government of Tanganyika declared a state of emergency today in the territory's northern province. A Mau Mau band is moving south out of Kenya into Tanganyika.

DURBAN, South Africa, May 18 -- The South African press gave prominence today to the United States Supreme Court's ruling against segregation in schools and also to new action by Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan to further codify and tighten the segregation long in vogue in South Africa.

A new delicacy shop opened today at 872 Madison Avenue, at Seventy-first Street. The attractive, well-stocked establishment is owned by Fraser Morris, a mail-order concern that ships food parcels to all parts of the world. This is its first retail outlet here.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Le Plaisir," a French-made offering in three episodes, based on stories by Guy de Maupassant, is at the Normandie Theatre. Danielle Darrieux, Jean Gabin, Simone Simon, Daniel Gelin, Madeleine Renaud, Claude Dauphin and Pierre Brasseur head the cast. Max Ophuls produced the Arthur Mayer-Edward Kingsley release, which has English titles and is narrated by Peter Ustinov.
The teachers' boycott of extra-curricular activities went into its second day yesterday. Officials of the Board of Education said its effect had not yet been felt.
PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, May 19 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Lloyd H. Wood, organization-backed "harmony" candidate, early today won the Pennsylvania Republican gubernatorial nomination in a walkaway.

RABAT, Morocco, May 18 -- Gen. Augustin Guillaume, French Resident General of Morocco, was summoned to Paris today for consultations prior to the appointment of his successor, now believed to be imminent.

VARYING its long list of one-man shows of paintings by celebrated artists of Europe and America, the Museum of Modern Art is opening today an exhibition of sculpture by Jacques Lipchitz. More than 120 pieces illustrating forty years of his work have been spaciously installed: The heroic size pieces are strikingly displayed in the garden, with smaller examples in the adjacent galleries along the back of the main floor.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and prices declined 3 to 8 points.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (UP) -- Johnny Logan's triple sparked Milwaukee to a four-run sixth inning that carried the Milwaukee Braves to a 6-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight before 9,529 fans at Connie Mack Stadium.
The fur business gives promise of emerging from its recent doldrums and the chief credit is given to the recent 50 per cent cut in the excise tax, a survey of the trade showed yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 -- Humphrey Bogart, who will start work next month in "We're No Angels" for Paramount, also is interested in "The Desperate Hours," the Joseph Hayes novel William Wyler will direct and produce for the studio.

The Army's chief intelligence agent at Fort Monmouth, N. J., a civilian who had been publicly praised by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for "trying to do a good job," indicated yesterday that he had ended his thirteen-year career at the Signal Corps Center.
Three distinguished service awards were presented and new officers were elected yesterday at the annual spring reception of the Alumni Association of the Columbia University School of Journalism.

The writer should like to suggest a plan to meet the problem of financing higher education in a period of shrinking endowments. The plan is one which would avoid the danger of Government intervention in the academic program, but at the same time make Government funds available to individual students on a loan basis.
PITTSBURGH, May 18 (AP) -- A five-run third inning helped the Cincinnati Redlegs trim the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, 6 -- 5.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- New York State's chances for joining a $600,000,000 St. Lawrence River power project brightened today through default.

Every Jew in Rumania "is in danger of arrest and long imprisonment as a result of the cruel prison sentences given scores of leaders of Rumanian Jewry for Zionist and communal activity," Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, declared yesterday.

Resilient of the Killian Farms won the Attention Handicap, the classified event of a mile and sixteenth that served as the star attraction at Belmont Park yesterday. With George Glassner in the saddle, the 4-year-old son of Sir Damion gamely held off the bid of Ogden Phipps' Bassanio to score by a head.

GENEVA, May 19 -- Agreement on a joint Allied proposal for Korea is closer than ever. But if South Korea will not go along with it several of the Allied countries plan to make proposals of their own for Korean unification.
The Wheatley Stable's High Voltage won $20,710 in the filly division of the National Stallion Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

Robert L. Joseph has added a second play to his production schedule for next season. It is a romantic comedy called "Too Dear For My Possessing," the first playwriting effort by T. B. Morris, an English author.

DUBLIN, Thursday, May 20 -- Returns for more than half of 143 seats at stake in the general election Tuesday for Ireland's new Dail (Parliament) indicated early this morning that Premier Eamon de Valera's Fianna Fail (Party of Destiny) had lost control of the Government.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 19 -- Smith College awards for the year 1953-54 were announced this morning at the last full college assembly of the academic year.

LONDON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower's remarks today on the possibility of a Southeast Asian alliance without Britain startled and distressed senior Government officials. Only forty-eight hours ago, Prime Minister Churchill declared Britain would certainly join in discussing establishment of a collective defense system in Southeast Asia.
ALBANY, May 19 -- Governor D wey set up a special committee today to promote the drinking of milk and its use in cooking.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- A handwriting expert testified in Federal Court today that signatures on a number of stockholder proxies recorded at the American Woolen Company's April 23 annual meeting were "not genuine." The testimony was offered by Miss Elizabeth McCarthy of Boston.
W. H. Lawrence, a member of the Washington bureau of the New York Times, voiced here yesterday his own opinion as a political reporter that President Eisenhower would not seek reelection in 1956.
PITTSBURGH, May 19 (AP) -- Dick Hall's two-run single in the fifth and Max Surkont's steady eight-hit pitching carried the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs tonight.

Two five-story apartment buildings housing a total of 115 families in the Dyckman section of Manhattan have passed to new control with the purchase by Walter L. Rothschild of 73-83 Vermilyea Avenue and 611-19 Academy Street through Robert E. Hill, Inc., broker.

The obvious way to find out what matter is composed of is to smash it into bits. There comes a time when ordinary means of smashing will produce nothing but microscopic powder, which is still the original matter. So the physicists had to invent the atom, long regarded as the ultimate unit of matter.

A retail buyer who is a veteran in the field of textiles, linens and domestics reported yesterday that the European textile industry was continuing the comeback it had started at the end of World War II.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower declared today that the public hearings on the Army-McCarthy dispute should be continued.
BONN, West Germany, May 19 -- The West German Central Bank has followed the lead of the Bank of England and reduced its discount rate from 3 1/2 to 3 per cent, effective tomorrow.
The local executive board of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., voted yesterday to accept the fact-finders' recommendations in the union's dispute with the Transit Authority over a new contract.
IN view of the fact that he was hitting home runs at a more furious clip than ever before, did Stan Musial have any ambitions to win the homer championship this year?

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- Sam Tufano's Wise Margin, an 11-1 shot, sprinted through the pack over the last quarter mile to defeat Find by a nose in a driving finish today in the twentieth Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs.
Cocoa prices continued strong yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.
BALTIMORE, May 19 (UP) -- Correlation, Hasty Road, Admiral Porter and For Free officially were entered today for Saturday's $100,000 Preakness Stakes at Pimlico.

ATHENS, May 19 -- Spokesmen in the Premier's office and the Foreign Office today denied various aspects of a dispatch from C. L. Sulzberger, chief foreign correspondent of this newspaper, published in The New York Times yesterday and reprinted here.

Scoring nine runs in the eighth inning, the Chicago Cubs downed the floundering Dodgers, 9 -- 3, at Ebbets Field yesterday and swept the two-game series. Carl Erskine, the first of four Dodger pitchers, was working on a three-hit shutout until the eighth.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption in April averaged 33,564 bales a working day.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Shipbuilding Council of America told Congress today the nation's shipbuilding industry needed immediate Government help if it was to "continue as a vital element" in the defense mobilization program.

Prices touched Tuesday by United States Government securities must have convinced investment specialists that the market had fallen too far, because lively bidding yesterday sent values up as much as 1/2 point. The volume of trading continued very thin, however.
The Murry and Leonie Guggenheim Foundation has made a grant of $500,000 to establish an Institute of Dental Research as part of New York University's College of Dentistry.
Stock market prices seemed to grope uncertainly yesterday and presented a ragged appearance at the close. Every group of importance had both plus and minus signs.
Philadelphia, Pa., sold three issues of bonds totaling $43,520,000 in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.3164 per cent.
PARIS, May 19 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly decided today to take a formal vote on May 26 on the European Army Treaty -- probably to reject it.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- An unexpected break in May corn occurred in the closing minutes of the Board of Trade session here today, together with an equally unlooked-for upturn in May oats. Soybeans experienced another hectic session, but anything was expected in that quarter.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves, bolstered by Ed Mathews' seventh home run and the seven-hit pitching of Warren Spahn, defeated the Phillies, 6 -- 2, tonight to sweep their two-game series at Connie Mack Stadium.
PARIS, May 19 (UP) -- Tony Trabert and Art Larsen, who had drawn first-round byes, gained the third round in men's singles at the French tennis championships in near-freezing weather today.

Two United States Cabinet members and thirty-one other Government officials and educators will receive honorary degrees June 1 at Columbia University's combined commencement exercises and bicentennial convocation.

The news in summer knitwear is concerned chiefly with the variety of attractive tops that have been designed for every hour of the day. Improved construction methods coupled with a lively sense of fashion have brought knitwear strongly to the fore this season.

Mayor Wagner's announcement that the Russell Sage Foundation has agreed to undertake an intensive study of the statistical work carried on within city government departments is of front-rank importance, bearing on municipal government techniques generally.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- A group of Republican members of Congress told President Eisenhower today his popularity "has increased rather than diminished since the election."

ATLANTIC CITY, May 19 -- While cerebral palsy is not synonomous with mental deficiency, many victims are mentally handicapped, and the disease must be a major interest of specialists in mental deficiency, the American Association on Mental Deficiency heard today.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower said today it was a hard job to find a man to fit his qualifications for the chairmanship of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Proponents of the fair trade concept of merchandising, under which manufacturers specify minimum resale prices for retailers, say it is a major spur to advertising in newspapers by department stores and manufacturers. Similarly, the absence of effective fair trade operation is linked to a decrease in such advertising.
MONTREAL, May 19 (UP) -- Thirty-six British seamen began prison terms today for breaking a nineteenth-century English law and refusing to go to sea.

CAIRO, May 19 -- Abul Kheir Naguib, editor and publisher of a weekly newspaper, was sentenced today by the Revolution Tribunal to fifteen years at hard labor after trial on charges of treason, subversion and blackmail.
The city map was revised yesterday to provide for the projected Richmond Town restoration and a one mile and a half section of the contemplated $20,000,000 Richmond Parkway on Staten Island.

A drive to get the nation's thousand largest corporations to give a total of $8,500,000 a year to reduce the number of hospitalized mental patients and the cost of their treatment was announced here yesterday.
WEST NEW YORK, N. J., May 19 -- An attempt by local merchants to test the validity of the New Jersey lottery act ended in near fiasco tonight when a chimpanzee devoured hundreds of raffle tickets.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to bring farmers and all self-employed professional persons, including physicians and lawyers, under the Social Security Insurance system.

A decline last week of 124,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 175,750,000 barrels, compared with 175,874,000 a week earlier and 153,999,000 a year ago.

International trade is "bread and butter" to at least one person in every elevator load of American office workers, at every table of hungry harvest hands and on every train crew, Francis T. Greene, executive vice president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, asserted last night.

Yesterday was the beginning of the end for two big angels and an eagle that have been hovering over Madison Avenue since 1897. Said to be crumbling and a danger to pedestrians, they are being removed from the facade of 50 Madison Avenue, at Twenty-sixth Street.
YONKERS, May 19 (AP) -- The Quality Stable's Florita won the $4,500 Tibbets Purse for pacers on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway tonight in a driving finish with Paul Wixom's Fred Scott.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower made these main points at his news conference this morning:

Three floors in the new twenty-eight-story office building at 261 Madison Avenue, between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets, have been leased by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

In his letter published April 29, in which he is critical of Secretary Dulles' policy, Albert Guerard observes, "If we do actually meet the representatives of China for fair, free and equal discussion this implies recognition de facto: how can one discuss with a Power that does not exist?

Despite protests from Soviet Russia and India, the United States and Pakistan have now signed the long-discussed mutual defense assistance agreement providing for American military equipment and training for the Pakistani Army. As Foreign Minister Zafrullah Khan has emphasized, Pakistan has signed the agreement in the exercise of its unchallengeable right as a sovereign nation to take whatever measures it deems necessary for its self-defense.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 19 The president of Barnard College said here today that parents who spent money on television sets, cars and amusements, and little for books, records and family activities, had no right to criticize schools when children acted like savages.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (UP) -- A private detective said he had trailed the Philadelphia Phillies shortstop, Gran Hamner, home by mistake today but the club president, Bob Carpenter, disclosed the detective was acting under his orders.

One hundred years after its founding by Dr. Elizabeth Blackwell, America's first woman doctor, the New York Infirmary dedicated its new building yesterday at East Fifteenth Street and Stuyvesant Square East.

ST. LOUIS, May 19 (AP) -- The United States Wholesale Grocers Association adopted a resolution today opposing any amendments that would weaken the Robinson-Patman Act, regarded as protecting small merchants from price discrimination.
WEST POINT, N. Y., May 19 -- Army remained a strong contender in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League by defeating Princeton, 4 to 1, at Doubleday Field today.

Conrad L. Strandberg, 43 years old, a ship carpenter of 62 Cayuga Avenue, West New Brighton, S. I., was acquitted yesterday of the killing of his brother, Bernard Strandberg, 40, also a ship carpenter, of 57 Broadway, New Brighton.

Sixty years have passed since two young nurses, Lillian D. Wald and Mary M. Brewster, went down to the lower East Side "to find the sick poor and nurse them." Out of this adventure grew the Henry Street Settlement and the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 19 -- The United States and Pakistan signed an agreement today under which war material and technical military assistance will be given to Pakistan.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and closing prices were 6 points lower to 2 points higher than on Tuesday.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 19 -- The time has come for public health agencies to make isoniazid and PAS (para-aminosalicylic acid) available everywhere as the best existing treatment for un-hospitalized TB patients, according to Dr. Arthur B. Robins, director of the TB bureau of the New York City Health Department.

The consolidated net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and subsidiaries dropped to $4,059,093, or 47 cents a share, in the first quarter, from $8,100,501, or 93 cents, in the initial three months of 1953.
NEW DELHI, India, May 19 -- India is taking a serious interest in possible connections between the Communist party of India and the international Red espionage apparatus.

MOSCOW, May 19 -- Pravda, the Soviet Communist organ, devoted nearly half a page today to a declaration by a former Ukrainian emigre asserting that President Eisenhower and Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, had given orders far the formation of Ukrainian units to participate in the fight against the Soviet.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Community Council on Instruction of the Arlington, Va., Public Schools tonight ended its first year's work.

"In the struggle against communism the war is no longer over when men are forced to yield -- the prisoner-of-war stockade is only an extension of the battlefield where they must be taught to carry on an unequal struggle with the only weapons remaining to them -- faith and courage."

CHICAGO, May 19 -- Prosecution of Cook County's widely publicized horse-meat scandal case ended with unexpected abruptness today. Judge Leslie E. Salter in Criminal Court directed a verdict of not guilty before the State had completed its evidence.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Eisenhower Administration's continued abstention from a position on the statehood issue raised considerable doubt today whether the current bill would ever leave the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives.
ALBANY, May 19 -- The Appellate Division of the Third Department unanimously affirmed today without opinion Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein's decision in the "Mr. X." case.

CLEVELAND, May 19 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians stretched their winning streak to seven today by beating the Boston Red Sox, 5 to 3, on a pair of unearned runs in the eighth inning. Two errors by Shortstop Milt Bolling set up the tallies.
The old International Longshoremen's Association indicated yesterday that it might challenge the results of next Wednesday's waterfront election.
CHICAGO, May 19 -- The fiercest jurisdictional fight in the American Federation of Labor was settled harmoniously here today through the intervention of George Meany, the Federation's president.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- A member of the Federal Communications Commission today proposed an "immediate freeze" on new standard television stations in order to give ultra high frequency television a chance to take hold.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Democratic demands mounted today for the House of Representatives to undertake a separate public investigation of housing scandals.

The F. W. Woolworth Company, giant variety chain which is observing its seventy-fifth anniversary, is optimistic about sales for the balance of 1954, 1954 business, J. T. Leftwich, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Watertown, N. Y.

NEWARK, May 19 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was assailed here tonight as a "power-mad and ruthless politician" who has "declared war on the President" in an attempt to seize control of the Republican party.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., May 19 -- Plans for the raising of $500,000 for the creation of two endowed chairs at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America were announced today at the fifty-fourth annual convention of the Rabbinical Assembly of America.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that the United States, given cooperation in other quarters, might go forward with a Southeast Asian defensive alliance without Britain.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 19 -- Criticism of the Eisenhower Administration for failure to condemn the "antics and methods" of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican, was voiced here tonight by Charles S. Zimmerman, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, May 20 -- South Korean voters pick a new National Assembly today.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Thursday, May 20 (AP) -- Chiang Kai-shek was inaugurated as President of Nationalist China for a new six-year-term today. The city had a festival atmosphere despite the threat of Communist air raids on Formosa.

The six-story apartment house at 919 Park Place, in Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Park Holding Company, a syndicate of investors represented by Jack R. Weprin. It is assessed at $470,000 and was bought from Bernard Besdine and C. Froom in a deal negotiated by Isidore A. Jaffe, broker.

A $150,000 libel suit brought by Joe Julian, radio and television actor, against the publishers of Red Channels got under way yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Irving Saypol and a jury. The plaintiff charged that the listing of his name was "malicious" and had prejudiced his opportunities to make a living.

The Chase National Bank, as the registered holder of 800,000 shares of the New York Central Railroad Company, delivered the proxy for that stock yesterday to Clint W. Murchi son and Sid W. Richardson, Texas capitalists.

The West must not let down its bars on trade with Communist China or any Soviet area if there is to be effective resistance to Red aggression in Asia, a Republican Congressman with long experience in the Far East warned yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- A bright future was forecast for the electrical industry today by W. V. O'Brien, vice president and general manager of the apparatus sales division, General Electric Company. He addressed the National Federation of Financial Analysts Societies in convention.
TOKYO, May 19 -- Japanese Socialists today launched their heaviest attack on Premier Shigeru Yoshida's projected trip to the West.

JERSEY CITY, May 19 -- For forty-eight years, untold numbers of homeward-bound Jersey commuters have muttered imprecations as they struggled wearily up the 10 per cent grade between the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad's Erie station and the Erie Railroad's terminal, here.

Women headed by Mrs. Robert L. Clarkson Jr. and including Mrs. John C. Wilmerding are furthering the success of the carnival for the benefit of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled. The fete will be held tomorrow evening at the headquarters of the beneficiary, First Avenue and Twenty-third Street.
The recent end of another series of atomic tests in the Pacific marks the beginning of a new chapter in the military and industrial applications of atomic energy.
MADRID, May 19 -- The Falange party newspaper Arriba indicated today that the Spanish Government was considering a series of "gradual measures" to isolate the British colony of Gibraltar from Spain.

YONKERS, May 19 -- While policemen in radio cars kept watch, milk from the depot here of the Beverly Milk Company was delivered to homes today by the "independent business men" who had been induced to buy the delivery routes of the company.
The Eastern Steamship Company liner Yarmouth is slated to operate in cruise service out of Miami, Fla., to Haiti, Jamaica, Cuba and the Bahamas, it was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower declared today it was "disturbing" to have a shipload of arms from Communist Poland delivered to Guatemala. It would be "a terrible thing," he continued, if the Communist dictatorship were to establish an outpost on this continent.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with some of the President's remarks in direct quotation, as specially authorized by the White House. Under conference rules, the rest of the President's comment is in indirect discourse:
SYRACUSE, May 19 -- The state's Democratic leaders brought into the open today the key issue on which they hoped to capture control of the Governorship next fall.

A commuter on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has complained to the Interstate Commerce Commission about trainmen's time-honored practice of reserving coach seats, at 10 cents each, for card players.
A wrangle developed yesterday as to which magistrate should hear the case of the "Strike It Rich" television-radio program accused by the Welfare Department of soliciting funds without a license.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UP) -- The Air Force, in a new move to strengthen continental air defenses, today announced formation of a special unit of radar-bearing planes to guard North American sea approaches against atomic bombers.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower said today that he was looking for a way to get his international atomic pool plan started without the Russians.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Supreme Court was asked today to set aside a lower court ruling that upheld a Federal license for a $600,000,000 hydro-electric project in the International Rapids section of the St. Lawrence River.
A gray horse hitched to a flower peddler's wagon executed a remarkable piece of broken field running on Fifth Avenue last evening.
Another year of good business for the Sinclair Oil Corporation was forecast yesterday by P. C. Spencer, president, at the annual stockholders' meeting at the Biltmore Hotel.
CHICAGO, May 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The centenary of the Crimean War is reviving again this year some of the periodically told tales of the oddities of that conflict. Waged in the rough terrain around Imperial Russia's Black Sea naval base, the British-French-Turkish campaign had so little historic and military significance that more than one commentator has called it "the insane war."

The establishment of the first community-wide program for voluntary dental insurance was announced for the city and surrounding areas yesterday by the nonprofit Group Health Dental Insurance Plan, Inc., at a meeting at the Columbia University Club.

LONDON, May 19 -- Great issues, such as German rearmament, that divide the British labor movement remain unresolved after two days of solemn discussion, and Bevanism, although battered, is alive and kicking.

Hubert Fauntleroy Julian, aviation's "Black Eagle of Harlem" in the Nineteen Twenties and Nineteen Thirties, said yesterday he had been trying for six months to free 25,000 rounds of anti-aircraft ammunition seized by the Customs Service here when it was en route to Guatemala.

SALISBURY, England, May 19 (UP) -- Sir Gordon Richards, winner of more races than any other jockey in the world and the first of his profession to be knighted, suffered a concussion today but escaped serious injury when his mount fell during the Devizes Handicap at the Salisbury track.
LONDON, May 19 -- Prices rose and business expanded in the stock markets today. Government funds continued to improve and gained as much as 6s 3d (87 1/2 cents) on 100 ($280).

The first annual ship safety achievement award offered jointly by the marine section of the National Safety Council and the American Merchant Marine Institute was presented yesterday to the liner African Endeavor of Farrell Lines.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 19 -- Negro members of the Kenya Legislative Council are enthusiastic about the United States Supreme Court's decision abolishing segregation in public schools. White members are cool and hesitate to comment.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 19 -- Dr. Robert S. Myers, a fellow of the American College of Surgeons, said here today "it is time for the medical profession and hospitals to clos eranks to eliminate those who violate the principles of medical ethics and bring discredit on honest physicians and hospitals."

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Literary and other beneficiaries of money grants from tax-exempt philanthropic and educational foundations were accused today of wielding powerful adverse effects on morality, politics, and even the military policy in this country.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 19 -- Gen. Paul Ely, Chief of the French General Staff, arrived here today from Saigon for a first-hand look at the military situation in North Vietnam.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 19 -- Non - textile diversification is paying off for Textron, Incorporated, Royal Little, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting here today. Mr. Little made no comment, however, on his attempts to win control of the American Woolen Company. Afterward an officer said Textron was continuing to accumulate stock, its holdings now having passed the 300,000-share mark.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 12:
Some little deaf girls were hostesses to the Bronx Girl Scout Troop 143 yesterday afternoon at a "cook-out" at the Lexington School for the Deaf.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 19 -- Mr. Clapp, in a good-by message to all T. V. A. employes, said: "In the months and years ahead don't let little minds or the greedy intimidate or enchant you or divert you from your service to the public interest."

DETROIT, May 19 (AP) -- Carmine Fiore, a savage left-hooker from Brooklyn, scored two knockdowns and won his eighth straight fight tonight with a unanimous ten-round decision over Army-bound Jed Black of Janesville, Wis. Fiore weighed 146 1/4 pounds, Black 144 1/2.
LONDON, May 19 -- The Government decided today to introduce equal pay for women by stages before the end of March, 1955.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 19 -- A ban that prevented additional shipping of light harness horses to Roosevelt Raceway by three members of the Standardbred Owners Association was rescinded today. The action was taken by the Old Country Trotting Association to clear the way toward further negotiations in the dispute over purses between the track and the owners.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams declared last night that by 1932 standards the Police Department was short 6,000 men.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Eisenhower called today for calm and reason in the South over the Supreme Court's outlawing racial segregation in the public schools.
LONDON, May 19 -- Sir Winston Churchill is criticized for confusing the conduct of naval operations during the Norwegian campaign in 1940, in the first volume of an official history published today.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The four Republican Senators investigating the McCarthy-Army dispute said today they had signed statements consenting to the introduction in evidence of any monitored telephone conversations they might have had with Pentagon officials about the case.
HANOI, May 19 (UP) -- The heroine of the fortress of Dienbienphu has refused a Vietminh offer of freedom to remain in the battered bastion to tend the wounded, French sources said today.

GENEVA, May 19 -- Western delegates to the deadlocked conference on Far Eastern affairs were further depressed today by President Eisenhower's reference to the possibility that the United States might go ahead with a proposed Southeast Asian defense agreement without Britain.

A 20 per cent commutation fare increase and a new Pennsylvania Railroad investment of $5,000,000 in the Long Island Rail Road are under consideration as essential parts of a plan to rehabilitate the bankrupt commuter line.
BOSTON, May 19 -- A fourth postponement tomorrow of the adjourned annual meeting of the American Woolen Company was agreed to today.

The unequivocal statement of President Eisenhower yesterday that he hoped the McCarthy investigation would continue until the principals had told their stories should set at rest the suspicion voiced in some quarters that the Administration -- as well as some individual Republican politicians -- had been trying to shut off the hearings.
The consumer should be told exactly how a finished product made from textiles will perform, it was emphasized yesterday at a symposium of the American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists.

The total short interest on the New York Stock Exchange -- the position of those who sell stock they do not own with the expectation of being able to replace it at a lower price -- fell between April 15 and May 14. It was the first decline in a monthly report since that for the Dec. 15-Jan. 15 period.

Members of the Veteran Corps of Artillery of the State of New York, comprising the Military Society of the War of 1812 of which Col. Francis F. Steers is Commandant-President, will hold their annual Memorial Day luncheon and dance on May 31 at the Pierre.

NEW HAVEN, May 19 -- The Atomic Energy Commission will give Yale University and the University of California $1,200,000 each for the construction of heavy-particle accelerators for nuclear research, Yale authorities said today.

Investment banking syndicates headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. will place on the market today two new issues of public utility securities with a par value of $24,000,000. The money raised will be used largely to pay off bank loans and finance new construction. The offerings are as follows:

GUATEMALA, May 19 -- Nicaragua broke off diplomatic relations with Guatemala today. At noon, the Nicaraguan diplomatic staff of seven members and their families, headed by Ambassador Aurelio Montenegro, left the country.

Across the Harlem River from where he built his reputation, Vic Raschi showed New York baseball fans yesterday that he still was quite a pitcher. The former Yankee shut out the Giants, 3 -- 0, on five scattered singles to give the Cardinals a sweep of a two-game series before 6,663 spectators at the Polo Grounds.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- The big production push now is underway at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and stages that stood in silence a short while ago are bustling with activity.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 19 -- Negotiations for a settlement of the Standard Fruit Company strike broke down tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- Organization-backed Republicans and Democrats scored comparatively easy primary victories in Pennsylvania yesterday.
Five Governors who are scheduled to visit Korea will announce upon their arrival there the creation of a number of scholarships for Korean students, the American-Korean Foundation said yesterday.

ATLANTA, May 19 -- Attorney General Eugene Cook of Georgia today aligned himself with several other state leaders who said that "only as a last resort" would they back Gov. Herman Talmadge's private school plan to circumvent the Supreme Court's anti-hegregation decision.

The Board of Estimate will meet this afternoon behind closed doors to choose one of three available methods of raising the minimum of $30,000,000 needed to keep in balance the city's pending 1954-55 budget of $1,639,435,325.
LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- The decision outlawing segregation in United States public schools has won a good press over the non-Communist world, something the United States frequently does not get.

MONTAUK, L. I., May 19 -- Only an angler with a vivid imagination could have become seasick offshore today, for the only perceptible motion came as the result of the wake created by the thirty charter boats that were concentrated in a small area, casting and trolling for pollock.

An American edition of "The Way of the Four Winds," by Yrjo Kokko, will be published June 8 by Putnam. It presents in text and photographs a portrait of the Lapps of northern Finland and Scandinavia -- their land, their customs, their superstitions. Translated by Naomi Walford, the book has been a best-seller in Scandinavia and has received the Grand Literary Prize of the Finnish State.
VIENNA, May 19 -- With the dissent of only its four Communist members, the Austrian Parliament rejected today Monday's ultimatum by the Soviet High Commissioner to stop "anti-Russian intrigues."

Graduation exercises for 210 probationary patrolmen from the Police Academy were held yesterday at Police Headquarters. The additions bring the strength of the department to 19,738, still 1,140 short of the authorized quota of 20,878.
ALPINE, N. J., May 19 -- The Nathan M. Ohrbach Scoutarena of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, was dedicated this afternoon at Alpine Scout Camp.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The final session of the East Coast Conference on Migrants today approved Federal, interstate and intrastate plans to bring health, education and welfare services to the children of migrant laborers on the East Coast.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 19 -- The possible sale of copper to the Soviet Union and its satellites continues to be a live topic of debate here although the Government has blocked such moves up to now.

BALTIMORE, May 19 (UP) -- The Baltimore Orioles put on a rare hitting display in the sixth inning tonight, smashing six consecutive safe blows good for four runs. Joe Coleman used the rally for a 5-3 victory over the Washington Senators, his third in a row and fourth of the season.
CHICAGO, May 19 -- Because Chico Carrasquel, the usually slick-fielding shortstop of the White Sox, misplayed two grounders today at Corniskey Park, the Yankees downed the Pale Hose, 3 -- 2.
Senator Karl E. Mundt told the television networks yesterday that the public hearings on the McCarthy - Army controversy would be resumed Monday at 10 A. M.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, said today that Government restrictions on liquor advertising would establish a precedent that could lead to a "general Federal censorship" of the press and radio.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved a $484,095,500 Army civil functions appropriations bill. This is a 12 per cent increase over the amount voted by the House of Representatives.

DETROIT, May 19 (UP) -- Dr. Nathan P. Feinsinger, a University of Wisconsin professor, has been appointed umpire of the labor contract between the General Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers, C. I. O.

Early this month we had the first major statistical evidence that the contraction in business which began in the third quarter of 1953 might have begun to flatten out. This came in the form of the monthly report on unemployment (issued jointly for the first time by the Commerce and Labor Departments).

Traffic signal lights on Park Avenue between Eighty-sixth and 110th Streets failed yesterday when rain damaged a master controller. Soon after the lights went out at 5:10 P. M., two automobiles collided at the intersection of Park Avenue and East 105th Street.
Canadian governmental, industrial and cultural activities will be brought under one roof in mid-Manhattan, according to plans announced yesterday by Ray Lawson, the Canadian Consul General here.

Diplomas were given yesterday afternoon to seventy-eight nurses from St. Luke's Hospital, Morningside Heights. Miss Kathryn Helm, nursing director, presented the graduates to J. Stewart Baker, hospital president, who distributed the diplomas. The exercises were conducted at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

This country is sending more raw cotton overseas these days than it did at the same time last year. Now trade insiders are revising upwards their earlier estimates of cotton exports for the season that started Aug. 1, 1953, and ends July 31.
A state legislative investigation has been started into organizations that allegedly use for communistic or other propaganda purposes funds they collect in the name of charity.
DETROIT, May 19 (UP) -- As Kaline singled to left field with none out and the bases loaded in the ninth inning today to give the Detroit Tigers a 4-to-3 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it was making facilities at its Idaho Materials Testing Station available to non-Government users -- apparently a step toward bringing private industry into the nuclear-power field.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Senate approved today a bill providing $5,700,796,413 to operate the Veterans' Administration, Atomic Energy Commission and a score of other Government agencies during the 1955 fiscal year that begins July 1.

ALTHOUGH the music of "Fledermaus" is lovely, a theatregoer cannot help noticing the book. And although the singers are enchanting in the production that opened at the City Center last evening, they do have a plot to contend with.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 19 -- Margaret (Peggy) Mackie of the Inwood Country Club shot 37, 38 -- 75, three strokes over par, to win the low gross prize in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's opening tournament of the season at the Creek Club today. Mrs. Bernard Freeman, Inwood, and Mrs. R. M. Torgerson, Creek, were tied for second with 76's.
BARI, Italy, May 18 -- Inland from this coast is where one finds the "monster villages," one of the major social and economic problems of southern Italy.

While the Senate Subcommittee on Investigations is in recess considering the privilege against disclosure of the Executive branch of the Government, it may be worth while to take a second look at the privilege asserted by Senator McCarthy -- namely, his refusal to disclose the "informant" who gave him a copy of a security memorandum.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to become involved in the battle for control of the New York Central Railroad Company.

Fish sticks are the newest best seller in supermarkets. They are boneless oblongs, four inches long and three-quarters of an inch square, which are breaded, deep-fat fried, frozen and packaged. Like other heat-and-eat foods, they appeal to the cook who demands convenience.
TORONTO, May 19 -- Rubens' "Elevation of the Cross," purchased by the Toronto Art Gallery in 1928 for $27,000, was stolen from the gallery last night and found abandoned today.

Your recent editorial "Trial by Newspaper" is just what the public knows it can expect from The New York Times. As you say, "the courts, the bar and conscientious journalists have all been troubled" by the issue of properly commenting on pending litigation while avoiding impinging upon the guarantee of a fair trial.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 19 -- West Germany has canceled the appointment of a former Nazi party member as Bonn's observer at the United Nations.
Sauerkraut, apples and various cuts of pork will be heavily promoted in the fall as a hearty dish for dinner.

Wagner, helped by Bob Piela's three hits, defeated Hofstra in a Metropolitan Conference game, 4 to 2, at Grymes Hill, Staten Island, yesterday. With the score tied at 2 -- all in the eighth inning, the third baseman singled homo one run. The second run of the inning scored from third on a sacrifice fly by Bill May.

WESTPORT, Conn., May 19 -- Alan U. Parcell, a landscape contractor, has received permission to resume the gravel digging that for five years has been exasperating a New York advertising executive living on the dusty perimeter.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 19 (UP) -- Charles P. Farnsley, chairman of the Louisville Philharmonic Society's commissioning project, announced today the award of commissions to twelve more composers.

GENEVA, May 20 -- The World Health Organization has voted to assess the United States Government $350,000 more for 1955 than Congress has authorized as the United States contribution to this organization.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 20 (AP) -- The Argentine Federal police seized today copies of the illustrated magazine Esto Es (Here it is) from newsstands in Buenos Aires.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 20 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appealed today to the free world to give the Nationalists a "reasonable amount of moral and material support" to retake the Communist-held mainland of China.

John Collier will retire next month as professor in City College's Department of Sociology and Anthropology, but the job will stay in the family. Succeeding him will be his wife, Dr. Laura M. Thompson.
Hundreds of high school students staged a running melee yesterday on I. R. T. subway trains and stations between the Van Cortlandt Park terminal and Ninety-sixth Street.

The New York School of Social Work observed its first Founders Day yesterday, honoring the memory of Robert W. de Forest, who before the turn of the century had the vision to see that wise application of philanthropy required training as well as goodwill. He fostered the idea of professional education for social work and, as president of the Charity Organization Society, founded in 1898 the first graduate school of social work in the world.

OSSINING, N. Y., May 20 -- The Rev. Francis J. Mulligan of Jersey City, Roman Catholic pastor of St. Lawrence Parish at Renaico, Chile, suffocated early last Sunday morning when fire destroyed his overnight quarters in a rectory at Portezuelo, Chile, according to a cable received today at Maryknoll Seminary here.
LONDON, May 20 -- Stocks continued to advance here today under the influence of favorable company statements.

The purchase of about 41 per cent of the common stock of Robbins Mills, Inc., was announced yesterday by J. P. Stevens Co., Inc. The stock was owned by Karl Robbins, chairman of the Robbins board, and his family.

TUCSON, Ariz., May 20 -- After seeing an aircraft modification operation here dwindle from 4,000employes to a few score in the last year and a half, Tucson got a big uplift today when Douglas Aircraft signed a lease for 600,000 square feet at Tucson Municipal Airport.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- An effort appeared in the making today to sidetrack a fight over "one-man rule" of the Atomic Energy Commission.
Rail shares rumbled ahead yesterday and carried the market as a whole to the highest levels since mid-1930.

Two air-raid sirens went off unofficially in mid - Manhattan yesterday shortly after 2:30 P. M. Persons in the streets near by paid little heed, however, but there were many inquiring telephone calls to police stations, Civil Defense headquarters and newspaper offices.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 20 -- The undeclared guerrilla warfare in west-central Java has cost 374 lives in the first four months of this year, according to official dispatches from Bandung, capital of West Java.
Despite current uncertainties, Belgium will continue to work for expansion of trade with this country, it was asserted yesterday by the Belgian Ambassador to the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today a plan for reorganizing its operations to make them more economical and efficient.

Members of the women's committee of the Judson Health Center held their annual meeting and tea yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the organization at 34 Spring Street. Plans were discussed for the annual tea dance and fashion show for the benefit of the center, to be held on Nov. 11 at the Plaza.

OTTAWA, May 20 -- Although a start on the construction of the St. Lawrence power and Seaway projects is being held up pending a decision by the United States Supreme Court, the Canadian Government today called for applications from egineers for the navigation part of the works.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Uranium prospectors swarming over the Colorado plateau have unearthed "major" resources of fissionable materials, an Atomic Energy Commission official said today.

Seven apartment buildings, six of which are at Broadway and West 137th Street, have been sold by the Bernheimer Company to a syndicate of investors in a deal involving about $1,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

THERE'S an ultra-modern building at 275-277 Pearl Street incongruously hemmed in by faded and weathered century-old, blackened red brick structures. It houses the offices of Rudman Scofield, manufacturers of metal equipment for ships.

Somewhere along the 236 miles of rapid transit routes in New York City every day, a man often sits down beside the third-rail and drills holes in it while a lethal charge of 600 volts passes through the rail; the drill and his body.

A Canadian and two New Yorkers were named yesterday as the winners of Pulitzer Traveling Scholarships at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. The announcement was made by Dr. Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the school.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The House of Representatives inquiry into educational and philanthropic foundations turned today to possible evidence that some had engaged in "propaganda."

The English won the opening bout but the Americans captured the tournament. That was the story last night as boxers from the Boys Club of New York defeated the London Federation of Boys Clubs, 12 -- 3, at the St. Nicholas Arena.

BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP) -- Eleven 3-year-olds were entered today for the seventy-eighth and richest of all Preakness Stakes as rain blown in on a nor'easter pelted Pimlico and left the track in an extra sloppy condition.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The State Department ordered the United States representative today to raise for discussion at the next meeting of the four-power Allied Council for Austria the Soviet Union's recent "allegations and treats" against the Austrian Government.

A new flurry in the relations between the United States and our allies has been created by President Eisenhower's remark at his Wednesday press conference that, given essential cooperation by Australia, New Zealand and, above all, by the proper Asian nations, a workable Southeast Asian defense system might be established without Britain, even though it would not be as broad or satisfactory as we might wish.
NEW DELHI, India, May 20 -- The Indian Government has lodged a protest with the Soviet Embassy here against the employment of Indian nationals in Communist espionage activities abroad.

GUATEMALA, May 20 -- Virtually all operations of the United Fruit Company's banana holdings on the Atlantic Coast were paralyzed today when 4,000 workers struck for higher wages. About 2,000 acres were affected.

While the Dodgers and Giants flagging attacks, the Yankees fretted over ways of spurring came home triumphantly from the West yesterday bubbling confidence over their prospects of soon taking charge of the American League pennant race.
LONDON, May 20 -- Britain's newspapers today won a battle for an extra 50,000 tons of Scandinavian newsprint that may make possible the end of rationing of pages in 1955.

PARIS, May 20 -- The French Government replaced its Resident General in the protectorate of Morocco today. The action was the first step in dealing with anti-French terrorism and resistance, which have reached alarming proportions.
PITTSBURGH, May 20 (UP) -The St. Louis Cardinals stretched their National League lead to a game and a half tonight by blasting six Pittsburgh Pirate pitchers for seventeen hits and a 17-4 victory.
DETROIT, May 20 -- A leading Protestant theologian warned today against what he described as the dangerous rise to influence of the "invisible informer."
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 20 -- Ray Jenkins, back from Washington, had a toothache treated today.

The late Robert W. de Forest, one of the founders of what has become the New York School of Social Work, and a man given much of the credit for turning social work from an avocation to a profession, was honored at a celebration at the school yesterday afternoon.

Harry Cohen has leased an industrial building at Grand Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street in Maspeth, Queens, from the Kolac Realty Company. The structure, containing 7,500 square feet of space, will be used for manufacturing and distribution.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 20 -- Like Rip Van Winkle, a group of Dutchmen got together here today and pretended time had stood still.

BOSTON, May 20 -- Sherman Adams, chief assistant to President Eisenhower, restated today the Administration's intention of taking "second place to no agency of government" in protecting the internal security of the nation.
YONKERS, May 20 (AP) -- Meadow Abbe stepped through a mile of mud in 2:13 4-5 tonight to win the $4,000 Washington pace, the feature of the Grand Circuit program at Yonkers Raceway.
CAIRO, May 19 -- The Arab plan for the development of water resources in the Jordan River Valley would give nearly one-fifth of the Jordan River waters to Israel.

BOSTON, May 20 -- New England's cotton manufacturers, marking the centennial of their industry association today, were told that their faith in the region was "an inspiration to the entire community."
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Eisenhower's recommendation for modification of the Social Security retirement test was approved today by the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 20 -- Union and management officials said tonight that an agreement had been reached as a basis for ending the ten-month-old strike at the Hat Corporation of America plant in Norwalk.
LONDON, April 19 -- Norman Hartnell, for seventeen years the undisputed king of England's fashion designers, may soon have to squeeze aside on his throne to make room for somebody else.
The Transit Authority postponed yesterday until Monday action on recommendations by a fact-finding committee for labor peace on the city-owned transit system.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- United States corporations put $1,800,000,000 of new securities up for sale in the first three months of this year -- 10 per cent less than in the corresponding months of 1953 -- the securities and exchange commission reported today.
The resignation of Fourth Deputy Police Commissioner George P. Mitchell, former Chief of Detectives, is expected on his return from vacation June 10.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The Navy admitted today that it had made some "substantial -- although honest -- mistakes" in carrying out a 1951 tugboat construction program.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross released yesterday a letter from Dr. William M. Markel, Administrator of the Red Cross's New York Regional Blood Program, submitting his resignation from the board of directors of the Blood Banks Association of New York State.
The Italian Line will move from the American Export Line pier at West Forty-fourth Street after July 1 and is now looking around the port for docking facilities.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy tonight accused President Eisenhower and his Administration of invoking the "Fifth Amendment" to bar possibly self-incriminatory testimony about high-level strategy decisions.
Three unions operating in the retail, wholesale, distributive and processing fields were reported yesterday to be ready to merge into a single union of 140,000 members.

GUATEMALA, May 20 -- Washington's outcry over this country's purchase of arms from Communist sources in Europe appears to have boomeranged. It has achieved, for Guatemala, a greater degree of national unity than she has experienced in a long time.

A $500,000,000,000 opportunity lies before all Americans, and it calls for the greatest individual and industrial effort in peacetime history. This is the thesis of a booklet, "The Future of America," produced by The Advertising Council as a public service and released yesterday at a luncheon of the council's directors at the Pierre Hotel.

BOSTON, May 20 -- Joseph B. Ely, attorney for the American Woolen Company, was elected president of the organization today. The action was taken by the directors a few hours after a fourth postponement of an attempt to complete the annual meeting.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 20 -- Gen. Paul Ely, Chief of the French General Staff, continued to gather information here today on the military and political situation in northern Indo-China.
Robert R. Young acknowledged yesterday that he had not met seven of his fifteen proposed directors for the New York Central Railroad Company before their nomination.

THE lowering clouds and sporadic rain which brought frowns between the eyes of local anglers yesterday apparently did not spread as far as the Catskills. The reports received during the afternoon indicated good prospects for the week-end.
While the change in woman's status is the "outstanding social fact of this century," women should realize that it is just a beginning, says Mrs. Lucille Milner.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- Roger Seydoux, Minister-counselor to the French Embassy in Washington, said today that France "is doing its utmost to reach an agreement on honorable terms" in Indo-China "just as an armistice was concluded in Korea" but "if we fail" the rest of the free nations "will have to join in the fight * * * with troops."
GENEVA, May 20 -- Prince Wan Waithayakon, Foreign Minister of Thailand, emphasized today his country's readiness to join in a southeast Asia defense system.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- New Zealand, in effect, served notice today that she would not join a Southeast Asian defense alliance unless Britain were a member.

Your May 14 editorial entitled "Elections for Korea" carries an unjustifiable innuendo that the Republic of Korea delegation to the Geneva conference opposes its own Government. The delegation has done nothing to justify such a supposition. We request that you rectify this wrong impression.

It was on this day in 1927 that Captain Lindbergh's graywhite monoplane touched down at Le Bourget Field and touched off the stampede of nearly 100,000 spectators there. That makes it the twentyseventh anniversary of the flight, and no one gets excited over twentyseventh anniversaries of anything. Were it the twenty-fifth or the fiftieth, of course, much would be made of it: historians and publicists pounce upon such milestones.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- New Jersey's 485 savings and loan associations increased their assets by more than $142,000,000 during 1953 to a record $1,100,000,000

MINNEAPOLIS, May 20 (AP)-- Gideon. D. Seymour, vice president and executive editor of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, idled late today of a heart attack. He was 52 years old. Mr. Seymour had suffered a heart attack llate last December was and hospitalized for two months. He had returned to his office April 1.

The development of a new commercially available serum against rabies was announced here yesterday. It appears to increase the effectiveness of available rabies vaccines and might eventually replace painful rabies vaccines altogether.

ALBANY, May 20 (UP) -- The State Court of Appeals ruled today that a drunken driving conviction based on a blood test was valid, even though the police had failed to tell the defendant he had a right to reject the test. The decision was unanimous.

The Light Metals Refining Corporation announced yesterday the development of a new process for refining beryllium and other metals from ores, using a powerful electric arc like those employed in large military search-lights.

The Government subpoenaed yesterday the financial records of the old International Longshoremen's Association. The action was taken to determine the union's ability to pay a fine of $50,000 imposed last week for criminal contempt of...

The conduct of just one delinquent youngster compelled to remain in school when he does not want to can prevent 160 normal pupils from getting the education they do want, a special conference on youth problems was told yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) -- Bob Carpenter, owner of the Philadelphia Phillies, apologized today for the public embarrassment caused Granny Hamner by a private detective the club hired to see whether players were observing the curfew rules.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The American Federation of Labor prepared today to urge a world-wide union boycott on the handling, transportation or purchase of goods produced by slave labor behind the Iron Curtain.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 6 points lower to 2 points higher than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- During this dismal interval in the capital's history, the most edifying show in Washington has been Robinson Jeffers' "The Cretan Woman," now reaching the end of its run at the Arena Stage.
CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- There has not been a single case of serious reaction or death among the 438,000 school children getting inoculations of the Salk polio vaccine.

Long, blue - clad columns of firefighters paid a final honor yesterday to Dr. Harry M. Archer, who had served them tirelessly for a lifetime. Led by city officials, they escorted Dr. Archer's flag - draped coffin down Fifth Avenue from Fifty-fifth Street to St. Patrick's Cathedral at Fiftieth Street.

Striking workers of the United Fruit Company have replied to a Honduran Government proposal for negotiations today with a letter saying that "we will fix the date, hour and place for any meetings," according to a message received by The New York Times from a United Fruit representative at Tegucigalpa last night.
TOKYO, May 20 -- Japan will use the arms provided by the United States under the Mutual Defense Assistance agreement only if attacked, Premier Shigeru Yoshida told Parliament today.

Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey made a half-hour inspection of the Port of New York Authority's new pier in Hoboken yesterday. He described the ultra-modern, partly completed structure as complementary to his state's natural advantages as a world shipping terminus.

CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP) -- Republic Steel Corporation said today it would use the "delivered pricing" method in sale of cold finished carbon bars, effective on Monday. Under this method, a base price is quoted to the customer in published lists for bars delivered anywhere in the country.

Unlike the New York Stock Exchange, which reported a drop of about 50,000 shares in the aggregate short interest between April 15 and May 14, the American Stock Exchange yesterday reported a gain of 10,671 shares over the same period.

Irene Mayer Selznick is no longer wondering about the identity of her next production. It's a symbolical comedy by Enid Bagnold called "The Chalk Garden," dealing with a fashionable grandmother and her grand-daughter. Better known as a novelist, Miss Bagnold hasn't been represented here as a dramatist since she made her debut with "Gertie" (1952).
ALBANY, May 20 -- Lobbyists spent $89,552 to influence the passage or defeat of legislation during the 1954 session.

MONTREAL, May 20 (Canadian Press) -- Two of thirty-six British seamen convicted and sentenced Tuesday on charges of failing to obey their captains' orders, were freed today on bail of $200 each. Released were Bernard Lafferty of the freighter Shelldrake and Ronald Barker of the freighter Cibou.
VIENNA, May 20 (AP) -- Official Czechoslovak election figures indicated today anti-Communist opposition apparently was far greater than even the Reds were willing to admit.

" ATOMIC ATTACK," presented Tuesday evening over the A. B. C. network, was a drama bound to hold a viewer's attention. Its theme alone -- an unannounced hydrogen bomb attack on New York -- is one about which everyone would rather not think, yet inevitably does. For a play there hardly could be a more timely if ominous plot.

Costumed throngs at the annual "Spring Fantasia" of Artists Equity Association last night drew broad inspiration from the theme of the ball. Fantasy was interpreted as colorfully and, at times, as weirdly by the revelers that milled about in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor Hotel as it had been by Equity artists whose "fantasia" murals and mobiles decorated the setting.
GUATEMALA, May 20 -- The Guatemalan Government has permitted the re-entry of Sydney Gruson, New York Times correspondent who was expelled last February as "undesirable."
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department offered today to sell surplus feed grains for export at world price levels, which are sharply below the United States support price.

On sales of $294,892,434, Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., had a consolidated net income of $12,421,638 in the fiscal year ended March 31. In the preceding fiscal year a net of $11,345,200 was realized on sales of $314,894,718, before the acquisition of Benson Hedges.

President Eisenhower allowed the nine-year term of Chairman Gordon R. Clapp of the Tennessee Valley Authority to expire last Tuesday without any word of appreciation. Apparently his attention was called to this omission and on Wednesday the White House released a letter to Mr. Clapp expressing "appreciation and thanks" for his service to the Government.
The proposed extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services was unanimously rejected yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- During the week ended May 19, member bank reserves increased $205,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Stockholders of Alexander Smith, Inc., at their annual meeting here yesterday approved an increase of 450,000 shares in the authorized common stock. There are 937,925 shares outstanding of the 1,050,000 authorized common shares of $20 par.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Allen B. DuMont, head of the DuMont television network, recommended to Congress today that the Government intervene, possibly with network regulations, to prevent a television broadcasting monopoly.

The A. B. C. and Du Mont television networks will continue to televise the Army-McCarthy hearings in full when the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations reconvenes next Monday. Assuming that the sessions follow their previous time schedule, the proceedings will be presented here daily over Channels 5 and 7 from 10 A. M. to 12:30 P. M. and from 2 to 5 P. M.

One of the most popular victories of the season, outside of a performance by Native Dancer, was recorded by Col. Lafayette Henry Nelles' Extra Points at Belmont Park yesterday. Competing against four others in the $8,850 Charles L. Appleton Memorial Steeplechase, Extra Points had little trouble scoring, beating Mrs. Vernon G. Cardy's Sun Shower by three lengths.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 -- Establishment of an all-embracing national union of writers working in motion pictures, television and radio was approved unanimously last night by members of the Screen Writers Guild. The new body is to be set up in two sections and known as the American Writers Guild, West, Inc., and the American Writers Guild, East, Inc.
There is a tiny island in the East River where "out-of-thisworld" youngsters are being coaxed to exchange fantasy for reality.

ALBANY, May 20 (AP) -- Nathaniel Goldstein, State Attorney General, held informally today that a new state law does not prevent a part-time local public officer paid less than $5,000 a year from holding race track stock.

GENEVA, May 20 -- Thailand is concerned over the spread of Communist influence in Indo-China and is considering whether to submit an appeal to the United Nations. If she does so, well-informed sources believe the General Assembly may be called into special session this summer.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Eisenhower disclosed today that he would accept a one-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act in place of the three-year extension he had asked of Congress.
Discrimination and segration in housing are still the rule, but there is reason for viewing the future with optimism.

SAUK CITY, Wis., May 20 (UP) -- Le Roy Gore said today his "Joe Must Go" drive to recall Senator Joseph R. McCarthy would fail unless "this sleeping giant of anti-McCarthyism can be aroused" in Wisconsin's urban centers.

It seems highly desirable and not at all paradoxical that white people of the South who are possessed of funds should now become generous contributors to the campaign chest of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- A new derivative of isoniazid -- as yet unnamed and referred to as RO-24939 -- may have advantages over the parent drug, which has been used with much success in the last two years to treat tuberculosis.

The great majority of Puerto Rican people living here have adjusted successfully to our way of life and are making positive contributions to it, Mayor Wagner said this week as he announced the establishment of a new Committee on Puerto Rican Affairs.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 677,581 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Eisenhower and the Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, declared today that only a free and productive economy would enable the United States to remain strong and secure in a position of world leadership.

At its annual meeting last night the New York County Lawyers Association elected William J. O'Shea of Saxe, Bacon, O'Shea Bryan as its president. He will succeed Edwin M. Otterbourg, who had served two years.
" Grave misgivings" were expressed yesterday by the Civil Service Reform Association over phases of a proposed new pay plan for city employes that is scheduled to go into effect July 1.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Friday May 21 -- A spectacular fire, fanned by a northeast wind, virtually destroyed early today a four-story apartment house on the ocean front at Loch Arbour, just north of the Boardwalk here. All thirty families were reported evacuated without incident.

Permission was granted to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday to appeal from the Appellate Division reversal of the conviction before General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente of Minot F. Jelke for compulsory prostitution.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., May 20 -The Rabbinical Assembly of America deplored today the spreading "climate of fear" and "mutual distrust" that has "silenced" those who would dissent from popular opinion.
Frank J. Sampson, who left office last Jan. 1 as City Hall patronage dispenser, lost another job yesterday. Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. dropped him as an honorary battalion chief.

Your editorial of May 16 "The Great Dilemma" raises a standard to which men and women of goodwill can rally, particularly that part in which you advocate the propaganda of the deed as well as of the word, defining the propaganda of the word as consisting of "friendliness, of a new humility, unfeigned acceptance of men of different races and different colors as brothers."

The greatest test of true charity is that a gift go from an unknown donor to an unknown recipient. The Greater New York Fund is the most all-inclusive and largest non-sectarian appeal in New York. When you make a contribution to help all of the 423 agencies participating in the Fund, you are giving in the widest and truest sense of charity to help your fellow men in this area.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., May 20 -Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis took low gross honors in the second one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association over the Scarsdale course today. Despite rainy weather, Mrs. Choate, TriCounty champion, had a 41, 39 -80.
PARIS, May 20 (Reuters) -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, warned here tonight that "time is swiftly running out for the world of free men."

Events tonight: Ellen Wright, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall 8:30 P. M.; Letitia Kaye, soprano, Steinway Hall, 8:30; I. S. C. M. concert McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30; Marco Sorisio, tenor, School of Education Auditorium, New York University, 8:30; Bach Festival, High School of Music and Art, 8; Queens Symphony Orchestra, Forest Hills High School Auditorium, 8:30.
