Oregon awarded $10,000,000, of state veterans welfare bonds maturing in 1968 yesterday to a syndicate jointly managed by C. J. Devine Co. and Smith, Barney Co.

The operations of the New York City Center of Music and Drama from April 26, 1953, to April 24, 1954, rejected in an operating loss of $227,135.27, it was announced yesterday by Newbold Morris, chairman, at the eleventh annual members' meeting of the City Center.
LACROSSE, Wis., May 20 (AP) -- The Pentagon's atomic coordinator proposed tonight immediate formation of an agency to push a highspeed program for peace-time nuclear power development.

Former Senator William Benton of Connecticut last night criticized Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. and Commissioner of Internal Revenue T. Coleman Andrews for not prosecuting Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for his "strange financial transactions."

The dollar volume of new drafts drawn by United States exporters on Latin-American importers during April increased by 32 per cent over the March level, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the draft experience of fifteen banks.

It's no secret among baseball followers that the Giants have to make their pennant run on pitching and defense -- particularly pitching. Runs don't come easy for the Giants. They get the long ball now and then, mostly at the Polo Grounds. They hit-and-run to fairly good effect. But they hardly have an overwhelming attack.

Ground will be broken this year for a plant pathology and research laboratory at the New York Botanical Garden, costing $650,000, Dr. William J. Robbins, director, told the garden's annual meeting yesterday. It will be a two-story glass structure facing the administration building in Bronx Park.

LA CEIBA, Honduras, May 20 -- The Standard Fruit Company's fourteen-day strike was settled last night. It was the first break in the wave of stoppages that has brought commerce on the north coast to a standstill.

Dr. Charles Sandler, chairman of the reference committee of the New York State Medical Society, clarified yesterday the position of the society's Heure of Delegates when it disapproved a so-called Tennessee plan at its convention May 11.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., May 20 -- The State Council of Parks voted unanimously today to oppose any mining or mineral exploration operations in any of New York's eighty state parks.
Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams is experiencing the first organized opposition from the public in his extensive plans to reorganize the Police Department.

RABAT, May 20 -- Pierre Voizard, French Resident General in Tunisia, is making a determined effort to cope with the difficult problem of banditry in the central part of the country before the coming elections.

LONDON, May 20 -- Prime Minister Churchill declared today that Britons "must bear in mind" that the opening of French-United States talks on Indo-China was inconsistent with the spirit of the Western Alliance.

Commodity futures moved up irregularly on the New York exchanges yesterday. Coffee, cottonseed oil, zinc, tin, lead, burlap and silk closed higher; rubber lower, and cocoa, sugar, hides, soybean oil, potatoes, wool and copper mixed.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 20 -- With a one-over-par round of 74, Henry Kowal of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., won the qualifying medal in the forty-fourth Walter J. Travis Memorial tournament at the Garden City Golf Club today.

Inconsiderate and over-ambitious fleet operating schedules and subordination of the line officer to specialists and "shore-side" personnel are among the internal factors in the Navy that make for reduced morale.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- In the sixteen months this Administration has been in office it has encountered a set of hard facts -- some implicit in a political system of checks and balances, some inherited and some created by adverse events -- which its recruits from business have discovered cannot be overcome by the methods familiar to them, and which its recruits from politics have discovered cannot be eliminated by the stratagems of their trade.

To those millions of us who spent our youth in segregated Negro schools of the South and know the psychological and spiritual damage of segregation the unanimous decision of the Supreme Court outlawing segregation in the public schools does much to heal a deep wound.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- William Cashore, a tall handsome boy who refused to be flustered by a bevy of tongue-twisters, walked off with the national spelling bee championship today.

TORONTO, May 18 -- Crude rock carvings discovered in soft limestone northeast of here were probably the artistry of Algonquian Indians who roamed the area before the white man came to southern Ontario.
The fact that eggs have been selling at their lowest price since June, 1950, suggests their generous use in custards, a dessert held in highest favor by gourmets and good cooks everywhere.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- An increase in Federal funds for research in the fields of mental health, neurology, blindness, arthritis and metabolic diseases was urged today before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 20 -Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the board of the Studebaker Corporation, former Marshall Plan administrator and a personal friend of President Eisenhower, will speak to the Indiana chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union here Tuesday.

Supreme Court Justice Nicholas M. Pette reserved decision yesterday on a motion to dismiss a suit by four tenants of Glen Oaks Village, Queens, for a rent reduction through the recovery of a $4,000,000 mortgage to which the builders allegedly were not entitled.
The author of Britain's comprehensive social security system said here last night that in his country socialized medicine "has come to stay."

The election of Lewis A. Lapham, executive vice president of the Grace Line, as a director of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York was announced yesterday by William F. Giesen, general manager.
Former Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink was appointed yesterday as trial examiner of the Board of Education. He succeeds Arthur Levitt, who recently was elected president of the board.

City College honored twenty-nine varsity athletes last night at its ninth annual all-sports program in the college's main gymnasium. Warren Neuberger, a pitcher, Jerry Domershick, captain of the basketball team, and Steve Levin, captain of the wrestling squad, received two awards each.

EDDIE STANKY never was one to stare supercritically at gift horses. He accepts them without question. Hence he didn't even raise an eyebrow when his St. Louis Cardinals surged into the National League lead for the first time the other day. If he was surprised, he failed to show it.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 20 -- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo said today that Communists had been responsible for recent widespread labor troubles in Chile. He said he was determined to find means to defeat the Reds.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended May 15 were 8 per cent below sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Watermelons are here. On street corners in at least one part of town slim pink slices are being sold from trucks in individual portions -- 5 or 10 cents a slice. Restaurants are showing big green melons in their windows. Reporting a city-wide price on watermelons for the first time this year, the Department of Markets advises that they are being offered generally on fruitstalls at 10 cents a pound.
TRENTON, May 20 -- An increase of $28,500,000 in this year's state aid to schools was virtually assured today as the result of major defections in the State Assembly.
WASHINGTON, MAY 20 -- The general services administration announced today it had signed a contract with the Anaconda Sales Company for the purchase of 64,000 tons of Chilean copper.

LONDON, May 20 -- The United States Government was reported today to be prepared to approach Egypt with Britain for settlement of the two-year-old deadlock on evacuating Britain's 80,000 troops from the Suez Canal base.

BONN, Germany, May 20 -- The debate on the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union is continuing despite Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's efforts to prevent a new departure in West German foreign policy now.

PARIS, May 20 (AP) -- The "big four" of amateur tennis -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas of the United States and Australia's Lewis Hoad and Ken Rosewall -advanced without the loss of a set today into the third round of the men's singles in the French international tennis championships.

DETROIT, May 20 (AP) -- American Motors Corp. declared an initial dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share today, payable at June 24 to stock of record June 7. American Motors was formed by the consolidation of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation and Hudson Motor Car Company.

The New York Life Insurance Company has leased for its Manhattan branch office almost all of the third floor in the fifteen-story office building nearing completion at 579 Fifth Avenue, one of two similar structures being built by the Rovi Corporation on the same blockfront.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, May 21 (AP) -- Liberal party followers of President Syngman Rhee appeared today within reach of a majority in the one-house National Assembly as unofficial returns from yesterday's election reached the 80 per cent mark.

ROME, May 20 -- Pope Pius XII held today his first consistory since his grave illness earlier this year. Twenty Cardinals and about 100 Archbishops and Bishops gave their formal approval to the canonization of Pope Pius X and five others.

HAMILTON, N. Y., May 20 -- Colgate University students have voted, 748--331, to establish within their own student governing organizations procedures aimed at eliminating fraternity discrimination on the campus within ten years.

Today's new film is "Blackout," a suspense melodrama produced by Lippert-Hammer and starring Dane Clark, at the Palace. Michael Carreras produced the British-made offering and Terence Fisher directed from a screen play by Richard Landau, Belinda Leo and Betty Ann Davies head the supporting cast.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UP) -- The Senate today approved by a voice vote legislation that would limit the right of federal savings and loan associations to establish branch offices.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 20 -- The Workmen's Circle, the oldest Jewish labor fraternal organization in the country, voted unanimously here today to establish a comprehensive health insurance plan for its branches in fifteen major cities.
With the arrest yesterday of two men, the Kings County District Attorney's office announced it had started a drive against unscrupulous practices by auto repair service men.
A man who should know said yesterday that supply has generally caught up with demand in one of the nation's most spectacular "war baby" industries.
CHICAGO, May 20 -- The wheat market showed an inclination to rally early today, but the volume of buying was not especially great and prices receded sharply.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., May 20 -- Eighty members of the South Mountain district of Boy Scouts here have learned a lesson in botany the hard way.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Almost forty of the leading scientists of the United States and the official journal of the atomic scientists today charged the Government with a breach of faith in suspending the security clearance of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer.
The Pabst Brewing Company, through its subsidiary, the Hoffman Beverage Company, will enter the cola beverage field on Monday.

DUBLIN, May 20 -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera conceded defeat tonight. Final returns of Tuesday's general election showed that his Fianna Fail (Party of Destiny) had failed to win a majority in the new Dail (Parliament) and that his opponents would be able to form the coalition government they had promised.
CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Hog producers encountered another over-supplied market today and prices tumbled 25 cents to $1 a hundred pounds. Cattle were steady to 50 cents lower and sheep steady.

Combined production of newsprint mills in the United States and Canada during April amounted to 590,038 tons, a new record for that month, it was reported yesterday by the Newsprint Service Bureau. In April of last year the output was 568,510 tons.

This is a day for pride! The Supreme Court of the United States stands as the symbol of the democratic process. We rejoice for our Negro citizens, but we recognize that the decision banning racial segregation in public schools is a victory for American ideals.

Joey Giardello, 23-year-old Philadelphia middleweight who has stopped his last three opponents on technical knockouts, will face Pierre Langlois of Pont-Audemer France, in the feature test of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 -- A United Nations report has warned that rapidly accelerating demands of industry on the world's water resources are growing acute.

MOSCOW, May 20 -- The newspaper Red Star reported today that a military tribunal of the Kiev district had condemned Vasily Ostapovich Okhrimovich to death as a spy for the United States and that he had been shot.

The financial program of the Eisenhower Administration aims at economy, lower taxes and "honest money," W. Randolph Burgess, deputy to the Secretary of the Treasury, said yesterday. He was addressing the eighty-eighth annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters.
ALBANY, May 20 -- The State Public Works Department announced today the low bid on the last highway contract for the 427-mile main route of the Thruway.

Repayments by public utilities were the major influence in a decline of $23,000,000 in New York bank loans to business last week. The reduction, during the week ended on Wednesday, was the eighth registered in the last nine weeks.

The usual week-end practice of evening up holdings limited volume on the New York Commodity exchanges yesterday. Prices moved within narrow ranges. The markets closed irregularly higher with coffee, zinc, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes, silk and copper showing gains; cocoa, rubber, hides and tin easing and sugar, wool, burlap and lead ending mixed.
LIMA, Ohio, May 21 -- Mr. Leech was more puzzled than disturbed today.

Events tonight: Estonian Male Choir, Town Hall, 8 P. M.; Carnegie Pop Concert, Gershwin program, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and excerpts from "La Forza del Destino," Malin Auditorium, 225 West Forty-sixth Street, 8:15; "Aida," Amato Opera Theatre, 8:30; "Le pauvre matelot," "The Weeping Widow" and "Trial by Jury," Brooklyn College, 8:30.

BONN, Germany, May 21 -- The West German Government's draft law prohibiting cartels passed its first reading today in the Bundesrat, the upper house of Parliament. The draft was amended seventy-three times before it was approved without a roll call vote.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21 -- Sharp attacks on the new For America group and on the Eisenhower Administration's domestic and foreign policies highlighted today's sessions of the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the Workmen's Circle, the largest Jewish labor fraternal organization in the country.

White Skies, the fine sprinter owned by William M. Wickham, will undertake a difficult assignment in the Roseben Handicap at Belmont Park today. The 5-year-old son of Sun Again will carry 135 pounds in the seven-furlong test, giving away from 10 to 37 pounds to the fourteen who are listed to compete against him.

About five years ago Eileen, with chestnut hair and very blue eyes, got off the boat, fresh and healthy, from Galway, Ireland. She worked hard, lived in a cheap room, scrimped. Her letters home glowed with hope from the brave New World. Then a doctor found she had developed tuberculosis.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 21 (UP) -- The first American jazz festival will be held at Newport Casino July 17-18.
The legal aspects of the murder of three United States Army officers in Germany in 1946, as revealed yesterday, recall those surrounding the slaying of Maj. William V. Holohan in Italy in 1944.

Irving Billings has purchased the thirty-family apartment house at 25 Fleetwood Place in Irvington, N. J., from the 343 Anderson Avenue Corporation. $. L Kislak, Inc., was the broker. The building contains eighty-nine :rooms in suites of two and onehalf to four rooms.

DETROIT, May 21 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today new car sales are continuing on a "near-record" level and "firming industry hopes for a 5,000,000 plus sales year in 1954." "In definite prospect," the agency said, "is an unusually strong year-end sales push, based upon present sales trends and an anticipated minor boom in deferred automobile buying." January-June volume of retail sales, it added, is expected to total 2,740,000.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Consumer Price Index dropped again in the period from mid-March to mid-April.
A Senate Internal Security subcommittee heard yesterday that the volume of Communist propaganda coming here from abroad had increased "very materially" since 1951.

LOS ANGELES, May 22 (UP) -- Two world marks were chalked up tonight in the Coliseum Relays as Parry O'Brien broke his shot-put record with a toss of 60 feet 5 3/4 inches and a sensational Fordham University two-mile relay team clipped almost two seconds off the old record.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 21 (UP) -- An attempted Communist invasion of the Tachen Islands [cross on map] has been stalled and possibly defeated by Chinese Nationalist air power, authoritative sources said today.

Builders of non-segregated housing in the future will receive the full support of the Federal Housing Administration. That promise was made yesterday by the agency's new acting commissioner, Norman P. Mason.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- Elimination of the subsidy provision in the trade agreement between Italy and the American motion picture industry is being sought in preliminary discussions between the Motion Picture Association of America and the Italian Government and industry representatives. The pact expires in August.

PARIS, May 21 -- The military situation in Indo-China has been developing so fast that it is understood tonight that the French Government is under pressure to hasten decisions before action there would be too late.

DETROIT, May 21 (AP) -- Bob Keegan allowed only three singles -- two by Frank Bolling, rookie second baseman -- as he pitched the Chicago White Sox into third place tonight with an 8-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers before 41,641.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Democrats and Republicans clashed today in a wordy legalistic duel over the best means to get the Army's monitored telephone calls into the public record of its controversy with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
A new trophy, presented by Mayor Wagner, will be at stake when the Yankees and Dodgers clash at Yankee Stadium on Monday night, June 14, in their annual sandlot benefit exhibition game.

SEOUL, Korea, May 21 -- Final official returns from South Korea's national election showed tonight that President Syngman Rhee's Liberal party had won at least a slim majority in the new National Assembly.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 -- President Carlos del Campo Ibanez opened an ordinary session of Congress with his annual message to the people. He urged the need for belt-tightening, suspension of party strife, removal of parliamentary obstructionist tactics, reinforcement of the Presidential powers and the stamping out of all Communist-inspired activities.

Three public representatives on the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange have been re-appointed for one-year terms. They are John Sloan Hickey, president of Dartmouth College; Clarence Francis, chairman of General Foods Coporation, and Charles R. Hook, chairman of Armco Steel Corporation.

Block-by-block housing inspections will be put on a permanent basis, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday. The decision stemmed from the results of a pilot inspection project begun March 1 involving 6,000 buildings so far in the city's war against slums.

The higher cost of potatoes, pork chops, chicken, coffee and several other staple foods contributed to the first advance this year in the city's monthly consumer price index. This is compiled by the regional office of the United States Department of Labor.

You recently had a news item mentioning the rubber-tired subway in Paris. Having just returned from Paris, where I studied the transportation problem, I should like to shed a little light on this all-important experiment for the benefit of our straphangers.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 21 (Reuters) -- All but ten members of the Opposition walked out of a joint sitting of the South African Parliament here tonight over a seven-day suspension of a United party member.

ANCONA, Italy, May 21 (Reuters) -- Four Yugoslavs who boarded an Italian fishing boat off the Yugoslav port of Sebenic were brought to this Italian port tonight for questioning after being seized by an Italian gunboat.

Senator Karl E. Mundt declared here last night that no Congressional investigating committee had ever erred so badly in trying to oust Communists from government as Executive branches had erred in bringing them into it.

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 21 -- The Century Country Club won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub team championship by defeating rivals from New Jersey and Long Island over the Old Oaks course today.

CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP) -- Cleveland's general manager, Hank Greenberg, today offered a plan for regular season games that count in the standings to be played between all National and American League clubs.

The board of directors of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, A. F. L., recommended yesterday the acceptance of proposals for settling the ten-month-old strike against the Hat Corporation of America in Norwalk, Conn.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Representative Charles A. Wolverton, chairman of the House Commerce Committee, demanded today that the major radio networks answer charges that they discriminate against temperance interests seeking to buy time to expound the evils of alcohol.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent to 111.3 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The increase was a result of higher average prices for farm products and for processed foods. The prices of all other commodities remained unchanged on the average.

Chiang Kai-shek has again been inaugurated as the President of the free Chinese. His choice, while free, was overwhelming. In his inaugural address he pledged that his fight against the Communist invader would not be abandoned. To those who know what he stands for this would go almost without saying.
BOSTON, May 21 (AP) -- Federal Judge Bailey Aldrich took under advisement today a motion by Textron, Inc., to widen the scope of its challenging of the American Woolen Company's April 23 election.

NEW JERSEY anglers seem to be getting the cream of the salt water fishing. Bluefish are plentiful in the Cape May area and the "bull bass" are cruising off Sandy Hook, with "small bass abundant in the Barnegat area.
YORK, Pa., May 21 -- This Pennsylvania Dutch city is in the second year of an experiment in teaching a foreign language in its elementary schools.

I was delighted to read in the issue of May 14 your editorial entitled "Guarding the Supreme Court" approving the proposed constitutional amendments contained in the resolution introduced by Senator John Marshall Butler.

There was no question that Moses Rogers would follow the sea. He was a New London man and, like his father, his grand-father and great-grandfather (and perhaps even farther back than that) he would duly serve his apprenticeship and, at an early age, receive his first command.

The fallacy of Henrikas Rabinavicius' premise as stated in his letter in The New York Times of May 16 lies in his misunderstanding of the issue facing the American people today. It is one which, though not amenable to quick solution, none the less must be resolved sooner or later if the United States is to retain its independence and dignity among nations.
If wishes came true, then the make-believe miracle that took place last night would become a reality.
The value of the average share on the New York Stock Exchange on April 30 was $45.37, the highest month-end figure since July, 1946, the Exchange reported yesterday. On March 31 it was $43.87.

Sixty-five new Assembly Districts, reduced from the present sixty-seven, were mapped for New York City yesterday by the City Council, sitting as a Board of Reapportionment. The reallocation, a process carried out every ten years, distributed twenty-two Assembly seats to Kings County, sixteen to New York, thirteen to Queens, twelve to the Bronx and two to Richmond.

BOULDER, Colo., May 21 (AP) Wes Santee of Kansas failed to set a half-mile record but Neville Price of Oklahoma smashed his own 1953 broad-jump mark in the preliminaries today of the Big Seven track and field championships.

Women headed by Mrs. Samuel F. Pryor Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., are aiding in the plans for the annual meet of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association to be held next Saturday at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club in Purchase, N. Y.

DETROIT, May 21 (AP) -Walter P. Reuther, president of the C. I. O. and of the U. A. W., said today that he "welcomed" the drop in living costs even though it means a penny-an-hour pay cut for U. A. W. members.

WESTBURY, L. I., Saturday, May 22 -- The trotting associations that operate at Roosevelt Raceway this morning offered horsemen purse-money equal to 35 per cent of the track's share of pari-mutuel receipts.

KANSAS CITY, May 21 (AP) -- A police lieutenant and a rookie policeman who eight months ago were the heroes of the Greenlease kidnapping case were sentenced to prison today for lying about what happened to the record $600,000 ransom.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- John R. Norris of Compton, Calif., plans to provide for train and bus passengers individual, battery-operated radios to be worn on the head. The user inserts a coin, tunes in the program of his choice, and adjusts the volume. There is no captive audience, as the sound is audible only through the user's earphones.
MILES CITY, Mont., May 21 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Army, Robert T. Stevens, thanked President Eisenhower today for his support in the Secretary's feud with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Disabled children and patients of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center presented to the American-Korean Foundation "a scroll of salute" for the Korean people yesterday afternoon at the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.

BARABOO, Wis., May 21 (AP) -- A circuit judge refused today to halt a John Doe hearing, reportedly into affairs of the Joe Must Go Club, which spearheads a movement to recall Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
TRENTON, May 21 -- A fantastic escape plot was thwarted today by New Jersey State Prison officials here. They stumbled on a fifty-five-foot tunnel, freshly dug by inmates.
Dr. Emery I. Valko has been named director of research of the Onyx Oil and Chemical Company, Jersey City.

MOSCOW, May 21 -- The Soviet Army newspaper Red Star called on all military personnel, and particularly all sentries and guards, to maintain the highest vigilance in view of what it charged was a widening United States spying and diversionist offensive.

MEXICO CITY, May 21 -- The Mexican chief of civil aviation complained sharply today of the "evident disproportion" between the commercial routes granted to United States carriers by Mexico and Mexican air rights in the United States.
Columbia University scientists have snatched two precious scientific specimens, at least 10,000 years old, from Davy Jones' locker.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- United States exports dropped $55,000,000 in March, chiefly because of a decline in the overseas sale of finished manufactured goods.

Penn State, led by Roosevelt Grier and Art Pollard, defeated Manhattan College 71-59, in a dual track and field meet at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium, the Bronx, yesterday. The loss ended a fifteen dual meet string over a four-year period for the Jaspers.
Women should define their goals in life before they begin looking for a job, according to Alice Gore King, executive director of the Alumnae Advisory Center.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Following is the 34-24 vote that defeated a proposed Constitutional amendment to grant the vote to 18-year-olds, with a two-thirds favorable vote required:

MOSCOW, May 21 (AP) -- Pravda accused the United States today of producing forged documents to show Soviet participation in the Korean war and Russian and Communist Chinese intervention in Indo-China.

This generation lives in the immediacy of the present -- it does not "try to buy heirlooms or to live for things" -- Donna Newell Meyers, vice president of Werbell, Seklemian North, told a luncheon given yesterday in the Astor Hotel by the Fashion Group.

LONDON, May 21 -- Widespread gains throughout the industrial list was the main feature of the stock markets here today. During the week industrial shares have made much more progress than Government funds.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate rejected today President Eisenhower's proposal that the Constitution be amended to lower the voting age from 21 years to 18.

" EUROPE, a Journey With Pictures,"* is a passport without visas to a thousand vistas of recollection and adventure. All concerned with this enterprise have carried out their missions splendidly. The overture, by Lewis Mumford, is as discerning an introduction to the lands of our in-laws as anyone has written recently.

A new musical comedy, "The Hot Rock," based on the theft several years ago of the Stone of Scone from Westminster Abbey in London, is shaping up for Broadway production next season under the auspices of John Arent, former president of Laurel Films, Inc.

Ira Berne, builder, who recently bought the southwest corner of Second Avenue and Seventieth Street, has enlarged his plottage at that location by purchasing the adjoining three five-story tenement buildings on plot 75 by 100 feet at 229-31-33'East Sixtyninth Street.

DETROIT, May 21 -- A major step toward the reunion of American Presbyterian groups was taken today. The 166th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. voted unanimously to approve a three-way merger plan that may unite 3,500,000 churchgoers into one body.

LITTLE ROCK, May 21 (UP) -- Arkansas' legislators and the directors of two state - supported educational instiutions today took the first known state action in the South to comply with the United States Supreme Court's anti-segregation decision.
GENEVA, May 21 -- The biggest economic news from Western Europe this spring is about things that have not happened.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Provisions to increase tax allowances for depletion in the mining of uranium and salt have been written into the Administration's omnibus tax reform bill by the Senate Finance Committee.
GENEVA, May 21 -- The conference on Far Eastern affairs plunged into a debate this afternoon on the method of determining the general principles that should govern an armistice in Indo-China.

LONDON, May 21 (Reuters) -- Trading on the London and Liverpool grain markets came to a halt today following the United States announcement that Government coarse grains would be offered to exporters at prices 10 to 15 cents a bushel below American domestic prices.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay said today the Air Force had assembled an "instant" atomic striking force that neither bad weather nor Communist air defenses could stop.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., May 21 -- The trustees of the Town of East Hampton have lost their claim to a strip of beachfront 150 feet deep in the Eastern Plains district.
Stocks made the longest gains of the week yesterday in the heaviest trading of the month and closed at the highest level since June 13, 1930.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21 -- Israel accused Jordan today of having stirred up thirty-seven border clashes in forty-three days.
CLEVELAND, May 21 (UP) -- Early Wynn scattered five hits tonight to beat the Baltimore Orioles, 2 -- 1, and extend the Cleveland Indians' winning streak to eight games.
I have read with great surprise your very unfriendly editorial of May 19 about my country, Honduras.

CATANZARO, Italy, May 21 -- Southern Italy is emerging from centuries of what might be called the dark ages. Its transformation is varied, uneven and enormously complex, but in going around one finds certain social and economic patterns repeating themselves.
CHICAGO, May 21 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves won a home run duel from the Chicago Cubs today, 6 to 4, before 8,179 fans.
A spectacular invasion of flying elm beetles, gypsy moths and tent caterpillars is disrupting the charm of country and suburban life in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Protests against the proposed 5 per cent tax on amusement admissions began to pour into City Hall yesterday. The storm of opposition began to rise even as Mayor Wagner's aides were drafting for introduction in the City Council next Tuesday the bill to impose the levy.
BERLIN, May 21 -- Archbishop Aloysius Muench, considered the Vatican's representative for all Germany, entered East Germany today for the first time since World War II.

It is hardly a surprise that Dr. Syngman Rhee's Liberal party should have emerged victorious in the Republic of Korea's election of members of the Assembly. The support for his firm anti-Communist position is so widespread that anything that could be interpreted as a test of national confidence would be most likely to go in his favor.

New issues of public utility bonds continued to back up on the hands of underwriting syndicates this week. Life insurance companies and industrial pension funds held steadfast in their refusal to buy new top-grade debt securities at yields of less than 3 per cent.

A special grand jury that investigated organized crime and official corruption for two and a half years on Staten Island called yesterday for more stringent rules to deal with dishonest policemen and gamblers.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) Willard Widerberg of De Kalb, Ill., was honored today by President Eisenhower as "teacher of the year" and four young children were showered with attention and numerous gifts from the President's desk drawer.
According to a veteran Communist, the United States has lost the "war of ideas" in Latin America.

The snowballing "do-it-yourself" trend, linked to the rapid increase in home ownership, is becoming increasingly important in advertising. The latest example is a community-style editorialized feature called "Do-It-Yourself Digest," under the sponsorship of a company of that name at 270 Park Avenue.

TRENTON, May 21 -- Some $178,000,000 in capital improvements are needed immediately to relieve overcrowding in New Jersey public schools and replace obsolete structures, according to a report made public here today by the State Commissioner of Education.
