The Board of Estimate has unanimously rejected extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services, thus reversing itself and ending a long period of on-again-off-again uncertainty. The decision is a wise one, and we congratulate Mayor Wagner and the board on a second thought that is better.

It is an act of desperation for Senator McCarthy to accuse the President of "Fifth Amendment" tactics on the ground that he has ordered his subordinates not to testify to private conversations among themselves on the subject of Mr. McCarthy's dispute with the Army. This order has no more relation to the Fifth Amendment than the man in the moon.

GUATEMALA, May 21 -- The Guatemalan Government said today that the United States ban on arms shipments here was aimed at leaving this country defenseless before its enemies. Guatemala's recent purchase of arms, presumably from Czechoslovakia, was "perfectly normal," Foreign Minister Guillermo Toriello asserted at a press conference.

BOSTON, May 21 -- The Unitarian Ministers Association adopted three resolutions today criticizing proposed legislation in Congress having religious connotations. Its meeting, with 150 present, was in conjunction with the 129th annual meeting of the American Unitarian Association.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 21 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today asked members of the New Jersey Savings and Loan League to help him find "a workable solution" for the state's fiscal problems.

BONN, Germany, May 21 -- Dr. Gerhard Schroeder, Minister of the Interior, assured the Bundestag today that the Government did not have any plans to interfere with the freedom of the press and the free expression of opinion.
PARIS, May 21 -- An international experiment in bilingual education will be undertaken this year by York, Pa., and a French city.

I wish to commend The New York Times for publishing C. L. Sulzberger's denial, on May 18, of "Italian press allegations that Koca Popovic, Yugoslavia's Foreign Minister, had revealed details of a proposed solution of the Trieste problem published in The New York Times of May 8."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- John Ireland, the actor, has agreed to an out-of-court settlement of the $1,756,000 slander and breach-of-contract suit he filed last March in Superior Court, Los Angeles. The defendants were Norvin Productions, Television Programs of America, Leon Fromkess, producer, and others.
Pierre Langlois, a clever Frenchman with a rapier-like left and a talent to keep a rival off balance, scored a decided upset last night at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Uneasiness over developments in Indo-China sparked a buying movement in wheat today which resulted in a sharp advance after a small price dip early. There was also some buying of coarse grains on the announcement that the Government would sell surplus corn, oats, barley and rye at world prices in an effort to lighten the big stocks in this country.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 21 -- Samuel Faile, District Attorney of Westchester for the last seventeen months, won Republican endorsement for the top political job of the county today when party leaders chose him to run for Surrogate.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Industry executives representing about half the country's commercial coal production warned the Federal Government today that it must not "remain blind" to the closing of hundreds of coal mines and the joblessness of 100,000 miners.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- American President Lines appeared today to have won much support in the Maritime Administration for purchase of a substantial fleet of ships for its trans-Pacific and 'round-the- world routes.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Dr. James G. Beckerley, for the last five years Director of Classification of the Atomic Energy Commission, will leave Government service in the next few months.

" Back of History: The Story of Our Own Origins," by William Howells, chairman of the Department of Sociology and Anthropology of the University of Wisconsin, will be published June 21 by Doubleday. The development of man and his cultures, languages, societies and religions is traced by the author.
RIDGEWOOD, N. J., May 21 -- Former Representative J. Parnell Thomas announced today the shutting down of his four weekly Bergen County newspapers because of financial difficulties.

YONKERS, May 21 (AP) -- Irish Hal, driven by Jimmy Fitzpatrick, won the $6,500 University Pace by a head over Scotch Spencer at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The time for the mile was 2:10 on a slow track. A crowd of 23,134 attended the Grand Circuit program.

The lightweight championship fight between Titleholder Paddy DeMarco and Jimmy Carter, scheduled for San Francisco on June 2, was postponed yesterday. DeMarco was taken to Columbus Hospital several days ago, from his training camp at Greenwood Lake, suffering from a virus infection.

MOSCOW, May 21 -- The Communist party's First Secretary, Nikita Khrushchev, has just completed a 3,000-mile trip to Kazakhstan. He went there to inspect the progress of the campaign to increase Soviet grain production by bringing vast areas of virgin land under cultivation.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 21 -- A wounded Foreign Legionnaire evacuated from Dienbienphu said today he had seen about a dozen European officers in Vietminh uniforms there. The legionnaire, 23-year-old Ernst Haas, said the Europeans were German, French and Polish.
The 1954 bathing season at Jones Beach State Park, marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the park, will get under way today.

Merlyn S. Pitzele, chairman of the State Mediation Board, will attempt Monday to find a peace formula in the stalemated negotiations between Manhattan apartment house owners and their unionized employes.
BALTIMORE, May 21 -- On the morrow at Old Pimlico, the Preakness Stakes will be run for the seventy-eighth time.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The United States has silenced a short-wave radio operated by the Communist Rumanian legation here.

The Fact-Finding Committee appointed Jan. 6, 1954, by Mayor Wagner to inquire into the Transit Authority labor dispute has brought in a report that is satisfactory to leaders of the Transport Workers Union, but the rest of the public cannot, in our opinion, be too happy about it.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A loaded Soviet poison gun gingerly exhibited before the (Senate) Internal Security subcommittee, was directly linked today to an assassination ordered by Aleksander Panyushkin, former Soviet Ambassador to the United States.

The position of General Motors Corporation today "is just a little bit better than it was in 1940 and 1941, when we had 47 and 48 per cent of the passenger-car business," Harlow H. Curtice president, told a record 1,860 attendance of shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del.
ST. LOUIS, May 21 (UP) -- Rip Repulski's sharp single with two on in the tenth inning gave the St. Louis Cardinals an 8-7 victory tonight over the Cincinnati Redlegs.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation believes the best means of dealing with surpluses is parallel action by individual countries. This position also has been given some support by President Eisenhower.

ITHACA, N. Y., May 21 (AP) -- Cornell University announced today it had withdrawn its offer of a summer teaching job to Harry C. Steinmetz, who was dismissed by San Diego State College after he had refused to tell a Congressional committee whether he was or had been a Communist.

Negotiations are under way for the purchase of up to one-third of the outstanding common stock of the Hotels Statler Company, Inc. The management of the $63,500,000 hotel chain said yesterday it had not been approached in the pending negotiations.
If the turnpike comes, can the shun-pike be far behind?
SEATTLE, May 21 (AP) -- The New York Giants of the National Football League lost their suit today to prevent Arnie Weinmeister from leaving the club.

NEW DELHI, India, May 21 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today his Government did not oppose transit of French wounded from Indo-China over Indian soil -- provided the planes were unarmed and flying alone.
GENEVA, May 21 -- President Eisenhower's decision not to press Congress to enact his whole foreign trade program has come as a blow to Western Europe.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 21 (AP) -- The United States Air Force is moving its team of technicians from the northern Indo-China port of Haiphong to Tourane, the big French air base 450 miles down the coast, American sources revealed today.
Nicholas Craig has been elected president of Icelandic Airlines, Inc. Mr. Craig has been in transportation for more than twenty-five years, eleven with Pan American World Airways.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21 -- A tuberculosis expert said today the "very success" of drugs and surgery in lowering the death rate from tuberculosis "is likely to add to the size of the chronic disease problem."
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Eisenhower's requests for increases in Social Security taxes and benefits were approved today by the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 21 -- A rally that brought victory to Joe McBride, former Metropolitan amateur champion, at the twentieth hole marked the second round of the Walter J. Travis Memorial tournament at the Garden City Golf Club today.
The Dodgers squeezed out a 3 -- 2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates at Ebbets Field last night.
Efforts to aid Puerto Rican families by New York City's private agencies are many and diverse. Welfare, health, recreation, and community action programs are included.

LONDON, May 21 -- The uncertainty on the highest levels of the United States Government on exactly what it intends to do specifically in Indo-China and generally in Southeast Asia was said tonight to be complicating policy-making for the British and French Governments.

The Glidden Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $2,902,830, equal to $1.27 a share, for the six months ended on April 30, compared with $3,112,926, or $1.36, for the similar period a year earlier.

PARIS, May 21 (AP) -- America's Davis Cup aces, Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas, and three of their fellow countrymen moved into the fourth round of the men's singles in the French international tennis championships today before the program was rained out.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Harold E. Stassen said today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy deliberately presented "false statements" to the Senate Wednesday "in order to draw vicious conclusions" about the Administration's East-West trade policy.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 21 -- An 18-month-old black miniature from the classes, Mrs. Peter Frelinghuysen's Smilestone's Tabarina, became best of breed in the specialty of the Poodle Club of America under a soggy, half-dark tent today.
BERLIN, May 16 -- The last remnant of the United States cavalry, which was once reckoned in divisions, is a single mounted platoon stationed here, 100 miles behind the Iron Curtain.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Air Force reversed itself and offered today to pin lieutenants' bars on 4,840 college seniors.

The six-story building with seventyrtwo apartments at 1475 Wythe Place in the Bronx has been sold by 1475 Associates to i a client of Jacob 1VL Leibner, lawyer, for cash above mortgages of $290,000. Rubin Mason were !the brokers and Goodman :lVfabel were attorneys for the sellers.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- New Zealand's Foreign Minister declared today that he did not believe a "basic disagreement" split the United States and Britain on the "course of action" for combatting communism in Southeast Asia.

DUBLIN, May 21 -- John Aloysius Costello, Prime Minister in 1948-51, was held up as a political miracle man when he kept a coalition Government composed of some of Ireland's most divergent elements together those three years.
MADRID, May 21 -- The Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs asserted today that early in World War II Prime Minister Churchill promised to return Gibraltar to Spain.

Many city, village and rural churches will join in prayers tomorrow in thanks for the fruits of the earth and the labor of those who till the soil, and in asking for fair play for agricultural workers.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee voted today to liberalize down-payments and repayment periods for homes purchased under the Government's housing program.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 21 -- United States authorities today charged former Army Capt. James M. Leech, of Lima, Ohio, with the eight-year-old axe-and-fire murder of three United States officers in Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) -- Miss Frieda B. Hennock, lone woman member of the Federal Communications Commission, burst into tears today as she berated Senators for using "Senatorial pressure" to get television stations for their home towns.
The Federal Government impounded yesterday the bank assets of the old International Longshoremen's Association.

LONDON, May 21 (Reuters) -- Britain's largest private enterprise, the Imperial Chemical Industries Company, today announced plans to give its 75,000 employes a chance to speak up at the annual meetings and tell the bosses how they think things should be run.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics went reeling to their seventh straight defeat tonight as Bob Porterfield recorded his fifth triumph, pitching the Washington Senators to a 7-3 victory.
The last-place Red Sox ganged up on Whitey Ford for six runs in the sixth inning last night to spoil the homecoming of the Yankees from their triumphant tour of the West.

RANGOON, Burma, May 21 -- Speculation in the world press on participation by Burma in any South East Asian security pact has produced no official comment here, but it appears that Burma is using the utmost caution to avoid being drawn unwittingly into either power bloc.

The United States can no more depend upon foreign merchant fleets in time of war than it can depend upon foreign navies, Representative Thor C. Tollefson asserted last night. He warned that if we want ships in time of war we must have them in time of peace.

A thorough investigation was ordered yesterday into Thursday's juvenile disorders, in which hundreds of high school students staged a running melee on I. R. T. subway trains and in several of its stations. The order came from Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

THE younger American painters who are showing work in five current metropolitan exhibitions have little in common beyond a fooling that they are at complete liberty to paint what they want to and how they want to.

George P. Monaghan, harness racing commissioner, said yesterday that he had sent back as unsatisfactory a trust agreement accompanying the resignation of James O. Marra as an officer and director of Batavia Downs.

BOSTON, May 21 -- The New England Gas and Electric Association reported today consolidated operating revenues of $38,680,001 for the twelve months ended April 30. This compared with $36,306,843 for the corresponding period last year.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet and somewhat sluggish yesterday. Prices closed 11 points lower to 5 points higher than on Thursday.

The outrageous rowdyism in which several hundred high-school students took part Thursday on I. R. T. subway trains and stations uptown and for which forty-three of them were taken to a police station is one more piece of evidence supporting greater severity in dealing with vandalism in New York.
Two sisters, 7 and 8 years old, died in a fire in their third-floor bedroom at 106 West 143d Street, near Lenox Avenue at 6 A. M. yesterday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 20 -- Allan B. Kline, president of the International Federation of Agricultural Producers, suggested today that parallel action by individual nations to cope with surplus produce might be more effective than joint action by world control bodies.
WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Saturday, May 22 -- Exits were guarded last night during the Woodbridge High School Senior Prom to guarantee sober driving on the way home.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Department of Justice said today that it had not received any papers yet in the proceedings against Mr. Leech.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Robin Roberts, whose pitching this spring has been alternately hot and cold, was his sizzling old self tonight. To make the situation even more hopeless, the Giants spotted the fireballing right-hander to a 5-run lead in the first inning and that, of course, settled it for the evening.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Elgin National Watch Company filed a $450,000 suit today against the Kay Jewelry Stores, Inc., a big retail chain, claiming damages as a result of discount sales of Elgin watches and statements made in Kay advertising.

The surrender of Luis Taruc, leader of the Philippine Communist Hukbalahap movement, may well mark the end of the overt menace in the archipelago. There are still die-hard Communists in the hills and swamps, but Taruc's leadership has had a name value that none of his comrades enjoyed.

The International Society for Contemporary Music presented last night the fourth concert of its current season at McMillin Theatre, Columbia University. The program offered two novelties -- the first performance in this city of Twelve Pieces for Piano by Keith Robinson and the first complete United States performance of Luigi Dallapiccola's

BALTIMORE, May 21 (AP) -- Bob Toski shot another fine round of golf in the $20,000 Eastern open tournament today, then sat back to see if anybody would match his 9-under-par 135 at the halfway mark. Nobody did.

THE review of my novel "The Devil's Brigadier" represents the book as a sordid account of "about eleven murders for each of which the killers keep adding notches to their guns" -- a preposterous statement even regarded as hyperbole, since the guns in question were long-barreled rifles.
The 1953 edition of The New York Times Index, which records the day-by-day history of the world in all its phases, was published last Wednesday.

SCRIABIN'S Symphony No. 2 in C Minor, begun about 1897 and finished in 1903, stands in much the same relation to its composer's later work as does "Verklaerte Nacht" to Schoenberg's and the "Hymn-Tune Symphony" to that of Charles Ives.

EDITOR of the Christian Science Monitor and one of the best-known of American newspaper men, Erwin D. Canham, offers in this brief volume his own optimistic analysis of our evolving economic and social structure. His approach is that of a liberal conservative.

SINGAPORE, May 22 -- About 2,500 Singapore Chinese schoolboys and girls barricaded themselves inside the compound of the Chung Cheng school today in the latest protest against an order requiring them to register for the national service call-up.

The work week in major Atlantic Coast shipyards has dwindled in two years from less than thirty-four hours to a present average of sixteen, John J. Grogan, president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., asserted yesterday.

GENEVA, May 22 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from a speech at the Geneva conference today by Pyun Yung Tai, South Korean Foreign Minister; the text of South Korea's proposal on Korean unification and excerpts from remarks by Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier and Foreign Minister:

Some sufferers from cancer are benefited by the administration of hormones or the removal of hormone-producing glands, and others are not. Why? Dr. William H. Fishman, working with a grant from the American Cancer Society at Tufts College Medical School has the answer.

THERE are sixteen pleasant stories in this volume, many of them written by authors whose names are familiar to readers of the two previous issues: R. Bretnor, H. Nearing Jr., Idris Seabright, Manly Wade Wellman, L. Sprague de Camp and Fletcher Pratt, to name a few.

Purchasing methods in a buyers' market economy will be the theme of the four-day 1954 convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, which opens today in the Conrad Hilton Hotel, Chicago.

Annual awards in the arts and induction of new members will be features of the joint ceremonial of the American Academy and National Institute of Arts and Letters Wednesday at 3 P. M. in the academy auditorium, 632 West 156th Street.

The Owens-Illinois Glass Company, Toledo, announces that it has established a two-year post-doctoral fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to find out how glass is constructed. A square centimeter of glass surface will be bombarded by a stream of 100 billion neutrons per second.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco -- You can lose your money at the Monte Carlo Casino any time of the year. But comes June, the 370 acres of loveliness that constitute the Principality of Monaco burst into a multitude of activities that would keep visitors contented even if there weren't a roulette wheel for miles.
NORWALK, Conn., May 22 -- Striking hat workers here voted tonight to end their ten-month walkout at the plant of the Hat Corporation of America.
JERSEY CITY, May 22 -- The double murder trial for George W. Rogers, one-time hero of the Morro Castle disaster, ended in a mistrial this afternoon when the jury was reduced to eleven members.

Bonds that can be converted into common stock have been attracting more attention among investors. Certain Wall Street accounting firms have been calling attention to them as "reasonably safe" vehicles in which top-bracket clients may take stock market fliers.

THE ancestral tree of man's descent from the apes used to be a fairly simple affair with a rather noble-looking savage at the top and a succession of near-men or ape-men underneath, each more bent and decidedly more shaggy than the one above.

LONDON, May 22 -- Billy Graham, American evangelist, wound up a twelve-week revival campaign here today with two huge outdoor meetings. Although it was raining and cold, the second meeting, at Wembley Stadium, easily surpassed his previous record for a single audience.
LIMA, Ohio, May 22 (UP) -- Mr. Leech denied today charges that he murdered three Army officers in Germany.

THERE'S a soft streak of sentimentality in Frank Frisch that seeps all the way down to the soles of his shoes. The Old Flash tries to conceal it behind the facade of bellicose bravado which made him the ideal manager of the rip-roaring. Gas House Gang of two decades ago. But he doesn't always succeed.

THIS is the third volume in the series that began with "The Burned Bramble" and was continued with "The 'Abyss," and it may or may not be the last. It need not be the last, for the story, like the journey that is its theme, can have no end.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Export-Import Bank of Washington, bowing to a suggestion from Brazil, modified payment requirements today on its $300,000,000 credit to that country.
NEW DELHI, India, May 21 -- The Indian Defense Ministry introduced legislation today providing compulsory recruitment for the Territorial Army.
IN the National Assembly of France all the Deputies arose to honor the heroic sacrifice of the fifteen battalions at Dienbienphu. All arose, that is, except one group -- the Communists.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Congress is being flooded with mail, but on a subject far removed from the McCarthy-Army hearings that hold the headlines.

AS reports of musical happenings come from all parts of the country one gains the impression of opera as the great surging spring bubbling in the nation's musical life. From Denver, for instance, comes the news of the founding of the Greater Denver Opera Association, which, following the success of its first production this spring, is planning a season of five operas next fall.

Duke Snider's three-run homer in the third inning provided the Dodgers with a 3-1 victory over the lowly Pittsburgh Pirates at Ebbets Field yesterday. Outhitting the Brooks, 10 -- 7, the Pirates left fifteen men on the base paths.

FORTIFIED by its promising start this season with "The Remarkable Mr. Pennypacker" and "The Confidential Clerk," Producers' Theatre is making impressive plans for the future. The Messrs. Roger L. Stevens, Robert Whitehead and Robert W. Dowling, who direct the organization, having searched for scripts at home and abroad, have come up with a list of projects that includes the following:

PARIS, May 22 -- Government leaders concluded today that unless France obtained greater aid from abroad or a cease-fire was called swiftly she would have to give up defense of the Red River delta in Indo-China.
In the Pennsylvania Dutch country the word "all" means finished, through, all over, dead. To housewives throughout the country it means a detergent, and that product is thriving.

Business and public administration will be combined with law in a new four-year graduate program announced by Cornell University. The law-administration combination is the latest in a series of Cornell offerings to prepare specialists for administrative roles.

STOCKTON HELFFRICH, a gentleman possessed of a durable sense of humor and the patience of Job, works in a small office at the National Broadcasting Company, surrounded by some placid-appearing Chinese prints, a few branches of magnolia leaves and several comfortable chairs.

The record shut-in production of crude oil in the nation's fields is getting to be a problem. Estimated at 1,500,000 to 1,800,000 barrels a day, the cost of keeping at amount of oil off the market becoming a burden to some of the companies operating only in the United States.
GUATEMALA, May 22 -- The Guatemalan Government is considering airing its dispute with the United States before the United Nations Security Council.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics reached Spec Shea and Camilo Pascual for seven runs in the first two innings and coasted to a 10-3 victory over the Washington Senators tonight. The triumph ended a seven-game Philadelphia losing streak.

HOWARD HUGHES' candid defiance of Hollywood's firm Production Code in going ahead and releasing "The French Line" without a Code seal appears something less than a fine challenge flung down in the name of Free Art when one takes a good look at the picture, now on the Criterion's screen.
An attractive blonde, who gained wide publicity a week ago when a court upheld her right not to divulge her age, discovered early today that fame can be a double-edged sword.
JERUSALEM, May 17 -- Israel has a discrimination problem on her hands. This fact emerged from meetings here last week of the Congress of the World Sephardic Federation.

Hasty Road, paying $12, survived a strong stretch run by the favored Correlation to win the seventy-eighth Preakness Stakes by a neck at Pimlico. Hasseyampa finished third. The winner, ridden by Johnny Adams, earned $91,600.

Finance at short notice is his specialty, but the career of one of Israel's leading bankers approaches romance. Sigfried Hoofien, chairman of the board of the Bank of Leumi le-Israel (National Bank of Israel), has found adventure in currency since he left his native Netherlands forty-two years ago.

NORTH NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., May 22 -- A former convict, paroled last month after serving a term for grand larceny, was found dead in, a ditch at 3:30 P. M. today off New Hyde Park Road, 100 feet north of the entrance to Northern State Parkway.
Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks in a Maritime Day address here yesterday pledged the full support of the Eisenhower Administration for a strengthened merchant marine.

It is eighty-six years since the Fourteenth Amendment was proclaimed a part of the United States Constitution. It is fifty-eight years since the Supreme Court, with Justice Harlan dissenting, established the doctrine of "separate but equal" provision for the white and Negro races on interstate carriers.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) -- George Bante of Chicago held a lead tonight over Woodruff Randolph in the election of the International Typographical Union, A. F. L. Mr. Randolph is seeking re-election as union president.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22 -- A United Nations mission has diplomatically indicated to Pakistan that abandonment of the veil by Moslem women would benefit the country.

GENEVA, May 22 -- South Korea agreed today to all-Korean elections, provided they were under United Nations supervision. The voting would have to be held within six months after the plan was accepted by the conference here on Far Eastern affairs, the South Koreans insisted.

In each city throughout the world there is a "special hospital," at least a hospital that is "special" to the hundreds of physicians who have trained and practiced there and to the thousands of patients it has served.

THE 3c Statute of Liberty stamp, which will be issued at Albany on June 24 as the second denomination of the new regular United States series, will also be released in booklet form. The Post Office Department has not announced when the 3c booklet will appear, but four plates have been made to print it: 24975, 24976, 24980 and 24981.
TRENTON, May 22 -- New Jersey residents this week took a keen interest in the Supreme Court decision that outlawed racial segregation in public schools.
" THE wind in the trees seemed to put words to her thoughts. What was it saying? 'Keep up your courage, Sarah Noble. Keep up -- keep -- keep -- keep . . .'"
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 22 -- A flashy buff-colored 4-year-old Afghan, Ch. Karli Ben Ghazi, became the first all-breed best-in-show winner of a new metroplitan area outdoor season today.

IT is hard to pinpoint the qualities that make one picture book a favorite and allow another to gather dust on the nursery shelf. Much hinges on sparking the fancy with humor, on suspense and imaginative phrasing -- elements overlooked by Mr. Barker.

THE awesome fidelity with which P. G. Wodehouse clings to the England he created mostly between the two major recent unpleasantnesses is probably comparable only to the distaste for it evidenced by the late Big Bill Thompson of Chicago.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- There were increasing signs this week that the Eisenhower Administration was moving in on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 22 (AP) -- Brookmeade Stable's Capeador today won $24,500 as his share of the gross purse of $35,350 for taking the first renewal of the Thomas J. Healey Handicap at Garden State Park.

THOUGH this is the last full week in May, there is plenty of activity to keep the insatiable dance-goer busy, whether his interest is in ballet or modern dance. To be sure, it is all in the outlying halls, but that is quite customary nowadays.
The unanimous decision of the United States Supreme Court banning racial segregation in the nation's public schools was hailed yesterday by Rabbi Leo Jung as "a second emancipation" of Negroes.

WRESTING a strip of the vegetable garden from the man of the house can be a battle. For the distaff side of vegetable gardening is usually concerned with small crops (dubbed toothpick snacks at our house) and some herbs that no cook should be without.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 22 (UP) -- A mysterious woman witness, who withheld her story in fear for years, saw the axe-murderer of three American Army officers throw his weapon into the Danube River, William D. Canfield, United States Prosecutor, said today.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- A six-month decline in non-farm employment in Illinois was ended in April, the State Employment Service reported. Preliminary estimates of April employment showed 2,967,600 workers, compared with 2,946,100 in March. However, the April figure was 117,400 below that of April, 1953.

A PLANTING that gave pure pleasure and no headaches last summer was one of nasturtiums. Three packets of the big wrinkled seeds, two of Golden Gleam and one of Scarlet Gleam, provided a mass of double, fragrant blossoms between the driveway and the front walk.

The Board of Education and Queens College will cooperate in the fall in a pilot project to lower the hurdles for new teachers. The aim is to reduce the number of young persons who leave the teaching profession because of unhappy experiences in their first jobs.
A halt seems to have been reached in the decline in yields on prime securities.

IT has long been recognized by perspicacious observers of Russians and Americans that regardless of profound political differences there is one field of human conduct in which they greatly resemble each other. That is the field of drinking.

A glance at photographs of the airplane of twenty-five years ago and today's sleek jets suffices to dramatize aviation's fantastic progress in a quarter of a century. That progress would have been impossible without the medical research which conquered factors of increased human stress due to flight at modern speeds and altitudes.

THE airlines agree that the seats left empty by no-shows -- persons who make reservations but neglect to cancel them when they find they can't use them -- constitute a financial hazard of such proportions that they are a menace to black-ink operations.
WATERLOO, Iowa, May 22 (UP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell said today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's "unquenchable thirst for power" threatened to reduce the Government to "anarchy."
LOS ANGELES, May 22 -- KTHE, one of the nation's pioneer educational television stations, is rounding out its first six months of operation.

MAKING up "The Nature of Love" are three novellas -- "the beautiful and blest nouvelle," as Henry James called the long story upon which, until very recently, both English and American editors have cast so scornful an eye.

A YOUNG girl who only a few days ago, could have walked down West Forty-fourth Street without stirring a ripple or attention, today finds the same walk rather a struggle -- in a wonderful sort of way. Autograph hunters, the betes noires of more seasoned Broadway performers, descend on her in droves and she takes pleasure in them.

MEXICO CITY, May 22 -- The Army took over government buildings and disarmed all local police today in the state of Guerrero, after Federal authorities had proclaimed the ouster of the state government.

THE May Salon, as one knows, has played the same role for generations of artists from thirty to fifty years of age as did the Autumn Salon for the fauves and cubists. So with the tenth May Salon in progress it is a very suitable moment in which to take stock of the younger school of French painting -- its principal tendencies and the direction in which it is moving.

WHEN drought and water shortages threaten during the summer months, both city and county are likely to pass ordinances for the conservation of water. And one of the first things to go thirsty is the garden.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 22 -- The South's railway systems have invested more than $2,000,000,000 in improvements since the end of World War II.

THIS high-geared story concerns a beautiful Irish orphan, who comes to the United States after her father, an Irish patriot, dies in jail. Her flight from Galway is the first in a long series of mistakes. She has a hard row to hoe from the day she arrives in Corioli (a river town noted for its murderers at large) to the stormy end of her own calorific adventures.

Re: "Segregation -- Two-Edged Sword" (April 25) by Milton Gordon and John Roche. May I voice a dissent? [The Gordon-Roche article discussed segregation in the United States from the standpoint of "four major areas of substantial loss" -- economic, psychological, moral and international -- Editor.]

ANCIENT Norsemen believed that when Odin ruled in Asgard, heroes second only to the gods lived in their land. These were the Volsungs, half gods, half men. Tales of their courage and might, which together form the Volsunga Saga, have come down in various forms. In our time they are most notably encountered in Wagnerian music.

THE most important result of the last two world wars has undoubtedly been the rise and spread of communism, which today controls 800,000,000 people and gives reality to the specter of atomic war. It rose and spread on the ruins, created aggressive empires and is especially virulent and menacing at the moment in the Far East.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -- The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report urged Congress today to swing into action on government reorganization plans hanging fire since last year.

THE story of Clement R. Attlee's life and times is clearly worth telling. He was Deputy Prime Minister in Sir Winston Churchill's wartime coalition Government. For six years immediately after the war he headed the first majority Labor Government in Britain; and for thirty uninterrupted years he has served in "The Mother of Parliaments."

ESSENTIALLY, Hal Clement's latest work of science fiction is an astonishing new kind of sea yarn. It is the enthralling chronicle of the voyage of a sea trader, one Captain Barlennan, from the equator of his world, Mesklin, to its southern pole.

NORFOLK, Va., May 22 -- In less than four years the Navy has poured into the Fifth Naval District, where one of the world's largest navel bases and servicing facilities for the Atlantic fleet are located, more than a quarter of a billion dollars in construction work.
LONDON, May 22 -- British policy remains concentrated on the search for an agreed settlement in Indo-China, Anthony Eden declared tonight.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 -- Fifteen seasoned race drivers and three newcomers filled the thirty-three-car field for the 500- mile Memorial Day race today in a high-speed day that produced six of the ten fastest qualifying trials ever run.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 22 -- Princeton's varsity 150-pound crew spurted today to beat Pennsylvania by a length and retain the Wood-Hammond Cup on Carnegie Lake.

Twenty-seven newspaper executives from nineteen states and Canada will participate in a one-week seminar on Management and Costs beginning tomorrow at the American Press Institute, Columbia University.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -- This resort played host to 60,000 Roman Catholic pilgrims here today in a great Marian Year religious demonstration honoring the Virgin Mary.

A publication of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations lists about fifty names for protein malnutrition. In South Africa the name is "infantile pellagra," in Jamaica "fatty liver disease," in India "nutrition dystrophy." In some parts of Africa nearly every child suffers from it at some time in his life.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 22 -- Hofstra closed its baseball season today with a 2-1 triumph over Manhattan in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game. The Dutchmen won thirteen of twenty-three tests during the campaign.

PHOTOGRAPHS by twelve prize winners in the seven annual open photography shows held thus far by the Village Art Center are included in the prize winners' exhibition of the center to be held June 2-15 at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street.

Clement Clarke Moore, who knew and loved Chelsea well (he wrote "A Visit From St. Nicholas" there), would have been surprised recently had he been able to look in on a combined meeting of the ParentTeacher Association of Public School 33, P. S. 11, and the Hudson Guild in the Chelsea School.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The United States Air Force has moved its men, at least temporarily, from the drifting ice island weather base in the Arctic Ocean about which Soviet scout planes have displayed interest.

At 65 years of age a man is expected to be ready to retire nowadays. But at 80, this time- span has no such meaning for Edward Tayler, vice chairman of Smith, Kirkpatrick Co., foreign trade and finance organization.
HOBOKEN, N. J., May 22 -- Known at Stevens Institute of Technology as the "Professor Who Wouldn't Stay Retired," Charles O. Gunther celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 22. -- Women have been elected to the corporation of Springfield College for the first time in the college's seventy-year history.

The Marine Corps was credited yesterday by a member of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee with being largely responsible for the development of small atomic weapons to supplement "city-killer" bombs.

WHEN Canada was called New France, a settler found a bear cub, brought him home and trained him for a soldier. Alphonse, the bear, appeared to listen when the settler told him not to volunteer for anything; he rolled his eyes a little, co and lo.
A "gang" of reform school graduates got together for dinner last night.

A VETERAN journalist with enthusiasm for his craft, Edmond D. Coblentz has collected here some of the most salubrious sayings of successful newspaper men. The selections range widely from William Allen White and Adolph S. Ochs to Hearst and his editors, of whom Mr. Coblentz was one.

FOR Bonnie Jean Andrews going to high school really meant taking a giant step. Since there was no school on Bayberry Island, Bonnie had to leave her family and go off to the mainland. This is the story of that eventful period in her life: the four years at school in a small Maine town, vacations at home and an ill-fated summer at a music camp.

Barring some last-minute development, the months-long fight for control of the New York Central Railroad will reach a showdown on Wednesday in Albany. More than 90 per cent of the railroad's 6,447,410 outstanding shares are expected to be voted that day.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 22 -- Negro leaders of eighteen Southern and border states met in a closed conference here today to map a course of action under the Supreme Court decision banning segregation in the public schools.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 22 -- Except for Moncay, which remains in French Union hands at the eastern end of the Tonkin-Kwangtung border, and for a narrow coastal strip south of Moncay, the French-Vietnamese holdings in North Vietnam (Tonkin) are now restricted to the Red River Delta.
A Milwaukee man, cured by Alcoholics Anonymous, was sued for divorce by his wife because he spent all his time in the organization and was never home.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Freeing the atom to make its potential a peacetime driving force appeared today to pose as many problems as the first atomic bomb.
LONDON, Ont., May 22 -- The problem of saving Ontario farmlands from the encroachments of industry is expected to be made more acute when the St. Lawrence Seaway is built.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 22 -- Pennsylvania, rowing its first dual race of the season, scored by five lengths over Rutgers on the Raritan River today. The Quakers crossed the finish line 22 seconds in front of the Scarlet shell.
ONE of the fascinating aspects of reporting the child development field over the past five years has been observing changes of feeling and opinion on the topic of youngsters and television.

Professional guidance of pre-medical students, established ten years ago in New York City's four municipal colleges, has contributed greatly to the high rate of acceptance into leading medical schools of the country. A report prepared by the Board of Higher Education indicates that municipal college graduates who applied to medical schools for the current academic year achieved a higher rate of acceptance than applicants from the rest of the country.

MANILA, Sunday, May 23 (UP) -- The Philippines Herald said today the No. 2 Huk rebel in this country is ready to surrender to Government authorities "soon." following in the footsteps of Louis Taruc. The paper said Mariano P. Balgos, who heads the Huk command in South Luzon, has signified his intention to surrender.

QUITE a few months ago there was a discussion on this page whether an adult, near or at middle age, ought to consider studying a musical instrument for the first time. The question was raised by a reader who wanted to know whether she should take some tests to check if she had natural qualifications.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 22 -- The entry of President Eisenhower into the rhubarb over whether the record of the so-called "strategy session" of high Administration officials should be made available to the McCarthy-Army investigating committee appears to have heightened Texas interest in the hearings.

THIS is a historic moment for the Chinese. After a century and a half of domination by foreign powers, China -- that is, the continental body of China controlled by the Communists -- is today negotiating from a position of strength at an international conference with the greatest of the Western nations.

AMONG the many books which have been written about Latin America, this one is unique in many respects. It is not travel literature or journalism or history, yet it partakes of all three. It is a work of interpretation, distinguished by good judgment and good humor.
RALEIGH, N. C., May 21 -- In North Carolina two affirmative reactions followed the Supreme Court decision.

HARTFORD, May 22 -- The Connecticut Public Expenditure Council said recently that Connecticut taxpayers would have to make some important decisions in the next ten years because of a coming rapid increase in public school enrollment.

FORT HUACHUCA, Ariz., May 22 -- This fort that was the base for the Army's operations against Geronimo and his Apaches is being prepared to take over from Fort Monmouth, N. J., the electronics proving ground phase of Signal Corps activity.

LALI HORSTMANN, wife of an ex-diplomat who served as German Minister in Belgium and retired from the service in 1933, lived the last years of World War II in Kerzendorf, a charming estate with an eighteenth-century mansion, about fifteen miles east of Berlin.

PARIS, May 22 -- Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall of Australia advanced and two Americans were eliminated today as the third round of the French tennis championships was completed despite intermittent showers.

In the three months since the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy flared into the open, the controversy has increasingly and inevitably become a conflict between the Administration and the Senator. The question which this conflict has raised -- a question which has large meaning for both parties in a campaign year -- is this: "How has the conflict affected Senator McCarthy's influence with the voters?"

CLEVELAND, May 22 -- Steel production in the Cleveland-Lorain district, which climbed to 78 per cent last week to match the highest mark of the last three months, dipped to 71 per cent this week. Orders for steel, which increased steadily over a three-week period and resulted in the retiring of seven additional open-hearth furnaces, have slumped and three furnaces were dropped this week.

WHETHER it is sold in a florist shop or greenhouse supermarket or roadside stand or from the wagon that goes up and down city streets, one of the hardest plants to resist now is a geranium in a four-inch pot. And a geranium with a red flower is impossible to resist.

FIFTY years ago, in 1904, a noted originator of beautiful peonies, Auguste Dessert of Chenonceaux, France, released to the world a new variety called Therese. Little did he know then that Therese was destined to become one of the greatest of all peonies and to exert incalculable influence that lead to the betterment of peonies in general.
WE are on the verge of a new summer theatre season. Soon someone will say, "And what do you do in the wintertime?"

THE end of a recession is as difficult to discern as its beginning. The economic indicators tend to confuse because they fail to show a clear- cut trend. Moreover, they will not necessarily follow one another, and while employment figures may show a rise, retail sales may appear to be going in the other direction.

IF you'd care to observe the range and variety of the modern spy novel, you should investigate two recent examples, both highly readable and suspenseful but representing opposite poles in their attitudes toward espionage, toward life and even toward the nature of a novel.

This is the between-season period for stores and resident buying offices are busy shopping fall lines and preparing reports for June meetings. Inclement weather over most of the country has slowed sales somewhat. However, most merchants look for a pick-up when the weather improves, and are optimistic about fall.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., May 22 -- Plans for summer troop training at near-by Camp Drum are now well advanced.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -- A House subcommittee's investigation of alleged Army coddling of athletes took a reverse tack today. The chairman, Representative William E. Hess, ordered an inquiry into possible discrimination against Billy Martin, the Yankee star.

THE term "creative" as applied to photographic achievement has been misconstrued, particularly in amateur circles, to mean abstraction as opposed to reality, Fred Stein, free-lance photographer and author of several picture books, said in a recent talk at the New York Public Library on "Creative Photography."
Evidence that locals of Harry Bridges' left-wing West Coast dock union had contributed funds to the embattled old International Longshoremen's Association was disclosed yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 22 -- The sixtieth year of the Yacht Racing Association on Long Island Sound opened with a new look today. There were new boats, new owners and skippers, and a new committee boat. But the notoriously fluky Sound weather was as of old.
TARANTO, Italy, May 19 -- Southern Italy is attracting more tourists than in the past from abroad and from the north of Italy.

The recent anomaly of Senators feeling compelled to testify on one of the crucial issues in the Army-McCarthy hearings points up the need for Congressional inquiry reform. For it is the duty of those same Senators impartially to make findings as to the very issues to which their testimony related after judging the credibility of all the witnesses, including themselves.

IN addition to the general field day iris bloom is having in New Jersey today, an official Iris Field Day is being held at Rutgers University, New Brunswick. The program includes displays of both blooming plants and cut specimens contributed by the Iris Society of New Jersey.
Consumers are buying more gas heaters but fewer vacuum cleaners.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 22 -- The endorsement by several Democratic clubs of former Representative Ernest Greenwood of Bay Shore for a comeback try against the incumbent, Representative Stuyvesant Wainwright of Wainscott, has started the political wheels turning in Suffolk County.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt put it up to the Army today to decide whether Pentagon records of monitored telephone calls in the McCarthy-Army dispute should be made available to Senate investigators.

Britain, though unmistakably second in power to the U. S., has a strong navy and air force in its own right, and Commonwealth ties with a quarter of the world's population living in a quarter of its territory.

May 1 offer a minor correction to the caption appearing with the 1927 picture of Buster Keaton accompanying Milton Shulman's "Then and Now" (May 9). The caption should have read "Keaton in" not "Keaton as "The General'" (italics mine).

The Borussia soccer team of Dortmund, Germany, winds up a six-game tour of the United States today with a match against the Chelsea Club of London. The contest at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, will begin at 3:15 P. M.

SET in a township called Avalon in the psychosomatic belt of Connecticut, "The Tunnel of Love" is a comedy of Upper Middlebrow suburban mores with overtones of farce and undertones of Sophoclean irony. The author has been faithful to his percept that "a novel should have a beginning, a muddle, and an end."
Two hundred scholars, business and labor leaders and Government officials will study American economic policy at Columbia University's third bicentennial conference, which begins Wednesday evening.
Dissatisfaction with a fact-finders' formula for transit labor peace erupted yesterday at an angry meeting of shop stewards and section managers of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.
More than 1,100 girls from thirty-one schools in the metropolitan area competed in the third annual high school track and field day events at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday.

In the wake of the Supreme Court decision outlawing segregation, the South last week began the difficult task of adjusting to a new school system. The dual system of education has been the accepted norm. Segregation was the law in seventeen states and the District of Columbia.

Cold and rainy weather continued to slow sales of seasonal apparel, with the result that retail sales in New York City's stores dipped about 5 to 10 per cent, according to estimates by retailers. Strength where shown was mainly in the hard goods categories.

MEXICO CITY, May 14 -- The Mexican and United States Governments will consult in Washington in June or July to study the effects of last month's devaluation of the peso, from 8.65 for one dollar to 12.50.

FOR the first time in its four-year run on television, the N. B. C. Sunday night "Comedy Hour" will continue through the summer. The hot weather series will present established headliners and fresh young talent -- many of whom will be new to television -- in a revue-type format.
ST. LOUIS, May 22 (UP) -- Four home runs, all with the bases empty, powered the Cincinnati Redlegs to a 4-2 victory over Joe Presko and the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

ALTHOUGH everyone talks about Chekhov with love and admiration, hardly anyone puts him on the stage. As the last production of its first season, the Phoenix Theatre is now acting "The Sea Gull," which has not been done in New York since the Lunts staged it in 1938.

This is a good time of year to sit on a brook bank, or out on your own lawn if the mower is not in sight, and think through to the answer on a few fundamental matters. Why does grass grow wild in the garden so much better than it does tame on the lawn?

Strong winds and waves up to ten feet kept the Coast Guard and police helicopters busy yesterday rescuing fishermen who had ignored small craft warnings. Seventeen persons, including two women, were brought to shore after mishaps in Rockaway Inlet and Jamaica Bay.
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 22 -- Interest in the Army-McCarthy controversy in the Middle Western states has continued at almost the same high pitch since the televised hearings began.

LONDON, May 22 -- The makers of British policy this week came face to face with a problem that has been developing steadily for more than a year and has been behind Anglo-American differences during that period. The problem is the choice between negotiation with the Communist bloc and maintenance, at all costs, of the Western alliance, in which Anglo-American unity is the principal factor.

All the available exhibition space on the first floor of the New York Public Library's Fifth Avenue building has been given over to material selected from eight recently acquired collections. Hundreds of items make up the exhibition, including rare works on chess, American historical documents, Presidential autographs and first editions of Robert Nathan.

RALPH VAUGHAN WILLIAMS comes to America next October as visiting professor at Cornell, where he will celebrate, on the 12th of that month, his eighty-second birthday. He will come not only as the greatest living English composer, but as a precipitating force in contemporary music.

BOSTON, May 22 -- The National Association of Cotton Manufacturers began this week distribution of a publication intended to "switch New England thinking from the mills that have gone to the mills that are here."

MEMBERS of the Caribbean Tourist Association were advised at the body's recent third annual meeting in Aruba in the Netherlands West Indies that their officers were hopeful of action by the present Congress toward eliminating the 10 per cent Federal travel tax on trips to the West Indies.

IN the Geneva Conference and other arenas of international affairs American diplomacy has been undergoing a new series of the most formidable tests. Embattled on a vast external front, and now at crisis in Asia, it finds itself assailed as well at home.

City College defeated Brooklyn College, 75 1/2 to 64 1/2, in a track meet on the loser's field yesterday. Each team won eight of the sixteen events as the Beavers recorded their fourth victory in five dual meets. It was the Kingsmen's first loss in five tests.

The University of Rochester has announced a sweeping reorganization of its undergraduate program in the College of Arts and Science under a Committee on Student Welfare, headed by a newly appointed dean of instruction and student services. Knowland, who is a member, the week-by-week program that the Republicans, as the responsible party, must bring to the Senate floor for action.

LONDON, May 22 (AP) -- Violetta Elvin, the Russian-born beauty, returned in triumph last night with the Sadler's Wells Ballet after an injury had cut short her American tour six months ago and had threatened her career. The critics and the public loved her.

DETROIT, May 22 (UP) -- Minnie Minoso connected for a three-run homer in the ninth inning today to give the Chicago White Sox a 5-to-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers before 10,974 fans at Briggs Stadium.

LONDON, May 22 -- In the six months ended May 15, the Board of Trade received 216 applications from British industrialists for licenses to export machine tools to the Soviet Union and has allowed sixty-one, amounting to 2,202,262 ($6,165,773).

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Rows of seedlings from seeds planted outdoors two to four weeks ago require thinning if they are to develop properly. Soil should be moist before attempting to thin, so that the seedlings can be pulled out with the least disturbance to those left in place. Thinning should start after the second pair of leaves forms.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22 -- The fifty-four-year-old Workmen's Circle, which has combated communism since the Russian Revolution, adopted stringent measures here today to circumvent any Communist infiltration into its ranks.

A BIG retrospective exhibition of an artist's work, such as that of sculpture by Jacques Lipchitz at the Museum of Modern Art, is always a severe test. The exhibition includes more than a hundred and twenty pieces representing forty years of unswerving search for the forms that would express adequately the steadily expanding philosophy of the artist.

REVIEWER Henry Steele Commager indicates his agreement with Harold Taylor's view expressed in his book "On Education and Freedom" that colleges and universities are "institutions where students and scholars engage * * * in the imaginative search for truth." Commager then observes that "from this elementary fact" it follows "that we must eschew abstractions and loose theories about education" All of which poses some pertinent questions.

LONDON, May 22 (Reuters) -- More than half the money needed to provide a dignified retirement for the famed sailing ship Cutty Sark has been received by the Cutty Sark Preservation Society, it was announced this week.

MADISON, Wis., May 22 -- Harvard's young, rangy crew rowed to a half-length victory over Wisconsin today.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 22 (AP) -- Tom Lawson McCall, a 41-year-old political newcomer, gave a surprise beating to Representative Homer D. Angell in yesterday's Oregon primary election.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Earl Warren is nearing the end of the first term of court since he became Chief Justice of the United States, amid growing convictions that he is a "take-charge guy" -- the kind of leader who, on a baseball club, inspires teamwork among the other players.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 22 -- The appointment of Prof. T. Cuyler Young as chairman of Princeton University's Department of Oriental Languages and Literatures and director of the pioneering program in Near Eastern affairs, was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 22 -- The strike situation has worsened on the north coast of Honduras. The Government is considering drastic action, possibly martial law.

Although the stock market continued its advance last week, gains were on a more selective basis than before. Trading was heavier, but the progress was less spectacular, with price moves quite mixed at times. While a new high for the movement was achieved, stocks wavered under moderate selling pressure as secondary issues gained An prominence.

NEXT Sunday the Shenandoah Central Railroad at Penn Laird, Va., will start its second year of operation as a museum of narrow-gauge railroading. With its one and only train, the famed Tweetsie, all slicked up and ready to go, the museum will mark the start of the season by the issuance of a first anniversary cachet cover.

MANHASSET, L. I., May 22 -- Yale and Harvard divided the first four matches today in the final round of the court tennis tournament for the James H. Van Alen Intercollegiate Trophy.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 22 -- The Saw Mill River, which meanders for 23.5 miles from ponds at Chappaqua to the Hudson River at Yonkers, received a moderately clean bill of health today from sanitation engineers.
ATHENS, May 22 -- Greece and her northern neighbor, Bulgaria, are to resume normal diplomatic relations after thirteen years of enmity.

White Skies gave another successful exhibition of weight carrying at Belmont Park yesterday. BOSTON, May 22 -- New Englanders appeared this week to welcome the respite in the Army-McCarthy hearings, but apparently only to give themselves a chance to get their second wind. There was ample evidence that interest in the hearings had grown, rather than diminished.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 22 -- The struggle to halt the spread of the Mau Mau is centering on the Kamba tribe. The Kambas furnish the core of native African police and most of the recruits for the King's African Rifles.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, May 3 -- Little Swaziland's efforts to escape from South Africa's attempts to extend its sovereignty and its color bar system of life threaten to embroil the South African Union with Portuguese Mozambique.
As business loans by banks continue to decline, an increasing volume of commercial credit requirements is being met through open-market borrowing.

Economic trends in the steel industry, widely considered among the most sensitive of business barometers, are expected to get a thorough airing by some 1,200 steel executives and operating officials here this week.
Seventy would-be Coast Guard officers, each loaded with dozens of questions, got their answers yesterday on a guided tour of Coast Guard facilities in New York Harbor.

THE novel built around a man's driving ambition is no new thing, but it usually turns out to be a rather grim account of crushed victims and sacrificed ideals. Certainly Felix Holt's new novel, which deals with that theme, doesn't dodge the matter of victims and ideals, but it is far from grim.

CONVENTIONS must be great fun for a lot of people. Otherwise why should such big crowds congregate at regional, state, national and international get-togethers time after time, apparently with undiminished enthusiasm?

RABAT, Morocco, May 21 -- Francis Lacoste, career diplomat who was appointed yesterday as French Resident General in Morocco, will find many urgent problems when he arrives in Rabat in ten days to fortnight hence. M. Lacoste succeeds Gen. Augustin Guillaume.

YONKERS, May 22 (AP) -- Tom Walters took the lead with Volto Man at the three-quarters pole and went on to win the $5,500 Woodlawn junior free-for-all pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway in 2:04 2-5. The Woodlawn highlighted the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers, which ended its spring meeting tonight.

With Mickey Mantle taking charge at bat and Allie Reynolds in command on the mound, the Yankees bounced back to defeat the Red Sox, 7 -- 0, before a Ladies Day crowd of 27,734 at the Stadium yesterday.

STANLEY KUBRICK, the young man from the Bronx, who, at 25, has independently turned out several short subjects as well as "Fear and Desire," the feature-length drama released here last year, reports that he is in the process of editing his second feature production.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd said today it was the "public duty" of Albert M. Cole to make known at once the identity of any persons who had reaped "unconscionable and unwarranted" profits out of Government-insured apartment construction loans.

CHICAGO, May 22 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves staged two ninth-inning rallies today to sweep a double-header from the Chicago Cubs, 5 to 1 and 11 to 9, before 30,267 fans and moved into a second-place tie with the Dodgers.
Adoption of some pension and profit-sharing plans is being held in abeyance because of proposed changes in the Internal Revenue Code.

Senator Flanders in "What Ails the United States Senate" (May 9) discussed the Senate's abuse of its investigative powers and very properly raised the question of the responsibility of the electorate and of the press.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 22 -- Officials of Roosevelt Raceway, where a threatened strike by horse owners may delay Monday's scheduled opening, said tonight the harness horse owners had rejected a compromise agreement.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 22 -- Army's baseball team, the closest pursuer of Navy, the leader in the Eastern Intercollegiate League, dropped a 12-6 decision to Cornell today.

THIN, tender, boneless slices of veal long have provided appealing dishes in many countries. The Italians, in dealing with them, call them scaloppine (literally, pieces), and prepare them diversely as well as deliciously.
The American Radio Association, C. I. O., informed the Federal Communications Commission last week that it favored ending the issuance of temporary limited licenses for shipboard radio officers.
The Federal capital gains tax is still in a period of evolution. Its development, however, does not follow broad and undeviating principles.

The Senate Bill 3378, to provide a Revised Organic Act for the Virgin Islands, is now being considered by the United States Senate. While this bill grants certain economic benefits to the people of the Virgin Islands, it would at the same time curtail certain powers which are now vested in the Legislative branch of the Government.

LONDON, May 22 -- Cecil Frank Powell, Nobel Prize winner for physics four years ago, urged on behalf of his fellow-scientists today that Britain take the initiative toward a United States - British - Soviet conference on hydrogen-bomb control.
PIERRE, S. D., May 22 -- With Senator Karl E. Mundt having no opposition, interest in South Dakota's June 1 primaries will center solely on nominations for Governor by both Republicans and Democrats.

The Moscow correspondent of this newspaper has been following reports of what Soviet scientists have been doing on and under the surface of the Arctic. There is no question about the importance of the discoveries made. But, as usual, the Soviet scientists leave the impression that they and they alone know the Arctic.

The search by Dayton, Ohio, police for a young man charged with robbery and auto theft ended when they found their quarry at police headquarters being interviewed for a job on the force He had attained the highest grade in the examination
GENEVA, May 22 -- Within the last two weeks the two largest industrial countries of Western Europe have made a practical declaration of independence from the United States.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 22 -- Now that the Supreme Court of the United States has ruled out public school racial-segregation laws as unconstitutional, the great problem confronting the South is how to attain conformity with the spirit and intent of the historic ruling.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower tonight saw themselves portrayed in the leading roles of "Mamie's Matinee," a take-off on television "soap operas," presented by the Women's National Press Club.

THOSE who have been wading the trout streams only because the bass season was not open are now counting the days until the law is lifted on the largemouth and small-mouth. Thousands are willing to travel to enjoy the early fishing.
When William Stiles Bennet receives the Minute Man award of the National Society of the Sons of the American Revolution tomorrow at Williamsburg, Va., he will be honored for 123 years work.
BOSTON, May 22 -- Christianity must rise above the limitations of orthodoxy just as the free world must rise above nationalism if civilization is not to be wrecked, Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer said tonight.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., May 22 -- Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany and Democratic National Committeeman, declared tonight there was a trend in the nation that made "overwhelmingly" certain the election of a Democratic Governor in the coming state election.

BALTIMORE, May 22 (AP) -- Bob Toski cracked Mt. Pleasant's par today for the third straight round, going 2 under with a 70 and increasing his lead in the $20,000 Eastern open golf tournament to six strokes at 205.

" THE flowers that bloom in the spring" will be exhibited in their best attire Wednesday as part of the horticultural classes of the Spring Flower Show to be given by the Garden Section of the Scarsdale Woman's Club.
One way to assure [U. S. security] is to make certain that we do not overlook our own backyard * * * -- SENATOR ALEXANDER WILEY.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 22 -- The leader of East Pakistan, the largest province of Pakistan, said today it wished to become an independent state.

BELLINI: Hightlights From Norma; Re-issue of collectors' items, excerpts from the score as sung by Celestina Boninsegna, Giovanni Zenatello, Mario Gillion, Oreste Luppi, etc. (Eterna). Old acoustic recordings, of interest to vocal specialists.
GENEVA, May 22 -- In pushing the formation of a Southeast Asia defense pact, the United States is seeking to promote an anti-Communist front in a comparatively weak and disunited part of the world.
FORT ATKINSON, May 22 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy declared he wanted to "remind" President Eisenhower of precedents established in the Teapot Dome inivestigation.
Among the 225 doctors, technicians and scientists who moved last week into the $6,500,000 Atran General Laboratory of Mount Sinai Hosiptal was Mme. Pham Thi Thu, a research student from Indo-China.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sunday, May 23 (AP) -- Differences between the Communists and the West at Geneva echoed here yesterday at a three-and-a-half-hour session of the Korean Military Armistice Commission.

A CONTRARY folk, the people of the theatre grow morose over the first robin, bursts of forsythia, daylight saving and other manifestations of spring. They have reason for their resentment. By experience they know the havoc rising temperatures can work at the box office, how alarmingly they can advance the end of a show.

The annual meeting of the All-American Conference to Combat Communism heard yesterday a strong attack on American journalism by James F. O'Neil, past national commander of the American Legion and publisher of its magazine.

TOKYO, Sunday, May 23 (AP) -- Japan's versatile featherweight, Shozo Sasahara, today damaged Turkey's chances in the world amateur free-style wrestling championships by upsetting Bayam Sit, an Olympic titleholder.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 22 (UP) -- Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana said today the United States would not go to war unless Congress was consulted but would "fight back" if attacked.

IN the words of its author, "Typhoon in Tokyo" is the story "of the greatest civilian overseas commitment ever undertaken by Americans * * * a stupendous but improvised social experiment which used an empire and 74,000,000 people as its laboratory materials."

The Atomic Energy Commission is promoting the development of nuclear energy for the generation of electricity in the Pacific Northwest. Traditionally a hydro generating territory, a novel arrangement has been worked out for the area in co-operation with privately-owned power companies.

WITH a below-the-surface scrutiny and a sympathetic feeling for her background material, Kathryn Grondahl dissects embassy life in picturesque Bangkok and comes up with an interesting first novel. The author writes perceptively of the diplomatic set, as well as those Siamese who mix with them on a social or business level.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The United States has refused Guatemalan requests to buy arms here because of the "obvious uncertainty" of the use that might be made of them, the State Department said today.

AFTER many months of what at times has seemed an overwhelming tendency toward fanciness in the modern interior, it was interesting to run across a series of rooms in which the individuals still held out strongly in favor of what could be called oversimplification.

The rather mild and bungling drive to cut the voting age to 18 by constitutional amendment has failed. Every Republican present in the Senate on Friday afternoon deferred to President Eisenhower's wishes and voted for it, rolling up a 34-24 majority. But so many Republican Senators packed their traveling bags and went home before the vote was taken that the resolution failed to get the required two-thirds majority.

HERE in the East, geraniums are a staple for summer. House plant enthusiasts may grow them indoors in winter or maintain a constant supply by moving geraniums outdoors in May and indoors again before frost in September.

FORT ATKINSON, Wis., May 22 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy tonight warned President Eisenhower that the McCarthy-Army hearings about to be resumed Monday in Washington could cause the "suicide" of the Republican party.

AS White House social secretary to three First Ladies, Mrs. Edith Benham Helm has seen a lot of recent history from inside the formidable barriers of protocol and precedence. When she left the White House in January, 1953, she closed the door on an office she had held for twenty-five years -- six with the Wilsons, twelve with the Roosevelts and seven with the Trumans.

A NOVELIST and a successful Ohio farmer, Louis Bromfield has here a rather odd book. It is redolent of a good many prejudices. And a good part of it is indistinguishable in tone and script, intentionally or not, from the political line of the old-fashioned Ohio-country Republicans, who were led by the late Senator Taft.

IN 1817 the twenty-fourth anniversary of the execution of Louis XVI was marked in Paris by the premiere of a new Requiem Mass in C minor by Cherubini. Ten years later the same Requiem was sung in Vienna at a memorial service for Beethoven just after his death.

St. John's Prep of Brooklyn captured the team title yesterday in the thirty-eighth annual track and field championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium, the Bronx.

Eight boys 16 and 17 years old were arraigned yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court on a charge of "unlawful assembly." They had been part of a large group dispersed by the police from a playground at Gleason and Noble avenues, the Bronx, on Friday night just before a gang fight.

MANY individuals today seek frantically for anchors amid the tempests of our time. To make the search less frantic and more realistic, Lowell Russell Ditzen, pastor of the Reformed Church of Bronxville, New York, has written a penetrating analysis of the causes of personal insecurity and the ways and means of attaining personal security.

HIGH up in a fashionable Fifth Avenue hotel one recent afternoon, a plain, quiet-spoken woman looked back. Immediately ahead loomed her first trip abroad, and Marjorie Main sounded as though she might take the Queen Elizabeth, and Europe, well in stride.
Henry T. Folsom, senior vice president of the H. D. Folsom Arms Company of New York, announced yesterday that he would resign from the firm to study for the Protestant Episcopal ministry.

THE men and women who got their first college degrees twenty-five years ago, as members of the "depression" class of '29, may not like to admit it; but they are now past 45, the men with less or graying hair, the women with fewer illusions about everything, including men -- and all of them incredulously, unmistakably and irrevocably middle-aged.
