President Eisenhower's proposed formation of an international pool of knowledge and experience to develop the peacetime potentialities of atomic power met with world-wide approval. Even the Russians, who were to be important participants, at first looked with some favor on the proposal, probably because nothing was said about international inspection of uranium distribution and plants and because the military applications of atomic energy were deliberately excluded from consideration.
THE big profits in bridge come from doubling the opponents, and the average player does not double often enough. Nevertheless, players also do quite a bit of doubling when they should not.
BOSTON, May 22 -- Unrest in Massachusetts penal institutions was laid this week to "unwarranted inadequacies" in the correctional system.

The House of Representatives has passed and sent to the Senate a bill intended to save the frigate Constellation, America's oldest fighting ship. The Navy will be authorized to haul the Constellation from Boston, where she lies rotting, to Baltimore, where the vessel was built and launched in 1797.
HONG KONG, May 22 (Reuters) -- Charles E. Wilson, United States Defense Secretary, said here today that "broadly speaking it is a mistake to fight for somebody unless they want you to do so."

Scientists and educators at the University of Michigan have just completed a "classroom of tomorrow," which opens new horizons for educators, architects and builders seeking to create the ideal environment for learning. Educational authorities have called it the most advanced schoolroom in America today.
The lost battle of Dienbrenphu was still influencing the course of history last week.

GRANADOS: Goyescas; El Pelele; Nikita Magaloff, pianist (London). This is not a complete version of Granados' gorgeous suite. Magaloff plays the first-four of the six pieces. "El Pelele" does not belong to the "Goyescas" set.

AUTHORIZATION for the City of New York to operate a television station, granted ten days ago by the Federal Communications Commission, would appear to dictate a fresh approach to non-commercial TV in this community. The time is at hand for those interested in achieving a new and different programming service, complementing rather than competing with the output of existing commercial stations, to join forces for the public good.

ASCALON, Israel -- For a picnic in antiquity, it is hard to beat this blessedly green spot on the sandy coast of Israel which, for more than two thousand years, was a favorite with the Philistines, the Greeks and the Crusaders.

Young officers of spirit and ability are now quick to perceive "how shoddy are the rewards for a successful career in the armed forces," a commander in the Regular Navy declared recently in commenting on the problem of service morale.

THE New York Dance Film Society has announced the schedule of its three-program festival next month at the Museum of Modern Art. The dates are June 10, 17 and 24, and since last year's festival was completely sold out ten days before the series opened, it would be well to make reservations promptly.

REMARQUE'S new novel about a front-line soldier of World War II is so different in imaginative and historical feeling from "All Quiet on the Western Front" that there would be no reason to relate the two if Remarque had not provoked comparison by making their concluding paragraphs almost identical.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 22 -- Widespread rains and cool temperatures retarded the movement of seasonal merchandise last week. Household appliances have begun to pick up in volume, notably in the major appliances and in furniture, but remained below the year-ago level.
PRINCETON, N. J., May 22 -- Fordham's baseball team handed Princeton its fourth straight reversal today with a 4-1 decision on University Field.
MELBOURNE, Australia, May 15 -- Australian electors go to the polls on Saturday, May 29, for the triennial general election of the House of Representatives. A close race is indicated.
THE back-to-work movement appears to be gaining momentum in Hollywood studios. In March, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer raised its production schedule for the year from eighteen to twenty-six pictures.
A fleet of nineteen vessels -- seven excursion steamers and twelve sight-seeing boats -- will be on hand this summer to provide New Yorkers with one-day cruises and shorter trips.
A program of orientation for new members of the faculty will begin at Hunter College in September, George N. Shuster president, announced yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 22 (AP) -- Averell Harriman said today that "the return to discredited Republican policies in Washington and [Governor] Dewey's complacent inaction in Albany" were responsible for the drop in farm income and the rise in unemployment.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., May 22 -- Lawrenceville and The Hill School waged an extra-inning thriller this afternoon with a single by Charley Shumway in the thirteenth enabling file Lawrentians to triumph, 3 -- 2. The safety broke up a keen duel between Chuck Heppenstall, the winning pitcher, and Bob Hydeman.

DES MOINES, May 22 -- Primary contests in Iowa this year will center on a Republican fight for the Gubernatorial nomination and four races in both parties for Congressional nominations.

REALLY three books in one, "Zapotec" is (1) a sentimental journey through Mexico's Southland; (2) a study of the history, customs, folklore and character of the Zapotecs and their neighbors; and (3) a speculative excursion into some of the problems of American culture.

THIS spring a great many people must have been reading "Huckleberry Finn" at the same moments I was. How many of them, I wonder, were reminded again how conclusively it proves that a great work of fiction does not need to be what is called a "good novel" or, indeed, a merely "good" anything else.

SAN MIGUEL ALLENDE, Mexico -- A method of combining a month or two of study of fine arts and handicrafts with a comprehensive exploration of little visited central Mexico is being discovered by large numbers of budget-conscious American families.
BUENOS AIRES, May 22 -- The Argentine Government will be ruled by a six-man super-Cabinet after Congress approves next week a bill reorganizing the nation's administrative machinery.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 22 -- The Turkish-Pakistani pact, keystone of Washington's Middle East policy, is threatened by the drive for Moslem unity.

President Eisenhower recently submitted to Congress what he described as "a minimum program" based on the findings of the Randall Commission on foreign economic policy. "Conceived as a whole," he said, "this program consists of four major parts: aid -- which we wish to curtail; investment -- which we wish to encourage; convertibility -- which we wish to facilitate, and trade -- which we wish to expand."

NEWARK, May 22 -- The National Administration's acceptance of the current rate of housing construction -- 100,000 units a year -- as adequate was characterized as "calamitous" today by Dr. William C. Wheaton.
DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- Thirty-nine thoroughbreds and two lead ponies died today in a fire which destroyed a wooden barn at the Detroit Race Track in suburban Livonia.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 22 -- After capturing a long extra hole semi-final, Jack Lyons, Garden City Golf Club member, won the Walter J. Travis Memorial tourney at his home course today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Plans are nearly complete for military staff talks among representatives of the United States, Britain, France, Australia and New Zealand in Washington in the next ten days or two weeks.

New York City's on-again-off-again commercial services tax was off again last week -- for good. Two months ago Mayor Wagner, searching for $30,000,000 in new revenue to finance wage increases for city employes, proposed to extend the 3 per cent city sales tax to commercial services (brokerage houses, advertising, public relations, repairs, maintenance, among others).

THE tall bearded iris are beginning to flower now as far north as Long Island and New York City. But North, South, East or West, growers and gardeners are still enjoying and talking about a new group of smart-flowered, low-growing, intermediate iris named Lilliput Hybrids.
The Fifth Amendment to the Constitution is being widely abused by witnesses before Congressional committees, high school students on a New York Times Youth Forum panel agreed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- Coming up with a varied attack that included a two-run homer by Monte Irvin and a dazzling steal of home by Don Mueller, the Giants tonight contrived to bring about a sharp change in their fortunes.

THE Budd Company announced last week that it had finally made the first sale of its new Siesta Coach, the coach-fare, room-type sleeping car it has been peddling to the nation's railroads for the past year.
While city and state employes are receiving pay increases in line with rising living costs, 150 Customs Service workers here are faced with demotions and salary slashes ranging up to $500 annually.

SATIRE has become rare enough in United States letters. Anyone with the authentic gift ought to be put on government subsidy as a contributor to the general welfare, not that this is any more likely to happen today than at any other time.

CLEVELAND, May 22 -- Al Smith's tenth - inning single, which drove in Rudy Regalado from second, gave the Cleveland Indians their ninth straight victory today, a 4-3 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles. The Indians' first-place margin remained at two games.

DECORAH, Iowa -- Transcontinental motorists who like to take time out from driving to poke around museums and pick up interesting background facts on the settling of the country should make a note of the Norwegian-American Historical Museum here at Decorah in northwest Iowa.

LONDON -- Travel experts in the United States and the United Kingdom have estimated that in the current year about 250,000 travelers will move by sea and air from the United States to Great Britain. This advance report is written by an early-season American tourist who has just completed a swing through the northeast country to Edinburgh and back by way of the Border and Lake countries.
ATLANTA, May 22 -- In the southeastern states the Army-McCarthy conflict has had to take a back seat this week.

IN this collection of ten stories and three poems Robert Lowry offers fragmented attitudes, moral indignation, the verbal accompaniment for a George Grosz landscape. Contrapuntal themes which rose briefly to the surface of four previous novels have now become atolls, isolated and forbidding.

AN old song kept running through my mind as I read Rosamond Marshall's story of Renaissance Italy. "She's more to be pitied than censured," I hummed, thinking of the heroine, "for a man was the cause of it all."
HANOI, Vietnam, May 22 -- Lieut. Genevieve de Galard-Terraube, 29-year-old French nurse who is a prisoner at Dienbienphu, has been permitted by the Vietminh to Send a letter to her mother in Paris.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- "A rising spring, a summer lull and a fall spurt" is the business forecast of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. Business men recognize that declines thus far have been moderate and are confident that "we're due to come out of this thing soon," the bank says.
Comprehension is the greatest gift the United States can give to Puerto Rico, Mrs. Felisa Rincon de Gautier, City Manager of San Juan, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- John Foster Dulles is carrying the burden of United States policy in the Indo-China crisis very much as did his illustrious Republican predecessor, Henry L. Stimson, in the Far Eastern crisis of 1931 and 1932.

THE years after the Revolution were perilous for the young American Republic. Some factions, seeking power, advocated war with France -- others wanted reunion with Britain. John Adams, our second President, putting duty and the welfare of his country above partisan feeling, managed to steer the nation on a sane course.

PARIS, May 23 -- Indo-Chinese stocks on the Paris Bourse continue to suffer as a result of military events in Indo-China. Their fall last week was less severe than that of the previous week, but ratings in virtually every department are now lower than they were on March 15, when the first attacks on Dienbienphu were announced.

MANHASSET, L. I., May 23 -- A crowd of 60,000 persons, quadrupling yesterday's attendance, scored a record gate for North Shore charity fetes today at the third annual country fair of the North Shore Hospital on the polo field of the John Hay Whitney estate. Traffic was bumper to bumper from two main highways -- Routes 25D and 25A -- along Valley Road.

PARIS, May 23 (UP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., led five United States players into the quarter-finals of the French clay courts tennis tournament today by whipping top-seeded Lewis Hoad of Australia, 6 -- 2, 2 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, in one of the year's greatest upsets.

ZURICH, Switzerland, May 23 -- The Finance Miinster of West Germany has published in the Swiss press the terms of an offer to exchange original German debt certificates held by Swiss residents for new scrip.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 23 -- Turkey's emergent labor movement flexed its political biceps today in a declaration calling on the Government to grant the right to strike.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Aid Chief, said today adoption of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's East-West trade policies would leave this country standing alone and make world war three "more inevitable."
SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 -- Congress is being urged by Pacific Coast steamship lines not to act hastily on "piecemeal" legislation dealing with Panama Canal tolls.
LONDON, May 23 -- The British Association of Scientific Workers, meeting here today, urged the limitation of armaments and effective inspection and control of atomic weapons.
This is the first of two articles on problems facing the nation's airports.

ATLANTA, May 23 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today instructed its branch offices in Southern states to petition local school boards for action to abolish public school racial segregation "without delay."

Parents should "use television as a worth-while family experience, not as a chamber of horrors or a built-in baby sitter," the Rev. Edwin B. Broderick declared yesterday. He is director of radio and television for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.
CHICAGO, May 23 -- Much of the activity in the grain markets last week centered in the expiring contracts for May delivery.

At La Toque Blanche, newly opened restaurant at 350 East Fiftieth Street, the diner sees no photos of the Eiffel Tower, no sketches of La Place de la Concorde. The decorator, Pierre Jalier, said lightly that he wanted to create "at least one French restaurant in New York that would carry no memories of Paris."
The American flag, largely swept from the seas in recent months as far as chartering is concerned, reappeared in the ship charter market last week.
Advertising, a brokerage firm and atomic energy have set up a triple alliance.
J. Russel Sprague, who resigned last November as Republican National Committeeman, announced yesterday that he would not accept a new election to that post.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 23 (UP) -- United States authorities today postponed for at least three weeks an attempt to bring former Capt. James M. Leech from Ohio to face charges of murdering three fellow Army officers with an axe and fire.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Astonishment was expressed in Congress last week at Congress' own "baby," the Library of Congress. It got a talking to, and was threatened with a reduction in its spending money.
Webb Knapp, Inc., is completing negotiations to sell its majority interest in the Daniels Fisher Stores Company, ninety-year-old Denver department store, it was announced over the weekend.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 (AP) -- Wally Post, who hit two homers last night, drove in five runs today with another home run and a double as the Redlegs knocked the Cardinals out of the National League lead, 13 -- 6.

Msgr. John A. Flynn, president of St. John's University, Brooklyn, urged yesterday that individuals re - examine their rights and obligations under law as the first step in implementing Catholic Action in their lives.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Some of Hitler's former generals and other high officers are turning up in the uniform of Soviet-controlled East Germany's police force-army.

Schools will close in a few weeks. All over the land teenagers look forward to summer vacation and fun. Besides their blue jeans and sweaters, shirts, shorts and bathing suits, their wardrobe must include some day-time and party dresses.

The Fund for the Advancement of Education announced yesterday the granting of 274 fellowships to public high school teachers for the 1954-55 academic year. The grants total $1,480,000.
MANHASSET, L. I., May 23 -- The first invitation intercollegiate court tennis tournament to be held in this country was won by Yale today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Government is prepared to set up a "clearing house" of Federal employes who survive in the event of an atomic attack on Washington.
OTTAWA, May 23 -- Canada this year is concentrating a greater effort than ever on her mineral potential in the vast, largely unknown North.

GLASSER, N. J., May 23 -- Rain squalls whipping through these rocky North Jersey mountains seemed to help rather than spoil the northern season's first outboard regatta today on Henderson Cove, an arm of Lake Hopatcong.
India will extend research on burlap to the United States with a view to increasing industrial uses of her largest export to this country, according to a jute industry delegation visiting here.
GENEVA, May 23 -- The Korean phase of the Far Eastern conference has entered a period of hard and probably fruitless negotiations.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- An Air Force colonel spotted an apple-green lake in an Arctic wilderness during World War II. As a result, a scientific expedition will try to determine this summer whether the Labrador crater that holds the lake may have been caused by a meteorite.

LONDON, May 23 -- In the week that has elapsed since the bank rate was reduced it has been possible to gauge the city's initial reactions to this change in monetary conditions. These have been very much as expected.

Now that the tumult of a few uninformed readers has died down, perhaps it would be well to bring to the attention of the great mass of readers of The New York Times the real facts concerning the St. Lawrence Seaway.

COSENZA, Italy, May 21 -- This provincial town lies at the foot of one of the most beautiful and most backward regions of Italy. It is the Sila, one of nature's great fortresses, a steeply eroded highland of about 2,000 square miles in the toe of Italy's boot.
Two 25-year-old automotive workers who were arrested yesterday on robbery charges attributed their predicament to a hospitable cab driver.

Auto use tax stamps must be affixed to the windows of New York City cars by June 15. The stickers may be bought in person or by mail from the borough offices of the Bureau of City Collections. Checks should be made out to the Bureau of City Collections and should be accompanied by a self-addressed stamped envelope.

A survey of technical assistance and cooperation in seventy-nine countries, made by this newspaper's correspondents and summarized by Will Lissner today, shows the miracles that can be achieved with a comparatively small sum of money in helping people help themselves.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 23 -- Medical science has conquered most of the major diseases that once made the tropics "inhospitable" for permanent white residents, a United Nations report maintains. However, there has been a failure to achieve similar relief for many millions of the native populations, Dr. M. Vaucel of France asserted in the World Health Organization bulletin.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower, attending services today at the National Presbyterian Church, heard the Supreme Court's anti-segregation decision described as "logic to its fruition."

As a railroad clerk (subway token salesman) I am in a position to note how the city administration, the old Board of Transportation and the present Transit Authority have all unwittingly contributed to juvenile delinquency.

HANOI, May 23 -- (AP) -- The French High Command in Saigon announced tonight that French and Cambodian troops had withdrawn from Siempang in northeastern Cambodia. Siempang, a community of about 3,000, was attacked in April by two batallions of Vietminh troops invading from Laos.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that there had been fifty-eight more registration statements filed under the Foreign Agents Registration Law during 1953.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 23 -- The Vietminh insurgents declared today that a total of 858 French Union wounded would be released from Dienbienphu in the airlift evacuation that began May 14.
HAWTHORNE, N. Y., May 23 -- Governor Dewey joined with the Jewish Board of Guardians today in "an assault on barriers to social progress and the ramparts of ignorance in the field of mental illness."
In your editorial on May 4 you hail the possibility of "water metering at last," and generally decry the fact that New York City has been so tardy and remiss in adopting "universal" water metering.

Following is a country-by-country survey by correspondents of The New York Times of governmental and international programs of technical cooperation and assistance in seventy-nine lands. The statistical data have been compiled from reports of the several administrations. Totals are given for the last two fiscal or calendar years. United Nations totals are contingent upon payment of pledged contributions. Domestic contributions reported cover in most cases only part of recipient's expenditures.

In talks before the Committee for Economic Development in Washington last Friday, President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles both stressed the importance of maintaining this nation as a permanent showcase of freedom, security and high living standards.

MOSCOW, May 23 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party secretary, appeared together today at a big sports spectacle in Dynamo Stadium dedicated to the 300th anniversary of the union of the Ukraine and Russia.

Larry Evans, United States champion, headed the Marshall team against the Manhattan Club in the final round of the Metropolitan Chess League title play yesterday. He defeated Arnold S. Denker, national champion in 1944, at the top board in the competition at Manhattan's rooms.

In a vigorous letter addressed to the Mayor, Harold Riegelman, counsel of the Citizens Budget Commission, revives the proposal to supply the city with all the water it needs by drawing on the Hudson River. Drink river water polluted by the effluents of a hundred towns that line the river?
A strong undertone prevailed for the British pound sterling and Canadian dollar in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Business transacted was reported as only moderate in volume.

The Children's Aid Society, which last year observed its 100th anniversary, has now entered upon another century of service to New York City children. In its annual report the Society reviews the work it has done in the past, and points to the many problems that still remain before it.
LONDON, May 23 -- Sir Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden examined in the quiet countryside today the possibility of failure at Geneva -- and what Britain, with her Allies, could do to offset it.
LONDON, May 23 (Reuters) -- Roman Catholic leaders in England and Wales have approved a plan for a survey of the personal background of Catholics.

DETROIT, May 23 -- The chief spokesman for the World Council of Churches was sharply critical here tonight of recurring efforts to prevent the entry into this country of church leaders from behind the Iron Curtain.
Three thousand worshipers attended a ceremony yesterday at Carnegie Hall as part of the Marian Year program of the Blue Army of Our Lady of Fatima.
Better ways of cleaning cotton floor coverings in the home are being studied under the auspices of the United States Department of Agriculture by the Hoover Company of North Canton, Ohio.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $83,419,427,692. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
A series of brief showers, chasing a hide-and-seek sun repeatedly out of sight, kept crowds on the highways and beaches yesterday down to readily maneuverable size.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 23 -- Gold and foreign exchange reserves last week rose 30,000,000 guilders to 4,469,000,000 guilders, a new high. The guilder is worth about 26.45 cents.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., May 23 -- Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr. took the day off from his International Class title-defense with Susan today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland today announced appointment of a National Sponsors Committee for the newly organized America-Israel Society.

The visible supply of state and municipal bond offerings for the next thirty days totals $598,782,748, compared with $307,808,352 a week ago, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This does not include $119,210,000 of local housing authority bonds scheduled for June 22.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 23 (AP) -- Ethiopia, which claims to be the original home of the coffee bean, is beginning a vast expansion program to claim a major share of world coffee production.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox, seeking their first pennant since 1919, today acquired George Kell, third baseman, in a trade with the Boston Red Sox. The White Sox gave up infielder Grady Hatton and a "very substantial sum of cash."

DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox, silenced for seven innings by Steve Gromek, erupted in the eighth for three home runs -- by Minnie Minoso, Cass Michaels and Sherman Lollar -- to complete a three-game sweep over the Detroit Tigers today. The score was 4 -- 3.

One important milestone at the Geneva conference on Korea has been passed. The Republic of Korea has presented a clear, moderate and entirely reasonable proposal for the unification of a free Korea. Seoul has made its direct concession to the United Nations Powers and has endorsed the principle of a nation-wide election for a new Assembly.

At 6:13 yesterday evening a rainbow appeared over Ebbets Field, with one end seeming to be in short right center field. At that moment, while the Dodgers didn't pick up the legendary pot of gold, they had achieved a lead over the hapless Pirates.
BUDAPEST, May 23 (Reuters) -- One of the world's hottest athletic combinations exploded behind the Iron Curtain today to hand England a crushing soccer defeat.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy and his wife Jean returned here by plane this afternoon from a week-end trip to Wisconsin.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Eisenhower Administration once rejected the two-price system, but has now put it to use in a major way to dispose of farm surpluses.

THE New York Central Railroad's Shareowners Special, due to leave Grand Central Terminal for Albany at 8 o'clock Wednesday morning for the most important annual meeting in the road's history, will literally be something special.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon smashed a home run and three doubles to pace a fifteen-hit Washington attack today as the Senators defeated the Athletics, 9 -- 4. Elmer Valo clouted a three-run homer for Philadelphia.

The New York City Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild announced yesterday that it had elected Frank Serri as president. Other officers elected were listed as Hubert T. Delany, Osmond K. Fraenkel, Leo J. Linder, Harold M. Phillips and David L. Weissman, vice presidents; Julius Cohen, treasurer, and Simon Schachter, executive secretary.

That hipper-dipper brand of running by Chico Ferro in Lawrenceville's 3-2 extra-inning victory over The Hill School on Saturday was something to see. The Red and Black shortstop, who hails from Havana, is a terror on the basepaths. He worries the pitcher as well as the catcher.

WHEN we drove into our driveway Wednesday night the whippoorwill was calling from one of the oak trees with a rasping sort of bong, or maybe a tonk, which would have seemed more appropriate to a South American jungle than to a Connecticut hillside. Honey began to bark furiously as soon as she heard us.
Veteran's groups held pre-Memorial Day services here yesterday to honor the men and the women who died in this country's wars.

The John Hay Whitney Foundation announced yesterday the award of "opportunity fellowships" to eight New Yorkers. They were among forty-eight young men and women getting $100,000 in fellowships this year.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 23 -- Delegates of farm organizations of twenty-seven nations attending the conference here of the International Federation of Agricultural Producers have plunged into a battle over greater economic freedom versus more effective control.
DALLAS, May 23 (UP) -- Phil Cavarretta said today that he had reached an agreement with the Chicago White Sox and would join the club tomorrow when it returned home from a road trip.
BONN, Germany, May 23 -- The West German and British Governments are in substantial agreement on a plan to bring about free convertibility of Western European currencies in the foreseeable future.

Heretofore associated exclusively with musicals, Abe Burrows will direct a play for a change. He has been engaged to stage "Reclining Nude," the Harry Kurnitz comedy formerly labeled "Reclining Figure." The attraction is scheduled to arrive here the week of Sept. 27 under the auspices of Martin Gabel and Henry M. Margolis, in association with Peter Cusick. Mr. Gabel also will appear in the cast.
Changes in merchandising personnel were announced yesterday by L. Bamberger Co., Newark and Morristown, N. J., department store operator.
Nine new films, including English, French, Italian, Greek and Russian imports, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

William White and Robert R. Young, contending for control of the New York Central Railroad, met yesterday for the first time since having lunch together on Feb. 2. They shook hands -- once. When photographers, caught short, asked for a repeat, Mr. White admonished, "You're not going to make a pink tea out of this." There was not a single other shake, either before or after the television program that brought the men together.

The N. B. C. Symphony, which gave its first concert on Dec. 25, 1937, yesterday "concluded a long series of broadcasts." The words were those of Ben Grauer, the announcer, and there was evidence that the concert was the last one the orchestra, which was brought to fame by Arturo Toscanini, was likely to give in public.
Famine-plagued India has increased her food production by 5,000,000 tons and thinks the time is near when, barring natural calamity, she will be self-sufficient in foodstuffs.

The Borussia soccer team of Dortmund, Germany, concluded a six-game tour of the United States yesterday by beating the Chelsea Club of England's First Division, 6 -- 1, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Army is planning to make a distinction in the four top enlisted grades between personnel who have leadership or supervisory jobs and those who do technical or administrative work.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Gordon Dean, former Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer "deserves many medals" for helping this country develop the atomic bomb.
RANGOON, Burma, May 23 (Reuters) -- The United States has approached the Burmese Government with an offer of renewed aid on the lines of that offered to India, several newspapers reported here today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- The Giants are still climbing. They walked right over the Phillies and into the first division today as they drove Curt Simmons to cover in three innings and from there went on to topple Steve O'Neill's cast, 6 to 4.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 23 (UP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, charged tonight the Republican Administration had "blueprinted" plans "to sweep under the rug" facts about rising unemployment.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., declared yesterday that Governor Dewey would share the responsibility if a strike of transit employes should occur here.

The seven-story commercial building at 197 Lafayette Street, in the entire block bounded by Lafayette, Broome and Kenmare Streets and Cleveland Place, has been purchased by Sidney Kramer and others, represented by Louis P. Sill, vice president of Herbert Charles Co.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- United States officials back from a visit to Hong Kong tell how the Chinese Communists exploited the misery of some of the million and a half anti-Communist Chinese refugees there.
Ratification of a new contract covering 5,300 members of New York Typographical Union 6 employed by New York commercial printing plants was announced yesterday.

In mid-March atomic scientists and experts from twenty or thirty companies interested in atomic energy and radioactive materials gathered at the Biltmore Hotel for a forum. Today, setting some kind of record for the proceedings of the learned, the results are available in a meaty volume called "Business Opportunities in Atomic Energy."*

The Ladson Realty Corporation of Great Neck, L. I., has sold the four-story apartment building for thirty-nine families at 37-76 Sixty-second Street, Woodside, Queens, to an investor in a deal negotiated by George Brezel, vice president of Sydney M. Siegel Co., New Gardens brokers. The property, which was modernized last year, is assessed at $130,000.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- If progress on appropriations bills is the key, as it usually is, Congress stands an excellent chance of meeting this year's adjournment target of July 31.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that he would not shrink from imposing new taxes to protect the welfare of the city's residents, including its school teachers and other employes.

TOKYO, Monday, May 24 (AP) -- A victory by Russia's Olympic heavyweight champion and the upset of Turkey's Olympic featherweight titleholder improved Russia's chances to retain its title as the world amateur freestyle wrestling competition reached the decisive stage today.

ALBANY, May 23 -- Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the State Thruway Authority, said today that he was "confident" the first toll section of the expressway would open on June 24. His statement discounted the interference of a three-week-old cement strike and was a change from his view of two weeks ago. He said then that the opening would have to be postponed if the strike continued.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd said today that lenders had filed claims for more than $150,000,000 from the Federal Housing Administration on defaulted Government-insured home repair loans.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 23 (AP) -- Twenty-seven seasoned drivers and six newcomers filled a record field today for the thirty-eighth annual 500-mile auto race May 31 in a hectic final qualifying session.
BOSTON, May 23 -- Dr. Jacob Trapp of the Community Church of Summit, N. J., described the present era today as "a troubled age of troubled St. Augustines, too much preoccupied with evil."

By legend George Washington tossed a silver dollar across the Rappahannock at Fredericksburg. Paul Leicester Ford said it was a stone. No matter. Some of the dollars contributed to the Greater New York Fund in its current campaign to help 423 agencies will go farther than Washington could toss them.

CLEVELAND, May 23 (AP) -- Pitcher Art Houtteman won his own game today with a twelfth-inning double that scored George Strickland and gave the Cleveland Indians a 2-1 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles in the night-cap of a double-header.

Demand deposit turnover declined 4 per cent in New York City in April, but remained at the March level throughout the rest of the country, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the week-end.
Many of us, naval officers and civilians, who knew him well were dismayed over The Times' Pasadena date-lined obituary of the late Rear Admiral Herbert V. Wiley, U. S. N.

ATLANTA, May 23 (UP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge declared today that Negroes and whites would not attend the same schools in Georgia even if troops were sent to enforce the Supreme Court's ban on segregation.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein has ruled that the new law barring state officials and officers of political parties from racing horses or having an interest in pari-mutuel tracks does not apply to John Hay Whitney.

The fourteen-story apartment house containing duplex suites of thirteen rooms each at 9 and 11 East Seventy-ninth Street has been purchased by Edwin L. Weisl and L. Boyd Hatch, who plan to convert the property to cooperative ownership. The Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker in the sale, and the cooperative plan will be supervised by Riker Co.

PROMINENT among this week's art events is the exhibition, opening on Thursday at the American Academy of Arts and Letters, of work in various mediums by newly elected members of the academy and by artists who received grants from the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

"A director of the International Monetary Fund," according to a dispatch to this newspaper from Geneva, has proposed that the I. M. F. be liquidated and its holdings of hard currencies (which are principally dollars) be distributed among the fifty-five member countries.

GENEVA, May 23 -- The Secretary General of the United Nations, Dag Hammarsjkold, arrived in Geneva today for an "administrative" meeting that may have bearing on the future work of his organization in the economic field.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- John L. Lewis, who could not swing a bank loan twenty years ago when his union was virtually penniless, is telling the bankers now.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Farm exports showed a seasonal gain in March but were still 3 per cent below shipments the same month last year, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
The pioneer of elevated express roads, the Miller Highway, is finally to be modernized.

GUATEMALA, May 23 -- The consensus here among Guatemalans and foreigners alike is that the United States has chosen the wrong issue in seeking a showdown with Guatemala over her purchase of arms from behind the Iron Curtain.
Dean James A. Pike of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine), criticized the churches of the country yesterday for "lagging behind secular society" in abolishing racial segregation.

Post-war population shifts and housing shortages are giving the city's public and private welfare and health agencies "new and serious" problems, according to the Welfare and Health Council of New York City.
Forty top-grade law students from ten universities have been appointed law assistants in the United States Attorney's office for the summer recess.
CHICAGO, May 23 -- Nine days of higher fares helped the Chicago Transit Authority to maintain an almost even keel financially in April, the Authority's monthly statement disclosed today.
Now that man-made fibers are appearing in materials on the yard-goods counters as well as the garment racks in stores, the home seamstress may wish to make use of such fabrics.

Eddy Gilmore, now with the London Bureau of The Associated Press, has written an account of his private and professional experiences during eleven years as a correspondent in Soviet Russia. The author, a winner of the Pulitzer Prize for reporting, covered World War II from Russia.

Scripts for a new radio series entitled "The American Story," which tells of this nation from the "age of discovery" to the "age of the atom," have been prepared by Broadcast Music, Inc., in association with the Society of American Historians.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 23 -- Jordan's highest court issued a ruling today that is expected to make two banks liable for payment of 5,000,000 to 6,000,000 ($14,000,000 to $16,800,000) to Arab depositors whose accounts are blocked in Israel.

"LAMP Unto My Feet," seen at 10 o'clock Sunday mornings over C. B. S. Television, is both one of the oldest and best of the religious programs on TV. Its succinct and unostentatious use of the dramatic format conveys the meaning of faith in easily understood terms.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- The American Federation of Labor Film Council has announced its opposition to the production in foreign countries of television films to be used in this country.
NEW HAVEN, May 23 -- The Yale University School of Forestry has leased 300 acres of the Valhalla (N. Y.) property of the John A. Hartford Foundation for research and education in forest biology.

PITTSBURGH, May 23 -- Based on the production experience of most companies, the steel industry is definitely on the upgrade. The trend is slow and bears a striking resemblance to the action pattern of the downward movement which set in in the fourth quarter of last year.

CHICAGO, May 23 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves took both games of a double-header from the Chicago Cubs today, 4 -- 2 and 9 -- 3, to sweep their five-game series, run their winning streak to seven games and move into a first-place tie with the Brooklyn Dodgers.

PARIS, May 23 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault returned to Geneva late tonight convinced that a cease-fire would be possible in Indo-China if the Soviet group could be convinced that there would be an Allied alliance in Southeast Asia should the Geneva conference fail.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 23 -- According to George M. Levy, chief counsel for the track, "chances are extremely slim" that Roosevelt Raceway will open its 108-night harness racing season tomorrow night.

Representative Chester E. Merrow, Republican of New Hampshire, predicted here yesterday that the Communist structure would begin to disintegrate when no additional force could be applied to the people of Communist-controlled countries.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 23 -- A 90-pound 2 1/2-year-old black and tan Doberman pinscher went to his first best in show today in the fifty-second event of the Long Island Kennel Club at the Meadow Brook Club.
BALTIMORE, May 23 (AP) -- Bob Toski coasted to his third major golf victory of the year, winning the $20,000 Eastern open today with a par 72 in the final round and a 72-hole score of 277.

Smoked tongue (45 cents a pound in one chain) provided a thrifty selection for the weekend. What remains in the refrigerator today has many culinary possibilities. Among them is this smoked tongue and vegetable casserole:

PARIS, May 23 -- The first plenary session of the Second International Conference of Manufacturers, attended by the delegates of the United States and thirteen European countries, opened today. Georges Villiers, president of the French Employers Association, was chairman.

TED WILLIAMS was seated atop a trunk in the Red So dressing room, methodically punching the pocket of his glove with his right fist. At sight of his visitor he leaped as violently as if he'd just been given a hotfoot.
A man and a puppy that he tried to rescue for a convalescent boy disappeared yesterday afternoon in an angry East River ebb-tide.
GENEVA, May 23 -- A study of the prospects of the conference on the Far East was begun here today by V. K. Krishna Menon, India's chief representative at the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- There appears to be an uncertain truce in the fight to liberalize this country's tariff and foreign trade policies.

GENEVA, May 23 -- If an armistice is reached in Vietnam, the United States will propose that a permanent political settlement be determined by the United Nations General Assembly. Whether an armistice can be obtained here remains doubtful, for the deadlock on Indo-China may become as complete as that on Korea.
Cotton prices moved narrowly in the domestic market again last week, with the near deliveries losing ground and the distant months making small gains.
LOS ALAMOS, N. M., May 23 (AP) -- The camera that "stops" an atom bomb explosion has been speeded up to take pictures at the rate of 15,000,000 a second. It used to take only 3,500,000.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Representative Martin Dies, Democrat of Texas, first chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, today defended the role of Congressional investigating committees.

City-bred youngsters of this generation are enthralled when they can see and pat the horse of a mounted policeman. They seldom have the opportunity to view the once-familiar horse-drawn wagon of the itinerant peddler or of the junkman, whose cluster of bells clanged merrily as he clucked his weary old mare over the city's concrete.

Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism announced yesterday the election of Prof. Richard T. Baker as secretary of the faculty of journalism and Prof. John Hohenberg as secretary of the advisory board on Pulitzer Prizes.

I have followed with some anguish the campaign of one of our citizens, Robert R. Young, to capture one of our great railroad systems. Obviously he is anxious enough to own the railroad to spend a vast fortune in its acquisition.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today his speaking requests had increased "25 to 30 per cent" since the Army-McCarthy hearings started a month ago.

The Citizens Committee on Children of New York City, in a report to be published today, holds that "dangerous gaps" in services hamper efforts to provide adequate foster care for 20,000 city children. The committee proposes a four-point program to expand, coordinate and improve services to meet proven need.

Twenty-four high school students, out of 10,000, have written themselves into summer trips on U. S.-flag ships traveling on the Great Lakes, the inland rivers and the oceans in all parts of the world.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor was accused yesterday of trying to win Wednesday's dock election for the American Federation of Labor pier union.

Craig Timberlake, who won the American Theatre Wing's seventh annual auditions, last night gave the recital at Town Hall that was his reward. The young bass was accompanied by Alice Wightman, one of the teachers with whom he has coached under Wing auspices.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UP) -- A private nonprofit, nonpolitical research organization today disclosed new cracks in the wall of Negro segregation in Southern industries.

When Thomas Paine long ago expressed his fear of the "summer soldier" among us, little did he realize that we were destined to become a nation of summer sailors. The increased interest in sailing and motorboating displayed by the American family in recent years has been phenomenal.
PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania has completed its collection of the published scores of Victor Herbert's operas and operettas.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- United States exports to the Soviet bloc increased in 1953, while imports from those countries declined.
JERUSALEM, May 23 -- Four cases of violence on the Jordanian border and one in the demilitarized zone facing Egypt were reported tonight by the Israeli Army.

SINGAPORE, May 23 (AP) -- Three thousand Chinese students who staged a sit-down strike at Chung Cheng High School to protest compulsory military service marched out today after having been without food for twenty-seven hours.

The traditional prayers of Rogation Sunday were said at many Protestant Episcopal churches yesterday morning. The day emphasizes the bounties of the soil and the dependence of mankind upon God for the fruits of the field.
It was too cold to swim but the opening of Jones Beach last Saturday heralded the approach of the beach season.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission heard arguments today on whether the American Natural Gas System has enough gas for a $154,000,000 expansion program. American Louisiana Pipe Line Company, a subsidiary of American Natural, seeks authority to build a pipeline to carry Southern Louisiana Gas to affiliated utility companies serving the Detroit and Milwaukee areas.

Your editorial concerning the proposed study of the statistical work carried on by the various city departments deserves commendation. Such a study is long overdue. It is astonishing that the Police, Fire, Sanitation Departments and many others do not have a single employe with the title of statistician.
The big Armour Co. meat and dairy advertising account -worth $4,000,000 or so in annual billings -- is still not placed, although a decision is believed to be near.
Motion-picture theatre operators went to Mayor Wagner yesterday with their protests against the city's plan to enact a 5 percent tax on amusement admissions.

The South American Gold and Platinum Company announced yesterday the election of Lewis B. Harder as president to succeed Newton C. Marshall, who is retiring on July 1 after forty years with the company. Robert C. Stanley Jr., active in a number of Canadian mining companies, was elected executive vice president.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 24 -- Lieut. Genevieve de Galard-Terraube, 29-year-old French nurse who did heroic woman among the French Union war during the siege of Dienbienphu arrived in Hanoi tonight following her release by Vietminh insurgents.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Possible perjury prosecutions against the Secretary of the Army and his legal counselor were suggested today at the investigation of the Army controversy with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

It is a pleasure to learn that the public's response to pleas for a cut in water consumption has resulted in appreciable gains in our reservoir supplies. According to figures released by the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity the steady reduction in consumption of water since April 4 finds this city now using some 56,000,000 gallons less a day.
BALBOA, C. Z., May 24 (AP) -- A contract was let today for blasting a section of cracked Contractor's Hill in Gaillard Cut that endangers navigation through the Panama Canal.

The Firth Carpet Company! may have to make an upward l adjustment in some of its prices soon, Harold E. Wadely, presi-I dent, said yesterday after a meeting of the board of directors. He said he did not expect the second quarter to be very muuch better than the first, when a nominal profit was re-! ported.

BONN, Germany, May 24 -- The American Joint Distribution Committee and the Central Jewish Agency of Germany announced today in Frankfurt they would establish a series of free loan funds in West Germany to help take needy Jews off the relief rolls and enable them to become self-supporting.

The regional Red Cross Blood Program reported yesterday that 530 pints of blood were donated in this area last Friday. Employes of Macy's Herald Square gave 261 pints. The program received an additional 209 pints Saturday.

OSLO, Norway, May 24 (UP) -- A charter airliner with thirty-seven passengers aboard left today for a flight across the North Pole to test the possibility of a regular Europe-to-Japan run avoiding both Russia and the United States.
LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- British sports writers today declared England, beaten, 7 -- 1, by Hungary, has suffered a blow to its international football prestige from which it may never recover.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 24 (Reuters) -- Nominations for Iraq's general election June 9 closed at noon today, with 650 candidates contesting 135 parliamentary seats.

GENEVA, May 24 -- Vietnam has not yet been asked to join a Southeast Asia defense pact, Prince Buu Loc, Vietnam's Premier, said today. He indicated that Vietnam would be agreeable to participation in such a pact if membership was offered.
After pushing forward to new highs for the present upward movement, the stock market lost momentum yesterday and closed with virtually no change on the day.

CAIRO, May 24 -- A series of Arab refugee lawsuits against Barclay's Bank to recover funds frozen by Israel six years ago has been filed as a result of a decision yesterday in Amman by Jordan's highest court.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A House committee's investigation of tax-free educational foundations was suspended abruptly today when the two Democratic members walked out in protest against the way the inquiry was being conducted.

Operations of the Truax-Traer Coal Company and its subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended on April 30 resulted in a net profit of $2,502,035, against $2,802,377 for the previous year, excluding $799,323 profit on sale of coal lands.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Administration has abandoned plans to dispose of Government-owned surplus butter at cut-rate prices to consumers.
SLIGHTLY jumping the gun, the Downtown Gallery has opened the first officially-styled 1954 summer exhibition of paintings and sculpture.

Dr. Peter Marshall Murray was inducted last night as president of the Medical Society of the County of New York. He is the first Negro to hold major office in the society. He was named president-elect in the election a year ago.
Business men representing a variety of powerful interests vied with each other yesterday in attacking a proposal for a uniform national commercial code.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), May 24 -- The Jordanian Government reiterated today its refusal to consider peace negotiations with Israel and its demand that United Nations decisions on boundaries and on Arab refugees be implemented.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Treasury announced tonight that it had sold $1,503,051,000 in discount bills at the lowest interest rate since the bills sold on June 10, 1947. Those sold today went at an average price of 99.818. This represented a discount rate of about 0.718 per cent per annum.
The New York City Transit Authority rejected yesterday the three major recommendations of a fact-finding committee.
The committee form of advisory city government -- already employed in finance, housing and a multitude of other categories -- was extended yesterday by Mayor Wagner to one more field, traffic.

Events today: Thurston Dox, organist. St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University noon; Florence Kopleff, soprano. Town Hall, 5:30 P. M.; Lilly Williams, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Federation Choral of New York, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30; Commencement Concert, Manhattan School of Music, 8:30; Leonid Hambro, pianist, and Rae Muscanto, soprano, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40.

St. John's, Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference champion, won four places on the all-star nine. Three other Redmen were named to the fourteen-man squad which was made public yesterday. Seven teams are in the league.

THE weather in the Canadian prairie provinces during the next few weeks will have an important effect, not only on the waterfowl production for 1954, but on the hunting regulations for next fall, according to the Fish and Wildlife Service.
Former Vice President Alben W. Barkley said last night that a strong Israel would help bring peace in the Middle East.

TOKYO, May 24 -- The conservative Japanese Government will press for enactment of the rest of its controversial legislative program before the Diet adjourns May 31 and Premier Shigeru Yoshida departs June 4 for a tour of the United States and Europe.

Relative to the joint communication you published recently from Judges Frederick Backer and Hubert T. Delany of the Domestic Relations Court, concerning the matter of curbing vandalism, may I say I do not always agree with Park Commissioner Moses, but I am behind him 100 per cent when he says we should punish the parents for these acts of vandalism.
The board of directors of the Blood Banks Association of New York State issued yesterday a statement replying to criticisms made by a Red Cross official last week.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Bernard M. Shanley, special counsel to President Eisenhower, said by implication today that former Vice President Alben W. Barkley was trying to ride into the Senate on the President's coat-tails.

The payment by the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation of $261,522 to defray expenses of rival slates of candidates during an election of directors in 1949 was upheld yesterday by unanimous decision of the Appellate Division, Second Department.

"Arias Sung and Acted." a series of recordings featuring dramatic adaptations in English of famous operatic excerpts, together with the arias sung in their original language, were previewed yesterday by R. C. A. Victor Records at the R. C. A. Exhibition Hall, 40 West Forty-ninth Street.

Accidents involving radioactive materials are already a factor in the calculations of insurance actuaries. It will be a growing factor -- alongside the possibilities of vast catastrophic payments -- an insurance conference of the American Management Association was told yesterday at the Statler Hotel.

A big and growing market exists for advertised products of all types among students at all levels. This was set forth yesterday by Dr. Ernest V. Hollis, Chief of College Administration of the United States Office of Education, in an address before the first annual Student Market Clinic, put on at the Roosevelt Hotel by the Student Marketing Institute.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Since the relations of the United States and Great Britain with respect to an Indo-China policy have been as fluid as the military situation in that country, today's dispatches from London and Paris, which presage a speed-up toward united action by the two Powers, may not be verified by the event.

A dispatch from Washington notes that the Eisenhower Administration, which is on record as being opposed to the so-called two-price system, is now employing that device as a technique for getting rid of the farm surplus.

TOMMY JACKSON is a 22-year-old heavy-weight fighter who bears the impressive label of Hurricane Jackson. He was blowing along in rather forceful fashion when he knocked out Rex Layne and beat Clarence Henry. Then he hit with full velocity when he obliterated Dan Bucceroni, the third ranking heavyweight.
The cotton futures market was quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Prices moved 3 points up to 15 points down, with new crop months relatively weaker than old July.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -- A panel of leading industrialists expressed optimism today regarding the economic period ahead but stressed that it would be a time of strong competition.

GUATEMALA, May 25 -- The Guatemalan Government asserted today that the "groundwork for talks to end the tenseness" of relations with the United States had been laid in a conference this morning between Foreign Minister Guillermo Toriello and John C. Peurifoy, United States Ambassador.
A speedy ship-to-shore-to-sky relay was carried out here last night to speed a soldier to his sick infant son.
The General Electric Company yesterday offered its employes a wage increase averaging 5 cents an hour.

DETROIT, May 24 -- The 166th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. approved overwhelmingly today the controversial "Letter to Presbyterians'' issued in October by the church's General Council.

Two automotive workers, who on Saturday night accompanied an unidentified taxi driver on a round of Queens taverns, including one that the cabman held up and robbed of an unspecified sum, were held yesterday on robbery charges.

Epitomizing Ethiopia's efforts to emerge from isolation, Emperor Haile Selassie arrives here today for a fifty-day tour of the United States, Canada and Mexico. He is coming here on the invitation of President Eisenhower, renewing a bid originally made by the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1944.
Washing children's toys as a part of home safety programs is explained in a report by a home economist.

SALERNO, Italy, May 22 -- It is clear after a week's trip around southern Italy that the political struggle here is between communism and Christian Democracy. The 1953 elections were undoubtedly the last time that the south will have voted monarchist, and fascism is dead in this part of the country.
NEW DELHI, India, May 24 -- With Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's approval, a movement is growing among India's 8,200,000 Christians for autonomous churches divorced from foreign affiliations.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 24 -- French B-26 bombers and fighter planes continued to blast the Vietminh's main communications line east of Dienbienphu yesterday in a series of air strikes against Route 41 between Tuangiao and Mocchau, eighty miles west of Hanoi.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Supreme Court sent three racial segregation cases back to lower courts today with orders that they be re-examined in the light of its historic ruling last Monday that public school segregation was unconstitutional.

Baier Associates have sold the four-story apartment house accommodating forty-nine families at 73 Grove Street in Montclair, N. J., to the K. M. W. Realty Company. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker. The property, on a plot 111 by 334 feet, has suites of two to six rooms.

As the Geneva conference enters what Secretary Eden characterized yesterday as its "decisive" stage, it becomes evident again that what separates the free world and the Communist bloc, aside from all other considerations, is the fundamental question of what constitutes legitimate government, how it should be created, and what its duties and purposes should be.

ALBANY, May 24 -- State Education Commissioner Lewis A. Wilson reserved decision today on an appeal by Nat Holman, former basketball coach of City College, New York, for reinstatement to his faculty post.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 24 -- Despite South Africa's refusal to cooperate, an extensive United Nations report was made public today on conditions in neighboring South-West Africa.

Two young descendants of the Mayan Indians are demonstrating centuries-old weaving techniques in the main-floor fashion fabrics department at Lord Taylor this week. Like their looms, many of their motifs are traditional, but they constantly weave them in vivid new designs.

An increase in the nation's unemployment unless production is $15,000,000,000 higher in 1954 than in 1953, was forecast yesterday by Dr. Gerhard Colm, chief economist of the National Planning Council.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Willie Mays put on a one-man show tonight as the Giants downed the Phillies in the series finale, 5 to 4.

Trading volume was unusually light on the New York commodity futures markets yesterday. Prices of most items drifted irregularly with zinc, burlap, sugar, potatoes, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, rubber, hides and copper mixed; cocoa, wool, silk and lead higher, and coffee and tin lower.

ATLANTA, May 24 -- A meeting of Attorneys General from states affected by the United States Supreme Court decision outlawing segregation in the public schools has been postponed until after the Southern governors' conference in Richmond, June 7-8.

PARIS, May 24 -- The French-United States conversations on Indo-China have reached the critical point at which it soon will be essential for the United States to determine the defense line beyond which Washington will not permit the Communists to pass.
David Marks Jr, insurance agent and pension trust consultant, representing New England Mutual Life Insurance Co, floor in 579 5th Ave through Cross Brown Co, agent -- Joseph F. Bernstein, broker.

A look at the weather record for most of last week turns up some depressing prose. "A low-pressure system over Northern New England caused considerable cloudiness and showers in the Northeast * * *." "Rain fell yesterday along the Atlantic seaboard from Maine to Virginia * * *

ANKARA, Turkey, May 24 -- Premier Adnan Menderes has accepted President Eisenhower's invitation to visit the United States in the near future to discuss the long-range program of United States economic and military aid to Turkey.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 24 (AP) -- The Providence Journal-Bulletin will say tomorrow that twenty-six newspaper men from nine newspapers and two wire services were listed as receiving a total of $30,000 pay from one or more of six major race tracks in New England during 1953.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Benjamin Weintraub, president of the Omnibus Corporation told stockholders at the annual meeting today that the company had signed the contract for sale of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company to the New York Management Ownership Corporation.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 24 -- Representatives of the 8,000,000 members of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers were warned today not to abandon the juvenile delinquent.

The "electronic office" may soon become a reality in a number of industries. This long-sought type of office appears to have been advanced considerably by the development of a new "giant brain" by the International Business Machines Corporation.

Carl Sandburg's one-volume biography of Lincoln will be published Oct. 7 by Harcourt, Brace. The author has "distilled the essence" of his six-volume work, adding new material in the light of recent research and rewriting and condensing his work into an 800-page volume.

PARIS, May 24 (AP) -- Australia's hopes for a second straight men's singles title in the French international tennis tournament almost disappeared today when Ken Rosewall, who had won last year, lost to Sven Davidson of Sweden,...

LONDON, May 24 (UP) -- A $2,520,000 Comet jet airliner will be submerged in a huge water tank and air pumped into its fuselage until it blows up or proves it can stand fantastic pressure, an Air Ministry spokesman said today.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- American business men -- facing the stiffest competition they have seen in twelve years -- were warned today that they have the responsibility for avoiding reverses in the country's economy. They must prove that free competition "can provide the good things of life much faster and better than Government," H. E. Humphreys Jr., president of United States Rubber Company, asserted.

Theodore F. Behler, known for coordinated railroad-motor truck operation, will direct the Missouri - Kansas - Texas Railroad's "piggy-back" service to be started between Kansas City and Oklahoma City early in July. Donald V. Fraser, president of the Katy, announced yesterday that Mr. Behler has been named vice president of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Transportation Company, a wholly owned subsidiary which will operate the service for the road.
ROME, May 19 -- The Colosseum, symbol of Roman greatness and early Christian martyrdom, threatens to crumble.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today it would offer processors' loans ranging from 4 to 8 1/2 cents a pound on whey products and dried buttermilk displaced in the market by Government sales of surplus dried milk for livestock feed.

In March of 1947 President Truman, advised by General Marshall and Secretary of State Acheson, was granted permission by Congress to intervene in Greece. This action was based on the new policy that this country would go to the aid of any section of the world that felt it was threatened by Russian communism.

A court order was served yesterday at City Hall on City Council President Abe Stark. It challenged the action of the City Council last week in allocating two Assembly Districts to the new Queens Fifth Senate District and three Assembly Districts to the new Sixth Senate District.

The Greentree Stable's Diving Board "won all by himself" at Belmont Park yesterday. Under the guidance of Ted Atkinson, the son of Devil Diver had almost three lengths the better of it over Full Flight at the end of the featured one-mile Natchez Purse.

The port-wide election to be held tomorrow to determine what union shall represent the longshoremen in collective bargaining with the New York Shipping Association is of an importance that goes far beyond the immediate issue of union rivalry. It affects the welfare of this city, so dependent upon sea commerce, and of the whole port.

The 300-room Emerald Beach Hotel which is nearing completion in Nassau, the Bahamas, has been leased by Leo F. Corrigan, real estate and hotel operator of New York and Dallas, Tex. Scheduled to be ready for occupancy on July 1, the five-story building is being erected by a syndicate of British investors.

LONDON, May 24 -- More than three hundred concerns whose products typify the variety and ingenuity of Scotland's manufacturers will be represented in the Scottish industries exhibition in Glasgow from Sept. 2 to 18.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in the nineteenth day of its hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, May 24 -- An "accidental" war, that is a war caused by unexpected error in politics or calculation, probably would not be as dangerous to the free world as to the Soviet Union, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, deputy Allied supreme commander, indicated today.
CHICAGO, May 24 -- Higher prices were registered for wheat and corn at the opening, affected by disturbing news from Geneva and the Far East, but the demand faded and the market weakened.

Allan P. Kirby, associate of Robert R. Young, failed yesterday to appear for pre-trial questioning in a Supreme Court action against the directors of the New York Central Railroad. Mr. Kirby, president of the Alleghany Corporation of which Mr. Young is chairman, was scheduled to be examined by counsel for Central's directors before Special Referee Harry Grossman.

Samuel D. Leidesdorf, founder and head of S. D. Leidesdorf Co., certified public accountants, has been elected president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York. He succeeds John A. Hill, president of Air Reduction, Inc., who had served one-year terms.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 24 -- Paralyzation of all rubber processing industries looms unless the Government takes immediate steps to circumvent a shortage of crude rubber in the market. Three large factories in Sao Paulo announced they will have to close their doors.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The United States is airlifting arms to Nicaragua and Honduras, the State Department announced today.

Easily one of Broadway's most industrious directors these days is Harold Clurman, who has just agreed to stage the London presentation of Jean Giraudoux' "La Guerre de Troi N' Aura Pas Lieu" ("The Trojan War Will Not Be Fought").

MEXICO CITY, May 24 -- Guatemala's purchase of arms from the Soviet sphere and the mounting uneasiness in Central America have begun to jolt Mexico out of her apparent indifference to events just below her southern border.

From time to time on this page we have reviewed the progress of legislation in this second session of the Eighty-third Congress, mindful of the President's statement that unless the Republican party can develop and enact a progressive, dynamic program for the American people "it does not deserve to remain in power."

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A careful relaxation by the United States of certain information on the utilization of atomic military weapons is "an urgent necessity" for North Atlantic Treaty countries, Representative W. Sterling Cole said tonight.

The Kaiser Engineers division of the Henry J. Kaiser Company announced yesterday that it had acquired the exclusive United States right to use the European oxygen steelmaking process, under license from Brassert Oxygen Technik A. G. of Zurich, Switzerland.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A Democratic attack on President Eisenhower personally provoked a debate today in the House of Representatives that transcended the issue on which it started.
Edward R. Newcomb has been elected vice president of export sales of the international division of the Minnesota Mining Manufacturing Company. Formerly he was export sales manager.
Louis Stark was probably as warmly esteemed among trade union leaders and newspaper men handling labor affairs in the United Kingdom as among their opposite numbers in the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, today proposed a code of fair procedures for investigating committees of the Senate.

Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators and representatives of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., will resume negotiations at 10 A. M. tomorrow on a contract to replace one that will expire June 15. The meeting will be held in the union pension and welfare headquarters, 259 West Fourteenth Street.
This is the second of two articles on problems facing the nation's airports.

Bargain rates go into effect today on the loan of works of art from the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. Arrangements for this summer special must be made before the end of June. In announcing it the museum's art lending service disclosed that business organizations are now eligible as borrowers.

The four - story apartment house accommodating forty-two families at 1116 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the East Sixty-sixth Street Realty Corporation to clients of Joseph Ginsberg, attorney. The property, assessed at $134,000, occupies a plot 107 by 100 feet at the corner of Rogers Avenue.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 -- The world leader of the Seventh Day Adventist Church declared here tonight that "we have come to the closing hours of man's existence on earth."
Western Union staged a race yesterday between the oldest and newest telegraph machines. The result was a triumph for modern ingenuity.
LONDON, May 21 -- British zoologists have received an eye- witness report of the birth of a living relic of the age of dinosaurs.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., May 24 -- Mike Turnesa of Knollwood, a member of one of the nation's best known golfing families, led the Metropolitan District qualifiers for the Professional Golfers Association championship today. Mike, once a caddy and assistant pro at the course, had a 36-hole score of 142, two under par, at the Fairview Country Club.

Even the Pirates must win some time. Last night at Ebbets Field one of their few professionals, Max Surkont, pitched. The young Bucs played like champions and the Dodgers were soundly beaten, 5 -- 2, before a disappointed Ladies' Night gathering of 15,336.
SEOUL, Korea, May 24 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, President of South Korea, apparently has become convinced he cannot hope to unify his country without extensive aid from the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Army will commission and call to active duty this year all but a handful of its Reserve Officer Training Corps' 16,000-man graduating class.
CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Butchers and sows dropped 25 to 50 cents on the livestock market today, responding to quite heavy receipts totaling 12,000 salable head.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 24 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan and Bill Campbell led an eleven-man American advance today in the British amateur golf tournament, but thirteen of their fellow countrymen didn't make it.
Industrial activity has continued to improve in May at about the same moderate rate as in April, according to the monthly survey of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 24 -- The "home-like atmosphere" created at the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry by fourteen women's clubs and two men's organizations was credited today with being a major influence in rehabilitating the maladjusted boys.

DETROIT, May 24 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today: "Nation-wide, used car sales have been climbing for three straight months and reached art eight-month crest during April. Retail demand during the month rose to the highest level since July, 1953.
The operating companies comprising the Royal Dutch-Shell Group last year had a net income of 130,413,373 ($365,157,444), after taxes.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 24 -- Roosevelt Raceway was dark tonight.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

The annual garden party and bazaar for the benefit of the Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged, Indigent Females will be held this afternoon and early evening at the headquarters of the organization's home, 891 Amsterdam Avenue at 103d Street.
Bob Baker of Pittsburgh gained a unanimous decision over Joe Baksi, East Nassau, N.Y., in the main event of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

DORIS BETTS, a pretty girl still only a junior at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, has accomplished more in less time than seems possible. She has worked on the staff of The Statesville Daily Record for several years. She has been a correspondent and free lance contributor to numerous other North Carolina papers.
LONDON, May 24 -- Stock markets here became hesitant today in the face of the news from Indo-China and of the railway strike.

TRENTON, May 24 -- The New Jersey Senate voted today to legalize night harness racing. It also adopted a reapportionment bill that would increase by four seats the Republican majority in the State Assembly.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its April 5 ruling against the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan for merging the Florida East Coast Railway with the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad.
For the thousands of American nurses who are members of the American Nurses' Association we commend your editorial in The Times of May 21 entitled "Angel of Dienbienphu."

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 25 (AP) -- The last two American entrants in the world free-style wrestling tournament were eliminated today. The American grapplers, Allan Rice of New York and Wendel Huebel of Los Angeles, were eliminated in the fourth round.

The five-story remodeled building at 211 to 215 East Fifty-seventh Street has been resold by Jack Brause, real estate developer and operator, to the Sutton Realty Company. Robert S. Kline was the broker and Irving Lester Levitt was attorney for the seller.

Two first-run foreign film attractions set box-office records last week. "Le Plaisir," the French-made tripartite feature, which opened at the Normandie on Wednesday, set a mark for the theatre by "playing to nearly $1,000 more than the record set by 'Encore,' the previous box-office champion, for the first five days of its run," according to a spokesman for the distributors of the import.
RYE, N. Y., May 24 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association was host to teams from Boston and Philadelphia today in a match over the west course of the Westchester Country Club.

There was some clearing of shelves by underwriters of corporate securities yesterday to free underwriting capital for commitment to buy $83,000,000 of new public utility bonds coming up at public bidding today and tomorrow.

LONDON, May 24 -- The House of Commons accepted by a majority of 166 votes tonight a bipartisan motion to increase the salaries of members of Parliament by 500 to 1,500 ($4,200) annually. The vote was 280 to 166.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 25 (AP) -- Yoshio Shirai, world flyweight champion, saved his crown last night with a split decision over Leo Espinosa of the Philippines. The verdict brought howls of protest from the challenger's corner.
