GENEVA, May 24 -- The conference on Far Eastern affairs has decided to take up tomorrow the general principles that should govern an armistice in Indo-China, starting with a cessation of hostilities.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 (UP) -- Jim Davis, a rookie left-hander making his first major league start, tonight held the St. Louis Cardinals to seven singles to give a 6 -- 2 victory to the Chicago Cubs. The Cards protested the game.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 24 (AP) -- French Union forces, outnumbered three to two, beat off a six-day siege by the Vietminh in northern Laos near the Chinese border, the French High Command said today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 24 -- Prime Minister Moshe Sharett expressed today the Israeli Government's "shock" over the news that Zionist leaders in Rumania had been sentenced to long prison terms.

The committee for the Republican state organization's annual dinner tomorrow night announced yesterday that it had decided to help Governor Dewey's campaign to reduce the milk surplus. The committee reported that it had taken a good bit of cajolery before the Waldorf-Astoria agreed to substitute milk for the conventional demi-tasse as the final menu beverage.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Phil Cavarretta, happy as a kid with a new bat, today signed with the Chicago White Sox and 30 minutes later was working out on the field with the characteristic hustle that endeared him to Chicago Cub fans for twenty years.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The United States Foreign Operations Administration and the International Bank have agreed to join with private Indian, British and United States investors to form a new kind of development corporation in India.

Only 10,598 fans turned out for the fill-in game between the Yankees and the Athletics at the Stadium last night. That's a record in reverse. Never before had so few fans seen an after-dark encounter in the Bronx ball park. The fans watched Casey Stengel's champions outscore the A's, 7 -- 3.
Increasing unemployment in the city caused Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy to warn Mayor Wagner that welfare costs may be expected to rise rather than to diminish.

Magistrate Charles F. Murphy yesterday notified Larry M. Vetrano, chief clerk of the Magistrates Courts, that he would ask the City Board of Magistrates at their meeting next Wednesday to investigate Mr. Vetrano's official conduct.
The Government asked yesterday that a receiver be appointed for the impoverished International Longshoremen's Association.
Norman L. Winter has been named director of the Federal department of the Sperry Gyroscope Company, a division of the Sperry Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -Harvard economist Sumner H. Slichter said today the chances were "better than even" that the economic downturn in progress since mid-1953 had touched bottom and the economy was headed upward again.
The stocky officer who testified in the Army-McCarthy hearing in Washington yesterday was the key figure in the United States plan to revitalize the Korean Army.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 -- George Jessel is making new plans to re-enter film production here.
WOODSTOCK, Conn., May 24 -- The United States Commissioner of Education and the Governor of the state came here today to pay homage to an ideal and to perpetuate an American dream.

BOSTON, May 24 -- Judge Bailey Aldrich of the Federal District Court refused today to consider an alleged violation of the Securities and Exchange Commission proxy rules by the William G. Smith committee of American Woolen Company stockholders in the solicitation of proxies.

We sometimes overlook the fact that New York City, with its infinite variety and incessant bustle, is virtually a museum of American architecture. Not all of us know the location or significance of the best examples of the late and early style of this or that designer, or where to find representative survivals of important periods, or the masterpieces of the men whose work broke old precedents and established new ones.

PARIS, May 24 -- The glories and tragedies of three centuries of French history were re-enacted in the Palace of Versailles tonight before an audience of industrialists controlling more wealth than was dreamed of when this chateau was built.

LONDON, May 24 -- The British Cabinet granted Anthony Eden full authority today to decide the duration of negotiations with the Communist bloc at the Geneva conference. The Foreign Secretary was pledged the complete support and confidence of the Government in his efforts to negotiate what he termed an "acceptable and peaceful" settlement during the "decisive" two weeks of conference beginning today.
Defense Secretary Wilson is visiting the Philippines at the right time. There are several aspects of our defense relationship that are in need of further clarification and his visit can help.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Senate Banking Committee completed the draft of a housing bill today bearing more the mark of the Fair Deal than of the Eisenhower Administration.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) -- Representative Thor C. Tollefson, Republican of Washington, introduced legislation today calling for the construction of sixty cargo and cargo-passenger ships a year.

Mayor Wagner opened Sanitation Week yesterday with a proclamation urging a "year-round effort to make this the cleanest city in the world." Men and machines of the Sanitation Department paraded behind the sixty-man departmental band to City Hall Plaza for the ceremony.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 24 (UP) -- Lieutenant de Galard-Terraube was still the chic Parisienne when she stepped off the plane at Hanoi. And she remembered at the last moment to ask a fellow nurse for lipstick. Then she faced the welcoming crowd.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the right of Congress to make past membership in the Communist party a ground for the deportation of an alien.

A prepared mix for baking at home the high-protein white bread devised at Cornell University by Dr. Clive M. McCay, Professor of Nutrition, now is packaged by the mail-order concern Great Valley Mills, Ivyland, Bucks County, Pa.

Raymond C. Ellis of New York, Grand Master of Masons in the State of New York, announced yesterday the appointment for the coming year of twenty district deputy grand masters in New York City and Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
MOSCOW, May 24 -- Pravda today devoted two of its four pages to publishing the text of a speech delivered to Soviet railroad men ten days ago by Lazar M. Kaganovich, a Deputy Premier.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the Government's appeal from a lower court's dismissal of its anti-trust suit against the International Boxing Club of New York, the Madison Square Garden Corporation and others. The case is expected to be argued during the next term of court, beginning in October.

The Carrier Corporation, air-conditioning and refrigeration equipment manufacturer, increased its net profit in the twelve months through April to $7,298,900. It had earned $4,798,126 in the preceding fiscal year.
The Lake Ontario Land Development and Beach Protection Association, Inc., asked the Supreme Court last week to set serted today.

LONDON, May 25 -- British support for five-power staff talks on what Prime Minister Churchill called "immediate, practical issues" in Southeast Asia solidified today. Participants in such talks would represent Britain, the United States, France, New Zealand and Australia.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank, heretofore an advocate of public housing asserted today that he would oppose any new public housing program because of the Supreme Court's anti-segregation rulings.

Directors of the New York Central Railroad Company failed yesterday in a last-minute legal effort to force postponement of the stockholders' meeting scheduled to be held in Albany today. The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court took no action on their request to delay the meeting until June 28.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 -- Paul G. Hoffman said here tonight at a meeting of the Indiana Civil Liberties Union that disagreements over "extraneous issues" were hindering the fight against "deadly" communism.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- A self-styled ex-Communist testified today that former Representative Hugh De Lacy, Democrat of Washington, and State Senator Michael Gallagher of Washington were once secret Communist party members.

CINCINNATI, May 25 (UP) -- Southpaw Warren Spahn pitched a six-hitter against Cincinnati, contributed a fifth-inning homer and stretched Milwaukee's winning streak to eight games tonight by leading the Braves to a 3-1 victory.
" Ondine," adjudged the best foreign play of the season by the Critics Circle and a hit of the first magnitude, will be forced to close July 3 at the Forty-sixth Street, where it opened Feb. 18.
LONDON, May 25 (Reuters) -- Britain's latest jetliner, the De Havilland Comet III, will make its maiden flight next month.

The state-created Long Island Transit Authority announced yesterday an agreement by which the Pennsylvania Railroad would resume running the Long Island Rail Road. It involved a twelve-year redevelopment plan including $58,739,000 in new car and other improvements.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Listing more than 4,500 price cuts ranging up to 45 per cent, Sears, Roebuck Co.'s 1954 midsummer sale catalogue is being distributed nationally this week. Prices in the new 464-page catalogue. largest ever issued by the mail order and retail concern, have been reduced an average of 9 per cent from those in Sears previous catalogue.
The Army-McCarthy hearings are playing havoc with some plans of the Chrysler Corporation.
CAIRO, May 25 -- An Egyptian archaeologist cut through six feet of limestone and five millenniums of history today.

President Eisenhower's decision to wait another year for Congressional action on a major part of his liberal trade program was described yesterday as a "temporary postponement" compelled by events rather than a "surrender" to high-tariff forces.

CAIRO, May 25 (AP) -- Saudi Arabia accused Britain tonight of stirring up fresh violence in the remote desert rea of Burairmi. It called for an international commission to investigate an eighteen-month dispute there. Prospective oil riches lie in the background of the dispute.

The slogan "Asia for the Asians" has become the leitmotif of Communist propaganda at Geneva and elsewhere. As Chou En-lai and Molotov seek to use this propaganda slogan to win the backing of India, Pakistan, Burma and other free Asian countries, they point to the French in Indochina, the British in Malaya and American troops in Japan as the chief targets.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Defense Department lifted the curtain today on its overnight currency purge at military posts around the world.
ALBANY, May 25 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department predicted today that cows in New York State would turn out more than twice as much milk this month as New Yorkers normally drink.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -Following is the text of Secretary Dulles' formal statement on Guatemala at his press conference today:

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Emanuel Katz. president of Doeskin Products, Inc., urged the Senate subcommittee for the District of Columbia today not to let the capital be used as a base for price-cutting operations.

THE decision of the National Broadcasting Company to cancel "The Voice of Firestone" understandably has disturbed a number of television viewers and radio listeners. The musical program, with Howard Barlow conducting, has been such a fixture on Monday evenings that its departure was certain to arouse protests.
A 5 per cent tax on amusement charges was adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate as the cornerstone of new financing estimated to produce $29,800,000 for the next budget.
MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 25 (AP) -- Robert Sweeny, Frank Strafaci and a group of servicemen restored American prestige today in the British amateur golf championship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 25 -Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, one of the United Nations' top officials, today received a hearing before a United States board investigating the loyalty of all United States employes of the organization.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in the twentieth day of its hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph E. McCarthy.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 -- Teen-agers were defended here today by Dr. Margaret Mead, associate curator of the American Museum of Natural History. She spoke to delegates to the convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The American Medical Association once again demonstrated its power to influence legislation today as a Congressional committee decided against bringing physicians under the Social Security insurance system.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 26 (AP) -- Turkey dethroned Russia yesterday as the world free-style Wrestling champion.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- An indictment charging Val R. Lorwin, a former State Department official, with lying to a loyalty board about his alleged Communist affiliations was dismissed in Federal District Court today at the request of the Department of Justice.
Off the stage since the summer of 1949, Tallulah Bankhead is planning to return.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that one purpose of the recent "massive shipment of arms from behind the Iron Curtain" to Guatemala might be the creation of a Communist bastion near the Panama Canal.

BONN, Germany, May 25 -- The Social Democratic party demanded today that the West German Government cancel its decision to grant pensions to members and surviving dependents of Hitler's Condor Legion, which fought with Generalissimo Francisco Franco's forces in the Spanish civil war.
Columbia University has ended the arrangements whereby it has received $10,000 annually from the Polish Government to finance a chair of Polish studies.

A stronger cocoa market paced New York commodity prices generally higher yesterday. For the second consecutive day cocoa prices rose the 1-cent daily limit in all positions. Wool, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, hides, zinc, tin, lead and copper also ended higher; rubber, silk and potatoes closed lower, and coffee, sugar and burlap were mixed. Volume was generally heavier with hides registering the fifth most active day of the year.

A debut recital of considerable distinction was sung at Town Hall yesterday afternoon by contralto Florence Kopleff. Altough she was making her formal bow in recital, Miss Kopleff is known to music audiences hereabouts, having been soloist with the Collegiate Chorale, the Concert Choir, the American Chamber Opera Society and other groups.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Eisenhower is being pressed by defense officials to order the printing of the more than 20,000,000 ration books and the billions of coupons that would be needed in event of all-out war.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A young Army lieutenant used televised boxing today to punch back at Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's attack on charts of the training camp absences of Pvt. G. David Schine compared with a norm.

Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey said here last night that the Administration had cut planned expenditures by more than $5,000,000,000 for the coming fiscal year beyond the $7,000,000,000 reduction in the present year.
STRASBOURG, France, May 25 (AP) -- Speakers in the European Assembly urged France today to agree soon to a European Army, including twelve German divisions.
A bus driver who tried to extort $5,000 from a retired New York banker was arrested yesterday afternoon at York Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street by detectives who had set an elaborate trap for him.

LONDON, May 25 -- The edgy stock markets here were unnerved today by a false rumor that an American warship had been sunk in the Straits of Formosa. The rumor arose from the recall of United States Navy men from Hong Kong to their ships for the issue of new military scrip.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 25 -- Benjamin A. Cohen, United Nations Assistant Secretary General, declared today that racial and religious discrimination were giving way to the influence of education and the Declaration of Human Rights.
HARRISBURG, Pa., May 25 (UP) -- Chief Justice Horace Stern of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court said today that a man's face was his property and "cannot be photographed without his consent."
PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- The John B. Stetson Company, manufacturer of men's hats, has set up a "Retirement Forum" for employees past 60 years of age.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- August A. Busch Jr. said today that he would gladly sell the Cardinal baseball team if he could get his investment back and the team stayed in St. Louis.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Foreign investments of the United States, both private and governmental, increased an average of $3,000,000,000 annually from 1947 through 1953.

DETROIT, May 25 -- The Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. today unanimously requested Colombia to grant Protestants "the same degree of religious freedom which the Roman Catholic minority enjoys under the Constitution in the United States."
The City of New York has overcome its years-old antipathy for stevedoring companies as pier tenants.

Senator Prescott Bush of Connecticut, a Republican who is generally identified with the conservative elements of his party, has been saying some things in the last few days about the McCarthy hearings that we think are well worth repeating.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Eisenhower announced today the creation of a committee of three Cabinet members to seek a national water policy.
Waterfront employers will be assessed another .5 of 1 per cent of their payrolls for the fiscal year beginning July 1, the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor announced yesterday.

Mayor Wagner asked for feminine support yesterday in getting city-state fiscal relations out of politics. He told a luncheon meeting of the League of Women Voters of the City of New York: "It looks almost as though the anti-city Albany group likes to keep New York City in trouble.

BOSTON, May 25 -- One of fourteen escaped inmates of three state penal institutions in Massachusetts at large today was captured tonight in South Bellingham. He was said to be the leader of a group of "dangerous" escapees.
" Evidence that the recession has been flattening out is now so abundant that this conclusion must be accepted as established."

The Standardbred Owners Association and the management of Roosevelt Raceway agreed to terms yesterday, settling a two-day-old strike that had put off the opening of the track's fifteenth season of trotting and pacing. Racing at the Westbury oval will begin tonight.

The death of Dr. Harry Mortimer Archer impels me, for the first time, to address a letter pointing up a personal recollection of his noble service going back to the time I was secretary of the New York Fire Department. For any man to attend every important fire in New York occurring within a period of seventy-five years is surely a striking performance.
PARIS, May 25 -- Industrialists from thirteen European countries and the United States concluded a three-day conference here today with resolutions favoring free trade and opposing state planning.

AUGUST BELMONT 3d climbed into the dank tomb of John Slidell in the churchyard at St. Marks-in-the-Bouwerie one afternoon a few weeks ago and cleared up, after almost a century, the mystery of the last resting place of Commodore Matthew Calbraith Perry.
Following is the text of the Long Island Transit Authority's new plan for reorganizing the Long Island Rail Road by an agreement under which the Pennsylvania Railroad would resume control:

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (UP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals were hopeful today that they would get a replay of last night's game with the Chicago Cubs because of a two-way decision that the senior umpire, Larry Goetz, called "lousy."

The four varsity crews that figure to lead the procession were drawn in adjoining lanes in the middle of the course for the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association. It is scheduled for June 19 on Onondaga Lake at Syracuse.

The problems of old age as a family responsibility are discussed in two new publications. "How to Help Older People," by Julietta K. Arthur, $4.95, is published today by J. B. Lippincott "When Parents Grow Old," by Elizabeth Ogg, 25 cents, was published last week by the Public Affairs Committee.

The egg problem that stumped a schoolmaster back in 1897 when he applied for a teaching job in Woodstock, Conn., puzzled quite a few persons here yesterday. On Monday the 206-yearold Quasset School, oldest in point of continuous use in the United States, was dedicated as a public shrine.

MADRID, May 25 -- United States Ambassador James C. Dunn told the American Chamber of Commerce in Barcelona today that he expected the construction of United States air and naval bases would begin "in early autumn."

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox snapped the league-leading Cleveland Indians' eleven-game winning streak tonight, winning 4 -- 2. The Sox jumped on Bob Lemon for two runs and four hits in the fifth inning and scored single runs twice without benefit of a hit.
TRENTON, May 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner appointed Orrie de Nooryer of Garfield as chairman of the New Jersey Highway Authority today. Bayard L. England of Linwood was reappointed vice chairman.
RYE, N. Y., May 25 -- The New York women's golf team of seven again won the intercity team matches against Philadelphia and Boston today to capture the Griscom Cup for the eighth straight year.
The Washington Suburban Sanitary District in Maryland, borrowed $7,600,000 on serial bonds yesterday. The district sold two issues of securities to a banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co.
BOSTON, May 25 (AP) -- Mr. and Mrs. J. M. Lingle's Valenciano raced to a length and a half victory over Riverwood Farm's Seaflash today in the feature at Suffolk Downs.
Owners of the Empire State Building, tallest structure in the world, are asking the city to grant a whopping reduction in assessed valuation on the property.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- sound base is being erected for future economic expansion to serve the country's expanding population, Martin R. Gainsbrugh, chief economist for the National Industrial Conference Board, asserted today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Thousands of small airports would be excluded from Federal aid under a proposed new aid-to-airports program, F. B. Lee, Civil Aeronautics Administrator, said today.
ALBANY, May 25 -- The venerable Tenth Regiment Armory on Washington Avenue here was clearing its vast drill shed today for the New York Central Railroad's annual meeting of stockholders.

A heroic figure personifying the successful struggle of a nation for independence and increasing liberty in the face of desperate odds has arrived for the first time in the United States as the personal guest of President Eisenhower and the guest of the whole American nation.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- Dick Haymes received at least a temporary reprieve from deportation today so he might air his charges that immigration officials gave him a "dishonorable deal."

SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 25 -- Robert Stillman Productions filed a $1,750,000 damage claim hero today against Glenn Ford in Superior Court, alleging the actor had refused to honor an agreement to complete "The Americano."
ST. LOUIS, May 25 (UP) -- Harvey Haddix pitched and batted the St. Louis Cardinals to a 9-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight. The triumph halted a three-game losing streak by the Redbirds.
The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., rejected yesterday as "completely inadequate" an offer made Monday by the General Electric Company for a wage increase of 5 cents an hour.

The Regional Blood Program of the Red Cross received 485 pints of blood in this area on Monday. Local 891 of the Custodian Engineers, A. F. L., gave 133 toward this total, blood bank officials announced yesterday.
The main charge in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Sales of Oliver Corporation, farm and industrial equipment manufacturer, increased to $61,832,000 in the six months ended April 30 from $59,062,000 in the corresponding period a year earlier, Alva W. Phelps, chairman, reported today. Net earnings rose to an estimated $1,209,000 from $769,000 a year ago.

PROVIDENCE, May 25 (AP) -Ten more Boston news men, including six State House reporters, received about $60,000 from the State of Massachusetts in four years, according to an article to be published in The Providence Journal-Bulletin tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -Ray H. Jenkins, special counsel of the McCarthy-Army inquiry, said today he had received -- but did not intend to read -- an Army summarization of its report on the case of Maj. Irving Peress.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 25 -"The nurse of Dienbienphu" said today she had returned to freedom with a feeling of both "joy and sadness."
Textron, Inc., is seeking to buy 100,000 additional shares of American Woolen Company common at $23 a share. Textron already owns about 300,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -Congressional Democrats responded with anger and ridicule today to a White House official's charge that they were responsible for the impeded progress of President Eisenhower's legislative program.
MONTREAL, May 25 -- A surge of grain traffic is expected to move through here during the next month, bringing the port its first vitality this season.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- The grain futures market showed considerable early strength today. Coarse grains and rye held most initial gains but the demand for wheat wilted and prices reacted sharply from early levels.
BERLIN, May 25 (UP) -- "Truman Hall" became the "Berlin Command Shopping Center" today, and the United States Army hastily explained that politics had nothing to do with the change.

As President of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of the City of New York I should like to correct certain impressions which were created by your editorial of May 19 which is captioned "Blocking Police Reform." The subject-matter of the editorial is a proposed local law of this city under which the Police Commissioner be given authority to employ individuals not members of the Police Department of this city to guard school crossings.

The old International Longshoremen's Association was thrown into Federal receivership yesterday. Meanwhile, 25,000 dock workers prepared to vote today on whether the scandal-scarred union or its American Federation of Labor rival would rule in the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Bureau of Foreign Commerce took action today against Bangkok importers found to have tried to divert antibiotics to Communist China.

John Scalia, furniture manufacturer, bought the eleven-story loft building on a plot 50 by 200 feet at 321-23 East Seventy-second Street and 520-22 East Seventy-third Street. He also acquired the capital stock of Schmeig Kotzian, Inc., custom furniture manufacturers, who use six floors in the building. John J. Reynolds was the broker.
GENEVA, May 25 -- If she has sufficient support, Thailand will ask the United Nations to send observers to Thailand to check on the Communist threat from Indochina.
TRENTON, May 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner questioned today the constitutionality of a bill adopted yesterday by the New Jersey Senate and designed to legalize night harness racing.

PARIS, May 25 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, American champion, eliminated the last Australian threat and Art Larsen upset the Wimbledon titleholder, Vic Seixas, of Philadelphia, in quarter-finals today to make possible an all-American final in the French international tennis tournament.

NORRIS, Tenn., May 25 -- Gordon R. Clapp expressed concern today that President Eisenhower was "inviting candidates pledged to a split allegiance to conflicting philosophies" to fill the vacancy on the Tennessee Valley Authority's board of directors.
Paul Tripp, who formerly conducted the "Mr. I. Magination" television program for children, will become the new producer and star of "On the Carousel" beginning June 5.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 25 -- Army authorities arrested a member of Parliament, Kasman Singodimedjo, on Amboina Island, in East Indonesia, on charges of attacking President Sukarno in a public speech and insulting Indonesia's Christian minority.
New issues of public utility securities totaling more than $34,000,000 will be offered publicly to investors today. The securities consist of debentures and preferred stock.

SOPHIA AUGUSTA FREDERICA, Princess of Anhalt-Zerbst, was only one of many obscure heiresses to petty German titles when she and her mother made a trip to St. Petersburg in 1744. "Figchen" was 15 years old. But a year later she was a grand duchess of Russia, the wife of the "poor, half-crazy creature with his nerves perpetually on edge" who is known to history as Czar Peter III.

The month of May is good for many things, not the least of them the pleasant labor of starting a new garden. This thought is even now occurring to the parents of small boys noted for enormous, if irregular, energy.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) -- The Veterans Committee of the House of Representatives voted today to increase Federal benefits by about $169,000,000 a year to some 2,026,000 disabled veterans and survivors of soldiers who died as a result of their service.

TORONTO, May 25 (Canadian Press) -McIntyre Porcupine Mines, Ltd., big Northern Ontario gold producer, had consolidated net profit for the year ended March 31 of $2,237,022, or $2.93 a share, compared with $2,301,912 in the preceding year.

LA LIMA, Honduras, May 25 -- A Government study commission arrived today to confer with United Fruit management and labor on the strike that began May 2. The commission arbitrated the Standard Fruit strike last week.
GENEVA, May 25 -- A simultaneous cease-fire everywhere in Indochina and withdrawal of the opposing forces into large zones was proposed here today by the chief Vietminh delegate.
Scoring eleven runs in the eighth inning, the Giants pounded five pitchers for twenty-two hits as they crushed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 21 to 4, before 7,206 fans at the Polo Grounds last night.

Intaglio Service, manufacturer of rotogravure plates, has leased a building under construction by the RGR Construction Company at 33-01 Hunters Point Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, through Robert Joseph Co., brokers. The building, containing 60,000 square feet of space, is scheduled to be completed by Sept. 1.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 (UP) -- The waiver process made an American Leaguer out of Outfielder Cal Abrams today and turned Southpaw Dick Littlefield into a National Leaguer in a deal between the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Baltimore Orioles.

Because his training has been interrupted by an apparent trivial injury to his right forefoot, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Native Dancer must be classed as a doubtful starter in the Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park next Monday.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -Following is the transcript of Secretary of State Dulles' remarks on Indochina today:
SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 -- Four persons convicted of harboring Communist fugitives in a California mountain cabin were ordered released on bail today by the Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
DOVER, Del., May 25 (AP) -- A contest between two slates for nine posts as directors of American Industries, Inc., forced a recess in the annual meeting today for a count of proxies.

PARIS, May 24 -- An experiment with solid rails about a half-mile long has been so successful here that the French National Railroad System has decided to replace all track on major lines with long rails.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 25 -- Robert Capa, well-known photographer, was killed by a mine today in the vicinity of Thaibinh, about forty-five miles southeast of Hanoi.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A policy intended to give high unemployment areas special consideration in defense spending provided little relief in the first three months of 1954.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, is apparently becoming a banking tycoon. Mr. Lewis, or interests closely allied with him and the union, were reported today to have acquired majority stock control in a second bank in the nation's capital, the Hamilton National.

" Yankee Whalers in the South Seas," by A. B. C. Whipple, will be issued July 1 by Doubleday. Among the stories the author tells of the danger and excitement of whaling in the old days about the voyage of the ill-fated Essex, Herman Melville as a whaler, the "almost perfect" mutiny on the Globe and the sailor who became a missionary.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP) -- Catcher Sam White hit a bases-empty ninth-inning homer to give the Boston Red Sox a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- They gave Bucky Harris a new, high-priced automobile at Griffith Stadium tonight, but Casey Stengel got more mileage out of his old Ford -- Whitey Ford, that is.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 -- A great religious awakening in the foreign field was reported today to the quadrennial world convention of the Seventh-Day Adventist Church.

The election of Ernest Nathan as executive vice president of the Palestine Economic Corporation was announced yesterday. His duties will include direction of the activities of the corporation, which is the largest American development company in Israel, Robert Szold, chairman of the board, said.

DETROIT, May 25 (UP) -- Bill Tuttle hit a triple off the left-field wall tonight to score Al Kaline from first base and give the Detroit Tigers a 5-to-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in twelve innings.

Readily available and reasonably priced, frozen sandwich steaks provide a convenient solution to the problem of preparing lunch or supper in a hurry. Buttered beef steaks, thin pieces of meat on which butter is spread before freezing, are a variation.

GUATEMALA, May 25 -- The odds are against any meaningful improvement of United States Guatemalan relations unless a change has come about, unannounced and unnoticed, in the Guatemalan Government's basic thinking on the Communist question.
Issues in which special situations existed stood out on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday but the general tone of the market was heavy and prices closed downward.

Plans are being furthered at frequent meetings for a benefit performance of "Fanny," a new musical production, on the night of Dec. 2, at a theatre yet to be announced. The event will aid the Manhattan School of Music.
The fur industry has slid into a one-fur industry in search of "the easy dollar," according to Louis A. Cohen, newly elected president of the American Fur Merchants Association.
" NOW listen, George," drawled the grinning Billy Goodman, "don't you go holdin' no meetin' in the White Sox clubhouse and tell 'em my arm's weak."

For the first time American specialties like Boston baked beans, Southern fried chicken, corn on the cob and apple brown Betty will compete with the best of European dishes in an international culinary exhibition in Berne, Switzerland.

The Whitney Museum of American Art has held its last exhibition in the well-known building at 10 West Eighth Street. But, before it moves to midtown, the half-century-old institution is saluting the youngest art organization in the neighborhood, the Village Art Center.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Democrats of the special House committee investigating tax-free educational foundations, after bolting a public hearing yesterday in protest against "loose" testimony, returned today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that the prospects for moral sanction by the United Nations of possible military intervention in Indochina "look somewhat better than they have recently."

Inventories at every level are so low and consumers are so handicapped in choosing goods that heavy buying by retailers is assured for the near future. A statement to this effect was made yesterday by Robert A. Whitney, president of National Sales Executives, Inc., following five months of talks with some 15,000 business leaders in 50,000 miles of traveling.

As the final production of its ten-week season, the American Savoyards, operating under the guidance of Dorothy Raedler, offered "The Sorcerer" at the President Theatre last night. The Gilbert and Sullivan comic opera, rarely performed since its first production in London in 1877, will be presented through next Sunday.
RABAT, French Morocco, May 25 -- A bomb apparently intended for Gen. Augustin Guillaume, retiring Resident-General in French Morocco, exploded in the main thoroughfare of Marrakesh today.

Today's new film is "Mistress of the Mountains," an Italian-made drama featuring Vivi Gioi, Adriano Rimoldi, Camillo Pilotto and Renato De Carmine, at the Cinema Verdi. Fernando Cerchio directed the import, which was based on a book by Giovanni Guareschi and produced by Giorgio Venturini. The Arthur Davis presentation has English titles.

Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, Emperor of one of the world's most ancient territories, arrived here yesterday. He voiced the hope that -- with American private investment -- his country might swiftly develop mod...
A family group that trekked 16,000 miles through Africa to study nomadic tribes arrived here yesterday aboard the American Export liner Independence.
KALIMPONG, India, May 25 -- Reports from Tibet indicate that an airport, said to be Asia's largest [cross on map], is near completion at Jyekundo near the Tibet-Chinese border.

The Long Island Rail Road has been in bankruptcy for five years. In 1950 it had two shocking accidents, in February at Rockville Centre, where thirty-two persons died, and on Thanksgiving Eve at Richmond Hill in Queens, where there was immediate death toll of seventy-five.

A broad new policy for improving conditions in multiple dwellings was set by the Wagner Administration yesterday. It is proposed to tighten housing laws all along the line to protect those who live in apartment houses and tenements.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, said today that there was no reason to fear the attitude of any university toward communism.

PARIS, May 25 -- On the return of three top generals from a survey of conditions in Indochina, the French Government began today to prepare for quick decisions on how much territory could be defended.
AN abundance of weakfish in Great South Bay and Peconic Bay, including a number of five-pounders and a few scaling up to eight pounds, is stirring even the laggard salt water anglers to activity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- Allied Artists has concluded arrangements with John Huston to make a minimum of three pictures on a profit-participation basis. The company also expected to complete similar deals with William Wyler and Billy Wilder, it was announced today by Steve Broidy, president.
A visitor at the Divine Providence Foundation, 225 East Forty-fifth Street, asked if all the homeless children cared for there by the nuns were Roman Catholic.
GENEVA, May 25 -- There is plenty of good money to be made by any European country smart enough to go after it.

MANILA, May 25 -- President Ramon Magsaysay and Charles E. Wilson, United States Secretary of Defense, have agreed on the creation of a joint Philippine-United States council to implement the 1951 Mutual Defense Treaty.

SOME enterprising off-Broadway theatre managers have demonstrated in the last few seasons that a play need not have been a success on Broadway in order to flourish in less elaborate productions. The sponsors of "Montserrat," which opened last night at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre, believed, perhaps, that they, too, could salvage a failure and endow it with the qualities necessary to attract audiences.

June has been designated air parcel post month by Henry Epstein, Deputy Mayor of New York. The proclamation was made yesterday afternoon at the Battery after he and two groups of Post Office Department and airline officials arrived at the city's Heliport No. 2 aboard two of New York Airways' helicopters from La Guardia and Newark Airports.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Indochina military situation is slipping faster than was expected and is now confronting the United States Government with the choice of an armistice or military intervention.

In celebration of its 100th anniversary, the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers presented a showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of fashions styled from the fabrics of these New England mills.
A strong demand for "used" homes in urban areas is reported by J. L. Kislak, Inc., which listed eighteen such sales during the past week in the North Hudson section of Jersey.

The Soviet High Commission representative in Berlin, S. A. Dengin, has rejected the demand to release Dr. Trushnovich, head of the Russian Rescue Committee in West Berlin, who was kidnapped April 13. This was to be expected. No doubt the Soviets now hope the matter will be dropped.
Six polling places have been set up for today's waterfront election.

After listening yesterday to thirteen witnesses protest a State University order banning fraternities and sororities with national affiliations, a three-judge Federal statutory court reserved decision until next week.
The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., led by Michael J. Quill, moved yesterday to strike the city-owned subway, elevated and surface lines June 14.

The sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building for seventy-nine families on plot 160 by 100 feet at the southwest corner at 239 Central Park West, southwest corner of Eighty-fourth Street, has been sold by Seymour and Jerome Berger in a deal negotiated by Allan Haymes and M. A. Spinrad, brokers.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today the President was setting up a studio for his painting in a third-floor room in their Gettysburg, Pa., farm house. The room has many windows facing south.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Complete desegregation of public schools in the District of Columbia by September, 1955, was recommended today by Hobart M. Corning, Superintendent of Schools here.

The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday the election as vice presidents of Winthrop E. Mange, who will serve in industrial relations, and Otto W. Manz Jr., who will be in charge of testing and distribution.

TAIPEI, Formosa, May 25 -- Formosan Gov. O. K. Yui was confirmed overwhelmingly by the Legislative Yuan (Parliament) as Premier today. He said Nationalist China was "ready at all times" to support world and Asian collective security and to contribute to any "united action" to resist Communist aggression.

TWO art galleries are closing the season with group exhibitions of work by artists identified with them during the season. Samuel Kootz is showing paintings and sculpture by his American contingent and paintings by three contemporary French artists, before taking off for his summer quarters in Provincetown.

James Reston in his column of May 2 called attention to the fact President Roosevelt foresaw the situation in Indochina ten years ago and demanded independence for the Indochinese people. Unfortunately, Roosevelt's demand was neglected by the United States after his death.
CHICAGO, May 25 -- Willis Gale, chairman, told stockholders of the Commonwealth Edison Company at their annual meeting today that he views the months ahead "with a reasonable degree of optimism."

A German shepherd dog bit seven school children who had been playing on 137th Street between Willis and Alexander Avenues, the Bronx, during the lunch recess yesterday. The dog was captured by a patrolman.

American Stock Exchange governors moved swiftly yesterday to protect the "continuity" of their market and, in an unusual action, ordered specialists to pay a rebate of 7/8 point to every investor who bought New Mexico and Arizona Land Company common stock at its opening price of 17 7/8.
The Royal Netherlands Steamship Company cargo vessel Charis was shown off to the shipping public yesterday.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 26 -- Salary increases totaling $220,000 have been approved for 400 teachers by the Greenwich Board of Education for inclusion in its 1955 budget now being prepared.
LONDON, May 26 -- Former Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee and Aneurin Berlin, his principal foe in the Labor party, will lead a Laborite delegation to Communist China this summer.

The New Music Quartet played a concert at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Auditorium of the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. last evening under the sponsorship of the International Society for Contemporary Music.
A couple of Polynesian's sons figured most prominently in the A. M. and P. M. proceedings at Belmont Park yesterday.

Events today: Searle Wright, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; Carnegie Pop Concert, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Composers Group of New York City. Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Stephen Goldberg pianist-composer, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30.
The Grace Line will end its use of Pier 65, North River, tomorrow and will transfer the pier's Caribbean shipping to Java Street, Brooklyn.
HANOI, Vietnam, May 26 -- French Union defenders of the Red River delta, menaced by an apparent Vietminh pincers advance, today blew up two of their posts on the southern rim of the delta.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- President Eisenhower made public an inter-agency report today calling for fewer but stronger airlines and for orderly reduction and withdrawal of Federal subsidies to domestic airlines "where appropriate."

Even with strong world-wide return of confidence in the pound, Britain and the sterling area must continue to regard complete currency convertibility as - long-term goal, a British business group was informed here yesterday.
CAMBRIDGE, England, May 26 (AP) -- Prof. Paul Adrien Dirac, Nobel Prize-Winning British physicist, disclosed today he had been refused a visa to enter the United States for a year's study.

"THIS is the imaginary journal of an imaginary person," William L. Shirer observes on the flyleaf of his new novel, "Stranger Come Home,"* "and all the other characters in its pages are likewise imaginary. If there is any resemblance whatsoever to persons living or lately dead, it is purely coincidental."

The four-story apartment house accommodating thirty-nine families at 120-10 Rockaway Beach Boulevard in Rockaway Park, Queens, has been purchased by the Purgess Holding Corporation of Brooklyn from C. Beneduce. W. F. Brunner, Inc., was the broker in the sale of the prop!erty which is assessed at $107,000. ][. A. IVfac-aro was attorneyl for the seller and I. Greenbaum acted for the buyer. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
The main charges in the Army-McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:
PITTSBURGH, May 26 -- The Post-Gazette resumed distribution tonight after a two-day suspension of publication caused by a jurisdictional dispute between two A. F. L. unions.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., May 26 -- Eyewitness accounts of the Bennington disaster were told today by weary survivors who were flown into this Naval Air Base by helicopters and by those who were on the carrier when she docked here.

LONDON, May 26 -- Duncan Sandys, Minister of Supply and son-in-law of Prime Minister Churchill, will fly to the United States June 1 for a visit at the invitation of Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson.

Some years ago the country was persuaded to adopt the policy of "negotiation from strength," and during the interval the strength has been achieved and published at home and abroad. This policy was taken to mean that when it became apparent that our policy was not dictated by weakness the emphasis would be shifted to negotiation.
CHICAGO, May 26 (UP) -- Two top baseball executives said today that radio and television broadcasting of major leagues games was strangling minor league attendance.

MERIDIAN, Miss., May 26 -- Constitutional powers have become unbalanced because of the failures of leadership and demoralization of Executive-Congressional relations, Adlai E. Stevenson declared tonight.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Cass Michaels' single with the bases loaded in the ninth gave the Chicago White Sox a 5-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians today. The triumph moves the White Sox to within a half a game of the first-place Tribe.
The appalling loss of life by explosion and fire aboard the aircraft carrier Bennington yesterday ranked among the worst disasters to befall United States naval vessels by accident.
The Sanitation Department showed yesterday how alternate-side parking enabled its mechanized brooms to save time and manpower in cleaning the streets.
PARIS, May 26 -- Partisans and opponents of the proposed European army agreed unexpectedly today to postpone a vote on the treaty in the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly.
Harry Gross' sentence for bookmaking was reduced again yesterday. Three justices of the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn cut his term from eight years to four.

The Estate Securities Company, operators, bought the fivestory walk-up apartment building at 1021 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, from Charlotte L. Jen nings, who had owned it for about thirty years. 'The terms were cash over a new first mortgage of $30,000, according to 1VL C. O'Brien, the broker. Assessed at $50,00, the property is' 50 by 100 feet and contains sixteen apartments.

CINCINNATI, May 26 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves stretched their winning streak to nine games tonight when Andy Pafko's fourth hit provided the decisive run in a 7-6 triumph over the Cincinnati Redlegs.
Memorial Day visitors to the city will see a "blackout" in the Broadway area next Monday night.

ST. LOUIS, May 26 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs, major league leaders in home run production, raised their season total to fifty tonight, hitting four as Paul Minner gained a 15-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Dr. Alan J. E. Wace sailed yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Queen Mary to begin his ninth year of digging into the life and times of Mycenae, the ancient capital of King Agamemnon in southern Greece.
Union preparations for a legal battle over the right of Transit Authority employes to strike were being made yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Administration's housing program, cut sharply following disclosures of scandal, was hit hard again today by Southern resentment at the Supreme Court decision May 17 barring segregation in public housing.

"Going steady," a custom among teen-agers that is a source of much adult concern, was defended last night by a youth counselor as a means of normal adolescent adjustment and a measure of "social security."
HANOI, Vietnam, May 25 -- A system of "democratic centralism" and tight political controls reminiscent of Communist China is being applied in Vietminh-controlled areas of Indochina.

One of the largest wine tastings ever held in this country -- 4,000 persons were invited -- took place yesterday at the Croydon Hotel, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street. Jean de Lagarde, consul general of France, presided at the party.

Business is showing a seasonable pick-up but the over-all picture is not as rosy as some economists and Government officials paint it, according to Dr. Jules Backman, Professor of Economics at New York University. He spoke yesterday at a luncheon after the annual spring membership meeting of the Carpet Institute, Inc., in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NEWARK, May 26 -- Abner (Longie) Zwillman, prohibition era bootlegger and reputed syndicate gambler, was indicted today by the Federal grand jury here for income tax evasion. A two-count bill charged that Zwillman willfully evaded the payment of $46,100 for 1947 and 1948.
MOSCOW, May 26 -- Parity or duality of the Communist party and the state in the Soviet Union has been growing.
PARIS, May 26 -- A petroleum prospecting project to be undertaken in the region of Orleans, financed jointly by French and American capital, was authorized today by the Cabinet.

A six-hit pitching job by Ruben Gomez and Davey Williams' home run in the fifth inning brought the Giants a 2-1 triumph and a sweep of the two-game set with the Pittsburgh Pirates at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The victory was the fifth straight and the twelfth in the last seventeen games for the Polo Gounders.

SEAFORD, L. I., May 26 -- A bulldozer and a crane, halted three days ago while clearing underbrush for a housing development, remained idle today as crews waited for a wild duck to hatch her clutch of twelve eggs.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., May 26 -- The first survivors of the Bennington explosion who arrived at the Naval Air Base here at 7 o'clock tonight participated in an impressive emotional scene with wives, relatives and friends gathered in the enlisted men's recreation hall to greet them.
Boot, a Marine Corps canine veteran, helped a private detective yesterday to capture a suspect in the hold-up of a Broadway corset shop.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Information coming here from Central America through diplomatic channels is that Guatemala's neighbors to the south see a much greater potential of danger than an increase in Guatemala's military power in the arms supply to that country from an Iron Curtain port.
NEWPORT, R. I., May 26 -- The seventy-six most seriously injured aboard the Bennington were brought to the Naval Hospital here today by helicopter and boat.
Vice President Richard H. Nixon made an appeal last night to Governor Dewey to run for re-election in November.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- Federal and New York State officials asked the Supreme Court today to throw out an attempt by Lake Ontario landowners to block construction of a vital St. Lawrence River power project.
Cost of food before it reached the housewife in the week ended last Tuesday was up in the clouds.

It is a bitter pill for the theatre people, having got the federal admissions tax down from 20 per cent to 10, to face the prospect of a 5 per cent city tax that deprives them of half of their Washington victory. Perhaps it is television, rather than tax, that has most hurt the movies and baseball.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- The board of directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad today formally elected James M. Symes to succeed Walter S. Franklin as president of the transportation system on June 1.
Teddy the tortoise, with some human assistance, parted a white ribbon yesterday to open the Bronx Zoo's reconstructed reptile house at the spring members' party of the New York Zoological Society.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Senate Finance Committee announced today its approval of proposals to relieve about 1,000,000 persons of the task of filing annual declarations of estimated individual income taxes.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., May 26 -- The two men most closely concerned with directing damage control and rescue operations in the tragedy aboard the carrier Bennington have had long service in the air arm of the Navy.

A drop last week of 1,198,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline; stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 174.552,000 barrels, compared with 175,750,000 a weak earl/er and 152,403,000 a year ago.
TAIPEI, Formosa, May 26 -- Nationalist Premier O. K. Yui completed his "young" cabinet line-up today and the new cabinet will assume office June 1.
CAIRO, May 26 -- The British Government has informed Egypt it is ready to resume negotiations on the sovereignty of the Suez Canal zone, a Cairo Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

Robin Roberts, who had suffered many indignities at the hands of the Dodgers in the recent past, gained a measure of vengeance last night. It was not by any means a full measure. Philadelphia's ace right-hander was pounded hard, but he rode out the storm and beat the Brooks, 8 -- 6, before 17,097 spectators at Ebbets Field.

Following is an incomplete list of those killed and injured in the fire and explosion aboard the Bennington. A complete list will be published in tomorrow's editions. Addresses are those of next of kin:

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Four Republican Senators outvoted three Democrats today to dismiss misconduct charges against H. Struve Hensel, Assistant Secretary of Defense, and Francis P. Carr, staff director for the McCarthy investigating subcommitee.
A thousand American insurance men listened with envy here yesterday to an account of the scope and flexibility of the wholly unregulated British underwriting industry.

NEW DELHI, India, May 26 -- Secretary of State Dulles' clarification yesterday of United States policy on Indochina advanced a significant recent trend here toward a friendlier appreciation of Washington's views.
Benjamin Franklin's aspirations for liberty and the rights of man are so out of tune with the temper of the present as to seem downright subversive, Robert E. Sherwood said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- An appeal to the Federal Government not to withdraw grant-in- aid funds to the fight against tuberculosis and venereal disease was made today by Dr. Leona Baumgartner, New York City Health Commissioner.
PARIS, May 26 -- The French seemed today to be moving toward acceptance of a partition of territory in Indochina.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 -- A membership double the present 924,000 was called for today as a goal of the Seventh-Day Adventist Church for the next quadrennium.
JERUSALEM, May 26 -- A new attempt to save the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, the holiest place in Christendom, from the shoddy ruin threatening it was set on foot today.

LINDEN, N. J., May 26 -- Another sales record and "probably slightly better" earnings this year were predicted for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) by M. J. Rathbone, president, at the annual meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Four Republican farm leaders of Congress told President Eisenhower at a White House breakfast today that the best he could hope for was a compromise on farm legislation.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, acting chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, opens each day's session with the prize understatement of the year. This is, he says, a public hearing.

The modern Ondine, whether she favors sand and surf, lake shores or pool edges, hangs a great deal of equipment on the proverbial hickory limb before she dashes in the water. While bathing suits become briefer and scantier each season, beach accessories gain in importance and originality.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26 -- Olivia de Havilland will co-star with Robert Mitchum in the Stanley Kramer production of the best-seller noval, "Not as a Stranger."

CAIRO, May 26 -- The youthful Egyptologist who directed the discovery of Cheops' funeral ship near that king's pyramid, is Kamal el-Malakh, 34-year-old director at Giza and in Lower Egypt for the Egyptian Government's Department of Antiquities.
CHICAGO, May 26 -- Selling by Southwestern houses, reflecting the much-improved crop prospects in that section, was largely responsible for a recession today in wheat prices.

In deciding yesterday to dismiss the charges against Assistant Secretary of Defense Hensel and Francis Carr before its hearings are concluded the McCarthy investigating committee has in our view made a grave blunder. The fact that this action was taken by a straight party vote does nothing to increase our confidence in the wisdom of the decision.

Shipbuilding continued to decline in the United States in the first three months of 1954 at a more precipitous rate than in the rest of the world, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday.

The strategy of the Soviet and Chinese Communists in Southeast Asia is aimed directly at the the most vital of United States interests, Robert Aura Smith of the editorial board of The New York Times declared yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 26 -- A tremendous surge from second position during the final quarter carried Scotch Dean, driven by Al Clark, to a one-length victory over Florita in 2:02 4-5 in the Inaugural Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Plans are being made for the annual Summer Day Fair for the benefit of the Society of St. Johnland. The fete will be held on June 30 on the grounds of the home in Kings Park, L. '

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26 -- The investigation into the loyalty of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche was denounced as an "unseemly farce" today by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
DETROIT, May 26 (UP) -- George Zuverink, making his first major league start, pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 6-to-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today before 3,609 fans at Briggs Stadium.

The Royal Dutch Navy began yesterday its first official visit to this country in twenty-eight years. Four minutes after sunrise the pride of the Netherlands fleet, the 18,040-ton aircraft carrier Karel Doorman, was made fast at Pier 26 North River.

Since the publication of Anna Perrott Rose's "Room for One More," the author's husband has died, her children have grown up and she has been teaching school to keep occupied. Into her classroom one day was thrust a young Latvian boy, who had come to America from a German displaced persons camp.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres, this morning. "Johnny Guitar," a Republic Western drama in Trucolor with Joan Crawford, Sterling Hayden, Scott Brady and Mercedes McCambridge, is at the Mayfair. Nicholas Ray directed, from a screen play by Philip Yordan, based on the novel by Roy Chanslor. Ward Bond, Ben Cooper, Ernest Borgnine and John Carradine head the supporting cast.
HARTFORD, May 26 -- Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India, said today he would not seek the Democratic nomination for Governor at the state convention here June 25 and 26.
The Times of May 23 carried the news of the death of Msgr. Robert Howard Lord, formerly Professor of History at Harvard University and later Vice Rector of St. John's Seminary of Boston.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Charles S. Thomas, Secretary of the Navy, went to the White House this evening to report to President Eisenhower on the Bennington disaster.

Sales and earnings of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., and subsidiaries in the 13 and 52 weeks ended on May 1 were higher than in the preceding year, according to the report issued yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president.

GUATEMALA, May 26 -- Despite its acquisition of a large quantity of Czechoslovak arms, the Guatemalan Government has no intention of seeking the withdrawal of United States Army and Air Force missions. They have worked here since May, 1945.

EMERSON, N. J., May 26 -- Two suspects were arrested today on a charge of robbing two officials of the First National Bank of Spring Valley, N. Y., of a $32,000 payroll last month. At the same time, $8,988 of the loot was recovered from a cache near the home of one of the suspects.

Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Theatres have reached an impasse on terms for a new contract governing legitimate theatre performers. The present pact is scheduled to expire next Monday.

PARIS, May 26 (AP) -- The United States and Australia gained a monopoly of the men's doubles semi-finals of the French international tennis championships today as the top teams -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas of the United States and Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall of Australia won in straight sets.

DALLAS, Tex., May 26 -- Having concluded a winter season of nine new productions, Theatre '54 is now repeating five of them in a week of repertory performances. Tennessee Williams' "Purification" was put on for the first time this season, and Giraudoux' "The Apollo of Bellac" comprise the Thursday bill.

MOSCOW, May 26 -- Moscow proposed today that Britain break with her policy of support for the North Atlantic Treaty, abandon United States-inspired trade restrictions and join the Soviet Union in a common effort for peace, security and profitable business contracts.
CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Endon, owned by Marion H. Vanberg of Columbus, Neb., lost the lead near the finish, then regained it to triumph in the $5,000 Peabody Prep at Lincoln Fields today.

The New York Board of Rabbis adopted a resolution yesterday opposing a proposed amendment to the Constitution calling for recognition of "the authority and law of Jesus Christ, Saviour and Ruler of Nations."

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- (UP) -- The Veterans Committee of the House of Representatives today unanimously approved an increase of nearly 10 per cent in Federal pension and compensation payments to ex-service men and their dependents.
City auto owners were reminded yesterday by City Treasurer George M. Bragalini that $5 and $10 auto use stamps for 1954 were now on sale and must be displayed on cars not later than June 15.

This is Sanitation Week, by proclamation of Mayor Wagner, and the best news to come out of it so far is Sanitation Commissioner Mulrain's statement that "the litterbugs are beginning to correct their bad habits." This is due in part, no doubt, to a drive which has resulted in summonses to 4,000 offenders since mid-April.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 26 (AP) -- The American Baptist convention, representing 1,500,000 church members, today unanimously approved a statement striking out at those "so intent upon combating the menace of communism that they adopt the very principles and methods which makes communism itself frightening."
LONDON, May 26 -- A better tone developed in the stock markets here today, but business was still restrained by the railway strike and the Indochina situation.
For the second time in five months a fiercely contested National Labor Relations Board election failed last night to settle the interunion fight for control of the Port of New York.
CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Hogs continued their steep drop in the livestock market today, selling 50 cents to $1 lower. Top sank to $27, paid for only one load, the lowest top figure since March 23.

If the public will continue its cooperation with the water-saving program for a short time longer the prospect is that water restrictions can be relaxed. This promise was held out yesterday by Arthur C. Ford, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
A general wage increase of 5 cents an hour was approved last night for employes of Macy's, Inc., the department store, at a meeting of Local 1-S, United Department Store Workers of America, C. I. O.
Seventeen leaders of the terrorist Nationalist party of Puerto Rico were indicted here yesterday on charges of seditious conspiracy.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 26 -- A sparkling round of 38, 42 -- 80 enabled Mrs. J. B. Balding of the Creek Club to finish with a score of minus 1 and to capture first place in the women's Long Island Golf Association match play-against-par tourney at the Huntington Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Patience, fortitude and a timely pinch hit enabled the Washington Senators to catch up with Eddie Lopat tonight at Griffith Stadium.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP) -- Sen. Edwin C. Johnson said today he would write "every professional baseball club in the country" to explain what he called the evils of ownership by brewing companies and other corporations.

FOR the better part of two decades Fordham's athletic heroes have been trying to get to California for some spectacular muscle-flexing activities. The original idea during the era of Sleepy Jim Crowley was that the football team would go "from Rose Hill to Rose Bowl." But that ancient rallying cry has become rusty from disuse.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 26 (AP) -- Frank Strafaci of Garden City, L. I., missed an easy three-foot putt on the twenty-fifth green today and lost in the fourth round of the British amateur golf tournament.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 26 (UP) -- King Ranch's High Scud, holding a 21-pound edge in weights over the favored Imbros, today raced to a half-length victory in the $15,000 Compton Handicap at Hollywood Park. Imbros led the field into the stretch, then faded to third behind Kingly.

PARIS, May 26 -- "Illustrations for A Calendar" is this year's theme for special window displays in smart shops along the Faubourg Saint Honore. Held when roses begin to bloom, Paris calls this enchanting festival "The Fortnight of The Rose."
OTTAWA, May 26 (Canadian Press) -- Canada and the United States have opened new grain talks in Washington designed mostly to clarify United States selling policies, it was learned today.

The fundamental principles of American policy in the Far East have been outlined again by Secretary Dulles in relation to Indochina. These principles are based squarely on the United Nations Charter, and within that framework (1) on the "Uniting for Peace" resolution which empowered the vetoless General Assembly to initiate collective action against aggression, and (2) on the historic Vandenberg resolution which authorized American association with regional and other collective security arrangements.
CHICAGO, May 26 (UP) -- Vince Martinez, 148 1/2, pounded Chuck Davey, 149, into complete submission tonight for a seventh-round technical knockout in the Chicago Stadium.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Dr. Gordon A. Granger, of the Division of Medicine of the Food and Drug Administration, today warned against glandular products under "male formula" and "female tone" labels.
UNITED NATIONS, May 26 -- Western delegations held their first conference today on the mechanics of putting the Indochinese situation before the United Nations.
MADRID, May 26 (AP) -- Spain has ordered her frontier with Gibraltar closed to all Spanish tourists, a Government spokesman announced today.

GENEVA, May 26 -- The United States, Britain and France will resume efforts tomorrow to determine whether the latest Vietminh proposal offers substantial encouragement for an armistice in Indochina on honorable terms.

President Eisenhower's chief economic adviser predicted last night an early recovery from the economic let-down that began last year. He said the Government's business-cycle policies were working out "reasonably well."
CAIRO, May 26 -- A perfumed ship built by a Pharaoh nearly 5,000 years ago to carry his soul to heaven was discovered today in a subterranean corridor beside a pyramid.

The political, social and economic problems of our times had their origin in the repudiation of the Christian understanding of life, the Rev. Dr. John H. Hallowell, Professor of Political Science at Duke University, declared yesterday.
The aircraft carrier Bennington has known tragedy before.
A new issue of $50,000,000 of Public Service Electric and Gas Company long-term first and refunding mortgage bonds will be placed on the market today at a price to yield 3.1 per cent to investors.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 26 (UP) -- The Dickey Stable's Menolene, the favorite, scampered to a three-quarter-length victory today in the $20,000 Rancocas Stakes at Garden State Park.

Commodity prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, coffee, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, silk and tin were lower than on Tuesday; wool, hides, zinc, and copper, burlap and rubber were higher, and sugar and potatoes were mixed.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- (UP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, Democratic floor leader, said today he believed Aug. 15 was the earliest the Senate could complete its legislative work and adjourn.

THE stripers seem to have moved in. Reports from Sandy Hook to Cape Cod indicate that the fish are running quite large but are not too plentiful. In most instances, they are being taken by trolling rather than surfcasting.
The first step toward a possible healing of the rupture between the Welfare and Health Council of New York City and Roman Catholic agencies was taken yesterday by a council official.

Leading steel producers reported yesterday that steel demand had improved moderately in the last few weeks and that steel-making operations are expected to continue at about the present rate through the summer.

BUENOS AIRES, May 26 -- The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) is expected to enter its bid for the development of Argentine oilfields tomorrow, when top officials of the company are scheduled to meet with President Juan Peron.

Manhattan's athletic department honored ninty-three athletes with major letters and sweaters last night at the annual Block "M" dinher, held on the college campus. Brother A. Philip, F. S. C., president of the college, presented the awards.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in the twenty-first day of its hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

The Silver Star decoration was presented yesterday to former Chaplain (Major) Joseph A. Dunne assistant pastor of St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in White Plains. N. Y., for gallantry in Korea. Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, First Army commander, made the presentation on Governors Island.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation and Westcoast Transmission Company, Inc., today insisted they had the qualifications Ito provide natural gas to the ;Pacific Northwest.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- United States customs officials are inspecting a French merchant ship at the Panama Canal on suspicion that her cargo may include unlisted weapons.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Eighteen Senators, forming what is commonly called the Senate's liberal bloc, will propose tomorrow a "code of fair procedure" for investigating committees.

Baltimore County, Md., borrowed $22,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance public improvements. The county sold an issue of serial bonds maturing from 1957 to 1994 to a banking syndicate headed by National City Bank of New York at an interest cost of 2.5078 per cent.
DETROIT, May 26 -- The Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. called upon its 8,550 congregations today to offer membership "sincerely and personally" to every individual without regard to race.

ALBANY, May 26 -- A two-section Shareholders' Special streaked through spring greenery along the New York Central's water-level route from Gotham to Albany today carrying 830 of the road's deceptively genial small-holding owners.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Eisenhower welcomed Emperor Haile Selassie to the nation's capital today.
GENEVA, May 26 -- The United States Government has taken a firm position in favor of changing the system of allocating United Nations funds for technical assistance to underdeveloped areas.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Senate Government Opera-] tions Committee asked the Senate tonight to cite Corliss Lamont, wealthy New York leftist,I for contempt for Congress.
Dismayed by last Thursday's disorder on the subway, the student body of the High School of Commerce has offered to pay for the damage.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended May 19:
Newspaper advertising is backing up other indications that the economic recession has about run its course.

Jan Meyerowitz' opera, "Eastward in Eden," the libretto by Dorothy Gardner, author of the play, on the subject of Emily Dickinson, which had a brief run some months ago in this city, was produced last night by the opera department of the Mannes College of Music in the Hunter College Playhouse.
JERUSALEM, May 26 -- Hard words were exchanged in the privacy of a Cabinet meeting today following a police search in the headquarters here of the Mizrachi (religious Zionist) movement.
The Republican State Committee met yesterday morning and adjourned without naming a Republican National Committeeman to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of J. Russel Sprague.
Near-by large white Grade A eggs were quoted in local markets yesterday at prices ranging upward from 59 cents a dozen.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The National Education Association was accused today of having sponsored classroom textbooks stressing "the seamy side" of American life but picturing the Soviet Union as a land of "sweetness and light."
ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 -- A "crusade for children" to stem crime by youth was advocated today by Bertram M. Beck, director of the Federal Special Juvenile Delinquency project.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and prices moved 5 points higher to 3 points lower than on Tuesday.

PATERSON, N. J., May 26 -- The New Jersey Bar Association will not act "at this time" to contest a State Supreme Court decision of May 17 ordering John E. Selser, a lawyer, to disclose conversations with his client, the late Willie Moretti.

Everybody ought to go househunting in the country at least once in five years, even without the slightest intention of removing from the city. The entertainment value of a turn around the rural areas inspecting the dwelling places of a former era is very high, especially when the third party -- the country real estate broker -- is there to provide a narration which evidently has nothing whatever to do with the scenario.
LONDON, May 26 -- Bipartisan support in Britain for West German rearmament under the proposed European Defense Community received two severe setbacks today.
Cheops reigned over Egypt for fifty years, according to Herodotus.
BOSTON, May 26 (AP) -- Leslie Jane Stable's Heiress, a 4-year-old daughter of Stymie, scored a two-length victory today in the Everett Purse at Suffolk Downs.

David Dubinsky, often called "the boss" of the Liberal party, asked 1,500 party members last night to consider "whether there is enough political, moral and financial strength in New York to support a party of quality without an early promise of quantity."
Stocks made a broad but restrained upward movement yesterday Under the leadership of steels and aircrafts.

The regional Red Cross Blood Program received 637 pints of blood Tuesday. Employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Electric Company at 195 Broadway gave 179 pints on the first of three days of contribution.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), May 26 -- Washington's response to a request by the United Nations truce supervision organization for the continued services of a United States Navy officer is awaited here as an indication of United States policy on the Arab-Israeli dispute.
ALBANY, May 26 -- The noisy battle of the last eighteen weeks for control of the giant New York Central Railroad quieted today to a shuffling of a stack of 40,979 papers -- representing votes.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., May 26 -- Rescue work aboard the aircraft carrier Bennington got under way almost simultaneously with the blasts and fire this morning. Sailors and marines were wrenched from sleep or routine tasks and plunged into the work of saving shipmates who lay burned.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 26 -- Jordan formally declined today to make any commitments under the United Nations Charter that might be used to force her to undertake direct peace negotiations with Israel.

The Liberace show played Madison Square Garden last night and, thanks to the physical vitality, the ready wit and the showy night club pianism of the 34-year-old Milwaukee entertainer, the mammoth audience was kept at a high pitch of enthusiasm.
