CHICAGO, May 26 -- The next decade will be one of synthetic substitutes, developed because they produce more and better products at lower cost, George Stuart Brady, consultant to the Office of Defense Mobilization, said today. He addressed members of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the closing session of their convention.

Recently some teen-agers took part in an act of riotous destruction. Thwarted through a rain squall in attending a grand field day in Van Cortlandt Park, the disappointed youngsters switched the pent-up aggression to another object. The public is shocked and alarmed.
GENEVA, May 26 -- A Communist spokesman discussed in an open press conference today the matter of the thirty-two United States citizens being held captive inside China.

Typical of the attacks on Secretary Benson's farm policies, and more important than most of the others, was this comment by former President Truman: "The so-called Benson farm program, designed further to reduce farm prices and farm incomes, should be tossed out the nearest window * * *."

GASTONIA, N. C., May 26 (AP) -- Six Negro boys have applied for positions on Gastonia's all-white American Legion Junior baseball team and an official said today they would get equal treatment with white players.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 26 -- A New Jersey school teacher was accused today of first-degree manslaughter for deliberately driving his automobile into a pole. His wife was killed in the crash. They had been arguing over $20.

The State Public Service Commission endorsed as "sound and constructive" yesterday the agreement worked out by the Long Island Transit Authority to return the Long Island Rail Road to Pennsylvania Railroad control.
QUONSET POINT, R. I., May 26 -- Explosions and fire aboard the aircraft carrier Bennington killed at least ninety-one men and injured more than 200 today.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 26 (AP) -- One young mountain climber was killed and another lay seriously injured at the 14,000-foot level on Mount McKinley after a "terrible spill" that ended a student expedition.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 27 (AP) -- Rushing up from last place in the last half-mile, Dale Frost, an 8-5 chance, tonight won the feature $3,500 Garden City Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

The Erie (Pa.) Sewer Authority sold yesterday an issue of $5,300,000 revenue bonds to a syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation at an interest cost of 2.8277 per cent. The offering consisted of $2,900,000 of serial obligations maturing from 1956 to 1974 and $2,400,000 of term bonds due in 1984.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The collapse of the Yankees' defense cost the world champions their second straight defeat by the Washington Senators today. Two infield errors behind Bob Kuzava led to five unearned runs in the fifth and the Nats, who also got a gift run in the first, went on to record a 7-3 victory at Griffith Stadium.

NEWPORT, R. I., May 27 -- Rear Admiral H. Lamont Pugh, Surgeon General of the Navy, said that it would be a long pull for many of the eighty-two injured men of the Bennington who are at the Naval Hospital here.

Although gross revenues of the Union Pacific Railroad Company in April shrank to $37,794,019 from $42,642,557 in the similar month last year, net income rose to $5,590,119 from $4,875,518, the report disclosed yesterday. Net operating income was $2,618,111, against $2,253,766.

A combat veteran of World Wars I and II, Capt. Frank Kenneth Johnson, was named yesterday as Captain of the Port of New York by Rear Admiral Louis B. Olson, commander of the Third Coast Guard District.
GENEVA, May 27 -- France proposed today that representatives of the opposing high commands meet here "as soon as possible" to start arranging a cease-fire in Vietnam.
GARDEN CITY, May 27 -- State-wide elimination of thousands of unsafe jalopies and ending fraudulent car sales practices were urged today by the head of the New York State Automobile Dealers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- The Gulf Oil Corporation celebrated the completion of a $50,000,000 expansion program at its Philadelphia refinery today with a tour through the new facilities and a luncheon attended by 450 civic and business leaders.

A shopping center site comprising five acres and occupying a triangular plot on Jericho Turnpike, West Hills Road and Jones Lane in Hutington, L. I., has been sold by Elizabeth V. Fox and Jerome Thralls to Louis Pergament, president of Pergament Distributors, Inc. John L. Loesel was the broker and the attorneys were Milton Kendall for the buyer and Jack T. Thralls for the sellers.

BONN, Germany, May 27 -- The seventh annual congress of the German Society for Space Research convened today in Hamburg. Two hundred and fifty astronomers, astrophysicists and rocket researchers were present.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Ray H. Jenkins, special subcommittee counsel in the Army-McCarthy inquiry, was defense attorney for Alfred Dean Slack in an espionage case referred to today by Roy M. Cohn.
A working woman living in this city with her family needed about 38 per cent more money to support herself last year than she did in 1946, according to the New York State Labor Department.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today he had asked the Army to report to him on its investigation of the "F. B. I. letter" given to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy by an Army Intelligence officer.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in the twenty-second day of its hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Fifty angry mothers, some with small children, protested yesterday at Police Headquarters that the Eighty-fifth Precinct at Stagg Street, Brooklyn, should not be closed as was ordered by Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 27 (UP) -- The defending champion, Indiana, held a slight lead in Big Ten tennis play today by scoring 22 points in the first round of play.

FORT WORTH, Tex, May 27 (AP) -- Peter Thomson of Melbourne, Australia, making his second tour of American golf, shot a four-under-par 66 at the Colonial Country Club today to take the first-round lead in the $25,000 Colonial national invitation tournament.

CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- Hogs showed a little more steadiness today than on other days this week even though the top price fell to a new low since March 19. Lightweight hogs sold steady to 25 cents lower while offerings scaling more than 220 pounds mainly held steady. Salable receipts at 7,000 head were in line with expectations.
PARIS, May 27 -- Half a million Parisians forgot the desperate problem that besets their nation in Indochina to celebrate the fete of their city today in hot spring weather.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Department store sales last week were 5 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:
A temporary injunction prohibiting unionized musicians from picketing Yankee Stadium and the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn was signed yesterday by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger.
The economic potentials of the United States in the next quarter-century are "enormous," economists from many countries were told yesterday at Columbia University.

CHICAGO, May 27 (UP) -- Chuck Davey, one-time golden boy of television boxing, retired from the ring today, declaring last night's defeat by Vince Martinez "convinced me it's time to hang up the gloves."

RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 27 -- Former Representative Ernest Greenwood's reluctance to say whether he will run for Congress again this fall is due to the fact he may be the Democratic nominee for Lieutenant Governor in October, it was learned today from a reliable source.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee overrode Administration objections today in voting unanimously to continue operation of the Government-owned tin smelter at Texas City, Tex., until June 30, 1955.
ALBANY, May 27 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the Mayor of New York cannot be forced to make public reports he receives from his Commissioner of Investigation.
Business loans of New York banks are still declining. The reduction registered in the week ended on Wednesday was $60,000,000, compared with a reduction the week before of $23,000,000.

Roy M. Cohn, the 27-year-old chief counsel to the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigation, has been referred to at various times as a "brash kid," a "Keystone cop," and -- by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy -- as "the most brilliant young fellow I have ever met."

The Baldwin - Lima - Hamilton Corporation, manufacturer of heavy industrial machinery, has arranged to reacquire 515,000 shares of its own common stock from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. The price was $4,635,000, or $9 a share, a joint announcement by both concerns said yesterday.

New table-size 17-inch and 21-inch television receivers featuring controls on their tops were shown here yesterday by the Raytheon Manufacturing Company, Chicago, at a news conference in the Gotham Hotel. With the sets the company is offering at a slight extra charge metal stands and "slip-on" fabric jackets so that the units can be mad to conform to a room's decor.

A daily vacuuming will do a great deal to keep a rug presentable. But even with this care there comes a time, usually about this time of year, when ingrained dirt in carpets gives the entire room a rather unhappy appearance.

Following is the text of the address entitled "Today's Alternatives," by Admiral Robert B. Carney, Chief of Naval Operations, before the National Security Industrial Association at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday:
Marc Connelly, 63-year-old playwright, was knocked to the sidewalk on the upper West Side yesterday evening by a chair said by the police to have been shoved from the roof of a five-story building.
MEXICO CITY, May 27 -- An unofficial attempt to organize a hemisphere-wide campaign against communism began today with the opening of the first Congress Against Soviet Intervention in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- A quarreling House subcommittee voted today to dismiss its chief counsel and chief investigator and the Republican chairman charged that it was part of a "campaign" to cover up labor racketeering.
Integration of competing bus and rapid transit systems on Staten Island with a two-zone fare at 15 cents a zone was approved yesterday by the Transit Authority.

Reports filed with the New York Stock Exchange under the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 revealed yesterday that two newspaper employes' beneficial funds in Springfield, Mass., had been buying stock in Exchange Buffet Corporation for many years and now were holding 172,866 of its 246,889 common shares.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 27 -- The Westchester County Golf Association's mixed-four-somes title was won today by Connie Edgar, 20-year-old Hudson River Country Club player, and Paul Godridge of Mahopac.

" THE GREAT CHAIR," which was the Tuesday evening attraction on the United States Steel program over the A. B. C. network, missed by a hair being one of the season's most forceful dramatic productions.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Political repercussions from the House of Representatives investigation of tax-free educational and charity foundations broke openly in an Ohio Congressional campaign today.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A new allotment of $45,700,000 designated for defense support for Spain was announced by the Foreign Operations Administration.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- The Council of the Authors League of America gave unanimous approval yesterday to plans for the establishment of a new national union of writers to be known as the American Writers Guild, East and West, Inc.

ALBANY, May 27 (UP) -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that a release signed by a blood donor did not give a blood donor center protection from responsibility for negligence in taking blood. The vote was 6 -- 0, with one judge abstaining.

An indication of "slight progress" between Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Theatres over the terms for a new contract affecting legitimate theatre players was apparent yesterday as negotiations continued.

Three four-story buildings containing nine stores and forty-two apartments at 5010-5016 Twelfth Avenue and 1179 Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn, have been purchased by the Amorr Realty Company, of which Lillian Kensigsberg is president, from the N. S. N. Realty Corporation, headed by Nachman Nachamczyk.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- During the week ended May 26, member bank reserves decreased $69,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

" The Arabian Peninsula," by Richard H. Sanger of the Department of State in Washington, will be published Monday by the Cornell University Press. The book provides historical background, outlines the physical characteristics and describes the recent political, cultural and economic changes in that region.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 27 -- Pakistan is willing to assume a key role in an anti-Soviet bloc provided the Western powers underwrite that role, a responsible Government official said tonight.

THE Fifth Avenue bus line, through a $5,000,000 deal worked out the other day, was restored as a purely local institution, which it was when it started in 1885 with horse-drawn vehicles. The deal freed it from a Chicago affiliation.
GENEVA, May 27 -- If the deadlock on the Korean question continues at the conference on Far Eastern affairs the Allies may try to refer the issue to the United Nations for study.
The weather man looked at what he could see last night of thet Memorial Day week-end, the season's first three-day holiday.

BALBOA, C. Z., May 27 -- Panama Canal officials confirmed today that a consignment of Browning automatic rifles destined for El Salvador had been found aboard the French Line's freighter Wyoming now detained at Cristobal. They stated, however, the weapons were on the manifest. The rifles were loaded at Antwerp.
IN view of the current unstable conditions, any column listing fishing prospects for the week-end should open with the phrase -- "Weather permitting."
Introducing chocolate flavor into cheese cake is the newest wrinkle in the preparation of one of the most popular desserts served in New York homes and restaurants.
Civilian school-crossing guards will be employed by the city, beginning with a pilot project of 100 at Bronx crossings next fall.
Morning gains for steels, oils and aircrafts were reduced or wiped out in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, and the day ended with a net loss.

It is impossible to read accounts of the investigation of the foundations recently begun without experiencing both disgust and anxiety. The disgust may be transient, but the anxiety is deeply rooted. Where does this incredibly persistent campaign for conformity end?
GUATEMALA, May 27 -- Guatemala proposed to neighboring Honduras today that they immediately sign a pact of friendship and nonaggression.

LONDON, May 27 -- A slightly more optimistic interpretation of the course of the Geneva Conference, yesterday's strength in Wall Street and the continued flow of favorable annual company statements stimulated the stock markets here today to continue yesterday's improvement.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 27 -- French B-26 bombers and fighter-bombers are continuing to attack roads east of Dienbienphu in an attempt to slow the eastward movement of Vietminh assault troops toward rebel bases rimmining the Red River delta.

Only one child among the 651,159 participating in the nationwide trials of the Salk polio vacine has contracted paralytic poliomyelitis, it was revealed yesterday. It is not known whether the child, who lives in Michigan, actually had received the vaccine or an ineffective injection.

Four meets records were established as Cardinal Hayes won the team title yesterday in the annual track and field championships of the Bronx-Manhattan-Westchester division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

Dr. Arthur Burns, who obtained a leave of absence from Columbia University to take the post of Chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, returned to the Columbia campus this week to talk about the state of the national economy.

A project aimed at helping new teachers get started, and at reducing the number of young teachers who leave the profession because of unhappy experiences, will be tried in the fall. The Board of Education and Queens College will conduct the experimental plan at Public School 201 in Queens.

Col. Sosthenes Behn, who founded the giant International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in 1920, yesterday relinquished his tight rein on that enterprise. Mr. Behn, who is 73, will continue as chairman of the board and executive committee of the world-wide communications and manufacturing system, which last year had revenues of $362,193,000 and a record net income of $22,377,000.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today reinstated an indictment against Ray Brennan, a reporter for the Chicago Sun Times. He has been accused of posing as a Government officer to get secret Senate Crime Committee testimony.
Mrs. Anna M. Kross, City Commissioner of Correction, was named "Woman of the Year" by the American Association of University Women yesterday afternoon.
Federated Department Stores, Inc., owner of a chain which includes Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus, reported yesterday modest gains in sales and earnings for the thirteen weeks ended May 1.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Republicans are showing a growing apprehension over the outlook for President Eisenhower's legislative program and its correlative, the fall political campaign.

CORYTON, England, May 27 (Reuters) -- Steel-helmeted workers lined up as "honor guards" today to greet Queen Mother Elizabeth at the opening of a $40,000,000 Anglo-American oil refinery here. Work on the refinery was begun in 1950 by the Vacuum Oil Company, which is controlled jointly by the Socony-Vacuum Company of New York and Powell Duffryn, Ltd., of Britain.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 27 -- A sterling around of 35, 40 -- 75 enabled Margaret (Peggy) Mackie of Inwood to win the low gross prize during the one-day tournament of the women's Cross County Golf Association at the North Hempstead Country Club today. Mrs. Mortimer May, Middle Bay, was four strokes back, with 41, 38 -- 79 for second prize.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- "I Am a Camera," the John Van Druten play produced on Broadway in 1951, will be filmed in London this fall.

Paul G. Hoffman, former administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration, and father of seven children, was named Father of the Year yesterday. He was guest of honor at a luncheon given at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the National Father's Day Committee, which also cited twelve others for various achievements.

NEW DELHI, India May 27 (AP) -- Sir Edmund Hillary, conqueror of Mount Everest, was reported today to be ill with pneumonia in a camp 22,500 feet up the ice-bound slopes of Mount Baruntse, in the Himalayas. Penicillin and oxgygen from a near-by United States expedition have been sent to him.
GENEVA, May 27 -- Talks between United States and Chinese Communist officials may take place here regarding Americans being detained in Red China.

The port-wide election to determine what union should represent the longshoremen in collective bargaining with the New York Shipping Association was disappointingly inconclusive. But the old, and now independent, International Longshoremen's Association has a lead of 319 votes. The National Labor Relations Board has hundreds of challenged ballots to dispose of, and the result will not be known for some time.
The third and final round of inoculations in the Salk polio vaccine trials will begin in the city Tuesday.
PARIS, May 27 -- French diplomacy has started leaning toward the idea of recognizing the right of the Indochinese states to secede from the French Union.
The Long Island Transit Authority began yesterday supplying to officials of this city and to Nassau County details of its plan to return the Long Island Raid Road to Pennsylvania Railroad control.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Albert M. Cole, Administrator of the Housing and Home Financing Agency, said today that certain slum clearance operations in New York were being scrutinized by his agency.
ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) -- Hank Sauer hit his fourteenth homer and Ralph Kiner his seventh as the Chicago Cubs beat the St. Louis Cardinals today, 7 to 3.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

The approach of the long weekend limited volume yesterday on most commodities on the New York exchanges. Zinc, however, registered the highest activity of the year and the number of sales almost reached the 1953 high. Prices moved irregularly with wool, zinc, lead, rubber, burlap, hides and potatoes higher; cocoa, coffee, sugar, silk and tin lower, and cottonseed oil, soybean oil and copper mixed.

While families of the dead and injured aboard the aircraft carrier Bennington went into seclusion here yesterday, civilian employes of the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, donated their blood to help those still struggling to live.

Native Dancer will not "go" in the Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park on Monday. The 4-year-old gray colt was withdrawn yesterday from the $50,000 added test of a mile and a quarter because of a foot condition not yet diagnosed.

Testimony of the commanding general at Fort Monmouth, N. J., was invoked yesterday by Roy M. Cohn, chief counsel for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigation of the Signal Corps Center, to dispute earlier Army claims about efforts to track down possible security risks at the post.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- Seventh-Day Adventist leaders reported progress today in a program to make the denomination's 3,000 churches in North America centers for casualty care in a disaster.

The Red Cross representative resigned from the board of directors of the Blood Banks Association of New York State because of Red Cross concern "about the assurance program sponsored by the association that contemplates selling a large percentage of the blood collected." "Nowhere in the brochure of the association is this fact given to the public," the Red Cross added.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Aviation leaders indicated today that they would fight part of a plan to make the nation's airlines operate without Government help.
Following the example set by Governor Dewey on Wednesday, State Controller J. Raymond McGovern charged yesterday that the Wagner Administration was playing politics with the city's fiscal problems.

Ineffective pitching nullified the efforts of the reawakened Dodger attack again yesterday. The Brooks, who had belabored Robin Roberts the night before, knocked out Curt Simmons, Philadelphia's southpaw ace, within five innings. It did no good. The Phillies pounded four Brooklyn pitchers for fourteen hits and won, 11 -- 5, for a sweep of the two-game series at Ebbets Field.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Emperor Haile Selassie, here on a state visit, is laying the groundwork for a loan of $100,000,000 for Ethiopia. Details of the credit will be worked out in conferences of State and Treasury Department officials with Ethiopian officials, it was reported today.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 27 (AP) -- Springfield shattered Holy Cross' eleven-game winning streak today by scoring three runs in the ninth inning to whip the Crusaders, 7 -- 5. It was the first defeat of the season for Holy Cross.
Slacks, as separate pants are known these days, are gaining as promotional items.

CAIRO, May 27 -- Dr. Mustafa Amer, director general of the Egyptian Department of Antiquities, and his chief architect today described the discovery of a 5,000-year-old funeral ship of the Pharaoh Cheops as "beyond all others in importance."
Boot, a Marine Corps canine veteran, wound up in the brig yesterday for his part in the capture of a hold-up suspect Wednesday.

" A Moon for the Misbegotten," due about Oct. 15 at the Bijou, will be one of three bills to be offered by The Ensemble, a new repertory group established by Leo Kerz and Joseph Kramm. The last of Eugene O'Neill's scripts to be produced before the death of the famous author in 1953, the drama had a preliminary hearing on the road under the auspices of the Theatre Guild and was withdrawn in 1947.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, said today in a Senate speech that the Supreme Court had become "indoctrinated and brainwashed by Left-wing pressure groups."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today dared the Eisenhower Administration to indict him for admittedly receiving from Government employes secret information in violation of Presidential directives.

Walter White, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, testified yesterday in behalf of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, one of the top United Nations officials, at a loyalty board hearing at 640 Washington Street.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the resignation of William M. Ellard of Queens as director of the real estate bureau of the Board of Estimate, effective June 15. The Board of Estimate, upon the Mayor's recommendation, elected Percy Gale Jr. of 141 East Fifty-sixth Street, as Mr. Ellard's successor in the $15,000 post.
YONKERS, May 27 -- Creeping steadily toward the Bronx boundary, work on the New York-Buffalo Thruway is within three miles of its destination.
The threat of a new dock strike hung over the harbor last night. It came in the wake of a second inconclusive election to determine union representation for the port's 25,000 longshoremen.

Two loft buildings at 661-63-65 Broadway through to Mercer Street have been sold by the Adam Hat Company to Jack Brause, realty operator, who leased back for ten years to the hat concern the 50,000 square feet it uses there. Tankoos Co. were the brokers in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $434,000.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Eisenhower, devotee of a certain other sport, watched Washington tee off on New York today in a game of baseball.

As dusk falls later now there arrives the opportunity for suburbanites to do a number of things after dinner that one could not do earlier in the spring. Wash the car, for example. Mow the lawn or, what is much less fun, weed it; or assist the lady of the house with her gardening. Then there is always the opportunity to spend more of one's time with the children.

NEW DELHI, India, May 27 (UP) -- The control board of the Bakra dam project said today the contracts of some of the approximately forty Americans employed there were being terminated because actual construction of the dam would begin soon.

SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras, May 27 -- The Government commission, here to study and mediate the strikes in the north coast area, submitted to the United Fruit Company today a list of data required from the company to begin the negotiations.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 681,967 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Manhattan's two-year reign as kingpin of the outdoor Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America track and field championships is expected to be menaced today and tomorrow. Many of the East's top powers will be shooting for the crown in the seventy-eighth edition of the meet at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

In the Supreme Court's anti-segregation decision we can be happy that the principle of equality of opportunity has been guaranteed to groups who have doubted their access to the right before. However, to assume that this principle permits the invasion of one's privacy by another, by making associations mandatory, would be a misinterpretation of the principle.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today proclaimed Memorial Day as a day of prayer for lasting peace.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 27 -- Thailand's United Nations delegate said today his country had decided to ask the Security Council to help guard against a spread of the Indochinese war.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- More than sixty bids for Government-owned synthetic rubber plants had been received up to the close of business today. The bids were submitted to the Rubber Producing Facilities Disposal Commission, designated by Congress to get the Government out of the synthetic rubber business.

The Pressed Steel Car Company, Inc, is disposing of its freight car building business with the closing of its last freight car plant at Mt. Vernon, Ill. Until 1949, when the company began its diversification program, freight car business represented 100 per cent of its sales.

Patrolman Edward Giannattasio, on sick leave as a result of bullet wounds suffered in pistol fights with thugs, cornered a sneak thief after a chase on Madison Avenue yesterday and subdued him after a fight.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Roy M. Cohn swore today that the Secretary of the Army and his legal counselor had suggested that the McCarthy investigating subcommittee should turn its inquiries from the Army to the Navy and Air Force.
The advent of summer was never hailed as auspiciously as the Hayden Planetarium plans to greet the season on June 21.
PARIS, May 27 -- Five French citizens were murdered last night by Tunisian bandits. The attacks were carried out on farms in the Le Kef region of northwest Tunisia near the Algerian border.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- French sources here feel that next week may see the turning point in the Geneva negotiations for a settlement in Indochina.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- Members of the Federal Communications Commission clashed here today over the issue of moving telecasting into the ultra high frequency (UHF) broadcast bands.
JACKSON, Miss., May 27 -- Adlai E. Stevenson today moved to strengthen his ties with Mississippi Democrats.

In two successive days, or nights, we have heard three new operas by American composers of variegated sorts. The experience has impressed upon us one indubitable fact, which is, that the way for American composers to learn to write operas is to keep on writing them till they understand some of the special demands and techniques required by this particular form of art.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), May 27 -- A carefully worded resolution of the Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission, issued today, suggested that both sides were trying to head off a new wave of violence on the border.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 27 -- Four thugs shot their way into a fashionable home near Armonk, N. Y., tonight. They terrorized the wife of a toy manufacturer and disarmed the policeman sent to her rescue.

Cautious preliminary evaluations were made yesterday by Egyptologists of reports from Cairo of the find of a wooden-deck ship built for a Pharaoh 5,000 years ago, at the base of the Great Pyramid of Giza.

NEW HAVEN, May 27 -- George Herbert Walker Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., received the Morys Cup tonight as the outtsanding Yale alumnus of the year. The award was made at the annual meeting of the board of governors at Morys, a popular eating and drinking place.
The Transit Authority decided yesterday to seek an injunction against the strike that the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., has threatened to start June 14.

ALBANY, May 27 (AP) -- Another legal battle on whether Robert R. Young's group seeking to unseat the New York Central Railroad management can vote its long-contested block of 800,000 shares raged today behind closed doors.

The Consumers Power Company, one of the largest electric and gas utilities in Michigan, reported yesterday a net income of $25,621,287 for the twelve months ended on April 30. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.98 a common share. It compares with $21,161,338, or $2.62 a share, in the preceding twelve months.

The alleged theft of $217,566 by an employe of the Manhattan State Hospital over a ten-year period was made possible by antiquated accounting methods, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan charged yesterday.
The forty-five-wee kstrike of 1,500 workers against the Hat Corporation of America of Norwalk, Conn., formally ended with the signing of a new three-year contract last night.
Those who own a home and those who hope to own one will find much of interest this week and next at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, 34th Street and Park Avenue.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., May 27 -- Two-year-old Barbara Jackson will be able to undergo skin-grafting operations at Meadow-brook Hospital here beginning Monday, thanks to twenty donors who have offered to help save her life.

A special trial committee of the Board of Higher Education began hearing evidence last night in the cases of three associate professors at Hunter College who were suspended last April as a result of an investigation into alleged subversive influences in the municipal colleges.
New York City's first savings bank merger since 1949 is slated to be completed within the next few weeks.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 27 (AP) -- An Air Force pilot who plays golf on Sundays and a Walker Cup star who plays nearly every afternoon won their matches today to keep the United States in the running in the British amateur tournament.
CHICAGO, May 27 -- Further declines were registered in grain futures today with wheat the weakest.

Station WOR-TV and the Zenith Radio Corporation will begin a series of Phonevision tests over Channel 9 next Monday. Phonevision is a form of subscription television in which a scrambled picture is transmitted by a station and decoded through a special device attached to the receiver.
LONDON, May 27 (Reuters) -- Steadily rising coffee prices in Britain will probably mean a further decline in consumption, the Coffee Information Board said yesterday.

Tom Jackson, a Far Rockaway heavyweight who came into prominence when he knocked out Rex Lane last January, and Charley Norkus, a 25-year-old former marine from Jersey City who has won five in a row, will be the principals in the main ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that some Congressional investigations had been conducted "in such a way as to hold the Congress up to ridicule."
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A seven-page memorandum by a former Communist was depicted today as the original basis for the McCarthy subcommittee's investigation of subversion in the Army.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 27 -- The Most Rev. Edward W. Dargin, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, conferred forty-five degrees -- twenty-one Bachelor of Arts and twenty-four Bachelor of Science -- at annual commencement exercises on the campus of the Roman Catholic College of Our Lady of Good Counsel here this afternoon.

Charlie Dietlin's strong pitching and timely hitting carried Fordham's baseball team to its twelfth victory of the season yesterday, when the Rams downed Manhattan, 4 -- 2, at Coffey Field in the Bronx.
The investor has been the forgotten man of the steel industry and he must be forgotten no longer, Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the National Steel Corporation, warned fellow steel executives yesterday.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., May 27 -- Admiral Robert B. Carney, Chief of Naval Operations, visited the carrier Bennington today, a few hours after a Navy court of inquiry convened to investigate what he termed a "freakish" disaster.

IT was in the year 1845 that the Jew came to Calvary, the county seat of a tobacco-growing district in the Jackson Purchase, which is the tip of Kentucky west of the Tennesse River. All the farmers and their wives and children came into town to look at him, for none of them had ever seen a Jew. They found he looked just like anybody else, but was kinder and more patient than many.

It seems to us that it is time for the New York City Transit Authority and the unions, especially the Transport Workers Union, to sit down together and grapple with their common problems. There is little doubt that the basic difficulty is one of attitude, and there is no doubt that both sides share the blame.
The Navy's top-ranking officer asserted yesterday that the free world faced even "graver" alternatives in Indochina than those that led to the 1950 decision to fight in Korea.
BABYLON, L. I., May 27 -- The $11,000,000 Captree State Parkway Bridge project across Great South Bay to the eastern tip of Jones Beach is scheduled to be opened to traffic on June 12 at 1 P. M.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 27 (UP) -- Don Conrad, the defending champion, swept into the semi-finals of the Southern amateur golf tournament today with two easy victories on the rain-soaked Memphis Country Club golf course.

Honorary degrees will go to Msgr. Frederick G. Hochwalt, director of education for the National Catholic Welfare Council, Washington, and Robert L. Hoguet, former president and chairman of the board of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, New York, at the 103d commencement of Manhattan College June 8.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Discovery in Egypt of a ship described as Cheops' funeral vessel centered attention today on the Chicago Natural History Museum's exhibit of a mortuary boat built for another Pharaoh, who reigned about eight centuries later.

DETROIT, May 27 (AP) -- Detroit's Ned Garver pitched his first victory in almost three weeks today, hurling seven-hit ball for a 7 -- 1 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles, who dropped their seventh straight game in a disastrous road trip.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was very quiet yesterday. Prices moved 5 points lower to 2 points higher than on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The United States has agreed to back Thailand in a move to have the United Nations check on the Communist threat in Southeast Asia.

SURBITON, England, May 27 (UP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., and Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, gained the semi-finals of the Surrey lawn tennis championships today, but the remaining two United States players in the men's division were eliminated.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- William A. Gallagher, a trial attorney in the Department of Justice, made public today written instructions from his superiors directing him to disobey an order of a Federal Court.
MONTREAT, N. C., May 27 -- The retiring Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the United States declared tonight that racial segregation could never be "justified before God."

Four new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Dial M for Murder," a Warner Brothers version in WarnerColor of the Broadway stage success, is at the Paramount. Ray Milland, Grace Kelly and Robert Cumming's are starred.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Both exports and imports gained notably in April, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Under final rules announced today by the Federal Trade Commission, highly flammable fabrics will be banned for shipment in interstate commerce from July 1 on.

LONDON, May 27 -- Sir Winston Churchill predicted today that Britain's struggle to abate world tension would bring her through present perils. Her Government will be hailed as a principal factor in keeping the peace of the world, the Prime Minister said.

The predicted secession of the port's tugboat men from the International Longshoremen's Association is expected to become a reality today. A referendum among the approximately 4,000 members of Local 333, the United Marine Division of the I. L. A., will be finished.
Markets are full of attractive values in picnic foods, in optimistic preparation for a sunny holiday week-end.

Once again we have suffered a shocking peacetime naval disaster in the explosions and fire on the carrier Bennington. These recurrent tragedies are a part of the hazard that is faced by the men who sail our ships and fly our planes. No matter how many precautions are taken, there seems always to be an accident margin and an element of mechanical or human fallibility that takes its toll.

Debutantes of the forthcoming season in New York, including the Misses Barbara Look and Molly Gayley, are aiding in plans for the New York Giants-Boston Red Sox baseball game on the night of June 28 at the Polo Grounds in behalf of the American Red Cross.
A plan for recapitalization of the American Car and Foundry Company was defeated at a special meeting yesterday in Flemington, N. J.

NAPLES, Italy, May 27 -- Europe's first great International Maritime Exhibition was opened here today by Premier Mario Scelba. Twenty-five countries, including the United States, are represented on the huge permanent exhibition grounds in the Campi Flegrei (Flegreian Fields) on the western edge of Naples.

Stanley Clifford Weyman, described by Federal authorities as "a fabulous impostor," was sentenced yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court to eighteen months in the penitentiary. He had pleaded guilty May 12 to cheating a Long Island bank of $5,000 by making false statements to the Federal Housing Administration in a loan application.

KHIRBET JINBA, Jordan, May 27 -- A band of armed men identified by a witness as Israelis raided this village of harvesters' huts a quarter of a mile inside Jordan last night and killed four men with automatic weapons fire.
The following statement outlining the New York City Transit Authority's position in its dispute with the Transport Workers Union, C I. O., was issued yesterday:

PARIS, May 27 (UP) -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., gained the men's singles final in the French international tennis championships today, while Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., reached the title round in women's singles.

BERLIN, May 27 -- The Soviet ballet made its debut before the outside world tonight and proved what many have long suspected: That Russian dancers can make more friends for Moscow than any number of speakers.
The Composers Group of New York City presented its annual concert last evening at Carnegie Recital Hall.

CLEVELAND, May 28 (UP) -- Early Wynn pitched a two-hitter against the Detroit Tigers tonight and the Cleveland Indians stayed in first place in the American League with a 3-0 victory before 15,413 fans. The triumph was Wynn's sixth of the year.
One of the world's largest scheduled airlines has received official permission to make regular commercial flights between the United States and Europe via the North Pole.

MEXICO CITY, May 28 -- A Guatemalan rose before a congress of anti-Communists here today to ask a minute of silence for a countryman who was said to have been murdered to prevent him from attending the meeting.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 28 -- Columbia has bought "Cell 2455 Death Row," the recently published autobiography by Caryl Chessman about the career in crime for which he is awaiting execution in San Quentin Prison.

Without trying to belittle her skill and endurance, Germany's present boom, on the face of it, must appear as a belated justification of American occupation. We should feel rightfully proud that our policy of speedy "economic recovery above everything else" has finally paid off and paid off so well.
A consent judgment terminating the Government's anti-trust suit against the United States Rubber Company and the Dunlop Rubber Company, Ltd., of London, was filed here yesterday in Federal Court.

An insurgent group of Queens district leaders met quietly last night at the home of a Forest Hills attorney in what was apparently a snowballing move to oust the Queens County Democratic leader, James A. Roe.

PARIS, May 28 -- Emile Zatopek, the Czech distance runner, who was in Brussels tonight en route here, was refused a visa because of an insult he has directed at Paris, the French Foreign Ministry said.

A man of Gordon R. Clapp's managerial talents doesn't remain "at liberty" for long. After being with the Tennessee Valley Authority a score of years and chairman since 1946, Mr. Clapp involuntarily retired from that Government agency at the end of his term on May 18.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Roy M. Cohn testified today that he and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy held Army Counselor John G. Adams "directly responsible'' for an honorable discharge given Maj. Irving Peress, Army dentist described by Mr. Cohn as a "Communist.''

The regional Red Cross Blood Program received 782 pints of blood Thursday. On Thursday employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Western Electric Company ended a three-day donation at 195 Broadway, totaling 493 pints.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture has reopened a program under which it will pay subsidies, if necessary, to encourage private construction of more commercial storage facilities to handle the nation's mounting grain surplus.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 28 (AP) -- A top-level shakeup in the management of the Connecticut Company, bus operating subsidiary of the New Haven Railroad, was disclosed today.
Patricia Brown, a 17-year-old senior at Girls High School in Brooklyn, was honored yesterday at the school's music assembly for outstanding scholarship and leadership.

DALLAS, May 28 -- Fortunately, Tennessee Williams' "The Purification" and Jean Giraudoux' "The Apollo of Bellac" harmonize and complement each other perfectly. They are poetic improvisations by gifted men of letters.
GUATEMALA, May 28 -- The Guatemalan Government is prepared to negotiate directly with the United Fruit Company to reach an amicable basis for the company's future operations in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board took note today of the plight of a group of Lebanese pilgrims stranded in New York and approved special air passage to take them to Beirut next Monday.

DOVER, Del., May 28 (AP) -- A slate of nine incumbent directors polled some 60 per cent of Great American Industries, Inc., stockholder votes today to retain control. The vote was reported as about 600,000 for management and 400,000 for the opposition ticket.
The city was urged yesterday to let its struggling entertainment industry alone as far as taxes go.

GULLANE, Scotland, May 28 (UP) -- Bill Campbell, a 31-year-old insurance agent from Huntington, W. Va., today upset Joe Carr of Ireland, the defending champion, 3 and 2, to gain the final round of the British amateur golf tournament.

MEXICO CITY, May 28 -- With great fanfare the Mexican Government announced today that it had completed plans to ship 2,000 tons of wheat from the dry plains of Sonora in the north to the jungle state of Yucatan.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 28 (AP) -- The Big Ten today devised a method of breaking a tie vote in the selection of a Conference Rose Bowl representative and arranged 1957 and 1958 Conference football schedules.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- On an adjusted basis, manufacturers' inventories dropped $500,000,000 while their sales rose $300,000,000 in April from the March levels, the Office of Business Economics reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -The Senate Banking and Currency Committee unanimously approved an Administration-backed "scandal-proof" housing bill today. There were signs that a threatened Southern Democratic revolt against public housing might not materialize.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- An Administration spokesman indicated today that the Government was now ready to stay in "the tin business" despite a previous decision to abandon it next July 1.

In The Times of May 4 L. C. Johanson speaks of communism as "a tangible and terrifying fact against which we have no protection except from the Congressional investigating committee." One could believe from this that the Army, Navy, Air Force and F. B. I. had all vanished; that America faced immediate destruction with Senator McCarthy as its only shield.

Senator Mundt, the acting chairman, opened the hearing at 10:14, and Ray H. Jenkins, special inquiry counsel to the subcommittee, resumed the direct examination of Roy M. Cohn, the subcommittee's chief counsel under the chairmanship of Senator McCarthy.]

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Following is a translation the text of the address by Emperor Haile Selassie I, before a joint session today of the Senate and House of Representatives (the Emperor spoke partly in English and partly in Amharic):

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 28 -- The Wilson Truck Company, one of the South's largest over-the-road carriers, will be taken over on Monday by a group of three Nashville business men who announced their purchase of it this week at a reported $1,867,500.

Mountains are that way -- you can never forget them. When you have won and gone far away they'll lure you back with a siren song of remembered exaltation that was found on their inspiring peaks. And when you come back to the treacherous slopes the mountains are still proud and defiant.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (AP) -- Washington scored at will for the first seven innings and piled up enough runs to survive a late rally tonight as the Senators whipped the Philadelphia Athletics, 12 -- 6. Jim Busby, Wayne Terwilliger and Roy Sievers hit homers for the winners. Gus Zernial had two four-baggers for the A's.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and held within a 6-point range. Prices rose 1 to 5 points on the day.

BONN, Germany, May 28 -- The Federal Republic is not yet secure against Communists and ultra-nationalists, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer told the fifth annual congress of the Christian Democratic Union, which convened today in Cologne.
Commencement exercises for 6,800 members of New York University's 1954 graduating class will be held at 10:30 A. M. Wednesday, June 9, on Ohio Field at the University Heights campus in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Roy M. Cohn heatedly denied today that he and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had used any improper means or sought any special favors from the Army in the case of Pvt. G. David Schine.

The winners of three Cutting Traveling Fellowships worth $3,000 each were announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University. They are Dr. John Benjamin Stewart of New York, John Senior of Huntington, L. I., and Power Yung-Chao Chu of Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (UP) -- Sunbury Wire Rope Manufacturing Company of Sunbury, Pa., filed a $7,755,000 triple-damage suit in Federal Court today against nine steel companies, charging they conspired to drive it out of business with "predatory practices."
DANVILLE, Ill., May 28 (AP) -Two Milwaukee milling company officials were fined a total of $6,500 in United States District Court today for contempt.

The Giants really mean business. Certain it is they weren't fooling last night as, amid the roars of 38,758, they crushed the Dodgers, 17 to 6, in the opener of the big week-end series at the Polo Grounds.
LONDON, May 28 -- The Soviet Union asked the British Government tonight to shut down an organization in this country run by anti-Communist Russian emigres.

GENEVA, May 28 -- The United States declared today that the fundamental issue in the Korean question was the supervision of elections by the United Nations. Five of the members of the organization supported the United States.

NEW DELHI, May 27 -- The economic stringency has led to widespread criticism of the high salaries paid to United States engineers and other experts employed by the Government on major construction projects.
DETROIT, May 28 (AP) - An automobile organization prepared today to shift principal operations from its traditional Detroit location to Milwaukee and Kenosha, Wis.

HAVANA, May 28 -- President Fulgencio Batista and the Cabinet ordered the dismissal today of all Communists employed by the Government, the provinces, municipalities, autonomous organizations and public service enterprises.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The United States today cleared the French merchant ship Wyoming of suspected violation of Federal customs regulations and freed her for passage through the Panama Canal.

Virginia C. Gildersleeve, who for thirty-six years was Dean of Barnard College, is completing her autobiography. Macmillan will issue it in the fall under the title "Many a Good Crusade." Dr. Gildersleeve begins her book with a period piece on growing up in the New York City of the Victorian age and presents a panorama of history since then as she interprets it.

OTTAWA, May 28 -- Support for the principle of collective security arrangements under the United Nations Charter anywhere peace is threatened was voiced today by Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister for External Affairs.

Mayor Wagner and Hulan F. Jack, Manhattan Borough President, cut a multicolored ribbon at 1 P. M. yesterday, officially opening the South Street Elevated Highway which links the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive with the Battery Park Underpass.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Eisenhower Administration challenged today Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's invitation to Federal employes to pass him classified information regardles of security regulations.

MILWAUKEE, Saturday, May 29 (AP) -- Johnny Logan drilled a single, his third straight hit, into left field in the twelfth inning early today to send Jim Pendleton home from third base and give Milwaukee a 3-2 victory over St. Louis.

DURBAN, South Africa, May 28 -- Dr. D. L. Smit, former Secretary for Negro Affairs, today charged Dr. H. F. Verwoerd, the Minister of Native Affairs, with endeavoring to set up a black empire under his dictatorship.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Operations Administration Director, agreed today to appoint a labor union leader as head of the F. O. A.'s labor office.

ANNAPOLIS, May 28 (UP) -- Former Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat of Maryland, said today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had failed to back up his 1950 charges that forty State Department employes were "very bad security risks."

The Southern Pacific Transportation System and its affiliated companies showed sharp declines in gross revenues and net income in April and the first four months of this year, compared with the corresponding periods a year ago.

Four dancers, the first graduates of the Juilliard School's 3-year-old Department of Dance were among the 11 young musicians who received diplomas and degrees yesterday afternoon at the school's forty-ninth commencement.

After twenty-four years in the Marine Corps, M/Sgt. John R. Thek, first sergeant for recruiting Marines in the metropolitan area, re-enlisted yesterday for six years. Maj. Lawrence Snoddy Jr., officer in charge of Marine recruiting here, swore in the noncommissioned officer at a ceremony at 346 Broadway.

This community, shocked by the rowdy conduct and property damage done by high school youngsters May 20 on uptown I. R. T. subway trains and stations, must feel satisfaction with the offer of restitution voted by the student body of the High School of Commerce.
The appointment of Gordon R. Clapp, former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, as a Deputy City Administrator was announced yesterday by City Administrator Luther H. Gulick.
CAIRO, May 28 -- Kamal el Malakh, discoverer of the solar funerary bark at the Great Pyramid built by the Pharoah Cheops, explained tonight the evidence that convinced him the ship was Cheops'.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

FORT WORTH, May 28 (AP) -- Young Peter Thomson, the methodical Australian, rallied with a one-under-par 34 on the back nine today to retain his lead in the $25,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament with 137 at the 36-hole mark.

The safety of EQ-53, a product developed by the United States Department of Agriculture for mothproofing washable woolens, has been affirmed by Dr. Wayland J. Hayes, chief of the toxicology section of the Public Health Service.

GUATEMALA, May 28 -- The temporary retirement of Jose Manuel Fortuny as Secretary General of the Guatemalan Labor [Communist] party was announced today by the party's Central Commitee. Senor Fortuny was said to be ill. Bernardo Alvarado Monzon, secretary of the Central Committee, was named to replace him temporarily.

A FRIEND of mine who was taking the sun and the curative liquids known as planter's punches in the Bahamas last winter said he dived off a springboard one day and met five authors writing books about underseas adventure on the ocean floor.
For the first time in the history of commercial aviation, a man was arrested yesterday and charged with a theft in the air over the high seas.

Two aspects of the defense of Southeast Asia are coming sharply into the news at the same time. They are the familiar pair, the political and the military. They overlap and interlock. Each move in either field is influenced by what is proposed, possible or done in the other.

ROME, May 28 -- Rome is overflowing with pilgrims today. Tomorrow Pope Pius X will be canonized. Born Giuseppe Sarto, he was a modest priest who became the patriarch of Venice and later the supreme Pontiff.

Retirement of several large issues of public utility securities lifted the total of bonds called in May for payment before maturity to $92,365,000, the largest amount for any month since January, 1953, and the biggest for a May since 1950.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Favorable weather inspired considerable selling of feed grains today, both corn and oats showing substantial declines. Wheat, although affected by the promising crop reports, had considerable support, and at times showed fair recoveries.

Hyman Harvey Klein, former Baltimore liquor dealer named with eight others in a $16,400,000 tax evasion indictment, was held in $50,000 bail yesterday in Federal Court. Klein, whose tax difficulties were investigated in 1952 by a House subcommittee, pleaded not guilty.

A group of twenty-one German exchange students received certificates of achievement yesterday from Brother Augustine Philip, president of Manhattan College. The informal graduation ceremony marked the completion of a special one-year course in Industrial Relations.

VIENNA, May 28 (AP) -- Charles W. Yost, Acting United States High Commissioner in Austria, charged the Soviet Union today with threatening to destroy Austrian freedom in violation of Big Four agreements.
A proposal that the United States reduce tariff barriers for nations that restrict to a minimum their trade with Communist countries was made yesterday by an authority on international commerce.

That pre-school children are better off at home than they would be in pre-kindergarten classes in public schools is the consensus of two-thirds of the nation's school administrators, according to a survey by The Nation's Schools, a monthly education magazine.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Eisenhower will discuss the international implications of Columbia University's bicentennial in his address in New York on Monday night.
Transactions on the New York Stock Exchange in May, while slightly smaller than those in April, were the largest for a corresponding month since 1948.

In the issue of May 23 under the caption "Eastern Pakistan Desires Freedom" your newspaper published your Karachi correspondent's interview with the Hon. A. K. Faziul Huq, Chief Minister of East Pakistan. When the contents of this report became available in Karachi Mr. Huq issued the following statement disowning the remarks attributed to him:

HANOI, Vietnam, May 28 -- Gen. Rene Cogny, commander of the French Union ground forces in North Vietnam, declared today he now "envisaged the future with optimism" in the Vietminh-infiltrated Red River delta. He said his optimism was based on the arrival of reinforcements in North Vietnam and on the promise of more reinforcements in the "near future."

The agreement between the city and the newly formed 69th St., Brooklyn Ferry Corporation was formalized yesterday afternoon in the offices of Marine and Aviation Commissioner Vincent A. G. O'Connor. The Commissioner signed for the city and Harry C. Shanks, president, for the operating corporation.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 28 -- A distance yacht race, a small-scale preview of the Newport-to-Bermuda event to be held next month, began from this port today. The contest was the ninth and biggest of the Storm Trysail Club, begun in the early evening with an assist from the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 28 (UP) -- Five second-string Communists were convicted here late today of charges of having conspired to teach the violent overthrow of the Government.
Opposing sides in the city's transit crisis were invited yesterday by Mayor Wagner to meet with him Tuesday at City Hall.
GENEVA, May 28 -- The United States Government has agreed to give a substantial contribution to the refugee emergency fund of the United Nations.
The Waterfront Commission and representatives of the New York Shipping Association met yesterday afternoon in the first of a series of sessions on the commission's proposed budget for 1954-55.

Stocks wavered through most of yesterday under the triple influence of merger rumors, dividend increases or reductions, and the normal pre-holiday desire to reduce commitments. But prices steadied in the final thirty minutes and closed the day with a moderate gain.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 28 -- Scotch Spencer, a 6-year-old bay gelding by Scotland, owned by Donna Lee Owen of Omaha, Neb., and driven by Neal Houslet, won by a head from Adio Abe in the $25,400 Roosevelt Special No. 1 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 28 -- Jordan withdrew today from discussions on Palestine in the United Nations Security Council.
The Hurricane that was thought to have died out in Brooklyn on April 26 came back with full force in Madison Square Garden last night.
Highways in the metropolitan area were jammed yesterday as the vanguard of nearly a million families left the city by automobile to spend the three-day Memorial Day week-end elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -The Federal Trade Commission announced today that eight major ice cream manufacturers and fifty-five of their subsidiaries had denied charges of using unfair methods of competition to divert business from other producers.
The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., has revoked the charter of a Newark local whose funds allegedly were used for the purchase of two Cadillacs for the local's president.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- James R. Landis, 29 years old, was sentenced to three to nine years in jail and was fined $10,000 today for the $160,000 New Year's theft from the Bureau of Printing and Engraving. Four others were also sentenced. All had pleaded guilty.

The post of secretary of the division of evangelism of the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. will be filled on Sept. 1 by the Rev. Dr. Charles Bradley Templeton, it has been announced by the Rev. Dr. Hermann N. Morse, general secretary of the board.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- If a fisherman uses an instrument patented this week, he can find the exact spot where they were biting so well last time. Claud A. Herrick of Rochester, N. Y., says his invention can be employed by anyone, even without knowledge of navigation or mathematics.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 28 (AP) -- Michigan State made a strong qualifying move today to threaten Illinois' title defense in tomorrow's finals of the fifty-fourth Big Ten outdoor track and field meet.

MIAMI, May 28 (UP) -- Former Cuban President Carlos Hevia was arrested today on a charge of seeking to smuggle guns into his homeland. Another former Cuban President was indicted on similar charges less than six months ago.
NAPLES, Italy, May 27 -- A necropolis, or ancient cemetery, was discovered two days ago during continuing excavations of Pompeii.

PITTSBURGH, May 28 (UP) -- Murry Dickson allowed only four singles tonight as he pitched the Phils to a 4-0 victory over his former Pittsburgh Pirate teammates in a game called after six innings because of rain.

The WOR radio and television stations withdrew yesterday the contract offer that had been made in negotiations with the musicians' union. The union immediately charged WOR with "deliberate bad faith."
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., May 28 (AP) -- Seven suspended General Electric Company employes were discharged automatically today under provisions of its loyalty policy.
The use of the recent Supreme Court decision regarding de-segregation in education as a public relations weapon against current Communist criticism of the United States is a dangerous device.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 28 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche received a public and unanimous loyalty clearance today from a United States investigating board.
LONDON, May 28 -- The stock -- markets here were dull today, and prices fell slightly during the morning on fears that the railway strike would spread. However, the close was steady.
Some object lessons on how downtown shopping areas can be rehabilitated are given in a report by a National Retail Dry Goods Association committee.

Penn State's aspirations for its first Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America track and field title since 1942 took on a bright hue yesterday as the seventy-eighth edition of the classic began at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

Financial and commodity futures markets throughout the United States will be closed on Monday for the observance of Memorial Day. Canadian and European markets, however, will be open for business as usual.

The threat of an actors' strike on Broadway lessened yesterday as Actors Equity Association agreed to an extension of negotiating time. The union's current two-year contract with the League of New York Theatres expires next Monday at midnight.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt's cigar today brought Senators Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, into agreement on at least one issue at the Army-McCarthy hearings:

Today's new film is "The Mistress," a Russian-made color adaptation of a play by Maxim Gorky featuring V. Pannayeva, M. Zharov, N. Shamin and V. Evstratova, at the Stanley Theatre. The Artkino release was produced at the Maxim Gorky Film Studio, Moscow, and directed by L. Lukov. There are English titles.

ATLANTA, May 28 (UP) -- Georgia honored one of its leading figures of the Civil War today and Gov. Herman Talmadge warned that the "ills of Reconstruction" that followed that struggle "may again be inflicted" upon the South.

LONDON, May 28 -- Delegates of locomotive engineers and firemen on strike on the western region of the railway system recommended tonight a return to work from midnight tomorrow. By then the unofficial strike over new schedules requiring train crews to spend nights away from home will have lasted thirteen days.

PRINCETON, May 28 -- Twenty-six acres of flat pasture just northeast of this historic community are fast being transformed into New Jersey's newest and most modern shopping center. Massive but compact, the center is being built at a cost of nearly $6,000,000 and is slated to open officially Aug. 14. A preview opening is planned next Thursday.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The State Department reported today that about 120 alien Chinese students in this country had been refused permission to leave the United States since June, 1951.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 28 -- The demand among Seventh-Day Adventists for church - operated schools is so great that if financial support and teachers were available 2,000 new schools could be opened this fall.

State parks on Long Island, along the Palisades, at Bear Mountain and elsewhere will be the destination of a good portion of the passenger cars on the road this holiday week-end. The chief attraction at these places for outdoor cookery enthusiasts are the fireplaces and braziers over which they can go into action with skewer and skillet.
BOSTON, May 28 -- Midnight was only a few minutes away when the Yankees wrapped up a 10-9 victory over the Boston Red Sox before 31,034 fans at Fenway Park tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Haile Selassie I, Emperor of Ethiopia, told Congress today that the free nations, large and small, must together meet aggression anywhere, whatever the cost.
A Times Square chestnut peddler, who came here from Iraq in 1947 to study medicine, was jailed yesterday because he ignored eighteen summonses for hawking his wares without a license.
A number of projects of interest to theatregoers were discussed Thursday in the Alvin Theatre at the annual meeting of the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 28 (Reuters) -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, paid a courtesy call today on the Swiss Federal Government. He came here from Geneva where he has been attending the Far East Conference.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian sector), May 28 -- The Jordanian frontier village of Nazlet Eisa in Samaria was hit by small arms and mortar fire from Israel for five hours today, and five inhabitants were wounded, according to an Arab Legion spokesman here.
Ten thousand bees, give or take a few, apparently seceded from Westchester County yesterday morning and settled on a poplar tree in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx.

The settlement of the forty-five-week strike of 1,500 employes of the Hat Corporation of America at Norwalk, Conn., provides welcome evidence of the progress that has been made in American labor relations since the famous Danbury hatters' strike a half-century ago.

The city's new South Shore Incinerator, scheduled to start serving a forty-square-mile area in Brooklyn and Queens on July 15, was inspected yesterday by the Commissioners of Sanitation and Public Works.
CLEVELAND, May 28 (AP) -- Passenger ship service between Cleveland and Detroit may be resumed next season after a lapse of four years.
GENEVA, May 28 -- A technical committee met today to see common points in the proposals on Indochina at the conference on Far Eastern affairs.

Tests with single-celled eggs from sea animals suggest that hydrocortisone and perhaps other adrenal steroids act directly upon single cells and not upon units of organized cells, it was reported here yesterday.
Rear Admiral Anibal O. Olivieri, Argentina's Secretary of the Navy, arrived here yesterday for a one-month official visit to the United States.

PARIS, May 28 (UP) -- The United States kept its hopes today of winning or sharing all major titles in the French tennis championships. Its doubles team of Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas gained the final round and Maureen Connolly, teamed with an Australian, advanced to the final of the women's doubles.
A "revolving scholarship fund" and special scholarships will be available to students at the Berkshire Music Center, Tanglewood, Mass., when the school opens its six-week summer session on July 5.
A gunman robbed a secretary of a $900 payroll in a Fifth Avenue elevator yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Saturday, May 29 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox climbed to within nine percentage points of the league-leading Cleveland Indians today by topping the Baltimore Orioles in a twilight-night bill, 11 -- 6 and 14 -- 8.
MINEOLA, L. I., May 28 -- A new fight between Democrats and Republicans broke out in Nassau County today over a plan for the future of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road.
John L. Lewis won a foothold yesterday in the Port of New York.

Prices of bonds traded on the New York Stock Exchange climbed in April to the highest average month-end level since January, 1951, the Exchange reported yesterday. The April 30 average price was $101, against $100.64 at the end of March and $101.18 on Jan. 31, 1951.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The State Department announced today that a five-nation military survey of the Far East would begin here next Thursday.

PARIS, May 28 -- To facilitate the formation of a French reserve for Indochina, the Cabinet decided today to advance the draft normally starting in November. The conscripts affected will be called beginning in June.

The Perinton, Monroe County, N. Y. Central School District sold yesterday $1,775,000 of bonds due from 1954 to 1983 to Marine Trust Company of Western New York and associates at a bid of 100.449 for bonds bearing interest at 2.6 per cent.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -Short-term borrowing costs of the Treasury have again fallen to a new seven-year low.
Three men were arrested here yesterday and linked by the police to the wave of week-end robberies at fashionable homes in Westchester County.

Ray Murphy, national commander of the American Legion in 1935, warned yesterday of extensive Communist infiltration in the United States. He added that "too few of our leaders have an adequate knowledge or conception of the tactics and strategy of communism in America today.

A TREND that may be described as "dangerous thinking" is becoming manifest among certain fly fishermen in this area, and unless it is curbed without delay a number of professional flytiers will be forced to abandon vintage wines and fine Scotches in favor of the less expensive beers.

SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, May 29 (AP) -- Australians started voting today in what was expected would be a tight election to decide which party will run the national Government for the next three years.
W. W. Keen Butcher has been elected a director of Botany Mills, Inc. Mr. Butcher is a partner in the stock exchange firm of Butcher Sherrerd of Philadelphia.

Auxiliary Bishop Joseph M. Pernicone of the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese will preside at a departure ceremony in the Fordham University chapel tomorrow morning at which mandates will be given to twenty-three white-robed Jesuits who are to be sent to mission posts.

George W. Marsh has been appointed manager of general accounting, George H. Kitendaugh manager of tax accounting and George A. Horch manager of cost accounting for the accounting services division of the General Electric Company.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate Finance Committee sided with the South today in its fight to attract industries from New England and other regions.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Government received today nineteen ships and $4,000,000 in a settlement of civil libel and forfeiture proceedings.
NEW DELHI, India, May 28 -- Peace appears to have settled the once-turbelent cease-fire line separating Indian and Pakistani troops in the disputed state of Kashmir.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 28 -- France warned today that immediate presentation of the Indochinese case to the United Nations might jeopardize a "good possibility" of agreement at Geneva.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Depending upon the outcome of the nine-nation conference on Far Eastern problems in Geneva, President Eisenhower may decide within a week to ask Congress for intervention in Indochina, Senator John F. Kennedy said today.
" Take a table top. Throw oil all over it, add salt and pepper. Rub them in carefully, then scrub them off with an abrasive cleaner."

The rapid transit needs of the New Jersey-New York commuters, for whom nothing constructive has been done for over forty years, is much in the news nowadays. Governor Dewey recently signed a bill providing for the consolidation of the New York and New Jersey rapid transit commissions to study prospective rapid transit needs of the metropolitan area.
RABAT, French Morocco, May 28 -- Mounting anger and anxiety over terrorist assassination of five French settlers in Tunisia Wednesday night were reported today from many places in North Africa.
A repair man for an Astoria, Queens, television service testified yesterday in Long Island City Magistrate's Court that his employer had rendered a bill for $30.50 for replacement of a $2.75 tube.

The Coaching Club American Oaks will be contested at Belmont Park today. The race is the richest in the country for 3-year-old fillies, and if all eight that were listed compete, the gross value will be $62,000, with the winner earning $43,900. Each will carry scale weight of 121 pounds.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, in the fiscal year ended on Feb. 28, attained the highest sales in its history. A moderate gain in earnings was also reported in the annual statement issued yesterday.

Home furnishings designs from Norway, a country heretofore somewhat eclipsed by her Scandinavian neighbors, have come to the fore this spring. The enlarged number of imports from this country was pointed up in an exhibition held earlier this week by the Norwegian Export Council at Norway House, 290 Madison Avenue.
GENEVA, May 27 -- There are few outward signs of friction between the Communist powers at the Far East conference here.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Kirke B. Lawton, commander of the Fort Monmouth Signal Corps installations, whose name has figured in the McCarthy-Army controversy, apparently will retire from active duty this fall in his permanent rank of brigadier general.

CHICAGO, May 28 (UP) -- Art Fowler, 30-year-old rookie, scored his fourth victory of the season today, striking out eight Chicago batters as the Cincinnati Redlegs romped to a 6-to-3 triumph before 7,419 ladies' day fans.

The Consumers Power Company's decision to postpone for the time being its offering of $25,000,000 of new mortgage bonds takes from next week's calendar of new securities issue its only major offering of corporate debt.

DETROIT, May 28 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports today predicted a 6 per cent cut in domestic automobile production in June. The reduction, the agency said, "calls for a daily rate of 23,200 cars against 24,700 in May, 24,700 in April and 22,870 in March."
The first American combination ore-oil carrier, the 20,000 deadweight-ton Hawaiian, has been delivered to her owners, the Ore Transport Company, Inc., here, after conversion at a Japanese shipyard.
KEY WEST, Fla., May 28 -- Crew members of the Swedish freighter Alfhem, which delivered Communist arms to Guatemala, were questioned here today by United States officials.
GENEVA, May 28 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from a speech by Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Under Secretary of State, today before the Geneva Conference on Far Eastern affairs:
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

New financing increased in May as compared with the preceding month and a year ago. Flotations of new bonds were the greatest for a month in twenty-eight years. Stock offerings were the largest for a May since 1946.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 28 -- The Foreign Office has charged that international communism has infiltrated the ranks of strikers on the north coast of Honduras.

MONTREAT, N. C., May 28 -- Most Southern Presbyterians attending the ninety-fourth general assembly of their church here are convinced that on Monday the assembly will approve a plan to merge the three largest Presbyterian bodies in this country.

Commodity prices moved generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Wool, coffee, zinc, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, tin, lead, burlap and rubber were stronger; cocoa, potatoes and copper closed lower, and sugar, silk and hides ended mixed.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices increased four-tenths of 1 per cent during the month ended May 15.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams endorsed last week a proposal for an immediate 15 per cent increase for every member of the department, whose salaries he termed "pitifully inadequate."
