It is a pity that Dr. Ralph Bunche, one of this country's most distinguished public servants, had to go through the ordeal of a special examination before the American Loyalty Board that looks into the records of American citizens employed by the United Nations.

GENEVA -- It is probaby safe to say that, if you want to run a successful hotel, the practice of stationing an armed policeman outside the front door is not the best way to attract customers. Geneva hotel keepers, who are mostly taciturn Swiss from the German-speaking part of the country east of here, have had plenty of opportunity to ponder this proposition since the Far Eastern Conference began.

THE grandaddy of "Pop" concerts in this country is the series in Boston. It began in 1885, only four years after the Boston Symphony Orchestra itself was founded, and it has become a formidable institution in New England.
The Transit Authority was criticized yesterday by one of its members for approving a two-zone fare for Staten Island.

THERE is a place in California which does not appear on any map, and is known as "Upper Dubbing." No country seat, "Upper Dubbing" is simply a large room on the third floor of the Sound Department Building at Columbia Studios -- a room where sound and image meet, are balanced and synchronized.

With Administration tariff-reduction proposals deferred until 1955, further simplification of customs regulations appears to offer the major chance of giving direct encouragement to foreign trade this year.

THE founding of the Lady Sabena Club was announced last week at a luncheon given by Sabena Belgian Airlines. It is the world's first international airlines organization with an exclusively feminine membership.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's prestige is clearly falling, but he must receive at least a measure of credit for achieving certain important results. Among these are the following:
The American Waterways Operators, Inc., the organization that speaks for the towing and barge industry, will mark its tenth anniversary tomorrow.

THE Danes, like most other peoples, didn't find out until later that six million Jews -"more than the whole population of Denmark" -- had been murdered by Hitlerism. But Denmark knew which side she was on the instant the Nazi Occupation began paying special attention to Danes of Jewish faith.

IN her first book, a collection of twelve short stories. Doris Betts, a young North Carolinian, proves herself to be already a sturdy professional writer, a master of the short story form, and a candidate for an important position among those concerned with serious and perceptive reporting in literary form of the Southern small town and Southern people.

IN recent years the history of Civil War history has aroused considerable interest. In 1946 Howard K. Beale published a lengthy essay on "What Historians Have Said About the Causes of the Civil War." Now comes a book devoted largely to the same object.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., May 29 -- Two key officers of the carrier Bennington reported today that they smelled "hydraulic oil" burning during a series of explosions that killed ninety-nine men last Wednesday morning.
PARIS, May 29 -- The Premier of Tunisia, Mohammed Salah M' Zali was fired on this afternoon in an new outbreak of terrorism ascribed to Tunisian nationalists.

The first DeLong steel dock barge to be adapted for offshore oil drilling has gone into service, under lease, for a major oil company in the Gulf of Mexico, Col. L. B. DeLong, president of the DeLong Corporation, announced yesterday.

SEATTLE, May 29 (AP) -- Conference records in the javelin two-mile and high jump were broken today as Southern California's Trojans piled up 70 points to win their fourteenth consecutive Pacific Coast Conference track and field championship.

Last Wednesday 2,500 excited and sometimes noisy shareholders of the New York Central Railroad Company journeyed to Albany to watch the closing rounds of the battle for its control between Robert R. Young and William White.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 29 -- Fifty-three yachts turned out today for the third championship regatta of the season on Long Island Sound.

Among new recordings to be played at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Fortysecond Street, at its concert Wednesday noon to 2 P. M., is "Festival Mass for 53 Voices" by Orazion Benevoli, which was first sung at the consecration of the Salzburg Cathedral in 1628.
The ever-diminishing prospect of a European Defense Community and the crisis in Southeast Asia have revived discussion in Washington and overseas concerning an "American foreign legion."

MISTY-FLOWERED plants are to border what lace is to a dress; each lends its special quality of contrast and gaiety to the ensemble. And often the delicate flowers add the finishing touches to the planting scheme.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., May 29 -- Wes Santee, Kansas University's great distance runner, set an American outdoor mile record of 4:01.3 tonight as he made an all-out effort to break the four-minute barrier in the Missouri Valley Amateur Athletic Union track meet.

Romeyn Berry gives an amusing and human account of college class reunions in his "Class of 'Naughty-4' Comes Back to the Campus" (May 16). Mr. Berry points out at the very start, and with justice, that one peculiar contribution of America to college education has been the class reunion.

A PHOTOGRAPH of George Eastman taken in 1921, when he was 67, is being used in the design of the 3c stamp which will be issued on July 12 at Rochester, N. Y., to commemorate the centenary of the birth of the inventor and philanthropist.
THE 1954 Maggio Musicale Fiorentino opened with two revivals: Gaspare Spontini's "Agnese von Hohenstaufen" and Weber's "Euryanthe."

Most fall ready-to-wear lines are being shown and many buyers are expected in the market this week and next to cover needs for the coming season. Early orders are expected to be large as both manufacturers and retailers are optimistic, according to resident buying offices.

A NEW, independent film company, Sikor Productions, currently is turning out what is reportedly the first feature to be filmed and processed in its entirety in Israel. This is "Hill 24 Doesn't Answer," an English-language drama described as dealing with the stories of four soldiers, including a girl, who fell during the last moments of the Israeli battle for liberation.

GULLANE, Scotland, May 29 -Doug Bachli, a game little tavern-keeper from Rosebud, Australia, who neither drinks, smokes nor succumbs to pressure on the golf links, won the British Amateur championship today by rallying to edge Bill Campbell of Huntington, W. Va., 2 and 1.

Joint planning between one of America's leading universities and the community in which it is located has produced results of advantage to both organizations and citizens. WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -An announcement by Scandinavian Airlines System that it had been granted a Polar route between the United States and Europe drew a sharp denial from the civil aeronautics board today.
The counting of the New York Central Railroad proxies cast at last Wednesday's annual meeting of stockholders is continuing this holiday week-end.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 (AP) -- Three former winners and four former A. A. A. national racing champions (Johnnie Parsons is both) will chase a driver who has never won either title in the thirty-eighth annual 500-mile auto race Monday at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

LOS ANGELES -- A $3,000,000 development combining what is described as the world's most modern aquarium and a tourist and recreation center will open in July on the Palos Verdes peninsula, thirty miles south of Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Army-McCarthy hearings are indisputably fragmenting the Republican party in Congress, whether or not these divisions will long persist or will turn out to be as dangerous as they now appear.
TRENTON, N. J., May 29 (AP) -- Unseeded Jack Shapiro of Queens College provided the only upset today as the third annual Rider College invitation singles tennis tournament got under way.

SUMMER activity in museums and galleries far from Fiftyseventh Street and Greenwich Village promises to be lively and varied. One most ambitious and comprehensive undertaking will be the Boston Arts Festival to be held outdoors in the Boston Public Gardens from June 6 through June 20.

MOST of the recent deepsea books fall into a single category. They are accounts, more or less informative, dealing with the personal sensations of the individuals involved, with the complexities of their deep-sea apparatus and with a standard set of anecdotes and adventures.

SEATTLE'S historic anti-Chinese riots, labor troubles and catastrophic fire help whip up excitement in this pyrotechnic romance of the Eighteen Eighties. The riots are the special concern of Seattle's prettiest 18-year-old, Cassy Scandal, who is anxious to protect her family's Chinese servant from violence and expulsion.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 29 -- The Liberal and Country party Government led by Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies has been returned to office for three more years with a reduced majority as a result of today's elections. It was the closest race in Australia's history.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 16 -- Paraguay will again become one of the Pan-American republics under military rule in August. Gen. Alfredo Stroessner is scheduled to be elected President on the unopposed Colorado party slate.
Emperor Haile Selassie I of Ethiopia returned yesterday to this city after a three-day trip to Washington on which he addressed Congress and was the guest of President Eisenhower.
Seven more men were arrested in this area yesterday as Communist party leaders charged with conspiring to advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.
BOSTON, May 29 -- A sharp denunciation of "hate-mongers," "fear-mongers," "super-patriots" and "McCarthyism" featured a report tonight to District Lodge No. 1 of B'nai B'rith.

The outdoor living room of terrace or garden is receiving unusual attention this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, where a large variety of furnishings and decorations will be auctioned on Friday.

Your critic's comments about Mira Rostova's performance in "The Sea Gull" were largely concerned with the fact that her English pronunciation made her words unintelligible. While there is no gainsaying this observation, especially while one is becoming accustomed to hearing her speak at the outset of the play, it is insufficient ground upon which to condemn a performance.

More than 3,000 top executives of the nation's $25,000,000,000 electric power and light industry are scheduled to gather tomorrow at Atlantic City for their annual convention. The meeting, under the auspices of the Edison Electric Institute, will culminate a year of continued progress by one of the country's largest investor-owned enterprises.

THE lucky anglers who have caught their fish now wonder how to dispose of them. For this is that pleasant season when millions of Americans seek stream and shore with rod and line. Though many fishermen may not at first agree, we hold the preparation of fish can be as much fun as their pursuit.

UNICEF -- the United Nations Children's Fund -- is assisting 213 programs in seventy-eight countries and territories with nutrition projects, malaria and tuberculosis control, and general maternal and child welfare; and the wonder of UNICEF has always been that it has accomplished so much on so little.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 29 -- Information Minister F. L. Tobing declared today that a nonaggression pact had its place in the "cold war" atmosphere of the world today. He added, however, that the Indonesian Government had not yet taken any step toward negotiation of such a pact.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 29 -Paced by double victories by Willie Williams, a sprinter, and Willard Thomson, a hurdler, Illinois took seven events to capture its fourth straight Big Ten outdoor track and field title today.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Summer vacation starts for house plants whenever it is convenient to move them outdoors. A location that offers protection from full sun and wind is best. Sink pots up to their rims in the ground but place an inch of pebbles underneath to prevent roots from anchoring the plants. Water when necessary during summer.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- With every prospect of success, President Eisenhower asked Congress early this year to enact a housing program continuing most existing Federal aids but inviting a broader participation by private enterprise.

IT is impossible to attempt an informed estimate of the compositions of Charles Edward Ives, who died on May 19 at 79. COVE NECK, L. I. -- The legend of Theodore Roosevelt has brought more than 80,000 visitors to Sagamore Hill, his home and summer White House, since it was dedicated last June 14. The total will be over 100,000 by midsummer, according to Mrs. Harold Kraft, curator of the gabled house overlooking Oyster Bay Harbor here.

This is the least festive of all our holidays. It honors and commemorates those who have died for their country. We assemble to pay our tribute of respect and esteem. The Administration, according to Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey, has cut planned expenditures for the coming year an additional $5 billions beyond the $7 billion reduction for the current year.

PARIS, May 29 -- The French Socialist party began today two days of debate of capital importance for the future of the proposed European Defense Community.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A widely traveled two-man Senate subcommittee recommended today "a thorough Congressional reappraisal" of the financial aid given for years by the United States to friendly foreign nations.

DALLAS, May 29 -- Spring clearances and heavy summer promotions coupled with warm clear weather this week boosted department store sales over preceding weeks and possibly over the same week last year, merchants reported.

THE National Broadcasting Company's color television mobile unit is going to have an extremely busy summer. Its schedule calls for coverage of scenes and events in many Eastern and Midwestern cities, starting with a pick-up in Chicago and visits, on successive weeks, to Milwaukee, St. Louis, Columbus, Ohio; Cleveland, Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Boston and New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29 -- The delegation of Israel confirmed today that it intends to press for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council next week, in which to resume the continuing dispute with Jordan over Palestine border incidents.

ROME, May 29 -- Giuseppe Sarto, Pope Pius X, was canonized today in one of the most grandiose ceremonies in the history of the Roman Catholic Church. The ancient ritual was held outside St. Peter's Basilica, permitting hundreds of thousands of persons to take part under the blue skies.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -West Coast dock workers and shipowners took steps late yesterday looking to agreement on a common expiration date for longshore contracts on a national basis.

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 29 -Curly Joe, a 4-year-old jumper owned by Lawrence R. Troiano, won the Adjacent Hunts Cup today. The event was a hurdle test of about two miles, and was one of the features of the annual Adjacent Hunts race meeting at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

A comprehensive evaluation of the business-education program in New York City high schools is contained in a survey just released by the New York City Board of Education. Entitled "Business Education in Our High Schools," the 220-page publication is the final report on a twoyear study carried on jointly by personnel from the city school system and the New York State Education Department.

The Telefunken engineers, whose work on old-style 78 rpm disks was technically outstanding, seem to have lost no time in mastering the art of LP.

LOS ANGELES, May 29 -- California's most bewildering primary contest in years is entering its final week with Republicans campaigning as Democrats and the Independent Progressive party running candidates labeled as Republicans.

PARIS, May 29 -- Marc Jacquet, Under Secretary for the Indochina States, was reported to have handed in his resignation today, partly because of differences with Foreign Minister Georges Bidault on policy.

The Board of Higher Education said yesterday that 13,500 students were expected to take summer courses at the city's four municipal colleges in six and eight-week sessions from June 11 to Aug. 20.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -- The Democratic National Chairman, Stephen A. Mitchell, declared tonight that Republicans were using "Communist smear techniques" against Democrats in the California Senatorial campaign, even though President Eisenhower had frowned on such tactics.

BONN, Germany, May 29 -- The fifth annual convention of the Christian Democratic Union party agreed today that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer must pursue his policy of Western European integration. Day by day sales in New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were down slightly but the stores were comparing a five-day week this year with the four-day Memorial Day week a year ago. PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -United States intervention in Indochina will be interpreted by most Asians as supporting a "corrupt and inefficient French colonialism," Norman Thomas said here tonight.

Dr. Lionel Farber of the University of California's Medical Center, San Francisco, has devised a laboratory "nose" that sniffs such foods as fish, vegetables, fruit, cheese, butter, coffee, spices and pepper, and grades them according to smell. The instrument might also be perfected to determine when fruit should be picked for canning and when for eating.

TOM CORWIN, the Ohio politician, had Salmon Portland Chase in mind when he observed: "If you would succeed in life you must be solemn, solemn as an ass. MILWAUKEE, May 29 (UP) -The St. Louis Cardinals stopped the Milwaukee Braves' winning streak at ten tonight with a 12-7, seventeen-hit victory before a record County Stadium crowd of 40,001.

Which, lest anyone think this department isn't sticking to its prime business, means that Mr. and Mrs. Goetz have settled on one of the two ideas they've been tossing around and all is proceeding smoothly.

NEW HAVEN, May 29 -- Yale University will confer 2,000 bachelor's, professional and graduate degrees on June 7. The president, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, said today this would be 200 more degrees than were given a year ago.

THE rose has been the favorite flower of millions of persons for centuries, and can be found growing in every country on earth. Men have devoted their life's work to growing, developing and improving the rose, and thousands of acres, both in the open fields and under glass, are required to meet the ever-growing demand for this universal favorite in its old as well as its new forms.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -Seventeen members of graduating law classes of the country have been selected for legal positions in the Department of Justice.

As recently as a month ago it had seemed that the Hurricane had swept out to sea, its strength so spent that it no longer presented a danger to small craft or big craft. Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, the cyclonic young heavyweight, had bounced off a cold front, the wily Jimmy Slade, and reduced to a zephyr.

BALTIMORE, May 29 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox dealt the Baltimore Orioles their tenth straight defeat tonight by thumping the Birds, 11 -- 4, before 11,750 spectators. It was Chicago's eighth victory in a row.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Two prominent Republicans spoke out today against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's appeal to Federal employes to disregard security orders in giving him information. One of them was Senator William F. Knowland of California, the Majority Leader.

BEYOND the outermost bounds of hard-surfaced fact there is often a boggy zone of lush, romantic conjecture. Willy Ley has already exploited many such glamorous bogs (sea serpents, unicorns, space flight). His latest book of this sort, "Engineers' Dreams," tells about triumphs that engineers think they could accomplish if a friendly angel would only free them from the drag of economics and politics.

The heat of A-bombs and H-bombs may start fires, but the winds they create may also snuff out the flames, according to engineers of the University of California's Los Angeles branch, Among other things, they studied the effect of the bomb on wooded areas around urban targets.

THE sequel to "A Dance for Susie," the book which told so much about first lessons in ballet dancing, is mainly about Coco, the French poodle, and Giselle, the cat. Perhaps a cat, about to become a mother, would pick up a family of mice, one after the other, and carry them safely, like kittens, to the outside world.

CLEVELAND, May 29 -- A heavy volume of building permits and a sharp drop in new unemployment claims highlighted business activity in the Cleveland area. New unemployment claims dipped from 2,233 to 1,939, lowest since last November.

AN East African tribe explains the presence of evil in the world by the reasonable hypothesis that, although God is good, he has, most unfortunately, a half-witted brother who is forever interfering with what he does.

Daniel Defoe's classic tale of Robinson Crusoe, who survived a shipwreck to live 28 barren, lonely years on a wild, uninhabited island, has been brought to the screen in a version filmed largely off the rugged Pacific coast of Mexico with an Irish actor, Dan O'Herlihy, portraying Crusoe.
WILLIAM S. PALEY, chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, last week made a speech that could mark a turning point in broadcasting's evolution.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -Indifference was cited as "the great danger" confronting churches today.

PAWHUSKA, Okla., May 29 (AP) -- The Osage Indians, whom petroleum made wealthy in the fabulous boom of thirty years ago, choose their leaders June 7, with the tribe's oil business a major election topic.

When I saw the picture of Dawn Addams and her husband, Prince Vittorio Massino, in your "Personalities" (May 9), I was puzzled, for I had just recently seen another picture of the couple in another publication.

LONDON, May 29 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, sounded a note of caution today for those who have been predicting that free convertibility, or unrestricted exchange of currencies, was approaching rapidly.

PERHAPS because the setting itself is so hyperbolically beautiful, one is given to exaggeration in Rio. (For instance, a common and credible saying is: "God took seven days to make the world and He spent five of them on Rio.")

UNEMPLOYMENT is still close to 3,500,000 and we are beginning to hear the cry for shorter hours as a way to check any further loss of jobs. Steel workers, for instance, with 200,000 laid off, are reported to favor a six-hour day. Walter Reuther, however, says that a cut in the prevailing forty-hour standard would simply "share the scarcity."

WELL timed for the season and filling a real need for a useful book on the subject, "Photographing Your Flowers" (New York: Greenberg: Publisher. $3.75. Paper edition, $1.95), deserves wide acceptance by amateurs and semi-professionals as well.

THE iris on its uptown campus has long been considered the gem of Columbia University, but it is only this year that the gem has acquired its proper setting. A large greensward with well-foliaged shrubs and trees has been installed on a newly acquired, strategic piece of property.
An attempted double steal by Fordham failed in the ninth inning and the Rams bowed to the Villanova Wildcats, 6 -- 5, at Coffey Field today.

A team of four faculty members from Teachers College of Columbia University will take part in a project to improve teacher training in Afghanistan. The announcement was made yesterday by Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, dean of the college.
Two Brooklyn boys, 15 and 16 years old, admitted yesterday to the police that they had attempted to kidnap the 7-year-old son of an assistant corporation counsel and hold the child for $5 ransom.
Wholesalers and retailers are selling all the coffee they can get despite high prices.

GUATEMALA, May 29 -- For too long there was no planned United States policy, as the word is understood today, for Central America. Governments, mainly dictatorships, came and went and little was asked of them except generous treatment for, and protection of, United States business interests.

A SEVEN-POINT program designed to reduce highway accidents and traffic congestion throughout the country has been offered by Prof. Amos E. Neyhart, administrative head, Institute of Public Safety, Pennsylvania State College.
Through its increased research activities, medical science is making notable advances in its attack on the diseases that kill and disable.

Tachistoscope THE other week we wrote, with hardly any dispatch, about an article in Fortune which asked the question: "Why Don't Businessmen Read Books?" The answer was, with variations and modulations, not enough time.

Sixteen selected officers have been sent overseas to assist in screening the 209,000 persons who are scheduled to enter this country under the Refugee Relief Act of 1953. The sixteen men have an average of twenty years' service in immigration work.

PERHAPS, as your Sunday article captioned "Strictly Big Business" noted, "the ideal of stouter furniture and a happier furniture corporation doesn't cause the blood to run hot." Even so, there is a great deal about "Executive Suite" with which we can feel a sense of identification.

GENEVA, May 29 -- The State Department has not authorized the United States delegation to the Far Eastern conference to discuss with Communist Chinese representatives here the release of Americans held in Communist China.

LONDON, May 29 -- The Geneva conference, whatever its eventual outcome, should have the salutary effect of impressing upon the nations of the West, and particularly the United States, that the successful conduct of foreign affairs rests upon the recognition of established political facts. One of these facts, re-established at the Geneva meeting and during its hectic preliminaries, is the political interdependence of Britain and the Commonwealth.

STUTTGART, Germany -When tourists from America get to this end of their expensive trips across the Atlantic and stand finally looking at what they came to see, they will find themselves Rolleiflex to Rolleiflex with large numbers of other tourists -- the soldiers of the United States Army's European Command.

"TRUTH," says the storyteller of "The Caperberry Bush," "is like death, disease or bankruptcy. It's something that looks better on somebody else." Here, in capsule, is the moral of the story. It is a cynical moral, but this is a cynical, sophisticated, iconoclastic book.

Trod on heavily since the beginning of the last half of 1953, the wool carpet industry in still taking a beating. Production, off 24 per cent during the first quarter compared with the similar period last year, is not being increased in this quarter as much as expected and sales and profits remain considerably below par.

IN today's rapidly expanding communities, there is often a dearth of wild places, where boys may escape from prying eyes, be boisterous and voice ideals without self-consciousness. To five sixth-grade boys near Portland, Ore., the news that the town council planned to level Hobo Hill -- their private forest primeval -- for a public highway was disastrous.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 29 -- War of Roses, an English-bred thoroughbred that never had won a stakes race, took the $50,000 added Jersey Stakes at Garden State Park today under a whipping ride by Jackie Westrope as Correlation wound up sixth in the field of twelve.

Reverence for the past could interfere with fulfillment of the true purpose of individual lives, Rabbi William Berkowitz declared yesterday in a sermon at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Eigthyeighth Street, west of Broadway.
June is the critical month in the struggle for Southeast Asia.
summer wearing apparel.

NOW that peony bloom has come to the fore, gardeners are tempted to add new varieties to their collection. And long is the list from which to choose. For as early as 1904 to 1911 six ponies were brought to this country from Japan.

WITHIN a recent sevenweek period record manufacturers brought out new disks that contained more than half of Ravel's entire output as an orchestral composer. As if this were not proof enough of recording largesse, a period just a little longer also included two new versions of Debussy's La Mer, to say nothing of shorter Debussy pieces and various works by other composers whom the manufacturers have coupled with the two master Impressionists.

THE possibility of involvement in the Indochina war has created nervousness in the business community. An important trade question is this: Should inventory contraction be continued or abandoned? Most merchants and manufacturers believe that no extraordinary measures or drastic changes of policy are needed at this time.

James R. Tully has been named manager of petroleum, tire, battery and accessories sales for the United States Rubber Company. William F. Beardsley replaces Mr. Tully as merchandising manager of the Fisk-Gillette division.

BOSTON, May 29 -- Lou Boudreau's Boston Red Sox continued to lose ground and face today at Fenway Park. The Bosox fashioned only two hits this afternoon while the Yankees collected seventeen, including a grand-slam homer by Yogi Berra, for a 10-2 rout of the local club.

EACH year since the war the annual festivities at the American Academy of Arts and Letters have given evidence of progress toward a more contemporary outlook than previous occasions indicated. This is notable in the election of new members to the National Institute of Arts and Letters, which stands somewhat in human relation to the Academy as the Luxembourg formerly stood to the Louvre in the matter of recognition of works of art.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -Paul Crouch said today the Justice Department had "banished" him to Hawaii because a memorandum he wrote was submitted to the Army-McCarthy hearings.
MONTREAT, N. C., May 29 -- The Southern Presbyterian Church called upon its 3,776 local churches tonight to open their membership rolls to all individuals regardless of race.

It was with regret that I read in Mr. Thomas M. Pryor's column in Sunday's Times that the 3-D craze is dead. I belong to that small minority who prefer a stereoscopic film on a comparatively small screen to a million dollar 2-D epic on an oversized wide screen.

EACH year at this time of the most thrilling migrations in nature makes its annual appearance. Salmo salar, "the Leaper," begins moving from unknown oceanic feeding grounds and forms an ever-increasing silver chain through the pools, rapids and over the low falls of countless northern rivers.

GENEVA, May 29 -- Over the vigorous protest of four LatinAmerican Governments and Nationalist China, the governing body of the International Labor Organization decided today that the Soviet Union was one of the ten countries of "chief industrial importance."

The question of what kind of naval duty is most dangerous in wartime is a source of frequent dispute among Navy men. But there is little argument that the ships most prone to accident are the aircraft carriers. The planes, taking off and landing on a small, moving, and frequently unsteady "air strip," are a constant hazard.

THE goal of all bidding is game, and every sensible bidding system should be founded on this fact. Slams are very nice for dessert, but they have very little effect on a player's net winnings or losses in the course of a year.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed predicted today that the House of Representatives would approve the Administration's Social Security extensions "by an overwhelming vote" next Tuesday.
MOSCOW, May 29 -- SovietUnited States discussions on atomic energy, it was apparent today, have come to a dead end.

FOR any American of 35 or over the Spanish Civil War (1936-39) would surely be a vivid memory. No other war in which the United States did not join so stirred and divided the American people. Left and Right, liberal and conservative, Catholic and Protestant were passionately at odds.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- John L. Lewis, labor leader, became the town's second biggest banker this week. He did it by buying control of a second bank, which he will merge soon with one he has controlled since 1949.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson and Gen. James A. Van Fleet will return from military survey trips to the Far East next week. They will get here just before the United States and four other nations begin talks on the free world's defensive position in that area.
Millions of Americans will return to their desks, stores and factories Tuesday morning after a long week-end. One will begin his stint that day as head of the Pennsylvania Railroad.
A discussion of how youth can best serve in national defense was televised yesterday as the weekly New York Times Youth Forum.

A leading economic expert predicted yesterday that the free world would survive the Communist threat because our free economy was flexible enough to provide social welfare as well as individual freedom.

WHILE there is no reason to believe that Tuesday morning will see any sharp rise in the number of hang-overs or good resolutions noted along Broadway, the day, nevertheless, will mark the beginning of a New Year for the legitimate theatre.

AMARILLO, Tex., May 29 -The "Cinderella Harvest" is under way in the Texas winter wheat belt. Combines are whirring in the northeastern part of the state, north of Dallas and Fort Worth, and as far west as Wichita Falls.

Larry Evans, United States chess champion, yesterday began defense of his title, defeating Saul Wachs of Philadelphia in fortytwo moves in the opening round of the national tournament sponsored by the United States Chess Federation at the Marshall Chess Club.

It is indeed difficult to understand how The New York Times Magazine can give such prominence to the pseudo-scientific postulations of Dr. Joost A. M. Meerloo in his article "Pavlov's Dog and Communist Brainwashers" (May 9).
LONDON, May 29 -- Winthrop W. Aldrich, United States Ambassador, attended a special service at St. Margaret's, Westminster, today commemorating the American Memorial Day.

Fall orders for men's clothing are slow in coming through, but are much better than anticipated, manufacturers reported last week. Inventories are low at all levels -- retail, manufacture and mill -- and a light flurry of business has caused scurrying all along the line.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 29 -- A sketch drawn by a victim of Westchester's "party bandits" led tonight to the arrest of the confessed ring leader and finger man for the gang.

JUST when a faithful moviegoer is beginning to wax weary and provoked by the sprinkling of cheaply sensual pictures that have been descending on the screen of late, along comes a happy little item so, casual and free of furtive smut in the handling of a somewhat sensitive subject that the spirit is cleansed of despair.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (UP) -- A three-run outburst in the seventh inning, after Camilio Pascual filled the bases on walks with two out, carried the Philadelphia Athletics to a 7-5 victory over the Washington Senators today at Connie Mack Stadium.

NOW many books are published that are capable of altering the course of the arts in any significant degree, but Ann Hutchinson's "Labanotation" is definitely such a book. Published two weeks ago by New Directions, with the assistance of a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation, it may well date the birth of literacy in the dance.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 29 (AP) -- Five thousand French Union troops, including mobile artillery units, today broke the Vietminh siege of Yenphu in the biggest drive by the French since the fall of Dienbienphu. The rebels scattered into the hills around Phuly, thirty miles south of Hanoi, under heavy air, artillery and ground attack.
WE heard a story at an educational conference a couple of weeks ago that may be particularly appropriate to this holiday week-end with all sorts of family excursions on the docket.

PARIS, May 29 -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati won the men's singles title in the French international tennis championships today when he defeated Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., in straight sets as Maureen Connolly of San Diego, Calif., successfully defended her women's crown.

FORT WORTH, May 29 (AP) -- A couple of golf's old-timers, E. J. (Dutch) Harrison, making his nineteenth and last tour, and Byron Nelson, the Texan who retired from regular tournament competition eight years ago but still plays in a few events, today led the $25,000 Colonial National Invitation at the 54-hole mark with 210's.
ITHACA, N. Y., May 29 -- Pennsylvania scored its first victory over a Cornell varsity eight in a dual race today.

LOUISE BOGAN'S poems adhere to the center of English with a dark lyrical force. What she has to say is important. How she says it is pleasing She is a compulsive poet first, a stylist second. When compulsion and style meet we have a strong, inimitable Bogan poem.
PASADENA', Calif., May 29-- legal showdown is imminent lere on a system of school,pupil allocation that Negro spokesmen argue is disguised segregation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 29 -- Thailand appealed today to the Security Council to take note of the dangers inherent in the situation in Indochina. She asked for the appointment of military observers to keep watch on developments there.

OFFICIALS of the New York City Opera have been instructed not to make any commitments for new productions in the fall. A season "only of revivals" was decreed on April 20 by the directors of the New York City Center of Music and Drama.

Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick, a member of the editorial board of The New York Times, died yesterday at 6:50 P. M. in Doctors Hospital, which she entered as a patient on May 11. Her age was 72. She had lapsed into a coma in the late afternoon and did not regain consciousness.

WHEN planning a modern rose garden, an abundance of charm and interest can be added by including some of the old varieties and species. Many of these lesserknown roses have a charm and often a fragrance that few gardeners would want to do without.

To bring the meaning and scope of current world problems into sharper focus in the classroom, the international relations class at Dickinson College (Carlisle, Pa.) has organized as a model United Nations. Students are cast in the role of permanent U. N. officers and delegates.

THE nightmarish horror let loose in William L. Shirer's compelling novel is something called O'Brienism and its perpetrator is a gross United States Senator named O'Brien, chairman of the Senate Committee on Security and Americanism.

NICE -- On the French Riviera the pounding of hammers and the groaning of saws is just about over for another year. During the past winter, certainly masons, carpenters and just plain laborers never had it so good.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 27 -Stormy Kenya is becoming an increasing burden to the two other British East African territories, Tanganyika and Uganda, which provide nearly 80 per cent of East Africa's exports but are bound to Kenya in a customs union.

GENEVA, May 29 -- Pote Sarasin, Thailand's Ambassador to Washington, will present Thailand's request for military observers to the United Nations Security Council. Mr. Sarasin, who arrived this morning from Bangkok, will fly to London tomorrow and will arrive in New York Wednesday.

The use tax was devised as a complement to the sales tax. Its purpose is primarily to prevent avoidance of the sales tax by outof-state purchases. Being still in an experimental stage, the tax presents administrative difficulties and conflicts between the states.

MANY garden clubs are busy this week preparing for their annual spring flower shows. The first of these is the twentieth annual show of the Chappaqua Garden Club to be staged in the parish house of the Congregational Church at Bedford and Orchard Ridge Roads, Chappaqua, N. Y.

THE setting for this novel is Channel City, Calif., a sea-and-mountain Eden where middle-mass life can somehow seem more typical than elsewhere. The reasons are obvious in the case of Gordon Foster, a youngish dentist with a pink stucco office, a wife who says she can't stand the sight of dentures, and three children she uses against him.

A title that had eluded Chick Werner and his Penn State team since 1942 finally was won yesterday when a crack band of Nittany Lions marched off with the seventy-eighth track and field championship of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America. Manhattan College, titleholder for the past two years, finished second.

NEW DELHI, India, May 29 -Mushrooming of the Communist party's physical establishment in this capital has given a new point to the question often asked by non-Communists here: Where does the money come from?

Senator Clinton P. Anderson's assertion, in his letter printed in your April 11 issue, that the present version of the Alaska Statehood bill "does fully protect all existing rights" of the Aleuts, Eskimos and Indians of Alaska, and "broadens greatly the opportunities for full ownership of lands and resources in Alaska by natives," cannot be allowed to remain unanswered.
Delegates from eighteen countries and one colony will attend the general technical conference of the International Cargo Handling Co-ordination Association in Naples starting tomorrow.

ALLIED Artists (known as Monogram Pictures until last November) has set in motion the first phase of an ambitious program calculated to put it into the big league of Hollywood movie-making. The initial step was the signing last week of a contract with John Huston whereby the director-writer-producer will become an important stock owner in the company.

THE Thunderbird anchored many times in the year 1800 -- in Brazil, at Cape Horn and on the unexplored coast of wes tern Canada. Aboard were Roy and Jerry Lacey, owners of the cargo, intent upon a venture to save their Virginia estate.

The attention of the world is focused again on the Great Pyramid of Cheops at Giza, Egypt, because of the remarkable discovery of funeral ships in a passageway blocked by massive stones. The literature on that monument is enormous, because it is the finest and largest of all Egyptian pyramids, of which there are about two hundred.

NEWARK, May 29 -- Five hundred and fifty employes of the Ronson Corporation here -- more than half of its local personnel -- are being notified of their immediate dismissal. The notices are being given over the weekend by telephone, telegraph and personal contact.

DAY in and day out for six and a half years Buffalo Bob Smith has faced a television studio audience of fifty wildly cheering youngsters, most between the ages of 3 and 5. Sitting in the "peanut gallery" of N. B. C.'s "Howdy Doody" program for children, they scream with delight at the antics of 36-year-old Buffalo Bob, who conducts the show.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -President Eisenhower said today the Boy Scout oath expresses more succinctly than any other document the objectives of this Government both at home and abroad.
GUATEMALA, May 29 -- This is a tense, nervous city at the end of the second week of the crisis stirred up over the Government's purchase of arms from Czechoslovakia.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., May 29 -- Undefeated Navy won its twenty-eighth consecutive crew race today, defeating California by two lengths for the intercollegiate sprint championship of the Newport Harbor regatta.
LOS ANGELES, May 29 -- Bad-check artists, the bane of supermarkets, are being rapidly thrown out of business here by a very simple device: a camera that photographs them as they cash the checks.

MOSCOW, May 29 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party secretary, sat side by side today in the Government loge for the ceremonial session of the Supreme Soviet of the Russian Federated Republic marking the 300th anniversary of the union of the Ukraine and Russia.
RUMSON, N. J., May 29 -- A 3year-old cream-colored miniature poodle here from England for six months made it two-for-two in the all-breed show of the Monmouth County Kennel Club today.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) -A Government committee has recommended that voluntary measures, not Government controls, be employed to make efficient use of civilian manpower in event of war.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The United States Government is opposed "for the time being" to negotiating directly with the Chinese Communists for the release of Americans held by the Peiping regime.

AKRON, Ohio, May 29 (AP) -The ninety-sixth Generan Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church approved today a plan to unite three Presbyterian denominations with a combined membership of 3,500,000 persons.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 (UP) -- Joe Miceli and Al Andrews, both striving for a match with Kid Gavilan, welterweight champion, battled to a draw tonight before 4,000 fans at the State Fair Grounds Coliseum.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 29 -- Reinforcements equivalent to two light divisions are being brought to the Red River delta to increase French strength in this Vietminh infested area, according to authoritative military sources.

RALEIGH, N. C., Sunday, May 30 -- Former Gov. W. Kerr Scott held steadily to a slender lead early today in the Democratic primary returns for nomination to the United States Senate seat now held by Alton A. Lennon.

THE major conflict in this novel is of a psychologicalintellectual nature, revealed through the apostasy of two Catholics, a doctor and a nurse. Dr. Andrew Carew, who has been reared in an atmosphere of strict adherence to the faith, is torn asunder in his efforts to reconcile the medical bungling that contributes to the death of a patient before final absolution, and the whole Roman Catholic attitude toward life, death and the hereafter.

In the course of this Memorial Day week-end there is more than a little marching. This is not unusual, since the "Decoration Day Parade" long since became a classic in American folkways. Some of the marches will be a matter of perhaps two hours. One that is taking place at this time is a matter of two weeks. This is the Veterans' March for Korea, now in full swing.

WHEN making the rounds of Europe, summer visitors often overlook one of the most pleasant means of travel available to them. This is the network of ship routes over coastal and inland waterways which links up various parts of the Continent.

In his article "Have Fathers Changed?"(May 9) Edward Streeter disagrees with my statement that business success may leave little time for the business of being a successful father. Certainly there are some fathers who achieve both business and domestic success, although I suspect that most of them are geniuses or near geniuses like Theodore Roosevelt, whom the author cited, or the author himself.

GENEVA, May 29 -- The conference on Far Eastern affairs agreed today to ask the high commands in Indochina to negotiate here next week on the "dispositions of forces" throughout Indochina when a cease-fire is arranged.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 29 -Royal Mist, a 5-year-old bay mare owned by Franklin S. Hastings of Berlin, Md., and driven by Mack Hayman, equaled the world record for aged pacing mares by winning the sixth race at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:01 tonight.

The stock market last week kept to its now customary pattern of recovering from mild doses of selling pressure and ending on a firm note. Despite conflicting reports on economic conditions, the aircraft, steel and motor shares paced the reversal.

The Dodgers beat the Giants yesterday, 4 -- 2, on Pee Wee Reese's two-run homer in the ninth inning. The blow, which came off Sal Maglie, enabled Carl Erskine to notch his fifth victory of the year. In Boston, the Yankees defeated the Red Sox, 10 -- 2.
Since the end of World War II the nation's colleges and universities have put greater emphasis on the study of American history and civilization.

TOKYO, May 29. -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida sets out next week on his long-heralded tour of free-world nations. He will leave behind him a political situation that, if not chaotic, is at least difficult and dangerous for his dominant Liberal party.

Columbia University's busiest week in its year-long bicentennial celebration will be highlighted by an address by President Eisenhower tomorrow night at the national bicentennial dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
TOKYO, May 29 -- A last-minute Socialist attempt to block Premier Shigeru Yoshida's goodwill tour of the United States and other free nations was rejected tonight by the Japanese Diet.

One hundred and seventy-two years ago a Great Seal of the United States was adopted by the Continental Congress. Its approval had been no simple matter; the seal was ordered by the Congress on July 4, 1776, immediately after the Declaration of Independence had been acted upon.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29 -- With the aid of a $25,000 grant from the Fund for the Advancement of Education, the nation's third oldest college has just completed a two-year self-evaluation study. And it has reached the conclusion that on the whole the highly controversial "Great Books" program, introduced here in 1937, has proved successful.
COOKEVILLE, Tenn. May 29 -- Senator Estes Kefauver today announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for re-election.

A racing pigeon that could take flying lessons from a crow returned home yesterday more than a month overdue on what was to have been a routine flight from Rahway, N. J., to Stamford, Conn. It went to Italy instead.

OF all the earth's neighbors in the sky, the planet Mars has excited the greatest interest and attention, principally because of its nearness as distance is reckoned in the heavens, because of its striking color (it is "the red planet") and, above all, because of the fascinating possibility that life exists -- or once existed -- there.

The purchasing power of the average Soviet worker's takehome earnings may this year finally mount again to the low 1928 level, until now the high tide of Soviet real wages. Since 1928, real wages have generally been between one-half and two-thirds of the 1928 level, and have been less than one-half at the worst times.

CLEVELAND, May 29 (UP) -Bob Lemon became the first major league pitcher to defeat every rival team in his league this season when the Cleveland Indians routed the Detroit Tigers, 12 -- 1, tonight and retained their slender hold on first place in the American League.

ELEVEN physicians were visited in turn by the five young men who wanted so desperately to study medicine. All refused to consider their plea, for the obvious reason that, during the French Revolution under Robespierre, to teach medicine was to risk the guillotine.

IN the spring of 1952, 6,000 prisoners in the state prison at Jackson, Mich., staged what has been called "the most dangerous prison riot in American history." It appeared to touch off prison riots elsewhere in the United States, in Canada and in South America.

THE fears, the apprehensions, the reflections, possibly even the remorse, of the seven major Nazi war criminals jailed in Berlin's Spandau Prison present one of the most intriguing themes available to the historian of current events.

Top-level speed-boat racing for the super - powered inboards will have its first chance to see the checkered black and white victory flag this afternoon in the popular Fite Memorial Marathon which usually ushers in the heavy and expensive race boat season.

HARTFORD, May 29 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff of Hartford, a former United States Representative, was seen today as sure to be the Democratic party's nominee for Governor against the Republican incumbent, Gov. John Davis Lodge.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Business activity in the Chicago area and the rest of Illinois has continued upward at a slow pace, but there are many spotty sectors in the industrial scene. Home construction has forged ahead in April and the early part of May at an unexpectedly high rate in the larger centers.

TO this reviewer's knowledge, this is the first time in this century that a professional conchologist has written a book expressly addressed to the amateur collector. R. Tucker Abbott, Associate Curator of Mollusks, United States National Museum, has spent a good part of his professional life answering the questions fired at him by baffled shell collectors.

IZMIR, Turkey, May 29 -- A philosopher by the name of Herakleitos, who, some twenty-five centuries ago, resided at Ephesos in the neighborhood of this subheadquarters of NATO, concluded that "all is flux; naught abides." This observation bears certain resemblances to the opinions of disillusioned Allied statesmen today.

Testimony in the investigation of the explosion and fire aboard the aircraft carrier Bennington at sea recalled yesterday the facts deduced as to the cause of a similar disaster aboard the carrier Leyte in Boston Harbor last Oct. 16.

SALEM, ORE. RICHARD L. NEUBERGER, Democratic candidate for United States Senator from Oregon, recently took a different tack from most politicians regarding his appearances on television. He spoke out against use of any artificial devices to make him a theoretically more winning figure on the home screen.
THE new engraved Elizabethan series for Kenya-Uganda-Tanganyika, which will be issued in Nairobi, Entebbe and Dar es Salaam on June 1, consists of ten values and offers seven interesting designs.

STANTON, Del., May 29 (AP) -Mrs. Ada L. Rice's top-weighted Pet Bully rallied from far back today to capture the $12,950 Wilmington Handicap as Delaware Park opened a 32-day race meeting before 19,517 fans who wagered $1,005,198 on the eight races.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, May 30 -- Recent outbreaks of nationalist terrorism in Tunisia appear to have wrecked French efforts to promote political reform and restore public confidence in that North African Protectorate.
QUEBEC, May 30 -- Maurice Duplessis, Premier of Quebec, has announced his provincial Government had taken under "consideration" a request for oil exploration rights by Imperial Oil Company of Canada.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- Senator Lister Hill said today President Eisenhower departed from the "spirit, the letter and the clear intent of the T. V. A. Act" by failing to reappoint Gordon R. Clapp as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

PARIS, May 30 -- Premier Joseph Laniel announced today acceptance of the resignation of Marc Jacquet as Under Secretary for the Associated States of Indochina. It was said that this Gaullist member of the Cabinet would soon be replaced.
The basic toll rate of 1 1/4 cents a mile for passenger cars on the Thruway will compare favorably with charges on other pay expressways.

HARRISON, N. J., May 30 -The Chelsea Football Club of London today defeated an All-Star soccer team, sponsored by the United States Soccer Football Association, 2 -- 0, before 8,000 fans at Rodgers Stadium.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 -- Isolated reports filtering out of Communist China show that the Christian faith has not been stamped out, the Seventh-day Adventist world general conference was told here today.
LONDON, May 28 -- Leaders of both major British parties are increasingly worried over the effect of constant anti-American propaganda on the outlook of the mass of the British people.

LONDON, May 30 -- Disquieting influences have been at work tending to cause hesitation in the stock markets in the last week. Tension over the situation in Indochina has continued and there were rumors of trouble in the Far East, while at home there has been the threat of a serious extension of the already troublesome partial railway strike.

As an occupation for the long summer days, mothers and daughters, whether experts or debutantes in the art of knitting, might plan to get out their needles and begin casting stitches for their fall sweaters and knit accessories.
The merchant fleet of the world, now hard put to find cargoes for all of its units, will soon be half again as large as it was on the eve of World War II.

The Allied Stores Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $1,316,008, or 48 cents a share on the common stock, for the three months ended on April 30. This compares with $1,388,113, or 52 cents a share, for the three months ended on April 30, 1953.
YONKERS, May 30 -- Four armed robbers left a maid tied up in her employer's house early this morning and made off with household and personal articles worth several hundred dollars.
Your editorial of May 26 titled "The Outlaw Mr. Quill" contains an error of fact which I should like to call to your attention.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 -- In their disappointment that the steel business did not produce a strong upward movement in the first two months of the second quarter, most steel observers have lost sight of the fact that neither profit nor production has been too bad.

Two City College professors who joined the faculty at the same time twenty-six years ago will retire Sept. 1. They are Dr. Benjamin Harrow, chairman of the college's Chemistry Department, and Dr. Owen A. Haley, Associate Professor of Government.

The theory of "everything in its place," a home management practice advocated by home economists today, is particularly useful when applied to the numerous accessories and equipment needed for sewing.

GENEVA, May 30 -- Thailand's Foreign Minister said today that he would propose that the Far Eastern conference break off negotiations on Korea and set up a seven-nation commission to study the question.
The over-all cost of the 562 miles of the State Thruway network has been set officially at $962,000,000.

BUFFALO, May 30 (AP) -- Miss Margaret Barnard of Albany was elected president of the Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State, Inc., today. She succeeds Dr. Marguerite J. Fisher of Syracuse.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Congress is investigating itself out of house and home. The hearing fever is so intense there are just not enough rooms in the Capitol and Senate and House office buildings to go around.
The intercession of St. Pius X on behalf of a "spiritually sick world" was invoked yesterday by the Rev. Harry J. Wolff at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., May 30 -William Ritner Jr, of Philadelphia today won the Fite Memorial speed-boat marathon. A 21-yearold senior at Pennsylvania Military College, Ritner long has been active in racing circles since learning the sport from his father, a well-known competitor.
Nick Falcone, a 66-year-old Pennsylvania farmer, is back home today making puzzled comparisons between the two kinds of help a stranger lost in the subway gets from New Yorkers.
Last week's ship charter market was effectively bucking the usual annual trend of lower rates in inverse proportion to higher temperatures.
The United Medical Service, New York's Blue Shield Plan, passed the 3,000,000 mark in membership during 1953 when 337,917 new members were enrolled.

The Government's newly announced plan to make surplus butter stocks available to foreign countries was criticized sharply yesterday by Albert Lowenfels, chairman of the Hotel Bar Butter Company. In a telegram to Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, he described it as "a fantastic giveaway program" and charged the Administration with "a betrayal of the American housewife."
The most southerly ice penetration of westbound trans-Atlantic shipping lanes in many years has put masters of inbound vessels on the alert, the Coast Guard reported here yesterday.

In his letter printed May 16 Calvin B. Hoover sees the take-over of Indochina by the Communists as inevitable table in view of France's unwillingness to grant full independence to the Associated States, lack of intervention under United Nations auspices and the inability of Secretary Dulles to line up Western and regional nations for substantial military contributions.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Senators William F. Knowland, Republican of California, and Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, agreed today that the United States might have to try to bring Spain and West Germany into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) if the European Defense Community (E. D. C.) continues to be balked.

A slightly easier trend for the British pound sterling and a continuing strong undertone for the Canadian dollar marked the trading in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Volume of business transacted was reported as fairly large, especially as compared with that of the past few weeks.
LINDEN, N. J., May 30 -- The Seafren Kennels' 3-year-old miniature poodle Fircot L'Ballerine of Maryland achieved a dog show rarity in the event of the Plainfield Kennel Club today.

ATIQUIPA, Peru, May 29 -- The ruined "mystery" city of Cahuamarca, on the Inca road station atop a 3,400-foot mountain and in sight of the sea, is a key to a riddle of the Incas. The finding of an unreported ruin as important as this one was one of the thrills on our exploratory program.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 (UP) -- Rain clouds gathered over this auto-racing mecca tonight on the eve of the richest 500-mile speedway race in history. Jack McGrath was picked from a "wide open" field as the pilot to beat.

HAIFA, Israel, May 30 -- Israel made musical history today by playing host to the first World Music Festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music ever held outside Europe, with the exception of a wartime festival held in the United States during World War II.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The American Battle Monuments Commission is one of the few Government agencies here that maintain a passion for anonymity.

In 1902 Percy A. Reuss led an expedition into the jungles of Brazilian Amazonia in search of gold. He discovered a "lost" city, inhabitated by the reputed descendants of the old Inca civilization. He returned to England with solid gold ornaments of "fabulous wealth."
Subdued services in memory of the nation's war dead were held yesterday by Americans throughout the world.

BALTIMORE, May 30 (UP) -- The Baltimore Orioles ended their ten-game losing streak when Don Larsen pitched a six-hit, 5-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox today. The defeat snapped the White Sox' eight-game winning streak.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 30 -- A Chinese rebel band "heavily attacked" Idi, an important coastal town 110 miles north of Medan, in a reoccurrence of guerrilla activity in that area.

A tribute to the Netherlands as "the rock out of which we were hewn" was paid yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig at the West End Collegiate Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, Seventy-seventh Street west of Broadway.
SOUTH HAVEN, Mich., May 30 (UP) -- A noted Michigan trial lawyer today planned an "unwritten law" defense for Dr. Kenneth B. Small, who last night shot and killed a New York industrialist.

The Distinguished Service Cross, the nation's second highest combat award, was presented posthumously yesterday to Pvt. Albert Sherman, a medical aid man, for extraordinary heroism in Korea. The award was received at Governors Island by the soldier's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Sherman of 2023 Belmont Avenue, the Bronx.

Randolph E. Paul, once of the Treasury Department, has written a monumental history, "Taxation in the United States."* It is not, as some of Mr. Paul's one-time critics might expect, a plea for reform or a defense of the tax methods evolved by the New Deal. Mr. Paul does not like reformers, "a hungry breed of animal."

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- A powerful wing of Senate Democrats is reported lining up behind Senator Earle C. Clements of Kentucky to succeed Stephen A. Mitchell as Democratic National Chairman in what may develop into a battle for control of the party machinery.
Most so-called juvenile delinquency is a process of growing up, according to Dr. Sophia M. Robison, mother of five and grandmother of eleven.
GENEVA, May 30 -- Two members of the British Parliament conferred today with Chou En-lai, Chinese Commnist Premier and Foreign Minister, on the possibilities of increased trade.

CLEVELAND, May 30 (AP) -- Cleveland's first - place Indians swept a three-game series from the Detroit Tigers today, 3 -- 1. Dave Philley drove in two of the Tribe runs on long flies. Mike Garcia scattered four hits to win his fifth game against four losses.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- Standard Oil Company (Indiana) has formed a new subsidiary to handle sales of liquefied petroleum gas on a country-wide basis, John E. Swearingen, vice president in charge of production, announced today.

The leader of American Federation of Labor longshoremen in the Port of New York said yesterday that, if the old International Longshoremen's Association went on strike, he would urge his followers to cross picket lines.

MEXICO CITY, May 30 -- The first congress against Soviet intervention in Latin America came to a hectic close here today with the delegates as far from agreement on how to fight communism as when their meeting started.

The success of a pilot inspection program started March 1 has led Mayor Wagner to direct that block-by-block housing inspections be put on a permanent basis. Of the 6,000 buildings already inspected, 25 per cent were found with violations "dangerous to life or prejudicial to health" while 80 per cent of all the buildings had some type of violation.

ROME, May 30 -- The honors of the Catholic Church were paid today to its new saint, Pius X. The day began with a pontifical mass in St. Peter's and ended after dark as the brightly lighted glass coffin containing the body of Pius X was carried across Rome to the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore.
The hangar deck of the aircraft carrier Coral Sea, nearly 1,000 feet long, became a ballroom last night for a Columbia University bicentennial party.
MOSCOW, May 30 -- For the third time in two days, Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Nikita S. Khrushchev, first party secretary, appeared together today at a public function.

BOSTON, May 30 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. called for an economic conference among the free nations of the world to expedite aid to the free countries of South Asia and the Middle East.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (UP) -- A socially prominent woman was burned to death tonight when a cigaret set fire to her bed in a twenty-second-floor apartment of the Barclay Hotel in mid-city.

In an effort to stabilize his regime and broaden its base Premier Nasser of Egypt has issued a draft law for the creation of a National Assembly and has submitted it to public discussion for constructive suggestions and criticism. This step is intended to initiate a new era in Egypt and pave the way to political life based on "modern democratic principles."

TRENTON, May 30 -- The New Jersey Legislature will reconvene here Wednesday. As it is anxious to recess June 14 for the summer, it may well decide to increase the number of its sessions in the next two weeks -- for there is much to be done.

RADIO broadcasters, who have been so quick to complain of their problems in competing with television, apparently are determined to lose friends and infuriate people. Their handling of the Army-McCarthy hearings is enough to make a listener eager to throw his radio receiver into the nearest ash can.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 17 -- As far as Paraguay is concerned, Rutherford B. Hayes was one of the greatest Presidents the United States ever elected. As for Argentina, the memory of him still haunts President Juan Peron.

In your editorial of May 20 "Statistics as a City Aid" you mention Board of Education figures on expected attendance and on site choices for new schools as having been in the recent past notoriously and expensively faulty.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board for the first time barred a national labor union today from further board services on the ground that it was Communist-led.

LONDON, May 30 -- Members of the Labor group controlling the City Council of Coventry caused chaos today when a Home Office civil defense mobile column carried out Britain's first hydrogen bomb exercise there.

An audience of 5,000 persons assembled before the band shell in Central Park last night for the holiday concert presented to the people of the city by Walter W. and George W. Naumburg in memory of their father, Elkan Naumburg, who donated the bandstand.

If there is a surplus of dairy products this year, it will not be the fault of the advertising profession. Beginning tomorrow -- the opening of Dairy Month as proclaimed by President Eisenhower, Governor Dewey and other officials -- every kind of promotion will be stressed by all phases of the dairy and kindred industries.
PARIS, May 30 -- French industrial production in April reached the highest level it ever had touched, and experts are expecting May to establish a new record.
ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP) -- The president of the Southern Baptist Convention said today that the world was "in a continual struggle between the forces of righteousness and the forces of evil."

LUXEMBOURG, May 30 -- In general elections held today in the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, the Social Christians, the Roman Catholic party, added five seats to the twenty-one they held in the previous Parliament.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 30 -- The State Public Utilities Commission has ordered the Board of Selectmen here to continue to share its water supply with its neighbor in Westchester County, the Town of Rye.
LOS ANGELES, May 30 -- The proposed extension of Social Security to farm workers is regarded here as a possible means of reducing the number of illegal aliens from Mexico.

Last Monday, third formers at St. Mark's School in Southborough, Mass., were at it again. The baseball team had just beaten Groton and, in keeping with tradition, the students dragged a wagon filled with their conquering school mates through the village. It was a parade worth seeing.
An explosion "blew to pieces" a four-and-a-half-room apartment in Riverdale last night, killing one woman and injuring five other persons.

LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- Provisional figures published this week-end by the British Government showed that world consumption of wool in 1953 jumped 11 per cent over the 1952 total to a near record of 2,597,000,000 pounds.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 30 -- The cornerstone of the new $3,000,000 headquarters of the National Council of Boy Scouts of America in North Brunswick was dedicated today. More than 500 persons, including several national officers, attended.

The curious notion, fathered a few days ago under the lee of Coogan's Bluff, that the Giants had the Dodgers on the run, blew up at the Polo Grounds yesterday in the presence of 47,672 fans, largest National League crowd of the season.

Questions from readers are answered today. They cover such topics as how to store pre-packaged fresh meats, how to bake hard meringues (the kind used as a base for ice cream and crushed fruit) so they remain white, and the comparative food values of butter and margarine.

PARIS, May 30 (AP) -- Emil Zatopek of Czechoslovakia today broke the world record for the 5,000-meter run, traveling the distance in 13 minutes 57.2 seconds. The old record was 13:58.2, set by Gunder Haegg of Sweden in 1942.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 30 -- Rutgers University will confer eight honorary degrees at its 188th commencement exercises on June 9. Nearly 1,800 gradates from eleven colleges and divisions of the State University will receive degrees.
MILWAUKEE, May 30 (AP) -- Red Schoendienst's home run and four successive singles in the first inning gave the Cardinals all the runs they needed today to beat the Braves, 3 -- 2.

HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., May 30 -- Rags died at 11:15 A. M. today. They took her to the veterinarian at the county seat in New City last night. He said the only merciful thing to do was to put her to sleep.
MONTREAT, N. C., May 30 -- Presbyterian unity negotiations took an unexpected turn here today.

The Library of Congress has had a long history from its conception in the late eighteenth century until today. It is clear that the library has been developing along the lines of a National Library when 710,000 people used it last year, in addition to members of Congress themselves.
NEARLY a score of diverse group exhibitions of art and a few one-man shows are opening along with the coming of June.

Anne O'Hare McCormick's friends on this newspaper have had to say good-by to her many times since 1922, when she first began to write for The Times, and especially since 1936, when she became a member of the editorial board. She was not one who could sit in a library and gain all the knowledge she needed by reading.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 30 -- Gold and foreign exchange reserves rose 55,000,000 builders last week to a new high of 4,524,000,000. This unabated increase is becoming somewhat embarrassing here. It is believed largely due to continued foreign buying of Dutch securities. Such buying during the previous week was estimated at $15,000,000.

With the appointment of Lieut. Gen. David M. Schlatter of the Air Force to succeed Lieut. Gen. A. D. Bruce as commandant of the Armed Forces Staff College at Norfolk, this school for the study of the problems of unification at the operational level comes full circle.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Senate Finance Committee has completed four weeks of voting on the Administration's omnibus tax reform bill, but is yet to tackle the big issues.

Plans for additional apartments in the two buildings at 162 and 164 East Eighty-second Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues, have been announced in connection with the sale of the property by the Howscott Realty Corporation to Herbert H. Bachrach, operator. The houses occupy a frontage of fifty feet and contain twenty-two apartments. The Brener Lewis Company was the broker.
CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs and the Cincinnati Redlegs split a double-header today.

The bitter attack on President Eisenhower's atomic pool proposal printed in Pravda last Saturday appears to confirm beyond doubt earlier reports that Moscow has once again said "nyet" to a suggestion for easing world tension. Additionally ominous is the fact that Pravda declared there is a "growing threat of war with use of means of mass destruction of people."

HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 30 -- The Storm Trysail Club's ninth annual race around Block Island ended off this port today with Jim O'Neill's fifty-four-foot yawl Stormy Weather, flying the burgee of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, winning the Class A and over-all fleet prizes.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 30 -While Easterners watched the big fight for control of the New York Central, Westerners engaged in a pleasant free-for-all of their own here last week with millions of shares of "penny-ante" uranium mining stocks as the prizes.

The Coast Guard pressed a daylong air and sea search yesterday for an overdue thirty-two-foot cabin cruiser with two adults and five children. The craft had left Nutley, N. J., at 8:30 o'clock Saturday morning and failed to reach its destination at Fire Island.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., May 30 -- Dr. John C. Dingman, one of the last active old-time country doctors on the west side of the Hudson, is being honored at a testimonial dinner here tomorow night at the Villa Lafayette. It will be a widely represented demonstration of affection.
The chaplain of Columbia University warned the senior class yesterday against adopting a philosophy of life that emphasizes rules of outward behavior without regard to a deeper "inner devotion."
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the period May 22 through May 28:

ANKARA, Turkey, May 30 -- Premier Adnan Menderes left for the United States today. He goes prepared to argue that Washington should help cover the gap between Turkey's new international commitments and her present capabilities.

A temptation to make an idol out of democracy, and thus stifle individual freedom, is already evident among us, the Rev. Dr. Edmond L. Cherbonnier, Deacon for the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) and a member of the faculty of Barnard College, said in his sermon yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 30 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali dismissed Fazlul Huq as Chief Minister of East Pakistan today for "treasonable activities."
MOSCOW, May 30 -- "Hamlet," in a Marxist interpretation with a musical score by Dmitri Shostakovich, is being presented at Leningrad's leading theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Senator Henry C. Dworshak, Republican of Idaho, accused Democrats on the Senate Investigations subcommittee today of trying to seize on the McCarthyArmy hearings to stir trouble in the Republican party.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30 -- Ginger Rogers and George Raft are joining the cast of "The Black Widow" and will share co-star billing with Gene Tierney and Van Johnson in the mystery drama. Nunnally Johnson, the author-director-producer, is in New York City filming background sequences for the Twentieth Century-Fox production.

THE car had broken down again. This time the steering apparatus had collapsed. From Algiers all the way down to Tamanrasset things had been going wrong. This was the worst. The Sahara was no friend to a reckless couple, weak from lack of food, exhausted from continual digging out of sand dunes, hundreds of miles from help.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The State Department has received word from Tokyo that when Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan visits Washington he will present the United States officials a desperate picture of his nation's losing the struggle for economic survival.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 30 -A new rise in coffee prices is threatened as a result of losses estimated today at 20 per cent in the state of Sao Paulo's good export grades of coffee through excessive rain recently.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 30 -- Gen. Rene Cogny's French Union command in North Vietnam has received orders to defend the entire Red River delta, instead of pulling in its line for the defense of a smaller perimeter inside the delta.

FORT WORTH, May 30 (UP) Johnny Palmer of Charlotte, N. C., outfoxed gusty winds and a torrid group of challengers today to win the top prize of $5,000 in the $25,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament with a par 280.
The Rev. Albert L. Neibacher criticized Memorial Day observances yesterday as having degenerated into mere political platforms and forums for pious platitudes and noble panaceas.

The humorless leaders in the Kremlin probably do not see it, but there is more than a small touch of the comic in the artificial festivities these past weeks "celebrating" the "reunification" of the Ukraine with Great Russia 300 years ago. The more speeches, pageants, delegations and decorations which are invoked to mark this anniversary, the more ludicrous and clumsy does the spectacle become.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- Senator Price Daniel predicted today that the South would accept the Supreme Court's anti-segregation decision, but would find a legal way to continue segregated schools.

A fully integrated steel mill with a blast furnace, coke ovens, basic Bessemer steelmaking furnace and rolling mills, is scheduled for completion within the next few months on the outskirts of Belencito, in the State of Boyaca, Colombia.
