Active parent cooperation with schools, urged by educators and parent group leaders alike, has been carried out by mothers of elementary school children attending Public School 67 in the Bronx.

Dant Russell, Inc., has accepted an offer to sell its stock interest in Inman-Poulsen Lumber Company and in the Western Logging Company, plus an additional tract of old growth timber contiguous to Inman-Poulsen timber in Lincoln County, Ore., to the Georgia-Pacific Plywood Company.

CAIRO, May 30 -- The solar funerary bark of Cheops was unsealed for an hour and a half this evening for a surprise inspection by its discoverer, Kamal el-Malakh, and eight other noted scholars and Egyptologists.
" Ondine" will end its local run at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre on July 3.
BONN, Germany, May 30 -- The decision of the French Socialist party has lifted the lagging spirits of the West German Government.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP) -- Pinch - hitter Eddie McGhee smashed a double with the bases filled in the last of the ninth inning today to give the Athletics a 6-5 victory over the Senators in the second game at Connie Mack Stadium.
PARIS, May 30 (UP) -- American tennis forces today completed a sweep of the French international tennis championships. United States players won or shared in all five titles.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week held within a relatively narrow training range. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to up 14 points from the week previous. The strength was centered in the more distant deliveries.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- The Public Health Service is "really on the road" to conquering one type of cancer and has a substance that holds "great promise" in the fight against epilepsy.
Annual meetings held last week by the New York Tow Boat Exchange and the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York re-elected James P. McAllister and Thomas F. Horan, respectively, as president.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $83,421,752,962. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
ZURICH, Switzerland, May 30 -- For the first time, Swiss francs were sold by auction in Brazil last Friday, on all ten Brazilian Stock Exchanges.
RALEIGH, N. C., May 30 -- Former Gov. W. Kerr Scott won Democratic nomination to the Senate on the basis of unofficial and nearly completed returns in yesterday's primary election.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Phillis pounded out twenty-seven hits in sweeping both ends of a double-header from the Pittsburgh Pirates today. Robin Roberts won the opener, 8 -- 0, and Karl Drews received credit for the 10-7 victory in the second game.

PARIS, May 30 -- A badly split French Socialist party came out strongly today in favor of the proposed European Defense Community. It ordered its members in Parliament to vote with out exception for the treaty establishing this community.

It is common sense that any program that can involve the expenditure of more than sixty billion dollars in less than ten years ought to be carefully and continuously scrutinized. Senators Bridges and Symington, as a Senate subcommittee, have been conducting some of that scrutiny of our foreign aid program, and they have recommended a Congressional "reappraisal" of some phases of our operations.

GENEVA, May 30 -- The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, makes a forthright demand for a new approach by the United Nations to the refugee problem in his annual report published today.
JERUSALEM, May 29 -- Jordan branded as false today information given to the United Nations Security Council on frontier incidents by Abba Eban, the Israeli representative.

PASSAU, Germany, May 30 (AP) -- Deputy United States Prosecutor William D. Canfield said today he now had enough evidence to ask that James M. Leech of Lima, Ohio, be brought to Germany and tried in the 1946 axe killing of three Army officers.

SUMMIT, N. J., May 30 -- Entries from Fred Blum's Brooklyn stable came through for the honors in the jumper championship as the Watchung Riding and Driving Club horse show ended today. Stray Star captured the title as a stable-mate, Prince River gained reserve.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 30 -- Miss Helen Bruns, president of the Studio Council, was crowned May Queen at Marymount College here today. Miss Helen McCarthy of Swampscott, Mass., president of the senior class, placed the crown on Miss Bruns head in a ceremony for which Miss Bruns had written the script.

BOSTON, May 30 -- If only for the good of baseball in Boston, where the Red Sox had been stumbling about in the American League cellar, Willard Nixon, the righthander, could not have chosen a better time than today to pitch a 4-hit, 3-1 victory over the Yankees. The Bosox could not have afforded a third straight setback before the third big home crowd in a row.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- If some citizens have the idea that the "Senate has suspended regular work while the McCarthy-Army hearings are going on," Senator Franck Case, Republican of South Dakota, said today, he wants them to know "that is not correct."

PORTLAND, Ore. -- Brig Gen. Carlos P. Romulo today urged President Eisenhower to call a meeting with Asian leaders to set up a "Southeast Asia declaration" as the first step toward a mili tary alliance to combat the menace of communists there.
Haile Selassie I, Emperor of Ethiopia, received a regal ovation from scores of thousands of persons who lined the streets yesterday for the monarch's tour of Harlem.

Morton Gould's Concerto for Tap Dancer and Orchestra will be one of the two works to receive their New York premieres this summer at the concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium. It will be included in the program of dance music to be led by Thomas Scherman on June 12. Danny Daniels, for whom the concerto was composed, will dance the solo part.

The church plays a fundamental role in man's efforts to live in peace instead of war, the Rev. Dr. Raymond F. McLain, chairman of the Commission on Christian Higher Education, National Council of Churches, said yesterday.

COOKEVILLE, Tenn., May 30 -- A Southeast Asian defense pact, backed by economic and military support from Western powers, was proposed last night by Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, as the only means of saving southeast Asia from Communist domination.

Larry Evans, the champion, and Nicholas Rossolimo, international grand-master, failed to repeat their first-round victories in the championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Marshall Club yesterday.

An investor has purchased the one-story taxpayer building occupied in its entirety by the Crowley-Jones Camera Corporation at the northwest corner of Hempstead Turnpike and Crest Street, in Elmont, L. I. Sydney M. Siegel Co. were the brokers.
When Andres Revesz registered at the Yale Club recently, he was assigned room 814.

Reunion Day will be held on the Barnard College campus on Wednesday. Mrs. Berthold R. Comeau, chairman of the reunion program committee, said 700 Barnard alumnae were expected. The activities will begin at 2 P. M. with tours of the recently renovated Milbank and Barnard Halls.
A baccalaureate mass next Sunday at 11 A. M. will open Fordham University's 109th annual commencement week.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- Weather developments dominated the grain markets last week, when rains fell where they were needed most, rounding out the picture of improvement that has been shown since late April.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 30 -- A business agent of an American Federation of Labor union recently named a foreman as a job steward at Oak Ridge.
DENVER, May 30 -- President Eisenhower praised the General Federation of Women's Clubs today for more than a half century of service to the nation.

When Richard D'Oyly Carte visited New York in the early Eighties, at the height of his success as impresario for Gilbert and Sullivan, the lavish hospitality of American hotels made a fateful impression on him.

TRENTON, May 30 -- New Jersey institutions for the mentally deficient have been found greatly overcrowded and understaffed, despite an expansion program undertaken over the last five years at a cost of many millions of dollars.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 30 (AP) -- Pfc. George Argus of Brooklyn was found "alive and well" today after fourteen days on the slopes of the North American continent's tallest peak.
GUATEMALA, May 30 -- The Guatemalan Communist party called on its members today to "close ranks" against what it described as the "mounting menace of Yankee imperialism trying to engulf us in war."

TAIPEI, Formosa, Monday, May 31 (AP) -- Gen. Li Mi, former commander of Chinese Nationalist guerrillas in Burma, announced yesterday the formal dissolution of his "Yunnan Province anti-Communist National Salvation Army."

WASHINGTON, May 30 (UP) -- President Eisenhower went to church today and heard his pastor declare in a Memorial Day sermon that "mere anti-communism" is not the answer to the challenge of the Communist "world religion."
Patrolman Andrew Bruton will probably never come so close to being killed as he did at 4 A. M. yesterday.

IT was a lazy sort of day at the Polo Grounds. A hot sun beamed down and even the ball players were willing to concede that summer might not be far off. They weren't complaining, either. Warmth was to be welcomed after the dank, chilly spring.

Under date of May 21 there appeared in The New York Times a news item that Senator Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota, has achieved the first step in his campaign to have Ford's Theatre in Washington restored as it was the night President Lincoln was assassinated.
RYE, N. Y., May 30 -- Emil (Bus) Mosbacher scored another victory today with his blue-hulled Susan in the regatta conducted by the American Yacht Club.
TEDDY MAY has walked and crawled through Manhattan's 560 miles of sewers for fifty-one years, but tomorrow he must be done with them forever.

LONDON, May 30 -- High military circles here believe the Communist armed insurrection in Malaya has been brought sufficiently under control to permit some British troops to be spared for a Southeast Asia defense organization.

The Social Science Research Council announced yesterday 125 fellowships and grants. Pendleton Herring, president, said the $300,000 funds were provided by the Rockefeller Foundation, the Carnegie Corporation of New York and the Ford Foundation.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- After an unusually noisy preface in which Lewis L. Strauss, the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, has been represented by a familiar group of self-styled liberals as a putative "czar" and an administrator to whom "security" has become an alarming obsession, he is to testify before the appropriate Congressional committee on changes in the Atomic Energy (McMahon) Act.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The post-war wave of Soviet defections has now struck the Soviet secret police with shock effect.

The Government of Pakistan, under Prime Minister Mohammed Ali and Gov. Gen. Ghulam Mohammed, has been forced to take drastic measures against the East Pakistan regime of Fazlul Huq. The so-called "Lion of Bengal" has been forced out of office and his Cabinet dissolved.
James Barton is scheduled to return to the Broadway stage this fall in a comedy-fantasy entitled "With Drum and Colours," written by Romeo Muller.

Back in 1936, the Brown Williamson Tobacco Corporation, Louisville, Ky., placed on the market a filter-tipped cigarette which was known as "Viceroy." The product created only a mild stir in a market dominated by such giants in regular size and construction as Camel, Lucky Strike, Chesterfield, Old Gold and others.

Robert H. Scholl has been elected vice president, director and member of the executive committee of Esso Standard Oil Company, Stanley C. Hope, president, announced yesterday. He was formerly general counsel of the company and will be succeeded in that post by Einar B. Paust, who has been associate general counsel since 1951.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 31 -- The Eastern States Open tournament at the Log Cabin Chess Club was won tonight by Olaf Ulvestad of New York. He defeated Weaver W. Adams of Dedham, Mass., in the seventh and final round.

BONN, Germany, May 31 -- The West German Government is planning to reinvest the Deutsche mark equivalent of more than $250,000,000 in Marshall Plan aid in industrial re-equipment and expansion this year.

Americans will be happy to extend a warm welcome to the Turkish Premier, Adnan Menderes, and a group of his distinguished colleagues in government who begin a series of conferences in Washington today. These conferences are concerned with how to make Turkey stronger at a time when Turkish strength is a vital factor in the defense of the free world.
Summer got an unofficial, sun-filled send-off here as the Memorial Day week-end wound up its three-day spree of good weather yesterday with the hottest day of the year.
A total of 502,876 spectators watched major league baseball over the Memorial Day weekend, with the National League outdrawing the American League by approximately 25,000.

Silt at piers on the New York and New Jersey waterfront, an expensive problem for shipping men here, will be brought to the attention of Congress by Representative Frank C. Osmers Jr., Republican of New Jersey.
A bill to repeal the Lyons Residence Law will be introduced in the City Council today by Councilmen Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan, and Robert E. Barnes, Queens, Republicans.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 31 (Reuters) -- The Pakistani Government opened today an all-out propaganda drive to try to sell the population of East Pakistan on a "strong man" regime installed there Sunday.

All the good things about cloudless mornings are self-evident and need no annotation here. It is sufficient to say that cloudless mornings are one of Nature's noblest institutions. But the worst thing about them is that they often become cloudy afternoons add even rainy evenings, particularly in the springtime of the year.

" AS near as I can figure out," said Steve O'Neill, carefully choosing his words, "the main difference between the pitchers of today and the pitchers of my day is the ball. With the dead bail we weren't afraid to pitch to a batter's strength. With the lively ball, though, no one dares pitch to strength or it's -- boom! -- out of the ball park."
Lulu Perez, Brooklyn feather-weight who is hoping for a shot at Sandy Saddler's world crown, gained a unanimous 10-round decision over Mickey Mars of Cleveland at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

LOS ANGELES, May 31 -- Light from a huge exploding star, first observed on May 4, took about 20,000,000 years to reach the earth, the California Institute of Technology said today. The space explosion, known to astronomers as a supernova, was 100,000 times brighter than the sun.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., May 31 (AP) -- A solemn crowd aboard the flight deck of the Bennington today honored the 100 officers and men who lost their lives as a result of the explosion and fire in the carrier last Wednesday.
CAMDEN, N. J., May 31 (UP) -- Lillal, an 8-to-1 shot, made her first 1954 victory a significant one today by winning the $36,750 Colonial Handicap at Garden State Park by three lengths.
Solemn tribute to those who gave their lives in defense of this nation's freedom was offered yesterday in large and small communities.

ROME, May 31 -- The major ceremonies for the canonization of Pius X were concluded this morning when Pope Pius XII received the Cardinals and Bishops at the Vatican and spoke to them in condemnation of "lay theology."

The Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority plans to enter the investment market within the next year to borrow $15,000,000 on revenue bonds, according to the Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- Small business reports that the buying public is becoming more and more price conscious, often putting price ahead of quality, a Government survey disclosed today.
LONDON, May 31 (Reuters) -- Cinderella has joined Snow White and Little Red Riding Hood on the list of fairy tales attacked as a bad influence on children by British officials.
Brooklyn marked Memorial Day with a solemn parade down Eastern Parkway to Grand Army Plaza.
The Board of Estimate's Bureau of Real Estate was blamed yesterday by Dr. Luther H. Gulick, City Administrator, for "abuses" in the city's tenant relocation program.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- William F. Knowland, Senate Republican leader, has told Congress of what he purports to be a Communist blueprint for world conquest by 1973.

DULUTH, Minn., May 31 -- A National Guard plane with fourteen aboard, groping for a landing in a heavy fog, crashed into a gravel pit near here tonight. Seven of the passengers were reported killed and seven more were hospitalized, some in critical condition.

OTTAWA, May 31 -- Canadians were chuckling today over the ribbing given Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in a burlesque of a Senate committee hearing broadcast last night. The broadcast originated in Toronto and was carried by the Trans-Canada network of the Canadian Broadcasting Company.
Opposing sides in the city's transit crisis will meet separately today with Mayor Wagner.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 -- The Giants missed an opportunity to take undisputed possession of second place in the National League flag race today. The Polo Grounders' blew their chance by bowing to the tail-end Pirates after winning the opener of the twin bill.
CAIRO, May 31 -- Important new discoveries have been made by Dr. Zakaria Goneim, keeper of antiquities and director of excavations at the Sakkara necropolis.
State Department protocol lost some of its starch yesterdy when Haile Selassie I., Emperor of Ethiopia, tried to be just another sightseer in town for the Memorial Day week-end.
In advance of the conversion of Seventh and Eighth Avenues to one-way travel on Sunday, the traffic pattern around the Holland Tunnel has been radically rearranged.

The Food and Nutrition Board of the National Research Council, a cooperative organization of American scientists, has just published a revision of its booklet, "Recommended Dietary Allowances.'' This was originally issued in 1943 and revised in 1948.

HANOI, Vietnam, May 31 -- A French spokesman said today that 6,000 troops had spent three days sweeping the Phuly-Ninhbinh-Namdinh triangle in the Red River delta without encountering any appreciable Vietminh resistance.

NORTH BERGEN, N. J., May 31 -- The men's chorus of the United Singers of Newark and the women's chorus of the United Singers of New York County were the county winners in the singing contests held over the week-end in the 140th anniversary festival here.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's speech at the Columbia University bicentennial dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night as recorded by The New York Times:

CAIRO, May 31 -- The Egyptologist who discovered the Pharaoh Cheops' funerary bark unearthed today the upper part of what promises to be steps leading to the entrance to the subterranean corridor housing the ship.
MANCHESTER, England, May 31 (AP) -- Doris Hart of Coral Gables, Fla., and Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, gained the third round today in the Northern lawn tennis tournament.

Brazil has appointed her alternate delegate to the United Nations, Hugo Gouthier, as Consul General in New York. He holds the rank of minister and succeeds J. B. de Berenguer-Cesar, who has been named Ambassador to Colmbia.
NUREMBERG, Germany, May 31 (AP) -- An accusation of bungling was made today against an officer who headed the United States Army's investigation into the 1946 slaying of three officers.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- President Eisenhower led the nation today in remembrance of its war dead and in prayer for permanent peace.

The city's twenty-five Republican members of the Legislature charged yesterday that Mayor Wagner was determined to impose new taxes as part of "an audacious gamble to further his own personal political ambitions."

Company buyers will probably be scrambling for many types of merchandise by late summer or early autumn, according to the composite opinion of the economists who compiled the 1954 Commodity Year Book, out today.

MAJ. GEN. JOSEPH ORVILLE SHELBY, commander of the Missouri Cavalry Division of the Confederate Army of the Trans-Mississippi, was the best cavalry general of the South, in the opinion of one of the best Northern cavalry generals. Alfred Pleasanton fought Jeb Stuart in Virginia before he fought Shelby in Missouri. He is a good witness.

The New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company, the oldest operator of American-flag cargo ship tonnage between United States East Coast ports and the East Coast of Mexico, has quietly abandoned the employment of American tonnage in this run after almost sixty-five years.

The Union Tank Car Company and its wholly owned Canadian subsidiaries had a consolidated net income in the first quarter of this year of $1,258,196. This compared with $886,255 in the corresponding period of 1953.
JERUSALEM, May 31 -- Two different units of Israeli soldiers fired across the Jordanian border in the daytime Friday at the village of Nazlat Isa, north of Tulkarm, and wounded five inhabitants.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 31 (AP) -- Using a sled as a stretcher, a rescue party was making better time today than expected in bringing Pfc. George Argus down the perilous slopes of Mount McKinley, the highest mountain in North America.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 31 -- The private electric industry will do everything possible to make available more economical power from new sources, including atomic fuel, as fast as science and engineering make it possible.

In The Times of May 22 Leonard D. Adkins writes that the Butler constitutional amendment to set the number of Supreme Court justices at nine and mandate retirement at age 75 should be speedily passed by the House, now that the Senate has approved.
GENEVA, May 31 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, proposed today that Poland, Czechoslovakia, Pakistan and India be named to supervise an armistice in Indochina.
Families having traits in common with other families that are counted among their friends have a "better protection against the occurence of juvenile delinquency, desertion and divorce."

New Yorkers, along with the rest of the nation's residents, will run for shelters in the first nation-wide atomic attack exercise, planned for mid-morning of Monday, June 14. It is the same day that has been set by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., for a strike against city-owned subway, elevated and surface lines.
CAPILLO PEAK, N. M., May 31 (AP) -- Good week-end weather helped radio amateurs break the Southwestern bottleneck and complete history's first transcontinental relay on the two-meter band.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- Joe Black, who pitched the Dodgers to a pennant in 1952, when he won fifteen games, lost only four, and saved 15 more, today was optioned to the Montreal Royals of the International League.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UP) -- The National Education Association has reported an "alarming drop in prospective high school teachers at a time when a "sensational" rise in high school enrollment was expected.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., May 31 -- Light air produced sailing victories for Cornelius Shields' International Aileen, Henry Boschen's Class S Sirius, Leonard Romagna's Atlantic Ro's Folly and W. Earle Chase's Lightning Vee-Bob, among others, in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta today.

The Peerless Oil and Chemical Company has enlarged its holdings in Long Island City, Queens, where it has purchased 27,800 square feet of the former Socony Vacuum property on Review Avenue through the C. Grant Keck Organization, broker.
ALBANY, May 31 -- The annual meeting of the New York Central Railroad will resume today probably only to take another recess.

CHICAGO, May 31 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs blasted six home runs today for a 14 -- 4 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals in a contest called after seven innings because of rain. The second game of the scheduled double-header was postponed.

LONDON, May 31 (UP) -- Admiral Sir Dudley North, removed from duty in 1940 by the Royal Navy for permitting a French fleet to escape from the Mediterranean, said today he had been "condemned and punished unheard."

Ralph Diaz of Cardinal Hayes and Ted Johnson of Rice shared the spotlight yesterday in the twenty-eighth annual track and field championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.
BALTIMORE, May 31 (AP) -- Tiger pitcher Billy Hoeft struck out eleven, but the Baltimore Orioles Alagged out a 4-2 victory over Detroit to gain an even split before 23,709 fans today.

BUFFALO, May 31 (AP) -- The Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State, Inc., has asked each of the two major political parties to put a woman on its slate for high executive or judicial office.

In the six brief years of its independence Israel is developing a whole new literature in music, the theatre, the dance, the sciences, winging up from the shore, the plain and the desert just as with the early settlers of America. There seems to be a break with the nostalgic formalisms of the first immigrants to Palestine fifty years ago.

The ten-story buildlng containling thirty-five apartments and [two doctors offices-at 169 East !Seventy-eight:h 'Street has been sold by George, W. W. arnecke to the 169 East Seventy-eighth Street. Corporation, recently formed by a group of tenants in the.building.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, told 500 Columbia College seniors yesterday that the "free clash of contending ideas" was necessary for the survival of our society.

The holiday week-end automobile fatalities in this country have passed 340, which is the number that had been estimated as the total. A few of these deaths may have been due to mechanical failures that no one could foresee. But most of them could have been prevented.

GENEVA, May 31 -- The South Korean delegation to the Far Eastern conference will not be willing to go along with any plan to set up a committee to continue the Korean talks after the close of the Geneva conference.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP) -- The Socialist party wound up its twenty-ninth national convention today with the adoption of a policy platform hat included proposals for a multi-billion-dollar public works program and repeal of the Taft-Hartley law.

More than three and a quarter million young Americans are in the armed forces today. More than a million G.I.'s are stationed in countries where customs are unfamiliar and languages strange. During this period of uneasy peace, they train and drill and wait.

TURKU, Finland, May 31 (AP) -Australia's John Landy, who has been flirting with the four-minute mile for two years, ran the distance without pressure today in 4:01.6, equaling the fourth fastest performance ever recorded.

It is hard for people living in New York or another great American city to imagine what present-day Berlin is like. Let us suppose there were armed guards and barbed-wire fences between Manhattan and its sister boroughs on the east and north. Let us suppose that New Yorkers had to travel to Philadelphia through territory occupied by a foreign army.
First Deputy Premier Lazar M. Kaganovich has voiced a veiled Soviet threat to invade Western Europe if war comes again.

The fundamental faith that guides this nation was proclaimed anew by President Eisenhower last night in his speech commemorating the 200th anniversary of Columbia University. Speaking as President of the United States and one-time president of Columbia, he defined this faith as the revolutionary doctrine of the divine rights of the common man.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 31 -- An appeal has been made to governments for funds to bolster the United Nations' faltering program for Korean reconstruction.
James T. Sherwin took the lead in the third round of the United States chess championship by defeating Sidney Bernstein yesterday at the Marshall Chess Club, 23 West Tenth Street.

TOKYO, May 31 -- Crucial bills for the establishment of a new Japanese Army, Navy and Air Force under the germs of the Mutual Defense Assistance Agreement with the United States were virtually assured of enactment today after a long political battle.
WESTBURY, L. I., May 31 (AP) -- Up Top, a 3-year-old colt, was driven to victory by his owner, Ben Turlington of Melfa, Va., in the $2,500 Old Westbury Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
Whether it is a holiday or not, shoppers will go out of their way for bargains. This was demonstrated again yesterday by Hearn Department Stores, Inc.
LONDON, May 31 (Reuters) Matyas Rakosi was confirmed as party boss of Communist Hungary today, retaining the post he held for many years during Stalin's lifetime.
Winners in the 1954 student competition in interior design and decoration of the American Institute of Decorators today, include the names of five students in local schools.

President Eisenhower expressed last night the firm belief that knowledge and understanding would "drive from the temple of freedom all who seek to establish over us thought control -- whether they be agents of a foreign state or demagogues thirsty for personal power."
DENVER, May 31 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Gordon Allott has become the first person to announce as a candidate for the Republican nomination for the Senate here.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- Darius, winner of the classic 2,000 Guineas, replaced Rowston Manor as the favorite for Wednesday's Epsom Derby at a betting call- over tonight.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday net income of $2,045,026 for the first four months this year, against $2,791,461 earned in the similar period last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- The signing of agreements covering about 1,500 labor union locals to permit Seventh-Day Adventists to work at their jobs without being union members was reported today to the denomination's world convention.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 31 -Kenya's white settlers have split politically into an apartheid movement and a multiracial government movement. Just under half of the members of the European-elected Members Association, the old common front of the whites in Kenya, have resigned.
DENVER, May 31 -- The leader of 5,500,000 American club women declared here tonight that the greatest need in America was the strengthening of the home.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 31 -- Scientists from all parts of the world will gather here next Monday for the dedication of the $3,500,000 Rutgers Institute of Microbiology and for a two-day symposium to follow.
Representatives of the city's six biggest breweries and their 6,000 unionized workers sought last night to head off a strike that would dam the flow of beer at the start of the hot season.

MONTREAT, N. C., May 31 -- Presbyterian unity took a long step forward here today when the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) approved a merger involving the three largest Presbyterian groups in this country. The vote was 283 to 169.
STANTON, Del., May 31 (AP) -- C. V. Whitney's Cold Command, a 3-1 shot, won the $24,750 Brandywine Handicap today in a photo finish before a crowd of 28,829 at Delaware Park.

MOSCOW, May 31 -- Pravda published today on Page One a large photograph of Government and party leaders headed by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party secretary, hailing yesterday's Ukraine demonstration in Red Square.

PARIS, May 31 -- Premier Joseph Laniel was preparing tonight to fight a ten-day battle in the French National Assembly to gain time for a solution of the Indochina problem at Geneva. He is endeavoring to restore his Government's authority.

Jackie La Bua, East Meadow, L. I., middleweight, extended his winning streak to eleven when he gained a split decision over Jacques Royer of France in the main event of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.
ANGLERS and farmers agree that a mild rain during the night usually is good for the stream as well as the crops. Both were happy during the holiday week-end.

LONDON, May 31 -- Government funds rose sharply on the stock exchange today after a new Government loan was announced. Medium-dated stocks advanced as much as fourteen shillings nine pence ($2.08) on the Treasury's announcement of a combined cash and conversion offer of a new short-dated Government stock.

BOSTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox put on their heaviest attack of the season today - including two homers by Milt Bolling and one each by Ted Williams, Jim Pearsall and Harry Agganis -- to trounce the Philadelphia Athletics, 20 -- 10 and 9 -- 0.

When manufacturers believe strongly in fashion, price is no barrier to their ingenuity. They manage to crowd an amazing amount of style into every dollar's worth, as is proved by this summer's crop of budget-conscious fashions.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A national farmer leader said today that more adequate measures than the exchange of goods for dollars would be needed to move this country's farm surpluses into international trade.

The population of the New York metropolitan area has increased 1,250,000 since 1950 and now exceeds 15,000,000 persons, according to the Regional Plan Association. The association is a privately financed research and planning agency.
Three major steamship lines have announced long cruises for some of their liners leaving New York between this autumn and next February.

Children's play groups, equipped and supervised by cooperating parents, are becoming increasingly familiar throughout the country, especially in communities with many young families. That such projects can be as much a part of life in the big city as in the suburb or small town is proved by results of a study just released by the Welfare and Health Council of New York City.
GENEVA, May 31 -- Advance predictions that the Far Eastern conference would impose terrific strains upon British-United States relations have been borne out.

For thirty years Mrs. Blanche Stanley longed for a college education, but restrained her ambition because she felt that a woman's first duty to society was "to have children and to bring them up properly."

CLEVELAND, May 31 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians clung to a one-game lead in the American League today by taking the second game of a double-header against the Chicago White Sox, 6 to 3. Chicago had won the opener, 6 -- 4, before a crowd of 39,977.

The easterly store and' part of the third floor in 579 Fifth Avenue, corner of Forty- seventh Strdet, has been leased by: the William H. Jackson Company, Specialists in fireplaces and accessories, from the Rovi Co'rporation through the Cross. Brown Company, renting agent.

Two hundred and twenty-four men and women received Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science degrees yesterday at the sixty-ninth commencement of Wagner College. The exercises were held in the college auditorium, Grymes Hill, S. I.

GUATEMALA, May 31 -- The Government announced today the discovery of a plot to overthrow President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman. The announcement followed a series of raids and arrests in the last forty-eight hours.
Broadway went from light to dark to light for about ten minutes last night and nobody seemed to suffer except maybe the electric company.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- Duke Snider made one of the greatest catches of his career for the final out in the twelfth inning today and preserved a 5-4 victory for the Dodgers over the Phils at Connie Mack Stadium.
BOSTON, May 31 -- Condemnation of the disregard of constitutional authority "by some officials of Government" was voiced today by District Lodge No. 1 of B'nai B'rith.
Seven straight singles in the third inning gave the Yankees five runs and a 6-1 lead over the Washington Senators in the second game of the holiday doubleheader at the Stadium yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (AP) -- Bill Vukovich, the poker-faced throttle demon from Fresno, Calif., zoomed to a record-breaking triumph today in the Indianapolis Speedway 500-mile race. He thus became the third driver in the history of the race to win two years in a row.
LONDON, May 31 -- Troops were ordered to stand by as a new state of emergency, the second in six months, was declared today in Buganda, the troubled province of Uganda.

SINGAPORE, May 31 -- Inquiry into the crash of the British Overseas Airways Corporation Constellation at Kallang Airport March 13 with the loss of thirty-three lives opened here today before Justice Clifford Knight and two technical assessors.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 31 (AP) -- Authoritative French military sources said tonight the United States might undertake a big Globemaster airlift soon to help meet the menace of a Vietminh offensive against the Red River delta.

The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel hangs out a flag at the dropping-in of an international dignitary. But yesterday, two heads of state were at the hotel -- President Eisenhower, in for a Columbia University bicentennial dinner, and Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia. In residence also were Prime Minister Adnan Menderes of Turkey; a Spanish military mission and an Argentine naval mission.

Straight Face of the Greentree Stable scored a decisive victory under an expert ride by Teddy Atkinson in the $62,500 Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Count Fleet was a strong favorite in the field of twelve, and his mutuel price was $4.90 for $2.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Attacks on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were made today by two Democrats on the eve of the resumption of Senate hearings on his dispute with the Army.
GENEVA, May 31 -- Western labor representatives are seriously split over how to deal with Russian "labor" delegates to the international labor conference, which opens here Wednesday.
Morris Ernst's letter published on May 24 expressing his anguish over Robert Young's New York Central campaign is an extraordinary exercise in phantasmagoria.
Plans are being formulated at frequent meetings for the Mistletoe Debutante Ball to be held Dec. 30 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
Two patrolmen struggled for twenty-five minutes in the Hudson River early yesterday to save a woman who resisted their rescue efforts with cries that she wanted to die.

WALLINGTON, N. J., May 31 -- The Stork's Nest, a cabin cruiser that had been the object of a widespread air and sea search since Saturday, made port here tonight, her skipper bewildered at the furor he had caused.

BAY SHORE, L. I., May 31 -- A fresh wind out of the southwest put whitecaps on the wave crests of Great South Bay this afternoon and curtailed the first speed boat program of the newly-organized Bay Marine B. C.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31 -- Allied Artists is in the process of completing negotiations for screen rights to the French play, "Alouette," by Jean Anouilh. It is about the trial of Joan of Arc.
BROWNS MILLS, N. J., May 31 -- A member of the volunteer first-aid squad died here today in Mirror Lake during an underwater dive to test a new oxygen rescue device.

All but seven of the forty-nine branches of the Brooklyn Public Library will be closed Thursdays in an emergency economy program beginning July 1. Francis R. St. John, chief librarian, said it would have taken $300,000 a year in extra personnel funds to keep up the present services.

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 31 -- Eighty-six degrees were conferred here this afternoon at the 113th commencement of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart. It was the second commencement on the Purchase campus, developed when the college moved from New York.
PARIS, May 31 -- Reinforcements of infantry arrived today in the French protectorate of Tunisia to fight against renewed terrorism.
DETROIT, May 31 (AP) -- New car sales through this year's first five months were about 2,200,000, according to authoritative estimates.

An American edition of Richard Lewinsohn's "Animals, Men and Myths" will be issued June 9 by Harper. First published in Germany as the second in a series that began with C. W. Ceram's "Gods, Graves and Scholars," the volume presents a history of the relationship of man and animals from ancient times down to the present.
ALBANY, May 31 -- Even at its cost of nearly a billion dollars the Thruway system will be "a bargain," Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the State Thruway Authority, declared today.

NEW DELHI, India, May 31 -- Indian newspapers have tentatively linked anti-Indian disturbances in Nepal to the activities of United States technical assistance personnel. The Indians have been confronted with a violent outburst of antagonism in the neighborhoring Himalayan kingdom.

The New York State law has yet to catch up with the current theory that a husband and wife are partners in the home, according to Margaret Spahr, a lawyer. In an article in the May issue of The Journal of Home Economics, she discusses some of the shortcomings of laws that apply to a married woman, "over the age of 21 and in sound mind," who works at the job of homemaker.

The General Foods Corporation in the fiscal year ended March 31 achieved record sales of $783,007,626, representing the twenty-first consecutive year of increase despite taxes which were the largest in its history, earnings increased by $3,105,830.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- A protective committee for public holders of Missouri Pacific Railroad common stock asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to give them a larger share in the proposed reorganization of the company.

PARIS, June 1 -- Fears that the French forces in Indochina are not prepared to resist renewed assaults of the Chinese-aided Vietminh dominated the opening of the Indochina debate in the National Assembly today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Eisenhower's proposals for increases in Social Security benefits and taxes, broader coverage and other changes in the Old Age and Survivors Insurance System were approved by the House of Representatives today, 355 to 8.

The law of averages, bad weather and a letdown after Easter apparel buying activity caught up with New York City's retailers in May. As a result, according to a survey by The New York Times, business at eleven department stores here was 1 per cent below their level for May, 1953.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- With heavy rains since Friday in sections needing moisture through the Midwest and the Ohio Valley, wheat support faded after a steady opening and prices dropped three cents or more. Rain also fell in the spring wheat section where it was badly needed.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 1 -- The draft of Kenya's plan to aid the African peasant contains the warning that Kenya is short of land.

Ralph Izzard, foreign correspondent for The London Daily Mail, was ordered by his paper to beat the advance party of the 1953 British Everest Expedition to Katmandu. He has written an account of his 170-mile trip in "An Innocent on Everest."
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for an appropriation of $1,100,000,000 for military construction.

TOKYO, June 1 (Reuters) -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida said in the Lower House of Parliament today he thought it would be "inadvisable" for Japan to take part in the proposed Southeast Asian anti-Communist pact.

As an Assistant Attorney General of the State of New York I attended the annual State Committee dinner. The brief remarks of Richard Nixon, the Vice President of the United States, regarding a "draft Dewey for a fourth term" has set the spark for a fourth term.

Ogden Phipps' Privacy was the winner of the feature purse at Belmont Park yesterday. While a crowd of 17,247 watched, the son of Requested held firmly to a stretch lead and at the finish of the mile test enjoyed a margin of a length over Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Paper Tiger.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- Rear Admiral Lewis D. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, and Philip M. Klutznick, national president of B'nai B'rith, received honorary degrees tonight from Dropsie College for Hebrew and cognate learning.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 18 -- One of Paraguay's great needs is accurate statistical data.

MONTREAT, N. C., June 1 -- The Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) disassociated itself today from efforts to prevent religious leaders in Communist-dominated lands from attending sessions of the World Council of Churches.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 -- A torrential rain that cracked down on Forbes Field about forty-five minutes before game time washed out the Giants' concluding engagement of their scheduled three-game series with the Pirates tonight.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company announced today the details of the forthcoming initial distribution of Northern Illinois Gas Company common stock to holders of Edison common. At current market levels the cash value of the distribution would be about 75 cents for each share of Edison.

Personnel of the New York Naval Shipyard will donate blood today, tomorrow and Friday in memory of the victims of the explosion aboard the carrier Bennington last week. Donors from the shipyard in Brooklyn will visit the Brooklyn blood donor center of the Red Cross at 57 Willoughby Street.
Congratulating the United Service Organizations on its thirteenth anniversary, Presi dent Eisenhower recently wrote: "U. S. O. remains as vital a force today as it was in time of war.

The complaint voiced by Senators Mundt and Dworshak over the weekend that Democrats on the McCarthy investigating committee have been playing politics during the hearings has its ironic aspects. The Democrats on the committee have certainly been no more oblivious to the political implications of this affair than have the Republicans.

TOKYO, June 1 (AP) -- Two American Governors left for the United States today after an inspection of the Korean rehabilitation program. They said they had found "a truly remarkable degree of recovery."

A plea for more boarding home accommodations for older persons was made yesterday by Henry L. McCarthy, city commissioner of Welfare. He emphasized a special need for single rooms either on the ground floor or in elevator apartments.
ALBANY, June 1 -- The counting and tabulating of proxies cast in last Wednesday's vote for control of the New York Central Railroad Company will take the better part of another week or more.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 1 -- The Trusteeship Council is expected to agree that an early airing be given to a petition from the Marshall Islands asking that hydrogen-bomb tests near their Pacific atolls be ended.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 1 -- Mrs. Agnes Andrews, wife of a dentist here, was sentenced to ninety days in jail and fined $200 tonight for driving after her license had been revoked.
The harbor tug Brooklyn sank swiftly and without warning yesterday in shallow water off the Battery, carrying one of her seven-man crew to his death.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that consumer installment credit outstanding at the close of April totaled $20,909,000,000, a gain of $9,000,000 since March.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Isaac W. Carpenter Jr., paper manufacturer of Omaha, Neb., is under active consideration for appointment as Assistant Secretary of State for Personnel Administration.

About twenty million years ago a catastrophe occurred in the constellation Virgo, which lies beyond the Milky Way. A star exploded. We are only now hearing about the explosion, which took place long before man appeared. That explosion could be equaled only by detonating literally billions of hydrogen bombs.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- Air Force officials said today that reports of "flying saucers" had fallen off sharply since 1952. They said they believed more scientific investigating and better public education were responsible.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Adnan Menderes, Premier of Turkey, arrived here today to enlist support for his country's economic and military plans for the next four years.
Your recent editorial on "Controlling the Committees" was as timely as it was needful.

SOESTDIJK, the Netherlands, June 1 (AP) -- The nations represented at the conference called by Prince Bernhard were the United States, Britain, France, Belgium, Germany, Italy, Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Switzerland.

In a cash transaction negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker, and Morris Goldman, associate broker, the five-story store and loft building at 408-10 Broadway, running through to Cortlandt Alley, has been sold by the Thompson Greger Corporation.
NEWARK, June 1 -- Most of the 550 employes affected by the Ronson Corporation's discontinuance of lighter production in this city will receive cash pension payments, company officials said today.

GUATEMALA, June 1 -- Foreign Minister Guillermo Toriello and John E. Peurifoy, United States Ambassador, held a quickly arranged conference in the Foreign Ministry today. This and other recent events indicate extraordinary attempts at lightening the tension between the two countries that has been mounting steadily in the last few weeks.

The first large-scale practical application of a blood-chemical test for detecting internal cancer in a specific bodily site was disclosed here yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Urological Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford has warned Congress that any United States intervention in Indochina should be on an all-out basis, including use of atomic weapons, informed sources said today.

A plot of 35,000 square feet on the north side of Thomson Avenue, and running through to Skillman Avenue, in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Capital Distributors Corporation for improvement with a building to be used as offices and a warehouse.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Army counsel publicly voiced suspicions today about the authenticity of documents on which Senator Joseph R. McCarthy based his accusations against Army officials.

ROME, June 1 -- The triduum (three days) in honor of Saint Pius X began this morning with a mass celebrated by Francis Cardinal Spellman in the basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore. It is in this cathedral that the body of the saint rests.

JERUSALEM, June 1 -- A distinguished international audience, including President Izhak Ben-Zvi of Israel, tonight heard in the City of David the world premiere of "David," a powerful opera in five acts and twelve scenes by Darius Milhaud, with libretto by Armand Lunel. George Singer conducted.
One hundred union employes of Pan American World Airways walked off their jobs yesterday and early this morning at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

When in the middle of April I returned from a ten-day trip behind the Iron Curtain that took me as far as Moscow and Leningrad I came home optimistic. In Europe we have definitely established a balance of power that forecasts peace rather than war.

BOSTON, June 1 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics staged their greatest batting spree of the season today, pounding three Boston Red Sox pitchers for a twenty-three hit, 16-6 victory before 2,342 paying, fans, the smallest Fenway Park crowd of the year.

GENEVA, June 1 -- Representatives of the high commands of French and Vietminh forces in Indochina will meet here tomorrow to start negotiations on how much of Vietnam should be retained by the Communists under an armistice.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The highway safety movement has provided a market place for many self-seeking groups with axes to grind, it was asserted today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- The Navy said today the Bath (Me.) Iron Works would receive a contract for three $15,000,000 destroyers if Congress and President Eisenhower approved the Navy's new shipbuilding plans.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday. Active months were 7 points lower to three points higher than last Friday.
GENEVA, June 1 -- The idea that Western Europe could find economic salvation in some kind of exclusive British-Continental trading bloc seems, for the time being at least, to be politically dead.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 -- Walter H. Sammis, president of the Edison Electric Institute, said today that the progress of the past seventy-five years had made it obvious that "the Federal Government should not engage * * * in competition with the investor-owned electric utilities companies."

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in the twenty-fourth day of its hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Rubber Producing Facilities Disposal Commission today submitted to Congress fifty-four proposals and nineteen alternate proposals for the purchase of Government - owned synthetic plants.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The right of Nebraska to impose a personal property tax on the flight equipment of an airline operating in interstate commerce was upheld by the Supreme Court today.

Dr. Lillian Gilbreth, famous industrial engineer, urged educators and parents yesterday to remember that "educated hands have their place in life as well as educated heads," and "an educated heart" is needed to make the most of both.

An arbitrator ordered a pay cut of 9 1/2 cents an hour yesterday for 1,500 workers at the Passaic, N. J., plant of Botany Mills, Inc. The award was expected to set a downward pattern for wages in the woolen and worsted section of the textile industry, hard hit by competition from synthetics, foreign fabrics and non-union plants in the South.

Dr. David J. Seligson, president of the New York Board of Rabbis, asserted last night that survival of the American Jewish community depended on the restoration of the synagogue and school to their historic role.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Sales and profits of Beatrice Foods Company in March and April, the first two months of its fiscal year, increased substantially from a year ago, William G. Karnes, president, told stockholders at the company's annual meeting today.
"Carousel," which begins to spin at 8 o'clock tonight at the City Center, is the third and last of the fortnightly bills to be given by the New York City Light Opera Company.
The New York City Housing Authority is planning to borrow $36,000,000 for six months at an interest cost of $9,040. This is equal to 0.000505 per cent.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 1 (AP) -- Bill Vukovich, the driver, Howard Keck, the owner of the car, and their crew picked up $74,934.84 tonight for winning the fastest 500-mile race in the history of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

Sir Alexander Korda's London Films will produce nine feature pictures during the next eighteen months on a budget of $15,000,000, it was announced here yesterday by Morris Helprin, president of London Film Productions, Inc. Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, will participate in the production of the films.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Senate Finance Committee agreed today to exempt publicly regulated companies such as railroads and utilities from the 2 per cent penalty tax on consolidated tax returns.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Senate, without dissent, voted today to continue Government operation of the Texas City, Tex., tin smelter for another year.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 1 -- Brazil's outlawed Communist party is expected to attempt a comeback in camouflaged form during the campaign that is about to begin for Congressional elections in October.

Two suspended Hunter College faculty members testified last night at their departmental trials that while members in the Communist party they did not hear anyone advocate the violent overthrow of the United States Government. They declared that the Communist cell at the college was largely a discussion group.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 1 -- The United Nations' first hearing on the war in Indochina will begin at 10:30 A. M. Thursday.
Negotiations for a new wage agreement between representatives of the city's six biggest breweries and their 6,000 unionized workers were recessed late last night in an atmosphere of confusion.

An agreement on a link between the New York Thruway and the Garden State Parkway was reached yesterday. Ironically, it brought to light the prospect of major traffic congestion at the eastern end of the New York-New Jersey border because New York highway officials insist on another connection between the Thruway and the New Jersey Turnpike and Bergen County political leaders will have no part of it.
LONDON, June 1 -- Don Cockell moved closer to a chance at the world heavyweight crown when he scored an easy victory on points over Harry Matthews in a ten-round bout at White City Stadium tonight.
Some people who want to become investors have lengthy conferences with brokers before they buy securities. Others just hop aboard a plane to San Francisco.
The Appellate Division upheld unanimously yesterday the constitutionality of the Police Department's Retirement Rule at the age of 63.
The Transit Authority agreed yesterday to reconsider its rejection of key proposals for transit labor peace made by a fact-finding committee.
The people behind the comedians and the jokesters came up yesterday with several bits of news, all of it very serious, about laughs-in-the-making.

Trading in zinc futures yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange was the heaviest since the market reopened on June 23, 1952. The 132 lots traded represented 3,960 tons. Zinc closed 2 to 9 points higher, after a strong opening, influenced by London cables.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 1 -- Employers, including American-Affiliated concerns, came out strongly today against Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan's Industrial Conciliation Bill. The measure, now before Parliament, reserves certain occupations for specified races and enforces race segregation in trade unions.

THE umpires have a private signaling system of their own in order to guide each other on decisions. It's only used when one is caught out of position or when his view is blocked or when unusual circumstances arise. He looks to another umpire for help and gets it so unobtrusively that no one else is aware of the fact that information has been exchanged.

ACCORDING to "The Oxford Dictionary of Quotations," that inexhaustibly fascinating and marvelously useful reference book, it was Mme. de Pompadour who said, "Apres nous le deluge." She may have, being an articulate as well as a pretty and an attractive woman. At any rate, Louis XV did not say it.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, June 1 (AP) -- A Brooklyn soldier injured May 16 in a fall on Mount McKinley was evacuated by Air Force helicopter early today and flown here for hospitalization.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., June 1 -- The two officers most intimately concerned with launching planes from the carrier Bennington expressed doubt today that last Wednesday's explosion could have been set off in the port catapult room.

Ninety-three students received degrees last night at commencement exercises of the New School for Social Research. Eleven doctor's degrees, fifty-six master's degrees and twenty-six bachelor's degrees were conferred.

MANCHESTER, England, June 1 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly flew in today for her first taste of British competition and her first work on grass courts this year and hardly gave the spectators time to see her in winning two matches in the Northern lawn tennis championships.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- Newspapers were recommended to the Seventh-Day Adventists' world convention today as a potentially unexcelled medium for spreading Christianity.
One hundred and sixty New York school children received $1,700 in bonds and cash yesterday as prize-winners in the 1954 annual essay contest of the New York State Chamber of Commerce.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

EAST MEADOW, L. I., June 1 -- First of a series of skin-drafting operations aimed at saving the life of 2-year-old Barbara Jackson, who was critically burned on May 16, was performed at Meadowbrook Hospital here today.

LONDON, June 1 -- Britain's action in reinstituting a state of emergency in Buganda, a province of Uganda Protectorate, was defended today by the Colonial Secretary, Oliver Lyttelton, as necessary "to protect the law-abiding public."
Surrogate Christopher C. McGrath of the Bronx advised ninety-four women graduates of the College of Mount St. Vincent yesterday that they would do well to consider politics as a career.

The Paramount Pictures Corporation in the second half of this year expects to deliver "a greater concentration of outstanding pictures and potential box-office hits than ever before," Barney Balaban, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
WORK in lighter media and early summer group shows make up quite a burst of art gallery activity for the first week of June. Work in various graphic media bulks large in the total.

India, world's largest producer of tea, always exports the leaf to this country in bulk. Processors here package it in the containers in which it is sold to consumers. Several retailers questioned by this department yesterday agreed that they never had offered an India-packed tea.
BOGOTA, Colombia, June 1 -- Officials of the International Petroleum Company here have confirmed that it would build a refinery on Cartagena Bay, at the terminal of its pipeline.

LONDON, June 1 -- The Government threw Britain's largest film distributing company, British Lion, into receivership today. The company, the Government said, had lost heavily in producing unsuccessful films.

A potpourri of summer fashions ranging from airy peignoirs, beach togs, casual clothes and town frocks to evening dresses was presented by Bonwit Teller yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Children's fashions for beach, play and dress also were included, bringing a steady round of applause for their charm and daintiness.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The forty witnesses who appeared before the special board in the Oppenheimer case constitute a "blue ribbon" roster of American science.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Government was warned tonight against giving undue weight to the nontechnical opinions of scientists who might be tortured by feelings of guilt for the part they played in unlocking the destructive power of the atom.

Following are the texts of documents released through Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer on the Findings and Recommendation of the United States Atomic Energy Commission's special Personnel Security Board in his case, as contained in a letter from the board to Maj. Gen. Kenneth D. Nichols, commission general manger; the dissent by Dr. Ward V. Evans, and an exchange of letters between General Nichols and Lloyd K. Garrison, counsel for Dr. Oppenheimer.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court today reversed the conviction of Camilio Weston Leyra, who is under sentence of death in Sing Sing Prison for the murder of his parents in their Brooklyn apartment early in 1950.

IN spring and summer birds pipe in the thick ivy and the white ramblers on the old stone house that stands high off the north side of East Sixty-first Street west of York Avenue. Industrial plants cruelly nudge it.

"Mr. Hulot's Holiday," a French-made comedy, starring Jacques Tati, will have its local premiere on Wednesday, June 16, at the Fine Arts Theatre, it was reported yesterday by G-B-D International Films, the distributors.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 1 -- The senior class of Whitewater, Kan., High School, enjoying the fruits of four years of fund-raising, reached Stevens Institute of Technology late today, completing the first half of its 3,500-mile bus tour of the East.

LONDON, June 1 -- The British Government considers the five-power military staff talks starting in Washington Thursday the first step toward a realistic Allied policy for the defense of Southeast Asia.
The city's theatre men stepped into a day of high drama at City Hall yesterday and became part of it.
The citations accompanying the thirty-four honorary degrees conferred yesterday by Columbia University follow:

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 1 -- An Eisenhower Administration task force opened hearings today on the Government's role in power developments in the South and was challenged immediately on whether it could hear evidence with impartiality.

RANGOON, Burma, June 1 (Reuters) -- Dwindling resistance among Burma's Karen rebels today brought about the formal proclamation of a new state covering about 1,800 square miles of northern Tenasserim in East Burma.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont compared Joseph R. McCarthy to Adolf Hitler today and denounced the Senator as a menace to the United States.
FOR many years rumors have been circulating in scattergun circles involving a new auto-loading shotgun being developed by Winchester, but today this gun becomes a fact rather than a gunsmith's fancy.

May I, as an Englishman who has been visiting this country for the past seven months, ask the courtesy of your columns to comment on two aspects of American life which chiefly disturb a foreigner today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower expressed distress today over the "very high highway fatalities" on the Memorial Day week-end and said something could be done about it if the nation put its mind to the problem.

YONKERS, June 1 -- Mrs. Sally Francis of Apawamis gained low gross honors in the Westchester division of a one-day Class A tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today. Making only three mistakes, Mrs. Francis turned in a two-over-par 36, 40 -- 76 over Dunwoodie's hilly terrain.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UP) -- Enactment of the St. Lawrence Seaway bill may lead to a new study of an inland waterway linking New York City with Canada, the State Department said today.

BOSTON, June 1 -- Sharp criticism of the Reece Congressional committee for "unfair" methods in its investigations into tax exempt foundations was voiced here today by District Grand Lodge No. 1 of B'nai B'rith.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The special board that investigated Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer as a security risk may have made its decision in mid-April.

GENEVA, June 1 -- The South Korean delegation to the Far Eastern conference is eager to have the Korean talks ended. But the members have no intention of unilaterally walking out before the expiration of their ninety-day deadline on July 26.

MILWAUKEE, June 1 -- Russ Meyer's mastery over the Braves was demonstrated emphatically again tonight when he shut them out for the third time in two seasons. The Dodgers won, 2 -- 0, and moved within four percentage points of first place, still held by Milwaukee.

DENVER, June 1 -- The outlawing of the Communist party in the United States was unanimously supported today by the General Federation of Womens Clubs. The federation's members also were urged to read Karl Marx' Communist Manifesto so they would know what they were opposing.

BALTIMORE, June 1 (AP) -- Ralph Branca pitched his third straight victory and drove in a run as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Orioles, 4-3, before 10,397 spectators tonight in the rubber game of their three-contest series.
People by the hundreds of thousand, words by the tens of thousand and paraders by the thousand were marshaled yesterday by the city to honor Haile Selassie I, Emperor of Ethiopia.

Two former Presidents of Cuba and a former member of the Cuban Senate were named here yesterday with fourteen others in a superseding indictment that charged the group with conspiracy to export ammunition and implements of war from the United States to Cuba in violation of this country's Neutrality Act.
The police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are seeking a 6-year-old girl who was believed kidnaped, her mother and another woman who had cared for the child the last two days.

The meager record of legislative accomplishment at this session of Congress was given a boost yesterday with House approval of a bill extending social security to an estimated ten million additional persons. The measure now goes to the Senate.

Lightness and brightness characterize a new collection of furniture designs introduced by Habitat Associates in a shop that opened yesterday at 235 East Fifty-eighth Street. The designs, the work of three experienced young men -- Paul Mayen, Warren Nardin and Albert Radoczy, -- use conventionl, contemporary materials in an unconventional way.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court dismissed today a suit that was brought to test the constitutionality of the Virgin Islands divorce laws.

There may be as many as 150,000 persons in unlicensed nursing homes for the elderly here, according to Dr. James M. Rosen, president of the New York City Nursing Home Association, Inc., a group of sixty-six licensed proprietary nursing homes.

Brilliant sunshine lighted up the Morningside Heights campus as Columbia University completed its 200th academic year yesterday. But the commencement oratory was filled with warnings against clouds and confusion that might weaken and divide the nation and the free world.

Despite new delays caused by the Indochina crisis the prospects of the European Defense Community continue to improve as a result of three European party conventions and one election, all of which have endorsed this project. The party conventions were those of the Socialists and Popular Republicans in France and the Christian Democratic Union in Germany, the latter the majority party of Chancellor Adenauer.
Arthur B. Bisguier, former national open champion, took the lead in the national chess tournament last night at the Marshall Club. He won from Karl Burger of Brooklyn in forty-three moves.

COLUMBIA, S. C., June 1 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes today advised South Carolina school administrators to maintain the status quo on the racial question this fall. He told them to ignore the "threats" of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, to employ Negro teachers for Negro schools and to refuse to admit Negro students to white schools.

LONDON, June 1 -- Duncan Sandys, Minister of Supply, told a luncheon of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce today that a little more money spent on judicious advertising of British goods might bring worthwhile returns.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:

The commencement exercises yesterday granting degrees to 6,500 graduates of Columbia University and the accompanying convocation this week bringing scores of distinguished guests from far and near constitute a climax but not a culmination of the university's bicentennial year.

Commodore C. Ivan Thompson, master of the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth, said after docking here yesterday that the presence of ice at points "further south than it has been since the war" had caused him to alter course on the voyage from Channel ports.
BERLIN, June 1 -- West Berlin is preparing to lure from their Communist hosts about 500,000 youths due to attend a youth festival in the Soviet sector of the city next week-end.
The changing relationship between boss and employe in the retail trade was sketched yesterday for the graduating class of the Tube-Coburn School for Fashion Careers.

Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan ruled yesterday that David N. Leff, an American citizen employed by the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organization, would have to return here from Paris and answer a grand jury subpoena.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A special Personnel Security Board of the Atomic Energy Commission has voted 2 to 1 against reinstating Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer as a consultant to the Government on atomic energy matters.

BUENOS AIRES, June 1 -- The Argentine Government and the Atlas Corporation have reached "an agreement in principle" on a twenty-five year oil development contract, Floyd Odlum, president of Atlas, said tonight.

HARRISON, N. Y., June 1 -- Joe Moore Jr., Century Country Club professional, and Bill Levkoff, home club amateur, carried off the top honors after a tie in the Westchester County's Golf Association pro-amateur tournament today.

Three Bronx youths were shot yesterday -- one of them fatally -- in a flare-up of a teen-age gang war apparently set off by a dispute over a girl. One of the victims is in serious condition in Fordham Hospital and the third youth has a bullet graze on the arm.
LONDON, June 1 -- The securities markets here were in the process of adjusting prices today to take account of the new Government loan.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- A charter of incorporation was issued today by the Secretary of State in Springfield, Ill., to For America, a new organization that expects to recruit more than 5,000,000 voters to combat internationalism, interventionism and communism.

The stock market closed generally higher yesterday with strength centered in the aircrafts and some selected issues. Gains were as much as 2 points in some instances, while losses generally were held within fractions.

HANOI, Vietnam, June 1 -- French tanks, artillery, infantry and planes today drove back Vietminh troops six miles from Phuly, key road junction thirty miles south of Hanoi, French Army headquarters announced.
PARIS, June 1 (UP) -- Ten United States golfers gained the third round of the French amateur championship today along with the defending champion Roger LaGarde of France.
All hail to the zinnia and the marigold! No matter whether they bloom or not a little later -- but bloom they surely will -- right now they are the most wonderful annuals in the garden.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 1 (AP) -- Three of four candidates endorsed by former Gov. James E. Folsom moved ahead of their opponents in scattered returns from today's Alabama Democratic runoff primary.

Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said yesterday that the United States build-up of atomic weapons had reached the point where more and more effort could be turned to peaceful uses.

The issue of "collective leadership" seems once again to be agitating the rulers in the Kremlin. Marshal Voroshilov made this a major theme of his recent Budapest speech; Pravda has again begun stressing this concept and attacking the "cult of personality"; and, perhaps most impressive, Pravda's latest front-page picture of the Kremlin's masters shows both Malenkov and Khrushchev waving their hats at the crowd.
The summery weather continued yesterday in New York and its environs.

ON the radio these evenings -- at 11:15 o'clock over WCBS -- there is a series of fine talks by Dr. Lyman Bryson, Professor Emeritus of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University. He is reporting on a trip through the Middle East and is bringing to the microphone a wise, observant and unhurried account of this confused, troubled and intriguing part of the world.
Two new school bond issues totaling $30,000,000 were sold in the public market yesterday by Los Angeles.

EPSOM, England, June 1 (AP) -- Johnny Longden prepared for tomorrows Epsom Derby with a well-maneuvered winning ride today in a tune-up race. The rolling Derby course and Tattenham Corner proved no puzzles for the cocky American.

LONDON, June 1 (Reuters) -- Two prominent conservative British newspapers joined today in praising President Eisenhower's plea for free world unity, voiced at a Columbia University bicentennial dinner yesterday.

Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, told the graduating class yesterday that to overcome the materialism, competition and hectic rush of life they must establish habits of living and thinking that would keep them alert and constantly growing.

CAIRO, June 1 -- Excavations beneath an unfinished step pyramid at the Sakkara necropolis were reported today to have reached the entrance to the royal burial chamber. There is reason to believe that the Third Dynasty tomb is intact.

Three companies and four of their officers were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government by selling 19,000 yards of Government-owned wool serge valued at $76,000.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -- Universal-International is preparing a sequel to "Mutiny on the Bounty" under the title of "The Island Story."

BRUSSELS, June 1 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia's Emil Zatopek shattered two more world distance records today -- completing a triple in as many days, when he ran the 10,000 meters in 28 minutes 4.2 seconds. He broke his own 10,000-meter and six-mile records in the same race.
For the second time in three months a local court has upheld the legality of the Drunkometer, an apparatus that ascertains the percentage of alcohol in a person's blood.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission has submitted to the White House a report described by the American Watch Manufacturers Association as calling for higher duties on imported jeweled watches and movements.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court upheld today a certificate granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission authorizing the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company to operate eastbound in intercoastal trade between Pacific and Atlantic Coast ports.

EDGEWATER, N. J., June 1 -- Between 200 and 300 new automobiles, along with three warehouses, two piers and the local Civil Defense headquarters, were destroyed this afternoon in the worst fire of this borough's history.

Yogi Berra and Andy Carey, who have been carrying a large part of the load for the Yankees, were out of action yesterday. Phil Rizzuto, another key operative, needed further rest. Gene Woodling and Mickey Mantle played, although they weren't fully up to physical scratch.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Children's Bureau disclosed today that it was putting $15,000 into Michigan's program to develop artificial arms and legs to fit children.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Children's Bureau disclosed today that it was putting $15,000 into Michigan's program to develop artificial arms and legs to fit children.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -- Promising to "return" the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes to its 60,000 members; Roy M. Brewer today formally declared he would run against Richard F. Walsh, incumbent international president, to the biannual election convention opening Aug. 9 in Cincinnati.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The economy of Pakistan is to be revolutionized by the piping of natural gas from reservoirs 350 miles north of Karachi.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Eisenhower declared today that he was prepared to stand up and fight right down the line for the principles of his farm program.

RYE, N. Y., June 2 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of Westchester and Mrs. Harold Kilpatrick of Silver Springs gained a two-stroke lead in the thirty-six-hole best-ball tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, pointing out that the case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer was not closed, declined today to comment on a special board's finding that the physicist was a security risk.

Representatives of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., will present a "bargaining pattern" this afternoon to begin negotiations covering shipyard workers of the Bethlehem Steel Company.
