The store building at 585 Columbus Avenue has been purchased by Freeman Estates, Inc., from the Unimer Realty Corporation, which recently erected the structure. The building, on plot 100 by 100 feet at the corner of Eighty-eighth Street, is occupied under lease by Safeway Stores, Inc.
Further rapid expansion of the frozen food industry was predicted yesterday at the Advertising Club.

Advertising is an optimistic business. When the economic barometer points to "stormy," advertising volume should go up to guard against the high winds, and when the weather is fair, space and time figures indicate advertisers want it to stay sunny.

NIAGARA FALLS, June 2 -- The first attempt in some 30,000 years to give Niagara's thundering but somewhat ragged falls a face lifting was formally dedicated here today by United States and Canadian officials.

THE Whitney Museum, long since having outgrown its part as the nuclear inspiration of art in Greenwich Village, has fittingly handed over temporarily to the Village Art Center the galleries of the building from which it is soon to move uptown.
PARIS, June 2 -- The recent outbreaks of violence in Morocco and Tunisia were linked with French reverses in Indochina during the Indochina debate today in the National Assembly.
A pound of coffee is said to produce forty cups. With the use of a new powdered product called Buisman's Famous Dutch Flavoring, one pound of coffee gives eighty cups.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 2 -- Israel has drawn up her own plan for developing the resources of the Jordan River valley in collaboration with the Arab states.
The Paramount Theatre, a landmark in the heart of Times Square for nearly twenty-eight years, has offered its facilities on Monday evenings to a rival medium -- television.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- Demands for electric power by 1965 will be double those of today, and by 1975 it is reasonable to expect a three or even four-fold increase in the use of electric energy by the homes, farms, stores and factories in this nation.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported to Congress today that the United States had "gained a high state of preparedness against aggression" with atomic weapons.

The Yankees blasted Early Wynn and Don Mossi for six hits and seven runs in the first inning last night. Against four succeeding Cleveland pitchers the Bombers then went hitless and runless through the next nine frames and wound up by dropping an 8-7 decision to the Indians in the tenth.

The day's delay in City Council action on the 5 per cent amusement tax, while the legality and effect of certain exemptions are studied, gives the council an opportunity also to consider the feasibility of substituting good judgment for poor judgment on the whole tax problem.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 2 -- Marymount College awarded degrees today to ninety-seven young women at its thirty-first commencement. Members of the graduating class were from twelve states and five countries.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate Finance Committee has rejected a set of proposed statutory standards for determining whether company pension, profit-sharing and stock bonus plans are entitled to special tax advantages.

Walter Thornton, publisher of a directory of child candidates for jobs as models, was cleared yesterday of operating a "racket." Judge Peter T. Farrell in Queens County Court, Jamaica, granted a defense motion for dismissal of charges of conspiracy and grand and petit larceny against Thornton and five women associates.

ST. LOUIS, June 2 -- The Giants, eager to get moving in the steaming National League pennant race, found themselves stalled again tonight Rain washed out the opener of their two-game series with the Cardinals to give the Polo Grounders their second successive postponement. Rain had kept them idle in Pittsburgh last night.

TRENTON, June 2 -- Gov. Robert. B. Meyner, trapping all twenty Democratic Assemblymen in his office by a conversational ruse, today blocked passage of bills that would have granted an immediate increase of $28,500,000 in state aid to schools.

Public offering is being made today of 1,000,000 common shares of Scudder Fund of Canada, Ltd., a new investment company, by a group of underwriters headed by Lehman Brothers. The fund was formed last year by the investment counsel firm of Scudder, Stevens Clark.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A Congressional investigating committee was told today that only a fraction of 1 per cent of some 32,000 educational foundations had been found straying from the purposes that won them exemption from paying taxes.

The recent introduction of new sound techniques at the American Museum of Natural History is a reminder that the museum, far from being a dull and dusty warehouse of relics, is a place of spirit and change.

Featuring Vicki Cummings, Roddy McDowell and Paul Roebling, "The Homeward Look," a domestic comedy by Effie Young and Ernest Pagano, will open tonight at the Theatre de Lys, 121 Christopher Street, at 8 o'clock:
Warnings against a strike or a slowdown of the city-owned lines were sent yesterday by the Transit Authority to its 44,000 employes.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement made public by President Eisenhower at his new conference today covering recent Department of Justice activities against subversives:
The State Democratic Committee moved yesterday to establish a basis for charging Governor Dewey with responsibility for a 5 per cent tax on amusement admissions in New York City.
Max Pavey defeated Paul Brandts in thirty-seven moves last night in the fifth round of the national championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club.
The National City Bank of New York seems to think that the low point in whatever economic slump may be afflicting this country was reached in March.
A 14-year-old girl was beaten, stabbed and raped yesterday morning as she was leaving her East Side tenement home for a near-by parochial school.

LONDON, June 2 -- Trading in British Government issues, although it slackened today, was still heavy and dominated the securities markets. Medium and long term issues continued to rise and short-dated issues to decline, but movements in either direction were small.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 26, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
Heat waves soon will be only a happy memory for 170 men who left yesterday for about five months in iceberg country.

The need for business to provide satisfactory careers for young and capable people was emphasized yesterday by Theodore V. Houser, chairman of the board of Sears, Roebuck Co. He said this idea was basic under the American free society.

As the first chairman of the Long Island Transit Authority and former trustee in bankruptcy of the Long Island Raft Road I am tremendously interested in and pleased by the rehabilitation plan proposed by the authority and accepted by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- The House of Representatives passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate today a bill to let the Alabama Power Company produce hydro-electric power by building dams on the Coosa River in Northeast Alabama and Northwest Georgia.

DUBLIN, June 2 -- John A. Costello was elected Prime Minister of the Republic of Ireland today when the fifteenth Dail Eireann (Parliament) met after the general election. He was voted into office by 79 to 66.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, introduced a broad new anti-scandal proposal tonight on the eve of Senate debate on the Administration's housing bill.

GENEVA, June 2 -- A Soviet delegation took its seat at the International Labor Conference, which opened here today, and immediately began pressing for positions of influence within the International Labor Organization.
Dr. Edward U. Condon, former director of the National Bureau of Standards, confirmed last night that the Defense Department was studying his clearance for classified Government work.
BOSTON, June 2 -- The American Woolen Company election of April 23 may be invalidated, it was indicated today in Federal District Court.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 2 -- An Administration task force said today that it was not bound to support statements made by the President in the 1952 election campaign.

A proposal for a zoning amendment that would require most new non-residential construction to provide garage or off-street parking spaces was brought forward yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

The 2-to-1 decision by the Atomic Energy Commission's special Personnel Security Board denying restoration of security clearance to Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer focuses attention on the momentous debates in the winter of 1949-50.

An egg distribution-and-cost problem that has been plaguing many persons here since it was posed in a story in The New York Times a week ago brought in a flood of "solutions" last night after Arthur Godfrey presented the puzzle to television viewers.

NEW HAVEN, June 2 -- Eighteen men, all but one a graduate of the Berkeley Divinity School here, were ordained in the Protestant Episcopal priesthood in an unusual service at Trinity Church on the Green here today. Nine Bishops participated in the ceremony.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- President Eisenhower said today that his "dynamic, progressive" legislative program would "stand or fall at the polls" this November.

I witnessed both legs of President Eisenhower's journey through Manhattan from and to La Guardia Airport. There is no doubt that every precaution should be taken for his safety, and I believe this was the case.
The surest safeguard against treason is a system of government "so just and equitable that no one will wish to betray it," Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, declared last night.
Mrs. Frederick J. Woodbridge of 21 Claremont Avenue has been elected president of the Associate Alumnae of Barnard College.

Haile Selassie I, Emperor of Ethiopia, said last night the United Nations principle of collective security offers a better guarantee of world peace than any system of power politics, alliances or regional arrangements among the great powers.

Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf, a pioneer in the development of powder metallurgy, predicted yesterday that powdered metal techniques for making structural parts of titanium would be in widespread use in a few years.
For the first time in its forty-nine-year history the American Urological Association elected the son of a former president to that office.

CAIRO, June 1 -- Within a fortnight I am going to walk through the original entrance of the hull-shaped funerary chamber sealed by Pharaoh Cheops nearly 5,000 years ago and stand beside the solar boat he built to journey through the heavens at night.
Exactly 200 years ago today the people of "the province of New York" were officially notified for the first time that a new college was about to be established in their midst.

ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP) -- Jimmy Carter of New York, former lightweight champion, floored Charley Riley of St. Louis twice in the second round of their scheduled ten-round bout tonight, the last time for the full count of ten.
The flossiest-priced winner of the New York season won the fourth race at Belmont Park yesterday. A 5-year-old gelding named Idontknow was a $133.50-for-$2 proposition in that seven-furlong sprint.
Today's juvenile delinquent, compared with his counterpart of yesteryear -- the bully, the truant, the vandal -- has been described as an anti-social rebel caught in a whirl of tensions.
Twenty-four nations to date have entered film productions in the Fourth International Film Festival of Berlin to be held June 18 to 29, the Berlin Tourist Office announced yesterday.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 2 (AP) -- Miss Mamie 6-year-old mare owned by Paul Wixom of Chicago, tonight won the $3,500 Farmingdale Pace in 2:04 1/5, nosing out Vonian Chief at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Eisenhower called his legislative program today a "must" requirement that would get his exclusive attention.

Six performers have been signed for the basic cast of the "Robert Montgomery Summer Theatre" series on television. They are Jan Miner, Elizabeth Montgomery, Anne Seymour, John Newland, Vaughn Taylor and Cliff Robertson.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Following is the part of The Atomic Energy Commission's statement to the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy today dealing with the "Probable Course of Industrial Development of Economic Nuclear Power":
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) Roy M. Cohn said today he would not give the right time of day to former Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party of New York.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 2 -- Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh, Chief of Staff of the Vietnamese National Army, declared today that this army would soon enter a "new phase" in Indochina. He projected a picture of Vietnamese national troops taking the field in divisional rather than battalion strength in a protracted fight against the Communist-led Vietminh forces.

MILWAUKEE, Thursday, June 3 -- The Dodgers never achieved first place with more travail than they did today. They battled the Braves, the elements and the umpires for three hours and forty-five minutes and finally won a 7-6 decision in five innings.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- Allan McMahan of Fort Wayne, Ind., stressed here today that "the only object of the nation's book industry is to get good books into the hands of the public."

The removal of the New York Stock Exchange to Jersey City and the sponsorship of submarine bingo games by the American Stock Exchange are among the exclusive stories to be featured today by the Bawl Street Journal, dollar-a-copy satirical newspaper of the financial district.

The Allied Chemical Dye Corporation has completed negotiations for the acquisition of the outstanding stock of the Mutual Chemical Company of America, it was disclosed yesterday by Fred J. Emmerich, Allied president. Details of the stock transaction, subject to approval by Mutual shareholders, were not disclosed.

CINCINNATI, June 2 (AP) -- Curt Simmons tonight pitched the Phillies to a 7-0 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs. Three unearned runs in the sixth inning made it easy for Simmons to record his fifth triumph in nine decisions.
ATHENS, June 2 -- Marshal Tito arrived here today and with King Paul stressed the need of transforming the Balkan pact into an actual military alliance.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 2 -- A bill to repeal Louisiana's fair-trade law was withdrawn from the State Legislature today after an unfavorable report by the judiciary committee of the State's House of Representatives.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The District of Columbia Board of Education unanimously adopted today a two-year program to end public school segregation here.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in the twenty-fifth day of its hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

David S. Meister, real estate operator and investor, has sold the three-story business building at 30-93 Steinway Street in Astoria, Queens, to an investor through Murray Adler, broker. Walzer Walzer were attorneys for the seller.
GUATEMALA, June 2 -- The Guatemalan Government will use all its means to smash the "best organized plot in the history of the country," Interior Minister Augusto Charnaud MacDonald said today.

Paul Seligman, a teacher at Public School 42, the Bronx, who has been charged with lying concerning alleged Communist affiliations, received a temporary stay of his trial yesterday by order of Lewis A. Wilson, Commissioner of Education.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The record of the Administration in rooting out communists is an impressive one, President Eisenhower said to his news conference today.

NO doubt about it: June is really busting out all over. "Carousel" has turned up at the City Center, where it opened last evening, and the musical season is now at high noon. For this is the most glorious of the Rodgers and Hammerstein works.
The Senate Rules Committee shelved last week a proposed concurrent resolution that might have improved and protected the intelligence services of the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Substantial United States military assistance will begin to flow to Honduras and Nicaragua in about a month, defense officials reported today.

A decrease of 1,697,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Saturday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week's end, supplies were 172,855,000 barrels, compared with 174,552,000 a week earlier and 150,810,000 a year ago.

"No Tears for Tony" is the name of a play that opened on Tuesday night for a short engagement at the Provincetown Playhouse in Greenwich Village. The central character is a real bounder. There is no question about that.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service is considering the abandonment of Ellis Island as a detention station for immigrants and other aliens awaiting final clearance to enter this country or undergoing deportation proceedings.

PARIS, June 2 -- The $14,286 raised at the April in Paris Ball in New York this spring was distributed here tonight to six French charities. The distribution was made at a dinner party at Maxim's restaurant attended by C. Douglas Dillon, United States Ambassador to France.

The U. S. O.-Camp Shows troupe has just headed for another lonely outpost. Pvt. Wlliam Copeland of Silver Springs, Md., took pencil in hand and wrote his mother about the show. "Really," he summed up, "they do a great job.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Senator Symington of Missouri, a member of the Mundt subcommittee who has revealed during its hearings the ability -- not common in this group -- to clarify an issue, managed today to do this with respect to one dispute in which thousands of cloudy words have been uttered.

When the special Personnel Security Board of the Atomic Energy Commission began hearings on the case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer this newspaper observed that "no matter what the decision * * * the nation can have confidence that the case is being considered by men of experience, judgment and integrity."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy stirred a new controversy with the Eisenhower Administration today by charging serious Communist infiltration in the Central Intelligence Agency and in plants making hydrogen and atomic weapons.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Eisenhower said today he had not decided whether to ask Congressional authority for armed intervention by the United States in Southeast Asia.
A "bridge" that blind children may use to join the sighted community was dedicated last night.
A Coast Guard hearing into the foundering Tuesday morning of the tugboat Brooklyn was held yesterday. Witnesses said the craft heeled over suddenly and was beyond help in a matter of minutes.

The Whirlpool Corporation, St. Joseph, Mich., world's largest manufacturer of home laundry equipment, announced yesterday a $41.95 reduction in the price of its cheapest 1954 automatic washer. The suggested retail price of the company's model AA-40 is new $188 -- down from $229.95.

THE United States Open is less than a fortnight away and it should create more than the usual excitement in our thriving village. The golf championship will take place at Baltusrol in suburban New Jersey, virtually a mashie shot from Time Square. Oh, all right. Maybe it's more than a mashie shot. But there might be a strong following wind.
PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (UP) -- Joe Coleman scored his second straight victory over the Athletics tonight as he pitched the Orioles to an easy 9-1 triumph tat Connie Mack Stadium.
DEVON, Pa., June 2 (AP) -- A 22-year-old Charlottesville, Va., rider was knocked unconscious today in a fall from her horse at the annual Devon horse show.

PARIS, June 2 (AP) -- Three Americans, one a 65-year-old retired banker, swept into the quarter-finals in the French amateur golf tournament today along with two former French champions, one Canadian and one Briton.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that the Eisenhower Administration "is headed in the right direction" in rooting Communists out of the Government.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., June 2 -- The 38,000-ton tanker Statue of Liberty, second of four large oil carriers being constructed for the Cities Service Company and the Grand Bassa Tankers, Inc., was launched here today in the yards of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

THE weather that has made life pleasant and fishing productive on the trout streams has been received with equal delight by the salt water anglers, and reports from up and down the coast indicate that the variety and abundance of fish is increasing daily.
MADRID, June 2 -- Generalissimo Rafael Trujillo Molina, head of the Dominican Government, landed today at Vigo for an official visit.

McALESTER, Okla., June 2 (AP) -- Prison gates opened on a bright new world today for a convicted burglar whose behind-the-walls baseball feats landed him an early parole and a chance at the big leagues, thanks to the New York Yankees.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse, as required by White House rules:...
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:
TOKYO, June 2 -- The Japanese Legislature finally enacted today bills establishing a new national Army, Navy and Air Force.
MANCHESTER, England, June 2 (AP) -- American women virtually took over the northern lawn tennis is tournament today in the quarter-final stage and two Americans in men's singles survived.
Governors of the American Stock Exchange yesterday approved fines aggregating $500 imposed on two specialists for "failing to exercise due diligence" in opening the market for a stock on May 25 last.

The unsightly backyard trash can and the insects that it attracts are apt to be a more pressing problem in warm weather than at other times of the year. One solution is the home incinerator, relatively a newcomer to the appliance field and recently available in the New York area.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, June 2 (AP) -- Production of extra-wide tapered aluminum sheet and plate for the aircraft industry was begun today on the world's largest tapered sheet rolling mill at the Davenport Works of the Aluminum Company of America.

CAIRO, June 1 -- The swift progress of the investigation of the two funerary solar barks that Pharaoh Cheops sealed beside his Great Pyramid 5,000 years ago seems only a little less remarkable than the discovery itself.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Two more bidders were added today to the list of fifty-four seeking Government-owned synthetic rubber production plants.
A 32-year-old man, described by the police as "the brains" of Westchester County's "party bandits," was arrested last night in front of a tavern at 160th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.
The 500-family war housing development of Redbank Village in South Portland, Me., has been sold by the Public Housing Administration to a syndicate of New Jersey realty investors for $1,300,150.
TOKYO, June 2 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida will spend $80,000 on his trip to the United States and the Western free nations, Japan was informed today.
PARIS, June 2 -- Two Socialists voted today with a majority of the External Relations Committee of the Assembly of the French Union against the European Defense Community Treaty.

SYRACUSE, June 2 -- The editor and publisher of The Watertown Times said tonight "if the dairy industry would devote as much attention to promoting the importance of milk to the national economy as it does to the promotion of milk for health, there would be a prospect of a happier day for the farmer."

New York City's department store sales during 1954 have out-performed those of all other major urban areas in the Second Federal Reserve District except Rochester. This was determined by an analysis released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Activity increased yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Zinc registered the second highest volume of the year and cocoa had the fourth largest number of daffy sales. Prices closed generally higher, with coffee, cocoa, zinc, tin, copper, lead, rubber, hides and potatoes higher; wool, soybean oil, burlap and silk lower, and sugar and cottonseed oil mixed.

Sales and earnings of the Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., and its domestic consolidated subsidiary declined in the quarter and nine months ended April 30 from the corresponding periods of the previous year.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Following is the 42-to-40 roll-call vote by which the Senate adopted a proposal to add $35,000,000 to the Rural Electrification Administration's loan authority:
ROME, June 2 -- The national Monarchist party was split last night, and the dissidents are forming a Popular Monarchist party.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 2 -- For the first time in the United Nations history, an election was settled today by drawing lots. The winner was Dr. Miguel Rafael Urquia of El Salvador, who succeeds Leslie Knox Munro of New Zealand as president of the Trusteeship Council.
Saginaw, Mich., received bids yesterday for $5,000,000 of sewer revenue bonds maturing from June 1, 1958 to 1984.
The American Federation of Labor longshoremen's union announced yesterday that it would file objections today to last week's inconclusive waterfront election.
JERUSALEM, June 2 -- Hebrew University began today to build a second home on a stony ridge in the heart of Jerusalem's New City.

A much-disputed block of 800,000 shares of stock, voted for Robert R. Young in the proxy fight for control of the New York Central Railroad, has been included in the official tally by the inspectors of election.

ATHENS, June 2 (AP) -- Marshal Tito and Premier Papagos will start their conferences tomorrow on the proposed military alliance. Italy has expressed opposition to such a pact before her dispute with Yugoslavia over Trieste is settled.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The House Veterans' Committee today cleared the Disabled American Veterans of any fund-raising irregularities.
The regional Red Cross Blood Program has set a quota of 14,000 pints of blood for June, T. Morgan Williams, program chairman, announced yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures moved 4 points higher to 14 points lower yesterday. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was light.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Turkey is expected to press for United States support of an extension of the Middle East defense alliance.
CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, June 2 -- The dispute within the Conservative party over the proposal to increase the pay of members of the House of Commons led today to the repudiation of Sir Winston Churchill's party leadership by Sir John Mellor, a veteran member of Parliament.

MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., June 2 -- The self-styled "most pampered pilot in the world" took off and landed an experimental Navy plane on its tail today. The vertically ascending and descending aircraft, the Navy's new "pogo stick," the XFY-1, was harnessed with a series of cables.

The New York Times of May 26 contained a report that P. A. M. Dirac, professor at Cambridge University, England, had been refused a visa under State Department regulation 212A. The undersigned individuals, American physicists, believe this action is exceedingly unfortunate for science and for our country.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UP) -- Dean Stone, a rookie, pitched the Washington Senators to a 7-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight before 4,567 spectators, including Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, hero of Korea.

MILWAUKEE, Thursday, June 3 -- When Jackie Robinson was banished from the Dodgers-Braves game after he had come to bat in the fifth inning early today he tossed his bat toward the dugout after concluding his argument with Lee Ballanfant, plate umpire.
BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- Timely clutch pitching by Frank Sullivan and Ellis Kinder, relief pitcher, stemmed Chicago's late-inning bids tonight as the Boston Red Sox defeated the White Sox, 5 -- 2.

RENO, Nev., June 2 (AP) -- Former Gov. Vail Pittman, 70-year-old Democratic campaigner who will again oppose the man who unseated him in 1950, declared today he would defeat Gov. Charles Russell strictly on issues in the November election.
GENEVA, June 2 -- Virtually no progress was made here today at political and military discussions of ways to end the Indochina war.

DENVER, Colo., June 2 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director of the Foreign Operations Administration, called on the General Federation of Women's Clubs today for faith in President Eisenhower and his policies.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 19 -- Paraguay is expected to join soon the growing list of Latin countries attempting to attract private capital by special laws.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 2 (UP) -- Four labor leaders accused of consistent opposition to any settlement of the strike of United Fruit workers were reported today to have been arrested at La Lima.

The eyes of the world are on the United States. The stand taken by Governor Talmadge or any other official of Southern states will make or break the United States in its task of bringing sound democracy to the world.

Wonder as to the sanity "of citizens who plead for the admission of every Communist clergyman who wants to come to the United States," was expressed yesterday here by Dr. Kenneth R. Kinney, president of the American Council of Christian Churches.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 1 -- Eleven Pakistanis were arrested in a round-up early today of "Communists and other subversive elements" in Karachi.
A great choice of summer shoe styles, colors and materials is available for city sidewalks, life in the country, travel and beach wear.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare says that by April 30 it had dismissed or otherwise eliminated 238 security risks, including 114 suspected subversives.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 2 -- Mrs. Reinert Torgerson of Cherry Valley scored hen first victory of the Women's Long Island Golf Association season today. She beat sixty other players at the Meadow Brook Club course for the low gross prize.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Clarence B. Randall, chairman of Inland Steel Company and special consultant to President Eisenhower on foreign economic policy, today urged American business men to forget their own worries and devote themselves to their country's problems.
Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby advised girl graduates yesterday to cultivate their enthusiasms, which she called as important for a rich life as "the sense for logic or a taste for poetry or music."
Late afternoon declines wiped out morning gains in the stock market and prices closed virtually unchanged yesterday.

LONDON, June 2 -- The British Government refused in Parliament today to reopen the case of Admiral Sir Dudley North, who was relieved as top British admiral in the Mediterranean in 1940 for having allowed six French warships to slip past Gibraltar and escape to Dakar.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 2 -- A British spokesman took the initiative today in raising the thorny topic of Nationalist China's right to send a delegate to a United Nations meeting. The issue was raised "for the record."

EPSOM, England, June 2 -- Never Say Die, a stouthearted chestnut colt foaled in Kentucky and owned by Robert Sterling Clark of New York, burst out of the pack a furlong from the finish today to win the 175th running of the mile-and-a-half Epsom Derby.
BIRMINGHAM, June 2 (AP) -- Returns today narrowed the gap in a heated race for Alabama Attorney General and left the results hanging on the official canvass next week.
T. C. Gray, formerly director of engineering, has been elected vice president in charge of engineering of the Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 2 -- The United Nations' top staff appeals board has refused to reinstate a United States citizen who was dismissed for refusing to answer questions about reports that he had worked for the Communist party.

YONKERS, June 2 -- The New John Wanamaker store in the Cross County Center here was dedicated today by company officers. Only a network of steel now, the structure is to be completed in time for Christmas trade.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., June 2 -- Athletic games in the playground at the Marshall Public School here are being played this week with an air of solemnity. Soccer, softball and handball participants keep this important injunction in mind. The balls must not strike the signal and fire-alarm bell on a red brick wall. For it is there that a family of sparrows has its nest.

The courtesies of the situation required that the Transit Authority members accept Mayor Wagner's invitation to City Hall to talk over the labor emergency. They did meet with the Mayor for two hours, and they departed pledging to reconsider their rejection of certain important union demands.

Directors of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company of Hartford yesterday announced their approval of final plans for the company's new home- office headquarters to be created in Bloomfield, a short distance from Hartford.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- President Eisenhower made these main points at his news conference this morning:
The Interstate Commerce Commission has taken up V. Petrov Gopcevic's complaint against reserving coach seats for card-players on the 5:10 from Grand Central to New Canaan, Conn.

As the Geneva conference drags on, with no decisions in sight on either Indochina or Korea, the problem of the defense of Southeast Asia is being raised in three other forums. These three are the United Nations, a military staff meeting in Washington and the French National Assembly.
Opponents of James A. Roe, Queens Democratic leader, declared yesterday they had the votes in sight to oust Mr. Roe as chairman of the executive committee of the Queens County Democratic Committee.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Wheat prices moved up sharply early today, continuing the recovery started yesterday, but selling took over and the grain ended with a loss. Buyers were chary of following upturns with the crop picture as good as it is at present.

Ninety-two graduates of the State University Maritime College at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx received baccalaureate degrees and licenses as merchant marine officers yesterday afternoon at the nautical school's eightieth anniversary commencement exercises.
A new four-year contract pro-i viding a wagq increase of $2.50 a week for 11,000 building service employes in 1,200 Manhattan apartment houses was announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 -- Under a canopy of gray, moist clouds a caravan of 100 motion-picture workers, including actors, set out from here shortly after 6 A. M. today for Vasquez Rocks, a picturesque area of semi-desert near the south rim of Angeles National Forest, forty miles northeast of here.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- United States wholesalers sold $8,700,000,000 worth of goods in April, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen, Director of Foreign Operations said today he would dismiss any employe who gave unauthorized information to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
EAST MEADOW, L. I., June 3 -- The eighteen-day battle to save critically burned little Barbara Jackson ended tonight in defeat.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- St. John's Church on Lafayette Square celebrated today the acquisition of a "new" parish house through an unusual transaction. The other party in the transaction was the American Federation of Labor.
The new $1,300,000 ramp from the George Washington Bridge to the southbound lanes of the Henry Hudson Parkway was closed yesterday because of cracks in an overhanging retaining wall.
DENVER, June 3 -- Gradual reduction of trade barriers among nations of the world was called for today by the General Federation of Women's Clubs.
Check transactions at twenty-five principal cities of the nation in the short business week ended on Wednesday were $16,342,319,000, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

When the Transport Workers Union sends hundreds of men to picket the offices of Schenley Industries in the Empire state Building simply because a Schenley vice president happens to be the unpaid chairman of the New York City Transit Authority it certainly raises the question how secondary a secondary boycott can get.
THOSE who feel they will be unable to smile between tomorrow and Monday unless they spend the week-end fishing have an opportunity to indulge in wide grins on both fresh and salt water.

June brings an abundance of cantaloupes. The salmon-fleshed fruit with netted rind, now arriving from Arizona, California, Texas and Florida, is high on the list of foods to be plentiful throughout the nation this month.

Testimonial technique will be used in a new drive, without brand names, to promote cigar-smoking. Copy will run in the Sunday sports sections of newspapers in ninety-eight markets throughout the country, beginning June 13.

President Eisenhower's statement that he intends to fight for the principles of his farm program is heartening to all who have been dismayed by the thought that politics might win out over principle in this crucial year for farm policy. Those who think a Congressional election year is no time to adopt a new farm policy that might alienate some farmer votes have been urging "compromise."

Activities are expected to start once more toward the erection of a gigantic arts center, first proposed by Columbia University six years ago. The original announcement of 1948 was the outgrowth of four years of discussion. It said a fifteen-story building would be put up in the Morningside Heights neighborhood for the purpose of housing a couple of theatres in addition to schools of drama, music, architecture, painting, sculpture and allied fields.
Several thousand bees swarmed on a "limited parking" sign yesterday in the Inwood section of Manhattan and remained there long after a meter had clearly marked their presence as a parking violation.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, June 3 -- The Netherlands and her Western Hemisphere territories agreed today on granting the latter status above colonies but considerably short of dominions.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 3 (AP) -- Ernest Duke won the Oyster Bay pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:03 4-5. The winner beat Due Date by a half-length. Uhleen Fingo was third in the mile test.

The state and city health commissioners announced yesterday a new policy for distributing gamma globulin for poliomyelitis. The change in program was adopted because of the disappointing results of last year's experience with the blood fraction.

AL LOPEZ, the heap big chief of the Cleveland Indians, has always been a cheerful, pleasant guy. But there's a new air of confidence to him this season, almost as if he already had ambushed that unwary old frontiersman, Charles Dillon Stengel, and hung up that graying scalp on his wigwam wall.

LONDON, June 3 -- The British Labor party delegation going to Communist China this summer is to sound out the possibilities of friendly intercourse and fruitful cooperation, Aneurin Bevan, leader of the party's radical left wing, explained today.

THE Arts Center of the University of Arkansas is a notable source of light and progressive learning in that region of the country. Visiting artists and writers from many parts of the United States have lectured and taught there, and now the Bertha Schaefer Gallery is holding an exhibition of painting and sculpture by members of the permanent teaching staff.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 3 -- Robert LeBaron, assistant to Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson, said here today that atomic weapons and peacetime nuclear power were not rivals but "partners in our struggle for survival."
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The State Department strongly denounced today the "widespread persecution" of Jews in Communist Rumania.
The appointment of Walter M. Stankiewicz as deputy collector in charge at Newark was announced yesterday by Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs at the Port of New York.

LONDON, June 3 -- Britain's "Big Twelve" fashion designers have taken the bit in their teeth this year. For the first time in history, all the top English couturiers will show models from their latest collections at a horse race.
The main charges in the Army - McCarthy controversy now before a Senate investigating subcommittee are:
INDIANAPOLIS, June 3 (AP) -- Headquarters of the International Typographical Union said today that Woodruff Randolph had been re-elected president by a 500-vote margin over George ante of Chicago.

TELEVISION set owners who have tuned in Channel 9 during the daytime this week may have been puzzled by the weird pictures and strange sounds received over the air. There is no need to call the service man; the transmissions are a further test of a potentially intriguing new video service -- subscription television.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Senate gave another legislative victory to President Eisenhower today by approving the bulk of his housing program.

The price of zinc rose 1/2 cent a pound yesterday to 11 cents, East St. Louis basis -- the best level since last September. The quotation had been edging higher since early March when it was quoted at a four-year low of 9 1/4 cents a pound.
American universities must protect the heterodox since it may become the orthodox of the morrow, Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University, warned yesterday.
CLOSING its season with a diverse group exhibition, the Curt Valentin Gallery has brought together examples of modern European painting and sculpture.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 -- Five thunderous home runs, three by Henry Thompson, the other two by Willie Mays enabled the Giants to bring down the Cardinals tonight, 13 to 8, in the only game played in the series.
The American Federation of Labor's dock union scrapped last night its announced plan to protest last week's indecisive waterfront election.

Abraham Lincoln dethroned Boys High yesterday as the city Public Schools Athletic League outdoor track and field champions at Randalls Island. Lincoln tallied 29 points, three more than its Brooklyn rival.

MANCHESTER, England, June 3 (UP) -- America's women tennis stars, led by Maureen Connolly, set up an All-American singles semi-final today at the northern grass court tournament and Hugh Stewart carried the United States' hopes into the men's semi-finals.

The earth's most abundant chemical element was identified less than two centuries ago, and the two men who were chiefly responsible for finding it were severely persecuted by their respective countries for political heresy: one by death on the guillotine, the other by exile to the United States.

Acting Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Joseph ruled yesterday that the Eastman Kodak Company was entitled to enforce its fair trade agreements with retailers, even though the company was in the retail business itself.
MOSCOW, June 3 (AP) -- The editor and assistant editor of the magazine October, published by the Union of Soviet Writers, have been dismissed for a "gross political mistake," the union said today.

KAMPALA, Uganda, June 3 (Reuters) -- Britain today ousted eight tribal chiefs in Buganda province in her drive to subdue a growing wave of anti-British feeling in the East African protectorate of Uganda.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 3 -- Book editors and retail book store representatives concluded here today that when it came to reading the public had very definite taste -- not only adults but children too.

MILWAUKEE, June 3 -- Jackie Robinson and the Brooklyn Baseball Club may become defendants in a damage suit as a result of Robinson's bat tossing in the Dodgers-Braves game that was called by rain early today after five innings.

Conflicting court decisions on home air conditioning units have caused the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission to follow one policy for New York and the Bronx and another for the three other counties.

Reflecting a 26 per cent decline in sales, the net income of the International Harvester Company for the six months ended April 30 dropped to $16,949,000 from $25,705,000 in the similar period a year earlier.

Women of New York and adjacent communities are active in the plans for the National Golf Day tournaments to be held tomorrow on private and public golf courses throughout the country for the benefit of the United Service Organizations.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 3 (AP) -- Rowing crews of the United States and Russia will oppose each other during the Henley regatta, which will be held from June 30 to July 3.

The statement that Chairman Strauss of the Atomic Energy Commission has filed with the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy does all that can be done at present in predicting the immediate future of atomic power.

WORKMEN digging a foundation for a new house on the Dodge estate on Independence Avenue in Riverdale bit into a vein of pale amethyst the other day. Dr. Frederick H. Pough, former curator of minerals at the American Museum of Natural History, who lives in the street, seemed astonished at the find.
The bill to impose a 5 per cent tax on amusement admissions and charges was passed yesterday by the City Council. The vote was 22 to 3.

CAIRO, June 3 -- The solar boat of the night that Pharaoh Cheops built to carry him through the heavens nearly 5,000 years ago was unsealed for the third time today to give the world a photographic look at it.

In his letter published May 22 Michael F. Parrino asserts that Senator McCarthy is leading a fight to recapture our national independence and dignity. If one could assume that this is the Senator's real objective and could dismiss the more clearly evident attempt at political self-aggrandizement, it would still be difficult to reconcile so noble an aim with the dubious tactics employed in trying to reach it.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- John Foster Dulles told Congress today that negotiations with Russia for a peacetime atomic pool was near the break-off point and that there was the "utmost urgency" to share atomic weapon information with our allies.

A spirited public hearing before the City Council's General Welfare Committee resulted yesterday in a threat to eject James C. Quinn, secretary-treasurer of the Central Trades and Labor Council, A. F. L., from the chamber. The wrangle, however, fizzled out before the threat was made good.

Rumors about merger discussions between Studebaker Corporation and Packard Motor Car Company have been sifted to the point where the remaining facts may be characterized as "true but premature." Wall Street informants who should know declare that three of the investment banking houses that managed Studebaker's 1934 reorganization have interested themselves in the problem.
There was a lot of telephoning to WE 6-1212 from the Wall Street area late yesterday afternoon before the financial district's bond experts headed for the office elevators.
Kidney tuberculosis, which may spread unsuspected in patients who formerly had tuberculosis of the lungs, is being treated successfully with a combination of streptomycin and isoniazid.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The military and foreign policy leaders of the Senate received from Gen. James A. Van Fleet today a gloomy report of the free world's position in the Far East.

Dr. Otto Klineberg, Professor of Social Psychology at Columbia University, urged child development specialists yesterday to broaden their research to include more study of similarities and differences in child rearing practices throughout the world.

CINCINNATI, June 3 (AP) -- Dave Douglas of Grossinger, N. Y., gained a one-stroke lead today in the opening round of the fifty-first Western open golf championship. He shot a 35, 33 -- 68, three under par, on the Kenwood Country Club's rain-swept 6,766-yard course.

Changes in bus service arising from the conversion of Seventh and Eighth Avenues to one-way operation were announced yesterday by the New York City Omnibus Corporation. The new routing will go into effect at 8 A. M. Sunday simultaneously with the shift to one-way flow.

A new theory of the development of capitalism is expounded in Anatol Murad's "Private Credit and Public Debt" which Public Affairs Press of Washington will issue later this month. Mr. Murad, Professor of Economics at Rutgers University, contends that American manpower is not sufficient to utilize existing productive capacity.

Golf's top professionals and amateurs will be among the 1,904 competitors who will try to qualify over the thirty-six-hole route at thirty-two sites around the country on Monday for the United States open championship.
GENEVA, June 3 -- Chou En-lai, Communist China's Premier, rejected today United Nations supervision of an Indo-China armistice.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Expectation of bearish crop estimates caused free selling of wheat early, but there was good recovery after a private forecast estimated the crop of winter wheat at 730,000,000 bushels. However, buying demand was not impressive on the rallies until late in the session, when there was active support.
The New York Central Railroad Company yesterday dropped a court suit involving the 800,000 shares of stock bought by two of Robert R. Young's supporters in February.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- A pair of costly errors by Ray Boone and Charlie Kress helped Washington score all its runs and defeat Detroit, 4 -- 3, tonight behind the eight-hit pitching of Mickey McDermott

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 3 -- Banks must increase service charges to maintain adequate earnings under present conditions of low interest rates and rising operating costs, according to representative New York bankers.
The Board of Education voted yesterday to name Public School 34, now under construction at Avenue D and East Twelfth Street, for Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday that he had sent a letter to Mayor Wagner proposing a change in the city charter to eliminate two high departmental posts -- those of secretary of the department and one deputy commissioner.
PARIS, June 3 -- Gen. Paul Ely, Chief of Staff of the French land forces, was named Commander in Chief and High Commissioner in Indochina at a special Cabinet meeting tonight.
BERLIN, June 3 -- Moscow is still milking East Germany on a massive scale even though collection of reparations officially ended Jan. 1, a United States report said today.

GUATEMALA, June 3 -- The Government granted safe conduct passes today for several persons who had taken political asylum at E1 Salvador's and Ecuador's Embassies. The request for asylum followed a series of raids and arrests by the police in connection with a plot the Government announced it had discovered aimed at the overthrow of the Arbenz regime.
The Yankees gained a measure of revenge for their galling defeat of the night before by edging the league-leading Indians in a 2-1 thriller before 15,141 spectators at the Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, predicted tonight that "a blueprint for cooperation" between Congress and the Executive Branch of Government in fighting corruption and subversion would be one result of the McCarthy-Army hearings.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A member of Congress appeared in court on crutches today and told how he was crippled during a shooting affray in the House of Representatives on March 1.

GENEVA, June 3 -- The United States would like to end the discussions on Korea here next week. However, this plan is meeting serious opposition from several delegations, especially those from the British Commonwealth countries.
The threat of a transit strike June 14 was diminished yesterday as the Transit Authority offered to make peace with unions representing its 44,000 employes.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Eisenhower's chief economic adviser said today the Administration did not view the present level of unemployment as a situation to be accepted indefinitely.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Three of the Atomic Energy Commission's five members spoke out today against any increase in the powers of their chairman, Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss.

BRING back "The Three Penny Opera," and fast! Through last Sunday night the Kurt Weill classic was delighting everyone, including the hospitable ushers and the box office treasurer of the Theatre de Lys, where it had been happily in residence since March 10.
Meat prices this week offer some comfort to housewives watching their pennies.

VIENNA, June 3 -- A Belgian plane loaded with pure-bred pigs was fired on today over Yugoslavia near the Hungarian frontier. Crewmen said a Soviet-made MIG had raked the transport with cannon fire, killing the radio officer and wounding the pilot and mechanic, all Belgians.
A domestic airline in this country has placed an order for British-built, turbine-powered planes, and their delivery is scheduled for early next year.

Eduardo Lausse of Buenos Aires will be shooting for his seventeenth consecutive triumph when he meets Joe Rindone of Boston in a ten-round middleweight fight at Madison Square Garden tonight. It will be the Argentine fighter's first showing in the Garden.
Carmine D. DeSapio, leader of Tammany and Democratic National Committeemen, has stopped definitely into the movement to oust James A. Roe as Queens Democratic leader.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 -- President Eisenhower received an unusual tribute today from several thousand delegates and visitors to the Seventh-Day Adventists' world convention.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- During the week ended June 2, member bank reserves decreased $143,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday. Prices closed unchanged to points lower than on Wednesday.

ALBANY, June 3 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the state was entitled to collect a $36,826 contempt fine imposed twenty-two years ago on a financial agent for former Mayor James J. Walker. The vote was 4 to 3.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Re-examination of all drivers in Connecticut and more drastic motor vehicle laws in New York to rid roads of chronic violators were urged today.

While Larry Evans, the titleholder, was engaged in a stern struggle with Nicholas Rossolimo, former French champion, in the sixth round of the national championship at the Marshall Chess Club last night, Arthur B. Bisguier took the lead with a score of 4 1/2 -- 1 1/2.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- Following is the text of an address today before the United Nations Security Council by Pote Sarasin, Thailand's Ambassador to the United States:

ATHENS, June 3 (Reuters) -- Marshal Tito, President of Yugoslavia, and Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, Premier of Greece, reached "complete agreement" today on plans for an alliance with Turkey to block possible southward aggression by the Soviet Union or her satellites.
PARIS, June 3 (AP) -- Clarke Hardwicke, Los Angeles oil man, will play France's Henri De LaMaze, a four-time winner, tomorrow in the 36-hole final of the French amateur golf championship.

ALBANY, June 3 -- State Controller J. Raymond McGovern declared today there was "absolutely no need" for New York City to levy a 5 per cent amusement tax, or any other new taxes, to balance its 1954-55 budget.

Despite obstacles and hesitations, the effort initiated by the United States to organize the free world for self-defense against creeping Communist aggression has led to three new and promising developments.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3 -- At exercises tomorrow, 854 students of the United States Naval Academy will be graduated.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics pounded two Baltimore pitchers for fourteen hits and a 6-2 victory tonight as Marion Fricano, a right-hander, went the route for the first time this season before 2,187 fans, smallest night crowd of the year at Connie Mack Stadium.

QUONSET POINT, R. I., June 3 -- A Navy court of inquiry investigating the disaster on the carrier Bennington heard five more witnesses today, but no further light appeared to have been shed on what caused the 101 deaths. More than a score of the carrier's crew remain in critical condition.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., June 3 -- Supreme Court Justice Samuel W. Eager, in a ruling handed down here today, declared that newspapers in New York State had the right to reject advertising for any reason.
The ban on the watering of gardens and lawns was lifted yesterday by Mayor Wagner, who nevertheless warned against wasting water.

BOSTON, June 3 (UP) -- Don Johnson, a relief hurler, came on in the eighth inning with two out and two on to preserve Virgil Trucks' sixth victory of the year today as the White Sox beat the Red Sox, 9 -- 6, before a crowd of 5,568.

We are gravely concerned about the Sharkey bill, now pending in the New York City Council, designed to replace the largely ineffectual Mayor's Committee on Unity with a statutory New York City Commission on Intergroup Relations.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Defense Department said today it wanted Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's list of 133 alleged Communists in defense plants but not on the Senator's terms.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday, totaled 689,292 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

SOMEBODY ought to be thinking about it, somebody ought to be remembering Danskammer as it used to be," writes Marion Edey of her childhood home in the foreword to her charming volume of reminiscences, "Early in the Morning."* And isn't this the way that many people feel and the reason why so many books are written about the blue remembered hills of childhood?
The regional Red Cross Blood Program received 783 pints of blood Wednesday.
ATLANTA, June 3 (UP) -- The Deep South's first steps to meet the school segregation problem indicated today that its state officials would ignore "model" plans being made for the nation's capital.
I read in a recent issue of The Times a news item entitled "Police Pressure in Korea Alleged."
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Faster tax write-offs of business outlays for plant modernization and expansion were approved today by the Senate Finance Committee.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 3 -- Norman M. Tallan, 21 years old, of 24 Brock Avenue, Newark, today became the fourth student in the modern era of Rutgers University to achieve a four-year perfect academic record. A major in ceramics, he will be graduated next Wednesday.

A bill that would put the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I., on the same basis as the military and naval academies at West Point and Annapolis was put before Congress yesterday.

Pratt Institute held its sixty-fifth annual commencement yesterday morning in outdoor exercises on the Brooklyn campus. Degrees and certificates were awarded to 263 students in art, engineering, home economics and library service.
ALBANY, June 3 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed a 19-member special committee to coordinate the placement of refugee immigrants in New York State.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 3 -- Defense Minister Phan Huy Quat said today only about 10 per cent of a total of recruits estimated at 100,000 had been called up under the Vietnamese Government's national mobilization.
HAMBURG, Germany, June 3 (AP) -- The largest oil tanker in the world will be launched here Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The final choice of a permanent home for an Air Force Academy was postponed today when a five-man board failed to agree and recommended three sites from which the Secretary of the Air Force will choose.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in the twenty-sixth day of its hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Federation of American Scientists criticized today the findings of the Gray board in the case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer and called for a review of the Government's entire security clearance program.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UP) -- House Republican leaders abandoned efforts today to save President Eisenhower from a direct rebuff on the farm price support issue and ordered a showdown meeting Monday.

HANOI, Vietnam, June 3 (AP) Three Vietminh battalions numbering about 2,100 wiped out 200 Vietnamese and mauled 100 more today at Cungson, twenty-five miles west of Tuyhoa. This is about 220 miles northeast of Saigon.
LONDON, June 3 -- The British and West German Governments said today they did not intend to pursue any policy of providing open or concealed subsidies to exporters.

Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, potatoes, rubber and silk rose; cocoa, wool, hides, tin and copper declined, and sugar, zinc, lead, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and burlap ended mixed.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Department store sales in the United States last week were 8 per cent above those of the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Strength for the rails in the last few minutes of trading enabled the stock market to close with a small average advance yesterday.

RYE. N. Y., June 3 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club and Mrs. Harold Kilpatrick of Silver Spring won the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association four-ball best-ball tourney today at the Apawamis Club.
BONN, June 3 -- Zachariah Shuster, European director of the American Jewish Committee, charged today that pro-Fascist, anti-Semitic emigre organizations were operating in West Germany.
Mississippi will accept bids until June 30 for sale of $13,000,000 of highway revenue bonds, eighteenth series. The bonds are dated Aug. 1 and will mature serially to 1974.
The third-generation Robert F. Wagner entered public life yesterday.
Last night was the 313th night of the truce in Korea. An odd way to figure it? That's the way a soldier far from. home measures time, not by months or weeks, but by the long, lonely nights.

GENEVA, June 3 -- Both "worker" and "employer" representatives from the Soviet Union and its Eastern European satellites will be excluded from participation in the governing body of the International Labor Organization.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A Democratic boycott tonight blocked an attempt by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to get back in the Communist-hunting business on a part-time basis while charges and counter-charges involving him, his staff and Army officials still are unresolved.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., June 3 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells today won low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Essex County course.

Twenty-three houses are planned for a tract on Wolf Hill Road in Huntington, L. I. which has been purchased by Hal Dale Estates from Anthony Froehlich. The Ernest G. Blaich Company and Lewis T. Waldo were cooperating brokers in the transaction and title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Personal income in the United States ran at an annual rate of $282,000,000,000 in April. This was $1,000,000,000 lower than the March rate, the Government reported today.
TRENTON, June 3 -- An almost ghost-like quiet pervaded the aging State House today but the breach between Gov. Robert B. Meyner and the Republican majority in the Assembly apppeared to be widening.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 3 -- Ben Hogan, United States open golf champion, today decided to postpone his appearance as the principal participant in National Golf Day. Hogan originally was slated to play eighteen holes Saturday at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

" The Stranger," a new mystery program, will he presented weekly over the Du Mont television network beginning Friday, June 25, from 9 to 9:30 P. M. The leading character will be a stranger who appears to help some one in need and then suddenly disappears.
" Total" farm figures are as wrong as it would be to talk of a man's "average health" if all his organs were much stronger than average but he had a serious heart condition.
A warning against "the lurking menace of anti-intellectualism" was sounded yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University.

Directors of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation have approved plans to file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an issue of 577,551 additional shares of common stock.

A suspended Hunter College faculty member testified yesterday that an anonymous invitation to attend a "discussion group" led to his joining the Communist party in 1938. He added that the party's Hunter College cell comprised seven or eight persons in 1939.
Many parties were given at the dinner dance held last night to mark the formal opening of the St. Regis Roof for this season.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 3 -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, told a conference of 800 New Jersey business men here today that the job of guarding the Government against Communist subversion belonged to the Department of Justice and its Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter from Fred A. Seaton, Assistant Secretary of Defense, to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in connection with Mr. McCarthy's offer to make known to the Defense Department the names of some 130 alleged Communists in defense plants.

LONDON, June 3 -- Government funds made fresh gains on the market here today. Business in other departments was restricted by the approach of the Whitsuntide holiday, coinciding with the end of a Stock Exchange bookkeeping account. End-account selling caused some irregularity among industrial shares.

" Nagging" wives and "irresponsible" husbands are the two problems most frequently presented by couples who seek help from marriage counselors, according to a report in the May issue of Marriage and Family Living.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today denied a petition of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and forty other states seeking the end of Federal habeas corpus writs in state cases.
FRANKFURT, Germany, June 3 (UP) -- Two East German gunmen who deserted to the West with Nikolai E. Khokhlov, former Soviet secret police captain, were charged today with conspiracy to murder.
JERUSALEM, June 3 -- The Israeli Government denied today a Jordanian charge that it was guilty of "maltreatment and desecration of Moslem religious property in Palestine."

The personal shock and regret at the news of the death of Louis Stark and the remoteness of myself and colleagues from our headquarters at the time prevented us from earlier expressing our appreciation to The New York Times directly -- which we can no longer do to Mr. Stark -- for the nation-wide attention called to the action of our union in completing establishment of the U. I. U. members Appeal Board.

American Cyanamid Company, manufacturer of chemicals and pharmaceuticals, is offering today to its common shareholders rights to subscribe to 580,235 new shares of $100 par value convertible preferred stock.

The Third Avenue El was opened to service in Manhattan seventy-six years ago. It may have been -- as it was once described -- "the crowning achievement in solving the problems of rapid transit" in its day, but that day is long since dead and gone. Now, in 1954, the El is a major traffic hazard, an expensive eyesore and a thoroughly antiquated means of transportation.
The seasonal decline in business loans by New York banks, was intensified sharply in the week ended on Wednesday by unusually heavy loan repayments in the metals and chemical industries.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 -- A four-year revival program to begin in 1955 was announced tonight to messengers at the Southern Baptist convention by Dr. Courts Redford of Atlanta, executive secretary of the convention's Home Mission Board.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 3 -- The United States has told Turkey that it is prepared to underwrite a minimum program of $300,000,000 of economic assistance for this country in grants and loans over the next three years.
A short, middle-aged woman stepped onto an overnight bag to reach the George Washington Bridge rail, then plunged to death in the Hudson River at 2:40 P. M. yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 3 -- "The future of America looks bright," directors of the National Sales Executives reported at its nineteenth annual distribution congress.

Although the N. B. C. Symphony is officially disbanded, the orchestra met with its regular conductor, Arturo Toscanini, for a three-and-a-half-hour recording session in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.
UNION, N. J., June 3 -- With a two-under-par 69, Chet Sanok of Forsgate today gained the medal in the New Jersey State amateur golf championship at the Suburban Golf Club.
" There is a definitely developing taste for furniture reproductions of later and later periods," it was explained yesterday by an executive at Cassard Romano's, 305 East Sixty-third Street.
It is pleasant to note the cordial response evoked by our new Assistant Secretary of Labor for International Affairs, J. Ernest Wilkins, in his first appearance at a world labor forum.

TOKYO, Friday, June 4 -- Two hundred Tokyo policemen helped to quell a riot late last night in the Japanese House of Representatives. About fifty Deputies were scratched and bruised, or suffered other minor injuries in the fighting.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- The United Nations Security Council voted today to look into the possibility that the Indochinese war might spread.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 3 -- Public competition in denouncing Communists has created a "reign of intolerance" harmful to the nation, Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court declared today.

The tug of war that has been going on in Geneva over whether a regrouping plan for Vietnam is to apply simultaneously to Laos and Cambodia is no mere procedural wrangle. A major issue is at stake and Gen. Bedell Smith has been right in insisting that the cases of Laos and Cambodia are different from that of Vietnam and should be kept separate.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- research official for a special House investigating committee sought today to link money from tax-free grants used by education foundations to a movement to socialize this country into a "collectivist state."

Mayor Wagner yesterday called upon the city's business men to participate in formulating public policy. He said their help was needed "because the work of the Government so vitally affects the business community."

Sun Shower, Mrs. Vernon Cardy's game jumper, finally found his way to the winner's circle. The 7-year-old son of Easton won the Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, to the satisfaction of the greater part of the crowd of 17,740.

Mrs. Dorothy Schiff, publisher of The New York Post, said yesterday that "I wish that every loyal American who has been persecuted by [Senator Joseph R.] McCarthy and unjustly driven from Government employment could be hired by The Post."

A new liver spread makes a timely appearance at the start of the sandwich season. It is a lightly seasoned combination of pork, pork liver and milk, a pleasing product to dab on toast rounds or crackers or to put between slices of bread.
PURCHASE, N. Y., June 4 -- The Women's Tri-County Golf Association opened its 1954 season with a one-day tournament over the Century Country Club course today.

The Peter Pan Handicap will be the feature attraction at Belmont Park today. This $25,000 added race, at a distance of a mile and an eighth, will have its fifteenth running, and has attracted a field of eight. If all go, the race will be worth $36,400.
Coffee and cocoa futures were the major weak spots in the local commodity markets yesterday. Most other commodities were irregular in comparatively light trading.

William B. Mahoney of Erie County and seven other Democratic county chairmen in the Eighth Judicial District announced yesterday their support of Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for their party's nomination for Governor.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 4 (UP) -- Woodruff Randolph today won a sixth two-year term as president of the International Typographical Union, A. F. ., by a scant 569 votes of more than 75,000 cast.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Monitored telephone conversations disclosed today that Senator Stuart Symington had advised the Secretary of the Army last February to forget about the "Marquis of Queensberry Rules "if he were going to "play" with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 4 -Two officials have resigned from the Atomic Energy Commission, effective June 30, to enter private industry in New York.

Adlai E. Stevenson, former Democratic nominee for President, said yesterday on his arrival at La Guardia Airport that he would not have handled the controversy between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in the way the Administration of President Eisenhower has handled it.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Institute of Pacific Relations was cited today as a House inquiry was told that tax-free foundations should be careful in financing research projects.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization has decided not to promote the long-delayed $200,000,000 "third round" expansion of the aluminum industry, Government informants said today.

The Times on June 1 contains two reports which have a paradoxical relationship. One, President Eisenhower's speech at the Columbia University bicentennial dinner, underlined the bicentennial theme -- "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof." Two, the chief librarian of the Brooklyn Public Library, Francis R. St. John, announced that all but seven of the forty-nine branches of the library will be closed Thursdays in an emergency economy program beginning July 1.

DENVER, Colo., June 4 -- Cutting off of diplomatic relations with every Communist and Communist-influenced country, including Guatemala, was urged today by Clarence E. Manion, former chairman of the Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 4 (AP) -- Paige Direct provided an upset at Roosevelt Raceway tonight by gaining a close decision over the favored King Gaines in the featured $4,000 Huntington Pace. Steward Lad was third. The time for the mile was 2.04 2/5.
The state government won a round yesterday in its struggle with the city to correct the Legislature's error that inadvertently favors Democratic chances of picking up the new Assembly seat in Queens.
Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Theatres agreed yesterday on a new contract covering legitimate theatre performers.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Retailers' inventories advanced $100,000,000 during April to $22,686,000,000.

More than a year ago the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey urged repeal of the Lyons Law, which requires with certain exceptions that no one be hired as a city employe unless he has established the credential of three year's residence in the city and that he continue such residence after appointment.

France is obviously trying to build a position of greater military and political strength in Indochina. Gen. Paul Ely, one of the highest ranking and most respected officers in the French Army, will, for the time being, combine the positions of Commander in Chief and High Commissioner.
Eight million Americans changed their place of residence last year because of the...
CAIRO, June 4 -- Two important archaeological discoveries in ten days have caused a controversy over their relative merits.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators recommended today action to curb accidents caused by automobile drivers with defective sight.

The publication of another annual volume of The New York Times Index -- the organized cumulation of the twenty-four semi-monthly issues of 1953 -- will be welcomed by many libraries, Government agencies, colleges and universities, research organizations, business houses and newspapers in the United States and in many foreign countries.

PARIS, June 4 -- French Premier Joseph Laniel and Prince Buu Loc, Premier of Vietnam, initialed today the treaties by which Vietnam is accorded "complete independence." Under the treaties, the Indochinese state agrees to "free association" with France within the French Union.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Commissions for three members of the graduating class at the United States Naval Academy have been withheld pending the outcome of security investigations.

Carlos Prio Socarras, former President of Cuba, his Minister of the Interior, and two other men pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court to charges of plotting to export war material from the United States to Cuba in violation of the Neutrality Act.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 -Seventh-Day Adventists in world convention were told today of an increasing integration of "national groups" into Adventist hospitals and schools.

" The Portable Nietzsche," a new volume in Viking's Portable series, will be published June 21. It contains the unabridged texts of four of Nietzsche's works, "Thus Spoke Zarathustra," "Twilight of the Idols," "The Anti-Christ" and "Nietzsche Contra Wagner."

ALTHOUGH many men who encouraged their wives to take up fishing have lived to regret it, a report just received from the Bahamas indicates that women anglers have finally attained equal status -- three are now members of tournament fishing teams.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Carl Erskine's five-year frustration at Wrigley Field ended today. He hurled the Dodgers to a 2-1 victory over the Cubs before a chilled gathering of 5,547 fans. The triumph was Brooklyn's sixth straight, the league leader's longest winning streak of the season.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- An "atomic age" amendment to the Constitution, which would permit Governors to fill vacancies in the House of Representative during national emergencies, was approved 70-1 by the Senate today.
ST. LOUIS, June 4 (UP) -- Stan Musial's two homers gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, June 3 -- Indian opinion is apparently being prepared for acceptance of United States aid on a loan basis instead of as a gift, if, indeed, American assistance is to be taken at all.

As chairman of the Senate committee which has primary responsibility for proposed legislation revising the Organic Act of the Virgin Islands, I have studied with great interest the letter of protest published in your issue of May 23 under the caption "Rights for Virgin Islands."
BONN, Germany, June 4 -- Dr. Heinrich Bruening, former Chancellor of Germany, has emerged from political retirement to advocate a return to German neutrality between the Eastern and Western blocs.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Government declared today twenty-six home "luxury items" -- including barbecue pits, tennis courts and venetian blinds -- in-eligible for Federal Housing Administration loan insurance.
