WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -- The House Appropriations Committee voted $1,948,946,011 for the Labor and Welfare Departments and related agencies today and scolded the Cabinet's only woman member for failing to economize.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Wheat futures prices were higher here today but the trade volume was still of moderate dimensions. Corn was inclined to sag early but came back strong later. Oats also gained in a belated response to the recent strength in the major grains.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) -- Ed McGhee of the Athletics batted in four runs with a two-run homer and a bases-loaded single today as Philadelphia strengthened its grip on seventh place with a 7-6 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 4 (AP) -- The Chilean Treasury said tonight the Controller General was drafting a formal acceptance of credits totaling $300,000,000 from private United States and Japanese companies.
Daniel T. McFadden has been named manager of sales for the Atlantic division of the American Can Company.

GENEVA, June 4 -- So little progress was made today in the debate on Indochina that Georges Bidault, the French Foreign Minister, suggested that he and Vyacheslav M. Molotov, the Soviet Foreign Minister, start private conversations to determine whether a settlement was possible.
ANNAPOLIS, June 4 (AP) -Robert B. Anderson, Deputy Defense Secretary, told the Naval Academy's 1954 graduates today they must hold within them a "conviction of excellence" in their profession.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 4 -- Submarine crews will lose some of their privacy soon. A big helicopter with a submersible "ear" has been produced, and the Navy plans to use it to pry into the operations of foreign submarines listed among the uninvited.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican, South Dakota, said today his Army-McCarthy invesigating subcommittee planned to discuss protests of persons demanding to testify because their names had come up in the televised hearings.
A leading British producer of women's skirts plans to increase American sales this year by more than 50 per cent, it was made known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Netherlands said "Thank you" today to the United States for $1,124,800,000 of Marshall Plan aid given that country since the last war.
GENEVA, June 4 -- The United Nations side in the Korean war has decided to hold fast in its stand that the United Nations has the right to supervise the elections in Korea.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, said today he believed "a lot of good" would come out of the Army-McCarthy hearings.
CHICAGO, June 4 -- A rosy future for the American economy was predicted today by two speakers at the closing session of the nineteenth annual distribution congress of the National Sales Executives.
TOKYO, Saturday, June 5--The Japanese parliamentary system ground to an almost complete breakdown today. This was an aftermath of yesterday's early morning fight on...
The New York City Transit Authority filed a petition yesterday for an injunction to bar a strike threatened June 14 by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.
CINCINNATI, June 4 -- The Giants are gaining momentum in their bid to stay in the thick of the National League race.

PARIS, June 4 -- Lieut. Genevieve de Galard - Terraube, French Air Force nurse who was the only woman at Dienblenphu, said today that the letters she wrote to Ho Chi Minh, leader of the Indochinese insurgents, concerning her release after the fall of the Bastion, had been solicited by a Communist representative.
Eduardo Lausse of Buenos Aires, the middleweight with the heavyweight punch, stopped Joe Rindone of Boston in the second round at Madison Square Garden last night.
MANCHESTER, England, June 4 (UP) -- Maureen Connolly today gained the final of the Northern lawn tennis tournament by beating Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont of Wilmington, Del., 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4.

The amount of publicity being given to increased juvenile delinquency and the family's responsibility to combat it, starting at home, have raised questions in many parents' minds on how to help their youngsters avoid trouble.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Budget cuts are slowing the operations of the Patent Office. Forty thousand patents were issued in the last twelve months, but the estimate is that only 28,000 will be granted in the fiscal year starting July 1.
The Third Avenue Elevated line may be old, decrepit and unpatronized, but it is not without friends.

In Wayne J. Farnham's letter of June 1 he suggests that Admiral C. E. Rosendahl was in error when, in the course of his graceful tribute to the late Rear Admiral Herbert V. Wiley, Admiral Rosendahl referred to "the sinking of the Macon."

ALBANY, June 4 -- If art individual is injured while swimming in his or her employer's private pool after working hours, the State Workmen's Compensation Board is not obligated to help with medical expenses.
A surprise announcement from the Buckeye State yesterday gave rise to the hope that many vacationing motorists might pay less for their gasoline this summer.

DEVON, Pa., June 4 -- Auction, entered by James F. McHugh's Maule Farms of West Grove, Pa., took the young hunter championship at the Devon horse show today. Auction was ridden by Betty Bosley of Unionville, Pa.

ATHENS, June 4 -- A joint communique is expected to be issued tomorrow confirming that Greece, a limited monarchy, Turkey a republic, and Yugoslavia a Communist dictatorship, have decided to transform their pact of friendship and cooperation into a military alliance.
RIO JANEIRO, June 4 -- A formal move to impeach President Getulio Vargas came before the Brazilian Chamber of Deputies today.
New corporate and municipal bonds totaling more than $250,000,000 will be offered to investors next week.

LONDON, June 4 -- Two thousand museum articles were found in the home of a museum caretaker with an obsession for beautiful pieces. For twenty- three years the caretaker, John Andrew Nevin, 58 years old, had been furnishing his home with art objects he had stolen from the Victoria and Albert Museum.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 4 (AP) -- A terrific explosion that shook the countryside and damaged buildings within a radius of fifteen miles injured at least fifty-two persons at the Carbide and Carbon Chemical Company plant at near-by Institute tonight.

CINCINNATI, June 4 (AP)--Leo Bigetti, 26-year-old newcomer to the golfing wars, blazed to a two-stroke lead today at the halfway mark in the fifty-first Western open championship with a five-under-par total of 137.
Clarence Henry, 28-year-old heavyweight boxer, was arrested yesterday in an alleged $15,000 bribery attempt.

June is a month that's made for many things -- for weddings, graduations, reunions. It's a time for admiration of lush green foliage before the ravages of a summer's heat begins. It's a month for making little decisions -- how long to keep blankets on the bed, how long to take the sun for just a touch of tan.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 -The annual parade of weddings at the historic Naval Academy got under way here this afternoon after graduation exercises this morning in Dahlgren Hall.

For those who missed some conveniences on the first spring picnics and who plan to go on many more such outings in the long season ahead, new items to simplify picnic preparations are available in the stores.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Mobilization officials are "retesting" the home front's preparedness for war, officials said today, but definitely are not preparing to reimpose controls.
JERUSALEM, June 3 -- Israel has advanced the idea that the use of the Litani River in Lebanon would solve all the complications over development of the water resources of the Jordan Valley region.
Cotton futures trading was quiet again on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and prices moved 2 points higher to 8 points lower than on Thursday.
WEST BABYLON, L. I., June 14 -- Two 13-year-old boys were trapped tonight when the upper half of an abandoned barn collapsed on them. One was killed and the other was critically injured.
DENVER Colo., June 4 (UP) -- Three Governors who had made an inspection of Korean recovery programs predicted today that Korea would be rebuilt "into a powerful and prosperous ally."
LONDON, June 4 (Reuters) -- Communist Rumania denied today that recent trials of Jews there had an anti-Semitic bias and protested to Israel for having implied they did.

GENEVA, June 4 -- The non-Communist labor delegates to the International Labor Conference here have decided to challenge the credentials of "worker" delegates from the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Venezuela on the ground that they are tools of their Governments and not freely chosen spokesmen of the workers.

LONDON, June 4 -- Preparation of the British people for decisive action by this country and its allies in Southeast Asia is being discussed in Government circles as hopes for a successful settlement at the Geneva conference in Far Eastern affairs fade.
PALM BEACH, Fla., June 4 (AP) -- One of the year's briefest but most publicized marriages, during which the bridegroom ran off with the bride's fortune in cash and jewels, ended today in annulment.
SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., June 4 -- Morning showers failed to hold back measurably the annual assembly of the Bond Club of New York at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.
Your account of technical aid accomplishments and especially your editorial on them reminds me of the manufacturer whose books showed only income, and who was surprised when he went broke.
Two big natural gas producers, the El Paso Natural Gas Company and the Western Natural Gas Company, reported plans yesterday for entering the uranium and rare metals field.
How goes the response to the invitations contained in the mail each day to buy something or other?

Congress is now considering special legislation to permit the Maritime Administration to sell the trans-Pacific liners President Cleveland and President Wilson to American President Lines, which has operated them on charter for the last six years.

Stocks eased slightly in a generally lackadaisical session yesterday. The New York Times combined average dipped 0.29 point to 209.25. The rails were off 0.07 to 71.53 and the industrials 0.52 to 346.97.
TWO of the summer group shows that are beginning to sprout in large numbers in Fifty-seventh Street are concerned with American art of this century and the last.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Tax relief for the country's corporation stockholders, substantially as voted by the House of Representatives, was approved by the Senate Finance Committee today on a vote of 9 to 4.
The aggregate assessed valuation of New York City's real estate and the basic tax rate will rise to new peaks in the fiscal year 1954-55, beginning July 1.
The sale of a modern Norwegian - flag cargo vessel to the Soviet Union for a price well above the prevailing market was made known here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP)-A survey showed today that the average first grader, whose parents own a television set, spends two and one-quarter hours a day watching various programs.

The 5 per cent amusement tax bill was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. It had been passed Thursday by the City Council by a vote of 22 to 3, with two Republicans and one Democrat in opposition.

Karl Burger and Eliot Hearst, two members of Columbia's national intercollegiate championship team, played their adjourned game from the sixth round of the United States championship tournament to a finish yesterday at the Marshall Chess Club.
The American Federation of Labor pier union insisted yesterday that it was in the New York waterfront fight to the finish.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4 -The American Booksellers Association tonight presented a special award of merit to American Book-Stratford Press of New York City for the "furtherance" of the cause of bookselling in America."
TORONTO, June 4 (UP) -- The venerable Cayuga prepared today to head back to water from the junkyard, thanks to the faith of 700 sentimental shareholders.
BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- The White Sox went into a virtual tie for first place and Bob Keegan became the first American league pitcher to win eight games as Chicago defeated the Red Sox, 7-3, today.

Port Huron, Mich., has awarded $2,450,000 of school district bonds due from 1954 to 1971 to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates at a net interest cost of 1.963 per cent for bonds bearing interest at 2 1/2, 2 1/4, 2 and 1 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The United States and Britain will begin talks with Italy soon in a new effort to break the deadlock over Trieste.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 4 -- Crimes among children 16 to 19 years old in Westchester have remained generally at the same l level since 1940, County Executive James D. Hopkins reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent to 110.8 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices for farm products and processed foods were largely responsible for the decline as industrial materials prices remained unchanged.
A national distributor of comic books demanded to know yesterday what specific crimes had ever been attributed to such reading matter -- and soon found out.

Viewers-with-alarm on the state of the Yankees may have been premature. After squandering a seven-run lead in the series opener and squeaking through in the second game, the third-place Bombers took thorough charge of the league-leading Indians yesterday to win the set, two games to one.
The additional May Kings County grand jury had its term extended yesterday until Aug. 31 and was charged with conducting an all-inclusive investigation of crime and corruption in Brooklyn.

The Monarch Radio and Television Corporation and eight men, including a former president and a former vice president of the corporation, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on mail fraud and conspiracy charges.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 4 -- Current conditions and the Administration's easy money policy of low interest rates make it "impossible" for commercial banks to compete with "tax-favored" mutual institutions in the thrift field, bankers were told today.

Saturday is a busy day at the village hardware store, rain or shine. If it isn't raining people find they need things with which to begin to complete outdoor projects; if it is raining they need things for indoor projects.

The graceful sari, traditional garment of the Indian woman, has inspired Adele Simpson, New York designer. For warm summer evenings she has designed two soft dresses made of cotton saris handwoven in India. The dresses have simple elegant lines that emphasize the beauty of the authentic sari.
Industry will require new capital equipment replacements this year to the tune of $10,400,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -- Senator Karl E. Munt, Republican of South Dakota, said today he would introduce a bill to create a new Justice Department agency to evaluate Federal Bureau of Investigation reports and advise Government bureaus on which employes should be dismissed as security risks.

New York City was a better community last year because the Girl Scout promise to "help other people at all times" was translated into action by Scouts of every troop. Guided by 13,802 adult volunteers, 48,961 Girl Scouts gave 130,654 hours of practical service to 573 agencies and institutions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 4 -- The Philippines and Thailand have complained to the United States against being left out of talks on the military security of Southeast Asia.

Following are excerpts from yesterday's testimony in Washington before the Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as recorded by The New York Times. The subcommittee was in the twenty-seventh day of its hearings on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 4 -- Two big innings gave a 7-1 victory to Princeton over Yale today. Joe Castle of the Tigers hurled a six-hitter as the Eastern Intercollegiate League season closed on University Field.
LONDON, June 4 -- Although holiday week-end considerations were apparent, the stock markets finished the week firmly today and prices closed with many further gains.

BERLIN, June 4 (AP) -- An East German newspaper editor was convicted of sabotage and sentenced to five years at hard labor recently for having overlooked an "error" that made Stalin appear as a fighter for war instead of peace, the West Berlin League of Free Jurists reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The man whose ambition is to outdo his neighbors in trimming the shrubs on his lawn should look to William E. Brownell of South Bend, Ind. The Brownell guide, patented this week, makes possible perfect spheres, cones and other rounded shapes.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A sharp conflict between at least two members of the Atomic Energy Commission and their chairman, Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, was revealed today in their testimony before a Congressional committee.

Historic Manhattan property that had not previously changed hands since the days of the Indians passed yesterday into control of foreign investors. Seventy-three parcels on the East Side, held by one family of pioneers since the time of the original Dutch grant to Gov. Peter Stuyvesant more than three centuries ago, figured in the transaction.
Christians and Jews will attend pentecostal devotions the coming week.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Tax Commissioner has urged that Government-owned manufacturing facilities be made fully taxable.

QUONSET POINT, R I., June 4 (UP)--A survivor of the explosions and fire that roared through the aircraft carrier Bennington on May 26 testified today that the first blast occurred in the ship's catapult room.

Seventy-two would-be stage designers and scenic painters began a three-day examination yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House to qualify for union membership that will enable them to work for Broadway theatres, television and motion pictures -- providing they can find the jobs.
HANOI, Vietnam, June 4 (AP) -- Three thousand Communist-led rebels overwhelmed 1,000 Vietnamese troops and Roman Catholic militiamen in a battle yesterday marked by a seven-hour stand in a seminary.

PARIS, June 4 (AP) -- Henri De LaMaze won the French amateur golf crown for the fifth time today. He set back Clarke Hardwicke of Los Angeles, 4 and 3. The American never before had played in the final of a major tournament.

It is welcome news for thrifty cooks that processed American cheese is now selling at 55 cents a pound, the lowest price since January, 1951. Though processed cheese lacks the fine flavor and pleasing texture of the natural (unprocessed) product, it nevertheless has the same good food value.

MILWAUKEE, June 4 (UP) -- Max Surkont made it two in a row over his former team-mates tonight and stretched the Milwaukee Braves' losing streak to five with a 4-1 victory for the last-place Pittsburgh Pirates.

Signal, sign, marking and supervisory crews of the Department of Traffic will begin at 6 A. M. tomorrow to prepare Seventh and Eighth Avenues for conversion to one-way traffic schedules to start at 8 A. M.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP) -- Four Communists were sentenced to five years' imprisonment and a fifth received a three-year sentence today for conspiring to advocate the overthrow of the Government by force.

The Southern California Edison Company plans to spend approximately $73,000,000 this year on new construction and expansion of existing facilities, Harold Quinton, president of the utility, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.
PARIS, June 4 -- Talks between France and India on the future of the French colonies in the Indian state of Madras were ended here today without agreement.
W. Claggett Martin has been appointed vice president of the Jones-Dabney and Beckwith-Chandler divisions of Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., paint manufacturer.

PATERSON, N. J., June 4 -The Federal Government should look to the people for a strong economy rather than have the community depend primarily on the Government for solutions to its economic problems, Assistant Secretary of Labor Rocco C. Siciliano told Paterson area business leaders today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 4 -- Local 64 of the Bakery and Confectionary Employes International Union, A. F. L., announced today that employes of fourteen Union County bakeries would go on strike early tomorrow unless owners sign new contracts.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 4 -- A new United Fruit Company contract with the Costa Rican Government was signed here today at 5 P. M.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 4 (Reuters) -- Colin Bednall, managing director of The Melbourne Argus, said today there was "not the slightest doubt" that Robert Oppenheimer had given the newspaper a radiotelephone interview on the decision of a security board that he should no longer have access to atomic secrets in the United States.
VIENNA, June 4 (UP) -- A Communist newspaper reported today that a Belgian freight plane had been attacked over Hungarian territory for a refusal to obey an order to land.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -- "White Feather," a cowboy and Indian adventure, will be the last of ten pictures to be made by Panoramic Productions for Twentieth Century-Fox release. It will go before the CinemaScope camera next month as the first wide screen undertaking by Panoramic, which Fox originally subsidized to make standard size movies.
GUATEMALA, June 4--Evidence is multiplying that the Guatemalan Government is moving quickly and forcefully to take over the initiative held briefly by the opposition.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UP) -- Roy Sievers turned from a hero into a goat today when he dropped Jim Delsing's fly for a two-base error in the eighth inning to allow Frank Bolling to score from first and give the Detroit Tigers a 3-2 victory over the Washington Senators.

Operations of Gar Wood Industries, Inc., and subsidiaries for the six months ended on April 30 resulted in a net loss of $314,216, according to the report released yesterday. This contrasts with a net profit of $607,592 for the corresponding period a year earlier.

The United States is sitting records in its program for providing income security to its individual citizens through encouraging the accumulation of private wealth by saving, supplemented by employer and governmental insurance plans, the Under Secretary of the Treasury reported yesterday.

TRENTON, June 4 -- Joseph F. Walker, New Jersey Athletic Commissioner, today drastically revised state regulations governing wrestling. He warned that drastic fines, suspensions and even permanent banishment in the state would be the penalty for a violation.

MILWAUKEE, June 4 (UP) -- James Stern, attorney for a man and wife allegedly struck by Jackie Robinson's thrown bat, said today he would sue unless the National League president, Warren Giles, took action in the case.
The pending tax bill offers deceptive economic incentives for recovery from our national recession, and-therefore the bill is not tax-wise.

A $7,000 payroll intended for nearly 100 warehouse employes of Strauss Stores, Inc., was seized yesterday by two armed robbers. They escaped in the automobile of Murray Morton, who had been sent by the Concord Detective Agency, 605 Lexington Avenue, to guard the money.
One of the biggest real estate "transferals" in this hemisphere apparently was closed some 30,000 years ago.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4 -- An interunion fight resulted in the death of three persons and serious injuries to forty-eight others this morning. Dissatisfied with the leaders of the Metal Workers Union, who had accepted wage increases ranging from 12 to 25 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Italy and France were put on notice today that they might lose all United States military aid in the future unless they entered the proposed European Defense Community.
The Columbia College class of '29 presented two ornamental wrought iron gates to the college yesterday as a twenty-fifty anniversary gift.
ALBANY, June 4 -- The Court of Appeals again upheld today the constitutionality of the state's fair-trade act.
MEXICO CITY, June 4 -- The Mexican Government imposed new high tariffs today on a long list of luxury goods to pare the country's unnecessary spending abroad.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 4 (AP)--Lisbon Uranium Corporation stockholders have voted unanimously to turn control over to financier Floyd B. Odlum and his associates in return for additional uranium properties in the rich Big Indian district of desolate Southeast Utah.
UNION, N. J., June 4 -- Chet Sanok, who led the qualifiers yesterday, won two match - play rounds in the New Jersey State amateur golf championship today.
MINEOLA, L. I., June 4 -- Nassau County detectives bagged three birds today with the same pinch -- a bookie and his two carrier-pigeon accomplices.

COMPTON, Calif., June 4 (AP)--Wes Santee of Kansas hung up an American record for the mile run tonight when he ran the distance in 4:00.6, the second fastest time in history, but he missed out in his assault on Roger Bannister's spectacular time of 3:59.4.
BALTIMORE, June 4 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today the development of a solar geenrator that when refined could convert sunlight into energy to run a home.

WHAT the Metropolitan Opera needs is an opera about backstage life at the Metropolitan Opera. It is clear from Helen Noble's new book, "Life With the Met,"* that such an extravaganza would be awash with dramatic situations, lively plots, humor, hysteria and an awesome cycle of solos, duets, trios, quartets, quintets, sextets and splendid foolishness.

ROME, June 5 -- Italian hopes and fears were aroused today on the delicate problems of Trieste, the European Defense Community and the Balkan military pact. However, there is little if any reason to believe that a solution is imminent for any of these issues.

LOS ANGELES, June 5 -- A ten-year campaign to put Los Angeles, the nation's third-ranking metropolis, in the "big league" among convention cities by giving it a modern civic auditorium will make its third bid for success in Tuesday's primary election.

CLEVELAND, June 5 -- Sales of new automobiles soared to 2,263, highest weekly total since August, 1950, and used-car transactions aggregated 2,223, largest since mid-1952. Dealers also enjoyed a banner week in sales of both new and used trucks. New truck sales of 158 were the second largest weekly total this year and a season high of 107 used trucks was established.

I have read again the recent decision of the Supreme Court. It bears rereading. For it is a great historic document -- not only because its timing turns it into the most powerful political instrument against communism that the United States has as yet devised but because of its profound meaning for children.

ABILENE, Kan. -- Nearly 20,000 tourists have registered at the Eisenhower Museum here in the short time since it opened early in April. The "Ike Museum," a few miles off U. S. Route 40, houses a million and a half dollars worth of trophies, souvenirs, documents, prizes of war and other Eisenhower memorabilia.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 5 -- Bob Backus, the national champion, established a world record for the 56-pound weight throw today with a heave of 41 feet 11 inches at the New York Athletic Club's annual spring games at Travers Island.

GENEVA, June 5 (AP) -- Following are remarks by Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier and Foreign Minister; Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, and Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, United States Under Secretary of State, on the question of supervision of election for an All-Korean Government:
The keel for Norway's newest liner, the Bergensfjord, was laid in England last week, the Norwegian America Line reported here yesterday.

Max D. Howell, executive vice president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, enjoys outdoor life so much he once considered forestry as his career. But early in his college days he switched to the "indoor" field -- accounting -- and in the forty years since went on to achieve success with leading utility, banking and steel companies.

A new Balkan alliance has now been agreed upon among Greece, Turkey and Yugoslavia and will be incorporated in a formal treaty within a few weeks. This alliance is entirely defensive in purpose. It is designed to strengthen the independence of the signatory nations and guard them against attack.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 5 -- The long June-to-Christmas cotton harvest has started in Texas.

HE is a small, precise, unimpressive-looking man with a dish-shaped face, a pedantic manner and a humorless, utterly uninspiring public personality. Yet behind this undistinguished camouflage of "everyman" resides a subtle and confusing individuality.

WE visited some young friends in a comfortable suburb near New York one weekday last summer and were amazed at the silence that hung over the neighborhood. The two youngsters of the family wandered from front lawn to backyard rather aimlessly and finally settled down to a game of Old Maid on the front steps.

ATHENS, June 5 -- Allied policy in the Middle East has been hampered by inherent divergencies and conflicts of interest as well as by the highly charged emotional atmosphere engendered in the Palestine war. Traditional British attitudes find themselves running athwart the developing strategic and economic concern of the United States in the region between Suez and the Caspian Sea.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Washington, a city of eternal press conferences, will have a "first" one on Tuesday when Dr. Arthur F. Burns takes on all reporters who want to know about the state of the economy and the Administration's program for dealing with it.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 5 (AP) -- Despite a somewhat slow track, New Jersey scholastic runners set nine records and tied two in the thirty-sixth annual state track and field championships in Rutgers Stadium today.

BERLIN, June 5 -- Several hundred thousand youths were assembled in East Berlin today for the opening of a Communist-sponsored youth festival. As they listened to speeches attacking the West, policemen and Youth Corps guards prevented them from visiting West Berlin.

The American Council on Education warned last week that immediate steps must be taken to plan for a substantial increase in college enrollments. In a survey prepared for school officials, the council, leading spokesman for educational institutions in this country, estimated that by 1970 college registration would have increased by more than 70 per cent.
GENEVA, June 5 -- Communist China proposed today that the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission in Korea should supervise any all-Korean elections.

UP near Central Park, Manhattanites and visitors will have a chance to see a June indoor garden show on Wednesday. For the Horticultural Society of New York, Inc., will stage this annual event in the Colonnades Ballroom of Essex House, Fifty-ninth Street near Seventh Avenue from 1 to 4:30 P. M.

DOWN in Texas, Pecos is preparing to celebrate more than the nation's Independence Day on July 4. The day, according to historians of the famous old cow town, will also be the official seventy-first anniversary of the founding of that great outdoor institution, the American rodeo.

THE old saw, "always a bridesmaid and never a bride," might well apply to Doris Beckman. She is the young lady who shepherds five bridal couples through five wedding ceremonies every week (one each day, Monday through Friday) on N. B. C.-TV's "Bride and Groom." at 12 noon.
After more than nine years of legal maneuvering, trial of the multi-million-dollar suit of Arnold Bernstein against the Holland-America Line will begin here tomorrow morning.

STOCKTON, Calif., June 5 -- Wes Santee, America's greatest miler, tonight defeated Mal Whitfield, the 880-yard world record-holder, in the half-mile run of the annual Pacific Association Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships.

ROME, June 5 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York recently had a private one-hour audience with Pope Pius XII. He was the first member of the Sacred College of Cardinals whom the Pope saw alone since his grave illness earlier this year.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 5 -- A series of quixotic actions by East Pakistan's provincial chief brought about the dismissal of his administration this week by the central government in Karachi. But the case originated in the exploitation of grievances among the East Pakistani against the Karachi Government.

THE white settlers who ranch the dry uplands of Kenya grapple with two problems. One is their own safety and that of their families; the other, the safety of their cattle. At present, the second worries them more. Human beings can, and do, carry guns: cows can't.

WITH the coming of the fine weather, the birds are singing on phonograph records as well as in the trees. Thanks largely to the efforts of ornithologists at Cornell University, there are a number of new disks that enable listeners to study bird songs in the home and which should lead to happier and more interesting vacations when those songs, learned from recordings, are suddenly distinguished.
NEW HAVEN, June 5 -- Yale University will mark the opening tomorrow of its 253d commencement program.

Ralph Ellison, for instance, has told us that we are all invisible men, and Richard Wright that we are all outsiders.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- By sweeping a double-header with the Cubs today at Wrigley Field, the Dodgers ran their winning streak to eight games and moved a length and a half ahead of the second-place Giants.

WE have always wondered on what date a fellow became a schizophrenic, and now we know. The date is whatever date the special vacation reading issue of the Book Review comes out each year, which this year is today.
GUATEMALA, June 5 -- Mobilization plans for about 80,000 members of the National Confederation of Peasants are under study.

THE spread of television in the Far East is a subject best approached with crossed fingers. TV exists in Japan and the Philippines and is planned in Thailand. Elsewhere video generally falls into the "what's that?" category.

FOR almost four decades Elihu Root, dominant member of McKinley and Roosevelt Cabinets, then front - bench United States Senator, adroit opponent of Wilsonianism, and elder statesman of the Republican party, was a towering personality in American public affairs.

CINCINNATI, June 5 -- Dr. Nathan A. Perilman, a Rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, asked today whether the people would be saved from cynicism and hopelessness while the world was being saved from other menaces.

GENEVA, June 5 -- One effect of the Geneva conference has been to focus attention as never before on the Indochina states of Cambodia and Laos. The two Buddhist kingdoms sandwiched in between Vietnam and Thailand have emerged as key territories in the efforts of the democratic world to block the spread of communism through Indochina into the remainder of Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The impression grows among some observers here that too many may be expecting too much of a conclusive nature politically from the Army-McCarthy hearings.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 5 (AP) -- Patty Berg battled cold and wind through two rounds of the $7,500 Triangle round-robin invitation golf tournament today to finish the fourth round of the 90-hole "plus and minus" event with a commanding lead of plus 23 points.

CINCINNATI, June 5 -- There was still no checking the Giants today. They rode roughshod over the Redlegs, 7 to 0, to bag their second straight victory of the series before a Ladies' Day gathering of 5,741.

RIPON, Wis., June 5 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy tonight accused Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri of helping to instigate the McCarthy-Army dispute in a plot to "destroy" President Eisenhower and the Republican party.

THE Boston Arts Festival, begun three years ago as a kind of tourist promotion, opens its third annual program today for a two-week stand of art, culture and music in the Public Gardens in downtown Boston.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A Congressional committee is about to look into the adequacy of the Government's economic statistics.
A small wood board, designed to extend the existence of a rare species of tropical bird, has been devised by a United States conservationist.

Violence tends to be more prevalent on television programs in "children's hours" than at other times, two witnesses told the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on juvenile delinquency yesterday. The reference was to material shown between 5 and 7 P. M. on weekdays and from signing-on through 7 P. M. on week-ends.

IN his new group of pictures at the Egan Gallery, 46 East Fifty-seventh Street, Aaron Siskind, New York photographer and teacher now with the Institute of Design in Chicago, continues his preoccupation of the last few years with the curious images, left by chance markings and designs, that he has found on outdoor surfaces in desultory wanderings.

The Storm King School, Cornwall-on-Hudson, N. Y., has inaugurated a program to encourage students to read and promote a facility in writing and speaking. According to the headmaster, Burke Boyce, the plan is designed to bring English out of its category in the student's mind as something isolated and of no value to anyone but the teacher and to tie it in with present living.

A nation-wide trend toward the development of mass communications programs on the college level is reflected in the formation last week of New York University's "Communication Arts Group." To go into operation this fall, the course will combine offerings in journalism, television, radio, motion pictures and drama.
NEW DELHI, June 5 -- Developments in Indochina have caused Indians to take a sharp new look at their situation as Communist rule edges ever closer to India's frontiers.

DALLAS, June 5 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal District trailed off in May after setting a better-than-last-year mark in April, the Federal Reserve Bank reported. Sales early in May were 4 per cent below year-earlier figures, but appeared to be improving, merchants said.

"SHAKESPEARE ON TV," the much-talked of series of lectures on the dramatist and his works, given by Dr. Frank C. Baxter, Professor of English Literature at the University of Southern California, will make its local debut over WCBS-TV on Saturday afternoon from 2:45 to 3:30 o'clock.

In its efforts to obtain Congressional action on its housing program, the Administration has been treading a stormy path between conflicting pressures. A number of Republicans have opposed any Federal housing legislation at all as a form of "New Dealism."

The Yankees defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 1, after losing by 2 -- 1 in the opening game of a double-header at the Stadium yesterday. Bob Turley limited the Bombers to six hits in the first contest. Meanwhile, the Dodgers extended their winning streak to eight games by beating the Cubs at Chicago, 8 -- 5 and 8 -- 3.

BABYLON, L. I. -- A shorter route to Fire Island State Park is scheduled to open next Saturday, saving motorists 75 cents and about a half-hour of time in reaching one of the most beautiful and less frequented beaches on the Atlantic seaboard.

Less than 3 per cent of more than 652,000 children who received the first inoculation have dropped out as trials of the Salk anti-polio vaccine progressed from the first through the important second shot. The third shot is vital not only to round out the study, but to protect a child against paralytic polio.

Richard Maney's nostalgic article could only have been compiled by a man who has devoted a great many years to the theatre. But with all those years. I think by now he should realize that an agent, on closing day, does not feel sad because he is losing a 10 per cent commission. He feels miserable because he is losing a 5 per cent commission.
One of the world's outstanding soccer teams, the Glasgow Rangers, will meet the Chelsea Pensioners of London in an international match at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, today.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 5 (AP) -- On the eve of the tenth anniversary of D-Day, the leader of the Normandy invasion had more peaceful pursuits.

IT is hard to tell this tourist season whether visitors to Holland are more disappointed by the rarity of windmills or wooden shoes. Windmill-fanciers can take heart from societies for the preservation of the old landmarks, but clogs are hapless orphans whose destiny looks more somber.

Giraudoux' "The Apollo of Bellac."
LONDON, June 5 -- Britain will approach Egypt by the end of this month for a settlement of the two-year-old Suez Canal dispute, according to authoritative circles here.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- In its criticism of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer the Gray Board included two points which, it is fair to say, have increased the already alarming breach between the Government and a great many of the nation's leading scientists.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The rift between members of the Atomic Energy Commission over the powers of its chairman deepened today in a hearing before the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

HANOI, Vietnam, June 5 (AP) -- French planes scored direct hits with half-ton bombs today on Vietminh convoys moving along routes the rebels are using in an attempt to close a pincers behind this Red River delta capital.
JAMAICA in 1804 is the setting for this moderately low-bodiced novel in which Herbert Best recounts, in prose just discolored enough to escape parody, the fortunes of the Gowry Moores of Gramercie.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland said today that the free world had reached the "jumping off place" and that if it did not force some kind of showdown with the Communist on Indochina within thirty days, all Asia would fall to them.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 -- Charges of "smear" and "misuse of free mailing privilege" enlivened this week the California primary campaign that ends at the polls Tuesday.

THE author of "The Amateur Naturalist's Handbook" has written another informative book for boys and girls who have more than the usual drive to collect and keep. LOS ALAMOS, N. M., June 5 (AP) -- A raging fire lashed by gusty winds moved along the mountains toward this atomic laboratory city late today, but there was no immediate threat to the installation.

THE stage in Berlin is, like everything else in this city, divided by the cold war, but the resulting rivalry makes for consistently interesting theatre. Nine years after the bombings, thirteen of the city's shattered theatres are back in operation, seven of them in the Western sectors.

MANCHESTER, England, June 5 -- Maureen (Little Mo) Connolly of San Diego, Calif., and Ken Rosewall of Australia won the singles titles in straight sets today at the Northern lawn tennis tournament.

BOSTON, June 5 -- With final returns for May now available, it is found that department store sales were 2.6 per cent below the same month of last year. This showing is satisfactory considering that last month was the rainiest in the history of the Boston Weather Bureau.

New York University will begin its 122d commencement week activities today at 4 P. M. with a traditional baccalaureate service in the auditorium of the Gould Memorial Library on the University Heights campus in the Bronx.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 5 -- Foster Furcolo, State Treasurer, received today the Democratic endorsement as the candidate to oppose Senator Leverett Saltonstall in November.

All his stories have had the enchantment of mystic waters in far-away places, of tropical islands, of hexed ships, of duels to the death over rich cargoes and exotic women.

BEACON, N. Y., June 5 -- The late James Vincent Forrestal, the nation's first Secretary of Defense, was eulogized this afternoon when a new million-dollar grade school named in his honor was dedicated.

Young Paul Wild, a Swiss working at Palomar Observatory, stepped into the spotlight last week when the California Institute of Technology, where he is lecturing, announced that he had discovered in the Constellation Virgo, amid a whirlpool of stars to which astronomers give the catalogue number NCG 5688, a terrific explosion that occurred fully twenty million years ago.

THE repeated revisions and admissions of error in the Bureau of Reclamation's own figures in the Dinosaur National Monument controversy show the absurdity of the argument that this question has been sufficiently studied, that all the facts are in and that the superiority of Echo Park dam over any alternates has now been conclusively demonstrated.

AMANA, Iowa -- Twenty-one miles south and west of Cedar Rapids, on some of Iowa's most productive farm lands, lie the seven villages of the Amana Society, one of the oldest experiments in communal living still in existence in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Can any good to the United States be an end-product of the Senate subcommittee hearings of the charges and counter-charges between the Department of the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy? Senator Karl Mundt, the subcommittee chairman, has expressed the faith that this will happen.
A stick-up man was shot.dead late last night after forcing a taxicab driver to drive him through the upper West Side in an attempt to dodge the bullets of pursuing policemen.

ROME, June 5 -- The relation of the Vatican to the Christian Democratic party is an important and complex factor in Italian politics. Those who say the party is a tool of the Vatican and those who contend there are no links are equally wrong.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 5 -- Albert Young Jr. scored his first victory of the Yacht Racing Association season as he sailed his International, Wisp, across the finish first in the Orienta Y. C.'s forty-seventh annual regatta on Long Island Sound today. The event was the Y. R. A.'s sixth of the schedule, which calls for thirty-eight regattas during the summer.

DEVON, Pa., June 5 -- The Sunwood Farm Challenge Trophy for the champion working hunter of the fifty-eighth annual Devon horse show was taken today by Mrs. H. Nelson Slater Jr's Mike Mullen from Far Hills, N. J. Mike Mullen collected 15 1/2 points as Defense, owned by Peggy Augustus of Cobham, Va., took reserve with 12 1/2.
When he "smashed" his first piece of baggage in Grand Central Terminal back in 1912, John T. Franke had no idea that there might be a rewarding future in trundling a hand truck.

In Indochina last week the Communist Vietminh stepped up operations against the main French stronghold -- the Red river delta. From the fallen fortress of Dienbienphu five divisions continued, despite French air strikes, to move toward the delta.
OMAHA BEACH, France, June 5 -- This evening, of all evenings, it is quiet on the beach.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 5 -- Retail sales last week made a poor comparative showing with a year ago, mainly due to the weather. Merchants explained that shoppers for summer items were not interested when the temperatures were in the 50 to 60-degree range.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 5 -- Two hundred and twenty-seven degrees were conferred this afternoon at the tenth commencement of Iona College. Bishop Edward V. Dargin, vicar general of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, presented 103 bachelor of arts degrees. 106 bachelor of business administration degrees and eighteen bachelor of science degrees.
In his "A Frenchman's Cure for Communism" (May 23) Jules Moch evidences more faith in France's constitutional freedom than Washington does in our own.

Sunday morning church services and a leisurely breakfast are traditional parts of the American scene. The tradition is carried out for hundreds of our G. I.'s at the United Service Organizations Centers in Paris and Naples.
The first sale in thirty years of one of Manhattan's five privately-owned piers was announced last week.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Soviet Union's sudden preoccupation with the acquisition of maritime equipment of all kinds has aroused considerable speculation among Government officials.

The man who mows the lawn gave us the season's first whiff of that sweet, green fragrance of fresh-cut grass; but now come the haymakers, and the whole countryside takes on a fragrance as characteristic of June as the fragrance of lilacs is of May. The mowers clatter, the tall grass falls in windrows, and the haymaking is on.
NEW developments in bridge have been few and far between in recent years. In the 1930's dozens of original bidding conventions were proposed; in the last five years there have been almost none.

Today is the end of the tenth year since the Normandy landings. It is the beginning, therefore, of an eleventh year into which we may look with a mingling of hope and foreboding. Ten years ago, on the morning of Wednesday, June 7, this newspaper said editorially: "Victory may be hard to win, but it is as certain as the eventual triumph of good over evil is always certain."

BULBS have been found excellent sources of bloom in summer when it seems apparent in June that there will be vacancies in the borders. Certain bulbs supply color where needed and also mask maturing foliage of Oriental poppies and other earlier flowering perennials and bulbs.

THE dangerous cant that movies are only entertainment -- "If you have a message," runs the fashionable phrase uttered by some shallow producers, "use Western Union" -- has been struck a blow from an unusual quarter -- the New York Public Library.
Following is the text of the address by Adlai E. Stevenson at the Columbia University Bicentennial Conference yesterday as recorded by The New York Times:

CITY gardeners have their troubles just as do their country cousins, and maybe even more so. For instance, it is amazing how many insects can find their way with unerring instinct to anything that grows. Yet it is also amazing how many people, in spite of the difficult conditions, do have gardens in big cities.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, June 5 (AP) -- The Indonesian Communist party demanded today that foreign owned estates be handed over to peasants driven from their land by terrorists. Most of these estates are in the hands of Dutch, British and Chinese owners.

On the second day of the Army-McCarthy hearings -- April 23 -- Secretary of the Army Stevens was telling of a phone conversation with Mr. McCarthy at the time the Senator and Roy Cohn were trying to get special leave for Pvt. G. David Schine.
THE New York Dance Film Society will present the first of three programs at the Museum of Modern Art on Thursday, following up its highly successful first annual festival of last season.

IN a letter to you, Nathaniel Polster argues against the point made by Saul Padover in his review of "Supreme Court and Supreme Law" by Edmond Cahn, that "Chief Justice Marshall asserted, and set a precedent for, the far-reaching principle of 'judicial review' -- that is, the right of the court to pass judgment on acts of Congress.

"Let us not lose faith in our own institutions, and in the essential soundness of the American citizenry lest we -- divided among ourselves -- thus serve the interests and advance the purposes of those seeking to destroy us." -- President Eisenhower at the Columbia University bicentennial last Monday night.

EVEN though a rock garden is usually an artificial thing, it need not be a hodge-podge arrangement and look out of place. For it can be made into a pleasant garden that looks as though nature had put it there herself.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 5 (AP) -- Determine, the Kentucky Derby victor, came back to the races today and whipped six other 3-year-olds in the seven-furlong Debonair Stakes before 46,500 fans at Hollywood Park.

THERE was a ten-day gathering in Paris last summer at which musicians and technicians demonstrated the latest developments in electronic music. Most of the clan will be gathering again this summer for a somewhat similar conference in Switzerland.
THIS summer I may not even come close. Because this summer I have made up my mind not to make up my mind to read any of the classics that in a moderately long life I have never got round to reading.

OUT of drought - ravaged western Kansas of 1889 rode 12-year-old Tom Gilbert and his older brother Sam. Accompanied by Uncle Jake, they made the 400-mile trek to the Oklahoma Lands where the Government was opening the Cherokee Strip offering 160 acres to fortunate families.

"DOOR-KEY KIDS" are children of working mothers who come to school with door keys hung around their necks and who go home after school to empty apartments. They are the special objects of New York's unique All-Day Neighborhood School program which provides supervision and fills the empty hours until mother comes home.

The popular recorded concerts at the New York Public Library will wind up the season indoors on Wednesday with a "Liederkreis," a song cycle by Schumann, and works of Stravinski, Schubert and others. The two-hour program will open at noon in the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy today made public monitored phone records with Secretary Stevens.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 5 -- Earnings of the nation's large metropolitan banks are inadequate under present conditions, according to Hulbert S. Aldrich, president of the New York Trust Company.
LILLE, France, June 5 (Reuters) -- Europe's leading television engineers will have their fingers crossed tomorrow when they tune in the first eight-nation "Eurovision" hook-up through Lille.

ALBANY -- The City of Albany, heretofore accepting its historical heritage with an attractive if un-tourist-wise modesty, will this summer dust off a forgotten page of history which should make it a worthy contender for the laurels now shared by Boston and Philadelphia.

THE gardener to whom crabgrass is anathema should now definitely gird for battle. Only renegades who insist that it looks just as nice as regular grass can afford to relax in the coming weeks. Next to petunias, crabgrass is probably the most determined of the self-seeding annuals

THE vacation in a cottage by the park was planned specially for 6-year-old Susan, because at the end of the summer Mother was going to have a baby. And a grand vacation it turns out to be. Each chapter, a story in itself, tells of Susan's everyday adventures: how she makes new friends, builds castles on the beach and discover such wonders as tiger lilies, squirrels, rabbits and the clever killdeer bird.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- For the tenth consecutive month industrial activity declined in Pennsylvania during April. But there were indications that it might be leveling off. The decline was only 1 per cent for April, the lowest for that month since 1950, according to the index of the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University.
One of the most rapidly advancing phases of the textile industry has its roots in the movement of home-makers to do their own renovations and redecorating.

MR. DAVIES is a Welshman who, though living in London for the last thirty-odd years, has seldom forsaken his native heath in prose. "The Painted King" is his first novel whose locale is outside Wales. Laid in London, it is an entertaining and somewhat raffish story of two men and a girl, one of whom is destined to scale the heights of the British stage, dragging the others after him.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 5 -- That portion of Long Island Sound that lies near this harbor looked as it must have in the grand days of American yachting today.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) -- The monitored calls disclosed that Mr. McCarthy had told Secretary Stevens that "I am going to kick the brains out of anyone who protects Communists."
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy made public today edited transcripts from three of his monitored telephone conversations with Robert T. Stevens, the Secretary of the Army.

AT 13, Clint Barlow, native of the Puget Sound region, was an experienced small-boat sailor and a keen student of marine life. On one solitary expedition Clint discovered a baby seal whose mother had been shot by a visiting sportsman.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 5 (AP) -- In 1926, Paul Harrington received the Byron V. Kanaley prize as the "monogram athlete adjudged to be the most exemplary as a student and a leader of men" at the University of Notre Dame.

EISENSTADT, Austria, June 5 (AP) -- The skull of Austria's great composer Joseph Haydn, stolen from his grave 145 years ago, was reunited with his other earthly remains today and reburied in a new grave.

FOR a story that shows its quality in the first dozen pages, pick up BRANDON'S EMPIRE (Ballantine, $2 and 35 cents) by Dave Hardin. Old Dan Brandon dies and his widow surprises everyone by turning over the ranch to Leach Carlin, thereby supplanting her worthless foster son, Clint.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- Expansion of Chicago area industrial facilities continued to hold a pace well above last year's, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. Investment in new projects during May totaled $14,384,000, compared with $10,567,000 in the same month last year.

PETE LADD would have said as his summer vacation began that he was the most unlucky boy in Pacific Point. All his wonderful plans -- a visit to a ranch, a new bicycle, a pup to train and sell -- had crashed about his ears!

THE producers of Asia want their films to be seen just as the people of Asia want their voices to be heard. That's the impression American observers carried away from the first South East Asia Film Festival held in Tokyo (May 8-20).

A DEFINITE curb on traffic violators and accident repeaters has resulted from the use of point systems as a means of keeping tab on individual drivers, according to Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of the Center for Safety Education, New York University.

It took research through thirty years, the efforts of two museums and the cooperation of Baltimore city officials to bring together dispersed portions of a remarkable medieval tapestry for The Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park.

M. Moch overlooks the one transcendent fact of post-war Europe which more than any other thing has given the lie to the Soviet myth: the fact that literally millions of ordinary working men and women have risked their lives to escape from the workers' paradise behind the Iron Curtain.

THE latest of New York State's historic homes to be restored will be opened in Johnstown on June 26. It is Johnson Hall, home of Sir William Johnson, once Superintendent of Indian Affairs for the Northern Colonies.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 5 -- "So I intercepted the forward pass and ran 60 yards for a touchdown," said Rocky Marciano. He laughed delightedly at the recollection, just a big, unspoiled kid who was enjoying himself. The heavyweight champion of the world lounged on a deck chair in front of his cottage on the edge of the airport, batting the conversational breezes and having a whale of a time while so doing.

IT must be obvious to anyone Whose reading of mystery novels began even as recently as ten years ago that the field has been constantly changing, both in the intent of authors and in the classifications imposed upon novels by publishers and reviewers.

DEEP freezers have increased steadily in urban as well as rural homes. Even in the suburbs, a surprising number of people grow their own fruits and vegetables for freezing or, closer to the metropolitan areas, buy them in season when they are plentiful and low in price.

THE trouble started when Adam Michaels, an aspiring actor, let himself be talked into directing young women to an abortion ring -- for a fee. It was filthy lucre, of course; doubly so, since Adam also had to snap pictures of his victims for the purpose of later blackmail. In the "organization" he meets Marie, an "agent" with two illegitimate children and a heart of fourteen-carat gold.

IN 1944 when the German Third Reich, after barely a decade of its boasted millennium, was showing signs of coming apart at the seams, those Frenchmen in Paris who had been in any way identified with Collaboration were extremely uneasy.
NO corner of the ancient world has been more obscured by myth, mummery and misinterpretation than the Valley of the Nile.

A pre-Revolution Pennsylvania community has just met one employment crisis by persuading Southern textile operators to try running a mill above the Mason-Dixon line. The same community will face another employment problem this summer.

Plans are being made at frequent meetings at the Pierre for the premiere showing of "The Unconquered," Helen Keller in her life story, with narration by Katharine Cornell, on the night of June 15 at the Guild Theater. The event will raise funds for the American Foundation for the Blind, Inc., and the American Foundation for the Overseas Blind, Inc.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- Bobby Avila, second baseman for the Cleveland Indians, was fined $100 today, but escaped suspension.

CINCINNATI, June 5 -- Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina and Robert Rosburg, a former Stanford student, staged startling finishes today to share a two-stroke lead at the end of fifty-four holes in the fifty-first Western open golf tournament.

FOR almost the first time since 1878, when New York City's first telephone directory appeared with 271 listings, a new book is out with fewer pages than its predecessor. This is the 1954-55 Manhattan directory, which has 1,836 pages, as compared with last year's 1,858.

BONN, Germany, June 5 -- Another former German Chancellor, Dr. Hans Luther, has joined the conservative movement to reverse West Germany's foreign policy and make the country a mediator between the Eastern and Western power blocs.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., June 5 -- Richard H. Balch, chairman of the New York State Democratic Committee tonight accused Governor Dewey of using a "dastardly type of gutter politics," and rapped the Governor in a general condemnation of his Administration.

THE new Isherwood novel is a brilliant enigma. It is brilliant in the manner to which Mr. Isherwood's earlier work has accustomed us, in that body of precisely presented detail that evokes so effortlessly, as it seems, a variety of social atmospheres.

Last week the National Bureau of Standards demonstrated in Washington, D. C., what is calls a "physiological monitor." This is an electronic instrument that measures changes in the blood pressure, heart beat and respiration as they occur on the operating table, and indicates the changes on a panel for interpretation by the surgeon or anesthesiologist.

THIS story of one mallard and his family gives a broad, expert picture of waterfowl life, including many unusual details of natural science. Mallards are surrounded by wildlife enemies from weasels to hawks, and during duck hunting season, by the greater peril of ambush in the marshes.

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 5 -- The removal of Aaron H. Coleman, a Fort Monmouth, N. J., radar engineer and target of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, has been recommended by a First Army Security Hearing Board, his attorney said today.

Robert Murphy, deputy Under Secretary of State, will address more than 1,000 recipients of degrees on Wednesday at Fordham University's 109th commencement exercise on the uptown campus. Bishop Edward V. Dargin, auxiliary bishop of the New York Archdiocese, will preside.

M. Moch's naive example of the Communist school teacher who would be "severely punished" if he carried on propaganda for his party with his pupils strikes me as the joining of two French errors: the Cartesian enthronement of reason and the Rousseauistic trust in feelings.
TRENTON, June 5 -- The most serious political feud in this state since the Administration of Gov. Charles Edison more than a decade ago appears tonight to be in the making.

THE beneficial effects of a visit to the old home place is a theme not uncommon in junior novels, but Rebecca Caudill has brought to this story a lively sense of place and people that lifts it above the average.
HARTFORD, June 5 -- The 1,507 delegates to the Democratic state convention in Hartford June 25 and 26 will be picked this Tuesday night in the 169 cities and towns in Connecticut.

COLUMBIA, S. C., June 5 -- Two candidates for Governor and the six men seeking three other state offices wound up South Carolina's archaic county-by-county campaign tour here last night before 1,300 persons.

A major speech by Matyas Rakosi, Hungarian Communist party leader, indicates that a simultaneous economic plan directing development in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe will begin operation in 1956.

BOOKLETS of the new Statue of Liberty 3c purple stamp will be placed on sale first at Washington on June 30, six days after the stamp is issued in sheets of one hundred at Albany. This will be the second time that the Post Office Department has accorded the honor of a formal first-day release to a stamp booklet.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 5 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson this week was like a man trying to stuff a half-inflated inner tube into a tire casing. No sooner would he get part of it tucked in than another part would pop out.
A 27-year-old man the police stopped for a minor traffic violation was accused early today of three murders and the savage rape of a 14-year-old girl.

When a lump appears anywhere on the body or a tumor is found in the course of a surgical operation it is the practice to make a biopsy. That is, a bit of the suspected tissue is examined under the microscope. A pathologist can distinguish healthy cells from cancer cells.

LOS ANGELES, June 5 -- Of thirty-one contests for Federal offices for which several million Californians will vote on Tuesday, the one of widest national interest is in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District here, where ballots will bear the name of James Roosevelt.

WITH Sherlock Holmes canniness, James J. Rorimer, director of The Cloisters, followed up stray clues for thirty years and has finally reassembled the longest -- and surely one of the most beautiful -- medieval wool, silk and metal-thread tapestries.

WHAT are vacations made of? Since they are usually Somewhere else, they are made of the other things In other places: something. I guess, we long for Circled on the map: the sea, the lake, the mountain. Canyons, camps, corrals; the farm, the brook, the forest, Open sky, the wind, the sun, the stars, white cumulous, some rain.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 5 -- The home of the late President Theodore Roosevelt at Sagamore Hill has attracted more than 80,000 visitors since its dedication as a national shrine by President Eisenhower last June 14. Visitors have come from each state and many foreign countries.

THE first libel action against "Red Channels," the booklet described by its publishers as a report on Communist influence in radio and television, now has been heard and dismissed by Justice Irving Saypol in New York State Supreme Court.

EVERY year victims of shipwreck, cast adrift in lifeboats and on rafts, die quickly of hunger, thirst and mortal terror. Concerned about this heavy toll. Alain Bombard, a young French physician, went to work in the Museum of Oceanography at Monaco, in southeastern France, to determine how this loss of life could be reduced.

FALLS CHURCH, Va., June 5 (AP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell said tonight he supposed Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, would have to be considered a major issue "until the Republicans stop McCarthy from rocking around the Government like a loose bomb in an airplane -- immobilizing a good part of the Government.

THE big question about next season's season of the Havana Philharmonic is whether the 30-year-old orchestra is going to have a season at all. The musicians of the Philharmonic are very gloomy about the prospects.

THIS year professional entomologists all over the country are celebrating the centennial of the founding of their profession with special meetings, commemorative events and open houses to acquaint the public with the work they are doing.
Telephone service was being restored yesterday for 7,400 Bronx residents affected by a fire that damaged twelve phone cables on 230th Street between Bailey Avenue and Broadway.

High income taxes are contributing to the shortage of engineers, teachers and professional men in the United States and also to the decreased enrollment and mounting deficits in privately endowed colleges, Dr. John N. Schlegel, treasurer of Lafayette College, said last week.
The semi annual invasion of New York City by retail store buyers of apparel is under way.
Traffic will flow only northbound on Eighth Avenue and only southbound on Seventh Avenue beginning this morning at 8 o'clock, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley reminded motorists yesterday.

LONDON, June 5 -- A 24-year-old Czech, Stanislav Jungwirth, ran Roger Bannister into the rain-drenched cinders at the White City Stadium today to prove the four-minute miler can be beaten the same as any other runner.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 5 -- World tin-plate production in March was 589,000 long tons, the highest monthly output ever recorded, according to the International Tin Study Group. The United States produced 423,843 tons of this total. Canada's output was 18,594 tons.

GENEVA, June 5 -- United States representatives met with Communist Chinese officials here today to try to obtain the release of American citizens detained in Communist China. The meeting took place in the European headquarters of the United Nations, part of which is now being used for the conference on Far Eastern affairs. It lasted about thirty minutes.

NANCY MITFORD, who has delighted her English and American readers with such novels as "The Pursuit of Love," "Love in a Cold Climate" and "The Blessing," written with a glossy sophistication that conceals a certain superficiality, now turns to biography in "Madame de Pompadour."

STONEHENGE, the place of the "hanging stones" on England's Salisbury Plain, has attracted historians, archeologists, astronomers and tourists, all wondering about its origin and purpose. Today scientists have established that it is close to 4,000 years old, but the arguments concerning its reason for being continue, and remain unanswered.

THE combination of unskilled driver and car is one of man's most dangerous weapons. Too few drivers understand the simple scientific principles on which a car operates or have had proper driving instruction. In "Driving Today and Tomorrow" Margaret O. Hyde, aided by Clifford Geary's excellent illustrations, explains with admirable clarity the mechanics of the automobile, and its maintenance and discusses safe driving methods, the causes of accidents and ways to avoid them.

THE striped bass have been dwindling in numbers for years. School tuna have dropped to midget size and weakfish have decreased in size and numbers. However, the bluefish seem to be making a strong come-back from Cape Hatteras to Cape Cod, so coastal anglers have every reason to anticipate a pleasant season.

WESTWARD from Kansas City, Kan., and eastward from Ogden, Utah, twenty-three Kansans and thirty Utahans will soon reenact Pony Express days. Beginning at 6 A. M. (Central Time) June 14 the horsemen will ride day and night across plain and mountain to Colorado Springs and the convention of the National Junior Chamber of Commerce, whose local Junior Chambers are sponsoring the run.

CLINTON, N. Y., June 5 (AP) -- Arthur H. Dean, former peace negotiator in Panmunjon, said today the United States could not hope to win the fighting support of the free Asians against communism "unless we convince them that we will not leave them holding the bag when the going gets tough."

MEXICO, Mo. -- A group of students in photojournalism, amateurs and professionals from nine states, assembled here recently to work for ten days under the guidance of picture editors on a workshop project of photographic thinking and attitude that promotes a fresh approach to and sets a new standard in photographic teaching.

DURING the past eight years Trans World Airlines pilots flying over the Atlantic between the United States and Europe have mastered the techniques of getting maximum range from their planes by flying "pressure patterns."

CLEVELAND, June 5 -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen announced today that it would serve demands on the railroads Monday for wage increases and improved working conditions for its 215,000 members.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Eisenhower recalled today the close unity among the nations of the Great Alliance ten years ago, when Allied forces struck at the German-held French coast in World War II.
The uncertain transit labor situation has caused Mayor Wagner to call a special meeting of emergency advisers tomorrow afternoon at City Hall.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 5 (UP) Sentator Symington said tonight that the Republicans had created "one of the greatest messes in the world and put it on television."

PRINCETON, N. J., June 5 -- Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and Jacob Beam, deputy director of the State Department's policy planning staff, will be among the participants in a series of seminars that will highlight Princeton University's pre-commencement program this week.

Resident buying offices that have shopped fall lines report that values are better this year than last. Prices are generally about the same, but the workmanship is superior and the fabrics are of higher quality in many lines, they say.

THE first major struggle in thirteen years for control of more than 60,000 workers in the entertainment business -- movies and the theatre, primarily, although some television employes are involved -- got under way officially last week.

THE annual family vacation trip may do wonders in refreshing the human spirit, but it often has quite the reverse effect on the garden that is left behind. Beds of withering flowers that have begun to go to seed and vegetable patches all but lost in thickets of weeds can make the returning gardener wish that he had never gone away.

SALEM, N. H., June 5 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito, who has dominnated the Rockingham Park scene since switching from Suffolk Downs last Monday, today booted home four more winners, including Larry Ellis in the $7,500 White Mountain Handicap.

UNION, N. J., June 5 -- Chet Sanok, one of the Metropolitan district's top competitors, and Joe Birofka, Union County public links champion, gained the final of the New Jersey State amateur golf championship today.

MILWAUKEE, June 5 (AP) -- Purdue's Gene Matthews raced the third fastest two miles in American collegiate track history and Auburn's Jim Dillion turned in the season's top discus throw tonight to highlight the twenty-ninth annual Central Collegiate Conference track championships.

THERE appear to be three different points of view on the summer reading habits of the American child. The Euphoric-Nostalgic camp rosily visualizes the American scene dotted with dreamy little figures, lying in daisy meadows or perched in apple trees, lost in the wonderland of "The Wind in the Willows" or "Tanglewood Tales."

Weather favored the stores during the week, but they lost the benefit of the unusually heavy Monday shopping because of the Memorial Day holiday. The result, according to estimates by retailers, was that activity in the city was from 15 to 20 per cent below that of last year, comparing a five-day week, to one of six days.

Madison High School of Brooklyn and Bryant of Queens reached the final of the city Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship tournament with shutout victories at Ebbets Field yesterday. Madison downed DeWitt Clinton, the Bronx, 3 -- 0, and Bryant blanked Curtis, Staten Island, 7 -- 0.
