I am at least ac quainted with the Russian school of acting and writing and therefore I mentally reserved my opinion of what Montgomery Clift would do with the character of Constantin. * * *

DISEASE and insect control in the garden is constantly being revolutionized by the appearance of new types of sprayers and sprays. For example, there is the garden edition of the aerosol bomb. Stemming from the fog generators used by our armed forces, the first domestic bombs were the small ones for household pests.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday that colleges must teach students to respect man's right to be a nonconformist.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 5 -- Vice Admiral Edward L. Coch rane, retired, will deliver the principle address at the eighty-second annual commencement of Stevens Institute of Technology at 10 A. M. next Saturday when 280 persons will receive degrees.

DAKAR, French West Africa, June 5 -- Recent flare-ups of nationalist terrorism in Morocco and Tunisia come as a reminder to a world distracted by the anguish of Indochina that in North Africa too the French Union is in trouble.
The income tax evasion trial of Joseph D. Nunan, former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, is scheduled to start in Brooklyn Federal Court on Tuesday before Judge Walter Bruchhausen.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 5 -- Charles A. Johnston, a reporter for The Asbury Park Press, received top honors today in the annual awards of the Working Press of New Jersey. He was cited at the organization's sixth annual convention here for the best spot news story last year.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration disclosed today it had instructed 7,000 apartment owners with Government-insured financing not to distribute further profits to stockholders unless they got F.H.A. approval.

THEY gave a party for Ella Fitzgerald twelve days ago. The occasion was her nineteenth anniversary in show business, an odd number to honor, but how are you going to fence in a press agent with tidy round numbers? In any case, Miss Fitzgerald rates a party any time anybody wants to get one up for her.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 1 -- The cultural conflict between white and red men that marked settlement of large areas of Canada and the United States is now being repeated in the Arctic.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5 -- The Cleveland Indians broke out with three runs in the eleventh inning today to defeat Philadelphia, 4 -- 1, as Mike Garcia limited the Athletics to two hits.

WHEN a photographer with Godfrey Frankel's high standards sets out to teach young people the fundamentals of his craft, this is the happy result: a how-to book with a point of view. "You create the picture," he stresses; "a camera simply records it.

WHAT makes the teen-age Briton want to dress up like his grandfather or, to be more exact, like a fantastic caricature of the Edwardian dandy his grandfather probably snickered at? This is a very topical question here. Youngsters who a year ago would have dressed in a wide variety of styles, ranging from a neat, dark suit and slicked-down hair to the apache uniform of the slums, today are all "Edwardian."

REMARK was made a week ago in this place upon the singular fortunes of the music of Charles Ives and circumstances indicative not only of the nature of the man and his singular creative gifts, but also upon present conditions in America, which alone of all modern nations could have produced such a phenomenon as Ives and have been so careless of him.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A fundamental disagreement among the five custodians of the nation's atomic power for war and peace burst on Capitol Hill this week. Although the essential facts of the dispute had been known for some time, the open conflict before a Congressional committee shocked even those who had brought it to light.
A further comment on Philip Wylie's, "The Lure That Hooks Fishermen" (April 18) and Marius Selden Goldman's letter (May 16) stating that American anglers do not talk of "killing fish."
TOKYO, June 5 (AP) -- The Lower House of Japan's diet voted tonight to extend its current session for ten days. The session was unmarred by expected political violence.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 5 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., endorsed for Governor by eight upstate Democratic county chairmen, said today he would "carry the fight" to Governor Dewey "from now on."

PETER CARVER'S father owned a riding school on Long Island and, naturally, Peter wanted a horse of his own. When Thunder, descendant of Man o' War and Star Dust, was born to the Carver's Ladybird, the foal was given to Peter.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 5 -- One of the quietest primary campaigns in recent years will end on Monday when Iowa Republicans will choose among six candidates for Governor, and the voters of both parties will select Congressional candidates in some districts.
STANTON, Del., June 5 -- Chevation, owned and bred by William du Pont Jr., showed his heels to thirteen other 3-year-olds in the seventeenth and richest Kent Stakes at Delaware Park today.

THERE is no more painful task for a critic than to be confronted with a disappointing work by a writer of first magnitude whose performance he has respected and admired for years. However, even the most belligerent Thomas Mann worshiper would have to admit that Mann's latest effort is, to say the least, on a modest scale.

Ten commandments for parents of modern times were suggested yesterday morning at a consecration service by the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

BEETHOVEN: Violin Concerto; David Oistrakh, violinist; State Orchestra, Gauk conducting; GLAZUNOFF: Concerto in A minor; David Oistrakh, violinist; State Orchestra, Kondrashin conducting (Period). Two famous display-pieces brilliantly executed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 5 -- In mass campaigns against infections carried out during the post-war era, nearly 16,000,000 persons have been examined and 4,000,000 treated, the World Health Organization reported. All of the infections involved, including venereal and non-venereal syphilis, yaws, bejel, aichuchwa and pinta, are susceptible to treatment with penicillin.
The ability of other facilities to accommodate passengers who now use the Third Avenue Elevated line was disputed yesterday by speakers at a Transit Authority hearing.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Spray rose bushes weekly, if necessary, to get rid of aphids and prevent black spot. Disbud hybrid teas and hybrid perpetuals. Cut roses before they are fully open for bouquets either in morning or evening. Clip off faded flowers.

SUMMER maintenance of the lawn requires time and money. Still, it is less costly to keep the lawn in condition than to let it deteriorate until expensive renovation is required. And a cared-for lawn pays dividends in summer in its appearance and increased pleasure in outdoor living.
NEW DELHI, India, June 5 -- India and Communist China are implementing their agreement of April 29, defining New Delhi's future relationship with Tibet.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 5 -- What promises to be one of the bitterest gubernatorial campaigns in Tennessee history got under way this week-end, with both candidates taking the stump to begin two months of appealing for votes.

THERE are hundreds of hoary and hardy anecdotes illustrating the pressures exerted on Congress, to say nothing of exaggerating the responses thereto. Perhaps as good as the next one is the story of the Congressman who, at the moment of crisis for a bill to carry forward military conscription, was inundated by suspiciously identical telegrams asking:
PARIS, June 5 -- Transfer of the French colonies in India to Indian sovereignty is "inevitable," R. K. Nehru, director of political affairs of the Indian Foreign Office, said here today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 5 -- The possible impeachment of President Getulio Vargas, which almost certainly will not take place, was a subject of great interest in political circles here today.

If the 61,679,882 voters who chose between Eisenhower and Stevenson in November, 1952, had been confronted with 863,518,348 paper ballots -- that's fourteen apiece -- to be filled out and mailed to Washington, we might not have known for a long time how the Presidential election came out, either.

DANGER signals are flickering on the business horizon. Strangely enough, they are not the result of any marked economic movement. They stem rather from the instinct of self-preservation that impels many producers to "play it safe" and not risk going ahead on plant expansion or plans to increase distribution until the outlook becomes clearer.

ATHENS, June 5 -- President Tito of Yuogslavia left Athens for Salonika this evening aboard the Greek cruiser Elli accompanied by King Paul. Yugoslav Foreign Minister Koca Popovic returned to Belgrade by air.

Jim McDonald salvaged an even break for the Yankees by beating the Orioles, 3 -- 1, with a five-hitter in the second game of a double-header at the Stadium yesterday. In the opener, Baltimore's Bullet Bob Turley topped the Bombers, 2 -- 1, with a six-hitter.
LONDON, June 5 (UP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden gave a report to the Cabinet today on the Geneva Conference on Far Eastern Affairs.
KNOXVILLE, June 5 -- Two of the South's largest department stores are to become merchandising rivals with block-size buildings only a short distance apart.

TODAY for the first time in its history, the United States celebrates the opening of National Rose Week. Public gardens everywhere from California's Exposition Park Rose Garden in Los Angeles to New England's Memorial Rose Garden in Norwich, Conn., will be ablaze with blooms of pink, red, white, yellow and cream floribunda, climbing, hybrid tea, miniature and tree roses.

The recent shipment of Communist arms to Guatemala has brought about, in the press and elsewhere, references to the Monroe Doctrine. To many Americans it will come as a surprise to read present allusions to a Doctrine some one hundred and thirty years old.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP) -- Representative Katherine St. George, Republican of New York, said today that subversive literature and films from Russia and other overseas points were "clogging" the Customs Service at New York.
ARROMANCHES, France, June 5 -- The courage and fear, the killing and dying that led to the liberation of France ten years ago were commemorated on the Norman beaches today.

TO Francie Fenwick, each summer spent in Bellbrook, Conn., seems the best one ever. Her seventeenth summer, however, is fraught with problems. Adopted daughter of a beautiful movie star, Francie knows definitely that a Hollywood career is not for her, that she feels much more at home in Bellbrook.

HARTFORD, June 5 -- A special study committee reported this week to Gov. John Davis Lodge that Connecticut should not embark on construction of educational television stations until a "pilot" programming system was laid out.

ALMOST everyone is aware that the Soviets and Nazis exercised an absolute dictatorship over the arts. But -- as Hellmut Lehmann-Haupt points out in this book -- few people know how deeply that dictatorship penetrated into the entire fabric of German and Russian life.
Having once rushed to the bedside of a dying play I had neglected to see in its more animate moments. I can confirm what Richard Maney said in his "The Last Rites of Closing Nights."
"What's all this hullabaloo about progressive education, deliquency and communism?" a veteran educator would like to know.
PITTSBURGH, June 6 -- Steel activity is higher than it was a month ago, and it appears it will improve further this month. Steel people, however, can hardly be called optimistic.
WEST POINT, N. Y., June 6 -- Baccalaureate services were held this morning at the United States Military Academy.
The United States has become the world's mecca of learning for foreign students. A record 35,000 students from all of the free nations are attending 1,500 American colleges and universities.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the period May 29 through June 4.

Having been engaged in secretarial work during most of the past ten years I object to the testimony of Senator McCarthy's secretary, Mrs. Mary Driscoll. I wonder how she earned the title "private secretary."

UTAH BEACH, France, June 6 -- Soldiers and leaders of eight free countries commemorated today a battle that fighting men of the United States began ten years ago this morning for the liberty of France and the Western world.
MEXICO CITY, June 6 -- It is almost certain that the Organization of American States will meet by the end of this month to discuss the case of communism in Guatemala.
RUMORS that people are not watching television the way they once did received a measure of confirmation yesterday.

Although its earnings in Brazilian currency continued to expand in 1953, the Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company reported yesterday that the depreciation of the cruzeiro in the free market had halved its dollar earnings.
An innocent word is being given a bad name in the field of religion, according to the Rev. Dale DeWitt, regional director of the Middle Atlantic States Council of Unitarian Churches.
Entries in the design contest of the Celanese Corporation of America were so good that the company had to give two top prizes of $250 and a three-day visit to the New York textile market.

A new mortgage loan of $3,600,000 has been made to the City Investing Company, Robert W. Dowling, president, on the office building at 25 Broad Street. The financing was arranged through Donald Deppen, vice president of Ivor B. Clark, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Congress will move forward this week on pending appropriation bills and Republican leaders expressed renewed confidence today that the adjournment target of July 31 would be met.

Pentecost, which ranks with Easter as one of the greatest feasts of Christendom, was observed yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral with celebration of pontifical mass of the Holy Spirit. Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, cathedral administrator, pontificated.
The Government reports a decline in both the number of youngsters 14 to 17 years old who hold jobs and those who drop out of school to go to work.
JERSEY CITY, June 6 -- Four alumni of St. Peter's College received honorary degrees from their alma mater today at its sixty-third commencement, held in Roosevelt Stadium, here.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 6 (AP) -- Patty Berg, playing her finest golf in the last round, made a runaway today of the $7,000 Triangle round-robin invitation golf tournament. She finished with plus 73 points -- 51 more than her nearest opponent.

In a current bulletin of the World Health Organization, Dr. M. Vaucel of France points out some of the spectacular gains in the field of tropical medicine. At the same time he puts his finger squarely upon the big problem that remains.

In a letter published May 24 James W. Danahy, vice president of the West Side Association of Commerce, made several statements regarding the St. Lawrence Seaway project that deserve correction. These were:

The average wage-rate increase in union contracts negotiated in the state last year was 8 cents an hour, approximately the same as in 1952, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi reported yesterday.

Extreme dullness prevailed for the foreign exchanges during the abbreviated trading sessions of the past week. British pound sterling fluctuated narrowly while the Canadian dollar had a tendency to ease gradually lower.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox ran their winning streak to five games with 5-3 and 6-0 victories over the Washington Senators today. The Sox won the opener on Minnie Minoso's two-run homer and the nightcap behind Jack Harshman's seven-hit pitching.
The Indochinese situation moves closer to crisis this week as both Paris and Washington face major decisions.

CAIRO, June 6 -- Kamal el-Malakh, who discovered the funerary solar boat of Cheops, lost control today over further investigation of his find. He will be the lowest-ranking member of a five-man committee that will supervise the discovery.
Security considerations, as well as pressure of city business, may keep Mayor Wagner from attending the Second Migration Conference in San Juan, Puerto Rico, the week of June 20.

Msgr. Charles W. Walsh, director of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, warned undergraduate seniors at Fordham University yesterday against letting their intellectual lives "wither away from lack of care."

The wish to accumulate material seems to be one of the more important drives in human existence. It starts in childhood with collections of pebbles, sea shells, marbles, tops, match covers, silver paper and anything else which comes the collector's way.

In 1777 wealthy landowners of New Jersey were outraged that the state had imposed a tax for each slave owned -- New Jersey had 3,000 at that time -- and had neglected to tax the employers of indentured servants, who were considered virtually the same.
The North Atlantic Ports Association, meeting in Washington on Wednesday, will discuss, among other matters, the question of a proposed International Port and Harbor Association.
Central Maine Power Company is offering holders of its common stock and its 6 per cent preferred rights to subscribe for 50,423 shares of 4.6 per cent preferred at $100 a share.
BRICE CROSS ROADS, Miss., June 6 (UP) -- Mississipians today re-enacted a Civil War battle that paved the way ninety years ago for Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman's successful assault on Atlanta.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- Representative Francis Walter of Pennsylvania, ranking Democrat on the House Committee on Un-American Activities, said today he thought his committee and Sen. Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations should be abolished.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 6 -- Forty-six pilots of fragile stock outboard speed boats were tossed, bounced and bruised today over eighty miles of a marathon from Poughkeepsie upstream to Hudson, N. Y., and return. The competitors included white-haired grandfathers as well as young schoolboys and at least one sub-teenager of 12 1/2.

Vice President Nixon, several Governors and Senators, a blind man, some one-armed swingers, a 5-year-old boy and a sprightly 83-year-old man matched their handicaps against Ben Hogan's best on Saturday, the third annual National Golf Day.
Four new films, including importations from France and England, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
CHICAGO, June 6 -- Investment buying of wheat apparently was fairly substantial last week, as the market stood up unexpectedly well in the face of a lot of bearish influences.
Five scientists landed on a glacier in the Juneau ice field of Alaska last Wednesday to study the effects of glaciers on the weather. They will stay three months, according to word received here.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Atomic Energy Commission today granted Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer the right to file a brief, but denied his request for a final argument of his security case before the commission.

WASHINGTON, Monday, June 7 (AP) -- The Washington Post and Times-Herald said today that twice during April the United States proposed using Navy and Air Force planes based in the Philippines to intervene in the Indochina war, provided Congress and allied nations agreed. The British would not agree and the plan fell through, the newspaper said in a copyrighted article.

MILWAUKEE June 6 (UP) -- Jim Wilson of the Milwaukee Braves won his first start of the season with a four-hit, 5-0 shutout over Pittsburgh today, but the Pirates came back to win the second game, 6 -- 4, despite a grand-slam home run by Eddie Mathews.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge said today that Georgia was not going to provide unsegregated public schools regardless of what the Supreme Court and Federal Government said or did about it.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) -- Mr. Cohn and Mr. Carr, in agreeing to make public their calls, repeated the "stacked deck" charge that Mr. McCarthy had made.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 6 -- A highly placed Middle East observer disclosed today that as a result of Pakistan's decision to accept defensive military aid from the United States the Soviet Union was "actively concerned."

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 6 -- Economic negotiations about to begin between Austria and Switzerland aim at reaching agreement before July. 1, when the European Coal and Steel Community will create a common market for special steels.

GUATEMALA, June 6 -- Col. Rodolfo Mendoza Azurdia, Guatemala's foremost military and civil flier, fled the country Friday in a private plane. He is a former Air Force chief and director of civil aeronautics.

CINCINNATI, June 6 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum, 39-year-old professional from Niles, Ill., won the fifty-first Western open golf championship today by defeating Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., on the first hole of a sudden-death play-off.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 6 -- John Nicholas Brown's big yawl Bolero, William Ziegler Jr.'s schooner Bounding Home, Harvey Conover's yawl Revonoc and Agnew Fisher's Rhodes 27 Jubilee gained class yachting prizes of more than usual moment today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6 -- One of the largest locals within the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees voted overwhelmingly today to order its delegates to support Roy M. Brewer for president at the union's forthcoming convention.

LOS ANGELES, June 6 -- Malicious use of California judicial processes to further a "scheme" conceived by Serge Rubinstein, draft-dodger, now 46 years old, is charged in a document filed in Superior Court here.
GENEVA, June 6 -- A slight shift in the Communist position apparently has averted an early halt in the Korean phase of the Far Eastern conference.

OMSK, U.S.S.R., June 1 -- A quick air survey of western Siberia indicates that the first round of the battle to increase grain production by plowing virgin soil is being won, but that the final results are still in doubt.
Shipowners maintained their rates last week, but fewer shippers showed up with cargoes to be delivered.

GENEVA, June 6 -- Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, will probably delay his departure for Paris until after Tuesday's Far East conference session on Indochina, French sources said here today. He had originally planned to leave Monday night.

A selection of the "finest" modern historical writing that opens "windows on the past" will be issued June 23 by New American Library as a Mentor Book, entitled "The World of History." With the Society of American Historians as sponsor, the volume contains twenty-eight essays by such writers as Henry Steele Commager, Arnold J. Toynbee, Gilbert Highet, George Santayana and James T. Flexner.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- After a lot of gestures, false starts and backsliding, about a hundred labor unions are really going to take the pledge on Wednesday to quit raiding one another for members.

S.," leads me to make a few timely historical observations upon the subject of the constitutional separation of powers in our Government. I begin with a comment upon the following passage in your editorial:

PRINCETON, N. J., June 6 -- The 5,000 alumni returning to Princeton this week for their reunions can watch a seventeenth-century planetarium in operation and view gracious living in the style to which a statesman of the Revolution was accustomed -- all in the university library.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif, June 6 -- Gottfried Reinhardt will enter independent production with "Rosalinda," based on Johann Strauss" operetta "Fledermaus." Kathryn Grayson will star in the title role.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- President Eisenhower is determined to use his executive powers to the limit, according to informed sources, to prevent an investigation of the Central Intelligence Agency by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Jacob Horwitz is not new to this column, nor is he an unknown figure to the juniors of this country. For a generation he has been catering to their fashion tastes, season after season offering them something of interest, gleaned from the far corners of the civilized world.

Burns, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, holds his first general press conference tomorrow, he will indicate that the Administration is giving thought to the depressed state of the coal and textile industries. Each week brings fresh reports of shut mines and mills, widening unemployment and erosion of labor standards.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 6 -- The New York Athletic Club won its rowing regatta on the Pelham Bay Lagoon course for the third straight year today. N. Y. A. C. oarsmen won four of the twelve events and scored in the others for 84 points and possession of the Ensign Charles Froehlich Memorial Trophy.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 6 -- There is strong hope that within a year European conditions for convertibility for current account will have been substantially fulfilled, Johan van de Kieft, Finance Minister, said last week.

The award of medals to thirty-one uniformed members of the Fire Department for outstanding acts of heroism in 1953 was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. Ten of the awards are posthumous.

Mount Sinai Hospital in 1953 treated a record 88,000 patients and conducted its largest research and educational programs. In the 1953 report, made public yesterday, however, Alfred L. Rose, president, said a net loss of $628,090 "imperiled the hospital's reserves and cast a somber shadow ever the year's achievements."
BOSTON, June 6 -- The opening day of the third annual open-air Boston Arts Festival today attracted 50,000 visitors to the Public Gardens.
From the standpoint of the fish, the Atlantic Ocean off Sea Bright, N. J., was disagreeably crowded with boatsful of humans yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, June 6 -- Dr. A. Whitney Griswold said today that individual moral integrity was the key to the survival of democracy.

ON Saturday the Plaza Theatre ushered in "Dreams of Love," a French-made chapter in the life of the nineteenth-century musical giant Franz Liszt, who, fortunately, couldn't attend. Those who heed the lure of the beloved old title song will find it sectionally served, along with a swift smattering of other melodies, in one of the dullest and most insipid musical biographies from anywhere.
A small sailboat and an outboard motor boat capsized yesterday as a 30-mile-an-hour wind kicked up choppy seas in the New York area. The four occupants of the two boats were rescued.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 6 -- The governing board of the Southerrn Education Reporting Service voted today to begin publication about Sept. 1 of factual and impartial reports on the handling, in the South, of problems arising from the Supreme Court decision against public school segregation.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 6 -- Rocky Marciano had started to talk about his first-round knockdown by Jersey Joe Wolcott when his listener embarrassingly had run out of space yesterday, and the heavyweight champion of the world had been left dangling conversationally in mid-air. So this is a frantic attempt to get him off the hook.
DECATUR, Ill., June 6 (AP) -- Earl Heaton of Decatur today was elected president of the United Automobile Workers of America, A. F. L., at a special meeting of the executive board.

A serious lag in the sale of $5 and $10 auto use stamps was reported yesterday by City Collector Alexander E. Fronters. He urged car owners subject to the tax to purchase their stamps as far as possible in advance of the June 15 deadline.

City radio station WNYC began its fourth annual opera festival yesterday. A feature of the opening was the world premiere of "Tin Pan Alley," a one-act opera with libretto and music by Sam Raphling, who, for his performance, also played the piano accompaniment.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians increased their percentage point hold on first place in the American League to 8 points today by whipping the Philadelphia Athletics twice. A three-run triple by Hal Naragon in the fourth inning helped clinch the nightcap, 7 -- 5, while a pair of second-inning triples and two sacrifice flies decided the opener, 2 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said tonight that he would ask the Senate Armed Services Committee to investigate the passing of classified information to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy by an Army intelligence officer.
Maritime industry hopes, which soared two weeks ago as the result of encouraging Maritime Day speeches, subsided last week as two major pieces of legislation ran into heavy weather.
BOSTON, June 6 (AP) -- Harry Agganis, rookie first baseman of the Boston Red Sox, appeared in two ball parks today -- and did all right in both of them.

The seven - story apartment house for eighty-four families on plot 175 by 100 feet at 2230 University Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by an investing client of William Rosan, attorney, in a deal negotiated by the Sonnenblick Goldman Corporation, broker.

Two home furnishings fabrics suitable for drapery or upholstery have won top honors in a contest arranged for textile students by Celanese Corporation of America. Most of the sixty-three contest entries from six textile schools were of bold and dramatic design.

The Yankees will have to do something about the pattern they have set for double-headers this season. The world champions played their seventh twin-bill yesterday and for the seventh time this year they could do no better than break even.
CINCINNATI, June 6 -- The Giants' gay dash through the West ran off the rails today as they split their double-header with the Redlegs by identical scores.
MADRID, June 6 -- The Spanish press published today the text of a bill designed to ease the housing shortage. This is one of the country's gravest problems.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- When Congress issued an official invitation last week to Lieut. Genevieve de Galard-Terraube, the heroic nurse of Dienbienphu, to visit this country, it did something it does not often do.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 6 -- Iraqis will go to the polls Wednesday in a parliamentary election that offers them a choice only between the extreme Nationalist-left-wing coalition and the old-line conservatives, with the odds heavily favoring the latter.
BERLIN, June 6 -- A strange battle for the minds of several thousand members of the Communist-led Free German Youth organization is taking place in Berlin.

Plans for remodeling the eight-story loft building at 5 East Seventeenth Street and 6 East Eighteenth Street have been announced in connection with the sale of the property to Jack Begelman, a retired interior decorator, who has added the parcel to his realty holdings in Manhattan.
Six thousand New York brewery workers voted "nearly unanimously'' last night to accept a contract that will bring the wages of some of them up to $3 an hour for the first time in the industry.

We are now sufficiently far into the nuclear age so that virtually everyone knows that Geiger counters and similar instruments are indispensable for finding uranium, checking on the safety of workers handling radioactive materials, and the like. We know too that these devices must be in good working order or they may be worse than useless.

YESTERDAY was Thomas Mann's seventy-ninth birthday. His first novelette was published sixty years ago when he was 19. Seldom has any writer enjoyed so long a productive career and few authors, of course, can boast of so great a one. Mr. Mann's eminence as the foremost German writer of his time is unquestioned.
BOSTON, June 6 (UP) -- Boston batting power exploded again today as the Red Sox hit four home runs in a 7-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Robert T. Stevens, the Secretary of the Army, reportedly told G. David Schine last Oct. 21 that when drafted he would be employed so that his especial knowledge would be of benefit to the Army and to himself.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams said yesterday that his department was in need of three things -- money, men and recognition of merit.

The United Stataes needs investigators who are neither "head-hunters nor headline-hunters" if it is to uncover the dangers that threaten its freedoms, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday at New York University's baccalaureate service.

MILWAUKEE, June 6 (AP) -- Chuck Stevenson of Garden Grove, Calif., set a new track record today in winning the 100-mile Rex May Memorial big car race at the Wisconsin State Fair. He was clocked in 1 hour 1 minute 31.297 seconds.

In the welter of charges and complaints heard here and there about the city's program for relocating tenants dispossessed from their homes to make way for public improvements it is good to read the findings of City Administrator Luther H. Gulick that conditions are not as bad as many have painted them.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 6 -- Tropical Africa's population of 140,000,000 is in transition to some form of cash earning economy. Profound social changes demand skillful planning to avert food shortages or inflation.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 6 -- B. Glenn MacNary's sloop Annie in the International Class, Van Wyck W. Loomis' Atlantic Hound and Henry C. Boschen's Class S Sirius were among the victors in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's sixty-ninth annual regatta on Long Island Sound today.

Arthur B. Bisguier and Larry Evans, United States champion, were in a tie at 6 -- 2 for the lead in the national championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club last night. Each expert won his eight-round match.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 6 -- President Getulio D. Vargas faces a stiff battle with business men, industrialists and lawyers over decrees that double the minimum legal wage and increase social security contributions.

NO teacher group in the city's schools eats as well, or is as well served at noon table, as the faculty in James Fenimore Cooper Junior High School. Nowhere in the system is crockery and table silver so thoroughly cleaned.
Grants totaling $747,400 were announced yesterday by the Carnegie Corporation of New York. They included $200,000 for the University of Puerto Rico.
If you should happen to hail a very tall, handsome, well-dressed, cultivated gentleman driving a red, white and blue taxicab with a gold radiator ornament, that would be Arthur Mace Gwyer at work.

Premier Adman Menderes of Turkey, concluding a six-day visit during which the United States agreed to double military aid to his country, started home from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday morning. He and his party took off in the private plane of Admiral William Fechteler, Southern Commander for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The Chelsea Club of London and the Glasgow Rangers of Scotland played a scoreless tie in their soccer game at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday.
GENEVA, June 6 -- It is generally believed in Europe that by mid-autumn the status of most of the principal Western European currencies will be considerably different from what it is today.

LONDON, June 6 (Reuters) -- World stocks of natural rubber totaled 827,500 tons at the end of April, 2,500 tons less than on Jan. 1, according to advance information given here yesterday by the secretariat of the International Rubber Study Group.
Basic work on revision of a long-standing treaty for international protection of patents, trade-marks and other industrial property rights begins in Brussels today.

Trading ranges continued to be limited for cotton last week, but the market closed on somewhat lower ground. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange on Friday were down 7 to 13 points on the week.
UNDETERRED by the calendar's advance toward summer, local art galleries are opening a score of exhibitions this week.
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 6 -- State Senator Walter H. Jones, Republican leader of Bergen County, disclosed today that he was determined to end "misunderstanding" over toll road links in this county.
The rape and murder of three women in Harlem were reported solved yesterday with the confession of an 18-year-old youth whom detectives had found lurking near the body of the latest victim.
Several New York restaurateurs will gather for lunch today to honor a genial, white-haired man with seventy-three years experience in the hotel and restaurant business.

Marking the tenth anniversary of the invasion of Normandy, veterans of the 101st Airborne Division held exercises yesterday at the Eternal Light in Madison Square Park, Twenty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue. They were joined by representatives of France, Belgium and the Netherlands.

Twenty-three members of the executive committee of the Queens County Democratic Committee, who are opposed to James A. Roe, county leader, conferred last night with Carmine G. DeSapio in the Biltmore Hotel. The fourteen men and nine women adjourned without indicating their future course of action.
ROME, June 6 -- Pope Pius XII inaugurated a television hook-up of eight European countries today.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 6 (UP) -- Three Negro students said today they would apply for admission tomorrow to the state-supported Memphis State College.

LONDON, June 6 -- Although the stock markets as whole have been rather restrained by the imminence of the Whitsun holiday and by such national sporting attractions as the Derby, they have lost none of their strong tone.

Subscription to The Daily Bond Crier, the dollar-a-copy newspaper that appears once a year to poke fun at the municipal bond business, are being taken at the office of the First Boston Corporation, 100 Broadway.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 6 (AP) -- The most intensive search for oil in Australia's history is getting under way.

For all its parade of judicial calm and reasonableness, the report of the A. E. C. Personnel Security Board on the Oppenheimer case is a troubling document.
UNION, N. J., June 6 -- The New Jersey State amateur golf title went to Chet Sanok of Forsgate for the third time today.

LONDON, June 6 (Reuters) -- Two British newspapers today expressed differing views on the case of Dr. Robert J. Oppenheimer, United States scientist who was barred from further access to atomic secrets by a special security board.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, said today he favored use of the atomic bomb in Indochina rather than sending American troops there.

HANOI, Vietnam, June 6 -- French Union troops drove across the Day River today and pushed Communist-led Vietminh rebels six miles back from encircled Phuly, key road and rice center thirty miles south of Hanoi.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Pee Wee Reese has a sore back and Jackie Robinson still has a bruised heel, but these two 35-year-old players were the most potent factors in the Dodgers' 6-4 victory over the Cubs today, and Brooklyn's winning streak reached nine games.

Msgr. Frederick G. Hochwalt, director of education for the National Catholic Welfare Council, told 350 seniors yesterday at the Manhattan College baccalaureate mass that "your work, as of now, is the defense of your faith and your country."

LUC-SUR-MER, France, June 6 -- The sun came out this afternoon and everything was gay along the beach. Children urged fat donkeys across the sands and their elders played miniature golf or tennis or gossiped in the sun.

SAIGON, Vietnam, June 6 -- Prince Buu Loc, Premier of Vietnam, declared on his return from France today that while Vietnam wanted peace she would not subscribe to a "false peace" that would "strike a blow either at her national unity or independence." He said the cease-fire measures now being studied at Geneva would not threaten this unity.

It was a pleasure yesterday morning to turn from the antics of the well-known junior Senator from the familiar Middle Western state to the words Adlai Stevenson delivered on Saturday at Columbia University. Mr. Stevenson spoke, to be sure, as a candidate who didn't win and who therefore could be more critical of what is going on than could the candidate who did win.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The United States Information Service is preparing world-wide "atomic road shows" to demonstrate this summer what the United States is doing to develop peaceful uses of atomic energy.

Belluno, owned by Christopher Chenery and ridden by Eddie Arcaro, beat six others in the feature at Belmont Park yesterday. The performance was unexpected, for Belluno was next to the outsider in the wagering, and paid $30.90.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 7 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum, captain of the United States winning Ryder Cup golf team last year, and Jimmy Demaret are the top players in America's eleven-man challenge for the British open championship at Birkdale, July 5-9.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the appeal of Michael J. Regan, former New York policeman, who was sentenced to a year in jail for contempt of court.

A field of 1,904 entrants sought 129 places yesterday in the nation-wide qualifying rounds for the United States open golf championship. The 36-hole tests, preliminary to the championship tourney June 17 to 19 at the Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, N. J., were held in thirty-two sectors.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 7 -- A free society must have newspapers that are both free and solvent, Mrs. Ogden Reid, chairman of the board of The New York Herald Tribune, said today at the One-hundred seventeenth commencement exercises of Mount Holyoke College.

Seventy boys and girls were confirmed yesterday at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, by Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi of the congregation.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of the Federal law regulating lobbying. In a 5-to-3 decision, the high court reversed a ruling of a Federal District Court here that the statute was unconstitutional.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld, 6 -- 2, a $129,326 damage award against three John L. Lewis unions.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Business men's plans for spending on new plant and equipment through October indicate they will invest just over $27,000,000,000 this year -- about $1,250,000,000 or 4.5 per cent less than their 1953 record capital outlay.

Despite the doubling of its estimated cost since 1950, the New York Thruway will be able to pay off out of earnings the $931,000,000 debt being incurred in its development, Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the Thruway Authority, said here yesterday.

An attempt to strip James A. Roe of his Queens Democratic leadership failed yesterday by two votes. Three district leaders who signed a petition asking him to resign refused to vote to take his leadership powers away from him.

VANCOUVER, B. C., June 7 (Canadian Press ) -- Angry passengers debarked today from the 8,000-ton luxury liner Oronsay, protesting the slowness of immigration and medical clearances. Among the passengers were up Australia and New Zealand business men. Many protested that standing in line-ups wasn't part of luxury service.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 7 -- A shining $3,500,000 scientific temple for the study of the germ was dedicated in an academic program here this afternoon. Close to 1,000 scientists and guests of Rutgers University gathered on a sunny rolling campus overlooking the Raritan River for the ceremonies opening the house that streptomycin built -- the New Rutgers Institute of Microbiology.

ZANZIBAR, June 7 -- The tyranny of the bazaar, a group of merchant profiteers and money lenders, bears heavily on the population of this little two-island British protectorate off the east coast of Africa.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (UP) -- Ben Fischer, Housing Director of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused the Eisenhower Adminstration and Congress today of "playing politics and worse" by proposing a public housing program he termed "a drop in the bucket."

The six-story building at 1014 Madison Avenue, near Seventy-eighth Street, has been sold by the Walt Whitman School to Robert Graham. The first two floors of the structure will be occupied by James Graham Sons, Inc., art dealer, who have been at 514 Madison Avenue for the past twenty years, and the upper floors will be rented out to art dealers.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., June 7 -- The Republic Aviation Corporation said here today that three engineers had been suspended for security reasons pending further investigation of charges against them.
